title: Oregon's Mail-In Election Brings Cheer to Democrats
description: While the rest of the country fussed over this state's novel election-by-mail, Oregon voters today appeared more astonished at the result of their experiment: for the first time in 34 years, they sent a Democrat to the United States Senate.

title: Mutual Fund Industry's Fast Growth May Be Past
description: Investors on Main Street love mutual funds, but the smart money on Wall Street has sent a strong signal that the brightest days of the rapidly growing mutual fund industry may be past.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: COMPANY NEWS;GENZYME OFFERS STOCK FOR SURGICAL AIDS PARTNERSHIP
description: The Genzyme Corporation has offered to acquire Surgical Aids Partnership for $93 million of Genzyme General Division stock. Genzyme said yesterday that its offer was made in lieu of its existing option to purchase the outstanding partnership interests for a lump-sum cash payment and future royalty payments. Shares of Genzyme, a biotechnology company in Cambridge, Mass., rose $3.375 yesterday, to $75.875, in Nasdaq trading. Genzyme set up Surgical Aids Partnership in 1989, raising $36.8 million to finance the development of surgical products to reduce adhesions, the scarring of tissue caused by surgery.

title: Fed's Decision to Lower Rates Advances Dow to 5,395.30
description: The stock market continued to demonstrate its strength yesterday after the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point -- its third reduction since last July.

title: BASKETBALL: PART MAN, PART MYTH, ALL PLAYER;Johnson Still Has the Touch
description: Daddy has a job after all.

title: Crash Kills Indiana Player
description: One player was killed and five others were injured, along with their coach, when one of two vans carrying the Indiana-Purdue-Indianapolis women's basketball team crashed on icy Interstate 65 Tuesday night.

title: The Pop Life
description: Posthumous CD

title: Handcuffing the Police
description: In the vast drug bazaar that Washington Heights has become, homicide is the leading cause of death for young men. A Federal judge's decision to dismiss charges against a woman caught with a carload of cocaine there is bound to make things even worse.

title: HOCKEY;The Rangers Conclude A Nonpareil January
description: Most of the Rangers didn't realize they made club history tonight -- until Mark Messier gleefully informed them afterward.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Nicaraguan Police Free 81 Held by Students
description: The police fired tear gas today in rescuing the remaining 81 people who had been held hostage by protesting university students in the Foreign Ministry building, the Government said.

title: Corrections
description: A list of production credits on Tuesday with a television review of "Frontline: So You Want to Buy a President?" misidentified an organization that worked with the co-producers. It was the Center for Public Integrity, not the Center for Public Information.

title: Julian W. Hill, Nylon's Discoverer, Dies at 91
description: Julian W. Hill, a research chemist whose accidental discovery of a tough, taffy-like compound revolutionized everyday life after it proved its worth in warfare and courtship, died on Sunday in Hockessin, Del. He was 91.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Talk Troubles Riley
description: Coach PAT RILEY is dismayed about the prospect of a move by the Miami Heat from downtown to a proposed arena in Broward County.

title: Russian Samples Pastrami Politics
description: There was the historic walk in the woods at the Geneva arms control talks in 1982, and before that, the Cold War kitchen debate. Now, Vice President Al Gore has invented a new method of informal superpower interaction: deli diplomacy.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Mechanical Dolls and Modern Jitterbugs
description: Although experiment was once a way of life in American modern dance, many choreographers have settled into a comfortable rut. Not so Doug Varone, who can be counted upon to come up with unexpected shifts in both idiom and content.

title: Agreement or No, the Budget Squeeze Is On
description: With nine stopgap spending bills in four months, Congress is relentlessly squeezing money out of Federal programs, even in the absence of an agreement on how to balance the budget.

title: Whitewater Panel Delves Into Long-Sought Billing Records
description: Prompted by the recent White House discovery of copies of long-sought law firm billing records, Republicans on the Senate Whitewater committee today began dissecting a series of complex and fraudulent Arkansas real estate transactions to glean the role, if any, played in them by Hillary Rodham Clinton a decade ago.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Beethovenian Takes the Plunge Into Chopin
description: The hot news in Richard Goode's Carnegie Hall recital on Tuesday evening was the entire second half of the program, which was devoted to Chopin, the latest object of Mr. Goode's technique of total immersion. But the route there, circuitous and scenic, was at least half the fun.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;It's No Rally, But Bonds Do Move Higher
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved moderately higher yesterday but fell short of the strong rally some traders expected after a cut in short-term rates by the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Market Place;The Wells Fargo wagon may be the merger vehicle of the future.
description: IS Wells Fargo's $11.6 billion takeover of First Interstate the beginning of a decade of hostile bank takeovers?

title: Whitewater Billing Records Don't Compare to Iran-Contra Diary
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Safeguarding Genetic Data
description: Information obtained in genetic screenings by a potential employer or insurance company would be protected as private property under legislation to be proposed today by Democratic State Senator Jack Sinagra. The bill would prohibit basing a decision to hire or insure someone on data from genetic testing or releasing such information without consent.

title: Warren Chernock, Nuclear Engineer, 70
description: Warren Philip Chernock, a nuclear and metallurgical engineer whose career took him from the Argonne National Laboratory to Three Mile Island and Chernobyl, died on Saturday at his home in Fairfax Station, Va. He was 70.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a Time Warner test of an Internet access service that links subscribers in Elmira, N.Y., to local organizations including The Elmira Star-Gazette misstated the ownership of the newspaper. It is a unit of the Gannett Company, not locally owned.

title: Survival of AIDS Patients Linked To Experience of Their Doctors
description: How long a patient survives from AIDS is directly linked to a doctor's experience in treating the disease, according to a study reported today at a scientific meeting here.

title: Herman Buchman, Makeup Artist, 75
description: Herman Buchman, a makeup artist who worked in film, theater, opera and television, died on Saturday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 75.

title: Man Guilty In Slaying Of Officer
description: A teen-ager who admitted taking part in a Brooklyn robbery during which his uncle shot and killed a police officer was found guilty last night of murder.

title: Judge Tells Village to Keep Fire Department It Replaced
description: A State Supreme Court justice today issued a temporary restraining order preventing the village of Rye Brook from severing ties with the Port Chester Fire Department, which has served Rye Brook for more than 100 years.

title: Man Dies in Route 9 Crash
description: A driver was killed today when his car spun into the path of a commuter bus on snow-slickened Route 9, closing the major thoroughfare for almost three hours.

title: Immigration Lottery Phone Line Crashes
description: Swamped with telephone calls from immigrants hoping to enter the Federal immigration lottery, the city's lottery phone line crashed yesterday, city officials said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;New Conde Nast Magazine
description: Conde Nast Publications, a unit of Advance Publications Inc., said this week that it planned to begin publishing a monthly women's sporting magazine early next year.

title: TRACK AND FIELD;Track Stars Blend In On New York Streets
description: As a light snow fell, a man of relatively average height and weight wearing black knit cap, gray down jacket, corduroys and hiking boots emerged from the subway station at 50th Street and Broadway at 10 A.M. yesterday and then proceeded south on Broadway. Hardly any of the passers-by or anyone driving in an automobile seemed to take any particular notice. And why should they? After all, he was like everyone else trapersing the thoroughfare, other than that he was carrying a 17-foot pole on his shoulder.

title: New Stadium Needs Work
description: Olympic Stadium, the 85,000-seat centerpiece of the 1996 Summer Games, must have parts of its steel skeleton reinforced, an engineering firm said today.

title: U.S. Is a Defaulter At United Nations
description: To the Editor: William Safire (column, Jan. 25) reminds us that George Washington equated a "defaulter" with a crazed despot and a miserable thief. Mr. Safire adds, "A debtor who chooses not to pay what he owes is as reprehensible as anyone who robs his neighbor or fiddles while Rome burns."

title: Charges Fly As the Greeks And Turks Avert a War
description: The political reverberations of a narrowly avoided confrontation between the military forces of Greece and Turkey over a cluster or rocks in the Aegean Sea continued in the capitals of both countries today.

title: POLITICS: THE LEAD;Low-Key Dole Shrugs Off Forbes Threat
description: After a week of bad news for his campaign, Senator Bob Dole showed a relaxed and confident face today to New Hampshire voters, who go the polls Feb. 20 to pick a Republican Presidential nominee.

title: Rebecca LaBrecque Dies at 45; Pianist Who Helped New Music
description: Rebecca LaBrecque, a pianist who championed new music and new ways of using the keyboard in a classical concert setting, died on Sunday at Calpary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 45 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Currents;The Towers In Prague That Swirl And Waltz
description: EARLY on a recent Saturday morning, people in central Prague heard an ominous sound. But not to worry -- the Russian-made helicopter thwump-thwumping in the overcast sky was on a peaceful mission.

title: A $50 Million Payment Fuels Mexican Scandal
description: At best, the $50 million that one of Mexico's richest businessmen says he invested blindly with an old friend, the former President's brother, was a highly irregular business transaction.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EUGENE L. McCABE, the president and chief executive of North General Hospital at Madison Avenue and 124th Street, will be awarded the President's Medal at a luncheon today at Hunter College today.

title: Chemical Warfare Detection Is Criticized
description: Military equipment to detect chemical agents during the war in the Persian Gulf was inadequate and unreliable, and there was no system to warn quickly of biological agents, a draft report on illnesses of veterans concludes.

title: No Headline
description: We now live in a house that once belonged to a Croat. How is it that he will be allowed to come back and throw me and my children out on the street, but no one will force the Croats to let me go back to my home?" -- JORKA DUSANOVIC, a Serb living in Croatia. [A3:2.]

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Index of Commodity Prices Soars To Highest Level in Five Years
description: Commodity prices rose to their highest levels in more than five years yesterday as frigid temperatures in much of North America threatened crops and lifted demand for heating fuels.

title: Legislation to Overhaul Farm Policy Finds Opposition in Congress
description: Legislation to revamp the Federal farm program began working its way toward final passage in Congress today but ran into trouble in both houses.

title: SKIING;For Hourglass, the Time Has Come
description: It may still be a trick question for the average skier. But to aficionados in the ski industry, knowing what the word hourglass means is as vital today as a tennis professional's understanding of the word widebody was a decade ago.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Lowers Interest Rates To Nudge a Weak Economy The Federal Reserve lowered short-term interest rates by one-quarter percentage point to give the economy a modest spark. In its second rate cut in six weeks, the central bank lowered the Federal Funds rate at which banks lend each other money overnight to 5.25 percent and the discount rate, at which it lends banks money, to 5 percent.

title: Serb-Held Bit of Croatia Resists Pact
description: The 150,000 Serbs here in eastern Slavonia have mounted a campaign to undermine a provision in the Dayton peace agreement that calls for them to relinquish this last slice of Serbian-held territory in Croatia.

title: 4 Architects + 4 Dreams = 1 Nightmare
description: BUILDING the Buttrick family residence in Lyme, Conn., was a wonderful opportunity (actually, it was a nightmare).

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Western Publishing Gives Snyder an Equity Stake
description: After months of start-and-stop negotiations, the Western Publishing Group announced yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement that gives Richard E. Snyder and Warburg Pincus Ventures a significant equity interest in the company.

title: Astronomers Detect Farthest Galaxy Yet
description: Astronomers working at the Keck Observatory in Hawaii have detected an extremely faint galaxy some 14 billion light-years away, in the constellation Virgo. Measurements of its light indicate that this is the most distant galaxy ever observed, pushing back the earliest known time when galaxies formed to only a billion years after the universe came into being.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Bridge
description: Second-hand low is a good principle, but defenders must avoid slavish adherence: there are subtle exceptions. The diagramed deal is from the World Mixed Pairs Championship in Albuquerque, N.M., in 1994. North and South were Roslyn Kurlan of Great Neck, L.I., and Ron Andersen of Chicago.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Ford Reports 58% Decline In Fourth-Quarter Earnings
description: The Ford Motor Company today reported a 58 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings, as its successes as a lender proved inadequate to cover its problems as an auto maker.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;New Campaigns
description: WNET-TV, Channel 13, New York, is introducing its largest consumer campaign ever. The advertisements, which were created by Earle Palmer Brown in New York, carry the theme "Channel 13. It takes your mind off the dumb stuff." There will be print ads and posters on buses, telephone kiosks and other sites; TDI in New York as well as magazines and newspapers are donating more than $1 million of ad space.

title: North Carolina Democrat to Quit Congress
description: Representative Charlie Rose, the North Carolina Democrat who has been a champion of tobacco farmers for more than 23 years in Congress, announced today that he would not seek re-election.

title: GIULIANI'S BUDGET PLAN: THE PROCESS;Giuliani's Preliminary Plan Will Undergo Some Revisions
description: The release of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's preliminary spending plan yesterday kicks off a five-month process during which the New York City government decides its budget for the next fiscal year, which begins on July 1.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League DETROIT TIGERS -- Named Tyler Barnes director of public relations.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Christie Claim Rejected
description: The agent for LINFORD CHRISTIE and British track officials yesterday rejected a claim by the Canadian sprinter DONOVAN BAILEY that Christie faked an injury at last summer's world championships.

title: Executive Changes
description: GYMBOREE CORP., Burlingame, Calif., named a former Dayton Hudson Corp. executive, Gary White, senior vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Albany Set to Relax Secrecy In Instances of Child Abuse
description: Spurred by the killing of 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders agreed today to loosen secrecy laws that have tightly restricted public disclosure of information on child abuse cases, even after a child has died.

title: The Author Could Not Be Reached for Comment
description: Forget about Hillary Rodham Clinton's long-lost billing records. The Washington mystery of the moment, the one that truly consumes the tight little handful of President Clinton's aides and former aides -- and the industries that thrive on studying, influencing and opposing them -- is simple: who is Anonymous?

title: A Fresh Cachet for Jazz in New York
description: One evening not long ago, the Blue Note All-Stars opened a six-night engagement at Sweet Basil in Greenwich Village. The weather that evening was unspeakable, a combination of snow and sleet, and the All-Stars, a new group made up of excellent but hardly famous young jazz players who record for the Blue Note label, are not what anyone would call an obvious big draw. Yet the club was packed, and the audience cheered the players enthusiastically.

title: 'Keep Fokker Flying': A Cry That Transports a Dutchman's Soul
description: AMSTERDAM  In the Netherlands, the financial crash of Fokker,the world's oldest aircraft maker and a company as Dutch as Hans Brinker, has struck the national soul.

title: Offices Shut After Water Main Break
description: Scores of offices on lower Fifth Avenue were shut down yesterday as building managers continued to clean up the muddy mess caused by a break in a century-old water main on Tuesday.

title: Milton Sorokin, Lawyer, 69
description: Milton Sorokin, a Hartford lawyer and a specialist in First Amendment issues, died on Sunday in Hartford Hospital. He was 69 and lived in West Hartford.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about proposed timber imports from Russia referred incorrectly to a Federal agency that issued a grant for a feasibility study of logging old-growth forests in Siberia. It is the U.S. Trade and Development Agency, not the Trade and Development Administration; it is an independent agency, not a part of the Commerce Department.

title: The Mayor's Budget Mirage
description: After two years of tough spending cuts, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is calling for New York City to continue on a steady and stringent budgetary path toward financial health. But the Mayor's latest fiscal plan, outlined yesterday at City Hall, is filled with shaky assumptions that are likely to collapse, thus requiring bolder and more painful budget reductions in the next several months. To his credit, Mr. Giuliani has begun to rethink some of his earlier budget strategies, particularly in the area of police. But several basic causes of the city's insolvency need to be addressed more aggressively.

title: Group Concerned About Family Members on Boards
description: Investors, citing the need for management accountability, usually frown on companies whose directors are beholden to the chief executive. Now the Council of Institutional Investors has come across an even bigger red flag: boards studded with members of one family, often but not always the chief executive's.

title: Investor Group Is Seeking Koger
description: An investor group said this week that it might increase its 13.8 percent stake in Koger Equity Inc. to as much as 25 percent, if the company lifted its takeover defenses.

title: BASEBALL;A Veteran's Leadership Is Sought From Gilkey
description: Growing up in St. Louis, Bernard Gilkey said yesterday, his dream was to play the outfield for his hometown Cardinals. He did, for five-plus seasons, surrounded by veterans like Ozzie Smith, Pedro Guerrero, Gerald Perry and Milt Thompson.

title: Affordability Index of Houses Increases
description: The purchasing power of home buyers rose in the fourth quarter as mortgage rates continued to fall, the National Association of Realtors said today.

title: Magic Shows the Way
description: Representative Robert Dornan of California and his benighted followers in Congress could learn a lot about AIDS and humanity and common sense by following the saga of Magic Johnson, one of the all-time great basketball players who has just returned to the National Basketball Association after a four-year exile caused by AIDS phobia.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Rhone-Poulenc Profit Rose 11.4% in 1995
description: Rhone-Poulenc S.A., France's biggest chemical and pharmaceutical company, said yesterday that its net income rose 11.4 percent in 1995, even as fourth-quarter profits fell 77.4 percent because of a weak economic climate and strikes in France. Fourth-quarter net profit fell to 174 million francs, or $34 million, from 771 million francs a year earlier. That also reflected charges for the company's takeover of Fisons P.L.C. and Allied Immune Sciences.

title: This Model Was Too Rough;Why Economic Forecasting Became a Sideshow
description: Want to know what I.B.M.'s in-house economist thinks is in store for the American economy in 1996? You're out of luck: the giant computer maker, which counted more than two dozen economists on its payroll in the early 1970's, no longer employs a single professional to estimate key numbers like interest rates, capital spending and inflation.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;New Sterling Forest Bill
description: Republican lawmakers from New Jersey and New York met yesterday with House Speaker Newt Gingrich and said they were drafting new legislation to help the two states purchase Sterling Forest under an "omnibus environmental bill that would include Sterling Forest, among other items." They did not provide details of the proposal, which follows the collapse of a House plan to sell thousands of acres of Federal prairie in Oklahoma and use the revenue toward the purchase of Sterling Forest, which straddles the New York-New Jersey border.

title: Netscape's 4th-Quarter Profit Exceeded Analysts' Estimates
description: Buoyed by growing demand for its Internet software, Netscape Communications Inc. reported fourth-quarter earnings today that exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates.

title: THEATER REVIEW;2 Plays Linked by Oppression
description: Two personal declarations of independence could be heard on different stages of the same theater company in the nation's capital last week. Both pronouncements came late in their respective dramas at the Arena Stage: one from a female cancer patient in a hospital bed, the other from a former slave confronting the ambiguities of freedom in the age of Reconstruction.

title: Ebbets Field, In Queens?
description: The Mets have already borrowed the color blue from the Brooklyn Dodgers. Now, if the Mets' president, Fred Wilpon, has his way, it looks as if Ebbets Field -- or a facsimile -- might be next.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Ex-Communist Offered As New Polish Premier
description: Poland's governing coalition today nominated a former Communist to become the next Prime Minister and replace Jozef Oleksy, who resigned over allegations that he had been a spy for Moscow.

title: POLITICS;Kemp Keeps His Neutrality
description: With Senator Bob Dole and Steve Forbes ardently seeking his endorsement for the Republican Presidential nomination, Jack F. Kemp said today that he had reached a decision: he would not pick either one, yet.

title: The Harder the Life, the Better the Student?
description: To the Editor:

title: Kennedy Center Names Two Advisers on Dance
description: Lawrence J. Wilker, president of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, has announced the appointment of Charles L. and Stephanie Reinhart as artistic advisers for dance at the center. Mr. and Mrs. Reinhart will remain co-directors of the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., while advising the center on ballet and modern-dance events.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Reader's Digest, Citing Loss, To Lay Off 1,000 Workers
description: Reporting a 10 percent decline in second-quarter profits, the Reader's Digest Association said yesterday that it would lay off 1,000 people worldwide and sell Travel Holiday, one of its four special interest magazines.

title: DC-9 Swerves to Miss Plane
description: The pilot of a USAir jet landing at the airport here today was forced to pass below a small plane that blundered into its path, narrowly averting a collision.

title: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;Dole Takes Off the Gloves
description: campaign for the final pushes in Iowa and New Hampshire. Called "Gravy Train," it is an out-and-out attack on Steve Forbes, the candidate causing the most jitters in the Dole camp. (The second advertisement, intended principally for Iowa voters, is meant to complement the harsh message in this one. It features Mr. Dole in a warm setting with ordinary Midwesterners, tractors and the candidate in a decidedly un-Washington-like field coat.)

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGES;Impostor Meets Officials
description: A 30-year-old man who used a false identity to bluff his way onto the University of Texas football team has met with school officials who are reviewing the case.

title: Calendar: Shows, Tours and a Talk
description: Decorative Arts Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street; (212) 534-1672, ext. 206.

title: Chicago Gives a Pedestrian Mall the Boot
description: There was a time when no place in town was quite so jaunty as State Street on a Saturday night. "On State Street, that great street," sang Frank Sinatra in the song "Chicago," "I just want to say, they do things they don't do on Broadway."

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Man Finds Help in Helping Others
description: Two years ago, Zeke B. was at a turning point in his life. A hot temper and a propensity for getting into trouble seemed to be leading him down a self-destructive path.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DELUXE MOVES TO CLOSE 26 PLANTS AND TRIM 1,200 JOBS
description: The Deluxe Corporation said yesterday that it planned to close more than half its check-printing plants and to eliminate 1,200 jobs in the next two years. The company said it would record expenses of $30 million to $35 million in the first quarter to pay for the closings. Deluxe, which previously said it would close five plants, said yesterday that it would close 21 more, leaving 15 open. The company, based in St. Paul, estimated that the closings would affect 2,400 full-time and 600 part-time workers at the 26 plants. The company said, however, that it expected to add as many as 1,800 positions to the remaining plants by expanding the number of work shifts. The company said it expected more staff cuts in the next two years.

title: POLITICS: IN THE PACK;Legislators Get the Pitch, Taylor-Style
description: The rich man's Presidential campaign of Maurice M. Taylor, the tire-and-wheel tycoon better known as Morry, blew into the New Hampshire Legislature today, hurling blustery derision at fellow Republican contenders and startling the staid chamber with a studied informality.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mexican Protesters Block Oil Wells in a Gulf State
description: Demonstrators have blockaded dozens of oil wells belonging to Petroleos Mexicanos in the state of Tabasco this week, demanding compensation for pollution by the huge state oil monopoly.

title: Megabucks, Minibucks
description: To The Home Section:

title: HOUSE PROUD;Beyond the Grecian Formula: Grandeur on a Small Scale
description: WHEN his ceiling collapsed with a thunderous crash during a recent dinner party, John Woodrow Kelley, a classical painter, claims he was undaunted. "That's what you get for living in an old brownstone," he said with a grin.

title: U.S. Warship Pays a Visit To Shanghai
description: As the warship Fort McHenry inched its way toward a warehouse pier shortly after noon today, its steel-gray hull gently brushing past clumps of garbage floating on the Huangpu River, a Chinese brass band struck up a tune: "Welcome the Guests."

title: The Spy Agency That Lost $2 Billion
description: The National Reconnaissance Office, which designs dazzlingly sophisticated spy satellites, manages its books with considerably less skill. In the last few years, it somehow lost track of more than $2 billion in its own budget. This remarkable accounting feat, partly disclosed last year and confirmed this week by the Senate Intelligence Committee, is attributed by intelligence officials and members of Congress to lax management and excessive secrecy at the organization.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Civil Rights Before the 60's
description: The centerpiece of "A. Philip Randolph: For Jobs and Freedom," tomorrow night's appreciation of a big figure in black America's history -- which is to say, American history -- is his role in organizing and leading the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters. Randolph's socialist ideals, his organizing skills, his toughness, shrewdness and endurance came together in a resounding achievement for its time. For viewers whose acquaintance with civil rights leaders begins with the 1960's, this program may be a revelation.

title: Education Company Banned From Hartford Schools
description: Only a week after Hartford announced that it wanted to end the nation's largest experiment in private management of public schools and reach an "amicable" settlement with its corporate partner, Education Alternatives Inc., the city today barred the company from its 32 schools.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Michael E. Kassan, chief operating officer at Western International Media, Los Angeles, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was promoted to the added new post of president.

title: Where Art's Outsiders Are Totally In
description: AT the fourth annual Outsider Art Fair, which ended Sunday at the Puck Building in SoHo, it was sometimes the customers who found themselves to be outsiders.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AT $115 MILLION, A BUYER FOR SAMUEL GOLDWYN
description: Metromedia International Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Samuel Goldwyn Company, a struggling independent Hollywood studio, for $115 million. The news from Metromedia, which first made a bid for Goldwyn in December, followed an announcement earlier in the day by the Dutch company Polygram N.V. that it had withdrawn its offer to buy Goldwyn's film and television library. Metromedia, controlled by the investor John W. Kluge, owns the Orion Pictures Corporation and the Alliance Entertainment Corporation. The companies said Goldwyn shareholders would receive $5 worth of Metromedia stock for each Goldwyn share. Goldwyn shares rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $4.75, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Officer Is Shot by Another
description: A police officer with a drawn gun was wounded by a fellow officer's fire on a Harlem rooftop during a burglary investigation before dawn yesterday, the police said.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;A Wave Of Wagner Rolls In
description: Recordings of Richard Wagner's operas are few enough and far enough between to arrive like squalls in calm weather. The "Ring" cycle has recently been the scene of intense activity; "Parsifal" appeals to a secular-spiritual age. But "Lohengrin" and "Tristan und Isolde" are markedly rare: the first has fallen off in popularity as the 20th century has progressed, while the second, looming larger than ever, has suffered from a severe shortage (some might say total drought) of singers capable of singing the title roles. Here, now, are new versions of these monumental love stories, early and late exemplars of Wagner's Romantic obsessions in pure form.

title: GIULIANI'S BUDGET PLAN: THE OVERVIEW;GIULIANI'S BUDGET CUTS SPENDING 5% AND LOWERS TAXES
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani presented a preliminary $31 billion budget yesterday that would cut New York City's total spending by nearly 5 percent, continue to reduce taxes and rely heavily on help from Albany and Washington that appears unlikely to come.

title: Sports of The Times;There's a Good Reason They Call Him Magic
description: THE moment that would symbolically serve as Magic Johnson's reintroductory statement was also a brainy commentary on basketball's generational divide. Having just faked his opponent into photographers' row, what would Shawn Kemp, for argument's sake, have done with the empty space between himself and the basket?

title: Class Suit on Tobacco Illness Can Go to Trial in Florida
description: Anti-tobacco plaintiffs won a partial victory yesterday when a Florida state appeals panel unanimously ruled that the first class-action lawsuit against leading tobacco companies for cigarette-related illnesses could go to trial. But the court limited the case to the state of Florida, instead of permitting the plaintiffs' lawyers to mount a case with national effect.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. No. 500 for Hawerchuk

title: BASEBALL;Yanks See Bullpen Solution In Ward
description: While the Yankees have been unsuccessful in securing a quality left-handed reliever, General Manager Bob Watson indicated yesterday he was close to signing right-hander Duane Ward, believing that the once-dominant pitcher can help alleviate the bullpen shortage. Watson said it would not matter that Ward is right-handed if his arm were healthy.

title: City Opera Fills Out Top Team Of Officials
description: Paul Kellogg, the new artistic and general director of the New York City Opera, yesterday announced the appointments of George Manahan as music director, Sherwin Goldman as executive producer and John Conklin as director of production. The appointments round out the company's administrative and artistic team, and in interviews, Mr. Kellogg and the others spoke of a collaborative approach in which the lines of responsibility would be deliberately blurred.

title: Sports of The Times;The St. John's Two-Step, Up and Back
description: IT'S amazing how quickly and easily St. John's young Turks climb into their comfort zones. They exude a cockiness that's not substantiated by their record, and past the midway point of the season they seem more concerned with personal statistics than team success.

title: Schools Brace for State Aid Fluctuations
description: In a process akin to hearing a mortar shell whining in flight and then bracing for the impact, school superintendents across New Jersey await the state aid figures, wondering which districts will take a hit and which will be spared in the distribution of $4 billion from Trenton's purse.

title: Currents;Gucci's Latest Can't Be Worn
description: IN the 1980's, star architects put their names to home furnishings: Richard Meier crystal, Robert Venturi china, Michael Graves everything.

title: Oklahoma Bomb Victims Seek to Curb Death Row Appeals
description: Survivors of the April 19 bombing of the Federal Building and families of those who died asked today that the public help them lobby the House of Representatives to curtail appeal times in death penalty cases.

title: Japanese Stocks Gain
description: Stocks were trading higher here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 122.38 points, or nearly .59 percent, at 20,935.12. On Wednesday, the index gained 90.30 points.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PAUL McCARTNEY returned to the scene of his childhood on Tuesday to open the Liverpool Institute of the Performing Arts, a school that it is hoped may someday be likened to the New York City high school in the movie "Fame."

title: COMPANY NEWS;ESCO ELECTRONICS LOOKS TO SELL ITS HAZELTINE UNIT
description: The Esco Electronics Corporation of St. Louis said yesterday that it had hired J. P. Morgan & Company to explore the sale of its Hazeltine Corporation electronic systems subsidiary. Hazeltine makes and services advanced electronics systems for military purposes, including electronic identification equipment. It also makes antenna systems for the wireless communications market. Shares of Esco rose $1.125 yesterday, to $11.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Esco makes products for the military industry.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Father Faces Murder Charges
description: Michael Sulsona Sr., 34, who police said violently shook his 2-month-old son to stop him from crying, is due to be arraigned on murder charges today, after the boy died Tuesday night at Morristown Memorial Hospital. The father had originally been charged with aggravated assault following the incident on Sunday, said Boris Moczula, first assistant prosecutor for Passaic County.

title: Essay;The Dole Comeback
description: When Anonymous writes his or her novel about the 1996 Dole campaign, the first dramatic chapter will be the fortnight that three forces converge to enliven what would otherwise be "Primary Colorless":

title: Westchester Executive Seeks a $23,250 Raise
description: Ending widespread speculation that he would be stepping down as Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke has announced that he will not accept a judgeship this year. Moreover, he has proposed that he be given a $23,250-a-year raise.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Total's Profit Fell 35% in 1995
description: The profit of the French energy company Total S.A. fell 35 percent in 1995 because of the costs associated with the adoption of a new accounting rule and tighter profit margins from refined products in Europe and the United States. The new standard required Total fields in Norway, the United States and Vietnam to be priced at market value, and cut the company's net income by 800 million francs, or $156.86 million.

title: 2 Holders Sell Stake In Czech Chemicals
description: Stratton Investments and the Czech investment company Harvard Capital and Consulting have sold their stakes in Spolana Neratovice A.S., a Czech chemical company, to Chemapol A.S.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;4 Agencies Win Grand Awards
description: Four agencies have won the best of show Grand Awards at the 38th annual international television advertising competition sponsored by the New York Festivals.

title: Charlie Jewtraw, Speed Skater, 95
description: Charlie Jewtraw, who won the first event at the first Winter Olympic Games, died last Friday. He was 95.

title: GIULIANI'S BUDGET PLAN: REVENUES;Parking Meters May Be Sold To a Company
description: New York State has sold off a prison and a highway to raise quick cash. Now the city wants to sell off one of its most familiar fixtures -- its parking meters.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Officers in Harassment Suit
description: Four city police officers and a New Jersey State Police trooper harassed six residents of the city between 1993 and 1995, and high-ranking officials ignored their complaints, according to a class-action lawsuit filed in Federal court, the A.P. said. One of the plaintiffs, Jose Clemente, a paraplegic, said a police officer threw him to the ground last March. A city police spokesman declined to comment yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Gtech Keeps Lottery Contract
description: The State Lottery Commission yesterday voted to award a five-year contract for running the Lottery's computer ticker sales to the Gtech Holdings Corporation, which now operates the system. Gtech's bid of $78.4 million won over a $96.5 million bid by Automated Wagering International, The Associated Press reported. Gtech, which has contracts in 27 of the 37 lotteries in the United States, was involved in legal controversy last January when a Federal judge in Kentucky threw out fraud charges against a former Gtech national sales manager but expressed dismay at Gtech's business practices. State Attorney General Deborah Poritz had assured commissioners that a state police background check "revealed no information" that would preclude Gtech from receiving the new contract.

title: Officer Pleads Guilty in Conspiracy to Sell Drugs
description: A police officer accused of attempting to sell drugs pleaded guilty yesterday to lesser charges of conspiracy to sell drugs in the second degree and second-degree assault.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;China's Move On News Flow Worries U.S.
description: Two weeks after China announced a broad plan to restrict the flow of news and economic information into China, the Clinton Administration said today that it would raise the subject in trade talks next week, the first indication that China's efforts to control Western news operations may soon become a new source of friction between the two countries.

title: RITUALS: Families and Traditions;Quinceanera: A Girl Grows Up
description: UNTIL Karla Chavez walked down the church aisle on her parents' arms, the entire Chavez family and the priest at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church here had struggled to stay calm. First, traffic delayed the family's arrival; then, the six-member mariachi band they had hired turned out to have only two players. Even the Rev. David Zapalac, a Texan with Czechoslovak roots, was anxious -- about his proficiency in Spanish.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Harold H. Goldberg, the former chairman of the committees at Moody's Investors Service that rate the quality of corporate debt, misstated his residence in some editions. It was South Salem, N.Y., not Norwalk, Conn.

title: Where Dogs See And Gadgets Talk
description: THE store at 111 East 59th Street may be one of New York's best kept secrets. In this friendly place, many of the gadgets on display can talk, and dogs are even more welcome than in a Paris bistro.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Move It on Over

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;North Sea Partners To Dissolve Venture
description: Enterprise Oil P.L.C. of Britain and Elf Aquitaine of France said yesterday that they would dissolve a North Sea partnership in a move analysts said gives both companies more control over cash flow from the oilfields. Elf held two-thirds of the venture, formed in 1991 to buy the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's interests in the North Sea; Enterprise held one-third. Enterprise said its stake in the fields was now worth roughly L219 million, about $331 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;The life insurance industry unleashes a tough-talk campaign on the advantages of planning ahead.
description: IT'S 1998. You're dead. What do you do now?"

title: Crews Scour Neighborhoods For Asbestos
description: In scenes that could have been lifted from a science-fiction movie, work crews in airtight white suits and purple gas masks scoured two East Side neighborhoods yesterday, seeking to capture asbestos fibers that had been released a day earlier, even though officials said the risk to passersby was negligible.

title: I.B.M. to Pay $743 Million For Developer Of Software
description: I.B.M. made another big bet yesterday that its future depends on becoming a supplier of software and services for computer networks, by agreeing to purchase Tivoli Systems Inc. for $743 million.

title: PEN Board Seeks Expertise, Not Just Money
description: To the Editor:

title: FEDERAL RESERVE TRIMS KEY RATES TO SPUR ECONOMY
description: Worried that the economy has slowed and needs a modest spark, the Federal Reserve lowered short-term interest rates today by one-quarter of a point. The move amounts to tossing out a bit of a lifeline at a time when housing and retail sales are flagging and consumer confidence is sinking.

title: Daily News Hires A Newsday Editor
description: The Daily News hired the former editor of its former competitor, New York Newsday, yesterday. The editor, Donald Forst, is to be metropolitan editor of The News.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Jersey City Schools Still Lag
description: Since Jersey City schools were taken over in 1989, there have been significant improvements in early-childhood education, kindergarten, advance placement and computer technology. But overall academic standards still need to rise before the state relinquishes control, Education Commissioner Leo Klagholz told the Joint Committee on Public Schools yesterday. He said the district still failed to meet one-third of state monitoring standards. Another review of the schools will be made in August.

title: Pataki Vetoes a New Police-Discipline Arbiter
description: Siding with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over the influential police unions for the fourth time in six months, Gov. George E. Pataki today vetoed legislation that opponents said would have removed the New York City police commissioner as final arbiter of discipline for officers.

title: BASEBALL;Griffey Becomes the First $8 Million Dollar Man
description: If ever a player deserved to be called "the Franchise," the Seattle Mariners yesterday identified him as Ken Griffey Jr.

title: Novell to Sell Wordperfect for $115 Million
description: Novell Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell its struggling Wordperfect unit and related products to Corel Inc. of Ottawa, Ontario, for cash and stock valued at about $115 million -- far less than it paid for Wordperfect just 22 months ago.

title: Fighting Kills 4 in Yemen
description: Four people were killed in shooting between troops and tribesmen suspected of kidnapping 18 French tourists last week, security officials said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DAMAGE CLAIM AGAINST AMERICAN GENERAL UNIT IS UPHELD
description: The American General Investment Corporation, the real estate unit of the American General Corporation, said late on Tuesday that a Texas appellate court had affirmed a judgment of $176.5 million in damages against the company in a case brought by the Avia Development Group. The $176.5 million award was reduced in September 1993 from an original verdict of $310 million, which was handed down in May 1993 as part of a breach-of-contract case. Avia, a developer, contended that American General had backed out of a joint venture to build air cargo facilities at New York and New Jersey airports. American General, a financial services company based in Houston, said its unit never agreed to the venture.

title: Junior Partner'? No Way
description: It is often said in the American press that Russia's Communists are by definition unfriendly to reform and to the United States. Yet the Communist Party of the Russian Federation was born six years ago precisely as a party of reform in opposition to decades of stagnation and to Mikhail Gorbachev's itch for revolution. While the West sang hallelujahs to perestroika, we knew that revolutions in Russia have always had painful consequences.

title: Barbara Skelton, Writer, 79
description: Barbara Skelton, a writer whose best subject was her own life of passionate abandon, died on Saturday in Worcestershire in western England from a brain tumor, The Times of London reported on Monday. She was 79.

title: HORSE RACING NOTEBOOK;Best Pal Gets to Retire After Making Millions
description: Best Pal, the third-leading money winner in thoroughbred racing history, was retired at the age of 8 yesterday with the promise that he would spend the rest of his life in leisure at the Golden Eagle Farm in California, where he was born and bred.

title: Museum's Walls Tell A Story of Division;A Planned Exhibition on the Irish Sparks a Bitter Battle Over Content
description: The exhibition was to be a milestone, a joyous event for the Irish in New York City. Instead, the show has become the center of a bitter battle between the museum that would present it and some in the community it would portray.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Argentine Officer Guilty In Case That Ended Draft
description: In a case that induced Argentina to end its draft, an army lieutenant was convicted of murder today for ordering the beating of a soldier he considered slow and lazy.

title: Method Is Found to Improve Results of Heart Procedure
description: By coating a heart device with an anti-clotting drug, European cardiologists have greatly improved success in keeping coronary arteries open after an obstruction has been removed. The method was also found to greatly reduce the major complications that have plagued the device.

title: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;New Hampshire Sustains Proud Tradition of Waiting to Commit
description: It was after the State of the Union address last week that Martha Orr started to have second thoughts.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the debate in Maryland over building two new football stadiums misstated the party affiliation of Jean B. Cryor, a member of the House of Delegates challenging the deals. She is a Republican.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Muster Set to Supplant Agassi as World No. 1
description: When the ATP rankings are published Feb. 12, THOMAS MUSTER will replace ANDRE AGASSI in the top spot.

title: Liberties;The Faberge Egghead
description: If George Bush reminded some women of their first husband, Steve Forbes must remind them of their first husband's accountant.

title: Summer Plans For Learning
description: FORGET reruns on television or mowing lawns. Teen-agers' summers are increasingly for academic enrichment and social experiences that will look good on college applications.

title: Mikhail Reshetnyov, Soviet Rocket Designer, 71
description: Mikhail Reshetnyov, who designed Soviet booster rockets and satellites, died on Friday. He was 71.

title: Budget Gap Is Driving Sale of Taxi Medallions
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Victims' Families Fight for Mercy
description: The unsolved slaying of her daughter, Frances, has haunted Anne Coleman for 11 years. She remembers the stench of blood and death in the car where Frances was shot; she remembers the sight of her body in the morgue.

title: BASKETBALL;Red Storm's Roller Coaster Bottoms Out Against Irish
description: In a season of disappointing losses and depressing developments, St. John's added another disturbing result to the ledger last night with a sobering 86-83 setback to Notre Dame.

title: New York Sued By Government On Foster Care
description: Federal prosecutors accused New York City and state officials yesterday of defrauding the Federal Government out of tens of millions of dollars by falsely reporting that services were delivered to thousands of children in foster care.

title: The Harder the Life, the Better the Student?
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitewater Billing Records Don't Compare to Iran-Contra Diary
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Credit Safety on Internet

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Four Executives Open New Shop
description: Four executives who have worked at agencies in San Francisco are opening their own shop there named Black Rocket.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Movie-Making Boffo in State
description: Movie-making in New Jersey set a record last year, with 50 feature films and 92 television programs partly made in the state, according to the New Jersey Motion Picture and Television Commission. Among current movies that used locations in the state is "The Juror," made partly in Newark and Glen Ridge. JOE SHARKEY

title: COMPANY NEWS;QUANTUM TO STOP MAKING DISK DRIVES AND LAY OFF 2,250
description: The Quantum Corporation will stop making its own high-end disk drives, a decision that will result in layoffs for 2,250 workers and the closing of a plant in Milpitas, Calif., and another in Malaysia. The company said late on Tuesday that work on high-end disk drives, which are used in large computer systems, will be contracted to Japan's Matsushita Kotobuki Electronics Industries. When the plant closings are completed, possibly by this fall, Quantum will have no manufacturing operations in the San Francisco Bay area for the first time since the company was founded in 1980. A Quantum spokeswoman said 1,800 permanent and 450 temporary workers will lose their jobs.

title: U.S. to Help Defray Russia's Expenses for the Space Station
description: The United States will help cash-strapped Russia keep its commitments to the planned international space station by adding three space shuttle missions, one to deliver a key Russian component to the station and two to ferry supplies to the existing Mir outpost, NASA officials said today.

title: Russell C. Smart, 82, Educator and Writer
description: Dr. Russell C. Smart, a retired educator who teamed with his wife to write 10 books on child rearing and family relations, died on Jan. 13 at his home in San Diego. He was 82.

title: Mass Wedding Had No Hidden Purpose
description: To the Editor:

title: Colombian Leader's Appeal to the 'Common Man' Is Often Unheeded
description: Over the last week, President Ernesto Samper, who is fighting for his political survival over allegations he solicited millions of dollars for his 1994 presidential campaign from Colombia's most powerful drug dealers, has taken to portraying himself as a friend of the common man who is under attack for his social commitment.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BLISS & LAUGHLIN AND BAR TECHNOLOGIES EXTEND DEADLINE
description: Bliss & Laughlin Industries and Bar Technologies Inc., formerly named the BRW Steel Corporation, agreed yesterday to extend the termination date of their previously announced merger agreement to Feb. 9. Bar Technologies will be unable to complete the merger if it does not obtain financing, and there is no assurance the proposed transaction will close, Bliss said. Bliss & Laughlin shareholders approved the $37.7 million transaction on Jan. 19. Under the agreement, Bliss & Laughlin shareholders will get $9.50 in cash for each share. Bliss & Laughlin, based in Harvey, Ill., is a maker of cold finished steel bars.

title: Dole Frees Communications Bill for Vote
description: Senator Bob Dole agreed today to back away from his objections to a sweeping telecommunications bill, clearing the way for rapid passage in both the House and Senate.

title: Tick Disease Threat Grows in the Northeast
description: To the Editor:

title: After Years of War, a Lawless Liberia
description: To judge from the money seen in circulation, April 6, 1991, was a huge day in the life of Liberia's troubled national accounts. Inspect any wad of the Liberian five-dollar bills that are the sole denomination here, and -- old and grimy, or crisp and new -- this is the only date of issue one finds.

title: Currents;A Chateau Made For Sleep
description: C@ESLEY McLAREN, a fashion designer, is also known for her loopy, Franco-friendly illustrations, drawn in a swashed, pen-and-ink style, that appear in Vogue, Harper's Bazaar and The New Yorker.

title: Bob Thiele, 73, Record Producer for Jazz Legends
description: Bob Thiele, a producer and record company owner who turned out a string of important jazz recordings for his Impulse label along with pop hits by Buddy Holly, Jackie Wilson and Teresa Brewer, died on Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 73.

title: Robert Adams Day, Literature Scholar, 71
description: Prof. Robert Adams Day, a Joyce scholar an' expert on 18th-century English literature, died on Jan. 19 at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 71 and lived 'n Manhattan.

title: White House Wish: Healthy Economy in Election
description: The Federal Reserve's move today to nudge along a sputtering economic expansion highlights the one question that looms over almost every political strategy meeting at the White House these days: What are the chances that President Clinton will run into the kind of economic downturn that killed off George Bush's candidacy four years ago?

title: Plan to Guard Credit Safety On Internet
description: Hoping to remove a major impediment to credit card transactions over the Internet, a business group led by Mastercard International and Visa International plans to announce an industry-standard technology on Thursday for protecting the security of electronic payments.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EDITEK INC., Burlington, N.C., an on-site testing company, acquired Medtox Laboratories Inc., St. Paul, a toxicology laboratory, for $19 million in cash and $5 million in stock.

title: GOLF;Youth Brigade Ready to Hit Pebble Beach
description: Almost every year when the tour returns to this misty, mystical place on the cliffs of the Monterey Peninsula, the moist air on the old golf course turns into an elixir. The Links at Pebble Beach become the cure for what ails middle-aged golfers, and players like Johnny Miller and Tom Watson and Peter Jacobsen and Jack Nicklaus somehow recapture the games of their youth and turn in performances sweeter than a ballad by Bing Crosby.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Hal Riney Gets Peet's Account
description: Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco has switched coffees.

title: J. Terence Reese, Bridge Writer And One-Time Champion, 82
description: J. Terence Reese, a prolific British writer on bridge who was widely regarded as the world's best player until a cheating scandal effectively ended his tournament career in 1965, died on Monday at his home in Hove, England. He was 82 and had been the bridge columnist for The Observer since 1950.

title: Currents;Inspired by African Odysseys
description: THOSE who fail to find a cultural resonance in polka dots and fleur-de-lis may find lots to like in the West African fabrics imported by Cheryle Williams Dent (right) and Kim Bressant-Kibwe. They sell their collection from Ms. Dent's brownstone-cum-furnishings store, called African Home, at 297 Decatur Street (Stuyvesant Avenue) in Brooklyn; (718) 363-1159.

title: Metro Matters;He Knows How to Find Budget Truth
description: A NONPARTISAN and objective view of the city budget from a pro:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Philip Morris Results Top Expectations
description: Buoyed by strong international tobacco profits and record market share for its Marlboro cigarette brand in the United States, the Philip Morris Companies reported fourth-quarter earnings yesterday that exceeded Wall Street's expectations.

title: The Harder the Life, the Better the Student?
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTBALL;Cowboys' Super Hero Stays Busy
description: He's far from the most celebrated football player on the Cowboys' star-studded roster. Until a few days ago, he wasn't even the most famous Larry Brown in professional sports. (The nomadic coach of basketball's Indiana Pacers holds that distinction.)

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Must Win the Battle at Home
description: As the National Basketball Association heads toward the All-Star break, this much is obvious: Chicago is the league's best team. Meanwhile, many other teams are trying to establish themselves as worthy challengers to the Bulls before the playoffs begin.

title: GIULIANI'S BUDGET PLAN: SOCIAL SERVICES;Broad Vision, Fiscal Constraints
description: The first thing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said as he presented New York with his latest financial plan yesterday was that the city must protect the needy. But a look through the details of his budget plan shows that his definition of protecting the needy is somewhat narrower than the expansive vision he presents.

title: Burne Hogarth, Creator of Tarzan Comic Strip, 84
description: Burne Hogarth, creator of the "Tarzan of the Apes" comic strip, died on Sunday at the Cochin Hospital in Paris. He was 84.

title: Judge to Be Asked to Rethink Drug Ruling
description: After many of the city's and state's top officials criticized a Federal judge for tossing out evidence in a Washington Heights drug case, United States Attorney Mary Jo White will ask the judge to reconsider his ruling.

title: Report Faults White House In Dismissals
description: A long-sealed Justice Department report on the White House travel office was released today. It criticized White House officials for engaging in "ill-advised and erroneous actions" in abruptly dismissing seven employees of the office in 1993.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BURGER KING BUYS 57 RESTAURANTS FOR $55.6 MILLION
description: The Burger King Corporation said yesterday that it had bought 57 Burger King restaurants in Florida and Georgia from Davgar Restaurants Inc., a Florida-based holding company, for $55.6 million. The deal gives Burger King ownership of 505 of the 6,620 Burger King restaurants in the United States, according to Burger King's corporate parent, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. of London.

title: LeRoy Breunig, 80, Professor of French
description: LeRoy C. Breunig, an authority on modern French poetry and art criticism who served as interim president of Barnard College at Columbia University in 1975, died on Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 80 and lived in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Approves Stop By Taiwan Official
description: The State Department, saying it was a routine decision, approved a request by Taiwan's Vice President today that he be allowed to stop in the United States as he flies to and from Haiti and El Salvador.

title: BASKETBALL;Williams Is Nets' Secret Beneath the Boards
description: Dennis Rodman has formed a cult following by creating a niche for himself, that of rebounder extraordinaire.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Enough Fearful Twists for Everyone
description: THE HELLFIRE CLUB By Peter Straub 463 pages. Random House. $25.95.

title: COMPANY NEWS;INGERSOLL-RAND BUYS MASCOTECH'S STEEL- DOOR UNIT
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company said yesterday that it had acquired Mascotech Inc.'s Steelcraft Division, which makes steel doors used primarily in nonresidential construction. Terms were not disclosed, but Ingersoll-Rand said that Steelcraft, based in Cincinnati, had annual revenue of about $100 million. Steelcraft will become a unit of Ingersoll-Rand's Architectural Hardware Group. Ingersoll-Rand, based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., makes primarily nonelectrical machinery and equipment. The company had revenue of $5.73 billion in 1995. Mascotech, a maker of home-improvement products, is based in Taylor, Mich.

title: BASKETBALL: PART MAN, PART MYTH, ALL PLAYER;Los Angeles Embraces Star's Return
description: The waiting here ended Tuesday night, with 5 minutes 53 seconds left in the first quarter. Magic Johnson hoisted his arms, sank a graceful, arching shot, and an entire city sighed in relief. A week of tension and anxiety was over, a week in which rumor and disbelief gave way to joy and giddiness.

title: Economic Scene;Changing the tax system has an allure. But will the fixes work?
description: TAX reform is the Republican flavor of the month. The Kemp Commission, recruited by Newt Gingrich to give his party a tonier image on economic issues, is calling for an end to the income tax as we know it. Steve Forbes's tireless pitch for the flat tax has helped him to break away from the pack chasing Bob Dole for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Rita Lynn, 74, Actor And Play Therapist
description: Rita Lynn, an actress in radio and television who also helped develop the use of theatrical performances as therapy for psychiatric patients, died on Jan. 21 at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 74.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the New Jersey budget misstated the political makeup of the Connecticut State Senate. Republicans, not Democrats, have a one-vote majority. Democrats have a 31-vote majority in the House.

title: 9 Skeletons in Austrian Grave Pose Mystery
description: Work was halted today at a construction site where at least nine human skeletons have been unearthed. An Interior Ministry official challenged assertions that workers had stumbled on a rare mass grave of Holocaust victims.

title: Moscow Journal;Stalin's Music Man Is a Kremlin Star Again
description: Stalin's last surviving apparatchik has made a triumphant return to the Kremlin.

title: Last of Refugees From Cuba In '94 Flight Now Enter U.S.
description: After nearly a year and a half of detention at the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Caridad Alonso could have entered the United States two weeks ago. But she wanted to be one of the last Cubans to leave the refugee camps.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Poetry in Motion, Read Aloud or Simply Imagined
description: Last week, a PBS documentary about the photographer Richard Avedon declared that "images are fast replacing words as our primary language." Tonight on WNET, an Independent Television Service series called "The United States of Poetry" puts things in a more balanced and infinitely more comforting perspective. Words, serious or sassy, are alive and well, no matter how much advertisers and the fashion industry may try to debase them.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN IMBRIE, the geologist and oceanographer known for his pioneering study of the ice ages, and ROBERT DICKINSON, an atmospheric scientist who created computer models that show how atmospheric dynamics affect climate, will receive the G. Unger Vetlesen Prize, sometimes called the Nobel Prize in earth sciences.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CORNING REPORTED IN TALKS TO SELL LAB SERVICES DIVISION
description: Corning Inc. is negotiating a possible merger of its beleaguered laboratory services division with SmithKline Beecham P.L.C.'s lab unit, individuals familiar with the talks said yesterday. A Corning spokeswoman declined to comment on the possible deal, which was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal. But an industry source said Corning was eager to get rid of its lab services and might turn to other potential buyers. Corning Clinical Labs operates a national network of clinical testing laboratories and patient-service centers. It had sales of about $1.6 billion last year. Corning shares rose 75 cents yesterday, to $31.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Spain's Bailout Of Iberia Cleared
description: The European Commission approved a Spanish Government aid package yesterday that would provide 87 billion peseta, or $690 million, for the struggling Spanish airline Iberia. The European executive body said that the state-run carrier would also be allowed to apply for another 20 billion pesetas in 1997 if it improves productivity and earnings.

title: SAP America President to Run New Company
description: Klaus P. Besier, the man credited with fueling SAP America Inc.'s phenomenal growth over the last two years, is stepping down as president and chief executive to lead a hot Internet software company called Business

title: Elderly Prisoners
description: To The Home Section:

title: BASKETBALL;Rutgers Slows UConn, Then Gets Run Over
description: Connecticut 77, Rutgers 59 PISCATAWAY, N.J., Jan. 31 -- Doron Sheffer and Ray Allen each scored 25 points to spark No. 4 Connecticut (21-1 over all, 11-0 in the Big East) to a 77-59 rout of Rutgers tonight before a crowd of 8,091 at the Louis Brown Athletic Center Arena. It was the Huskies' school-record 19th consecutive victory.

title: Whitewater Billing Records Don't Compare to Iran-Contra Diary
description: To the Editor:

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Camellia Rx for Winter

title: Roman Smoluchowski, Physicist, Is Dead at 85
description: Roman Smoluchowski, a physicist who studied structures as small as atoms and as large as planets, died on Jan. 12 in Austin, Tex., where he was an emeritus professor at the University of Texas. He was 85.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFINGS;Rowan Students Not Indicted
description: Citing conflicting eyewitness reports, a Gloucester County grand jury declined yesterday to indict five Rowan College students -- including two members of the football team -- who had been charged with involvement in a brawl outside a bar last October, prosecutors said. JOE SHARKEY

title: BASKETBALL;Articulating a Vision Of the Women's Game
description: I think the biggest problem in women's athletics," said Nancy Lieberman-Cline, "is that we look at the guys and want to do it their way. Well, the marketing and the exposure is O.K., but do we have to fall into the traps? Do we have to live for the moment, for that one unbelievable play that will get us on 'Sports Center' that night instead of playing for the long term?

title: Giuliani Seeks Tough Laws To Help Abused Children
description: When a parent is accused of child abuse, city caseworkers should be given access to the parent's full criminal record, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani recommended yesterday.

title: Defendant's Flight Is Focus in Bombing Trial
description: Seconds after an explosion in a subway car wounded 48 people, a passenger who escaped serious injury noticed another man rolling around frantically on the station platform trying to extinguish the fire enveloping his trouser legs.

title: Russian Coal Miners Strike for Back Pay
description: Defying Boris N. Yeltsin, the President they helped bring to power, nearly half a million russian coal miners went on strike yesterday to demand $200 million in back pay.

title: BASKETBALL;Ex-Syracuse Player Ineligible to Play
description: Michael Lloyd, phe point guard who left Syracuse amid academic eligibility questions and was trying to transfer to Auburn-Montgomery, cannot play this season because he signed with an agent, the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics ruled.

title: No Headline
description: I thought the darn thing was broken. It was down below where the scale ends at 50 below zero. I've never seen it that cold." -- GENE MADDEN, an immigration inspector in Montana. [A10:1.]

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks' Bigger and Better Strategy Stymies Magic
description: Don Nelson sketched a new strategy last night to combat Shaquille O'Neal, Anfernee Hardaway and the Orlando Magic, and the Knicks unveiled their new "Go New York Go" video. The surprises did not stop there.

title: MGM Grand Seeks New Jersey License
description: In the latest sign of a resurgence in the Atlantic City gambling market, MGM Grand Inc. filed today for a New Jersey casino license.

title: Siberian Forest Protects Against Warming
description: To the Editor:

title: ART REVIEW;An African Renewal At the Metropolitan
description: AROUND the time Michelangelo was polishing up his colossal "David" for the Medici in early 16th-century Florence, a sculptor in West Africa was carving a woman's pendant head in ivory for the King of the great nation of Benin in what is now Nigeria. Less than a foot high, it is widely recognized to be among the sculptural masterpieces of world art.

title: Accused CBS Official Resigns
description: John Pike, a CBS programming executive who was reported to have made racist remarks about black people, resigned yesterday.

title: Art in Review
description: Alan Turner Lennon, Weinberg 560 Broadway, at Prince Street SoHo Through Feb. 10

title: Closing AIDS Trials Is Shortsighted
description: To the Editor:

title: For Children
description: 'African Tales' The Brooklyn Museum 200 Eastern Parkway Prospect Park (718) 630-5000 Ages 6 to 10 Tomorrow

title: HORSE RACING;King of the Claimers Wins 10th in a Row
description: He isn't D. Wayne Lukas, who has won the last five Triple Crown races with three different horses. And he isn't Bill Mott, who has won 12 races in a row with the one and only Cigar. He is Frank Passero Jr., king of the claimers, who bounced into the winner's circle in his bold yellow jacket twice today at Gulfstream Park after saddling 10 winners in 10 races over the last nine days.

title: Audit Says U.S. Capital Remains in Deep Fiscal Crisis Despite Drop in Deficit
description: In a city where people wait endlessly for snowplows to clear their streets, police officers sell baked goods to raise money for office supplies, and more than half of the city's 16 firetrucks are out of commission, another reminder of economic tough times was hardly needed. But today, residents of the nation's capital learned just how bleak the city had become.

title: Auto Sales for January Increased by 4.7%
description: New vehicle sales over all rose 4.7 percent for most auto makers in January compared with the comparable 1995 period as buyers snapped up brawny pickups, sport utility vehicles and mini-vans but passed over passenger cars, according to sales data released today by nearly a dozen auto companies.

title: NYC;Crisis or Not, Shadow of 70's Haunts Budget
description: HANG onto your old Bee Gees records. Don't throw out those Annie Hall clothes. It may be time to brush up on Watergate trivia and to dust off that copy of "Shogun."

title: Jamie Uys, 74, the Director Of 'The Gods Must Be Crazy'
description: Jamie Uys, who wrote, produced and directed the hit film "The Gods Must Be Crazy," died of a heart attack on Monday at his home. He was 74 and lived in Pretoria.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about workers cleaning up asbestos-contaminated mud and water after a water main break in Manhattan referred incorrectly in some editions to their employer and misstated the day of the break. The men work for the City Department of Environmental Protection, not the Consolidated Edison Company. The break occurred on Tuesday, not Monday.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Screen' Friedrich Petzel Gallery 26 Wooster Street, SoHo Through Feb. 24

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Finance Briefs listing of Business Day on Wednesday about a debt offering by CIT Group Holdings Inc. misidentified the lead underwriter. It was CS First Boston, not Morgan Stanley.

title: America Online Expands Service
description: America Online Inc., the leading United States on-line service, has started AOL Canada, extending its international reach.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Volvo-Mitsubishi Talks
description: The Swedish auto maker Volvo confirmed yesterday that it had talked with the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan about building cars together in the United States, but emphasized nothing will happen soon. Volvo just wants to keep "updated on the market and production in the U.S., but production in the U.S. is not currently on the management's agenda," a Volvo spokesman, Ingmar Hesslefors, said. Volvo and Mitsubishi recently teamed up in a joint venture in the Netherlands to build compact cars. (AP)

title: Chase-Chemical Date Is Set
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that they had set March 31 as the effective date for their $10 billion merger. The merged entity, to retain the name Chase Manhattan, will be the largest commercial bank holding company in the United States, with $297 billion in assets. The subsidiary banks will be merged later in the year, the companies said.

title: China, Vying With Taiwan, Explores Public Relations
description: Last November, representatives from the communications firm of Robinson Lerer Sawyer Miller were invited to the Chinese Embassy to present an ambitious three-year public-relations strategy for Beijing.

title: Judge's Reasoning in Drug Case Was Sound;Police as Scapegoat
description: To the Editor:

title: Goodbye, Quaint, Hello, Poconos!
description: I HAD grown up giggling at the television commercials: couples frolicking on the tennis court, lounging by the pool, clinking glasses over candlelight. The singsong tag line, "Beautiful Mount Airy Lodge," had become as familiar a refrain as "Coke is it" or "This Bud's for you."

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Seoul Hints at Pardons For Executives on Trial
description: President Kim Young Sam has assured some of South Korea's top executives who are on trial for corruption that he would allow them to concentrate on their businesses, hinting that he would pardon them if they were jailed.

title: Red Kamels Are Back
description: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, a unit of RJR Nabisco Holdings, said today that it would reintroduce its Red Kamel cigarette brand after a 60-year hiatus on Feb. 15. The brand was created in 1913 and was shelved in 1936 because R. J. Reynolds's Camel brand was more popular, according to Richard Williams, a company spokesman. Mr. Williams said the cigarettes would be sold in "trendy bars and clubs" in New York, Los Angeles, Dallas and San Francisco starting on Feb. 15.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Surgery Ends Webber's Season
description: Washington Bullets forward Chris Webber put an end to his most frustrating National Basketball Association season by undergoing surgery on his left shoulder today. Dr. Russell Warren performed the operation at the Hospital For Special Surgery in New York.

title: ICE SKATING REVIEW;Elegance With Some Eccentricity
description: The ice rink at Rockefeller Plaza became a stage on Wednesday afternoon when Ice Theater of New York offered the first of three free lunchtime performances.

title: Closing AIDS Trials Is Shortsighted
description: To the Editor:

title: TV WEEKEND;Dignity and Comedy From Handicapped Men
description: The Boys Next Door," on CBS on Sunday night, is about several mentally handicapped men living in a group home. Not too long ago they would have been called retarded. Today "mentally challenged" or simply "different" is the preferred label. In any event, Tom Griffin's Off Broadway play, now adapted by William Blinn ("Brian's Story"), succeeds in transforming a potentially depressing situation into a delightful comedy drama. A uniformly inspired cast manages to make "The Boys Next Door" hilarious while never for a moment ignoring its sad edges.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF RED ROOF INNS RISE IN FIRST DAY OF TRADING
description: The shares of Red Roof Inns Inc. were up yesterday in their first day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The shares, which were priced at $16, closed at $17 as almost four million were traded. Red Roof sold 10 million shares to raise $160 million. The company, which owns and operates economy hotels in the United States, has been closely held since being acquired for $335 million in 1993 by a group led by Morgan Stanley Group Inc. After the sale, Morgan Stanley will own 59.5 percent of the company, which is based in Hilliard, Ohio. Red Roof currently has 226 hotels with 25,400 rooms in 32 states.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a manic-depressive patient who killed two Roman Catholic nuns in Maine misstated the date of a book by an authority on manic-depressive illness. The book, "An Unquiet Mind," by Dr. Kay Redfield Jamison, was published by Alfred A. Knopf in 1995, not 1965.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Maverick Leftist Named New Polish Premier
description: The President of Poland asked a maverick former Communist with strong parliamentary support to form a new Government today and replace Jozef Oleksy, who resigned as Prime Minister last week over allegations that he was a spy for Moscow.

title: The Republican Welfare Trap
description: House Republicans have a plan to corner President Clinton politically. They want to pass the Senate's welfare reform bill, which is less extreme than the House bill but still nasty. No matter what he does, someone will accuse the President of betraying his promises. If he signs the bill he will, by his staff's estimates, throw more than a million children into poverty and infuriate his party's liberal wing. If he vetoes it, the G.O.P. will accuse him of repudiating not only his campaign promise to reform the welfare system but also his grudging embrace of the Senate bill when it passed by an overwhelming majority in September. That mistake has returned to haunt him.

title: Hart of the Arts
