description: Kitty Carlisle Hart, who recently resigned as head of the New York State Council on the Arts, which distributes grants to cultural groups throughout the state, fit her job as precisely as a shell fits an egg. In the 20 years since her appointment by Gov. Hugh Carey, there was hardly a cultural institution in the state that she did not visit or a legislator she did not buttonhole. If the Arts Council's grants have usually been sagacious and wide-ranging, much of the credit is due to her determination to expose its members to everything that was going on in the state's cultural community. Her high profile helped compensate for the Council's low budget -- now $28.9 million after a series of drastic budget cuts during the Cuomo years. Gov. George Pataki will find her hard to replace.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFINGS;Judge Allows Backpack Ban
description: A student at William Annin Middle School in Bernards Township who challenged the school's recent policy banning backpacks was rebuffed by a state administrative law judge yesterday. Elyse Meredith, 13, the only one of the 500 students to defy the ban, will have to drop her backpack, Judge Solomon Metzger said. He added, "This is a case about an eighth grader resisting authority over a minor school rule." The school said backpacks were bulky and dangerous in crowded hallways.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A Boom in Malaysia Reaches for the Sky;A New Capital. Tall Towers. Can It Last?
description: As far as the eye can see, fringed oil palms, the trees that once brought wealth to this peninsula, parade in ranks up and down the hills. But in a bulldozed clearing, rising like a glistening inverted ice cream cone, stands a steel monument to the future. It marks the site, 25 miles south of Kuala Lumpur, of what will be this country's new capital and has come to symbolize Malaysia's sprint toward status as a developed nation.

title: Art in Review
description: Rita Ackermann Andrea Rosen Gallery 130 Prince Street, SoHo Through Feb. 24

title: 25 and Under
description: Son of Luma

title: ART REVIEW;A Self-Effacing Avowal Of Geometry's Power
description: Given the space requirements of Sol LeWitt's wall drawings, New York probably will not see a full-scale survey of these cornerstones of Conceptualism any time soon. In the interim, the retrospective of the artist's prints at the Museum of Modern Art gives a superb if rather miniaturized account of his achievement and the remarkable way his art has unfolded over the last 25 years.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL

title: FILM REVIEW;Seafaring Boys in Stormy Weather
description: The year was 1960, and the group of schoolboys aboard the Albatross, a square-rigged brigantine vessel, were about to become men. They would do this by experiencing the tough love of Christopher Sheldon, their teacher and skipper, and by enduring a terrifying storm in the Caribbean.

title: Robert Gallati, Police Innovator, Dies at 82
description: Dr. Robert R. J. Gallati, a visionary New York City police official who designed the first computerized fingerprint identification system and sketched out many other advanced technological innovations in law enforcement, died on Sunday at a hospital in De Kalb, Ill. A resident of Harbor Heights, Fla., he was 82 and had been living with his daughter in De Kalb.

title: Adelphi Issues Criticisms Of State Case
description: In a passionate defense of its embattled administration, Adelphi University issued a 13-page declaration today, dismissing the State Attorney General's investigation of university spending as a "witch hunt" involving deliberate leaks of information and "outrageous requests."

title: Officials Reallocate Money For Grand Central Homeless
description: Federal housing officials, who last year rescinded a grant to the Grand Central Partnership after it was accused of involvement in beatings of homeless people, have chosen a new recipient for the money -- a competing organization.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Prices for Gold Sharply Higher As Demand Is Outpacing Supply
description: Prices for gold surged to their highest levels in almost six years yesterday amid continued strong demand and shrinking mine output.

title: ART REVIEW;Painterly Drawings Meet Sculptural Drawings, but Which Are Which?
description: People who don't really care for modern art often grumble that pioneering modernists like Picasso and Matisse at least knew how to draw, while more recent artists paint abstractly or use photographs because they couldn't draw a realistic figure if their life depended on it. As if to say, "It ain't so, folks," the New York Studio School (where the curriculum centers on drawing) has organized the exhibition "Caro and Olitski: Masters of Abstraction Draw the Figure."

title: A New AIDS Drug Yielding Optimism As Well as Caution
description: An experimental drug has nearly halved both the death rate from advanced AIDS and the number of serious complications of the disease in a large international study that lasted seven months, the drug's developer reported at a scientific meeting here today.

title: Political Dynasties: A Family Album
description: One outcome of this month's State Assembly race in the South Bronx seems certain: a new political dynasty will be born. One candidate, Pedro Gautier Espada, is the son of State Senator Pedro Espada Jr.; the other, Ruben Diaz Jr., is the son of the Rev. Ruben Diaz, a three-time political candidate. Indeed, politics has always been a family affair in New York City.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Angotti Chosen By PCS Primeco
description: PCS Primeco L.P. -- an alliance of Airtouch Communications, Bell Atlantic, Nynex and U S West that will provide national wireless communications services -- said yesterday that it had named Angotti, Thomas, Hedge in New York as the first agency to handle its account. The billings were estimated at $50 million.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;N.F.L. Shifts: Seahawks Eye Los Angeles
description: There were strong indications out of Seattle yesterday that the Seahawks intend to fill the National Football League void in Los An'eles by playing their 1996 home schedule at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif. Such a move would be the fifth actual or proposed relocation of an N.F.L. team in the last year and would send more shock waves through a league that is battling an image problem regarding franchise stability.

title: Prices in 1995 Up 2.5%, a 5th Subdued Year
description: Signaling that inflation has been vanquished to a degree not seen since the early 1960's, the Labor Department reported today that consumer prices rose only 2.5 percent for all of 1995, the lowest rate in nearly a decade and the fifth consecutive year that inflation held to about 3 percent or less.

title: Mayor Asks Aides for More Cuts in Case Budget Unravels
description: A day after presenting a preliminary $31 billion budget that cuts New York City's spending, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would order his commissioners to cut at least $100 million to $200 million more, giving him a cushion if his budgetary assumptions unravel.

title: Fixed Mortgage Rates Rise
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.02 percent in the current week, up slightly from 7 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today. Fifteen-year mortgages also edged up to 6.52 percent from 6.5 percent. But one-year adjustable mortgage rates were unchanged at 5.37 percent. A year ago, 30-year loans averaged 8.94 percent, 15-year loans 8.59 percent and adjustable loans 6.75 percent.

title: FILM REVIEW;Candidate's Brother's Keeper
description: In "Black Sheep," Chris Farley plays the slobby, embarrassing brother of a gubernatorial candidate (Tim Matheson) in the state of Washington. It takes exactly one sentence for the candidate's adviser to sum up the film's plot: "We have got to keep this bozo under wraps until the election is over."

title: Judge's Reasoning in Drug Case Was Sound;Police as Scapegoat
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Toll Is 73 and Rising In Sri Lankan Bombing
description: Rescuers dug out 13 more bodies today from the charred wreckage of a suicide bomb attack on Wednesday that turned Colombo's business center into a knot of towering fires. The death toll from the blast, linked to Tamil rebels, stood at 73 and was expected to rise.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Overdue Entrance

title: Judge's Reasoning in Drug Case Was Sound;Police as Scapegoat
description: To the Editor:

title: In Lawsuit, Portrait of Agency in Crisis
description: To those familiar with New York City's Child Welfare Administration, the early 1990's were years of wrenching despair over fiscal constraints and tension over competing philosophies about what was best for the city's huge population of foster children.

title: Judge's Reasoning in Drug Case Was Sound
description: To the Editor:

title: Siberian Forest Protects Against Warming
description: To the Editor:

title: Katrina de Hirsch, 93, Expert In Early Learning Disabilities
description: Katrina de Hirsch, a speech therapist who was a pioneer in the field of childhood language and learning disorders, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 93.

title: Nicaragua Student Protests Cloud Pope's Visit
description: Increased protests by university students are generating fears that disturbances could erupt when Pope John Paul II visits Nicaragua next week.

title: Ward Byron, 89, Big-Band Radio Producer
description: Ward Byron, a producer and director of some of the radio programs that featured the Big Band sounds of the 1930's and 40's, died on Sunday at the Sunharbour Manor nursing home in Roslyn, L.I. He was 89 and lived in Riverdale in the Bronx.

title: COMMUNICATIONS RESHAPED: THE BROADCASTERS;The Networks See Potential For Growth
description: Broadcasters walked away from yesterday's passage of the new telecommunications bill well satisfied with its deregulation of several parts of their industry and looking forward to a booming market in television and radio stations.

title: The Spoken Word
description: BLACK ART HISTORY, Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. The first of three weekends of discussion. Tomorrow at 2 P.M., Thierry Chauvaud will speak about contemporary African-American artists. On Sunday at 2 P.M., Lenore Fineberg will discuss African masks; at 3 P.M., Janet Whitaker will talk about the temples and tombs of Egypt. Free with museum admission: $4; $2 for students; $1.50 for the elderly; free for members and children under 12. Information: (718) 638-5000.

title: Judge's Reasoning in Drug Case Was Sound
description: To the Editor:

title: As Gingrich Shifts on Tax Cuts, a New Negotiating Team Seeks to Rescuea Budget Deal
description: In what some in Congress said were signs that a long-term budget deal might not be dead after all, Republicans and Democrats from both House and Senate met for the first time today to try to draft a compromise.

title: As in, You Know, Humor
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFINGS;Suit Filed on Residency Rule
description: Eleven public employee unions filed suit yesterday to block enforcement of a law that requires employees of Essex County to live within its borders. James W. Treffinger, the County Executive, announced last month that a dormant 1978 residency law would be enforced, and he gave more than 600 employees until June to move to Essex County or lose their jobs.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Long Bond Down Ahead Of Refunding
description: The prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday after the modest rises of Wednesday, when the Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates.

title: COMMUNICATIONS RESHAPED: THE DEALS TO COME;For Telephone Companies, Excitement Over New Markets
description: Nowhere has the call for telecommunications competition sounded louder than on Wall Street. As Congress finally passed its landmark communications bill yesterday, telephone companies and their investment bankers began suiting up for a flurry of deals that they said would flow from the wholesale deregulation of the industry.

title: Harsh Talk on Reform by Russian Communist Chief
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The head of Russia's resurgent Communist Party warned Thursday that the pace of economic reform in Russia was "too reckless" and that he would slow it down if he won next June's presidential election and replaced President Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: Clinton Seeks Prayer For Better Attitudes
description: Lamenting rising cynicism, conflict and mistrust, President Clinton today asked a cross-section of Washington leaders to "pray for us to have a more charitable attitude toward one another."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Allied Domecq Stake
description: Allied Domecq P.L.C., a British liquor producer, pub operator and brewer, agreed yesterday to sell its 75 percent stake in the tea company Lyons Irish Holdings P.L.C. to Unilever for 73.1 million Irish pounds ($115 million). Unilever, the British-Dutch food and consumer products company, which makes Lipton tea, agreed to pay 325 Irish pence a share in cash for the stake in Ireland's largest tea processor. Unilever said it would make a cash offer for the 25 percent of the shares Allied Domecq does not own. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Old Paint Under Fire Retardant Fed Blaze
description: Flames from a mattress set ablaze in a stairwell at a Bronx housing project roared upward 11 floors after igniting layers of old paint under newly applied fire-retardant paint, fire officials said yesterday. Although no one was injured, the fire again raised questions about the city's efforts to deal with such blazes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Deregulation Is Passed For Telecommunications Congress voted overwhelmingly to deregulate the nation's communications laws, passing, after four years of struggle and gridlock, a bill that will transform television, telephones and the emerging frontiers of computer networks.

title: Apple-Sun Deal Is Reported to Be Near Collapse Again
description: Apple Computer and Sun Microsystems on Thursday once again came close to merging, but the talks may now collapse in wake of reports today that Apple's chief executive, Michael Spindler, will be replaced with National Semiconductor Corporation's head, Gilbert F. Amelio.

title: U.S. Auto Makers Fear Strength Of Dollar Gives Edge to Japan
description: With rebates spreading and profits threatened, the nation's car makers are now complaining about the strength of the dollar.

title: Diner's Journal
description: You're ordering too much," the waiter keeps protesting. He's right, but we can't help it. Everything sounds so good.

title: Italy Turns to Top Bureaucrat To Try to Remake the Country
description: Italy emerged from a three-week Government crisis today with a surprise choice as Prime Minister-designate and a vague pledge by major political parties to push through difficult constitutional reforms.

title: Robbers Shoot Man in Midtown Gem Heist
description: A jeweler from Hong Kong was critically injured last night when a group of armed men shot him on a bustling stretch of midtown Manhattan in front of the New York Hilton, robbing him and a business partner of nearly $1 million in diamonds before fleeing in a car, the police said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNITED HEALTHCARE TO ACQUIRE HEALTHWISE
description: The United Healthcare Corporation will acquire Healthwise of America Inc. in a stock deal worth about $290 million, the two health maintenance organizations said yesterday. United is offering 0.6475 of a share for each Healthwise share, or a total of 4.6 million United shares. Healthwise's stock rose $2.375, to $39.875 yesterday, in Nasdaq trading. United edged up 37.5 cents, to $63.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shareholders representing about 20 percent of Healthwise's outstanding shares have agreed to vote in favor of the deal. United, which is based in Minneapolis, said the purchase would give it access to managed-care infrastructures in markets that remain largely unpenetrated by H.M.O.'s, including Tennessee, Arkansas, Maryland, Virginia, Kentucky and Washington, D.C.

title: Art in Review
description: Andrea Robbins and Max Becher 'Shrinking People, Exiled Cigars and Galloping Dinosaurs' Basilico Fine Arts 26 Wooster Street, SoHo Through Feb. 10

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;The Losses, Delusions and Terrors of the Lonely
description: CIVILWARLAND IN BAD DECLINE Stories and a Novella By George Saunders 179 pages. Random House. $22.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Gives Back Early Gains As a Key German Rate Isn't Cut
description: The dollar slipped against most leading currencies yesterday, giving back early gains on a day when Germany held its discount rate unchanged and bonds slumped in the United States.

title: WNYC Radio Sale Isn't for City Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: Americans Are Warned in Saudi Arabia
description: Americans in Saudi Arabia have been warned of the threat of terrorist attacks aimed at them, State Department officials said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TORCHMARK MAY DIVIDE INTO SEPARATE COMPANIES
description: The Torchmark Corporation announced a $130 million charge yesterday on its unsuccessful natural-gas unit and said it might divide into separate publicly traded companies. The company, a life and health insurer based in Birmingham, Ala., hired the investment banking firm of Morgan Stanley to advise it about the split. Lee Bartlett, a Torchmark spokesman, would not say into how many parts the company might split. Torchmark said it took a charge of $130 million, or $1.82 a share, for the fourth quarter to dispose of its Black Warrior energy investment, which was supposed to find ways to pull natural gas from coal seams. The charge led to a quarterly loss of $56 million, or 79 cents a share, compared with net income of $64 million, or 89 cents, in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;His Rehabilitation Over, Manning Is Set for Return
description: Forward DANNY MANNING, sidelined for nearly one year with a knee injury, has been activated by the Phoenix Suns and is expected to play tonight at Cleveland.

title: Education Chief Says Impasse Could Hurt Poor Children
description: Education Secretary Richard W. Riley warned yesterday that the continuing deadlock over the Federal budget could result in cuts of more than $1 billion in a program that provides the nation's poorest children with concentrated instruction in reading and mathematics.

title: Judge Extends 'Megan's Law' Prohibition
description: A Federal judge, who previously ruled that "Megan's Law" is unconstitutional, extended a 10-day-old order today barring authorities from notifying neighbors and nearby schools that a man now living in Englewood was found guilty 20 years ago of molesting and killing two boys.

title: Art in Review
description: Neil Winokur Janet Borden Gallery 560 Broadway, at Prince Street SoHo Through Feb. 17

title: Hanoi Takes Aim at West's 'Social Evils'
description: A copy of Paris Match hit the newsstands here recently with the model Naomi Campbell's bare breasts scratched out. Customs officials are confiscating videotapes of prime-time American television shows, and on Wednesday there was a public burning of pornographic videos and magazines.

title: Real Estate;A Paris-based real estate firm that deals in deluxe apartments closes its Manhattan office.
description: THE New York branch of Jean-Marc Levet, a real estate office that opened five years ago and quickly positioned itself as a seller of deluxe apartments, closed its 20-agent Manhattan operation last week.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DELTA RESTORING PAY CUT TO NONUNION WORKERS
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. said yesterday that it was restoring pay to the level before it imposed a 5 percent cut on all nonunion employees. Atlanta-based Delta, which cut its nonunion employee pay by 5 percent three years ago, said it was able to restore the pay because it was profitable and could afford to do so. The airline also said that on Feb. 23 it would pay out a lump sum advance profit-sharing equal to 5 percent of base salary from July 1, 1995, through Jan. 31, 1996. Delta, the nation's third-biggest carrier, cut employee pay in 1993, when the airline was in the middle of a string of losses that totaled nearly $2 billion. Delta's stock was up $1.625, to $70, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Russian Miners Strike, Defying Yeltsin
description: Defying the President they helped bring to power five years ago, nearly half a million Russian coal miners went on strike today to demand $200 million in unpaid wages.

title: HOCKEY;Prize Lures Cigar to New California Series
description: Three California racing classics with purses of $1 million each were joined today into a series with a $2 million bonus for the horse that sweeps all three. And the owner of Cigar promptly said his champion would be the first to try.

title: New Month, Same Forecast, More Snow for Shoveling
description: The second week of January brought the Blizzard of '96, a pitiless wallop that paralyzed the Northeast. February's debut promises to be gentler, but still, in the words of one forecaster, "a mess."

title: Proposal for Safer Bridge
description: Making the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge safer in earthquakes may be so expensive that the state should instead replace the eastern section of the 60-year-old structure, officials say. With an estimate of $1.2 billion for retrofitting the bridge, So officials on Tuesday proposed rebuilding the four-mile span from Yerba Buena Island to Oakland.

title: Microsoft and BET Form Joint Venture
description: The Microsoft Corporation and Black Entertainment Television said today that they were beginning a joint venture that at first would provide entertainment and news for black Americans on the Internet.

title: HOCKEY;Ferraro Enjoys Playing Sizable Role for Rangers
description: Ray Ferraro would love to be able to dunk a basketball. He can't. Not even close. The Rangers' center also would like to be a big guy. He's not. He's barely 5 feet 10 inches and 185 pounds, which makes him almost Lilliputian, even for the National Hockey League.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 1 about Columbia University's fund drive misstated the university's use of its endowment in the early 1990's. Columbia used endowment earnings to pay some operating expenses; it did not dip into the endowment itself. A reader's letter dated Jan. 7, pointing out the error, was delayed in routing at The Times.

title: Bronx Election Pits 2 Families;Outcome Could Establish A New Political Dynasty
description: The two candidates have a striking amount in common. Both are young -- 22 years old -- and pursuing college degrees. Both are politically ambitious. Both have fathers who gained prominence in Hispanic politics in New York City.

title: Chirac Offers a Vision of NATO; Few in Congress Come to Listen
description: President Jacques Chirac of France, speaking to a thinly attended joint meeting of Congress, called today for a more balanced partnership within NATO between the United States and an expanding, stronger Europe.

title: Toys 'R' Us Plans Charge For Global Reorganization
description: In a move intended to shore up sagging profitability, Toys "R" Us Inc. announced yesterday that it was reorganizing its worldwide operations, a plan that included closing 25 stores and paring the array of merchandise it offers to consumers.

title: Home Video
description: Foraging Abroad

title: POLITICS;Buchanan Vows an America-First Policy
description: Battling for third place in New Hampshire's Republican Presidential primary, Patrick J. Buchanan promised an America-first policy today, vowing to make sure the "new world order comes crashing down."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;SFAC of France in Bid For Trade Indemnity
description: Compagnie Financiere SFAC made a cash offer of L177.3 million ($266 million) yesterday for Trade Indemnity Group P.L.C., a British credit insurer. SFAC offered 97 pence for each Trade Indemnity share, about 33 percent above the Wednesday closing price of 73 pence.

title: The Fate of Colombia's Leader
description: This week, in a special session of Congress called by President Ernesto Samper to weigh accusations that he had solicited millions of dollars in drug money for his campaign, many of the politicians who could ultimately impeach him gave Mr. Samper a standing ovation after his opening speech.

title: TV SPORTS;Sorry, Farrah Fawcett. TNT Opts to Show Magic.
description: Magic Johnson's return is enthralling, but it obscures the sacrifices required to watch him dribble like a 22-year-old. When TNT added Tuesday's Lakers-Warriors game to show Johnson's comeback game, it delayed airing "Hannie Caulder," a Raquel Welch-Ernest Borgnine western, then dumped the "Bret Maverick: Lazy Ace" film.

title: THEATER REVIEW;New Life Off Broadway for Soviet Film of the 20's
description: With producers of Broadway musicals in seasonal hibernation, Off Broadway is doing its best to pick up the slack. A case in point: "Bed and Sofa," the oddball, engaging, pocket-size "silent movie opera" that opened last night at the Vineyard Theater.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Aramco in India
description: Aramco of Saudi Arabia is proposing to build a $1.1 billion oil refinery in a northern Indian state with the state-run Indian Oil Corporation, the newspaper The Hindu reported yesterday. If Aramco's proposal is approved by the Indian Government, it will give Indian Oil a near monopoly on oil refining and distribution in northern India, where it already operates two refineries. Although many foreign oil companies have expressed a desire to set up refineries in India, few have presented concrete proposals. (AP)

title: The Neediest Cases;Schoolchildren Count Pennies and Make a Difference
description: For Manhattan children like Michael Feher, 7, and Zachary Kaye, 8, charity begins at home and on their own. Last year, Michael's piggy bank fund grew from $5 to $58, and Zachary saved $54 from his weekly allowance. They both sent the money to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: U.S. Linked To Saudi Aid For Bosnians
description: Saudi Arabia funneled $300 million in weapons to the Muslim-led Government forces in Bosnia with the knowledge and tacit cooperation of the United States, it was reported tonight.

title: Ruling in Favor of a Suspect Puts State Judge Under Fire
description: A week after a political firestorm erupted over a Federal judge's decision to toss out evidence in a multimillion-dollar drug case, top city and state officials assailed a New York State judge yesterday for ruling that evidence in a rape case was illegally collected because the police searched for it at night.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VENTURE STORES TO CUT 390 SALES SUPPORT JOBS
description: Venture Stores Inc., a general merchandise discount chain, said yesterday that it would slash 390 sales support jobs as it transformed itself into a family value department store. The jobs, both part-time and full-time, include selected regional and district administration staff and some back-of-the-store positions, like merchandise receivers and clerks. Venture, based in O'Fallon, Mo., operates 115 stores in 9 states.

title: Teacher Facing Dismissal In Epithet Case
description: A white Queens schoolteacher accused of calling a fifth-grade pupil by a racial epithet is facing dismissal when the local school board in Jamaica meets on Monday.

title: Interleague Fuss Is Minimal
description: Baseball players have not raised serious objections to the idea of interleague play and will most likely approve the experimental plan for 1997, their union leader indicated yesterday.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Usual Suspects 1995. Polygram. $96.99. Laser disk, $39.95. 105 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Restaurants
description: It takes a while for a restaurant to hit its stride. There is no timetable for this; each proceeds at its own pace. It can take a year or two or more before everything comes together in one smooth motion. But when it finally happens, everyone knows it: one step through the door and you can feel the energy running through the room.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Erhardt Dismissed by Steelers
description: Ron Erhardt, the offensive coordinator who apparently differed with Pittsburgh Steelers Coach Bill Cowher over offensive philosophy, will not return next season. Erhardt, rumored to be interested in rejoining Coach Bill Parcells's staff in New England, and the tight ends coach, Pat Hodgson, were told today that their contracts would not be renewed.

title: Judge's Reasoning in Drug Case Was Sound
description: To the Editor:

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;Images of Mexican Life, From Trite to Exuberant
description: The photographs of Lola Alvarez Bravo will probably always be linked to those of her former husband, Manuel. Not only did she learn the technical basics of photography from him, but also her images of Mexico unavoidably bear a surface resemblance to his.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What tasty morsels of insight into the restaurant business one might expect in the autobiography of GEORGE LANG, the owner of Cafe des Artistes on West 67th Street and a co-owner of Gundel's in Budapest.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;U.S. Open Boosts Prizes
description: The United States Open has increased its prize money to almost $10.9 million for this year's tournament, an increase of 10.5 percent.

title: HOCKEY;Devils, Working Overtime, Tie Flames
description: For nearly 57 minutes tonight at the Saddledome, the Devils saw what they hath wrought and wished their Frankenstein monster would go away.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Marketers see gold in the photogenic cast of a huge NBC hit.
description: THE devotion of Damon and Pythias has nothing on the ardor along Madison Avenue to pal around with "Friends."

title: As in, You Know, Humor
description: To the Editor:

title: Winston S. Williams, Reporter, 51
description: Winston S. Williams, a former reporter for The New York Times, died on Wednesday in Norfolk, Va. He was 51 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sri Lanka's Agony
description: Even by the coarsened standards of our age, Wednesday's terror bombing in Sri Lanka evokes a peculiar horror. At least 73 people were killed and 1,400 wounded after a truck crammed with explosives plowed into the Central Bank in downtown Colombo, the capital. It is hard for any civilized society to defend itself against such an assault carried out by a suicide bomber. But it is harder still to understand how a political movement claiming to speak for lofty ideals could sanction such a bloodletting.

title: POLITICS: FINANCES;In Money, Dole Has Big Lead
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas began 1996 with $4.4 million to spend in the crucial weeks before the first Presidential primaries, nearly four times the money of Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, whose fund raising continued to drop off at the end of 1995, according to reports released today.

title: WNYC Radio Sale Isn't for City Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Trade Deficit Narrows in Britain
description: Britain's trade deficit narrowed in November to its lowest level in eight months, the Government said yesterday. More recent data suggested that manufacturing remained sluggish but new orders were picking up. The global trade deficit was L567 million ($855 million) in November, the lowest figure since March 1995, the Central Statistical Office said. The October shortfall was L1.63 billion.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Line of Strong Women With Faith in Destiny
description: Antonia's Line," the Netherlands' official candidate for this year's best foreign-language film Oscar, unfolds as a work of magical feminism. With the tone of a fable and the lulling bucolic look of a pastoral fantasy, it tells of one strong woman and her talented descendants, all blessed with self-sufficiency and remarkably little need for men in their lives. Indeed, the fact that the sturdy, formidable Antonia (Willeke van Ammelrooy) perpetuates her bloodline at all becomes one of the film's more fanciful little miracles.

title: Judge's Reasoning in Drug Case Was Sound
description: To the Editor:

title: At Prosecutors' Prodding, Laborers' Union Opens Up Elections
description: The Laborers International Union of North America, which has long had ties to organized crime, will hold democratic elections for top leadership posts for the first time, under an agreement announced today by the Justice Department.

title: COMMUNICATIONS RESHAPED: THE OVERHAUL;CONGRESS VOTES TO RESHAPE COMMUNICATIONS INDUSTRY, ENDING A 4-YEAR STRUGGLE
description: After four years of struggle and gridlock, Congress rewrote the nation's communications laws today, passing a bill that would transform television, telephones and the emerging frontiers of cyberspace.

title: Closing AIDS Trials Is Shortsighted
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;An Amateur Starts to Sound Like a Pro
description: Like a rock star or a veteran politician, Steve Forbes was running a bit late today, keeping a patient audience in this solidly Republican farming community waiting. When he finally made it to the Atlantic Meeting Center here, he shook a few hands, moved to the microphones, but did not immediately plunge into his flat-tax stump speech.

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. SATELLITE BROADCASTING'S STOCK GAINS
description: The stock of the U.S. Satellite Broadcasting Corporation rose strongly yesterday in its first day of trading after the company, a direct-broadcast TV concern, offered 8.3 million shares to the public. Initially priced at $27, the shares closed at $34.75 after 6.8 million were traded on the Nasdaq market. U.S. Satellite Broadcasting came to market just after the AT&T Corporation and the MCI Communications Corporation had marked satellites as the preferred method for information delivery in the future. U.S. Satellite Broadcasting has 14 movie channels and 6 channels of basic service. It had 628,000 subscribers at the end of 1995. Revenues is running at $182 million a year, and the company has posted losses since it was formed in 1993.

title: COMPANY NEWS;INTEL REDUCING PRICES ON ITS PENTIUM PROCESSORS
description: The Intel Corporation said yesterday that it was cutting prices on its Pentium and Pentium Pro processors by as much as 38 percent. Intel, in a quarterly announcement, said it had cut Pentium prices by 16 percent to 38 percent. Prices for Pentium Pro, successor to the Pentium chips and Intel's top-of-the-line product, were cut 15 percent to 23 percent. The prices are based on purchases of 1,000-unit lots. Intel traditionally cuts prices at the beginning of the second month of each quarter. A 100-megahertz chip, which was the most popular processor in consumer machines in the holiday season, was cut by 34 percent, to $198 from $300.

title: Where Midtown Pipes Ruptured, Traffic Headaches Will Linger
description: Life returned mostly to normal yesterday near the sites of two major breakdowns in mid-Manhattan's subterranean infrastructure. Still, city officials warned that repairs at both sites would likely last two weeks, causing continuing traffic disruptions.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Jan. 18 about Dr. Ernst T. Morch, an anesthesiologist who worked with the Danish resistance in World War II, misstated the date of his death. It was Dec. 13, not Jan. 13.

title: Progress Reported on Test To Detect Bladder Cancer
description: Scientists said today that they were making significant progress in developing a simple urine test to diagnose bladder cancer, a deadly tumor that can be effectively treated if caught early.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Longley on Injured List
description: The Chicago Bulls put center LUC LONGLEY on the injured list yesterday with a ligament sprain in his left knee. He is expected to return in two weeks. The 7-foot-2-inch Longley had started 41 games for the Bulls this season, averaging 8.8 points and 5 rebounds in 26.6 minutes per game. The Bulls activated center James Edwards from the injured list to take Longley's place. (AP)

title: TRACK AND FIELD;Bailey's Sprinting Speaks Volumes
description: In the world of elite sprinters, where trash talk has become an art form, Donovan Bailey ranks last in psychological gabbing and first at the finish.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DISCOVERY ZONE MAY FILE FOR CHAPTER 11
description: Discovery Zone Inc., the cash-short operator of children's indoor entertainment facilities, said yesterday that it might have to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection to meet its cash requirements. The company said that it needed to increase its credit line significantly but that it might not be able to renegotiate credit terms because of a disappointing January performance. Discovery Zone said it probably would not be able to generate sufficient cash flows from operations to remain viable in the long term. Discovery Zone's stock lost more than half its value yesterday, dropping $1.875, to $1.125, in Nasdaq trading. The company, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., is 49 percent-owned by Viacom Inc.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RONALD WINSTON, the president and chief executive of Harry Winston jewelers, has said farewell to one of his favorite possessions, the fabled movie statue of the Maltese Falcon. But he said his loss was tempered by the price he received for the lead icon, which he bought at auction in 1994 for $398,500.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TYCO UNIT BUYS PROFESSIONAL MEDICAL PRODUCTS
description: Tyco International Ltd. said yesterday that its Kendall Health Care Products unit had acquired Professional Medical Products Inc. of Greenwood, S.C. The terms were not disclosed. Professional Medical, which has annual sales of $150 million, makes adult-incontinence products and other disposable medical products. The company has manufacturing plants in Greenwood; Ocala, Fla., and Juarez, Mexico. Tyco makes disposable medical products, packaging materials, flow control products and electrical components. The company has annual revenue of more than $4.5 billion.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies yesterday about legislation to protect information obtained in genetic screenings by employers or insurance companies misstated the party affiliation of State Senator Jack Sinagra, who proposed it. He is a Republican.

title: INSIDE
description: Inflation Held in Check

title: Full Disclosure
description: I find it odd that, in articles about Whitewater, Hillary Rodham Clinton is depicted as a secretive, dissembling dragon lady who loathes the media. That's not the person I covered and knew for a decade.

title: Full Disclosure
description: I find it odd that, in articles about Whitewater, Hillary Rodham Clinton is depicted as a secretive, dissembling dragon lady who loathes the media. That's not the person I covered and knew for a decade.

title: Sports of The Times;This League Is Chock Full Of Griffeys
description: LAST Sunday, the National Basketball Association gave all but two teams the day off, so the players could join the rest of the nation in hunkering down with the snacks and the drinks and the betting slips and the blaring commercials and the yammering commentators and the lugs in helmets.

title: Fearing Terrorism, U.S. Plans to Press Sudan
description: Convinced that the Sudan is moving rapidly to the top of a list of rogue nations harboring international terrorists, the Administration plans to increase pressure on the Sudan through the United Nations, while effectively closing the American Embassy in Khartoum, officials said today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFINGS;Truck Chase Ends in Crash
description: The driver of a stolen truck led State Police troopers on a two-hour chase along local roadways and reportedly rammed a marked police car several times before crashing into a guardrail yesterday morning, the police said. They identified the driver as Edward J. Dunne, 28, who was hospitalized after the crash and faces charges including aggravated assault and vehicle theft.

title: Japan Stocks Lower
description: Japanese stocks traded lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 31.09 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to 20,904.03. On Thursday, the Nikkei closed up 122.38 points.

title: Envoy Denies He'll Soon Leave
description: The United States Ambassador to the Vatican, Raymond L. Flynn, yesterday denied reports that he was on the verge of stepping down from his post, but expressed his readiness to move on to another job.

title: A Swerve To the Right In California
description: Barely a month after the State Assembly's Republicans, already in the majority for a year, gained real control of the chamber by finally uniting to elect a Republican Speaker, party leaders have begun to push through an ambitious conservative agenda that could bring profound change to California.

title: INSURERS FIGHTING A BIPARTISAN BILL FOR HEALTH CARE
description: The health insurance industry, which helped kill President Clinton's ambitious health care proposal in 1994, said today that it objected to a provision of a much more modest bipartisan bill to guarantee coverage for people leaving employer-sponsored health plans.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Mariners Sign Two
description: The Seattle Mariners had a little left over after they signed KEN GRIFFEY JR. to baseball's richest contract, so yesterday they signed two free agents, outfielder LUIS POLONIA and relief pitcher MIKE JACKSON.

title: Judge's Reasoning in Drug Case Was Sound;Police as Scapegoat
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Mark Dion American Fine Arts 22 Wooster Street, SoHo Through Feb. 10

title: POLITICS: THE LEAD;Dole Backers See Fight in New Hampshire
description: Leading supporters of Senator Bob Dole portrayed his campaign today as faltering and said they feared that he could no longer count on New Hampshire as an inevitable stepping stone toward the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Bills Would Repeal Provision To Expel Troops With H.I.V.
description: A bipartisan effort is under way in the House and Senate to repeal a provision in a military budget bill that would force the Pentagon to discharge troops who have the virus that causes AIDS.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFINGS;Environmental Votes Tallied
description: The New Jersey Environmental Federation yesterday handed out its 1995 report card grading the state's 13 Congressional members on 16 votes that environmentalists considered critical. Rep. Donald M. Payne, a Newark Democrat, received 100 percent. Next were Democratic Representatives Robert Torricelli of Englewood and Frank Pallone Jr. of Long Branch, both receiving 94 percent. The highest-graded Republican was Rep. Marge Roukema of Ridgewood, at 69 percent. Rep. Rodney P. Frelinghuysen, a Republican from Harding, scored lowest, at 13 percent.

title: Broadway's Anonymous Stars
description: THEY have no entourages, no bodyguards, no marquee billing. They are headliners who make no headlines, household names who are known chiefly in their own households. When they walk the streets, no autograph hounds seek them out. When they go to work, it's not by limousine, but on the IRT.

title: 3 Boys Used Internet to Plot School Bombing, Police Say
description: Three 13-year-old boys from the Syracuse area have been charged with plotting to set off a homemade bomb in their junior high school after getting plans for the device on the Internet.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFINGS;Judge Weighs Shelter Protest
description: A battered women's program wants a court to stop Nicholas Jutchenko from picketing one of its shelters, where his wife is staying, arguing that demonstrations should be allowed only at the program's Morristown office. Mr. Jutchenko contends that the shelter failed to provide adequate supervision for his 13-year-old son, who died in a nearby apartment fire last October while living with his mother at the shelter. Jan L. Bernstein, a lawyer for Jersey Battered Women's Services said that allowing picketing by a aggrieved husband would undermine the program's ability to protect its clients. A judge is expected to rule on the issue next week.

title: POLITICS: IN THE PACK;Lugar Struggles to Revive Campaign
description: The small group of voters gathered in the library of the local high school listened respectfully but seemingly without great enthusiasm as Senator Richard G. Lugar outlined his views on a tax overhaul, gun control, illegal immigration and abortion. But when the subject changed to agriculture, things perked up.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFINGS;School Tries to Curb Tensions
description: After several fights recently between African-American and Dominican students at Paterson's John F. Kennedy High School, officials at the 2,171-student school have begun a conflict resolution program. "There's been tension for some time," said Joy Anne Friedman, a spokeswoman for the state-controlled school district. "It's a problem that exists in the community and it's spilling over into the schools. We're training students to teach other students how to resolve their differences peacefully."

title: GOLF;Leonard: Young, Confident and Atop the Leader Board
description: While it usually is true that there are lies, damned lies and statistics, here is one stat that is gaining credence with each passing week: Justin Leonard leads the PGA Tour statistics in the all-around category, and he is building a strong case that his really is a golf game with no apparent weaknesses.

title: Abroad at Home;Less Is More
description: A rich man campaigns for President on a one-plank platform: "Vote for me to cut my taxes drastically and make many of you pay more." The voters respond with enthusiasm.

title: Sprint Parcels Out Wireless Business
description: The Sprint Corporation said today that its wireless telecommunications venture had awarded contracts to an AT&T unit and BCE's Northern Telecom Ltd. to supply Code Division Multiple Access, known as C.D.M.A., personal communications equipment for its wireless network.

title: On My Mind;The Words Not Spoken
description: The Secretary of State worked hard polishing the speech. He wanted it to be his best, to sum up his vision of America's place in the world, particularly Asia.

title: Stocks Continue Climbing, With Dow Topping 5,400
description: Stock prices rose yet again yesterday, crossing another milestone in response to the Federal Reserve's cut in short-term interest rates on Wednesday.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Accountants' Union Asks for a New Vote
description: Provoking a fight within New York's largest municipal employees' union, the local representing city accountants is asking that its members be allowed to conduct a new vote because many suspect that officials from the parent union manipulated the results of their mail-in balloting.

title: BASKETS;This Time, Temple Routed By a Top-Ranked Team
description: A game that was going to be a challenge for mighty Massachusetts, perhaps even a hurdle for the No. 1 team in the land, turned out to be nothing of the kind tonight at Temple's McGonigle Hall.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Rooker Runs for House
description: The former Pittsburgh Pirates pitcher JIM ROOKER has announced plans to seek the Republican nomination for the Fourth Congressional District of Pennsylvania, a seat currently held by a Democrat, RON KLINK. Rooker, 53, said he will enter the Republican primary in April. (AP)

title: FILM REVIEW;Serb Is Romeo, a Croat Juliet
description: Boro Draskovic's devastating antiwar film, "Vukovar," moves so swiftly from scenes of joy into the pits of hell that watching it feels a little like being pushed off a cliff and discovering that there is no bottom. As the film opens, the people of Vukovar, a Croatian town of 50,000 on the Serbian border, deliriously unite to celebrate the fall of Communism. Amid the euphoria, Anna (Mirjana Jokovic), a Croatian woman, marries her Serbian lover Toma (Boris Isakovic), with the blessings of both their families. But the newlyweds have barely enough time to paint their house before their idyll is shattered.

title: Inside Art
description: Truce at Dia Center Breaks Down

title: Art in Review
description: Josef Albers 'Works on Paper' Andre Emmerich Gallery 41 East 57th Street Through Feb. 17

title: Global Alliance in Telecommunications
description: The Sprint Corporation, Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom have completed a deal worth up to $3.7 billion to form a new global telecommunications alliance dubbed Global One.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bundesbank Lowers Chief Money Market Rate
description: The Bundesbank lowered its chief money market rate yesterday while leaving its discount and Lombard rates unchanged. The central bank said it would offer banks securities repurchases at 3.30 percent for the next two weeks, cutting the repo rate, which sets a target for overnight lending in Germany, from 3.40 percent this week.

title: Casino Bid Withdrawn
description: The Casino Resource Corporation has withdrawn its $12 million bid to acquire the Palace Casino here, citing unacceptable financing terms. In November, a bankruptcy court in Mississippi approved Casino Resource's purchase of the Palace Casino from Maritime Group Ltd., a unit of Palace Casinos Inc. The casino has been operating under bankruptcy protection since December 1994.

title: Judge's Reasoning in Drug Case Was Sound
description: To the Editor:

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Starks Plays It Smart Coming Off Bench
description: Cameras, notepads and microphones surrounded John Starks in the Knicks' locker room last night. For the first time all season, Starks wasn't in the starting lineup. And though the Knicks won, the curious wanted to know how Starks would react.

title: Montana Journal;Where the Wind-Chill Has Been -90
description: When bitter cold creeps down from Canada and envelops Montana and the rest of the Northern Tier for days at a time, life is not necessarily brought to a halt, but it does change.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Truman 1995. HBO. $94.32. Laser disk, $34.98. 130 minutes. Closed captioned. 130 minutes. R.

title: Closing AIDS Trials Is Shortsighted
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Harper's Shares Electronic Profits With Authors
description: Harper's Magazine yesterday became the first publication to begin sharing its profits from electronic publishing with writers.

title: Johannesburg Journal;Hot Soccer Welds a Land Together
description: In the first month of 1996 in South Africa, a four-year drought has been declared over, Luciano Pavarotti and Louis Farrakhan have come and gone, there was a massacre of job seekers outside a factory and the Truth Commission geared up to investigate years of crimes committed in the name of apartheid.

title: Art in Review
description: Peter Campus Paula Cooper Gallery 155 Wooster Street, SoHo Through Feb. 17

title: Advocates of Gun Control Fear Results of a Trade Agreement With Russia
description: Next week's negotiations that could lift cold war trade restrictions on Russian firearms have angered some gun-control advocates in Congress, who say the deal could allow importers to flood the American market with millions of inexpensive Russian handguns and rifles.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-7

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: In America;Presumed To Be Guilty
description: Ira Glasser of the American Civil Liberties Union tells the story of a black couple who, some years ago, went to a movie in Times Square. When they came out of the theater around 11 P.M. it was raining, so the husband went alone to get their car, which was parked in a garage a few blocks away. When he returned to pick up his wife, she was gone.

title: Market Place;Kmart defies doomsayers with a turnaround plan that includes a management shake-up.
description: FOR months, Wall Street has been waiting at the end of the Kmart Corporation's bed with a coffin. But the discount chain just would not die.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: FILM REVIEW;Case of the Suave Creep Vs. the Feisty Mom
description: Making a welcome return to the 20th century, Demi Moore takes on the title role in "The Juror," about a woman named Annie Laird who is empaneled in a murder case involving a powerful mobster. The defendant's gangland friends would like to see him go free, so a suave Mafia hood called the Teacher (Alec Baldwin) undertakes the job of intimidating Annie.

title: Toyota Plans Kentucky Site
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation will centralize supervision of its North American manufacturing operations at a new site in northern Kentucky, company and state officials said today.

title: COMMUNICATIONS RESHAPED: A 'DIGITAL FREE-FOR-ALL';A Measure's Long Reach
description: Even the politicians who wrote the communications law stumble as they try to explain just what it will actually do, reverting to cliches about the "information superhighway" and the 21st century.

title: French Team Kills a Sniper In Bosnia
description: In the first combat fatality involving the NATO peacekeeping force now on the ground in Bosnia, NATO said that one of its French anti-sniper teams fired on two gunmen in a Sarajevo suburb tonight, killing one and capturing the other.

title: BASKETBALL;Eley Promoted by Nuggets
description: Todd Eley was promoted from assistant general manager to general manager of the Denver Nuggets, the team president and head coach, Bernie Bickerstaff, announced today. The Nuggets have been without a general manager since the start of the season, although Eley has been serving in that capacity.

title: Bomb Scars Are Visible At Oklahoma Hearing
description: In a windowless, heavily guarded Federal courtroom here, lawyers finished presenting evidence today on a defense motion to change the location of the trial of two men accused of bombing the Federal Building, which until last April 19 stood in one piece across the street.

title: Train With Chemicals Derails And Explodes in California
description: A freight train carrying hazardous chemicals derailed today in a mountain pass 10 miles north of here, killing two crew members, erupting in flames and closing the main highway between Los Angeles and Las Vegas, Nev.

title: THEATER REVIEW;True Confessions of an All-American Who Turned Sex Addict
description: Colin Martin's emotionally charged erotic memoir, "Virgins and Other Myths," pushes the boundaries of solo performance in ways that deliberately confuse confessional autobiography, the vocabulary of recovery, locker-room boastfulness and male striptease. Where performers like Tim Miller, David Drake and Dan Butler have used the format of the solo monologue to explore gay political issues, "Virgins and Other Myths" is overwhelmingly devoted to the libido in its more devouring aspect.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Rangers To Honor Ryan
description: NOLAN RYAN, who ran up some impressive numbers in a quarter century of pitching, will have another number retired. The Texas Rangers announced yesterday that they will retire Ryan's No. 34 in September, making him the first player in team history to receive that distinction.

title: Closing AIDS Trials Is Shortsighted
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about support from business executives for the candidacy of Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker, for the vice chairmanship of the Federal Reserve misspelled the surname of one executive, the chairman of Pfizer Inc. He is William C. Steere Jr., not Stier.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MONSANTO AND DEKALB GENETICS IN JOINT VENTURE
description: The Monsanto Company and the DeKalb Genetics Corporation said yesterday that they had joined forces in agricultural biotechnology. As part of the deal, Monsanto will invest nearly $160 million to take a significant minority stake in DeKalb, the second-largest company in the North American seed corn market. Monsanto will also pay DeKalb $19.5 million for a 10-year collaboration, which will concentrate on corn and soybeans. The agreement also covers other crops, including sorghum, wheat, oilseeds and produce. DeKalb's shares gained $4, to $63.25, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Monsanto advanced $1.125, to $131.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LOMAK PETROLEUM INC., Fort Worth, an independent oil and gas production and development company, agreed to buy three oil and gas properties in Texas and the Appalachian region for about $17.5 million.

title: Lawyers Seek Testimony Of President
description: One of President Clinton's former Whitewater partners asked a Federal judge today to compel Mr. Clinton to testify as a defense witness at her upcoming fraud trial.

title: Jury Acquits Youth in Death Of an Officer
description: A day after his brother was convicted of murder in the killing of a New York City police officer, a Brooklyn teen-ager was acquitted of the same charge yesterday by a separate jury, even though the evidence against them was largely the same.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFINGS;Rug Smuggling Is Admitted
description: A Iranian rug merchant admitted in Federal court yesterday to smuggling a truckload of Persian carpets, worth more than $1 million, into the United States from Canada, authorities said. The carpets, made in Iran, were driven to a storage building in Secaucus, where they were seized by U.S. customs agents. It is illegal to import Iranian goods under a 1987 law. The merchant, Abrahim Aberkar, 43, an Iranian citizen who lives in Illinois, faces a maximum of five years in prison.

title: Judge's Reasoning in Drug Case Was Sound
description: To the Editor:

title: Closing AIDS Trials Is Shortsighted
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York;Still All Girls, Still Teaching Self-Reliance
description: THE fetal shark lay split open on the dissecting tray, like a clay toy steeped in formaldehyde. A nearby index card read: "What Sex Am I?"

title: Larry Grenier, 46; Danced for Tharp, Feld and the Joffrey
description: Larry A. Grenier Jr., a dancer who performed with the Joffrey Ballet, Eliot Feld and Twyla Tharp, died on Wednesday at the Maitri AIDS Hospice in San Francisco. He was 46 and lived in San Francisco.

title: Pratt & Whitney Buyout
description: About 160 Pratt & Whitney workers have accepted an early-retirement package, leaving the company short of its buyout goal. Pratt, which makes jet engines, is a subsidiary of the United Technologies Corporation. It had expected 200 workers to take the offer, which was included in the new labor contract with the International Association of Machinists. The union estimated that 900 workers were eligible. Pratt, which has already eliminated thousands of jobs, has endured a five-year slump in production. The company has said it expects business to improve late next year.

title: How Fed Made Decision To Cut Rates in December
description: Federal Reserve policy makers listed the possibility of an economic slowdown and low inflation as reasons for their decision in December to reduce a key interest rate, minutes of their meeting showed today.

title: Antagonistic Allies From O.J. Trial Are Allies No Longer
description: F. Lee Bailey and Robert L. Shapiro, O. J. Simpson's feuding lawyers, appeared in court today on opposite sides in a case in which Federal prosecutors accuse Mr. Bailey of trying to keep $20 million in stock that one of his clients should have forfeited to the Government.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BIG FLOWER TO BUY WEBCRAFT FOR $107 MILLION
description: Big Flower Press Holdings Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Webcraft Technologies Inc., a privately owned direct mail marketing company, for $107 million in cash and the assumption of $90 million in debt. Big Flower, a producer and marketer of advertising circulars, newspaper TV listing guides and Sunday comics, had sales of $972 million in 1995. Webcraft focuses on specialty printing markets, including direct mail, fragrance samplers, promotional games and stamps, and lottery tickets. Its sales were $293 million in 1995.

title: BITTER COLD LOCKS MUCH OF THE U.S. IN A FIERCE GRIP
description: Wicked winds, dangerous cold and misery continued to strangle much of the nation today from the heartland to the Deep South, closing schools, threatening crops, plunging neighborhoods into darkness and making the insurance industry shiver and shake as hundreds of thousands of damage claims continued to pour in from two earlier winter storms.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Liberties With 'Gulliver': More Plot, Less Satire
description: In what is certain to be the year's most unexpected mating in prime time, Ted Danson takes on Jonathan Swift tomorrow and Monday on NBC. The bartending Lothario of "Cheers" meets the "mad dean" (1667-1745) who remains the greatest satirist in English literature. The occasion is an extraordinarily handsome two-part adaptation of Swift's "Gulliver's Travels" with Mr. Danson in the title role. Defying awesome odds, the collaboration is solidly successful.

title: Mattel Ends Bid to Merge With Hasbro
description: Mattel Inc. yesterday withdrew a $5.2 billion offer to merge with the rival toy maker Hasbro Inc., saying that Hasbro's "unbending stance" against the deal had made it impossible to complete the transaction in a timely and friendly manner.

title: World News Briefs;Conservatives in Turkey Fail to Form Government
description: Turkey's conservative parties failed in their longstanding effort to form a coalition today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Apple Computer Dismissess Spindler; Names Amelio Apple Computer dismissed Michael H. Spindler as president and chief executive and replaced him with Gilbert F. Amelio, a board member, who will become chairman and chief executive of the struggling company.

title: Bridge
description: Those who follow the law, which calls for a combination of technical knowledge, human understanding and quick thinking, are often attracted to bridge, which has similar requirements. Justice Henry Hudson of Watertown, N.Y., who served on the New York State Supreme Court for 25 years and was previously Mayor of his hometown, was still playing bridge enthusiastically when he died in October at age 90.

title: COMPANY NEWS;IOMEGA SHARES FALL AFTER OFFERING PLANS ARE CHANGED
description: Generally shares go up after a company announces it will delay or cancel a stock offering, but the Iomega Corporation's stock sank 15 percent yesterday on the news that the company was postponing its planned offering. Iomega, a maker of computer disk drives, said on Thursday that it was putting its offering of 5.25 million common shares on hold. The company cited confusion in the marketplace and volatility in its stock price. Iomega shares have seesawed since the company announced the offering on Dec. 14 as rumors spread that company's earnings were below estimates. More questions were raised by reports that Iomega had made its fourth-quarter earnings look better through accounting maneuvers. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Iomega closed at $13, down $2.375.

title: World News Briefs;Cambodia Forces Attack Major Khmer Rouge Base
description: Thousands of Government troops, backed by tanks and helicopters, launched an attack today on Khmer Rouge forces guarding the guerrilla group's main base.

title: Raised Hackles Over a Phone Plan
description: The battle is pitting town against town, neighbor against neighbor. It even threatens to divide parents from their children: Someday, even though they live in the same house, they may have telephone numbers with separate area codes.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.F.L.;Cards' Centers Out of Pro Bowl
description: Arizona Cardinals fullback LARRY CENTERS has been removed from the National Football Conference lineup for the Pro Bowl. Illness was listed as the reason for removing Centers from what would have been his first Pro Bowl. Atlanta's CRAIG HEYWARD will take his place.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies yesterday about a student at William Annin Middle School in Bernards Township who has challenged the school's policy banning backpacks misstated the ruling of a state administrative law judge in the case. The judge denied the school board's request that he order the student to conform to the ban until the dispute is resolved at a later hearing; he did not uphold the ban.

title: THE BOSNIA ACCORD: IN SARAJEVO;Across a Balkan Bridge, the Barriers of Hate and Suspicion Linger
description: Guarding his post on the Brotherhood and Unity bridge, Sinisa Jovic, a Bosnian Serb policeman, had a message for his best friend, a Muslim in the part of the city the Bosnian Serbs had shelled and besieged.

title: Sports of The Times;An Assist That Lasts Forever
description: THE transaction was hardly headline news. In a blizzard of pre-Super Bowl hype nine days ago, the New York Mets announced that the team had traded Damon Buford to the Texas Rangers for a young minor league outfielder.

title: HORSE RACING;Streak Grows to 13, or Does It?
description: Frank Passero Jr., the king of the claimers, won three more races at Gulfstream Park today and extended his record as a trainer to 13 winners in a row. But he also ran third with the second half of an entry in one race, opening a war of semantics over whether he actually had come to the end of a memorable 10-day roll at the races.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PENTAGON CANCELS HUNTER AIRCRAFT PRODUCED BY TRW
description: The Hunter unmanned surveillance aircraft, produced by TRW Inc. and Israel Aircraft Industries , has been canceled, the Pentagon said today. The entire Hunter program, including development and production, was expected to cost $4 billion. The Pentagon will end up spending about $667 million. TRW's Avionics and Surveillance unit in San Diego makes the Hunter. A spokesman, Bob Such, said the decision will have no effect on the unit's work force.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Jan. 26 about an exhibition at the New-York Historical Society focusing on New York City murders misstated the given name of the victim in a celebrated 19th-century murder at a brothel. She was Helen Jewett, not Sarah.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Boy Is Killed by Train
description: A Saddlebrook teen-ager was struck and killed by a New Jersey Transit train last night, a spokeswoman for New Jersey Transit said.

title: Soldiers in Article on Neo-Nazis Knew Accused Killers
description: Army officials said today that four soldiers from Fort Bragg, N.C., who posed under a Nazi flag for a magazine photographer on Sunday had been identified weeks before by base investigators as neo-Nazi skinheads and that all four had ties with two skinheads from the same division who are charged with killing a black couple from Fayetteville, N.C., in early December.

title: Civic Leader Is Sentenced In Chinatown Gang Crimes
description: Sobbing and begging for leniency as relatives and supporters wept with him, one of Chinatown's most prominent figures was sentenced to 10 years in prison yesterday for murder-conspiracy and racketeering by a judge who said that a "superficial veneer of respectability" had disguised his second career as a gangster.

title: Queens Shelter Is Ordered To Remain Open All Day
description: A State Supreme Court judge ordered New York City yesterday to open a homeless shelter in Flushing, Queens, around the clock for the next three weeks.

title: Cleansing 'Triumphant Portal' Ceiling
description: The keepers of Grand Central Terminal are betting that what was good enough for the Sistine Chapel will be good enough for the 83-year-old train station.

title: Alabama Businesses and Trial Lawyers Fight to Deadlock on Jury Awards
description: When a Birmingham jury awarded Dr. Ira Gore $4 million in punitive damages last year because BMW neglected to tell him it had touched up the paint on his new car, many here said the fate of Alabama's notorious civil justice system had been sealed.

title: HIGH SCHOOL REPORT
description: Basketball Tripleheader

title: Youth Unhappy as 'Filler' in Police Lineup
description: Fifteen-year-old Shaka King says he was walking on Broadway at 96th Street last month when two police detectives ordered him into their car, drove him to the 24th Precinct station house and held him there for more than three hours.

title: Martin Kessler, 66, Publisher of Noted Books, Dies
description: Martin Kessler, a New York publisher of influential books about contemporary social history, public policy and economics, died on Thursday at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 66.

title: Siebert Goes Public by an Unusual Route
description: Muriel Siebert, the first woman to become a member of the New York Stock Exchange, is taking her discount brokerage firm public in an unusual way.

title: Junk Rating For Kmart Debt
description: The ratings on $6.8 billion of the debt of the Kmart Corporation were cut to junk status yesterday by Moody's Investors Service because of the company's weakened financial flexibility and the difficult business conditions confronting almost all retailers.

title: Yoshihiro Tokugawa, 89, Aide to Hirohito
description: The man who served as Emperor Hirohito's closest personal aide for more than half a century, Yoshihiro Tokugawa, died today of respiratory failure. He was 89.

title: Tug-of-War Over Where to Hold Bomb Trial
description: Lawyers for the defendants in the Oklahoma City bombing case urged a Federal judge today to protect their clients' right to a jury free from prejudice, by moving the trial out of state. But prosecutors asked the judge to consider the difficulties that survivors and relatives of the victims would face by having to leave Oklahoma.

title: Campaign Briefs;Buchanan and Keyes Press Social Issues
description: Iowans who support Patrick J. Buchanan or Alan Keyes for the Republican Presidential nomination have varying priorities: fierce opposition to abortion, worries about one-world government, anxiety about working-class incomes. But, unlike the quieter crowds turned out by other candidates, they share a tendency to call out "That's right!" or "Amen!" -- and a fear that the front-runners are somehow missing the point.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Enjoying Their New Heights
description: After three days in Vail earlier in the week, coping with shortness of breath from the high altitude, you couldn't blame the Rangers if they weren't all that anxious to return to Colorado for Saturday afternoon's game against the Colorado Avalanche.

title: Investor Cuts Stakes in 2 Wall St. Firms
description: Michael Price, who last year took prominent stakes in several financial companies, has sharply reduced his holdings in two top brokerage firms.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Evocations Of Workers, Machinery And Unions
description: The Everett Dance Theater, seven dancers, actors, film makers and circus performers based in Providence, R.I., has developed a potent, specialized brand of dance and theater over its 10 years of existence. Company members do exhaustive research into cultural history and issues, then sift the data into mixed media work that can be appreciated on a number of levels.

title: Snag Is Cleared In Rail Deal
description: The Union Pacific Corporation signed an agreement this week that would end the Illinois Central Corporation's opposition to its proposed $5.4 billion acquisition of the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation.

title: N.Y.P.D. Size and Skills Make Cutback Bearable
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Awards Herbert Haft $10.2 Million
description: A Washington jury awarded Herbert H. Haft $10.2 million in damages yesterday in a dispute with his son Ronald Haft and Donald Bourassa over the management of Combined Properties Inc., a privately held real estate concern that owns 27 shopping centers controlled by Ronald Haft.

title: Bankrupt Merry-Go-Round Decides to Go Out of Business
description: Merry-Go-Round Enterprises, a retailer that clothed America's teen-agers for more than two decades, announced yesterday that it would liquidate all of its 536 stores and cease operations.

title: BASKETBALL;The Nets Stay Awake Long Enough to Win
description: Nowhere outside of a convention of narcoleptics have so many people fallen asleep so quickly. And tonight's lethargic game between the Nets and Vancouver Grizzlies seemed to even bore the partic'pants, as the Nets, after going up by as many as 13 points, had to stifle their yawns and hold off a fourth-quarter rally by the Grizzlies before emerging with a 93-84 victory at G.M. Place.

title: Religious and Rights Groups Back Abortion Clinic's Case
description: More than 50 groups have filed legal briefs in support of a Long Island abortion clinic that is facing eviction because it was the target of anti-abortion violence.

title: Olestra? Quelle Horreur!
description: The announcement that the Food and Drug Administration had approved olestra, a fat substitute, provoked great fanfare in the United States. And the manufacturer, Procter & Gamble, is seeking approval in Britain and Canada, too.

title: Judicial 'Sensitivity' Training Is Well Under Way
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;FIRST BANK EMPLOYEES TO SHARE IN A CASH WINDFALL
description: First Bank System Inc. said yesterday that its employees would share $11 million of a $200 million cash windfall from its unsuccessful fight to buy First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles. John Grundhofer, chief executive of the bank, told full-time employees they would receive $750 each and part-timers would get less. They will get the payments on Feb. 15. The bank was the "white knight" in First Interstate's attempt to resist a hostile takeover bid from Wells Fargo of San Francisco, but in the end First Interstate accepted a $11.6 billion Wells offer. First Bank got a $200 million breakup fee when First Interstate backed out. First Bank said the legal, investment banking and other costs of the takeover fight were about $10 million.

title: Film Financed by a Religious Group
description: Care of the Spitfire Grill" was the Cinderella story of this year's Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah. The tale of a young woman who brings spiritual redemption to a Maine town, the film won the festival's Audience Award for drama, making it the most popular movie at the festival. It was bought by Castle Rock Entertainment, a major distributor, for $10 million, more than four times as much as any previous film shown at Sundance.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SOCCER;No Superstars at the Olympics
description: ROBERTO BAGGIO, JURGEN KLINSMANN and other established European superstars will not be playing at the Atlanta Olympics this summer.

title: No Headline
description: When we bring Terry Nichols to the court to decide whether he will live or die, it is in our best interest to create a sanctuary in the jungle." -- MICHAEL E. TIGAR, a lawyer for Mr. Nichols. [10:4.]

title: Cutting Residencies Won't Solve Doctor Surplus
description: To the Editor:

title: Secularists and Religionists Haven't Always Been at Odds
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BOSNIA ACCORD: IN WASHINGTON;U.S. Denies Aiding Saudis In Arming The Bosnians
description: Senior American officials adamantly denied a report today that the United States had collaborated with Saudi Arabia in a secret operation to funnel arms to the Bosnian Government.

title: THEATER REVIEW;James Baldwin Heroine Haunts the Memory
description: When the stern storefront minister in James Baldwin's "Amen Corner" rebukes her congregation for unseemly levity, audience members at the Long Wharf Theater here may find themselves taking it personally.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Harassment Suit Is Won
description: An Atlantic City police sergeant won a $575,000 judgment in Federal court yesterday in a sexual-harassment lawsuit against her department and a supervisor, the A.P. said. Sgt. Donna Hurley, an 18-year veteran, contended that fellow officers created a hostile work environment, and that superiors failed to act on her complaints of harassment. One such complaint was that a sanitary napkin marked with sergeant's stripes had been hung from a ceiling. Sergeant Hurley's civil suit named the department, her one-time supervisor, Capt. Henry Madamba, and Police Chief Nicholas V. Rifice. The jury found against the department and Captain Madamba but cleared Chief Rifice of wrongdoing.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;A Plan for Voting by Mail
description: New Jersey residents would be able to vote by mail under a bill sponsored by Senator John Casey, a Delran Democrat. Mr. Casey said that voting by mail could be phased in over five years, starting with school elections, then expanded to primaries and finally to general elections. JOE SHARKEY

title: A Fresh Urgency Arises on Sharing Of Common Space in Public Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew was making his first official appearance in Queens, taking questions at a community forum, when two teen-agers approached the microphone.

title: Campaign Briefs;Perot, in Iowa, Warns Of Fiscal Calamity
description: Even as he was declaring that he would not run for President, Ross Perot castigated unnamed "politicians" by accusing them of allowing the country to teeter toward financial insolvency while at the same time cynically manipulating the voters.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FIRST AMERICAN CORP., Nashville, a banking company, revised its July agreement to acquire First City Bancorp. Under the revised agreement, First American will pay six-tenths of a share for each First City share if First American stock has an average closing price of more than $46.67 in the 20 days before the sale goes through.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Gold and Wheat Prices Gain; Orange Juice Suffers a Setback
description: Gold prices rose yesterday for a third consecutive session, extending a five-week rally.

title: Journal;Smoking Guns at '60 Minutes'
description: Reporters are human, too. If they're slapped down in public, they won't rest until they can prove their manhood again. That's why tomorrow night is a big one for that den of journalistic testosterone "60 Minutes." Three months after CBS lawyers killed a Mike Wallace interview with Jeffrey Wigand, the highest-ranking tobacco executive ever to spill the ugly secrets of his own industry, "60 Minutes" will air the piece.

title: Judicial 'Sensitivity' Training Is Well Under Way
description: To the Editor:

title: A Houston Plant Is Saved
description: The Anchor Glass Container Corporation, a unit of Vitro S.A., said today that it would leave its Houston plant open indefinitely.

title: In Performance;JAZZ
description: The Dark Side of Life And Yet a Note of Triumph Ke Fez

title: Grace Spurns Baxter's $3.8 Billion Dialysis-Chain Bid
description: Hinting that it was considering more lucrative offers, W. R.
