Grace & Company yesterday brushed aside a $3.8 billion bid by Baxter International for National Medical Care, Grace's big chain of kidney dialysis centers. Albert J. Costello, chief executive of Grace, said he would disclose "our plans" on Monday."

title: A Corporate Doctor Gets Mixed Reviews
description: Having rescued National Semiconductor Inc. from near bankruptcy, Gilbert F. Amelio is known as a turnaround artist, though he shuns the term.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: MEN'S BASKETBALL

title: Unemployment Climbs
description: The unemployment rate rose to 5.8 percent from 5.6 percent, and the number of payroll jobs dropped sharply in January.

title: BASKETBALL;Johnson's Night: 15 Points, 3 Rebounds, 'No Fun'
description: They stuck the blond on him.

title: TRACK AND FIELD;A Millrose Record: Now Bubka Has It All
description: When you've broken the world record 18 times indoors and 17 times outdoors, when you have won five world championships outdoors and four indoors, when you have made almost a mockery of the pole vault by dominating it for a dozen years, what's another meet record?

title: COMPANY NEWS;REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES BUYS MID-AMERICAN WASTE UNIT
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Mid-American Waste Systems Inc.'s Atlanta operations for about $52 million. Republic, a waste services company, also completed its purchase of Charleston Disposal Systems Inc. and its affiliates for 300,000 common shares. That transaction is worth about $9.3 million based on Republic's closing share price yesterday of $31.125. Republic's chief executive, H. Wayne Huizenga, is the former chief executive of Blockbuster Entertainment.

title: Apple and Disclosure: How Golden Is Silence?
description: American investors expect to be told, promptly and publicly, all the important information they need to gauge the value of a company's stock. But for weeks, Apple Computer Inc.'s investors have been trading in the dark.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL TO SELL LIFE INSURANCE UNIT
description: The United Companies Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its United Companies Life Insurance Company unit to a company formed by Knightsbridge Capital Fund I L.P. for a total of $164 million in cash and real estate and other assets. The closely held Knightsbridge, which is a private investment partnership with institutional investors, was formed last year to make equity investments, mostly in life insurance companies.

title: Intensifying Inquiry Seen On Milken
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission took its investigation of Michael R. Milken, the former junk-bond king, to a new level this week by granting itself full subpoena powers to look into his recent business dealings, according to people familiar with the inquiry.

title: Enron to Build Pakistan Plant
description: The Enron Corporation said today that it had agreed to build, own and operate a 754-megawatt residual power project in Punjab, Pakistan.

title: INSIDE
description: Strike Order Overturned

title: Trump to Issue Mortgage Notes
description: Donald J. Trump will issue $340 million in new mortgage notes to consolidate debt from two of his casino properties here, officials said this week.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Royals' Appier Tops $5 Million
description: KEVIN APPIER, Kansas City's No. 1 pitcher, went into salary arbitration seeking a $1 million raise over his 1995 salary of $4,387,500. The Royals submitted $4,715,000, and yesterday the two sides agreed to split the difference. That boosts Appier, 15-10 last season, to $5,051,250.

title: Peddler Testifies In Firebomb Trial
description: A peddler testified yesterday that about half an hour after a firebomb exploded in a subway train in Manhattan, he saw a badly-burned man drop a pair of singed, gasoline-soaked gloves in the Clark Street subway station in Brooklyn.

title: A Central Fiscal Argument Advanced by Forbes Proves Hard to Confirm
description: Don't take my word for it, just look at the history books," Steve Forbes told the Rotary Club in Nashua this week. "Every time the tax burden is reduced, Government revenues go up, not down."

title: THE BOSNIA ACCORD: IN TUZLA;Women Demand News of Srebrenica's Men
description: As rocks whistled by and the police clubbed her friends, 40-year-old Hasija stood silently in a corner today, huddled in the bitter cold. The other women threw stones and released their anger in painful screams, while she thought only about Medin, her 14-year-old son, and the day Bosnian Serb soldiers ripped him from her arms.

title: Child's Death Raises Doubt Over Private-School Drivers' Training
description: Simon Breuer always warned the children he drove to school that it was safest to cross the street behind the school bus. It wasn't until Mirel Friedman, a 6-year-old handicapped girl in his charge, slipped on ice and fell under the rear wheels of his bus that he learned how wrong his warnings had been.

title: Feminists Gather to Affirm Relevancy of Their Movement
description: The feminist movement has encountered rough waters of late. Issues that agitated its aging leaders in their youth three decades ago -- marriage and career, abortion rights and political clout -- are taken for granted by younger women. Some social critics have declared the movement irrelevant, out of touch, even dead.

title: G.O.P. Lawmaker Accuses Democratic Leader
description: Representative Jennifer Dunn, Republican of Washington, filed ethics charges today accusing the Democratic leader in the House, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, of misleading the ethics committee over real estate deals and of possible campaign finance violations.

title: At Javits Gem Show, Fatalism and Fear
description: As a Hong Kong businessman fought for his life yesterday after being shot and robbed of nearly $1 million in diamonds outside a midtown hotel, his fellow jewelers anxiously hustled their expensive wares into the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center for a trade show so exclusive it has until now been almost a secret.

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. ROBOTICS WITHDRAWS HAYES MICROCOMPUTER BID
description: The U.S. Robotics Corporation withdrew its $97.5 million bid to acquire Hayes Microcomputer Products Inc. yesterday, saying the acquisition would not be in the best interests of its shareholders. Hayes is a modem maker currently operating under bankruptcy-court protection. The withdrawal of U.S. Robotics' bid leaves two options for Hayes: to be taken over by Diamond Multimedia Systems Inc. for $111 million or to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings as an independent company. Hayes filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in November 1994.

title: Campaign Briefs;New Poll Shows Forbes Gaining in California
description: Steve Forbes is gaining ground in California at the expense of the Republican front-runner, Bob Dole, according to a San Francisco Examiner poll released today. The survey also showed that President Clinton would defeat any of the top Republican challengers if the election were held today.

title: Religion Ruled Valid Defense in Drug Case
description: Rastafarians can use their religious belief that marijuana is a sacrament as a defense against drug possession charges, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: Fuyang Journal;In Temblor of Anger, Faults Revealed
description: As in so many cities along China's coast, the people of Fuyang are getting rich. Their economy is outperforming the nation's by 50 percent, and the quality of life is soaring like the giant metal swans suspended over the central square here.

title: Dow Finishes Down 31.07; Nasdaq Climbs to a High
description: Blue-chip stocks fell yesterday, tracking significant weakness in the bond market.

title: Arts Agency Financing
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge to Hear Bid to Reverse A Drug Ruling
description: A Federal judge who came under fire for tossing out evidence in a Washington Heights drug case said yesterday that there was little chance he would reverse his ruling, and he called prosecutors' bid to get him to change his mind a "juvenile project."

title: His Accent Just Right, Chirac Plies His Charms
description: When the President of France came calling in Chicago today, John Bryan, the head of Sara Lee, praised him for once receiving an unusual but special honor: a certificate of honor from Howard Johnson's "for artistry in making banana splits."

title: Retirement Fever
description: Washington is not the only place where people are getting fed up.

title: Trapped in the Bilingual Classroom
description: My grandson David was born in New York City. His mother speaks English at home and at her job. And David grew up speaking English with his friends.

title: California County's Agreement With the S.E.C. Is Raising Concerns onTwo Fronts
description: If the devil is in the details, the fine print of the Securities and Exchange Commission's settlement last week of securities fraud charges against Orange County, Calif., is providing ample reason for concern among two very different groups.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.F.L.;Knee Surgery for the Bills' Smith
description: Buffalo Bills defensive end BRUCE SMITH will have minor arthroscopic surgery on his right knee after his Pro Bowl appearance tomorrow.

title: A Defender of Rare Birds Is Guilty of Smuggling Them
description: A bird breeder who was an outspoken protector of endangered parrots has pleaded guilty to smuggling scores of rare wild birds into the United States, resulting in the deaths of at least a hundred.

title: Another Snowstorm Strikes the Northeast
description: The third major snowstorm of a hard winter drove up the urban corridor from Washington to Philadelphia and New York last night, and forecasters predicted accumulations of 6 to 12 inches by noon today. The deepest falls were expected on eastern Long Island and in coastal areas of New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Calgene Upheld In Patent Case
description: Calgene Inc.'s genetically engineered Flavr Savr tomato does not infringe patents held by Enzo Biochem Inc., a Federal judge ruled today.

title: The Neediest Cases;Battered Wife Is Abused Again by Bureaucracy, Until Help Arrives
description: The first time Mildred R. realized she was pregnant was the day she gave birth to her daughter, two months prematurely. Her doctor, who had been treating her for fibroid tumors, had not realized that she was pregnant, either.

title: World News Briefs;Illegally Stored Dynamite Kills at Least 95 in China
description: Ten tons of illegally stored dynamite exploded in a village in central China, creating an inferno that killed at least 95 people, leveled 40 buildings and shattered windows for a mile around.

title: Coup in Africa Frightens Democratic Neighbors
description: In a fragrant courtyard in this desert's-edge capital, a spokesman at army headquarters busies himself explaining how the military will bring about a "march toward democracy."

title: In Performance;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: An Accompanist Steps Into the Spotlight Jonathan Feldman and Friends The Juilliard Theater

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHARMING SHOPPES TO TAKE ADDED $33 MILLION CHARGE
description: Charming Shoppes Inc. said yesterday that it would report an additional one-time pretax expense of $33 million in the fourth quarter from a restructuring of its sourcing and domestic corporate operations. The charge will be added to the $65 million pretax expense the company announced in December, which was related to the closing of 290 underperforming stores. The company's after-tax fourth-quarter earnings will now be reduced by a total of about $66 million, or 64 cents a share. Charming, which operates women's retail stores under the names Fashion Bug and Fashion Bug Plus, reported quarterly net income of $5.2 million a year ago. The company has shut 120 stores since December and now operates about 1,300 stores.

title: Shake-Up at Apple Computer Places Director in Chief's Job
description: Financially troubled Apple Computer said last night that Michael H. Spindler had been dismissed as president and chief executive.

title: Religion Journal;In Bookstores, Spiritual Journeys Are Taking Wing
description: According to publishers, books on religious themes are a hot item these days, selling well in secular and religious bookstores alike in a time when a search for deeper meaning seems much in vogue among a spiritually restless public.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Where Small Is Beautiful;For Italy's Family-Owned Weavers, Life Is Good
description: Because the weavers on the other side of the valley specialize in cashmere, and the nearby Loro Piana company has a two-year monopoly on the supply of vicuna wool, Paolo Ferla is betting his company's future on the highly prized fleece of the baby alpaca.

title: Gene Kelly, Dancer of Vigor and Grace, Dies
description: Gene Kelly, the dancer, actor, director and choreographer who brought a vigorous athleticism, casual grace and an earthy masculinity to the high romance of lavish Hollywood musicals, died yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 83.

title: Economic Data Cause Selloff in Long Bonds
description: Treasury prices were mixed yesterday, with the shorter maturities showing some strength, but with the longer maturities being hammered, as traders reacted uncertainly to the day's employment report.

title: Look Again at Safety Hazards in Air Traffic
description: To the Editor:

title: The Flat-Tax Debate
description: In pushing his flat-tax proposal, Steve Forbes contends that past tax cuts have caused an increase in Federal revenue, but that claim by the Republican Presidential candidate is difficult to document. Almost all economists agree that the taxes the Government collects depend much more on the economy than on the tax rate, and they point out that the American economy usually grows each year.

title: Red Flag Aloft, a Russian City Defiantly Upholds Soviet Ways
description: This place has always been mutinous. Risking death, serfs here routinely withheld beets and grain from the greedy Czars. Nothing changed with Communism: Between 1918 and 1921 tens of thousands of farmers refused to surrender their food to Soviet re quisition teams, which caused the Russian people's bloodiest rebellion against Bolshevism.

title: POLITICS:THE PRESIDENT;Clinton Takes a Trip up North and Down Memory Lane
description: Four years after the doughnuts and the laryngitis, the tabloid taunts and the trial by coffee shop, Bill Clinton returned to the voters of New Hampshire today, a bit tired but determined to become the "Comeback Kid" once more.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-6

title: San Diego Teachers Strike for Higher Pay
description: Teachers in California's second-largest school district went on strike on Thursday after negotiations broke down over raises, and more than 1,000 of them rallied today at district headquarters to press the board to return to the negotiating table.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column in some editions of Business Day on Thursday about an offer by Metromedia International Group Inc. to acquire the Samuel Goldwyn Company misstated Metromedia's relationship with the Alliance Entertainment Corporation. The boards of the two companies have approved Metromedia's acquisition of Alliance, but Metromedia does not currently own Alliance.

title: Foster Care Officials Fault New York City on Child Services
description: Officials of nonprofit foster-care agencies yesterday supported the contention of Federal prosecutors that New York City officials had for years improperly deprived many foster children of required services.

title: Aegean Tantrum
description: It should not have taken urgent telephone calls from President Clinton to pull Greece and Turkey back from military conflict over two uninhabited rocks in the Aegean Sea earlier this week. Athens and Ankara are NATO allies and Mr. Clinton has more serious issues to handle.

title: Look Again at Safety Hazards in Air Traffic;Ask Other Countries
description: To the Editor:

title: In Performance;POP
description: Getting It All Together As Egotism Slinks Off Ptage Jim Hall Blue Note

title: World News Briefs;Japan Decides Against Food Aid to North Korea
description: Japan does not see North Korea as being in a state of famine and has no plans to provide it either financial or food aid, the Government said today.

title: No Immediate H.I.V. Test
description: To the Editor:

title: James N. Goodsell, Foreign Correspondent, 66
description: James N. Goodsell, the chief Latin American correspondent for The Christian Science Monitor from 1964 to 1985, died on Thursday at his home in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 66.

title: Who Rules Over a Beauty Queen?;Miss New York and Pageant Officials in a Power Struggle
description: In a figurative sense, the crown of Miss New York never rested easily on Helen Goldsby's head, which was dizzy with the prospect of tall podiums, vast audiences, fat checks.

title: Party of Apartheid Looking for a New Identity
description: After 18 months of soul-searching, the political party that created apartheid and ruled this country for more than 40 years announced today that it was ready to remake itself -- if anyone has any good ideas how.

title: Schubertiade Resuming
description: The Schubertiade is to begin its ninth season next Saturday at the 92d Street Y, with the theme "Opposites Attract: Schubert and Beethoven." The series is to run through Feb. 18. Among artists taking part are the baritone Hermann Prey, the tenor John Aler, the pianists Grant Johannesen and John O'Conor and the Vermeer Quartet.

title: Strikers Fighting the Last War?
description: A good labor strike is much like a medieval battle, with both sides throwing all their forces and weapons into the fray in the hope of quickly vanquishing their foes with a superior show of strength.

title: BASEBALL;Girardi Starts Blocking Pitches
description: Joe Girardi has never been to Yankee Stadium, he has not yet donned the pinstriped uniform and yesterday was the first time he met some of his new teammates. But Girardi already has experience in one aspect of being a Yankee: he has rehearsed his remarks about Mike Stanley, the popular catcher he is replacing.

title: A Victory for Viewers
description: The communications bill that Congress passed this week will, over time, offer viewers attractive new choices for entertainment and news. They will be able to turn to their local telephone company for cable service, to their cable company for telephone service and to their electric utility company for both types of service.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SYQUEST TO CUT 60% OF WORK FORCE AND POST A LOSS
description: Syquest Technology Inc., a disk-drive maker, said yesterday that it would cut 60 percent of its work force, consolidate some Far East operations and assign some manufacturing to outside companies. The company also posted a loss of $33.8 million, or $2.98 a share, for the first quarter, which ended on Dec. 31. Syquest will cut 60 workers in the United States and 1,500 in the Far East from its permanent full-time work force of 2,600. The company will also halt the expansion of its Malaysia plant.

title: GOLF;A Drier Course, A Hotter Field
description: The sun broke through on the Monterey Peninsula today, bathing the three golf courses that wind through the Del Monte forests in warm light. The players in the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am responded to the change of climate by lighting it up, throwing golf balls into the soft greens like heat-seeking missiles and turning the golf tournament into a birdie party.

title: COOPER INDUSTRIES BUYS BLAZER INTERNATIONAL
description: Cooper Industries said yesterday that it had acquired Blazer Group's Blazer International business for undisclosed terms. Blazer International, which makes automotive lighting products, will become part of the Cooper Automotive division. The unit has about 200 employees. Cooper is a maker of electrical products, tools, hardware and automotive parts.

title: Russian Leaders Vow Action On Striking Miners' Demands
description: Top Russian officials gave a sympathetic hearing to striking miners today in a bid to limit the economic fallout at home and to protect President Boris N. Yeltsin's political prospects in the presidential election in June.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;The Seahawks' Move Faces Countermoves
description: The Seahawks' owner, Ken Behring, made it official yesterday. He intends to move his team out of Seattle, possibly to Los Angeles, saying that the Kingdome is not the first-class facility guaranteed in the lease and that it would be seismically unsafe without expensive renovations.

title: In Performance;JAZZ
description: Touring With His Own Band, A Bassist Has His Day John Entwistle Tramps

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Man Sought in Phone Fraud
description: The police were looking for Anthony Bernard, of Teaneck, charged yesterday with defrauding cellular phone companies and cell-phone users after the authorities said they found 2,500 so-called cloned phone numbers and the electronic gear for snatching legitimate cell-phone codes out of the air in Mr. Bernard's Englewood apartment. Stealing cell-phone numbers from the airwaves and programming them into cell phones that are then sold was a $600 million scam last year, said Robin Traum, a spokeswoman for AT&T Wireless Service. He said AT&T will begin using a radio frequency "fingerprinting" technology this year to try to combat the fraud.

title: Payrolls Fall by 201,000 Jobs; Blizzard in East Is Cited
description: The unemployment rate rose and the number of payroll jobs dropped sharply in January, the Government reported today, but analysts said the blizzard that crippled the Northeast made the already sluggish economy appear in worse shape than it really was.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;A Retroactive Payroll Tax
description: With legislation that would let Jersey City impose a payroll tax this year bottled up in Trenton, Mayor Bret Schundler plans to impose the tax retroactively for the last three months of 1995, when it was still allowed under state law. The 1 percent tax on payrolls of at least $2,500 would raise an estimated $5 million for the quarter.

title: Clinton Order Discouraging Striker Replacement Is Voided
description: In a blow to the nation's labor unions, a Federal appeals court today voided a Presidential order intended to penalize companies that in effect discharge workers who strike.

title: Observer;And the Bones Breaking
description: You can talk about your springtime in the Rockies, about autumn in New York, or summer in the Vale of Kashmir, but winter is the season for me. Give me winter and plenty of it.

title: Higher Earnings For CS First Boston
description: CS First Boston, the investment banking unit of the giant Swiss financial services company CS Holding A.G., had a sharp improvement in earnings in 1995, thanks to strong fixed-income trading results and a booming mergers-and-acquisitions business.

title: Ranald P. Hobbs, 88, Publisher Of a Classics Series for Colleges
description: Ranald Purcell Hobbs, a book publisher who developed the Rinehart Editions Series that is used widely in colleges, died last Saturday in Naples Community Hospital in Florida. He was 88 and lived in Naples.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Corrections Official Indicted
description: A former official of the State Department of Corrections and executives of two construction companies were indicted on bribery charges involving an $8 million prison construction project, Attorney General Deborah Poritz said yesterday. Joseph Maisto, 58, a retired administrative analyst for the department, was charged with accepting $20,000 in 1992 while he oversaw construction at the Albert Wagner Youth Correctional facility in Chesterfield. The executives were identified as Joseph DeLuca, 62, president of Dega Estimates Limit Co. in Ewing, and Paul Massei, 64, president of MGM Construction Corp. in Trenton, The Associated Press reported.

title: POLITICS: ADVERTISING;In Campaign Ads, Forbes Is Taking On All Comers
description: It is standard procedure for a candidate who is behind in the polls to use negative advertising against a rival who is ahead.

title: Tajik Rebels Halt Their March on Capital
description: A mutinous army commander seeking to oust the Government pulled back today from an advance toward the capital but rejected an offer for talks with the President.

title: The Governor's Attack on the Judges
description: Moving to make crime a central issue for the State Legislature in an election year, Gov. George Pataki has stepped up his attack on New York's seven-member Court of Appeals, the state's highest court. This week the Governor introduced radical legislation that would essentially strip the court of its authority to decide independently whether evidence obtained by the police should be suppressed as an unlawful seizure under the State Constitution. The Governor would require instead that the court bow to rules set by the United States Supreme Court.

title: Finance Chief Quits Disney to Take Top Executive Job at Hilton
description: After less than a year in the job, Stephen P. Bollenbach has resigned as chief financial officer of the Walt Disney Company to return to the hotel industry.

title: There's Hope for the Explorer in All of Us
description: To the Editor:

title: There's Hope for the Explorer in All of Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Huskies and Storm Face Off at Garden
description: Which St. John's team will phow up at Madison Square Garden tonight against Connecticut? Will the Huskies have to contend with the aggressive Red Storm squad that upset mighty Georgetown, 83-71, last Saturday, or will they see the uninspired bunch that lost by 86-83 to Notr' Dame, the Big East cellar-dweller, on Wednesday night?

title: BASKETBALL;After the Magic, Is It Time To Believe in the Knicks?
description: Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen toyed with them before deciding to blow them off their own floor. Now, with Thursday night's shootout victory over Orlando fresh in their minds, they are talking about such foreign concepts as "playing together" and "accepting their roles."

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Mets Sign Third Baseman Scott
description: The Mets signed a third baseman, but he's not the one they have been looking for. GARY SCOTT, who last played in the majors with the Chicago Cubs in 1992, agreed to a minor league contract. Scott, 27, has played for Phoenix of the Class AAA Pacific Coast League the past two seasons, hitting .286 and .265. He played in 31 games with the Cubs in 1991 and 36 games in 1992, compiling a .160 average.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.F.L.;Aikman Plans Surgery on Elbow
description: Dallas Cowboys quarterback TROY AIKMAN will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his right elbow next week to relieve pain caused by degenerative arthritis and deteriorating cartilage.

title: Businesses Scaling Back Plans To Defang Federal Regulations
description: Leading business groups are beginning to advise allies in Congress to scale back their ambitious proposals if they hope to pass stalled legislation restricting Federal regulatory powers.

title: In Performance;POP
description: For a Tenor Saxophonist, A New York Homecoming Billy Harper Sweet Basil

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Jail in Baby-Formula Scheme
description: Two Philadelphia men who schemed to cash in 100,000 counterfeit baby-formula coupons for $3 each were sentenced yesterday. Nimer R. Mustafa, who pleaded guilty, was sentenced to five months' house arrest. His brother-in-law, Mahmoud Raja, who pleaded guilty to being an accomplice, received a fine and probation. The men were arrested last March when a Federal agent posing as a counterfeiter delivered the bogus coupons to them at a North Bergen doughnut shop.

title: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;The Crop-Duster Approach
description: In an advertising campaign viewed as unusually negative for a primary, Steve Forbes has singled out not only his closest rival, Senator Bob Dole, but even those who trail him.

title: Channing Liem, 86; Sought United Korea
description: Dr. Channing Liem, a retired professor of political science, former South Korean delegate to the United Nations and longtime campaigner for the peaceful reunification of a democratic Korea, died on Jan. 24 at the Alta Bates Medical Center in Berkeley, Calif. A Berkeley resident, he was 86.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TODAY'S MAN FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: The men's wear retailer Today's Man Inc. said yesterday that it had filed for protection from creditors under bankruptcy laws but that it would continue to operate while it developed a plan of reorganization. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Today's Man fell 75 cents, to $1.875. The company operates 35 men's wear stores in the Philadelphia, New York, Washington and Chicago areas and in Florida. It filed a voluntary petition in United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code. In court documents, Today's Man listed assets of $108.7 million, including good will, and liabilities of $77.6 million.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Arnold E. Safer, 59, Analyst and Expert On Energy Markets
description: Arnold E. Safer, an economist who was an expert in the world energy markets, died on Jan. 13 in his home in Rockville, Md. He was 59.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 4, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction

title: Tower 'Trees' Help Prevent Extinction Of Bald Eagle
description: For decades the country's bald eagle population teetered on the edge of extinction. By the mid-1970's, loss of habitat and the widespread use of DDT had left only one infertile nesting pair in New York State.

title: Vatican Says Sudan Forced Priest to Confess to Bomb Plot
description: The Pope's representative in the Sudan accused the Khartoum Government today of using torture and death threats to force a priest to confess to plotting a bombing campaign.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Business Diary column last Sunday about earnings at brokerage firms misstated the results from trading at Salomon Inc. in the fourth quarter of 1995. Salomon had a sharp decline in profits from proprietary trading, compared with the previous quarter, but not a loss.

title: Remember 1987 Peak? It's Nearly Doubled
description: It was during a period of speculative frenzy that the Dow Jones industrial average hit a record of 2,722.42 on a summer day in 1987. Within a few months, after share prices crashed, money managers could be heard muttering they would never again let valuations grow so excessive.

title: Stepping In to Stop a Crime Was an Act of Humanity
description: To the Editor:

title: DRIVING;Trouble Spots on the Road to Avoid
description: A look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency.

title: Women's Work
description: Daughters of the Great Depression Women, Work, and Fiction in the American 1930s. By Laura Hapke. Illustrated. 286 pp. Athens: The University of Georgia Press. $45.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Reservation Procedures Revised for Campsites
description: Campground reservations procedures have changed for more than a dozen national park campsites, including Yosemite and the Grand Canyon. The system, which took effect Jan. 15, allows a family (up to 6) or group (minimum of 10 and maximum of 30) to reserve a campsite up to five months in advance. Beginning on the 15th day of the month, Destinet, a reservation service, will take reservations for a one-month period. For example, on Feb. 15, reservations can be made for the arrival dates starting June 15 through July 14.

title: SUNDAY February 4, 1996: COMPULSIVE SHOPPING;Insomniac's Salvation
description: You're channel surfing. An ad for the greatest thingamajig ever stops you. "Not sold in stores." The 800 number flashes. No pen or pencil. Gone forever.

title: Corrections
description: A cross-reference on page 45 of the Travel section today, with an article about a yacht, the Sea Cloud, omits a page number in some copies for a listing of Sea Cloud cruises. It is on page 33 of the section.

title: Fears That Loss of a Math Ph.D. Program Figures in a Bigger Equation
description: The University of Rochester is scuttling its doctoral program in mathematics, a move that has surprised and angered scientists and educators nationwide, who worry it could signal erosion at America's research universities.

title: Schools Facing 'Three-Way Squeeze'
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani presented his preliminary budget last Wednesday, officials at the Board of Education expressed some relief: while hardly insubstantial, the cut in projected spending that the Mayor proposed -- $181 million -- was about $100 million less than last year's reduction.

title: Sleepless in Albany
description: Gov. George Pataki is lying awake at night worrying about his budget problems. It turns out that he has imprudently assumed nearly $2 billion in savings for the next year, to be derived from a budget deal in Washington that may never occur. After resting in the Caribbean, Mr. Pataki journeys to Capitol Hill today to join other governors for an uphill push for a budget accord that would help bail many states out of financial problems similar to New York's. His mission will not succeed unless he demands more concessions on Medicaid and other issues from his fellow Republicans.

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;What Rocks and Is a Seat of State?
description: THE ROCKING CHAIR, THE MOST American of all furniture forms, has been a favorite of statesmen since the 18th century. Benjamin Franklin added metal bends to the base of his outsized library chair to make it rock, and Abraham Lincoln was assassinated while sitting in a Victorian rocker that had been installed at Ford Theater especially for him that night. John F. Kennedy's rocker, of course, became an icon of his White House years.

title: Ending Farm Welfare
description: Congress may be squandering a rare chance to end welfare for farmers as the United States has known it for half a century. A Republican bill to wean farmers from subsidies and move them toward a market-based system has been stalled by Senate and House Democrats and threatened with a Presidential veto. It deserves Democratic support.

title: STYLE;Beauty and the Brits
description: When did I first suspect that I might have lived in England too long? Perhaps it was when I could not understand the question, telephoned to me from New York. How can Charles prefer Camilla when Diana is so much more attractive by every prevailing standard?

title: Sermon On the Mound
description: IN A GARDEN WITHOUT flowers, exotic ideas flourish. Amid the rolling borderlands of Scotland, this 300-acre "theme park" bursts from the fertile mind not of a gardener but of an architectural theorist. Over the past five years the erudite and glamorous Charles Jencks (who is both admired and reviled for his efforts to popularize post-modernism) has transformed the staid country estate of his mother-in-law, Lady Keswick, from a charming, bosk-and-dell affair into a landscaped folly of bizarre originality.

title: Gay Editor's Transfer Rests on a Lie
description: To the Editor:

title: LIVING TOO LONG
description: Norman's aunt Millie is one of the "oldest old," past 85, and so am I, at age 89 1/2. I make the best of the faculties I still have. I grieve for friends less fortunate.

title: Prayer Wasn't Issue in Child's Wrongful Death
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME REPAIR;How to Keep Your Hot-Water Heating System Up and Running
description: A HEATING system is classified by the medium that transfers the heat from the furnace through the house. Forced air, hot water and steam are the most common systems in the United States.

title: DOES A SUGAR BEAR BITE?
description: As anyone who has heard her speak on the subject knows, C. DeLores Tucker's concern about the effect of gangsta rap on children is genuine. For Lynn Hirschberg to allow David Kenner, the lawyer for Death Row Records, to be her article's final judgment on the subject, as he moves to protect his client by dismissing Tucker as a financially motivated racketeer, is for this gifted reporter to indulge in an uncharacteristic lapse in responsibility.

title: Neighborhood Report;East Side Voters Keep Politicians Guessing
description: Only one thing is certain about Upper East Side voters. They're unpredictable.

title: MAILBOX;Room for Magic
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MAILBOX;Hire a Gorilla
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sprawl Isn't Just Ugly; It Costs the Taxpayers, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: CHATTER;The Governor's Midterm Grades
description: Governor Whitman is at midterm. How would you grade her performance so far?

title: Judges Find U.N. Unfair To Workers
description: An independent panel's decision that the United Nations erred in two cases in which its employees were punished shed new light this week on the operations of an organization that functions beyond the judicial reach of any nation yet is subject to political pressures from Washington and other capitals.

title: Seeking Support For Power Plan
description: DETERMINED to move forward with a plan endorsed by Gov. George E. Pataki to cut electric rates on Long Island by at least 12 percent, leaders of the Long Island Power Authority are traveling across the Island to drum up support.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: DOES A SUGAR BEAR BITE?
description: My eyes lit up when I saw Lynn Hirschberg's "Does a Sugar Bear Bite?" (Jan. 14). Glad to see you keep an eye on the hip scene as well as on more staid enthusiasms. Tupac Shakur's signing with Death Row Records was the music story of the year. No matter what you think of Tupac personally (I am not a fan of his misogynous impulses), "California Love" is a cutting-edge song and will make Suge Knight and Tupac even more powerful in the music industry.

title: Our Towns;In Suburb, Marianne Is An Enigma
description: THE police have nabbed Morristown's most notorious trespasser, but they are not happy about it. Since locking her up a week ago, they have been beside themselves trying to figure how best to help her out. "She doesn't belong in jail," Detective Jeff Paul said glumly. "She is not a criminal."

title: Longer Life for Detectors
description: New residential smoke detectors powered by lithium batteries that can last up to 10 years may save lives, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: WINTER OF '96;Sun Seekers Clog the Region's Exits
description: All Nicole Lovinger wanted to do was to get out of New York. Her job as a media buyer was straining her nerves. Asbestos had spewed into the air near her apartment when a steam pipe ruptured last week. She hadn't had a vacation in more than a year. And then the forecast sealed it: more snow.

title: Where Big Snowfalls Are No Reason to Moan
description: Against the brilliant white landscape of a 10,450-foot summit here, a snow blower worked doggedly today, clearing a path to allow an aerial ski tram to pass without dragging through snow drifts.

title: ON THE MAP;Line Up and Dance at the Marlboro Firehouse
description: Call it Marlboro country and western. Marlboro Township (pop. 31,000) may be trying to shake off its roots as a horse and cow town, but for a whole mess of folks with a hankering for western line dancing or the two-step to the strains of Garth Brooks and Hank Williams, this growing Monmouth county suburb is still their home on the range.

title: THE CRUISE ISSUE;Sailing Through The Classics
description: THE CRUISE ISSUE ROXANA ROBINSON writes about travel and people whotravel.

title: Get Me Rewrite!
description: The Frozen Republic How the Constitution Is Paralyzing Democracy. By Daniel Lazare. 393 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace & Company. $25. EXCEPTING only a private fortune in excess of $5 billion, nothing in the temple of the American civil religion is more precious than the Constitution brought forth by the corporate sponsors of liberty in Philadelphia in the summer of 1787. In "The Frozen Republic," Daniel Lazare, an accomplished iconoclast, manages within the space of a relatively brief polemic to assign the four pages of parchment to the realm of magical objects in which a museum of natural history might also place the totem poles and the bones of a departed saint.

title: Schools Grapple With Problem Of Bullies
description: TIM J., 14, dreaded eighth period at Yorktown High School. Every day the freshman (whose last name is being withheld to protect him from further repercussions) was harassed by a classmate. Sometimes the 6-foot bully would simply grab Tim's spiral notebook and tear out his homework, copy it and then leave the original crumpled on the ground. During tests, the bully would grab Tim by the arm, pull him close and copy Tim's answers. If he wanted money -- and he often did -- the bully would demand that Tim hand it over.

title: A Church Asunder Awaits the Pope in Salvador
description: SAN SALVADOR - Correction: February 25, 1996, Sunday

title: World News Briefs;Riyadh Holds Saudi In Pakistan Bombing
description: Saudi Arabia has taken custody of a Saudi man deported from Pakistan in connection with the car-bombing last year that killed seven people, including five Americans.

title: MAILBOX;Local Coverage
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Connecticut Q&A: Robert Clinton;Tribal Territory and Jurisdictional Issues
description: WHAT does it mean to live among tribal nations? Particularly if those nations are recognized by the Federal government?

title: Company Buys High-Rise Complex
description: THE Robert Martin Company, Westchester's largest commercial property owner, based here, which spent two years divesting itself of some of its so-called non-core properties, now owns one of the tallest office buildings between New York City and Albany.

title: DOES A SUGAR BEAR BITE?
description: Reading between the lines, it becomes clear that media hype, glorification of outlaws and violence masquerading as freedom are creating monsters. That you published this story the day before Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday is highly ironic.

title: WEDDINGS;Linda Gross, Robert E. Kahn
description: Linda Gross, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen C. Gross of New York, was married last evening to Robert E. Kahn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Kahn of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Gary Bretton-Granatoor officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Baltimore Project on Vacant Houses Gives Students Legal Insight
description: A group of high school students in one of this city's grittier neighborhoods is using the law to go after the absentee owners of vacant buildings that mar the community.

title: A World as Cruel as Job's
description: THE Autobiography of My Mother By Jamaica Kincaid. 228 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $20. THIS is a shocking book. Elegantly and delicately composed, it is also inhuman, and unapologetically so. Jamaica Kincaid has written a truly ugly meditation on life in some of the most beautiful prose we are likely to find in contemporary fiction.

title: The Magellan Fund Enters Its Next Phase: Cyclical Stocks
description: AMID all the market fascination about whether the Fidelity Magellan fund is buying or selling technology stocks, it's easy to forget that the $54 billion behemoth has anything else in its portfolio.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Monday The Ford Motor Company reports on vehicle sales in January. In December, Ford's sales dropped 9.2 percent, as car sales plunged 19 percent and light-truck sales rose 1.9 percent.

title: Q and A
description: Bullfights in France Q. I am interested in going to southern France this spring and would like to go to some bullfights. How can I obtain scheduling and ticket reservation information? -- Joanne H. Frazier, Tampa, Fla.

title: The Enduring Hadley of Parish-Hadley
description: THE day was blustery, steps leading up to the Southport front door icy and snow-laden. As the interviewer carefully inched her way to the front door, Albert Hadley, one of this age's decorating luminaries, opened the door and extended his hand.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES BUSINESS BEST SELLERS
description: HARD COVER

title: OFF THE SHELF;Feathering Retirement Nests, With Home Recipes and All
description: THE "elderly" person I knew best in the world was my father's cousin Sophie, a retired New York City schoolteacher who lived frugally on her pension and her savings and who always gave me her grasshopper-and-ant lecture when we got together. "I certainly hope you're putting something away for later," she would begin for the millionth time, as I obliged her with affirmative nodding.

title: The Good Moves
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SEARCH OF...;Ski Country (It's Bigger Than You Think)
description: WINTER is no time to vegetate by a fireplace. New Jersey's parks -- particularly those in the north and west, where the state begins its slow climb from sea to mountains -- offer a perfect chance to be where the season is more than slush.

title: Half Moon, Berth of a Legend
description: THIS winter, passengers on Metro-North may glimpse a tall, wood sailing ship on the ice-choked Hudson. Thanks to Washington Irving, tales of phantom ships and pirates' buried treasure abound along this stretch of the river.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE LAST SHOT: City Streets, Basketball Dreams By Darcy Frey. Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $11. A prevalent myth in the American ghetto is that athletic achievement -- particularly in basketball -- will provide a way out of poverty. As the author discovered at a high school in Brooklyn, this belief often helps perpetuate scholastic and professional failure. "This book -- compellingly written, with elegance, economy and just the right amount of outrage -- should be read by every parent who has a child involved in school sports," Brent Staples said here in 1994.

title: James is a girl
description: AN OCTOBER MORNING IN PARIS. JAMES KING, HER HAIR PULLED back into a ponytail, bounds from an elevator into the lobby of the Hotel de la Tremoille, not far from the Arc de Triomphe, where she has been staying for the past week. "How do I look -- what do you think?" she asks the 20-year-old Julia Samersova, who used to work at Company Management, the modeling agency that began representing James nearly two years ago, when she was still known as Jaime. (Company Management already represented Jaime Rishar, a top model. "James" was already Jaime King's nickname.) Samersova is now James's best friend and occasional chaperone. Seated at a breakfast table squeezing lemons into a bottle of Evian, she looks up at James, who gestures nervously at her black pants and long-sleeved black shirt. "Do you think this is proper? Do you think it's fierce yet subtle?" ("Fierce" is the superlative du jour this fall among the fashion crowd.)

title: DANCE VIEW;Why Film Makers Ask: Shall We Dance?
description: DANCING SWAYS THE SOUL before the brain can get a word in. It is the perfect language of seduction. Choreographers have always known this, but film directors are increasingly discovering dancing -- social dancing -- as a sure way to steer couples into the bedroom. Stirring and exposing feelings so quickly, dancing pre-empts the brain's job of weighing the evidence and making judgments.

title: VOWS;Ingrid Alexander, Kolbjorn Skipnes
description: EVEN in the age of cellular phones, Dr. Ingrid Catherine Alexander and Kolbjorn Skipnes are not exactly the type of people who can always be easily reached.

title: Body Parts Found On Subway Tracks
description: Transit workers found a hand and a foot early yesterday on subway tracks in Park Slope, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: DOGBOY By Gillian White. Orion/Trafalgar Square, $26.

title: THE NATION;Did the Fears Vanish, Like Magic?
description: WITH Michael Jordan behind him for now, Magic Johnson will confront another former nemesis tonight in Los Angeles at the Great Western Forum. His name is Karl Malone. The matchup of these two 6-foot-9-inch power forwards promises to be a fascinating struggle, considering that Mr. Johnson backed away from Mr. Malone's last challenge more than three years ago.

title: Spain Is Haunted by Basque Death Squad Scandal
description: It was in the summer of 1983 when Jose Amedo realized that his superiors in the secret police were planning something out of the ordinary.

title: Too Many People
description: To the Editor:

title: School Districts Upset By Pataki Budget Plans
description: AT a time when school districts are experiencing increasing enrollments and decreasing revenues, Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed cuts in the state education budget are expected to compromise the ability of superintendents to maintain instruction and other services at present levels without raising property taxes -- a move that could be restricted by some of the Governor's proposals.

title: The Battle of the Drug Trade in Fair Haven
description: JOE PETTOLA, a New Haven police detective, can remember a Fair Haven that lived up to its name. In the late 1950's and early 60's, when he was growing up there, the neighborhood in northeastern New Haven was pleasant and peaceful.

title: WEDDINGS;Stefanie M. Ilgenfritz, Scott H. Griff
description: Stefanie Margaret Ilgenfritz, a daughter of Erika and James Ilgenfritz 2d of Monroe, Mich., was married last evening to Scott Harrison Griff, a son of Merilyn Griff of Fort Lee, N.J., and David Griff of Paris. Judge Debra A. James of Civil Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony at the New York Academy of Sciences.

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;Hutcheson First Task For Derby Favorite
description: Unbridled's Song, the favorite for the Kentucky Derby, will take his first steps on the road to Louisville next Sunday when he races four opponents in the Hutcheson Stakes at Gulfstream Park.

title: U.S. WARNS CHINA OVER VIOLATIONS OF TRADE ACCORD
description: Despite concerns about Washington's already tense relationship with Beijing, the Clinton Administration has warned China that it risks the imposition of stiff economic sanctions in the next few months because Beijing has ignored previous warnings and continues to violate a key trade agreement signed a year ago.

title: RESTAURANTS;Everything Shipshape
description: THE men around us are wearing business suits and wire-rimmed glasses. They look prosperous -- which you need to be to afford dinner at the Frog and the Peach -- but also slightly countercultural. They probably appreciate the industrial look of the gutted factory in which the restaurant is located, as well as the lush, silken curtains, the primitive murals and the state-of-the-art restroom sink (no need to fuss with any fixtures; when it senses your presence, the water simply flows).

title: New Month, Same Forecast
description: February is debuting with a new storm forecast for today and tommorrow, although the accumulation is not expected to rival last month's blizzard. Already this winter, more than 40 inches fell in Central Park.

title: Appeals Judge Says Colleagues Are Not Being Soft on Criminals
description: A judge on New York State's highest court lashed out at state officials yesterday, saying the court is not soft on criminals, as Gov. George E. Pataki, Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco and other critics have complained recently.

title: COVER STORY;The Evil Francis Urguhart Returns
description: Few traits are more rewarding to act than villainy. For proof, just ask Ian Richardson, who was a notable Richard III in 1975 for the Royal Shakespeare Company and has been enlivening television screens on both sides of the Atlantic over the last several years as the fictional Conservative Party prime minister Francis Urquhart, a political evildoer in the Richard mode.

title: POP MUSIC;The Sorry State Of New York Radio
description: POP MUSIC Correction: February 4, 1996, Sunday An article on page 28 of the Arts and Leisure section today about music shows on radio in New York City misidentifies the station on which "The New Afternoon Show" is broadcast. It is WNYU, not WNYC.

title: PERSPECTIVES;New Residential Space Arrives in Lower Manhattan
description: BEFORE the year is over, about 1,000 apartments are expected to be in construction in older office and commercial buildings in lower Manhattan. Developers are taking advantage of relaxed zoning regulations and new tax incentives aimed at assisting economically stagnant properties and bringing in more round-the-clock occupancy.

title: Let It Snow
description: To the Editor:

title: SOCCER;At African Cup, South Africa Revels in Another Title
description: Sweet victory came to South Africa in the African Cup of Nations today, and with it, two side effects: a few hours of perfect racial harmony, and The Wave.

title: WINTER OF '96: THE REACTION;In a City Gone Numb, an Overachieving Winter Piles It On Once More
description: Where some saw an endless wait in an arctic breeze, David Millman saw only opportunity.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Duke's Krzyzewski Likes His Underdogs
description: The No. 24 Clemson basketball team traveled through snow and ice to arrive at Cameron Indoor Stadium on a bus called "The Good News Express." But Clemson's arrival today turned out to be good news for Duke, as the Blue Devils took control early and coasted to an 83-53 victory.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;Grand Central as a Hearth In the Heart of the City
description: GRAND CENTRAL TERMINAL is getting a sex change. There are probably more delicate ways to characterize the $100 million project to overhaul the historic station, which officially got under way last week. But to gloss over the issue of 'rchitectural gender-bending would be to miss the big story behind what's going on at Grand Central, New York's most cherished landmark, and in many other projects around town as well.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Turbulence, and Some Victories, Too
description: Because Reggie Miller and his teammates knocked them out of the playoffs last season, the Knicks are prepared to use the Indiana Pacers as their most accurate measuring stick midway through the season.

title: Neighborhood Report;Pickle Place at Pinnacle Pretties Up
description: As recently as 20 years ago, Essex Street between Grand and Hester Streets had four pickle stores. Today, only one remains: Essex Street Pickles, and it is being renovated, modernized. A concrete floor is replacing the wooden one. But the "Please Keep Your Hands Out of Barrels" sign is staying put.

title: Culture Clash in Pyongyang
description: YOU must walk faster!" the North Korean interpreter shouted at me and 20 other American, British and Japanese tourists as we strolled toward an ancient tomb outside Pyongyang. "There are many things to see in Korea and you have very little time! So, you must walk fast. In fact, you must RUN!"

title: 1897 Castle Redone for 1990's Entertaining
description: HOW to renovate a castle while preserving its magnificent stone exterior and splendid interior is the challenge facing the new owners of one of the few authentic castles left in the Hudson Valley.

title: Neighborhood Report;Madison Ave.: Ever Chichi, Soon Safer
description: Madison Avenue ranks among the world's premier shopping streets. Fashionable and famous emporiums like Polo, Armani and Barneys draw the rich and the recognized, as do the avenue's art galleries and restaurants. Rents for retail space are in league with those for stores on Fifth Avenue, 57th Street and the Ginza in Tokyo.

title: LIVES;Nana and the Anchormen
description: As the V-chip legislation makes its way through Congress -- requiring televisions to come equipped with devices enabling parents to block out violent programs -- I would like to propose an addendum: the C-chip, which would prevent CNN, C-Span and all other news and public affairs programming from appearing on my grandmother's television. Just as the V-chip is supposed to keep children from watching so much barbarous behavior that they become little sociopaths, the C-chip will keep grandparents from absorbing so much data that they become pathologically well informed.

title: Massachusetts Governor a Tough Rival for Senator Kerry
description: While it swept across most other parts of the country, the Republican revolution of 1994 spared Massachusetts. Not a single incumbent Democrat in Congress lost, leaving unchanged the state's reputation as one of the most left-leaning in the nation.

title: IN THE KITCHEN;Lesser-Known Pasta Cuts, Novel and Chewy
description: IN THE KITCHEN Correction: February 18, 1996, Sunday

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Psychiatric Tests For Graf's Father
description: According to his lawyer, PETER GRAF will undergo psychiatric tests in his German jail cell to determine whether he can plead diminished responsibility on tax-evasion charges.

title: STREET SMARTS;A Lesson From the Playground
description: THE tiny tots who run, jump and play at Discovery Zone have a lot of experience with the company's slides. There's the bouncy foam-rubber one. There's another made up of wooden rods. And, of course, don't forget that old favorite, the covered tunnel slide.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Jan. 28 - Feb. 3;Oregon's Mail-In Senator
description: If liberal Democrats are indeed the dinosaurs of the 1990's political landscape, somebody forget to tell the voters in Oregon. Concluding a three-week-long vote-by-mail, the first of its kind in the nation, Oregonians on Tuesday elected Representative Ron Wyden, a Democrat known for his consumer and health-care crusades, to fill the seat vacated by Bob Packwood.

title: In the Region/New Jersey;Gauging the Impact on Housing of AT&T's Layoffs
description: AT&T's plan to split into three smaller companies and cut up to 7,000 employees in New Jersey is another hard knock for the state's housing industry, which ended 1995 on a downward spiral.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Bradley, the Author: A Sense of Where He Is
description: Jesse Helms does not come off well in Bill Bradley's new book, "Time Present, Time Past" (Knopf), but he isn't exactly slam-dunked either, as one might expect considering that the two senators have found little in politics or ideology to agree upon. How come?

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Kotite Contacts Erhardt About Working for Jets
description: After reviewing the worst season in Jets history, Coach Rich Kotite has decided that the first change he will make is to remove himself as the team's play caller.

title: He Tends the Green Stuff at the Zoo
description: SOME people look at retirement as a time to relax. They take long vacations, play with their grandchildren, take up golf. But not Carl Cortucci. The 83-year old Bridgeport resident's focus in retirement is a zoo.

title: A LIFE IN PIECES;For du Pont Heir, Question Was Control
description: Along one wall of his indoor swimming pool, John Eleuthere du Pont had mounted a mosaic as Olympic-sized as the pool itself. Made of a million pieces and imported from Florence, the mosaic depicts Mr. du Pont in the various disciplines of the modern pentathlon -- running, swimming, horseback riding, shooting and fencing.

title: Prayer Wasn't Issue in Child's Wrongful Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Lesser Charge To Be Pursued Over Killing
description: In a case that has stirred passions and accusations of racial bias, murder charges against a San Francisco man accused of killing a bicyclist with a single punch have been reduced to manslaughter after prosecutors acknowledged that the evidence did not support the more severe charge.

title: Beethoven Back, Wit' Bells, Smoke, Lights and Whistles
description: FRESH from lunch and full of a "down-home country feeling and shiitake mushrooms," as he put it, David Alan Miller, music director of the Albany Symphony Orchestra and a finalist for the position of music director of the Long Island Philharmonic, was both live on the wire from his home in Albany and a very live wire himself.

title: Scientific Sleuths Hope to Track Pollutants to Their Sources
description: A plain-looking package addressed to scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology arrives every few months. Inside, there is a vial containing a sample for the institute's powerful electron microscope.

title: Feeling Bad? Get Better!
description: SAVING FACE America and the Politics of Shame. By Stuart Schneiderman. 325 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25. THE WILDING OF AMERICA How Greed and Violence Are Eroding Our Nation's Character. By Charles Derber. 181 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $22.95.

title: FRENCH CULTURE;Fertile Ground For Serious Art
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Bruce Giacoma Jr., Laura Salmonson
description: Laura Ann Salmonson, a daughter of Stephanie Bethke of Denver and John F. Salmonson of Fresno, Calif., was married yesterday to Bruce Monell Giacoma Jr., the son of Elizabeth Giacoma of Port Washington, L.I., and Mr. Giacoma of New York. The Rev. Geoffrey Quinn performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Denver.

title: SUNDAY February 4, 1996: Keep America Beautiful;CHEWING UP THE SCENERY
description: Public smoking is out; gum chewing is in. When the flavor's gone, though, gum has to go somewhere, and it's usually the sidewalk and then the shoes. But as with so many other sticking points of life, someone has now emerged who thinks he can clean up on it.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;15 Faberge Easter Eggs To Be Shown at the Met
description: Fifteen of the 44 extant imperial Easter eggs created by the legendary goldsmith Peter Carl Faberge for the last Russian czars, and selected from the greatest American collections of the artist's work, will be among more than 400 objects on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York beginning Feb. 16. "Faberge in America" will start the first national tour of these collections, focusing on the social history of American collecting during a 100-year period that witnessed a growing fascination with imperial Russia. The exhibition, which runs through April 28, will coincide with the 150th anniversary of Faberge's birth.

title: Bosnia Industries Find Big Obstacles to Recovery
description: Sulejman Sadic intends to start making jams, jellies and other fruit products at the Fructal Frigos plant here by June 1.

title: Neighborhood Report;Zoning Change May Lead to Renewal of East 14th St.
description: For years, 14th Street and Third Avenue has been a seedy crossroad at which people drink wine from bottles with twist-off caps, nod out on the corner and visit pornography shops and grocery stores that don't seem to stock any food.

title: An Outlaw in Cyberspace
description: THE CYBERTHIEF AND THE SAMURAI By Jeff Goodell. 328 pp. New York: Dell. Paper, $5.99.

title: MAILBOX;National League D.H.
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ATLANTIC CITY;At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

title: From Superstar Model To Lifelike Mannequin
description: ONE could see it as the perfect way for a supermodel to achieve immortality: have a mannequin made in her own image. But for the legendary Veruschka, it was just another way to do what she has always done: use her statuesque figure to explore new artistic forms.

title: On Cape Verde, Carnival Is Down to Earth
description: COME Carnival time, news broadcasts around the globe show a whirl of crowds and floats and bikinis and beads. But only on the local news in the Cape Verde Islands can one see pictures of little boys covered in mud. There have never been enough policemen to keep order at Carnival, so crowd control is left to mud boys who sprint along the sidelines, smearing anyone who gets in the way of the parade.

title: MUSIC;Sounds of Other Cultures for the Here and Now
description: PETER SCHICKELE opens his weekly radio show by announcing its premise that "all musics are created equal." New Jersey concertgoers can make their own judgment about that on Friday, when they have their choice of two out-of-the-ordinary musical events: Princeton Pro Musica's "Festival of Early Mesoamerican Civilizations" and Women of the Calabash, which opens Fairleigh Dickinson University's semesterlong series called Close Encounters With Music Around the World.

title: Not by Men Alone
description: THE SEASONS OF A WOMAN'S LIFE By Daniel J. Levinson in collaboration with Judy D. Levinson. 438 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50. BOOKS on adult development have attained great popularity during the past two decades because they offer precisely the same kind of reassurance as child development manuals: If my child is throwing temper tantrums, she's just going through the Terrible 2's. . . . If I'm awakened by a nightmare about my own death, I must be entering the Fearful 50's. . . . It's just a stage.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Ellis Given Award
description: LARRY ELLIS, president of USA Track & Field and the former Princeton track coach, was honored last night with the Fred Lebow Special Achievement Award for 1995. Ellis received the award at the Metropolitan Athletics Congress's annual dinner. Also honored were the M.A.C. 1995 athletes of the year ALISA HILL and ATO BALDON in track, and SONJA FITTS and LOU CHISARI in field.

title: IN THE GARDEN;Orchid-Growing Isn't Always Hard
description: AN orchid plant might be construed as one of nature's miracles. For many months, it is an ugly duckling with unattractive leaves and stringy roots. Then, suddenly, the plant blooms. It becomes a swan.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD;UPPER WEST SIDE
description: 'Our Children': Dancing In Search of Identity

title: Neighborhood Report;Feared Projects Arrive. Residents Survive.
description: It was a Nimby issue that sundered a neighborhood. A housing group, HELP, founded by Andrew Cuomo built a 12-story apartment building for 94 homeless and low-income families on East 13th Street. Neighbors protested that the project would be a "vertical ghetto" on their block, but to no avail. Then they sued.

title: Rights, Ethics and a Chimp With AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Jan. 28 - Feb. 3;A Taste of Ashes in Venice
description: A day after the fire that destroyed the Fenice opera house in Venice, all of Italy was pledging to restore the 18th cenutry building whose name, after all, means Phoenix in Italian. But the solemn vows did little to ease the shame many felt at what Riccardo Muti, conductor at Milan's La Scala opera house, called "a tragedy all'Italiana." How could such a building, one month away from reopening after a seven-month restoration, burn to the ground in a city like Venice, which is surrounded by water, and densely packed with art treasures? If there had been a night watchman on duty, if the nearby canals had not been drained, blocking access to patrol boats, if Venice had proper fire hydrants, then maybe the fire at the Fenice would not have been so dramatic, and the loss not so devastating. CELESTINE BOHLEN

title: Jan. 28 - Feb. 3;Newly Declassified: $2 Billion
description: The secret agency that builds spy satellites kept a secret from itself: the whereabouts of more than $2 billion of its own classified funds.

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 21 about crime in the county misstated the percentage increase of all reported crimes in Bronxville. It was 3.6 percent for 1995 -- not 39 percent, which was the increase in larcenies there for the first 10 months of the year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 7 about living in Lloyd Harbor, L.I., misstated the relationship of Jupiter Hammon to the Joseph Lloyd Manor House. Hammon, the first published black poet in America, was a slave who lived in the house in the late 18th century; he did not own it.

title: How Many Is Too Many Children?;No Laughing Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: Lots of du Ponts, Fewer Super-Rich Ones
description: Tracking du Ponts in America can be an imprecise pursuit, since many lines of the family are as prolific as they are rich.

title: ART;This Video Artist Runs With the Wolves
description: IN KOREA LAST FALL, THE Los Angeles video artist Diana Thater was presented with a solid-gold key, second prize in the newly founded Kwangju Biennale. This winter, she said, "I had to hock the key to pay the rent."

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Vox Populist;Just Regular Ruling-Class Guys
description: THE most striking thing about Steve Forbes's rapid rise from the protected bubble of his corporate jet, the Capitalist Tool, to the turbulence of life as the hot Republican Presidential commodity is what his opponents are not saying about him.

title: Postings: A Kiosk for the Fashion Center;Who's Got The Button?
description: The Fashion Center Information Kiosk is to open this spring in front of 555 Seventh Avenue, on the northeast corner of 39th Street. The 15- by 15-foot kiosk will stand only a few yards from a symbol of the area's earlier era -- "The Garment Worker,"a 1984 sculpture by Judith Weller of a tailor wearing a yarmulke bent over a pedal-run sewing machine. A florist is now on the kiosk site.

title: Sweeping the House
description: Storming the Gates Protest Politics and the Republican Revival. By Dan Balz and Ronald Brownstein. 424 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

title: YOUR HOME;Solving City Hall's Labyrinth
description: ON Jan. 21 this column described recent amendments to two New York City programs designed to provide benefits to elderly residents -- the Senior Citizens Rent Increase Exemption Program (Scrie), which provides exemptions from rent increases, and the Senior Citizens Homeowners Exemption Program (SCHE), which partially exempts certain property owners and co-op shareholders from property tax increases.

title: Discovering An Answer In the Flames
description: In 1913, a fire of mysterious origin gutted Jack London's newly constructed house, which had been built to last a thousand years in this wooded hamlet north of San Francisco. Only the rock walls were left standing.

title: Unheavenly Kingdom
description: God's Chinese Son The Taiping Heavenly Kingdom of Hong Xiuquan. By Jonathan D. Spence. 400 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $27.50.

title: LIVING TOO LONG
description: My never-married twin aunts helped my mother to raise my brother and me. They were our second parents, loving us unconditionally and, in a way, fulfilling their own maternal needs. We relied on them. So did our mother, who died suddenly.

title: FRUGAL TRAVELER;In Mexico, Beaches, Inns, Scorpions
description: FRUGAL TRAVELER Correction: March 24, 1996, Sunday

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Amid Defensive Pressure, Nets Showing More Poise And a Newfound Attitude
description: After an initial getting-to-know-you period, the new-look Nets believe they are coming together with a new attitude for a New Jersey team. As Exhibit A, they point to Friday night's 93-84 victory here over the Vancouver Grizzlies at G.M. Place.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Funds Watch column last Sunday referred incorrectly to a new account fee at the Janus Group. If an account balance falls below new required minimums because of a withdrawal by an investor, Janus will levy a $10 fee once a year, not monthly.

title: FOOD;Pasta Cuts That Are Novel and Chewy
description: SOME less common cuts of dried pasta can vary the spaghetti-linguine menu. They are increasingly available in supermarkets. And Italian pasta stores and specialty food markets are sure to carry them.

title: Putting Drama Back Into Shakespeare Class
description: ON a stormy winter afternoon whose natural atmospheric effects of blustery gales and raging rains seemed more suited to a staging of "The Tempest" than almost any other Shakespearean play, a group of two dozen ninth-grade students at Pelham Memorial High School here clustered in small groups on the bare auditorium stage to act out scenes from "Twelfth Night."

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: DIARY
description: UNSHACKLING Oh, Brave New World . . . Call it the ultimate test of the benefits of competition. Congress finally sorted out its disagreements and passed a bill intended to promote a free-for-all among cable television and broadcasting companies, local and long-distance phone companies and who knows what from the realm of cyberspace. Each of them will be able to offer services now provided by the others. The bill's enthusiasts (only 16 members of the House and 5 senators voted against the bill) and the companies themselves say Americans will have more choices, and companies will compete through lower rates and better service. "We have broken up two of the biggest government monopolies left: local telephone service and cable TV," crowed Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr. of Virginia, who managed the bill through the House. Consumers Union, however, predicted that cable television rates would rise, and others worried about what impact the concentration of power in the broadcasting business would have on local ownership and program content.

title: Prayer Wasn't Issue in Child's Wrongful Death
description: To the Editor: Stephen L. Carter (Op-Ed, Jan. 31), lamenting the Supreme Court's decision not to review the tort liability of a Christian Science mother for killing her child, pushes his anti-anti-religious case too far.

title: Questions Swirl Around Greystone's Ills
description: On New Year's Day, a 27-year-old patient escaped from a high-security ward at Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital. The patient, Lin Hong, who was admitted to the hospital in 1990, after he was charged with stabbing a teen-age girl, remains on the loose and is considered dangerous.

title: World News Briefs;Nigerian Publisher Wounded by Gunmen
description: The publisher of Nigeria's leading independent newspaper, The Guardian, has been shot and seriously wounded, the newspaper said today.

title: Anonymous? Not Me.
description: If you didn't write 'Primary Colors,' then why are you denying it on TV so much?" is the most frequently asked question in Washington these days. This is the new novel whose plot distinctly resembles the 1992 Clinton campaign. The book was signed Anonymous, the author with the very, very airbrushed jacket photo.

title: WEDDINGS;Elizabeth Sigler, C. E. Mather 4th
description: Elizabeth Mary Sigler, a vice president of Robinson Lerer Sawyer Miller, a public relations company in New York, was married yesterday to Charles E. Mather 4th, a vice president of the investment banking division at Smith Barney in New York. The Rev. William Pindar performed the ceremony at Central Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Mild Side of Five Points Is Old News to Historians
description: To the Editor:

title: IN BRIEF;New Trash-Hauling Rules May Not Help at Home
description: Since the early 1980's, New Jersey's garbage industry has been tightly controlled by laws requiring haulers to take all trash to county utility authorities, which charge rates set by the state. This week, the market began to open under a Federal court ruling that lets haulers take construction and demolition waste to cheaper out-of-state landfills.

title: HOCKEY;Mile-High Rangers Come Crashing Down to Earth
description: So much for the Rangers being unbeaten in 1996. After a perfect January, they began February today with a humiliating defeat at the McNichols Sports Arena.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY;Once Upon a Time in the Northwest
description: Hollywood is sure to ruin SHOOT! (St. Martin's, $22.95), an absorbing, panoramic novel set in the waning Wild West days of British Columbia. It's that good: intricately plotted, meticulously researched and shaded with nuance. In "Shoot!" the Canadian poet and novelist George Bowering tells the story of four young men whose Indian mothers and white fathers earn them the dismissive status of half-breeds. Caught between two cultures that neither understand nor accept them, the boys tumble self-destructively from petty thievery to murder. With page after page of thundering hoofbeats, shoot-outs and blood-red sunsets, Shoot! does the western genre proud. But what truly distinguishes this novel is Mr. Bowering's unflinching examination of bigotry and intolerance, which seems as relevant to today's world as to that of the 1870's. Steady doses of wit and adventure help his brusque prose recover from occasional didactic detours, and a spiraling narrative structure gives the old-fashioned setting some post-modern flair. If nothing else, discovering the source of its deceptively hee-haw title is reason enough to tempt plenty of curious readers. Liam Callahan

title: WEDDINGS;Virginia Handal, Thomas Miller
description: Virginia Margaret Handal, a daughter of Mrs. Joseph F. Handal of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Handal, was married yesterday to Thomas James Miller, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Miller. The Rev. Louis Jerome performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Fatima in Scarsdale.

title: Where to Write or Call for Information
description: Abercrombie & Kent International, 1520 Kensington Road, Suite 212, Oak Brook, Ill. 60521; (708) 954-2944 or (800) 323-7308 outside Illinois.

title: Who's Pre-eminent Church Designer?
description: To the Editor:

title: Word for Word/There You Go Again;But Seriously, Folks, He Was Funnier Than Nixon
description: IT'S not every former President who has a chance to be a multimedia sensation, especially one who counted among his most humbling experiences a confrontation with a kindergarten computer class. "There they all sat in front of their computers," Ronald Reagan told a group of Republican women in 1984. "Finally, the one I was sitting beside said, 'Well, go ahead and push the button.' I was scared to death."

title: In the Region/Long Island;'Stick-Builts' or Modulars Are Offered at Same Price
description: BUYERS of single-family detached houses to rise on a 35-acre site in Coram will be offered a choice by the Windemere Development Corporation of Bay Shore -- "stick-built" on-site construction or modular homes.

title: Westchester Q&A: Todd Hallinger;Early Birds Get Their Business Leads
description: ONCE a week at 7 A.M. on various days at various places in Westchester, groups of business people are getting together, drinking coffee and -- more important -- exchanging leads.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;Assessing Ships' Medical Care
description: NO international or industrywide regulations and few national ones currently govern the care of sick or injured passengers on cruise ships. For the first time, however, the major trade group of the cruise industry is considering setting standards for medical care aboard its vessels.

title: THE WORLD;A Duchess: Her Life In Debt
description: THE Duchess of York, the estranged wife of Queen Elizabeth's second son, Andrew, can't help getting into scrapes.
