A couple of years ago, sometime after she and the Duke separated, her financial adviser was photographed sucking her toes at an exclusive villa; the duchess was topless. In December, $500,000 worth of diamonds given to her by her mother-in-law was stolen at Kennedy Airport because the Duchess, hurrying to board her Concorde flight home, neglected to put them in her carry-on bag (they were later recovered).

title: Closed-End Funds: A Tough '95
description: LAST year the stock market soared, the bond market boomed and mutual funds took in more cash than they knew what to do with.

title: Q.& A.;Defining Forms of Ownership
description: Q How is owning property by the entirety different from owning it by joint tenancy or by tenancy in common? . . . Marcian E. Ferdinand, the Bronx.

title: SOAPBOX: Maestro, and More;Remembering Henry Lewis, Alight With Intensity
description: I AM known as a basso profundo, but Henry Lewis made me feel like a tenor. He had one of the deepest and most impressive speaking voices of anyone I have ever met. But everything about him was impressive: his intense, charismatic personality, his boundless energy and his superior musical talent.

title: THEATER;'The Amen Corner' In New Haven Revival
description: THE AMEN CORNER" at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven is a useful revival for two reasons. One is important. The other is momentous. Seret Scott's staging of one of only two plays by James Baldwin (1924-1987) allows for a rare re-examination of a voice of eloquence and influence.

title: Leader of Peru Won't Intervene for American
description: The President of Peru said today that he would not intervene in the case of a New York woman who has been convicted of treason for associating with a terrorist group and sentenced to life in prison.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: CHILLS, anyone? There are some surprising scene stealers in a batch of suspense films on television this week.

title: DINING OUT;A New Steakhouse With Some Potential
description: JUST a few years ago, new restaurants and Italian restaurants were nearly synonymous on Long Island. But lately the odds have shifted and the newcomer is just as likely to be an American steakhouse.

title: Uniforms: Public Schools Stand Up and Salute
description: SCHOOL uniforms, the bane of generations of students whose parents marched them unhappily off to class in off-the-rack ensembles of blazers, jumpers, skirts, shirts and ties, are in the midst of a revival. Really.

title: Stay on Their Backs
description: DELIGHTFUL FAIRY TALE HAS TAKEN HOLD LATELY IN SOME economic policy circles. After decades of inflation, slow growth and stagnant wages, the story goes, a restructured United States economy is poised for a glorious burst of sustained, 60's-style growth without inflation. It's a tale told by a spectrum of influential figures -- conservatives like Steve Forbes, the neo-Reaganite candidate, and Robert Bartley, editor of The Wall Street Journal, and liberal luminaries like the economist Lester Thurow and the financier-pundit Felix Rohatyn, who has recently been mentioned as a candidate for vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Like most good fairy tales, this one features a horrible monster who is blocking the path to eternal happiness. That would be Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, which controls the nation's money supply. The evil Greenspan and his colleagues, blinded by their obsession with inflation, cannot see that the economic terrain has shifted, that the economy can now grow much faster than previously without risking more inflation. Thus, to slay the inflation dragon, the Fed is keeping interest rates unnecessarily high, in a pointless war against a phantom enemy.

description: An American soldier was killed today when he stepped on a land mine in the American-controlled sector of northern Bosnia. He was the first American serviceman to die in Bosnia since the NATO-led peacekeeping mission began in December.

title: ART;An American Tour With Haunting Perspectives by Eli Reed

title: ON THE JOB;That First Job
description: Sure, you draw a hefty salary and have minions to do your bidding. Or at least hope to, soon. But as you buff that big nameplate, do you ever reminisce about your first real job -- those less exalted but often entertaining stints as an errand runner, house sitter or caterer's assistant? If you do, and the memories make you smile or cringe, send your story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: The Unknown Sundance, in Unlikely Places
description: ''WHEN THE FESTIVAL ends we have an intense post-mortem," Robert Redford said as the Sundance Film Festival headed toward its close last weekend. "First, we take a week off because everyone's fried. Then we have a retreat and ask: 'What happened this year? What worked? What went wrong?' "

description: STORIES come naturally to Cindy Brown-Austin. How could they not, she having once lived next door to a woman named Tomcat and to a man named Dr. Buzzard who threw gambling parties that lasted all night long.

description: Siberia's wilderness contains half of the Earth's conifers and is a habitat for rare tigers and other species. If a group of American entrepreneurs and their Russian partners have their way, something even more unusual may be found there: factories where logs would be bombarded with pest-killing gamma rays so the pest-free timber could be exported to American sawmills.

description: Even in world-class gymnastics, 13 is a little young for retirement.

The contest was limited to central Brooklyn; it was not citywide. The sponsor was the Central Brooklyn Martin Luther King Commission.

description: At a time when the Federal Government is squeezing many social programs, the veterans medical center here, on a serene 400-acre campus on Chesapeake Bay, has opened a cozy new refuge for people like Stanford Avant.

description: "Red -- Color/Metaphor" Wisser Library, N.Y. Institute of Technology, Northern Blvd., Old Westbury. Through Friday. 686-7657.

description: IN warmer weather, when Alan Hochberg looks out his window he can see a tractor tilling the land on a farm across the street from his home in Hartsdale, a hamlet in the Town of Greenburgh.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;Intimate Expressionism
description: In the appropriately titled essay "A Long View" in HOWARD HODGKIN PAINTINGS (Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth/Abrams, $39.95), Michael Auping, the chief curator at the Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth, traces the development of Mr. Hodgkin's career, asserting that the English artist's earliest work established the essential elements that have preoccupied him for some 40 years -- the representation of figures in an interior space and the depiction of memory, for example. A brilliant colorist whose work is often seen as falling somewhere between representation and abstraction, Mr. Hodgkin "does not allow illustration to interfere with the making of a painting," Mr. Auping writes. "Memory and metaphor are his preferred terrain." Mr. Auping finds that Mr. Hodgkin's paintings of the last two decades have forged the unlikely pairing of Intimism and Expressionism from wildly diverse influences like Henri Matisse, douard Vuillard, Barnett Newman, Jackson Pollock, Jasper Johns and Willem de Kooning. Or as the cultural critic Susan Sontag puts it in her illuminating meditation: "Hodgkin has understood that if the pictures are dense enough, they can go in two directions, doing justice to intimate textures as well as to emotions of a large expressiveness. (Both Vuillard and opera, so to speak.)" Along with 80 color illustrations are an erudite and informative epistolary exchange between Mr. Hodgkin and John Elderfield, the chief curator at large at the Museum of Modern Art, and the first catalogue raisonn of Mr. Hodgkin's oil paintings, compiled by Marla Price, the director of the Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth. Robin Lippincott

description: FOR years, the Harkness Atrium near Lincoln Center has had city planners climbing the walls. Under a proposed renovation, the public would be able to join in.

title: ON CAMPUS;For State Colleges, Whitman Has Good News, Bad News
description: When Governor Whitman presented a new budget last week, officials at New Jersey's public colleges and universities did not know whether to sigh with relief or sulk. Most of the 12 schools will not lose any state support, and they will be able to provide financial aid to an extra 2,600 students next year. But there was an unexpected wrinkle: the state plans to withhold $53 million from a fund for wages and benefits, leaving the colleges with a hefty expense.

During that time the burgeoning news program has covered Metro-North Commuter Railroad delays, the Blizzard of '96 and the multitude of school and business closings that followed in Fairfield County.

Even now, fingers are being pointed over who broke the law first, who struck the first blow and delivered the first kick, whose civil rights were ultimately violated and, as always, who has a greater claim as history's victim.

If beating the fourth-ranked Connecticut Huskies meant dragging them down to the level of the Red Storm, St. John's could deal with that.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;And Now, Some Spanish Music From, of All Places, Spain
description: ALTHOUGH SPAIN HAS A RICH, distinctive and varied musical tradition, based in folk idioms and embracing Gypsy and Arabic influences, it is probably best known abroad through the work of composers from other countries, like Bizet. Its snaky chromaticism, doleful modalities and urgent rhythmic complexities are instantly recognizable as Spanish. Yet even Spain's most famous composer, Manuel de Falla, is known merely through a handful of works, the zarzuela "La Vida Breve," the ballets "El Amor Brujo" and "The Three-Cornered Hat," and the concert work "Nights in the Gardens of Spain."

title: ARCHITECTURE;Luck, a Little Bad With the Good, Has Been Her Constant Companion
description: NEARLY ALL SUCCESSful violin soloists begin at a tender age, when other children are still playing stickball. Images that come to mind are of small, spectral children: Yehudi Menuhin in his velvet Little Lord Fauntleroy jacket, Midori in knee socks and patent-leather Mary Janes. But Pamela Frank has never had need of a pigtail: a robustly healthy woman of 28, she has created a major international career that did not begin until she was old enough to vote.

title: Changing Guard at Apple: The Board Says 'Enough'
description: On a late afternoon last fall the chief executive of Apple Computer Inc. stood dejectedly in the office of a longtime friend at 3000 Sand Hill Road, a venture-capital enclave in Silicon Valley's nerve center, and complained that at age 52 he was a burned-out man.

description: Pat Buchanan looks alarmingly cuddly in his new ad.

title: Jan. 28 - Feb. 3;La Bombe Est Fini
description: Denounced around the world for his decision to resume French nuclear testing last year, French President Jacques Chirac stopped it for good last week after six underground tests in French Polynesia. Mr. Chirac said that only six tests had been needed, instead of seven to eight as originally planned, to ensure the reliability of a new submarine-launched missile warhead and to gather data needed to do testing by computer simulation only.

title: COPING;My Diet Progress Report: 3.4 Lbs., a Start
description: The okay news and the good news was the same; after four weeks as a card-carrying member of Weight Watchers, I had lost 3.4 pounds, most of it probably the water pushed out of my system by all the water I drank. While it was not the six-to-ten pounds of saturated fats I might have lost with true "portion awareness", it was still not the five pounds I usually pack on, like fanny bags, this time of year. So, in the creative accountancy of fatties, I could figure an 8.4 pound loss. If you don't understand this, lucky civilian, you probably have stale cookies around, left-over left overs in the fridge.

title: STAGE VIEW;In Celebrity Theater, Icons Rule
description: THE PAINTER, THE PHYSICIST AND THE inventor of a very hard substance called Schmendimite walk into a bar. "Picasso, Einstein and Schmendiman. Somehow it doesn't have a ring," says the barfly Gaston, wittily noting the obvious in Steve Martin's smart hit play, "Picasso at the Lapin Agile." In a theater season with an unusual number of celebrity biographies -- from a dead superstar like Maria Callas to an evolving historical figure like Richard Nixon -- the Schmendimans of the world don't stand a chance.

title: ART;In 70's Deja Vu, Drawing Returns as a Quirky End in Itself

description: President Clinton's budget for the 1997 fiscal year will propose a 3 percent pay raise for Federal employees, less than workers wanted.

title: TECHNOLOGY VIEW;The Incredible Shrinking Sound of Home Theater
description: WHETHER YOU CALL IT home theater or home cinema, the idea is the same: to bring to the living room the sensory impact, visual and aural, that you experience at the movies. The key word here is "impact." Mark it well. It is a reference point to keep in mind as the audio industry, exploiting the popularity of home theater, presses its advantage toward an ever wider market with ever smaller (and cheaper) surround-sound loudspeaker systems. In the new vogue for "home theater in a box," one envisions a reductio ad absurdum: the visceral power of cinema sound diminished to the scale of a shoe box.

title: U.N.-Led Team Uncovers Grave in Bosnia

description: To the Editor:

title: Political Memo;Mayor Faces Tough Task In Showing His Soft Side
description: To hear Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his advisers tell it, there's nothing new about the New Rudy. The benevolent and warmhearted city father presented to New York in recent weeks -- the one who puts children first and cuts the police force -- was there all along, just veiled, reluctantly, behind other priorities.

title: IN THE GARDEN;Is Orchid-Growing Difficult? Not Necessarily
description: AN orchid plant might be construed as one of nature's miracles. For many months, it is an ugly duckling with unattractive leaves and stringy roots. Then, suddenly, the plant blooms. It becomes a swan.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: THE FENNEL FAMILY PAPERS By William Baldwin. Algonquin, $19.95.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: GOLF;Women on the Green
description: Women who play golf have to put up with a lot, from male golfers' condescension to being shut out of the best tee times at many country clubs. But the four Carefree Resorts' hotels are trying to eliminate the wrong kind of handicaps for women. Carefree's Women to the Fore, (800) 979-2999, includes refresher courses, equipment rentals and equal access to tee times. The resorts are the Boulders, Carefree, Ariz.; the Peaks, Telluride, Colo.; Carmel Valley Ranch, Carmel, Calif., and the Lodge at Ventana Canyon, Tucson. JOSEPH SIANO

title: From Runway To Health Spa At Men's Shows
description: THE New York Men's Shows -- four days of testosterone-laced presentations of fall fashions -- sweep into town today, and participants are likely to discover two new wrinkles in the stylish mix of money, models and motifs.

title: FRENCH CULTURE;Why All Those Expatriates?
description: To the Editor:

title: BENEFITSA Family Benefit WEDNESDAY -- The Metropolitan Museum of Art will hold its fourth annual Family Benefit evening from 6 to 8. Activities will include storytelling, jewelry making and treasure hunts. Tickets, $75, or $35 for children 15 and under, from  (212) 570-3948.
description: Pets at the Plaza WEDNESDAY -- The fashion designer Carolina Herrera will receive an award at a dinner-dance at the Plaza to benefit the Bide-a-Wee Home Association, the pet adoption agency. Cocktails at 7 P.M. Black tie. Tickets, $350, or $250 for those 35 and under, from (212) 838-2660.

title: Man of the House
description: Jack Collins doesn't claim to be much of a farmer anymore. He no longer has time to milk his cows. The livestock on his small farm here in southern New Jersey share a ramshackle old barn, and sometimes they have to wait until 8:30 at night to get fed.

title: SKI JUMPING;This Eagle Hasn't Landed
description: He appeared for training in his insulated pink jumpsuit like Gumby dipped in Pepto Bismol, his thick glasses perpetually fogged, having landed hard on his head a'd his wallet in recent years.

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 21 about how people grapple with unimaginably large numbers referred incorrectly to the Crab Nebula in Taurus. It is a remnant left by the explosion of a giant star; it is not a galaxy.

title: WEDDINGS;Darcy N. Sweatt, Ryan David Kaye
description: Darcy Nan Sweatt, the daughter of A'ice Lindley Ulm of New York and the late Robert W. Sweatt, was married yesterday to Ryan David Kaye, a son of Judith and Martin Kaye of Chagrin Falls, Ohio. The Rev. Dale H. Azevedo, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony with Rabbi Samuel Morgen at the Radisson Empire Hotel in New York.

title: Ban on Killing Canada Geese Poses a Conservation Predicament
description: A FEDERAL ban on killing Canada geese poses a predicament for conservationists.

title: FROM THE DESK OF: RICHARD J. MAHONEY;Attention, I.R.S.: Send Us a Bill, Itemized
description: IT was the time of the month for paperwork. He checked every item on the $650 Visa bill to make sure it was correct. Likewise the phone bill. He even double-checked the deductions on his and his wife's paycheck stubs. Once, he had found an error in the amount withheld for Federal taxes, and it pleased him that the monthly tedium of checking was worth it. This month, the Federal withholding correctly totaled $833.33.

title: FILM;Their Feet in Texas, Their Heads in the Clouds
description: WE KIND OF LIKED 'The Godfather' and those Scorsese movies, and we started out trying to do kind of a gritty movie," explained Owen C. Wilson of the script that five years later became the movie "Bottle Rocket."

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;Navigating 125th Street
description: DIAGONALLY opposite the burned-out shell of Freddy's clothing store, Barbara Askins, who heads the 125th Street Business Improvement District, is having a late lunch of okra and corn and oxtail stew and collard greens at Manna's Restaurant.

title: On Language;Congenital, Liar, Punch
description: WHEN THE GHOST OF THE VITUPERATIVE columnist Westbrook Pegler seized control of an ordinarily temperate New York Times columnist last month, readers were exposed to an opinion with the bark off. Pointing to examples of mendacity through 15 years of commodities trading, Travelgate and Whitewater, he concluded that the First Lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, was a congenital liar.

title: A Few Good Rat Terriers Are Better Than Poison
description: To the Editor:

title: HOCKEY;Isles Squander Big Lead Late
description: The Islanders took a three-goal lead into the third period last night. It wasn't enough.

title: Partisan Split Is Obstructing Medicaid Plan By Governors
description: The nation's governors opened their semiannual meeting here today expressing hope that they could reach bipartisan agreements on welfare and Medicaid that could serve as models for action this year by President Clinton and Congress.

title: Foreign Affairs;Where Beauty Stops
description: Nothing quite prepares you for the beauty of Kibuye. The tiny Rwandan village is nestled on a terraced hillside overlooking Lake Kivu, the huge volcanic lake in the heart of Central Africa. There are streams and waterfalls coursing through the hills. Not far from here, among the cloud-shrouded volcanoes, Dian Fossey researched "Gorillas in the Mist." On a promontory jutting into the lake is a large Catholic church built of stone, surrounded by tall banana trees.

title: A Raw French Film Survives Translation
description: THE TITLE OF MATHIEU Kassovitz's second film, "Hate" ("La Haine"), should have served as a warning. Many French moviegoers were nonetheless shocked by its raw portrayal of the violence and frustration gripping the immigrant-packed suburbs of major French cities. They were taken aback to discover a multiracial underclass, seething with anger, that spoke a slang that most French could barely understand. It was a France that many had not seen -- or heard -- before.

title: Turks Seek New Coalition
description: President Suleyman Demirel of Turkey tried again today to form a Government, designating Mesut Yilmaz, the leader of the conservative Motherland Party, to make the attempt, the Anatolian News Agency reported. It said that Mr. Yilmaz was given the mandate after Acting Prime Minister Tansu Ciller formally gave up her efforts to form a coalition.

title: Terms of Engagement
description: Over the past five years, the United States policy of steady engagement with Russia has paid benefits to the American people. With our help, the Russians have dismantled thousands of nuclear warheads and rocket launchers. Russian troops, having withdrawn from Germany and the Baltic states, are serving alongside their NATO counterparts in Bosnia. The United States is now the largest foreign investor in Russia, and bilateral trade has nearly tripled in the past three years.

title: THE GREAT OUTDOORS;When It Rains, It Pours: Floods Pit Towns Against Their Water Company
description: Late last month, for the fifth time since October, the Pascack Brook overflowed, filling basements, inundating roads and shutting businesses in Hillsdale and Westwood. To make matters worse, the storm caused a power blackout, so residents could not even bail out with conventional pumps.

title: JERSEY;Fish Rights: The Final Frontier
description: WE'RE having our fish costume made by a designer in London," Tracy Reiman said brightly. "Gil the Fish, we call it. We're going through the Internet for fishing tournament dates coming up."

title: SOAPBOX;Watch Out for Mr. $22.05
description: Robert Lipsyte's Coping column of Jan. 21, about a Manhattan con man, and his sequel last Sunday have attracted an extraordinary response. Dozens of New Yorkers have called or written to report their own encounters with a neatly dressed young black man with red hair and freckles who seems, somehow, to know them -- drawing the information out of them that he needs. Others wrote of similar cons. While there is not space for all of those tales, here is one with a twist.

title: THEATER REVIEWS;Leaving Home, and All That Lasagna
description: THERE are audience shows and then there are audience shows. Specimens of the first kind, like "Nunsense" (the first, the second and the third, coming up), are immune to critical opinion in defiance of rationality. And then there is the audience show, it seems safe to say, of the caring kind. It even cares what the critics think. It wants to please everybody, and it wants everybody to eat. "Over the River and Through the Woods," at the American Stage Company, is like that.

title: EVENING HOURS;Among Friends Of the Arts
description: Celebrations, and benefits for Venice's burned opera house and for creative programs in New York City public schools.

title: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF;One Act, 5 Boroughs, Many Extras
description: IF all the world's a stage, then New York is its premiere playhouse. And there are probably more stages here than you think. There are the literal ones -- the theaters and concert halls. There are nature's stages, where wildlife plays out daily dramas. And there have been street scenes throughout the city's history, in fact and in fiction.

title: How the 72d Street Station Can Be More Like Paris
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER;'Two Rooms' Directed As Hostage Love Story
description: LEWIS ARLT is a director of interpretive finesse and immense empathy. Out of Lee Blessing's "Two Rooms," a play that has appeared windy and oppressive in previous incarnations, Mr. Arlt has fashioned the love story he perceives it really to be. This is a considerable accomplishment -- in this case, a real feat -- which bears witness to the director as a visionary.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Magic vs. Michael: Coming Back to Reality
description: What transpired here Friday night was the logical evolution of a scene from the summer of 1992, the climactic moment of a riotous Dream Team intrasquad scrimmage between the Magic Johnsons and Michael Jordans.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Want Harper to Stay and Some Others to Go
description: Concluding that their future probably lies beyond this season, the Knicks are planning to make a move by the Feb. 22 trading deadline to free themselves of one or more players with long-term contracts, giving the club more clout in the summer free-agent market. At the same time, the team is ready to act soon to insure that the veteran point guard Derek Harper plays the rest of his career in New York.

title: Arthur Martin, 81, British Spy-Catcher Who Exposed Blunt
description: Arthur Martin, a retired British intelligence official who played a key role in identifying Anthony Blunt, a prominent British art historian, as having belonged to a Soviet spy ring, died on Jan. 10, the British newspaper The Guardian reported on Friday. Mr. Martin was 81.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Cantabria Marks a Holy Year
description: The northern Spanish region of Cantabria is celebrating a Holy Year through April 21 in commemoration of its patron saint, Toribio, the eighth-century monk credited with preserving the largest known piece of the Cross of Christ. The religious relic, known as the Lignum Crucic, or Vera Cross, is housed in the Monastery of Santo Toribio de Liebana, which was founded by monks as a refuge after the Muslim invasion and conquest of the Iberian Peninsula in 711. Situated in the mountains of Picos de Europe, the continent's largest national park, the austere medieval structure has long been the site of Christian pilgrimages.

title: MUSIC;Yale Dean in Performing Debut at Keyboard
description: ROBERT BLOCKER, who has been dean of the Yale School of Music since last September, has also been practicing, and this evening at 8 he makes his New Haven performing debut with a free piano recital at Sprague Memorial Hall. Mr. Blocker has chosen a demanding program, including Ginastera's Sonata, Brahms's "Klavierstucke," the Bach-Busoni Chaconne and a recent work by James Wintle, "The Sage Lectured."

title: A Son of the 19th Century
description: Trying to Save Piggy Sneed By John Irving. Illustrated. 432 pp. New York: Arcade Publishing. $21.95. READING "Trying to Save Piggy Sneed," John Irving's ninth book but only his first compendium of assorted prose, duplicated for this reviewer the sensation of moving in a large airplane over a long stretch of tarmac before suddenly, thankfully, achieving liftoff. Mr. Irving's miscellany -- divided into "Memoirs," "Fiction" (six short stories) and "Homage" -- shows how one of our most widely read novelists fares in what he might consider a triathlon of lesser events. What we find, in this order, are disappointments, confirmations and surprises.

title: TELEVISION;When Theater Turns Out to Be Just a Stage
description: LOS ANGELES - TELEVISION Correction: February 4, 1996, Sunday A caption on page 32 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the television director Barnet Kellman misidentifies the award he received in 1992 for his work on "Murphy Brown." It was an Emmy, not an Oscar.

title: Neighborhood Report;The Gritty and the Gentry Battle for a Waterfront's Soul
description: Pockets of homes dot the industrially dominated streets of western Red Hook, where ships' men once lived and maritime voyagers slept. Today the link between home and work is gone: most residents work away from the area and the small-business owners largely live outside the neighborhood.

title: WEDDINGS;Holly Arnold, Jeremy F. Kinney
description: Holly Arnold, a public relations executive in Denver, was married there yesterday to Jeremy Fowler Kinney, the president of the Kinney Oil Company, an exploration company in Denver. The Rev. John Anderson performed the ceremony at the Holy Ghost Roman Catholic Church.

title: SUNDAY February 4, 1996: TRENDS;Firsthand Reporting
description: As trendy as trend watching is, it dipped ever so slightly last year, according to one electronic media measure.

title: ON POLITICS;Whitman Presents Budget, Keeps Her Day Job
description: A year ago, a lot of people were predicting that Governor Whitman would not be able to make her second tax cut and balance her budget because a spike in the debt burden of $400 million would make the task impossible. But somehow it worked out.

title: DRIVING;Trouble Spots to Avoid
description: A look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: THE YOUNG MAN By Botho Strauss. Northwestern University, $24.95.

title: The View From: Westport;Will a Mansion Find a Home Before All the Doorknobs Are Gone?
description: WHEN word got out that a waterfront mansion was for sale for $1, curiosity seekers began showing up at Lorna Christophersen's estate on Saugatuck Avenue in Westport. "People are taking doorknobs!," Ms. Christophersen exclaimed. "People are taking knobs off the fireplace! It's unfortunate."

title: WINTER OF '96: THE COST;Inches Add Up to Millions
description: As if Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani did not already have enough fiscal headaches, the snowstorm yesterday dealt yet another blow to New York City's strapped budget, just three days after the Mayor's budget plan recognized $50 million in costs from the Blizzard of '96.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;Saving Stonehenge, A Victim of Success
description: PERHAPS no one will ever solve all the mysteries of Stonehenge, the ancient monument that has fascinated tourists and researchers for centuries. But it's a good bet that those who built Stonehenge did not envision two busy roads running within yards of it, or plan to accommodate the 700,000 visitors who now arrive each year by car and bus.

title: Adult and Child Die in a Suspicious Fire
description: A suspicious house fire killed an adult and a 5-year-old girl Friday night and injured four people, one of them -- a 60-year-old woman -- critically, the Nassau County police said today.

title: VIEWPOINT;Wrestling the Tax Devil We Know
description: TWO hundred twenty years ago, our country went to war in part because of the unfairness of consumption taxes imposed by Britain upon her colonies. One hundred thirty-seven years later, in 1913, Americans went to the extraordinary length of amending the Constitution to replace domestic consumption taxes with the Federal income tax as the principal source of our nation's revenue. Since then, our income tax system has consistently raised the revenue needed to meet the Government's spending decisions. Through two world wars and a worldwide Depression, the income tax system has proven capable, flexible and dependable.

title: And Then There Was Frank
description: HE'S LEFT ME OUT!" REPRESENTATIVE Barney Frank said with a frown one recent morning in Washington. "Can you believe this? Oliver North writes up a list of the 25 most dangerous liberals in Washington and he leaves me out!" It does seem like an oversight. In Washington, Frank, 55, is now considered among the last of the old-time liberals, a man who still believes that government is good, that public service is honorable. He is Newt Gingrich's nemesis, a pit bull of oratory, the point man of the House Democratic leadership for floor debates and a star of C-Span. He is also an unofficial adviser to President Clinton and was a force behind the Administration's recently proposed gay rights bill.

title: FRENCH CULTURE;Just Look At America
description: To the Editor:

title: DINING OUT;Steak and Seafood for Those With Time
description: NEWLY arrived, Mitty's has taken over the space last occupied by Hunan Manor. The place has been gutted and completely redone, and now it fairly glows with pinlights in trees and cascading ivy, which softens the sharp edges of a brick divider as well as the hardness of some marble surfaces.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: HONORABLE AMENDMENTS Poems. By Michael S. Harper. University of Illinois, cloth, $18.95; paper, $12.95.

title: HOCKEY;In Another Overtime, Devils Edge Senators
description: Before tonight's game, Devils goalie Martin Brodeur sat and contemplated the new-look Ottawa Senators.

title: No Headline
description: If a Peruvian were convicted in the United States of being a terrorist and sentenced to life in prison, I would welcome the sentence. I would not try to get them out early or try to intervene."

title: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;Here's a Way to Diversify, With Training Wheels
description: Q. I've been hearing a lot about so-called life-style funds that are supposedly well-suited to retirement planning. Are they worth investigating? ALIZANNE FORRESTER A. They may be, especially if you're among the millions of United States workers who plan to live off their 401(k) plans after retiring. When you add up your projected expenses and take inflation into account, you may find that the amount you've salted away so far is barely enough to season a large order of french fries.

title: SUNDAY February 4, 1996: Paperwork II;TIE ONE ON!
description: This is the way of the world with neckties: the newer and more expensive they are, the more immediate and permanent the stains. (Never mind that neckties serve no useful purpose.) Now along comes a 28-year-old Syrian with a flourish of artistic expression to make that a better world: paper ties.

title: THE NATION;In the U.S., All Medicine Is Local
description: DR. JOHN C. WENNBERG of the Dartmouth Medical School got a revealing glimpse of the idiosyncrasies of American medical care when he discovered in the 1980's that doctors in Boston were much more likely to hospitalize patients than were doctors in New Haven.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page picture caption last Sunday about Brookhaven National Laboratory's High-Flux Beam Reactor misstated the circumstances of a fire in March 1994. It occurred at an experimental station in the reactor building, but the reactor was not affected.

title: Neighborhood Report;Worst of Times at Park West High
description: About noon on Dec. 5, scores of students at Park West High School brawled for an hour with students from the Repertory School, an alternative school in Park West's basement. Chairs flew and table legs were used as weapons. Eight students were arrested. Seven others and a security officer were taken to the emergency room. It was the third major fight in or around Park West, on 50th Street between Ninth and 10th Avenues, in six weeks.

title: The View From: Lake Carmel;After a Nightmare, Hope For a Normal Young Life
description: EIGHT months ago, Lauren Taylor lay on an operating table at the County Medical Center while doctors removed half of her brain. Her skull was cut, lifted off in sections and set aside to be reassembled later. Then, one by one, each lobe of the brain's right hemisphere was snipped with a scissors and pulverized by an ultrasound device. The destruction was slow, painstaking and deliberate.

title: 200 Killed in Quake in Southwest China
description: A severe earthquake rocked southwestern China today, killing about 200 people in the remote mountainous region and injuring hundreds, local officials said.

title: WINTER OF '96: THE OVERVIEW;Winter Again Attacks Northeast With Less Snow but Worse Cold
description: Snow and cold, cold and snow: relentless winter buried coastal sections of New York and the Northeast corridor under another major snowfall yesterday and plunged the region into the harshest freeze of the season. It disrupted travel and business in eight states, but transformed the landscape to white radiance.

title: Neighborhood Report;Roosevelt Islanders Fear Pataki Will Pull Plug
description: In the legislative battle over Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed $64 billion budget, the clash between the Governor and Roosevelt Island residents over $6.2 million seems little more than a small-change skirmish. But many islanders consider what led to the clash evidence of the state's threatening indifference to their planned community.

title: In the Region/Westchester;Another Hurdle Cleared Toward an Irish Center
description: A GROUP of investors known as Tara Circle jumped another hurdle last month in its four-year effort to establish an Irish cultural center on the grounds of the former King's College campus.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 25 of the Arts and Leisure section today about Mozart's "Cosi Fan Tutte" misstates the history of Metropolitan Opera productions of the work. The production that is to open on Thursday is the company's fourth, not third. The most recent previous production was directed by Colin Graham, not John Dexter.

title: Rethinking School Busing In Yonkers
description: FIFTEEN years after a landmark Federal desegregation lawsuit was filed in this racially divided city, the firebrand leader of the local branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has questioned whether busing students across town to achieve a racial balance in classrooms is still worth the time and trouble, to say nothing of the cost.

title: SUNDAY February 4, 1996: MARKET RESEARCH;Tilling City Fields
description: When the superhighway, supersprawl and supermarket came, the farmers' market that used to bring country-fresh harvests to vacuum-packed urbanites went. These days, however, city dwellers seem overfed on supers and underfed on nutrition, and the market for markets is again growing. There are now 2,000 of them across the country, roughly twice the number 15 years ago, and their revival shows no sign of letting up. Indeed, the Department of Agriculture encourages them as a means of strengthening endangered farms and vitalizing vacant lots.

title: Dole, in Iowa, Makes Pitch for Backing of Anti-Abortion Voters
description: Senator Bob Dole came to this largely Roman Catholic city today and tried to rally Iowa's anti-abortion voters to his side with a promise that he would declare his first day as President "American Family Day."

title: Special Effects
description: DANCING ON THE CEILING Stanley Donen and His Movies. By Stephen M. Silverman. Illustrated. 390 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: ENCOUNTERS;Beset by Illnesses Yet Making the Most of the Literary Life
description: HOW much is it a matter of choice, to be victim or victor; to paint our lives in light colors or dark?

title: Unum in an Age of Yo
description: IT was a nice spring morning and Tom Henderson was on his way to work when the man next to him on the M15 bus started. The man was raving mad. First he complained that Mr. Henderson's elbow was invading his space. Then, noticing Mr. Henderson was reading something on the Catholic Church, he launched into a streak of high-volume Latin that had a familiar, ecclesiastical rhythm. "Must be a disgruntled seminarian," Mr. Henderson thought, before reaching deep into his schoolboy memories to come up with a suitable comeback: "Excede ad infernos!" It worked: The man left the bus.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: THE TROUBLE WITH FRIENDSHIP Why Americans Can't Think Straight About Race. By Benjamin DeMott. Atlantic Monthly, $22.

title: Habitats/A Brownstone on West 143d Street;At Times, Renovating a House Is Like a Soap Opera
description: GEOFFREY AND NANCY EWING, both actors, could star in their own situation comedy -- a show that combines "Home Improvement," "Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House" with a touch of "The Cosby Show."

title: Corrections
description: The Habitats column last week, about a dance student and her mother, referred incorrectly to a ballet dancer whom the women encountered while he was walking a dog. He was Michael Byars, not Byers. The dog he was walking was not his; it belonged to a friend.

title: Prayer Wasn't Issue in Child's Wrongful Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Vermeers That Didn't Make the Trip, and Other Delights
description: THE once-in-a-lifetime Johannes Vermeer exhibition is closing next Sunday, but New York art lovers should not despair when the Dutch master's paintings leave the National Gallery of Art in Washington for The Hague.

title: Help Wanted: Gyration Inspectors
description: TO the list of vacancies here at Baylor University there might soon be added the new position of gyration inspector. Having decided last week to allow dancing on campus for the first time since Baylor was founded 151 years ago, the school president, Robert B. Sloan Jr., assured alumni that there would be no "lewd gyrations." And so the search is on for someone to define and enforce his edict.

title: 5 Are Arrested in Heroin-Smuggling Ring
description: Five members of an international drug-smuggling ring -- believed to be responsible for importing $70 million worth of heroin a year -- have been arrested on narcotics charges, the Essex County Prosecutor's office announced today.

title: Neighborhood Report;Immigrants Blaze Political Trail
description: In recent years, the city's growing number of South Asians have begun to contribute money to political campaigns, but have rarely run for office themselves. Now a new step has been taken: for the first time, two South Asians are running for school board seats.

title: Overtaken by Events
description: WE ALL GOT HISTORY The Memory Books of Amos Webber. By Nick Salvatore. Illustrated. 443 pp. New York: Times Books/Random House. $25.

title: Screen Dreams
description: SPIKE, MIKE, SLACKERS & DYKES A Guided Tour Across a Decade of American Independent Cinema. By John Pierson. With the conversational collaboration of Kevin Smith. Illustrated. 371 pp. New York: Miramax Books/Hyperion. $22.95.

title: DOES A SUGAR BEAR BITE?
description: I was struck with how Suge Knight has incorporated so much of the vision of Newt Gingrich's America -- two-fisted capitalism, with no concern for the larger society. It's odd that Bob Dole and others are so quick to criticize Knight for his supposed deleterious effect on society, but they never complain about the huge corporations that lay off thousands of workers for quick proft. Which is worse -- unemployment or a few "dirty" words on a sound recording?

title: Navy Facing Criticism In Toxic Dumping
description: THE Navy may be using contaminated spoil to cap 1.2 million cubic yards of toxic-laden material that it dumped into Long Island Sound near Fishers Island, opponents of the project charge.

title: HOCKEY;Athletes See Indoors As a Road To Atlanta
description: In the 1960's, when Madison Square Garden staged major meets on five successive winter weekends, indoor track was an end in itself. For many athletes, indoors was more important than outdoors.

title: N.J. LAW;For Children Who Break the Law, Few Places to Turn
description: JERSEY CITY - N.J. LAW Correction: April 28, 1996, Sunday

title: FILMS AND COMPUTERS;Complete Control Is Within Reach
description: To the Editor:

title: Global Village, Local Angle, Young Faces
description: WHEN Jim Ziolkowski backpacked through India, Thailand and Nepal in 1990 after graduating from college, he came upon a Nepalese village in the midst of a two-day celebration.

title: Anarchy in America?
description: To the Editor:

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Lexus LX 450;Hitting the Trail in Soft Leather
description: DESPITE the rush into truck-type vehicles, many drivers are still reluctant to trade their cars' quiet, comfortable ride and nimble handling for the rough-edged versatility of most sport utility vehicles. More than once I have been asked, in effect, "Why doesn't some company make a Lexus LS 400 sport utility?"

title: GOLF;Neither Rain Nor Snow Can Dampen the Web
description: Let's say eight inches of new snow are on the driveway, an opaque sheet of ice is on the windshield and the windchill, well, it would really be a factor if you could just get outside. At times like these, you just have to get your golf fix.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: TOO RICH The Family Secrets of Doris Duke. By Pony Duke and Jason Thomas. HarperCollins, $25.

title: THE NIGHT;Eartha Kitt Passes Up Football
description: EARTHA KITT doesn't like football. But along with Joan Rivers, Andy Williams, Jerry Orbach, Sidney Poitier, Harry Connick Jr., Rita Moreno and dozens of other entertainment all-stars, she attended a Super Bowl party last Sunday at Sardi's, given by Pierre Cossette, a Broadway and movie producer who also produces the Grammy Awards.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;When Pitchers Grab The Bats, the Sound Often Heard Is 'Whiff'
description: Deprecators of the designated hitter argue that the game is better without it because use of the pitcher puts more strategy into the game, forcing National League managers to make moves more often than their American League counterparts. And, some say, they would rather see pitchers hit. Right.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Knit 1, Punt 2

title: THE WORLD: Not Quite Democracy;Africans Look East for a New Model
description: ACROSS the continent of Africa, for many of the countries that can still dream of economic progress instead of simply hoping to ward off disaster, the most seductive development model lies not in the ripe old West, but rather in the fermenting economies of the Far East.

title: With First Voting Near, Republicans Ask Who Can Win
description: In the final weekend of campaigning before the first actual votes are cast, candidates for President stormed around New Hampshire, Iowa and Louisiana today, each jousting for advantage in an atmosphere that is looking increasing volatile.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 28 of the Arts and Leisure section today about music shows on radio in New York City misidentifies the station on which "The New Afternoon Show" is broadcast. It is WNYU, not WNYC.

title: Theaters Stick Together To Survive, and Flourish
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL;Georgia Loses Forw'rd
description: The injured forward TIFFANY WALKER probably will not be able to rejoin No. 1 Georgia this season, the school said yesterday. Walker, a junior, averaged 7.4 points and 16 minutes of action in her first five games this season. She sprained her right knee in practice Dec. 11 and again in a game on Jan. 4. (AP)

title: FILMS AND COMPUTERS;A Special Inspiration
description: To the Editor:

title: ART;Behind the Occult, Vivid Sacred Art
description: SINCE COLONIAL TIMES, westerners have trivialized, feared and tried to suppress Haitian Vodou, the oldest of the African Diaspora religions. On one hand, it has been depicted as little more than malign mischief, a faintly farcical cult of little dolls stuck with pins and people being turned into zombies. At the same time, it has been treated as a sinister superstition that has helped stifle the development of Haiti, the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere, and contributed mightily to its long history of misery and misrule.

title: L.I. VINES
description: Cabernet Sauvignon Bridgehampton Winery, Grand Reserve, 1992. About $15.

title: Making Records Far From the Urban Beat
description: THE corporate canyons of midtown Manhattan where most recording deals are made are a commuter train ride away, as are the jazz clubs where the talent is, but Monad Records has set up its headquarters in a modest frame house here to produce jazz and blues albums.

title: THE TRIUMPH OF LIBERALISM
description: Roger Rosenblatt's claim in "The Triumph of Liberalism" (Jan. 14) that Mickey Kaus, Mary and Thomas Edsall and I have sought "a liberalism that repudiated liberalism" sidesteps the hard questions we unhappy campers are posing inside the liberal camp.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;No Rubber Chicken
description: OSTRICH, rattlesnake and alligator. Wolfgang Geckeler, the executive chef of the Showboat Casino Hotel, decided to cook all three for a recent dinner with 10 of his colleagues from the South Jersey Professional Chefs Association.

title: The Transformation of a Judge;A 35-Year Journey Starts on Left and Goes Right
description: Early in his career, an indefatigable lawyer for the poor named Harold J. Rothwax would tell his acolytes about the time he went home to Brooklyn for Friday night dinner with his mother and proudly announced that he was representing a man accused of robbery.

title: HOME CLINIC;Hot-Water Heating System Upkeep
description: A HEATING system is classified by the medium that transfers the heat from the furnace through the house. Forced-air, hot water and steam are the most common heating systems in the United States.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Indispensable After All?

title: A City's Deer Called Too Costly
description: SINCE 1936 children have delighted in the deer herd at Mohegan Park in Norwich. "I can still remember the first time I saw the deer at Mohegan Park," said Kathy Armstrong-Crouch. "I can remember how beautiful they were and how special it was to get close to them, especially when there really weren't many deer in Connecticut."

title: Prayer Wasn't Issue in Child's Wrongful Death
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CRUISE ISSUE;New Ships in an Uncertain Climate
description: WHETHER or not the cruise industry's fortunes improve on 1995, when the number of passengers probably fell slightly below the 4.6 million of the preceding year, 1994, this year should go a long way toward answering questions that bear on the future of the industry.

title: THEATER REVIEWS;A Questionable Character's Charming Side
description: FERDINAND JOSEPH LA MENTHE might have sung the blues over how he wound up a voyager from obscurity to overkill.

title: Crime
description: Writing in a whisper, Barbara Vine (who is Ruth Rendell) tells a dark, hypnotic story of romantic obsession in THE BRIMSTONE WEDDING (Harmony, $24). The dominant voice in this passionate tale belongs to Jenny Warner, a "care assistant" in a nursing home who forms a deep, loving attachment to one of her patients, a patrician woman named Stella Newland who is slowly and gracefully dying. The bond between the women is well and truly forged after they exchange confidences about the illicit love affairs that constitute the core of their lives. And when Stella gives Jenny the key to a house she secretly owns, their loves and their lives become more and more entwined.

title: Prayer Wasn't Issue in Child's Wrongful Death
description: To the Editor:

title: LOYAL OPPOSITION;A Former Speaker Finds a Kindred Spirit on the Podium
description: BY now, Joseph V. Doria Jr. should be used to playing the part of the loyal opposition in the State Legislature. Mr. Doria, a politician from Hudson County, where Democrats once ruled unchallenged, is starting his fifth year as the leader of the minority party in the Assembly.

title: On Internet, Memories Of Herricks
description: GRADUATES of Herricks High School don't have to wait 5 or 10 years between reunions, and they don't have to leave their homes as far away as California and Arizona to get there. They've been meeting Sunday nights at 7:30 in a chat room (keyword: Herricks) on America Online.

title: Virtual Realities
description: CIVILWARLAND IN BAD DECLINE Stories and a Novella. By George Saunders. 179 pp. New York: Random House. $22. GEORGE SAUNDERS has been thinking about the future, and he's decided it's really the past -- a cleaned-up, Astroturfed version of history, complete with tour guides and artificial trout streams. Most of the stories in his first collection are set in theme parks in the not-too-distant future, bucolic compounds that offer refuge from the chaos outside. But the past sometimes intrudes on this antiseptic rendition of itself, mainly in the form of ghosts.

title: The Politics of Justice
description: ABOVE THE LAW Secret Deals, Political Fixes and Other Misadventures of the U.S. Department of Justice. By David Burnham. 444 pp. New York: A Lisa Drew Book/Scribner. $27.50.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: DOUBLE VISION Reflections on My Heritage, Life, and Profession. By Ben H. Bagdikian. Beacon, $24.

title: Cuttings;Roots: Exploding the Myths and Misconceptions
description: They can be rather ugly, mostly invisible, and normal gardeners don't really understand them; yet, they provide sustenance and support for all plants. Because roots function mostly out of sight, gardeners have conjured up some pretty fanciful assumptions about how they grow. Such misconceptions permeate gardening behavior and have distorted how almost every shade tree and fruit tree in America is watered, mulched and fertilized. Here are some common myths about root growth:

title: Mother, Mentor, Baby Relief: A Navigator for the Postpartum Odyssey
description: When Beth Lee came home from the hospital, just 30 hours after the birth of her first child, she was tired and overwhelmed. A photographer's agent, she had no experience with newborns and couldn't remember when she had last changed a diaper. Yet there in her arms was Sophie Renee, a tiny alien presence with enormous needs.

title: What's Doing In:;Hong Kong
description: With only 17 months to go before China retakes Hong Kong, a cauldron of emotions is at work here. The territory has become a vibrant, frenzied, combative place where old and new, colonial and Chinese clash. And still at the heart of things like nowhere else is the sound and passion of money being made. For Hong Kong is the center of Asia's financial world, the biggest and busiest duty-free port and the most expensive concentration of real estate on earth.

title: Lawyer in Simpson Case Sues a Book Publisher
description: A lawyer who represented both former Detective Mark Fuhrman and the family of Ronald L. Goldman in O. J. Simpson's criminal trial has himself hired a lawyer and is suing a publisher for reneging on a contract to publish his book on the trial.

title: The Siskel and Ebert of Telecom Investing
description: JACK GRUBMAN and Dan Reingold say they like each other. You'd never know it from the hand grenades they toss back and forth.

title: Weep for Sri Lanka
description: To the Editor:

title: Streetscapes/The Payne Whitney House;A Cupid Renews Interest in a 1909 Mansion
description: At their marriage in 1902 Payne Whitney and Helen Hay received as a present a Fifth Avenue plot with a house to be designed by Stanford White. This gift was not from Whitney's father, William C. Whitney, who had made millions in street railways -- the son had quarreled with the father on the latter's remarriage after the death of his first wife, Payne Whitney's mother.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Basketball National Basketball Association NBA -- Suspended Denver Nuggets guard Jalen Rose and Milwaukee Bucks guard Sherman Douglas for one game without pay and fined them $7,500 and $4,000, respectively, for their actions in a game on Feb. 1.

title: The Neediest Cases;For Family in Need, Rough Road Is Smoothed
description: Robin Mitchell's daughters occupy almost all her time and thoughts, but she can think of no better way to spend her days.

title: TCI Cable Postpones Public-Access Decision
description: PRODUCERS of public-access programming will still be able to reach a systemwide audience, at least for the next few weeks. TCI Cable of Westchester decided on Jan. 26 to rescind its decision to reassign Channel 8, which now serves as a systemwide public-access channel.

title: Backtalk;Life at the Top: Jerry Bailey Reflects on Cigar
description: Cigar, who went 10 for 10 at the races last year to establish himself as the obvious horse of the year and the best horse of the decade, will begin his 1996 campaign next Saturday in the Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park in Florida. When he became a star last year, Cigar was already 5 years old. Now he's 6, and trying to do it again, with some expert guidance from his jockey, Jerry Bailey.

title: PURCELL;A Great Champion In Alfred Deller
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: A Kinder, Gentler Mayor: The Same as the Old One? To hear Mayor Giuliani and his advisers tell it, there's nothing new about the New Rudy. The city father who puts children first and cuts the police force was there all along, just vieled. Page 35.

title: Postings: Housing Activity Is Growing, City Official Says;2 Developments Planned for S.I.
description: Planning is under way for two housing developments of several hundred units each for the Charleston area in the southwest section of Staten Island. Together with a nearby commercial development that could be as large as a million square feet, the activity illustrates the continuing production of market-rate housing on the island, activity that the chief city planning official for the area says has increased in the last year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 7 about Guadalajara misidentified a work performed by the Jalisco Philharmonic at the Degollado Theater. It was Haydn's "Farewell" Symphony, not a work listed by the program as the "Symphony of the Gods."

title: THE WORLD: Mexico's Political Inversion;The City That Can't Fix the Air
description: THERMAL inversion is the name of the wintertime weather event that turns the air over Mexico City into a grayish-yellow pudding of pollutants. Cold air that sinks at night becomes trapped during the day in the bowl formed by the splendid volcanoes and mountains surrounding the city. The poisons spewed out by 2.5 million cars, 360 fume-filled gas stations and thousands of dirty industries are immobilized for city residents to inhale deeply for hours on end.

title: THE WORLD: Israel and the Ethiopians;Welcoming Newcomers Isn't Always So Easy
description: THEIR success in absorbing Jews from the world over has been a matter of great pride for Israelis. In the past decade alone, their country of about 5 million made room for 30,000 Ethiopian Jews and a half million Russian Jews, all without massive disruption.

title: Buddhist Rarities Travel To Katonah Museum
description: WHEN the staff of the Katonah Museum began planning five years ago for its current exhibition, there was a sense that the show would be special. But no one expected more than 1,000 visitors to stream through the galleries on opening day, nor the avalanche of interest that has followed.

title: Three Views, No Agreement
description: IS a recession coming? How much will the Fed ease, and what will that do for the stock and bond markets? During a week in which the Fed cut short-term interest rates a bit, and which ended with a surprisingly weak employment report, we put the questions to three leading Wall Street economists -- Stephen S. Roach of Morgan Stanley; Philip Braverman of DKB Securities, a part of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Japan, and Robert J. Barbera of Capital Investments International. We found big disputes on the past as well as the future, with one panel member saying workers were going to start scoring big wage gains and another arguing that workers had not done that badly in recent years, whatever the statistics say.

title: THEATER;Of Old South Violence Only Yesterday
description: IN MARCH OF 1965, WHEN THE playwright and director Emily Mann was 12 years old, her father left Chicago one day with their next-door neighbor, his mentor and best friend, the black historian John Hope Franklin, and flew south to march from Selma to Montgomery behind the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Also Inside
description: MAKING IT WORK 3

title: Neighborhood Report;City's Compromise On 14th St. Armory Pleases Local Groups
description: When the city announced last summer that it would put a job placement center for welfare recipients in the abandoned 14th Street Armory, coalitions formed to block the plan, voices were raised in anger at community meetings and some neighbors were certain that the center would bring crime to their streets.

title: The Future of Taiwan
description: With the cold war over and the nations of East Asia booming, arguments over the status of Taiwan might seem the relics of another era. Sadly, they are not. A sudden surge of Chinese belligerence toward Taiwan has made the island one of the most volatile issues facing America and the world. Before the issue turns into a dangerous crisis, political leaders in Beijing, Washington and Taipei need to step back from confrontational policies and put Taiwan back into perspective.

title: Jan. 28 - Feb. 3;The Line Is Busy
description: Congress opened a new era of wide-open competition in the communications industry last week, passing legislation to rewrite the country's 62-year-old communications laws from top to bottom.

title: THEATER REVIEWS;Into the Thicket, Riding a Trampoline
description: FOR an elucidation of "Entries" at the George Street Playhouse, read a program insert written by Mary McGinley, the assistant to the director, who has also compiled a synopsis and a study guide for student performances.

title: Jan. 28 - Feb. 3;On the AIDS Front Line
description: It was an upbeat week for AIDS therapy, the first in a while.

title: GARDENING;Is Orchid-Growing Difficult? Not Necessarily
description: AN orchid plant might be construed as one of nature's miracles. For many months, it is an ugly duckling with unattractive leaves and stringy roots. Then, suddenly the plant blooms. It becomes a swan.

title: SUNDAY February 4, 1996;A QUESTION FOR: Stanley Marcus
description: Stanley Marcus, 90-year-old elder statesman of the retail trade, is the former chairman of Neiman Marcus and the author of three books about his experiences.

title: Director of Shuttle Program Steps Down
description: The director of the space shuttle program, Bryan D. O'Connor, abruptly announced his resignation on Friday.

title: SPOTLIGHT;Just Visiting
description: GULLIVER'S TRAVELS, Jonathan Swift's 18th-century satire about a ship's physician and his voyages to lands inhabited by little warlike people and gentle giants, wise men and brutes, is a four-hour mini-series -- SUNDAY-MONDAY at 9 P.M. on NBC. Swift used Gulliver and his adventures to parody the political life and values of his day and to reflect on man's corruption of his highest attribute, reason. Ted Danson (above) stars, and Mary Steenburgen plays the wife he left behind. Jim Henson Productions did the special effects. Other members of the cast -- from very small to very large -- include Peter O'Toole, Edward Fox, Edward Woodward, Ned Beatty, Alfre Woodard, John Gielgud and Omar Sharif.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: XY On Masculine Identity. By Elisabeth Badinter. Columbia University, $24.95.

title: Neighborhood Report;English Catch-Up for CUNY
description: The teacher, Elizabeth Marner-Brooks, is expounding on "long." "You have heard people say Lawng GUY-land," she says. "That's not correct."

title: Harvard Student Picks Jail in Dispute Over Nude Photos of Son
description: A Harvard University photography student convicted of charges relating to a confrontation with the police over nude photographs of her young son has chosen to go to prison rather than accept a court's alternative.

title: Judge Orders F. Lee Baily to Return $3 Million or Go to Prison
description: A Federal judge held the criminal defense lawyer F. Lee Bailey in contempt of court today and ordered him to spend six months in prison unless he repaid $3 million that a client had agreed to forfeit to the Government.

title: MAILBOX;Focus on Stabbing
description: To the Sports Editor: The press at the Australian Open was able to turn what should have been a triumphant day for Monica Seles into her third traumatic episode ("High Spirits, and Also Tears, as Seles Claims Her Prize," Jan. 28).

title: THE CRIUSE ISSUE;Penguins and Politics in Antarctica
description: THE CRIUSE ISSUE REBECCA PEPPER SINKLER is the formereditor of The Times Book Review.

title: VIEWS;Of Breweries and Water Wheels in 1890's Essex
description: These ordinary scenes, frozen in old photographs from the 1880's or 1890's, capture a sense of Essex County as it struggled and prospered and grew from verdant pastures and meadows into the densely packed urban-suburban environment of Newark and its suburbs in the 20th century.

title: SOAPBOX: Maestro, and More;Remembering Henry Lewis, Alight With Intensity
description: YOU did not have to be a musician to enjoy Henry Lewis. The former conductor of the New Jersey Symphony, who died last weekend at 63, was not bound by the treble and bass clefs; his interests overflowed the scale, and he brought a magnificent intensity to everything he did. Which is also to say that his unrelenting enthusiasm could drive you crazy.

title: LIVING TOO LONG
description: I read with interest Michael Norman's article on aging, with his example of his aunt Millie ("Living Too Long," Jan. 14). The irony here seems to be that what many hope modern science will bring -- longer life -- has only brought a sense of diminished returns to his aunt and others like her. But the crux of his story is summarized when he writes: "In the years after she retired, Aunt Millie followed the pattern of labor, leisure, travel and volunteer work that dominated most of her adult life. . . . In other words, she kept busy, which seems to be our society's answer to questions of meaning and existence."

title: WEDDINGS;Erica C. Lalli, Hugh H. Sullivan
description: Erica Catherine Lalli, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Lalli of Newtown, Conn., was married on Friday to Hugh Hamilton Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Sullivan of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. Msgr. Benedict F. Tighe performed the ceremony at St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church in Stamford, Conn.

title: Rap Star Is Arrested
description: The actress and rap star Queen Latifah was arrested on drug and weapons charges today after officers stopped her for speeding. The California Highway Patrol saidspokesman Gary Goldenberg said officers stopped the actress, whose real name is Dana Owens, at 6:25 A.M. and found marijuana and a loaded .38-caliber pistol in the car.

title: FOOD;Lean on This Cuisine
description: As abstemious eating came of age, D., the city's most celebrated caterer, found it necessary to spend hours contemplating the relationship of fat to heart disease, and it was enervating. It reminded him of his Uncle Seamus, the notorious and poetic drunk, who would sit down at the breakfast table the morning after a bender, drain a bottle of stout and say, "Ah, the chill of consciousness returns." After years of bacchanalian entertaining, D. found this decade of dietary restraint tantamount to Uncle Seamus's stout.

title: Neighborhood Report;Manhattan Minute
description: * CHELSEA - After months of community pressure, New York Apple Tours has decided to vacate a bus maintenance and repair center at West 22d Street and 10th Avenue that had run afoul of building, environmental and fire codes. The vice president of the company, Hayim Grant, said the maintenance center would move to an undisclosed location in several months. "We're not interested in upsetting our neighbors," Mr. Grant said. Residents living near the center have complained about exhaust fumes from idling buses. "I think all of Chelsea can breath a collective sigh of relief," said Councilman Thomas K. Duane. "Good riddance."

title: Boy, 14, With Rifle Kills 3 in School
description: A 14-year-old boy with a high-powered rifle killed a teacher and two students and seriously injured another student inside their junior high school classroom on Friday, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about school districts' tightening of registration requirements misidentified Linda Wain. She is executive director of the Long Island Advocacy Center, an organization for the disabled, not director of the Westbury schools' registration center.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Jan. 14 about the new Centro Cultural Borges in Buenos Aires misstated its telephone number. It is (54 1) 319 5450.

title: THE WORLD;The Latest History of the Gulf War
description: EVEN at its best, as the late Phil Graham of The Washington Post said, journalism is no more than a first rough draft of history. And sometimes, as in the case of the war in the Persian Gulf in 1991, the draft is very rough indeed. Not surprisingly, the war's fifth anniversary last month prompted a series of revisionist retrospectives.

title: DOES A SUGAR BEAR BITE?
description: Hirschberg's portrait of Suge Knight exemplifies a trend that has been all too common in your magazine lately: the glorification and glamorization of violent or amoral subcultures. The author's breezy tone seems to condone, even celebrate, Knight's thuggishness. By the time I came to her gleeful description of Suge and his crew rejoicing over a lost piece of evidence at Snoop Doggy Dogg's murder trial, I had had more than enough.

title: Ray McIntire, 77, Dow Engineer And the Inventor Of Styrofoam
description: Ray McIntire, a former chemical engineer for the Dow Chemical Company who invented by accident the material now known as Styrofoam, died on Friday at his home in Midland, Mich. He was 77.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: JONES READING

title: Neighborhood Report;Bakery Stays In Jamaica
description: The future of the Continental Baking plant and its 450 employees was imperiled last July when Interstate Bakeries Corporation took over the South Jamaica company and decided it had one too many baking facilities in the Northeast.

title: Neighborhood Report;Troubled Haven, Now Bankrupt, Still Fighting to Survive
description: In 1972, Joyce Hartwell set up a school on Avenue B to teach carpentry and plumbing to inner-city women. Today, Ms. Hartwell's Lady Carpenter institute has expanded into the All-Craft Center, a sprawling complex of buildings on St. Marks Place offering social services that help, among others, abused children, recovering drug addicts and former prison inmates with AIDS.

title: Neighborhood Report;42d Street's Porn Era: A Brief Social History and a Farewell
description: The evangelist Billy Graham denounced its iniquity. The publisher of Screw magazine, Al Goldstein, glorified its pleasures. Angry feminists conducted scornful tours of it. Countless anonymous men, and a few women, patronized it. For three decades, dozens of peep shows, pornography shops and adult theaters proliferated along it -- naughty, bawdy, gaudy 42d Street.

title: A Market Barometer
description: Well, now we know: The stock market will keep going up. The Standard and Poor's 500 index rose in January, and if history is any guage, the market will end the year higher. A theory called the January Barometer holds that the market's January performance predicts whether stocks will rise of fall for the year. Since 1929, the first year that numbers are available, the theory has been right 78 percent of the time. But, oops, the market rose 3.26 percent last month. The five previous times the market rose between 3 and 4 percent in January, it fell an average of 0.3 percent for the year, although that was mostly because of a 38 percent decline in 1937. This is also an election year, which has tended to skew the results further. When the market rises in January of a Presidential election year, it has always gone up for the year. Always. And, by the way, after a January gain, the Democrat usually wins.

title: Shamus Culhane, a Pioneer In Film Animation, Dies at 87
description: Shamus Culhane, a pioneering animator who made the Seven Dwarfs march home singing "Heigh Ho" in Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs," died on Friday at his home. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: QUICK BITE;A Sure Cure for Wet Mittens
description: Depending on the time of day, the Village Coffee Company can be many things to many people. Morning commuters charging up the hill to the Maplewood train station stop for a bagel and coffee. After dinner or a movie, it's a good place for cappuccino and dessert from the impossibly large pastry selection that jams two glass cases at the front of the store. And for a 2-year-old who's spent a blustery afternoon at Memorial park, it's the place to go for hot chocolate.

title: ON THE STREET;Mink Wars: America Vs. Europe
description: The battle of the minks is being played out on Fifth Avenue between the American look (left), with its investment-quality, no-nonsense minimalist design, and the European look (right), richly decorated and embellished. These are the two dominant styles of the best-selling, durable mink coats, made from minks raised on ranches. The classic American coat is long, fluid and dark chestnut brown, with its skins worked in the let-out process, a technique developed in the 1930's. The European furs, dominated by Fendi designs, have revived the skin-on-skin construction of the turn of the century, with added novelty decorations. These coats arrive at their soft, crushable fluidity through reversible designs, with no inner canvas or lining. Both mink camps are holding their ground at the moment.

title: SIGNOFF;Feel the Burn, Change the Channel
description: The performance of exercise is not really compatible with a close examination of Billy and Alison's latest skirmishes on "Melrose Place," developments in emerging markets or John Stark's 3-point jumper.

title: LIVING TOO LONG
description: Advanced old age is the result of science without a human perspective. We have created a period of life that is dominated by loss -- loss of loved ones, loss of bodily and mental control, loss of meaning. And we insist that people who live into these advanced years should be grateful and happy to have this extra time on earth, no matter how painful and demeaning it may be.

title: Stocks Fall in Japan
description: Stocks traded lower here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 250.65 points, or 1.20 percent, at 20,653.38. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 31.09 points.

title: Anger, Not Discipline
description: To the Editor:

title: New Virus Designed to Tackle Windows 95
description: Software saboteurs have created the first computer virus specifically aimed at the Microsoft Corporation's Windows 95 program, British researchers said today.

title: Equity and Convertible Offerings Set This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFS;Buchanan Is Seeking Momentum in Louisiana
description: The first votes in choosing a Presidential nominee will be cast in Iowa on Tuesday -- Iowa, La., that is, a town of 2,500 people.

title: The Wealthy Town That Has Fostered Forbes Where Less Government Is the Rule
description: When Steve Forbes, on the Presidential campaign trail, talks about shrinking the government, his neighbors know where he's coming from: a private and pristine pocket of the country where government still knows its place.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Arraignment of Mayoral Aide
description: Jackie R. Mattison, the top aide and close friend of Mayor Sharpe James who was indicted on bribery charges, is scheduled to be arraigned at 9 A.M. today in Federal District Court in Newark. Mr. Mattison, 45, is accused of accepting $17,000 from William F. Bradley, 46, an insurance broker, to steer city contracts to two insurance companies. He is the highest-ranking official to be indicted in a two-year Federal investigation into corruption in Newark.

title: G.I. Killed in Bosnia Was From Ohio; Land Mine Now Doubted
description: As friends in tiny Ridgeway, Ohio, mourned Sgt. 1st Class Donald Allen Dugan, who grew up in the farming town and died in Bosnia on Saturday, NATO issued a statement yesterday saying that the explosion that killed him probably was not from a land mine, as first reported.

title: Mexico City Journal;At 95, Still Labor's King, but Ruling Party's Vassal
description: The old man with ashes on his sleeve was born with the century. He was once a fiery rebel, but the fight went out of him long ago. Now it is cooperation, not confrontation, that he seeks.

title: Its Art Squeezed, the Modern Buys Growing Room
description: The Museum of Modern Art, increasingly cramped for space, has bought the neighboring Dorset Hotel and two adjacent brownstones in a $50 million transaction that will nearly double the museum's size.

title: A Rapper Who Found Music to Be the Easy Part
description: Poetic, the rapper formerly of the group Too Poetic, rents out the basement of his sister's home in Brentwood, L.I. His car is a 1989 Ford Escort and, he says contentedly, "it serves its purpose."

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Debate on a Victim Rights Bill
description: Prosecutors would have to make every effort to notify crime victims before accepting a plea bargain or dismissing charges against a defendant under a bill that will be debated today by the Assembly Judiciary Committee. A similar measure passed the Legislature last year, but Governor Whitman sent it back for changes. Before lawmakers could revise the bill, the session ended.

title: Awards in Lausanne Ballet Competition
description: Young dancers from Italy, Japan and France have received top prizes in the 24th annual Prix de Lausanne ballet competition in Switzerland. The gold medal, awarded for exceptional talent, was not given this year.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Agassi Rips Rankings
description: The mysterious ATP computer says THOMAS MUSTER is the best tennis player in the world. To the man he knocked from the No. 1 spot, that just shows the absurdity of the ratings system.

title: U.S. Pushes Civilian Aspects of Bosnia Pact
description: With the military aspects of the Bosnian accords going reasonably well, with the shelling stopped and opposing forces separated, American efforts are turning sharply toward the more complicated effort to build a shared peace among recent enemies who have little trust for one another.

title: A View of Nynex At the Center Of the Universe
description: Though Ivan G. Seidenberg's new office on the 41st floor of Nynex's midtown Manhattan headquarters is windowless and remarkably humble for the chief executive of a $13 billion phone company, it offers him just the perch he wants from which to survey the new world of telecommunications.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Lowe and Mercedes Broaden Their Ties
description: The Mercedes-Benz of North America unit of Daimler-Benz in Montvale, N.J., has further expanded its relationship with Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York by naming Lowe to create and produce the worldwide marketing programs for the All-Activity Vehicle, a sports-utility vehicle that Mercedes plans to introduce in the United States in fall 1997. The billings on the assignment, which Lowe was awarded without a review, were estimated at $40 million to $50 million.

title: In Performance: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Memories of Gould, But Not Imitations Angela Hewitt, pianist Miller Theater

title: In America;Sliding Pay Scale
description: The buying power of the Federal minimum wage will soon reach its lowest level since 1955, when the minimum wage was 75 cents an hour.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Grants for Traditional Crafts
