description: The State Council of the Arts wants to make an investment in beauty, meaning and continuity. It is offering grants so people can apprentice with a master folk artist to learn a traditional art or craft. Last year, 23 people won grants totaling more than $52,000 to study such skills as Ukrainian embroidery, Japanese drumming and Iroquois women's social dancing. The deadline for applications this year is March 15. The first of four workshops explaining how to apply will be tonight at 6:30 at the Newark Community School of the Arts. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: Soothing Tone by Russian Communist at Business Forum
description: Plutocrats of the world, you have nothing more to lose in Russia if a Communist is elected President than you do already under the unpredictable incumbent, Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: Spy Agency Has More Money Than Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: DEEP FREEZE GRIPS SOUTHERN STATES
description: A deep freeze swung into the Deep South today, bringing ice, snow and temperatures below, or barely above, zero to parts of Mississippi, Georgia and Alabama.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: Dole (Yes, Dole) Plays the Age Card in Iowa
description: Seeking to transform a perceived shortcoming into a strength, Senator Bob Dole asserted today that the nation under President Clinton had gone "downhill" and needed someone from his generation to right its course.

title: Spy Agency Has More Money Than Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Executives On the Move
description: Alan Cohen, executive vice president for marketing at NBC television in New York, will join ABC in the new position of executive vice president for marketing. And Peter Chrisanthopoulos, who had been executive vice president for research, marketing and promotion at the ABC network in New York, is joining Ogilvy & Mather U.S.

title: Afghan Capital Grim as War Follows War
description: Before the pink light of dawn could touch the snowy peaks of the Hindu Kush mountains around this ruined capital, five young Afghans met on a bitterly cold morning last week for the gamble of a lifetime.

title: Car Driver Tries to Run Over and Kill Guatemala's New President
description: Guatemala's new President, Alvaro Arzu Irigoyen, escaped unharmed today from a bizarre attempt to run him over, officials said.

title: German Merger for Grace's Dialysis Unit
description: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to spin off National Medical Care, its nationwide chain of kidney-dialysis centers, into a new company that would be controlled by Fresenius A.G., a big German medical-technology company.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Maidenform Lines To Kirshenbaum
description: Maidenform Inc. in New York has named Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York to handle the account of its lingerie and intimate apparel lines. The billings were estimated at $6 million.

title: POP REVIEW;Getting Even, in a Very Even Tone
description: Songwriting can be the best revenge. At Irving Plaza on Thursday night, Aimee Mann had the last word on more than a dozen disintegrating romances, and she never had to raise her voice. Her songs contemplate unhappiness with cool hindsight. They wrap recriminations and second guesses, mea culpas and parting shots in tuneful, neatly rhymed pop-rock that unabashedly harks back to the Beatles.

title: Disavow Soviet Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: We fought against the country that Ronald Reagan called the evil empire, and it was as a result of our sacrifices that the evil empire collapsed. But afterward we were forgotten. -- NAJIBULLAH LAFRAIE, the Afghan Foreign Minister. [A8:5.]

title: Forbes Gains a Local Endorsement
description: If not for a few campaign banners and a box of blue "Forbes for President" buttons, it would have been hard to tell whether it was a campaign rally or halftime at a high school basketball game.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;400-Animal Zoo May Close
description: By April 1, the 400 animals at Turtle Back Zoo may need a new home. Essex County officials say they cannot afford to keep the 33-year-old zoo open. But the New Jersey Zoological Society is not ready to give up; it will begin a petition drive this week to save Turtle Back, The Associated Press said.

title: U.S. Backs NATO Growth
description: Defense Secretary William J. Perry insisted today that NATO would go ahead with its plans to admit new members from Central Europe despite Russia's objections.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Tonight at the Rainbow Room, there will be a benefit and screening of the new film "City Hall," a political thriller based in New York and starring Al Pacino.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Link Likely in 8 Arson Fires
description: Teams of arson investigators from Burlington and Camden counties say they believe that eight arson fires set in vacant buildings over the weekend were probably started by the same people. The A.P. said no injuries were reported in the fires, which damaged six houses and two former taverns in five towns.

title: BASKETBALL;Emotions Run High, and Knicks Go Low
description: Through all the head butts and the naughty words, Reggie Miller has learned from this basketball brouhaha that Knicks-Pacers does not always come down to big and strong bodies. It sometimes turns on big and strong minds.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: The Clarion Business Communications division of Clarion Marketing and Communications, Greenwich, Conn., which is owned by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, was named the first agency to handle accounts for three clients with combined billings estimated at $10 million: Hyperion Software, Stamford, Conn., for trade advertising; SEI Corp., Wayne, Pa., to handle marketing communications for the data processor, and Sony Entertainment Systems, New York, a unit of the Sony Corp., to develop a communications program.

title: Longest February Begins With Lowest Temperatures
description: The bicycle path alongside the harbor in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, was deserted yesterday -- no surprise, as each cruel gust of wind lifted a blinding sheet of snow from the ground. Not a person was to be found at the 79th Street Boat Basin in Manhattan, where ice floes thumped against the boats' flanks.

title: When Death Is a Blessing and Life Is Not
description: My cousin Florence Hosch finally died the Wednesday before Christmas, about a thousand days after she had wished to.

title: Bridge
description: Singleton honors tend to be more valuable in defense than in attack, so a player with such holdings should hesitate to save over an opposing game. When the diagramed deal was played in the Greenpoint Pairs at the Eastern Regional Championships in Manhattan in May, East had to decide whether to save in five hearts when his opponents reached four spades. Those who saved regretted it, for they were doubled for a loss of 500 if the defense was careful, and four spades was unmakable because the spade queen and the club king had a role to play in that contract.

title: Evan Jones, 80, a Food Writer Renowned for His Own Cooking
description: Evan Jones, a food writer who fell in love twice in Paris, finding both a career and a companion during a single extended sojourn after World War II, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 80.

title: HOCKEY;Islander Rookie Gets a Hat Trick at Home
description: Nicklas Andersson, the Islanders' rookie left wing who has been with the team for only six weeks, scored his first National Hockey League hat trick and assisted on Zigmund Palffy's game-winner as New York defeated the Dallas Stars, 5-3, tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Apple Computer Over Time
description: Almost from the time it was founded in 1976 in a garage by Steven P. Jobs and Stephen Wozniak, Apple Computer has enjoyed a special place in American business, sort of the corporate equivalent of the Grateful Dead. Its customers were fanatically loyal and could hardly walk by another manufacturer's personal computer without making contemptuous remarks. Every article in a computer magazine about hardware-software compatability or lack of standards for peripherals would prompt letters that said, in effect, "Not on my Macintosh."

title: The Outsider: Bomb Plot Suspect Was a Shy but Volatile Loner
description: Carol Person stared out her screen door in dismay as one of the boys playing street hockey near her house ranted over a bad call and then, suddenly, smashed four garage windows with his bare fists.

title: Schuble Sees Split On Monetary Union Lasting Year or More: EU Heading For Political Crisis, Kohl Aide Says
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The European Union is headed for a "political crisis" that will be touched off by growing divisions over monetary union and the EU's future size and shape,a top adviser to Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany says.

title: Girlfriend Held in a Plot to Kill a Baby
description: The girlfriend of a New York City police officer has been accused of trying to arrange the killing of his 14-month-old daughter in what authorities said was an apparent attempt to strengthen their romance.

title: Charities Aiding Poor Fear Loss of Government Subsidies
description: While critics of Government spending on social services have been asking the nation's charities to take responsibility for the poor, sick and elderly who would be hurt by budget cutbacks, many of the cuts would force those groups to turn away people they now help.

title: Tentative Settlement Is Reached In Maintenance Workers' Strike
description: With City Hall officials mediating in the final hours, more than 30,000 maintenance workers in New York City office towers ended their monthlong strike yesterday when their union accepted a compromise plan under which management would pay newly hired workers 20 percent less than current workers.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: Metro Matters;Spinning a Tale That Spins Out of Control
description: THIS tale is not about anything illegal or even out of the ordinary. It is very ordinary, in fact -- a story about how someone with connections got a city job. She is Sharon Marie Trotti; her brother is Michael C. Finnegan, the Governor's counsel, and Ms. Trotti was hired by the city's Department of Environmental Protection just as the Mayor and Governor reached an agreement on preserving the high quality of the city's water supply.

title: Officials to Fight Frivolous Inmate Lawsuits
description: Fed up with defending the state against lawsuits over bad haircuts and melted ice cream, New York State officials are planning to take punitive action against prisoners who file frivolous lawsuits.

title: China Issues Rules To Monitor Internet
description: The Internet is just starting to grow in China, and the authorities are trying to keep it firmly in their grasp. Yesterday, China issued a new set of rules to regulate Internet use, the latest in a recent series of moves to assert control over the flow of information in the country.

title: TECHNOLOGY: CONNECTIONS;Keeping it simple, avoiding exasperation -- the way we humans prefer.
description: TIDE and times have changed since Steve Jobs ran a pirate flag over his research building at Apple headquarters and delivered a "computer for the rest of us." At that time, he confidently invoked all the imagery left over from the counterculture: images of liberation, individuality, iconoclasm and opportunity. Apple Computer was opposed to the uniformity, dullness, rigidity and oppression -- the qualities Apple's advertising associated with Big Brother-style I.B.M.

title: New Cause Helps Feminists Appeal to Younger Women
description: The old warriors were present, among them Gloria Steinem, blond braid silvered with gray, and Molly Yard, the fiery past president of the National Organization for Women, who is now in her 80's. But it was a new generation of women in their 20's and 30's whom the organizers of the first Feminist Expo wanted in a new fight, to preserve affirmative action.

title: INSIDE
description: Feminists' New Cause

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Ready for Kashmir Talks With India, Bhutto Says
description: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto said today that Pakistan was ready for talks with India to settle their longstanding dispute over Kashmir, but declared that her country could match India "in every field" if need be.

title: Arguing Over the Dawn of Cyberspace's 'Day' Book
description: Talk to the photojournalist and entrepreneur Rick Smolan and he will describe an ambitious and innovative undertaking that will occur on the Internet this Thursday. On that day, Mr. Smolan, who gained fame from his best-selling "Day in the Life" series of coffee-table books in the 1980's, is sending 100 photojournalists around the globe armed with conventional and digital cameras to document a day in the life of cyberspace.

title: In Performance: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Traces of Strauss and Jazz In a Trio by Andre Previn St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble Alice Tully Hall

title: Essay;Beware Smilo-Communism
description: Look at those businessmen dancing around that Communist," said an unemployed Russian at the World Economic Forum held at this ski resort every year. "Don't they realize he will doom their investments?"

title: Audrey Meadows, "Honeymooners' Co-Star, Dies at 71
description: Audrey Meadows, whose portrayal of a working-class housewife on "The Honeymooners" placed her in the pantheon of television comedy's grandes dames, died on Saturday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. She was 71.

title: Sadie K. Klau, 97, Montefiore Trustee
description: Sadie Klingenstein Klau, who was an active member on the boards of Montefiore Medical Center and Hunter College, her alma mater, died on Saturday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York City. She was 97 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Time Trouble for Geyser: It's No Longer Old Faithful
description: A frost-covered bison placidly chewed its winter cud, but the tourists, standing in an expectant semi-circle, were getting restless.

title: Fix the Schools First
description: During his budget address last week, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani announced he would not support a plan to rebuild New York City's crumbling school system. Minutes later, he reacted angrily when a reporter asked why the money-starved city was paying $180,000 to renovate offices for a new agency head. "Decent office space helps the morale of an agency," he said. "It's part of good management."

title: Trust Voters to Analyze Campaign Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS Broadcasts Interview With Tobacco Executive
description: After withholding an interview with a former tobacco company executive out for fear of legal action, the CBS News program "60 Minutes" last night broadcast the first on-air comments from the official, Jeffrey S. Wigand, the highest-ranking whistle-blower ever to emerge from the American tobacco industry.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Few Hints On Nurture From the First Lady
description: Few people today are being watched more closely than Hillary Rodham Clinton, and that is no doubt one reason why her book soared in its first week after publication to the No. 1 spot on The New York Times nonfiction best-seller list. It may also explain why Mrs. Clinton seems almost to have been looking over her own shoulder as she wrote, guarding against any provocation or mistake.

title: China Appeals for Aid After Earthquake Kills 200
description: China mobilized its military today for rescue work and appealed for international assistance after a powerful earthquake leveled thousands of mud-walled village homes Saturday night and killed more than 200 people in the southern province of Yunnan.

title: Coming to a Theater Near You: the Latest Format War
description: For movie theater owners, the digital revolution is proving anything but peaceful.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Why Whitman Backs Dole
description: The focus was supposed to be welfare when three governors, including Christine Todd Whitman, appeared yesterday on "Meet the Press."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Interpublic Acquires Jay Advertising
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, which owns agencies including Ammirati Puris Lintas, the Lowe Group and McCann-Erickson Worldwide, has acquired Jay Advertising, a small shop known for its creative work in retail advertising. The terms were not disclosed.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Leader of Tajikistan Bows To Key Rebel Demands
description: Desperate to avoid another civil war, President Emomali Rakhmonov bowed to rebel demands today that he dismiss three top officials accused of corruption.

title: Returning, Slowly, From Descent Into Depression
description: Rosalie Berger had lost her mother. She had lost her job. She had lost the only home she knew.

title: Critics Fault Federal Enforcement of Laws Regulating Animal Trade
description: For the hunters who flock to the monthly dog and gun trade day here, the morning belongs to dealers buying research specimens. Dawn has barely broken when men in pickups begin pulling up to dealers' trucks, clamoring to sell them dog after dog.

title: Executive Producer at CBS News
description: Filling the final slot in his roster of top managers, the new CBS News president, Andrew Heyward, plans to announce today that Jeffrey Fager will take Mr. Heyward's old job as executive producer of the "CBS Evening News."

title: An Inconvenient Saudi Dissident
description: Mohammed al-Masari is a vocal but peaceful critic of the Saudi royal family who publishes a dissident newsletter from London. Now Britain is preparing to deport him to the tiny Caribbean island of Dominica, where he fears he would be exposed to Saudi reprisals.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week. Some reports were delayed by last month's partial shutdown of the Government.

title: GOLF;Pebble Beach Called on Account of Rain
description: Throughout the more than 50-year history of the golf tournament here, there have been snowstorms, wind sheers and enough standing water on the fairways to float a life raft. But there had never been a cancellation. Until today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: If being the conductor of one orchestra is good, then being the conductor of two must be twice as good -- or so MARVIN HAMLISCH, who is also a composer and pianist, thinks. He was recently named principal pops conductor of the Baltimore Symphony, a position he already holds at the Pittsburgh Symphony.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFS;Lugar Takes a Jog With His Beta Brothers
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana brought his campaign for President back to New Hampshire today, joining a dozen brothers of Beta Theta Pi fraternity and their dog, Clint, for a jog across the Dartmouth College campus here.

title: Block Grants Raise the Issue Of State's Role
description: Though legislators and lobbyists have homed in on the deep cuts in Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget, another little-discussed aspect of his plan could have a more lasting impact, fundamentally reshaping the way New York delivers services.

title: Los Angeles Trying to Fix 911, But Many Calls Aren't Heeded
description: Even though Los Angeles voters approved a multimillion-dollar bond issue more than three years ago to build a modern 911 dispatching system for police and fire services, a record number of 911 phone calls went unanswered last year, Police Department statistics show.

title: Divided Christian Right Aids Forbes
description: Almost all the candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination have labored to cultivate this state's powerful Christian conservatives.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LINDA A. FAIRSTEIN, chief of the sex crimes unit of the Manhattan District Attorney's office, will find herself in good literary -- and legal -- company this summer.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Pas de Deux Haunted By Narcissus' Ghost
description: George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins took new choreographic looks at old stories and bygone eras in the works that the New York City Ballet presented on Saturday night at the New York State Theater.

title: In Performance: DANCE
description: 'La Sonnambula' as a Study Of Innocence and Experience New York City Ballet New York State Theater

title: Bankers Grapple With How to Waterproof a Leaky Settlement System
description: NEW YORK  Shocks as varied as a Wall Street power failure and the collapse of an obscure German bank have threatened huge leaks in the global network of money transfers, which is as essential to the world economy as water mains are to a metropolis, but bankers are unsure how to waterproof the system.

title: In Performance: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Some Leading Players Get a Chance to Be Heard New York Philharmonic Avery Fisher Hall

title: Media Business Now a Job Fair For Executives Once Removed
description: For someone who was just thrown out of work, Frank J. Biondi Jr. certainly acts like a busy man. On Thursday, two weeks after he was ousted as the president and chief executive of Viacom Inc., Mr. Biondi raced from one meeting to another before heading to a going-away party at La Grenouille, the venerable midtown restaurant, where his former colleagues toasted him over a lavish dinner of ravioli with lobster and rack of lamb.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: WEEKEND

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FOOTBALL A.F.C. Misses Chances

title: U.N. Tries to Allay Fears of Sarajevo Serbs
description: Simo Tusevljak, the chief of the criminal division for the Serbian police in this suburb of Sarajevo, is now required to uphold the laws and constitution of what he calls "those Muslim fanatics" in his more diplomatic moments.

title: HOCKEY;Devils Torn Between Defense and Offense
description: With his teammates swooping up and down the ice working on passing drills, Devils forward John MacLean ducked into the Palladium's penalty box for a quick chat with a relative.

title: No Rush by Prosecutors To Seek Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Giuliani Complaint Belittled
description: New York's Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, is a crybaby, says Robert C. Janiszewski, who is both Hudson County Executive and a Port Authority commissioner. That is the message in a letter that Mr. Janiszewski mailed to City Hall. (It should be arriving this week, but Mr. Janiszewski did not wait for the Postal Service to deliver the message.)

title: Enforcing U.S. Anti-Bias Laws Abroad Brings Up Delicate Issues
description: WASHINGTON  You be the judge:

title: Insular St. Petersburg?
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: Ariel Poler, president at Internet Profiles Corp., San Francisco, was named to the new position of chairman. Assuming his responsibilities with the title of president and chief executive is Mark Ashida, who had been president at the Ashida Consulting Group, Portola Valley, Calif., which closed.

title: Out Magazine's Founder Resigns Amid Dispute
description: A longstanding disagreement over business strategy at Out Publishing Inc. has led to the resignation of Michael Goff, the founder of Out magazine, one of the most influential and widely read gay and lesbian publications in the nation.

title: BASKETBALL;Malone and Johnson: No Fears, No Grudges
description: They perspired on each other.

title: For Updating Hebrew, the Patience of Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Broke and Cutting Loose;Bankruptcy Has New Appeal for Music Groups Chafing at Their Contracts
description: Success, as abrupt and electric as a summer thunderstorm, enveloped the music group TLC five years ago and shows no sign of ending. The three-woman group based in Atlanta -- its music is a blend of rhythm and blues and hip-hop -- has two "multi-platinum" albums and half a dozen top singles. So the music industry was somewhat taken aback last year when the three women all filed for bankruptcy court protection, telling whoever would listen that they were "broke."

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Surprise Deal For National Medical Two days after spurning a $3.8 billion bid from Baxter International for its National Medical Care, W. R. Grace said it had agreed to spin off the unit, which dominates the kidney-dialysis market, with a new company created by Fresenius of Germany.

title: A Busy Week Ahead For Treasury Sales
description: The Treasury's quarterly refunding begins tomorrow with the sale of a new 3-year note, followed by Wednesday's auction of a 10-year note, and then Thursday's auctions of a 7-day cash management bill and a 30-year bond. The week's schedule also includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A World New and Vibrant, Another Old and Orderly
description: One of the most arresting images in contemporary ballet occurs in the first moment of George Balanchine's "Symphony in Three Movements," presented by the New York City Ballet on Friday night at the New York State Theater. The curtain rises on a long single line of dancers stretched diagonally across the stage, certainly not a novel idea but never quite so boldly stated.

title: Violence Has Declined in New York City Jails
description: To the Editor:

title: BASKETBALL;The Nets Disappear At Crucial Moments
description: Now you see them, now you don't. The Nets pulled a disappearing act tonight against the Golden State Warriors, an act that might play better with Siegfried and Roy than Sprewell and Seikaly.

title: MEDIA: PUBLISHING;With a campaign tell-all, an anonymous author takes a page out of history. And the resulting obsession turns into a publicist's dream.
description: IN an era in which virtually everyone seems to be clamoring for celebrity, the very notion that an author with a shot at fame would insist on anonymity has sent tremors through media and publishing circles. Especially, it seems, since the writer has produced a feisty political roman a clef that is not only bringing in good reviews but good sales as well.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SOCCER;Italian Star Signs With MetroStars
description: ROBERTO DONADONI, the creative midfielder of AC Milan and the Italian national team for the last 10 years, has agreed to a two-year contract with the MetroStars of Major League Soccer. Donadoni revealed his agreement with the MetroStars after playing in AC Milan's 3-1 victory over Roma yesterday in the Italian League.

title: At 14 Months, a TargetA college student has been charged with trying to kill the 14-month-old daughter of her boyfriend, a New York City policeman. Investigators say the woman believed that by killing the toddler, she would be able to cement her romance with the officer. Officials said the plot unraveled when an informant told investigators of her plan.    Article, page B3.
Taking In the Sites;A Ticket Backstage On the Web
description: Their daddies are rich and their mamas good lookin'. Orphans, cats and impossible dreams -- these are a few of their favorite things. What do these simple folk, these lovers of musical theater, do on the Internet?

title: New Effort to Clear an Anti-Nazi Martyr Still Branded a Traitor
description: In the eyes of many Germans, few 20th-century heroes seem braver or more inspirational than the martyred anti-Nazi theologian Dietrich Bonhoeffer. Yet in the eyes of the law, he is a traitor.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Next time you pick up a greeting card, Hallmark is hoping that you will look at  the back first.
description: GIVEN the purpose of a bold brand-building campaign for Hallmark cards, it is fitting that Missouri, home to Hallmark, is known as the Show Me State.

title: HOCKEY;Chicago Keeps Streak Alive
description: Chris Chelios scored twice and Jeff Shantz ended a 46-game goal-scoring drought tonight as the Chicago Blackhawks ran their unbeaten streak to seven games with a 4-1 victory over the Mighty Ducks of Anaheim.

title: Planned Hunt Puts 9 Buffalo In a Spotlight
description: Seen from a distance, the buffalo grazing in the snow on the pinyon-dotted desert of western New Mexico look inconspicuous. But since the State Department of Game and Fish held a hunting lottery last fall for licenses to kill nine old bulls, they have become celebrities.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Psychiatric Hospital Investigates A Patient's Death by Hanging
description: Officials at Greystone Park State Psychiatric Hospital are investigating the death of a patient found hanging by a belt from a bathroom towel bar.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the film "Care of the Spitfire Grill" referred incorrectly to a comment by Geoffrey Gilmore, program director of the Sundance Film Festival, about his knowledge of the film's backers. Mr. Gilmore said he did know before deciding to show the film that it was financed and produced by a company owned by Roman Catholic priests.

title: Commander of Navy Squadron Plagued by Crashes Is Reassigned
description: The squadron commander of the F-14 pilot in the Nashville crash that killed five people last week has been relieved of his command, the Navy announced today.

title: Shareholders Sue Hasbro Over Mattel Bid
description: Four stockholders of Hasbro Inc., the nation's No. 2 toy maker, filed suit against the company for rejecting Mattel Inc.'s merger offer, saying that Hasbro denied them increased profits.

title: A Class Split Over a Populist 'Boheme'
description: La Boheme" became an enormous popular hit almost immediately after its first performance, at Turin's Regio Theater on Feb. 1, 1896. Since then "the people's opera," as it was soon tagged, has been performed tens of thousands of times, its tragic love story never ceasing to break hearts. Even today, the Metropolitan Opera in New York, the Bastille Opera in Paris and Covent Garden in London keep it in their repertories as a certain crowd-pleaser.

title: FOOTBALL;The Opera That Is Football: Reid's Careers Meet on Broadway
description: The Super Bowl may be over, but this is crunch time for Mike Reid. He is about to premiere his treasured new work on Broadway, the musical-theater capital of the country. And after a long career of trying to figure out what he wants to do with his life, he has chosen to set his music to a story about a football player who is trying to find himself.

title: Patents;Prodigy's patent is being debated as a possible threat to Sun Microsystems' Java language.
description: THE on-line world has been riddled with messages recently, debating whether a patent held by the Prodigy Services Company, the third-largest on-line service, is a killer that would give Prodigy control over Java, Sun Microsystems Inc.'s new computer language.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;When Playwrights Cross (or Crisscross) the Footlights
description: Question: What do Athol Fugard, Harold Pinter, Sam Shepard, Christopher Durang, Alan Bennett, Wallace Shawn and William Shakespeare have in common?

title: In Performance: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Young Foursome From Miami Explores a Bit of Latin America Miami String Quartet Americas Society

title: MARATHON;Can a Doublemint Ad Be That Far Behind?
description: In the Philadelphia Marathon this past November, just before reaching the 14-mile mark and turnaround point at the Museum of Art, Karen Peterson heard spectators yelling at her.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;The More the Merrier, for a Vet and a Therapist
description: Children and animals. Jokes about fat people and cross-dressers. Prime time stumbles on with its new series.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Foyle Leaves Hospital
description: ADONAL FOYLE, Colgate's star center and the Patriot League's leading scorer, was released from Community Memorial Hospital in Hamilton, N.Y., yesterday morning after suffering a concussion in Saturday's game against Siena.

title: Mediator Saw Makings of Handshake
description: Last Thursday, after a month of snowy picket lines and frozen negotiations in the strike by building maintenance workers, both management and labor picked up the telephone.

title: Mexico 'Turning Corner' : Q&A /Ernesto Zedillo
description: Ernesto Zedillo inherited the presidency of Mexico in 1994 and with it a major currency and debt crisis, as well as political and labor turmoil and a peasant uprising in the Chiapas region.

title: The Environmental Counterattack
description: If Newt Gingrich requires any more evidence that he has badly mispositioned his party on environmental issues, he need look no further than last week's election of Ron Wyden, a Democrat, to fill Bob Packwood's vacant Senate seat in Oregon. Exit polls suggested that Republican efforts to undermine environmental laws played a critical role in Mr. Wyden's upset win.

title: Strub Stakes To Helmsman
description: Helmsman, a 4-year-old colt improving with age, scored a two-length victory today over the favored Afternoon Deelites in the $500,000 Strub Stakes.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFS;Des Moines Newspaper Goes for Dole, Again
description: The Des Moines Register, Iowa's largest and most influential newspaper, endorsed Senator Bob Dole for the Republican Presidential nomination today, saying that the current front-runner "ranks as one of the major political figures of the century."

title: Lewis Thinks Gold And Pumps Iron
description: Pumping iron was never necessary for Carl Lewis to bulk up his reputation as the greatest track and field athlete of all time. Eight Olympic gold medals speak for themselves. But, like a trailing parachute, injuries and illness and age have put a drag on his career in recent years. Six months ago, he began serious weight training for the first time. Today, he is stronger than ever. The question now becomes, can that new strength be converted into speed?

title: Youth Held in Five Deaths
description: A teen-ager was held for investigation of murder today after his parents, sister and two grandparents were found stabbed to death in a burning condominium on Saturday.

title: Post Plans Sunday Paper
description: In its second attempt in seven years, The New York Post said it will start publishing a Sunday edition on April 14. A modest version of a traditional Sunday newspaper, it will cost 50 cents and number at least 80 pages, The Post said. A full-fledged Sunday edition was published briefly in 1989.

title: Rig Count Drops by 10
description: The number of oil and gas rigs operating in the United States dropped by 10 last week, to 693, Baker Hughes Inc. said. There were 724 rigs operating nationwide during the corresponding week a year ago. Of the rigs running last week, 389 were exploring for natural gas and 295 for oil. Nine rigs were listed as miscellaneous. The rig count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and natural gas.

title: Kevin Williams, Former Football Player, 38
description: Kevin Williams, a former star wide receiver at U.S.C. and a member of the 1978 national championship team, was killed in a freight-train crash, family members and railroad officials said. He was 38.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Salary Cap Shuffling
description: It looks as if the Cowboys' owner, JERRY JONES, will be asking TROY AIKMAN to renegotiate his contract again to free some money under the salary cap to sign other players.

title: To Retain Momentum, Peres May Call Israeli Elections by May
description: Israel's major newspapers all reported today that Prime Minister Shimon Peres had all but decided to advance national elections to May and that he would make the announcement within two weeks.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Parole Board Above Blame
description: A Superior Court judge has dismissed a suit filed by the mother of a girl, 7, who was raped and murdered in Passaic in 1993 by a convicted child kidnapper on parole. Judge Margaret McVeigh ruled last week that the law specifically exempted state employees and agencies, including the State Parole Board, from liability for the actions of parolees, the A.P. said yesterday.

title: Chinese Tiptoe Into Internet, Wary of Watchdogs
description: Correction Appended

title: CHRONICLE
description: JUDY COLLINS, the singer, and LOUIS NELSON, the industrial designer responsible for the Korean War memorial in Washington, are planning to be married on April 16. But it is not a decision they rushed into: they have been together for 18 years.

title: Trust Voters to Analyze Campaign Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: HORSE RACING;Unbridled's Song Falls To Appealing Skier
description: Unbridled's Song met the fate of many other early favorites for the Kentucky Derby today when he took his first steps on the road to Louisville and was outrun by half a length by Appealing Skier in the Hutcheson Stakes at Gulfstream Park.

title: Abroad at Home;Futility Of the Drug War
description: When President Clinton named Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey to "lead our nation's battle against drugs at home and abroad," he said General McCaffrey would need, to succeed, "a force far larger than he has ever commanded before. He needs all of us."

title: Reach Child Criminals Before They Kill
description: To the Editor:

title: In Performance: POP
description: Stretching the Limits Without Losing Control Henry Threadgill Knitting Factory

title: Sports of The Times;The Feet Mean Defeat For a Seething Starks
description: ABOUT midway through the third quarter of a tough ball game yesterday afternoon between the Knicks and the Pacers here, John Starks, the Knicks' cool-as-a-cucumber guard, raised up his leg and gave an unsuspecting folding chair on the bench a kick it would not soon forget. The kick knocked the chair down, and, to a large extent, knocked the Knicks out of the game.

title: SHORTFALL POSTED BY MEDICARE FUND TWO YEARS EARLY
description: New Government data show that Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund lost money last year for the first time since 1972, suggesting that the financial condition of the Medicare program is worse than assumed by either Congress or the Clinton Administration.

title: BASKETBALL NOTEBOOK;Reality Has Taste Of Airline Ambience
description: Charles Smith would not blame outside factors for the Knicks' 90-83 loss to the Indiana Pacers today at Market Square Arena, but he did sum up the team's "quick" trip to the heartland with this thought:

title: Forbes's Positions Found in Early Writings
description: Contrary to the impression left by his speeches and his television ads, Steve Forbes's flat-tax plan is not the only mantra that throws this Republican Presidential candidate into overdrive. Advocating Congressional term limits gets his adrenaline flowing, too.

title: Nintendo Game Is Delayed
description: The Nintendo Company said today that it would delay the introduction of its new 64-bit game machine in the United States until Sept. 30 because of a shortage of chips. The company had been aiming for April. The machine will still be introduced in Japan in April, a Nintendo spokesman said. "We have tried to procure chips for hardware, but they are still in tight supply," he said. Nintendo has not decided when to introduce the 64-bit player in Europe, the spokesman said.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Nigeria Police Question Lawyer Urging Embargo
description: The lawyer of an executed human rights activist, Ken Saro-Wiwa, said today that he was interrogated by the police after returning from a trip to Europe and Canada to campaign for a boycott of Nigerian oil exports.

title: In Performance: POP
description: Eight Men's Voices Evoke Zimbabwe's Spirit Black Umfolosi Symphony Space

title: The Changing Face of Racing;A Rival Indy-Car Circuit Puts a Damper on CART's Season
description: They call this spring training, and the activity here this week at the Homestead Motorsports Complex has the same grim sense of conflict that surrounded the last spring training to take place in Florida. But for that one, baseball came to an accommodation that rescued its 1995 season; Indy-car racing appears headed toward no such peace in 1996.

title: New York City Police Union Pounds Beat in State Capitol
description: When the Assembly voted on a bill recently that would strengthen the hand of New York City police officers in contract disputes, a group of burly men sat stiffly in the back of the chamber, taking down the names of the wayward. They said little, but everyone knew who they were: the leaders of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, a union that often seems to work the State Capitol like a legislative battering ram.

title: Town Clashes With Agency Over the Future of Its Landfill
description: For nearly nine years, the state has been trying to shut down a landfill in this Rockland County town, charging that it is polluting streams that flow into the Hudson River.

title: Market Place;A Stock-Trading Seat Is More And A Gold-Trading Seat Less These Days
description: STANDING on the New York Stock Exchange floor costs more than ever before. But trading gold costs a lot less than it used to.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Mike Shula Is Bucs' Offensive Coordinator
description: MIKE SHULA, a tight ends coach with the Chicago Bears for the last three seasons, became the National Football League's youngest offensive coordinator yesterday when the 30-year-old son of DON SHULA was hired by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. (AP)

title: POP REVIEW;Recalling A Genius of British Pop
description: One has to wonder about the sincerity of a tribute that begins with a glib speech describing in gory detail how the person to be honored killed himself and his landlady in 1967 on the eighth anniversary of Buddy Holly's death.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Hard Pressed, Grundig Will Lay Off 3,000
description: German industry's pride and strength were dealt another blow today when the country's premier maker of consumer electronics, Grundig A.G., announced a severe retrenchment.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Consistency Is Not A Hobgoblin For The Minds Behind Tide's Miracle
description: Glance back 50 years, if you will, to an era when proclaiming a product a "miracle" was neither derided as hyperbolic overpromising nor accepted with a knowing smirk as retro-chic kitsch.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HARTE-HANKS AND DIMARK IN DEAL WORTH $155 MILLION
description: Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Dimark Inc., a provider of marketing and data base services, for about $155 million in stock. Harte-Hanks, a direct marketing and media company in San Antonio, will exchange 0.656 share for each share of Dimark, which would value Dimark shares about $15 each. Shares of Dimark, which is based in Langhorne, Pa., fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $14.125, on the American Stock Exchange; shares of Harte-Hanks fell 37.5 cents, to $22.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Hewlett-Packard Account Review
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company in Palo Alto, Calif., said yesterday that it would begin a review on the account of its peripherals products in the United States, which include printers and scanners. The billings on the account, which has been handled by Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide in San Francisco, were estimated at $40 million.

title: Julian Samora, 75, a Pioneering Sociologist
description: Julian Samora, a scholar who encountered such pervasive prejudice growing up Chicano in southern Colorado that he became the first recognized Mexican-American sociologist and a leader in founding the academic movement for Mexican-American studies, died on Friday at his home in Albuquerque, N.M. He was 75 and had been suffering from a rare disorder of the nervous system.

title: Baseball Talks to Resume
description: Like pains in giving birth, the negotiating sessions in the long-running labor dispute in baseball are coming closer together.

title: Fashion Council Reaches a Crossroads
description: Preparing the journal for the 15th annual awards gala of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, to be held on Monday at Lincoln Center, Fern Mallis, the council's executive director, was hard pressed to find photographs of designers from 1980's awards shows. Instead, she found scads of pictures of socialites.

title: Gianandrea Gavazzeni, Former La Scala Director, 86
description: Gianandrea Gavazzeni, a former artistic director of La Scala in Milan, died today at his home in northern Italy, his family said. He was 86.

title: U.N., Facing Bankruptcy, Plans to Cut Payroll by 10%
description: The top financial official of the United Nations said today that the organization is sliding toward bankruptcy and will have to cut about 10 percent of its permanent staff of more than 10,000 people at its headquarters in New York City and in seven foreign cities during the next two years.

title: HOCKEY;Northeastern and B.U. Win
description: Boston University and Northeastern were the victors tonight at the 44th annual Beanpot Tournament, this city's midwinter salute to college hockey. They will meet next Monday night for the championship.

title: U.N. Official Says She Found No Missing Men in Srebrenica
description: A United Nations human rights envoy confronted relatives of the missing today, saying that she found no survivors during her visit to Srebrenica.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 30 about efforts by American labor unions to organize poultry workers in the South misstated the period during which Prof. Marc Linder of the University of Iowa Law School says poultry processing was second to the automobile-parts industry in manufacturing job growth. The article also misstated the number of jobs involved. The period was 1983-1993, during which poultry plant employment grew to 193,000 from 115,000.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Long Beach State Students Get Apologies
description: The coach of Long Beach State, SETH GREENBERG, has apologized to two New Mexico State students who said he had slandered them and violated their civil rights by having security officers remove them from a game between the schools on Jan. 22.

title: Bosnia Holds 8 Serbs In War Crimes Cases
description: The Muslim-led Bosnian Government told NATO today that it had arrested eight Bosnian Serbs, including a general and a colonel, for investigations into suspected war crimes. NATO said in a statement that its ground forces commander, Lieut. Gen. Michael Walker, was told of the arrests by a Bosnian Government security official, Bakir Alispahic.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SOCCER;Metrostars Sign Italian Hero
description: ROBERTO DONADONI, a member of Italy's last two World Cup teams and an integral part of AC Milan for a decade, yesterday became the first foreign star to sign with the Metrostars of Major League Soccer. The Metrostars will play in Giants Stadium.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pharmacia & Upjohn To Cut 10% of Jobs
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. confirmed yesterday that it would trim its work force by 4,000, about 10 percent, and set up headquarters near London. The company's president, John Zabriskie, also said the company -- the world's ninth-largest drug concern -- planned to introduce 28 products for treating a range of illnesses, including Parkinson's disease, cancer, AIDS and central nervous system disorders.

title: EASTERN COLLEGE REPORT
description: Iona

title: CHRONICLE
description: Never mind the chocolates; forget the roses. CAROL WINCENC, the flutist, has received a more impressive cache of Valentine's Day tributes. Ten composers have written short works with romantic themes for her to perform on Feb. 14 at Merkin Concert Hall. The concert is to be the first of three performed at the hall by winners of the Naumburg Award, given annually to young musicians by the Naumburg Foundation.

title: Tepid on Giuliani
description: Using crime and "quality of life" as campaign themes, Rudolph W. Giuliani came into office with strong support among police officers. But these days, many officers say they see the Mayor in a different light.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFS;G.O.P. Committee Out-Raises Democrats
description: The National Republican Congressional Committee, the chief campaign organization for House Republicans, says it raised nearly $34.7 million in 1995, three times what its Democratic counterpart raised.

title: Brodrick Haldane, Aristocrat Behind a Camera, Dies at 83
description: Brodrick Haldane, a witty and stylish photographer who used his impeccable social credentials to gain access to the rich, famous and well-connected, died in Edinburgh on Saturday. He was 83 and died of cancer.

title: Europeans Ask if the Euro Is Worth the Sacrifices
description: Europe's experiment in creating a common currency by the end of the decade has come under rising pressure here in recent days as top business executives, economists and government officials urged nations to pay greater attention to the slowing economy and rising unemployment.

title: Digital Equipment Introduces Fast Chip
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation introduced a chip today that it said runs on AA batteries and is the first microprocessor as fast as a supercomputer -- paving the way for a new wave of mobile consumer products.

title: The Irish Know Their Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actress Audrey Meadows yesterday misstated her age and the year of her birth. She was 69, not 71. She was born on Feb. 8, 1926, not in 1922.

title: Clinton Is Ordered to Testify In Ex-Partners' Fraud Trial
description: A Federal judge ordered President Clinton today to testify next month as a defense witness in the bank fraud and conspiracy trial of his former Whitewater business partners.

title: G.M., Sharing Some Profit, Lifts Dividend
description: Deciding to share more of its record profits with shareholders, directors of the General Motors Corporation today raised the quarterly dividend on the company's common stock by a third to 40 cents.

title: Beijing's Public Relations Gambit Won't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Beijing's Public Relations Gambit Won't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times;Can Lewis Stand the Test of Time?
description: THIS year marks the 60th anniversary of Jesse Owens's remarkable Olympic performance at the 1936 Berlin Games. Owens won four gold medals and set two world records. To mark the anniversary, Herb Douglas, a close friend of Owens and founder of the Jesse Owens International Trophy Award, has arranged to have nine 100-meter gold medalists in New York tonight for the presentation.

title: Strong Aftershocks Hit Chinese Quake Region
description: Hundreds of aftershocks in southwest China, where an earthquake killed at least 250 people and injured 15,000 over the weekend, jolted terrified villagers today.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Shostakovich on a Bill With a Split Personality
description: It must be difficult to find suitable companion works for the Shostakovich Symphony No. 14, an 11-movement meditation on death with a text drawn from the poetry of Lorca, Rilke, Apollinaire and a Russian named Wilhelm Kuchelbecker. The work's gravity is such that only a work of similar gloominess -- another of Shostakovich's ruminations, for example -- can sit beside it comfortably.

title: BASKETBALL;Minutemen Seeking A's In History
description: They have flirted with defeat on several occasions this season, but the Minutemen of Massachusetts (21-0 over all, 9-0 in the Atlantic 10) have every intention of keeping a date with history.

title: Tobacco Company Says '60 Minutes' Avoided Data on Accuser
description: The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation yesterday complained that the CBS News program "60 Minutes" of had deliberately ignored reasons to doubt the credibility of a former executive whose accusations of possible criminal conduct at the company were broadcast on the program on Sunday night.

title: An Acquisition for Avon
description: Avon Products Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Justine Ltd., marking the beauty-care company's entrance into South Africa. Terms were not disclosed. Justine, of South Africa, is a privately held direct seller of skin care, color cosmetics, fragrances and other beauty products there.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BRODERBUND PREDICTS EARNINGS BELOW EXPECTATIONS
description: Shares of Broderbund Software Inc. fell sharply yesterday in after-hours trading after the company announced that earnings for the second quarter, which ends on Feb. 29, would fall short of analysts' estimates. After rising $3, to $53.125, in regular Nasdaq trading, Broderbund shares fell to $49. Broderbund, based in Novato, Calif., said it expected revenues in the quarter of $44 million to $49 million, compared with $45.2 million in the corresponding period last year.

title: BASKETBALL;Final Semester Is Time for Fun
description: The blueprint was so much easier to follow when it was simpler. Jennifer Rizzotti would identify a challenge, and soon it would take on the characteristics of a too-slow point guard scrambling back on defense while Rizzotti runs the break for the Connecticut Huskies. It would have no chance. "I've never backed down from anything," Rizzotti said, her voice more explanatory than defiant.

title: I.R.S Details a Policy in Ruling On Companions' Health Benefit
description: Workers who receive employer-provided health insurance for an adult companion to whom they are not married must pay income taxes on the benefit unless they provide more than half of the companion's support, the Internal Revenue Service said.

title: Roof Collapse Kills a Firefighter, 3d to Die in New York in 6 Weeks
description: For the third time in less than six weeks, a New York City firefighter died while on duty yesterday, when the roof of an auto body shop in Brooklyn collapsed on him as he searched for people inside the building.

title: Suspension, But No Foul
description: The Big Ten has reprimanded Michigan State forward Jon Garavaglia for striking an opposing player during a game at Purdue last Saturday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Yankees and Ward Experiencing Delays
description: General Manager BOB WATSON said the Yankees have experienced some scheduling difficulties in having reliever DUANE WARD audition for them again, which has caused a delay in reaching a potential contract agreement. Watson said yesterday that the Yankees would not make a decision on the right-hander until at least tomorrow.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BETTY FRIEDAN turned 75 on Sunday, and her friends MARLENE SANDERS, LINDA WOLFE and CYNTHIA FUCHS EPSTEIN assembled about 75 of Ms. Friedan's friends that afternoon to celebrate in Ms. Sanders's Upper West Side apartment. Thirty-three years ago, Ms. Friedan ignited a national movement with her book "The Feminine Mystique," and she has been in the limelight ever since.

title: Cold Imperils Fruit Harvest In the South
description: Roy Parke is spending his nights watching thermometers in strawberry bushes and chipping ice from sprinkler heads to protect his crop, a $1 million business endangered by freezing weather that swept through Florida after delivering misery to much of the country.

title: Executive Changes
description: DICK CLARK RESTAURANTS INC. , Burbank, Calif., a subsidiary of Dick Clark Productions, named Ando Teder executive vice president.

title: The Selling of Store Security;Buffeted by Crime, a Long Island Mall Adds Marketing to Law Enforcement
description: Ten hours a day, five days a week, Robert M. Walsh toils in the alternate reality of the Green Acres shopping mall, where the sun never rises and dusk never falls. He patrols the enclosed streets, his eyes hunting for potential perps and pockets of unruly adolescence.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Russian Economy and Excess
description: The program for the concert by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center on Friday night was all Russian. But little other than nationality linked the evening's two major works: Shostakovich's powerfully spare "Seven Romances on Poems of Aleksandr Blok" and Tchaikovsky's extravagantly excessive Trio in A minor for Violin, Cello and Piano.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Takeover of Zoo Is Sought
description: Essex County officials said yesterday that they were "vigorously negotiating" with several private companies to take over the Turtle Back Zoo. The 400-animal zoo, which officials say is a "tax drain" with deplorable conditions that drive visitors away, could close on April 1, when the county is scheduled to stop paying for it. County Executive James Treffinger said that, if the county did not find a private contractor to run the 33-year-old zoo, it would try to lease it to a nonprofit group.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Protests That Turned Into Killings
description: In December 1994 two women were killed and five other people were wounded in two clinics on a Brookline, Mass., road known to anti-abortionists as "abortion row." "Murder on 'Abortion Row' " explores the lives of the killer, John Salvi 3d, who went on trial yesterday, and his pictims, two clinic receptionists, Leeanne Nichols and, especially, Shannon Lowney.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Officers to Patrol in School
description: For the first time, Paterson school officials have decided they need police officers on patrol in their hallways. "We're not looking in any way shape or form to create a police state," Mayor William Pascrell said. "They're not going to be searching lockers or anything like that." But he said the mere presence of six officers assigned to John F. Kennedy High School would deter violence like the fights that have recently broken out there.

title: Capriati to Play Paris Next Week
description: Jennifer Capriati, the troubled tennis player who beat Steffi Graf to win the Olympic gold medal in 1992, is scheduled to make her first tournament appearance since November 1994 in the Paris Open next week.

title: Apple Computer Cuts Prices on Its Performa Line
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had reduced the prices of its Performa line of consumer-oriented Macintosh's as much as 12 percent, and broadened a rebate program on printers and monitors.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TWO MORE EXECUTIVES DEPART LOTUS DEVELOPMENT
description: Two executives announced their departures from the Lotus Development Corporation yesterday, joining the exodus of upper management since I.B.M. bought the company last summer. Jeffrey Beir, 38, senior vice president in charge of applications software for desktop computers, resigned to pursue an "entrepreneurial opportunity," according to a Lotus spokesman. Separately, Russell Campanello, 39, the head of human resources, announced his departure to pursue other interests. Neither was available for comment. Mr. Beir will be succeeded by John Throckmorton, who is in charge of the development of desktop applications programs. A successor to Mr. Campanello has not been named.

title: 26 Members of Chinese-American Groups in Atlanta Indicted
description: Federal law-enforcement officials today charged leaders of several Chinese-American fraternal organizations here with money laundering and drug trafficking, suggesting that these organizations, or "tongs," have been used as fronts for organized crime not only in New York and California but also in the South.

title: The Doctor's World;New AIDS Therapies Arise, But Who Can Afford the Bill?
description: Shortly after AIDS was first recognized in 1981, activists demanded: give us new therapies. Now the latest worry of activists and many others concerned about the costs of health care is: who can afford them?

title: INSIDE
description: Planning Another Budget

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Long Island Weekly on Sunday about David Alan Miller, a conductor who dresses as Beethoven, misstated the date of his concerts at Tilles Center in Greenvale, L.I. They are at 1 and 3:15 P.M. this Saturday, not Sunday.

title: Frustrated Users Sue PC Maker Over Busy Signals on 'Help' Line
description: Got a problem with that new personal computer? The manufacturer's "800" number is always busy? Finally, after hours, maybe days, you get through but the help-desk people aren't helpful?

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Investors Betting on Baxter To Sweeten Its Bid for Grace
description: Betting that Baxter International would raise its $3.8 billion bid for the big kidney dialysis unit of W.R. Grace & Company, Wall Street traders pushed up the price of Grace shares again yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, while Baxter shares again declined on the Big Board.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Monaco Government Tourist Office, New York, to Green Team Advertising, New York, to handle its advertising in North America, previously handled by Marshall Jaccoma Mitchell, New York. The billings were estimated at $1 million. * Rihga Royal Hotel, New York, to Krimstein/Clapps Ltd., New York, to handle its account, previously handled by Serino Coyne, New York. The billings have not been determined. * Sundance Film Channel, New York, a joint venture of Robert Redford and the Showtime Networks unit of Viacom, New York, to the New York office of Young & Rubicam Inc., to handle advertising for the new cable television network, previously handled by Air Force One, New York, which will continue to work for Sundance. The billings have not been determined. * Prestige Fragrance and Cosmetics, Holmdel, N.J., a division of the Revlon unit of MacAndrews & Forbes, to Linett & Harrison, Millburn, N.J., as the first agency to handle the account of the chain of outlet stores. Billings were not disclosed.

title: But What About February 9, 1934 . . .
description: The mercury began its plunge on a Thursday night 62 years ago this week. The moment that Thursday became Friday, the temperature was 7 below zero. By 7 A.M., it was 13 below, and at 7:25 A.M. on Friday, Feb. 9, 1934, the coldest temperature ever for New York City was recorded.

title: Beijing's Public Relations Gambit Won't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: The Heat of Stars

title: Beijing's Public Relations Gambit Won't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Strolling at Will, Chechen Rebels Mock Russians
description: This grim Chechen village looks pretty much like the others strung across the eastern plains here. It is a decimated little farming town surrounded by the Russian Army, which patrols the access roads with tanks, helicopters and hundreds of troops.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;MINNESOTA MINING & MFG. CO. (MMM,N)
description: Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing reported a loss yesterday of $97 million for the fourth quarter as a result of charges for job cuts and write-downs.

title: Editorial Notebook;The Littlest Killers
description: Imagine the terror of a 5-year-old child, dangling 14 stories above the pavement, as his brother tries fruitlessly to save him from two other boys, ages 10 and 11, who are determined to see him drop.

title: Polaroid Organizes Into 3 Businesses
description: The Polaroid Corporation said today that it would separate its operations into three business groups in an effort to return the company to profitability.

title: Clinton Meets Deadline With an Outline of 1997 Budget
description: With the Federal budget for the current year still far from settled, President Clinton today proposed a $1.64 trillion spending plan for 1997, sketching how he would balance the budget in seven years with a small tax cut. But the Republican-controlled Congress has already dismissed the plan as inadequate.

title: PERIPHERALS;All at Sea on a Voyage Through the Daunting World of Physics
description: THE Cartoon Guide to Physics is an entertaining and informative CD-ROM based on the book of the same name by Larry Gonick and Art Hoffman. It seems more entertaining than informative, but that may be a generational problem. Students who have grown up with computers may well get a lot out of it. Harumph.

title: Actuaries Fault Health Insurers' Stand on Bill
description: A leading organization of statisticians accused the health insurance industry's chief lobbying group today of greatly exaggerating the cost of legislation designed to enable people who lose group coverage to buy individual policies.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;R. J. Reynolds Picks Gyro Advertising
description: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company said yesterday that it had named Gyro Advertising in Philadelphia as agency of record for its Red Kamel cigarette brand, which is being reintroduced after a 60-year hiatus. The billings were not disclosed.

title: Chess
description: Anatoly Karpov made one move in his last-round game in the prestigious Koop Tjuchem International Tournament in Groningen, the Netherlands, and then offered a draw. When his opponent, Peter Leko of Hungary, quickly accepted, the International Chess Federation titleholder was assured of victory.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: GREENWICH BUYING AVIALL'S ENGINE SERVICES UNIT Greenwich Air Services Inc. signed a letter of intent yesterday to purchase Aviall Inc.'s Commercial Engine Services division for an estimated price of $260 million to $280 million. Shares of both companies surged yesterday. The acquisition will make Greenwich the world's largest company in the business of engine repair, maintenance and overhaul. The purchase includes Aviall's operations in Dallas, Fort Worth and Prestwick, Scotland, as well as its components business in McAllen, Tex. Greenwich shares rose $5, or 22 percent, to close at $27.75 in Nasdaq trading; Aviall shares rose $1.25, or 23.3 percent, to close at $6.625 on the New York Stock Exchange. (Reuters)

title: Secret Life of the Fungus Is Unveiled. Yes, It Does Have Sex
description: HOW can you tell if a fungus is having sex? Until now, the answer to this rather arcane scientific riddle has been: not very easily. Now a team of researchers, borrowing techniques from diverse fields to study the fungus that each year gives thousands of people Valley Fever, say they have found some straightforward ways to answer the question. They have discovered that the fungus, thought for over a century to be chastely asexual, is in fact having sex and quite a bit of it.

title: City Hall' Passes Muster With Real-Life Officials
description: The City Hall crowd finally got a look at "City Hall" last night.

title: A Museum Tackles A Monster: Abstraction
description: Time was running short. And with the opening on Friday of "Abstraction in the 20th Century: Total Risk, Freedom, Discipline" rapidly approaching, what was visible on a recent visit to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum was more applied science than art.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;GOODYEAR TIRE and RUBBER CO. (GT,N)
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that earnings rose 7.3 percent in the fourth quarter as productivity improvements and higher prices offset steep raw material costs and slow United States sales.

title: SFX Buys 2 Stations
description: SFX Broadcasting Inc. said yesterday that it had bought two radio stations in Charlotte, N.C., from Trumper Communications Inc. for $23.5 million. The New York-based SFX Broadcasting has operated the two FM stations -- WTDR and WLYT -- since April 1, 1995, under a local marketing agreement.

title: Xikou Journal;A Villain No More, Chiang Kai-shek for Tourists
description: The small armyof Red Guards charged up the moun tain screaming slogans into the tow ering pines.

title: Job Trainees Support Whitman on Welfare
description: Kathy Scott is a single mother of three who has been getting by on public assistance for more than a decade. Under Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposal to overhaul New Jersey's welfare system, Ms. Scott risks losing the only source of income she has known since the bridal shop where she worked shut down.

title: Will 'Efficacy' Help New York's Schools?
description: How much is "efficacy" worth? At a time when New York City's schools find their budget chipped away by the Mayor, Governor and Uncle Sam alike, when many buildings are in ruinous condition, when class size is rising and teachers lack books and supplies, any large educational innovation invites scrutiny -- even one ardently championed by an engaging new Chancellor in his honeymoon period.

title: Forbes Rejects Racism in All Its Forms
description: To the Editor:

title: POP REVIEW;The Word of God With an MTV Beat
description: Runway models and chameleons have a rival for quick-change skills: DC Talk, the Christian rock band that performed at the Mercury Lounge on Friday night. During its set, DC Talk sounded like Stone Temple Pilots and Kool and the Gang, Fishbone and Harry Chapin, U2 and the Doobie Brothers, L. L. Cool J. and Styx. It deployed all those styles to proselytize for Christianity.

title: USAir's Chairman Recruits Two Aides
description: Stephen M. Wolf, the recently appointed chairman and chief executive of USAir Group, has recruited two longtime deputies to help him try to turn around the nation's sixth-largest airline.

title: Harold Brasington, Speedway Builder, 86
description: Harold Brasington, the former dirt-track stock car racer who built the original Darlington Raceway, the first of the superspeedways on the Nascar circuit, died Sunday. He was 86.

title: Cables Show U.S. Deception on Haitian Violence
description: In the months after the United States invasion of Haiti, American officers repeatedly told their troops that the country's most dreaded paramilitary group was actually a legitimate opposition political party. "They're no different from Democrats or Republicans," soldiers in Haiti dutifully echoed when asked about their instructions.

title: Patterns
description: Bloomingdale's Presents

title: Union Leaders Claim Victory in Strike
description: As more than 30,000 striking maintenance workers returned to work, union leaders tried to cast their agreement to end the walkout as a victory for labor even though the union was forced to accept a lower starting salary for new workers.

title: Greece Rejects U.S. Visit
description: Greece has turned down a weekend visit by a high American official in which he proposed to try to resolve its dispute with Turkey over a small island, and the American has canceled the visit.

title: GOVERNORS GROUP FINDS AGREEMENT ON MEDICAID PLAN
description: Leaders of the nation's governors said tonight that they had agreed on a bipartisan proposal on Medicaid, one of the major stumbling blocks in the budget impasse between President Clinton and Republicans in Congress.

title: HOCKEY;Fichaud Between Pipes
description: The Rangers defeated the Islanders handily in their first two meetings this season, but the Islanders will have a new look in goal for the two meetings between the teams in the next three days.

title: The Arts Are Again Invited to the Budget Dance
description: The arts may be an economic engine driving New York City, as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has often said, but once again City Hall is threatening to cut back the fuel supply.

title: Ford to Offer Cheaper Cars As Sales Sag
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would begin selling a lower-cost version of its redesigned Taurus sedan as it reported that its sales of cars and light trucks dropped in January, pushing the pace of total industry sales into negative territory, compared with levels a year ago.

title: A 'Fireman's Fireman'
description: The four-five signal sounded yesterday afternoon at Rescue Company 2 on Bergen Street in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. In the old days it was done with bells, five peals repeated four times. Yesterday it came over the teleprinter, but the meaning was the same:

title: The Toad Shows That 'Handedness' Is Not Exclusive to the Higher Orders
description: IF you are going to shake hands with a toad, extend your right one.

title: SPORTS BUSINESS;Seahawks' Plan Shakes N.F.L.
description: For creativity, Kenneth Behring, the Seattle Seahawks' owner, is offering the blue-ribbon excuse for moving his team. In asking the Southern California market for its hand in holy relocation last week, he said the Kingdome is unsafe from earthquakes. So on Sunday he loaded up his trucks and sent them to Anahe'm, directly into America's seismic capital.

title: Ancient Smelter Used Wind To Make High-Grade Steel
description: EVERY year from June to September, powerful monsoon winds blow steadily off the Indian Ocean, lashing the slopes of the hills and ridges of Sri Lanka facing the southwest. The winds dump torrents of rain on parts of the country, while leaving the rest blow-dried.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday about Bob Dole's campaign in Dubuque, Iowa, misstated the date of his appearance. It was Saturday, not Sunday.

title: NYC;Firebombing: Putting Blame On Prozac
description: A 90's version of the Twinkie defense holds center stage in the plain, wood-paneled chamber that is Part 72 of State Supreme Court in Manhattan. That is where Edward J. Leary has been on trial for the last week, charged with attempted murder in two subway firebombings that burned and scarred 50 people in December 1994.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Thompson Canada Forms an Alliance
description: J. Walter Thompson Canada in Toronto, a unit of the WPP Group, and Groupaction Marketing Inc. in Montreal said yesterday that they would form a long-term strategic alliance as Thompson Canada agreed to make a nonequity investment in Groupaction. The other terms were not disclosed.

title: Italy Needs a New Political System
description: Italy's modern political system has hardly been a model of stability, but even by Rome's chaotic standards the last few years have been dizzying. Since the governing parties and most of their leaders were brought down by corruption scandals in 1992, Italy has stumbled from one crisis to another. Now, encouragingly, the country's main political groupings have finally concluded that what the country needs is not new leaders but a new constitution and political system.

title: POLITICS;Looking for Mr. Outside
description: The tensions within the Republican Party that hindered its efforts to advance a legislative agenda on Capitol Hill last year are showing up in the struggle for the party's Presidential nomination this year. They provide one key to understanding the surge of Steve Forbes in Iowa and New Hampshire, the two often pivotal states that vote later this month.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;A Homecoming in Harlem for Bradley
description: LONNIE BRADLEY, who wants to bring his native Harlem its first world championship since the days of Sugar Ray Robinson, is back in New York tonight. Bradley is the undefeated World Boxing Organization middleweight champion. He has not fought in New York in three years, but he returns to face RANDY SMITH of Rancho Cucamonga, Calif., at the 69th Regiment Armory, 26th Street and Lexington Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a tentative settlement in the New York City building workers' strike misidentified the man at the right, extending a hand to Gus Bevona, the union president. It was Edward Riguardi, chairman of the Realty Advisory Board's negotiating committee and executive vice president of Colliers ABR, a real estate management company, not James F. Berg, chief negotiator for the industry.

title: On My Mind;Washington Confronts China
description: Washington has chosen the issue on which it will at last acknowledge and confront Chinese Communist action detrimental to the United States.

title: Observer;Pilling It Up
description: For several weeks I took pills. I took cheap pills, and I took expensive pills.

title: Terrorism in Sudan
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Family Members Give to Honor Elders
description: Dr. Percy Klingenstein turned 100 last month and The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund received $500 from his daughter-in-law, Ann Holmes. She wanted to celebrate and honor Dr. Klingenstein's devotion to his hometown.

title: Communists Are Up to No Good, Russian Warns
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Russia's resurgent Communist Party will suppress civil liberties, devastate the economy and trigger widespread bloodshed if it is allowed to prevail in presidential elections this June, a leading Russian economic reformer warned the West on Monday.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Revlon Pushes an Offering At as Much as $22 a Share
description: Revlon Inc., the cosmetic company owned by the MacAndrews & Forbes Group, moved rapidly yesterday to offer its stock to the public by the end of the month.

title: Youth Gets Probation In a Killing
description: A former Mount Vernon High school student convicted of stabbing a classmate to death inside the school in 1994 was sentenced today to five years of probation. The Westchester County District Attorney immediately protested the sentence.

title: By Design;The Lariat Necklace
description: After months of no accessories, the necklace has returned. It started last fall when actresses on television shows like "Melrose Place" and "Friends" inspired legions of fans to wear necklaces of small beads with "Y"-shaped drops. The "Y" necklace is still going strong, and Saks Fifth Avenue has a trove in silver and gold adorned with pearls, rhinestones or colored beads ($48 to $545).

title: Small Companies, Big Problems
description: These days, when the California Public Employees' Retirement System talks, big business usually listens. After a slow start, the pension fund, with $97 billion in assets and a reformist's fervor to match, has won several breakthroughs as the leader of the decade-old shareholders' campaign to hold poorly performing chief executives' feet to the fire.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Refund for Envelope Stuffers
description: It sounded too good to be true and it was -- when a Massachusetts company promised easy money for sitting at home stuffing envelopes. Still, about 600 New Jersey residents were among 27,000 consumers nationwide who sent $39 to the Lifetime Nutrition Company to get the work. Now those who fell for the pitch may be able to get a little of their money back. Mark S. Herr, director of the New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs, said yesterday that the company had agreed to pay more than $100,000 to consumers to settle a lawsuit filed by Massachusetts. Mr. Herr's agency will send out letters about the deal.

title: Large Stockholder Quits Board at Micron
description: In the latest chapter in the Micron Technology drama, Allen T. Noble, one of the earliest investors in the memory chip maker, resigned yesterday from its board.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;MCA Stake In Theme Park
description: MCA Inc. will take an equity stake of 17 percent, more than initially envisioned, in the Universal Studios Japan theme park it will build in Osaka, company officials said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Metallgesellschaft Returns to Profitability
description: Metallgesellschaft A.G., the German metals, trading and financial services company that had to be rescued from the brink of bankruptcy in 1994, said yesterday that it returned to profitability in the year that ended on Sept. 30.
