The company said it earned 171 million marks ($115 million), a sharp turnaround from a loss of 2.54 billion marks a year earlier, when there were huge losses from risky oil deals.

title: Foschi's Parents Challenge Ban
description: The parents of Jessica Foschi, the 15-year-old Long Island swimmer who tested positive for steroids last summer, have gone to court to challenge her ban from competition.

title: Adele Bishop, 68; Popularized Stencils
description: Adele Bishop, who was instrumental in reviving the popularity of decorative stencils in the United States, died on Jan. 30 at Lenoir Memorial Hospital in Kinston, N.C. She was 68 and lived in Greenville, N.C.

title: New Venture Plans System On Internet For Travelers
description: The executive in charge of the American Express retail travel business has resigned to become president and chief executive of Middlegate Inc., a new start-up venture that plans to develop an Internet-oriented travel system to compete against conventional travel agents.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Fokker Holding Talks With 5 Possible Buyers
description: The financially troubled Dutch aircraft maker Fokker N.V. said yesterday that there were five serious candidates talking with the company about an acquisition. Fokker, which is faltering after 76 years of manufacturing planes, declined to identify the companies, but the companies themselves have said they are talking with Fokker. They are British Aerospace; Aerospatiale of France; Taiwan Aerospace; Samsung of South Korea and Bombardier of Canada.

title: Brutal Cold Air Sinks Its Teeth And Hangs On
description: It took a man with a hair dryer a good part of the morning yesterday to turn the cylinder of ice back into a running water pipe at the Bais Ezra home for the mentally retarded in Flushing, Queens.

title: Airbus Itching To Build Its Own Superjumbo Jet
description: SINGAPORE  Airbus Industrie, stung by the recent loss of aircraft orders in Asia worth nearly $17 billion to Boeing Co., is hastening moves to build a superjumbo jet to compete with its American rival, officials said Monday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MARVEL NAMES EXECUTIVE FOR NEW SOFTWARE DIVISION
description: The Marvel Entertainment Group has chosen Scott Marden to be chief executive of a new division, Marvel Software. Mr. Marden, 41, had been the president and chief executive of Philips Media, a unit of Philips Electronics. Mr. Marden said he hoped to propel Marvel into electronic publishing by developing on-line services and Web sites. Marvel, which owns comic-book titles like Spider-Man and the X-Men, has been somewhat haphazard in licensing those characters to multimedia outlets, he said. "It has become increasingly clear that the future of the company was going to be tied to electronic delivery," Mr. Marden said. At Philips, Mr. Marden established a multimedia publishing division and oversaw the company's cable TV holdings.

title: No Mercy on Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;HOSPITALITY PROPERTIES SIGNS DEALS FOR 45 HOTELS
description: Hospitality Properties Trust, a real estate investment trust in Newton, Mass., said yesterday that it had signed letters of intent to acquire 45 hotels and to lease them back to the sellers or to other parties. Hospitality will acquire 11 Wyndham Gardens hotels for $136 million from an affiliate of the Dallas-based Wyndham Hotel Company and will lease them to another Wyndham affiliate. In a second deal, Hospitality will buy 18 Residence Inn hotels from an affiliate of the Host Marriott Corporation for $172.2 million and will lease them to a Hospitality affiliate. Hospitality will also acquire 16 Courtyard by Marriott hotels for $176.4 million and will lease them to Host Marriott affiliates. Hospitality will own 82 hotels in 26 states after the transactions close.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Inoffensive Jets Give The Clipboard To Erhardt
description: In the wake of their failed 1995 season, which produced the worst record in the National Football League as well as in club history, the Jets began their off-season renovations yesterday by hiring the Super Bowl Steelers' offensive coordinator, Ron Erhardt, and their tight-ends coach, Pat Hodgson.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Aide Pleads Not Guilty
description: Jackie R. Mattison, chief of staff to Mayor Sharpe James, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of accepting bribes in the steering of city contracts to an insurance broker. "We feel there is no basis for these charges whatsoever," said Thomas R. Ashley, Mr. Mattison's lawyer. Judge William G. Bassler of Federal District Court set a Sept. 16 trial date.

title: Exxon to Add To Surge in Oil From North Sea
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it would spend $800 million to develop a big oilfield in the Norwegian part of the North Sea, adding to the area's surging output.

title: TRACK AND FIELD: NOTEBOOK;A New Timetable For Dashing Johnson?
description: Michael Johnson was in Atlanta yesterday, joining Carl Lewis, Dan O'Brien, Jackie Joyner-Kersee, Gail Devers and Sandra Farmer Patrick to model the United States track and field uniforms for the Summer Olympics in Atlanta. He will be in New York tonight to receive the Jesse Owens International Trophy award. Next month, he expects international track officials to adjust the Olympic timetable so he can comfortably run both the 200 and 400 meters and achieve a double no man has ever achieved.

title: Space Probe Is Set to Visit Eros, An Earth-Grazing Asteroid
description: SPEEDING through the wastelands of space is a riot of rubble left over from the creation of the solar system, including lumps of rock up to hundreds of miles wide that orbit the Sun, mainly in a belt between Mars and Jupiter. These bodies, known as asteroids, are studied for clues to how the solar system formed more than four billion years ago.

title: On Eve of Talks, Iraq Is Hopeful U.N. Will Let Oil Exports Resume
description: As Iraq and the United Nations prepare for talks that could allow the Baghdad Government to resume exports of oil, optimism has surged in the Iraqi capital, where the dinar is now seven times stronger against the dollar than it was at the start of the year.

title: New York's Thin, Angry Blue Line
description: Since he began campaigning for the job he now holds, Rudolph W. Giuliani has modeled himself as a Mayor every police officer could be proud of. He made crime and "quality of life" central themes of the campaign and now considers among his greatest accomplishments a stunning drop in murders, car thefts and other offenses.

title: BASKETBALL;From Harlem Playgrounds To Basketball Hall of Fame
description: Nancy Lieberman-Cline, who used to take the subway from Queens to play basketball against boys on Harlem playgrounds, was elected yesterday to the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame. She was joined by George Gervin, David Thompson, Gail Goodrich and George Yardley, all former stars in the National Basketball Association, and the late Kresimir Cosic, who played on four Olympic teams for Yugoslavia.

title: Helium Won't Fill Future Demands, Physicists Warn
description: IN the century since it was discovered as a trace ingredient of the uranium mineral clevite, helium, the second lightest of all elements, has become indispensable to science and technology. Scientists believe it could play a vital role in helping the world through future energy shortages.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFS;Forbes Unchallenged In Spending Race
description: In the last three months of 1995, Steve Forbes spent $14 million on his bid to become the Republican Presidential nominee, far more than the $8.2 million spent by Senator Bob Dole or the $5.3 million spent by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, according to records made public today by the Federal Election Commission.

title: Mr. Forbes's Millions
description: Senator Phil Gramm voiced frustration last weekend that his message had been drowned out by a bombardment of television commercials from Steve Forbes, the publishing heir whose heavy spending of his own money has catapulted him ahead of Mr. Gramm, and even Senator Bob Dole, in some New Hampshire polls.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Artificial Reefs a Success
description: Artificial reefs installed at Belmar, Cape May Point and Avalon have limited erosion from major storms, a new study says. "It is about as dramatic or as clear-cut a success as one could imagine in our field," said Michael S. Bruno of Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken. Mr. Bruno said that the reefs -- giant concrete slabs made by Breakwaters International Inc. of Flemington -- were most effective when used between jetties or groins. The reefs cost $600 a linear foot, The Associated Press reported. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFS;A Momentary Lapse For Uncritical Dole
description: Senator Bob Dole swore off speaking ill of his Republican opponents during a three-day swing through Iowa that ended today. And for the most part, he succeeded. But every now and then, it seemed, he just could not help himself, as when he appealed to a crowd of about 70 here today.

title: Virginia Democrat Joins the House Exodus
description: Representative L. F. Payne Jr. said today that he would not seek re-election, joining dozens of lawmakers, most of them Democrats, who are leaving Congress.

title: Assembly Democrats Press for Records on Pataki's Inaugural Funding
description: Setting the stage for a confrontation with the Pataki administration, Assembly Democrats threatened today to subpoena records from two former officers of the private corporation that raised at least hundreds of thousands of dollars for the Governor's lavish three-day inauguration last year.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Washington's Standing In Locker-Room Lineup
description: FOUNDING FATHER Rediscovering George Washington By Richard Brookhiser 230 pages. The Free Press. $25.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Medieval Fascination With Games and Puns
description: Through the Middle Ages, music struggled to transform itself from an oral tradition into an art with its own literacy. Finding a usable written language -- marks on a page that would suggest notes, meter and rhythm -- constituted one puzzle, how to print and proliferate that language another.

title: Stratton Air Base to Grow
description: The New York Air National Guard, which already flies supply missions to the Arctic for the National Science Foundation, is going to do the same in the Antarctic, Gov. George E. Pataki said today.

title: Simpson Offers Long Rebuttal To Accusations
description: With flashes of exasperation and combativeness, O. J. Simpson today gave the most detailed response he has offered to accusations that he killed Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman, denying that he had abused Mrs. Simpson and expressing suspicions that the police planted evidence.

title: ON BASKETBALL;Still Left Out, but Not Down, at Texas-El Paso
description: In the lobby of an El Paso hospital where Rick Majerus waited for Don Haskins to come through triple-bypass surgery two weeks ago, a man approached him and held out his hand. His name was Willie Cager, and, instantly, Majerus was back in Milwaukee, in the Marquette High School gymnasium in the spring of 1966.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VARITY DROPS BID FOR REMAINING STAKE IN HAYES WHEELS
description: The Varity Corporation said yesterday that it had withdrawn its offer for the remaining 54 percent stake in Hayes Wheels International Inc. Varity, an industrial company based in Buffalo, announced in September that it planned to buy the Hayes shares for $25 each, or about $236 million. Along with its 46 percent stake in Hayes, Varity owns Kelsey Hayes, a supplier of brake products, and Dayton Walther, a maker of wheel and brake parts for heavy-duty trucks and trailers. Hayes, based in Romulus, Mich., makes aluminum and steel automotive wheels. Its shares fell $4.625, or 19 percent, to $19.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;First, Nets Disappear; Next Up, It's Magic
description: After disappearing for four minutes Sunday night in a loss against the Golden State Warriors, the Nets traveled to Los Angeles, where they take their act to Magic's castle on Wednesday.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Running On Empty, The Knicks Hang On
description: Early in the fourth quarter, the Knicks were in control. A few minutes later, they were in trouble.

title: Mixed Verdict For Six Youths In Fatal Beating
description: In a case that revealed flaws in the 911 emergency telephone system and illustrated how teen-age violence has reached even affluent neighborhoods, a jury rendered a mixed verdict today against six youths accused of beating a 16-year-old boy to death.

title: Beijing's Public Relations Gambit Won't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FLEXTRONICS INTERNATIONAL LTD., San Jose, Calif., a maker of electronic components, purchased Astron Group Inc. for $35 million in cash, stock and promissory notes.

title: COMPANY NEWS;JACOR COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY NOBLE BROADCAST GROUP
description: Jacor Communications Inc., a radio and cable television holding company in Cincinnati, said yesterday that it would acquire Noble Broadcast Group Inc. from Conseco Inc. for about $152 million. The deal will make Jacor the nation's fifth-largest radio company. Jacor said it had received credit commitments of $300 million from a group of banks for the purchase and for future acquisitions. Noble's 12 radio stations serve Denver, St. Louis, San Diego and Toledo, Ohio. Conseco, a financial services holding company based in Carmel, Ind., acquired a 75 percent equity stake in San Diego-based Noble in August in return for providing it with $37 million of subordinated debt financing.

title: No Headline
description: I'm not walking out of this house. I'm not eating out. I'm not going out. I'm living on peanut butter." ELAINE BRODSKY, a dance instructor in Great Neck, L.I. [A1:3.]

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Leader Backed for Youth Job
description: It looks as if the state's new Juvenile Justice Commission will finally get a leader. The Senate voted, 30 to 8, yesterday to approve the appointment of Paul Donnelly, who most recently headed a drug-abuse program in Texas. Initially, some senators objected to the nomination of someone from out of state, but Gov. Christine Todd Whitman persevered in pressing her candidate to run the new agency, which will coordinate the treatment and punishment of juvenile delinquents.

title: BASKETBALL;Johnson Gives TNT a Lift
description: Magic Johnson's second comeback game, against Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls on Friday, set a record 7.1 Nielsen rating for the TNT cable television network and exceeded the 4.4 rating last Tuesday for Johnson's debut against Golden State.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AT&T NAMES A UNIT IT PLANS TO SPIN OFF
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it had given the name Lucent Technologies to the equipment business it plans to spin off this year. AT&T said it was registering with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of 15 percent of Lucent shares. It also named seven members to the new Lucent board. By the end of 1996, AT&T will divide into three companies: the AT&T Corporation, a telephone company; Lucent Technologies, and the NCR Corporation, a maker of large computers. Analysts said that Lucent would have the potential to be a big money maker, perhaps doubling its revenue within five years. AT&T shareholders will receive one share of each of the new companies for each AT&T share.

title: LONDON THEATER;A Large-Screen Classic Goes in Circles Onstage
description: Most flops are forgettable. A few drill their way into the memory like a melody that won't be dislodged by anything short of brain surgery. Thus one of the more memorable events of the current London theater season is "Les Enfants du Paradis," the elaborate, dizzying, wrongheaded Royal Shakespeare Company production that opened last Tuesday on the huge main stage of the Barbican Center.

title: F. Lee Bailey Plans to Return Money to Court
description: The criminal defense lawyer F. Lee Bailey said yesterday that he would meet a deadline to turn over $3 million to a Federal court in Florida by Feb. 29, avoiding a potential six-month jail sentence for contempt of court.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Natural Gas, Wheat and Juice Fall Back on Warmer Forecast
description: Natural gas, wheat and orange juice prices fell yesterday as forecasts pointed to an end to the recent deep freeze that has gripped much of the United States.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;The Demo Is Ready; Is the Product?
description: YOU are at center stage in front of an audience of technical wizards, chief executive officers and reporters. On computers that use video screens 10 feet tall, you begin demonstrating your forthcoming product. You aim for a particular site on the World Wide Web, but all you get is a "Waiting for connection" message. Another site displays a notice that the server is temporarily busy. You hear the classic Windows "ding," indicating trouble. Your crestfallen assistant mutters, "Our network went down."

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Microsoft to Give Away Web Server Software
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it would begin distributing free software that businesses could use to create World Wide Web sites on computers using its Windows NT operating system.

title: Sears Plans to Trim Jobs
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it would eliminate 125 to 150 positions at its corporate headquarters, or about 3 percent of the 4,300 jobs there. The move is part of a realignment the company announced in October to separate its 800 Sears stores from its more than 1,200 "off-the-mall" stores, which include furniture and automotive stores.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants' Free-Agent Focus Is on Their Own
description: Decisions, decisions. The Giants have so many of them when it comes to their own free agents. They have 12 unrestricted and 5 restricted free agents. That's a lot. And that is why the Giants are being extremely aggressive in attempting to sign their own players.

title: What Kind of Conservative Wants to Compromise Judiciary?
description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis Replenish a Stricken Forest
description: Zhana Matar planted a tree today to make Israel's rugged landscape a bit more green, like her native Moldavia. Reubin Schechter, formerly of Elizabeth, N. J., thought planting a tree was a good way to remind Jews of their own roots in Israel. The United States Secretary of State, Warren Christopher, planted a tree to commemorate an American who helped saved the lives of thousands of Jews, including Marc Chagall.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Technology Stocks Lead Market Higher

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tax Amnesty Plan Is Weighed
description: If you forgive them, they will pay.

title: What Kind of Conservative Wants to Compromise Judiciary?;Brooklyn Rape Case
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;Songs Of Men Doomed
description: 'Dead Man Walking'

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Christie Sidelined With a Leg Injury
description: The Olympic 100-meter champion, LINFORD CHRISTIE, will miss the rest of the indoor season because of a leg injury. Christie pulled an adductor muscle at the top of his left leg while running in the 60-meter final at the AAA indoor championships Saturday in Birmingham, England. (AP)

title: COMPANY NEWS;GREENWICH BUYING AVIALL'S ENGINE SERVICES UNIT
description: Greenwich Air Services Inc. signed a letter of intent yesterday to purchase Aviall Inc.'s Commercial Engine Services division for an estimated price of $260 million to $280 million. Shares of both companies surged yesterday. The acquisition will make Greenwich the world's largest company in the business of engine repair, maintenance and overhaul. The purchase includes Aviall's operations in Dallas, Fort Worth and Prestwick, Scotland, as well as its components business in McAllen, Tex. Greenwich shares rose $5, or 22 percent, to close at $27.75 in Nasdaq trading; Aviall shares rose $1.25, or 23.3 percent, to close at $6.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Copdero Avoids Arbitration With Red Sox
description: Infielder WIL CORDERO, obtained last month by Boston from the Montreal Expos, avoided an arbitration hearing yesterday by agreeing to a $1.85 million, one-year contract with the Red Sox. The deal, more than a fivefold increase over last year's $335,000 salary, also includes $300,000 in performance bonuses. (AP)

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;State Senate Now on Cable
description: With three cameras rolling, a cable television network broadcast the action in the State Senate yesterday, the first day of a one-year experiment with live coverage of the Senate. Viewers who tuned in to "Gavel to Gavel" saw a debate and a vote approving a bill to set up a Council on State Mandates to deal with a new constitutional amendment requiring the Legislature to provide money when passing a law putting a requirement on local government.

title: Texas Instruments and Fujitsu Reach Deal
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said today that it had reached an agreement with Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan to cross-license semiconductor patents through 2005. The news pushed Texas Instruments stock up $5.125, to $53.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.e

title: Two Freshmen Deliver Victory to Villanova
description: The happy noise was all around, coming from the top of the Spectrum. "Overrated," the Villanova fans yelled at the Georgetown Hoyas. "Overrated." As the words came down, John Thompson reacted the way he had for much of a perplexing night. This is a time for fixing, not fussing.

title: Foes of Affirmative Action Are Gaining in Ballot Effort
description: The once-faltering effort to eliminate California's affirmative action programs by putting them to a yes-or-no statewide vote in November is rapidly picking up momentum.

title: COMPANY NEWS;McDONALD'S DISCONTINUES ITS REDUCED-FAT BURGER
description: The McDonald's Corporation will discontinue its reduced-fat hamburger, McLean Deluxe, after it did little to improve the company's bottom line. The company will also discontinue its chef's salad and side salads, said Malesia Webb-Dunn, a McDonald's spokeswoman. McDonald's introduced McLean Deluxe about five years ago. It has 10 grams of fat compared with 21 grams of fat in a Quarter Pounder. Sales of the reduced-fat hamburger did not justify keeping it on the menu, said Mark Miller, an analyst at CS First Boston, especially as McDonald's opened smaller restaurants and satellite sites with limited menus.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about Bedminster, N.J., the home of Steve Forbes, the Republican Presidential hopeful, referred incorrectly in some editions to the pack of hounds shown. It was the Tewksbury Foot Bassetts, not the Essex Fox Hounds.

title: Tractor-Trailer Kills Midtown Pedestrian
description: A New Jersey woman was killed while walking to her job at a midtown hotel early yesterday when she was run over by a tractor-trailer truck delivering newsprint to The New York Times, the police said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: * Rick Myracle, partner, senior vice president and account management director at McKinney & Silver, Raleigh, N.C., was promoted to the vacant positions of executive vice president and chief operating officer. * David Marans, senior partner and director for United States media research at J. Walter Thompson New York, a unit of the WPP Group, was named to head a new unit, the Global Media Research Group. * Dan Stone, senior vice president at Turner Broadcasting Sales, New York, a unit of Turner Broadcasting System, was assigned the added responsibility of heading Turner Interactive Marketing and Sales. * Michael Kister was named to head Meldrum & Fewsmith Interactive, Cleveland, a new unit of Meldrum & Fewsmith Communications, as marketing director. He was previously vice president for operations at Multiverse Inc., Cleveland. * Bruce Tait was named to the new position of creative partner at the Leap Partnership, Chicago. He was previously vice president and account planning director at BBDO Toronto, a unit of the Omnicom Group.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Refunding Dominates Trading
description: Treasury prices were mixed yesterday as the market is facing the task of absorbing a huge supply of new debt securities this week.

title: POP REVIEW;Film, Physics Lab and Poetry In a Centrifugal Happening
description: It was a dance party, a film festival, a rock concert, a poetry reading, a physics lab and a sound experiment on Friday night at the Westbeth Theater when DJ Krush, Soul Coughing, Amiri Baraka, Byzar and many others performed. The sold-out event, a continuous collage of activities on two floors, was like a happening being pulled in several directions at once.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japan Is Pressed to Extend Music Copyright Protection
description: A Beatles fan in Japan has to pay about $30 for a recording of "Rubber Soul" or "Revolver" produced under license in Japan. But for as little as $5, a fan can buy a compact disk from a series called "Best, The Beatles."

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 97.77 points, or nearly half of 1 percent, at 20,751.15. On Monday, the Nikkei fell 250.65 points.

title: U.S. Details Plutonium Shipments Abroad
description: The United States during the last 50 years shipped nearly a ton of plutonium to 39 countries, including Argentina, India, Iran, Iraq, Israel, Japan, New Zealand, Pakistan, South Africa, Sweden, Turkey, Uruguay and Venezuela. And it acquired nearly six tons of plutonium from such nations as Canada, Taiwan and Britain.

title: POLITICS: THE CAUCUSES;Ever So Quietly, G.O.P. Is Beginning to Choose
description: The fact that the first voting of the 1996 Presidential campaign takes place in Louisiana on Tuesday is as much a secret here as the ingredients of Chef Paul Prudhomme's signature debris sauce that graces his beef filet.

title: Even Cleaner Smells Sweet as Strike Ends
description: It was the aroma that first signaled the change, the pungent, nose-tingling scent wafting through the fifth-floor men's room yesterday morning. It was just ordinary ammonia, but to Bob Zelen it meant that the regular cleaning lady was back.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bristol-Myers To Reduce Agencies
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company in New York said yesterday that it had begun a review to reduce the number of agencies that handle the accounts of its drug and packaged-goods products, whose billings are estimated at $200 million.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Manhattan Small Talk and Insecurities
description: The characters in Craig Lucas's "Blue Window," directed by Joe Mantello, are introduced with an image of luminous intensity: framed within an inky darkness, picked out by individual spotlights, seven faces stare at us from the stage. They could be holograms in a fun house, or still-living, if disembodied, heads that have been stashed away in some Bluebeard's closet. They float in a dark void.

title: Pataki Should Rethink Budget Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: Race Played No Role In Closing AIDS Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Notes
description: Heart-Shape Edibles

title: Pataki Should Rethink Budget Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Ford Quits Test Of Engelhard's Smog Reducer
description: The promise of the Engelhard Corporation's new smog-reducing technology dimmed yesterday, as the company announced that the Ford Motor Company, which has been conducting an exclusive test of the technology, had decided not to use it.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BRODERBUND STOCK DOWN AFTER EARNINGS REPORT
description: The shares of Broderbund Software Inc., which makes educational software, slumped yesterday, one day after the company warned that second-quarter results would be less than forecasts because of slower product sales. The negative report and a late conference call prompted several analysts to cut their ratings and earnings estimates, and the company's stock plummeted $7.125, to $46, in Nasdaq trading after falling as low as $43 during the day.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Jan. 30 with an article about labor union efforts to organize poultry workers misidentified the processing plant where workers along an assembly line were cutting chickens apart. It was Tyson Foods' nonunion plant in Canton, Miss., not the company's newly unionized plant in Hazlehurst, Miss.

title: Celebrating Four Who Shaped American Tastes in Food
description: A SERIES of celebrations honoring individuals and establishments that have shaped the way Americans cook and eat is taking place this month in New York.

title: Antonio Ruiz Soler, 74, Dancer Who Restyled Art of Flamenco
description: The Spanish flamenco dancer and choreographer Antonio Ruiz Soler, whose ballet-inspired footwork and arm movements brought new prominence to male dancers on the Spanish stage in the 1940's, 50's and 60's, died on Monday at his home in Madrid. He was 74.

title: N. Philip Miller, Engineer, 92
description: N. Philip Miller, an engineer who played a central role in designing the Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland, died of a stroke on Jan. 31 in Columbia, Md. He was 92 and lived near Columbia.

title: A Student Of the Soul And Politics Graduates To Love
description: David Grossman, at 42, is that awkward phenomenon: a gifted novelist whose devotion to fiction is constantly undermined by his helpless passion for politics.

title: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;Truth and Shades of It as Dole and Forbes Fight On
description: The Presidential candidates have mostly withdrawn from New Hampshire this week to concentrate on the battle for Iowa. But on television here, the warring commercials of Senator Bob Dole and Steve Forbes are more pervasive than ever.

title: Don't Vilify Internet
description: To the Editor:

title: Once She Put It Down, She Couldn't Pick It Up Again
description: Biting her ruby-stained and carefully outlined lips, her rouged cheeks reddening further in embarrassment, the actress Joan Collins publicly suffered through a writer's worst nightmare yesterday: her editor told a Manhattan courtroom what she really thought of her author's work.

title: POLITICS: IN THE PACK;Alexander Gives Iowa a Big Try but Still Lags
description: When it comes to the Iowa Republican Presidential caucuses, Steve Forbes may have spent the most money, and Bob Dole may have corralled the most elected officials. But no one has paid a more sustained tribute to Iowa than Lamar Alexander.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BURLINGTON NORTHERN ORDERED TO PAY DAMAGES
description: A Crow tribal jury in Montana yesterday ordered the Burlington Northern Railroad Company to pay $250 million in a case stemming from a 1993 accident on the Crow Indian Reservation in which three people were killed when a train hit their car, the railroad company said. A Crow National Tribal Court jury in Crow Agency, Mont., ordered Burlington Northern, a unit of Burlington Northern Inc., to pay $250 million in compensatory damages, the company said. The company said it would pursue an appeal to the Crow Tribal Appellate Court and even to the Federal District Court. "We are shocked and astounded by the verdict, which we firmly believe is wholly unjustified and the product of proceedings that lacked any semblance of fundamental fairness," Jeffrey Moreland, a senior vice president, said.

title: First Lady's Book Tour to Cost U.S.
description: Taxpayers will pick up a large share of the costs for a 12-seat Air Force jet for Hillary Rodham Clinton's tour to promote her best-selling book, airline estimates show.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Edna Kissman, vice chairwoman in charge of corporate strategy implementation at Burson-Marsteller, New York, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., was promoted to chairwoman of a new worldwide division for health care public relations, Global Health Care Practice.

title: New York City Settles Lawsuit On Mob Ties
description: In an unusual settlement that raises questions about the investigative tactics of the Manhattan District Attorney's office in an organized-crime case, New York City has paid $1 million to resolve a lawsuit with the owner of a construction company who claimed he was falsely accused of being linked to mobsters.

title: Theater in Review
description: The Cast of Villains Who Profit From Drugs 'Hubba City' Nuyorican Poets Cafe American Theater of Actors

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Court Setback for Unions
description: In a setback for construction trade unions, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that government agencies cannot always require builders to use union labor for public projects.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Pepsi Results Are Bolstered By Upswing in Restaurants
description: As Pepsico Inc. pressed strategies to further a revival in its restaurant business, the company announced fourth-quarter earnings yesterday that were driven by growth in the company's KFC fast-food chain, the Frito-Lay snack-food business and international beverage shipments.

title: Woman Dies in Raging Fire at a High-Rise in the Bronx
description: A woman died and 10 people were injured yesterday as fire raced across the 15th floor of a high-rise apartment building in the Bronx, where firefighters faced off against an icy wind and numbing temperatures to battle the blaze.

title: New Farm Proposal, Same Old Lack of Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: IMAGES;Strategists Feature Dole's Mild Side
description: Bob Dole the comedian was on stage again today.

title: Aegean Dispute Wasn't Over Mere Rocks
description: To the Editor:

title: Race Played No Role In Closing AIDS Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place;Asian Markets Start the Year With a Bang
description: Asia's stock markets, those darlings of 1993 and the dogs of 1994 and 1995, have come roaring back to life.

title: Willing to Pay More For a Simple Tax Code
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Young Gets $1 Million
description: ERIC YOUNG, the Colorado Rockies' second baseman who recently broke his right hand, will be able to console himself during his recuperation with the hefty raise he has received for the 1996 season.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Gas Plans To Split Into 2 Units
description: British Gas P.L.C. said yesterday that it would split into two companies, separating its financially troubled trading business from its profitable exploration and pipeline operations. The company also said its chief executive, Cedric H. Brown, would step down in April.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Opel Sees Big Profit Gain
description: The German auto maker Adam Opel A.G., said yesterday that it expected its 1995 profits to be nearly 30 percent higher than in the previous year. The chairman of Opel, David J. Herman, said at a news conference, "I can tell you today that our net profit for 1995 will be between the previous year's result and 400 million marks," or $274 million. The result for 1994 was 307 million marks, or $210 million. Opel, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, is Germany's second-largest auto maker, after Volkswagen A.G. (AP)

title: New Farm Proposal, Same Old Lack of Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: Willing to Pay More For a Simple Tax Code
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Divorce Your Trainer
description: BUILDING muscle is the least of what happens when exercisers work with personal trainers week after week: for many clients, the trainer becomes not just a coach but a confidant as well. So it's not surprising that severing the relationship can be the emotional equivalent of bench-pressing 150 pounds.

title: Guatemala's New President Shakes Up Army and Police
description: Guatemala's new President, Alvaro Arzu Irigoyen, has carried out an extensive purge of top officers in the country's notorious armed forces and dismissed more than a hundred police officers for corruption.

title: Ten Seconds Over Africa, the Hard Way
description: As I stand looking between my toes at the Zambezi River 366 feet below, I do have one coherent phought: Gee, I wish my boss were here.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;U.S. Transportation Aid
description: New Jersey will get $92 million of the $2 billion in financing announced yesterday by the Transportation Department. It will be used for viaduct work on Routes 1 and 9 and to replace a bridge deck in Newark, the A.P. said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;XEROX APPROVES $1 BILLION STOCK REPURCHASE
description: The Xerox Corporation, the copier company based in Stamford, Conn., said yesterday that it had approved the repurchase of as much as $1 billion of its common stock on the open market. Xerox's shares rose $5.125, to $130.875, in New York Stock Exchange trading of about 1.3 million shares. Xerox's board authorized the company to begin the buyback immediately but the company declined to give a time frame. The board last authorized a repurchase in 1989 for 11 million shares, when the stock was trading about $69. The company said it never repurchased any of those shares.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the importance of government support for charities operated by religious and other nonprofit groups included an outdated name for one such charity. It is the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York Inc., no longer the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Allstate's Net More Than Doubles in Quarter
description: The Allstate Corporation, the nation's biggest publicly traded home and automobile insurer, said yesterday that its quarterly earnings more than doubled from a year earlier, mainly because of sharp growth in auto premiums and a decline in catastrophe claims.

title: MUSLIM DETENTION OF BOSNIAN SERBS THREATENS TRUCE
description: Angered by the seizure and detention of two of its top commanders, the Bosnian Serbs suspended all contact with the Bosnian Government today and vowed to retaliate unless the men were released.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Rise As Auction Is Success
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday as the Government's quarterly refunding began with a successful auction of Treasury notes.

title: HOCKEY;Devils' Style Doesn't Suit Young Defenseman
description: When Scott Niedermayer joined the New Jersey Devils as a teen-ager, he reminded many of Paul Coffey, Ray Bourque and Brian Leetch -- all gifted attacking defensemen. Now 22 and in his fourth year with the team, Niedermayer's offensive skills have been minimized this season by Coach Jacques Lemaire.

title: Iraq and U.N. Open Talks on Oil Sales
description: Talks between Iraq and the United Nations on allowing Iraq to sell oil to pay for urgent civilian needs began today with optimistic predictions from the head of Iraq's delegation but no hint of his bargaining position.

title: Publicist Subpoenaed in Tobacco Company Case
description: A publicist said today that he had been subpoenaed to appear before a Federal grand jury investigating whether tobacco industry executives testified falsely about the dangers of cigarettes during Congressional hearings in 1994.

title: Police Surveillance of Streets Turns to Video Cameras and ListeningDevices
description: The year 1984 may have passed with barely a sinister hint of George Orwell's police state. But in 1996, American law enforcement is watching you, and listening, using advanced technology to record what goes on in entire city blocks.

title: Priorities at the Port Authority
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has declared war against the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for shortchanging New York City and favoring the interests of New Jersey. The Port Authority is a great regional resource, but unfortunately many of the Mayor's complaints make sense.

title: Moderating Path, Rowland Aims At Healing of Connecticut Cities
description: Riding the Republican wave to scrap the Great Society programs of the 60's, Gov. John G. Rowland last year won bipartisan approval to remove families from welfare after 21 months -- the nation's strictest time limit -- and to cut their checks 7 percent.

title: Theater in Review
description: Audience Participation In the Good Life The Living Theater The Vineyard Theater

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;14 Held in Drug Money Plot
description: For over two years, prosecutors say, business was good to 14 people who took money from illegal drug sales and hid it for drug lords in Colombia.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DEPUY PLANS TO BUY ORTHOPEDIC TECHNOLOGY
description: The shares of Orthopedic Technology Inc. rose yesterday after the company said that it had agreed to be acquired by Depuy Inc., a unit of Boehringer Mannheim G.m.b.H., for $10.43 a share, or a total of $46.2 million. Orthopedic Technology stock rose 32.8 cents, to $10.313 in Nasdaq trading. Closely held Depuy, which is based in Warsaw, Ind., plans to begin a tender offer for all of Orthopedic Technology's outstanding shares. Depuy, with more than $425 million in annual revenue, manufactures and sells orthopedic products worldwide including prosthetic implants, and trauma and spinal products. Orthopedic Technology, based in Tracy, Calif., manufactures custom and off-the-shelf orthopedic products. The company had revenue of $18.4 million for the year ended Sept. 30.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HERSHEY BOARD APPROVES STOCK BUYBACK PLAN
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation's board has authorized the repurchase of as much as $200 million of the company's common stock, Hershey said yesterday. The company, which makes Hershey's chocolate and Ronzoni pasta, plans to finance the repurchase plan with cash. Based on Monday's closing price of $71.25 for Hershey stock, the buyback would involve about 3.6 percent of Hershey's estimated 77 million outstanding shares. The new authorization followed a $200 million program begun in 1993. Hershey stock rose $2.375, to $73.625 in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: A String Quartet Adapts To Two New Members Takacs String Quartet Alice Tully Hall

title: Our Towns;Zoo Story: Extinction Imperils Mangy Menagerie
description: WITH the snow blanketing the bare grounds and the sun shining like a big mirrored ball, Turtle Back Zoo doesn't seem nearly as bad as everyone says.

title: We Can't Afford Voodoo 2
description: The experienced Republican Presidential candidates are amazed at the surge of Steve Forbes. They shouldn't be. They prepared the way for Steve Forbes. Indeed, they made him inevitable.

title: Stretch of River Is Closed
description: A stretch of the Ohio River has been closed, and a power plant was evacuated after freezing cold cracked a 280-foot smokestack, leaving it in danger of collapse.

title: Girl Scout Cookies, as Near as Your Phone
description: THIS year, for the first time, Girl Scout cookies can be ordered by telephone in New York City.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a week-old chess column appeared in some copies of Science Times yesterday. The current column appears today on page C16.

title: Firefighters Say Risks of Job Don't Diminish Their Ardor
description: All these years later, the firefighters can still recall it with vivid clarity, that moment in training class when the instructor told them to survey their 150 peers and come to terms with the possibility that at least two of them would not make it out of this job alive.

title: Balloonists Get Permission
description: A team of balloonists hoping to make the first nonstop balloon flight around the world reported yesterday that for the first time, every country over which their craft might fly has granted permission.

title: Aegean Dispute Wasn't Over Mere Rocks
description: To the Editor:

title: About Real Estate;Zabar Plans Expansion Of a Store On East 91st
description: Expansion is the order of the day for the Vinegar Factory, the food store owned by Eli Zabar at 431 East 91st Street, between York and First Avenues.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HUBCO AGREES TO BUY LAFAYETTE AMERICAN BANK
description: Hubco Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Lafayette American Bank and Trust Company of Bridgeport, Conn., for about $130 million in stock. Hubco, a commercial bank based in Mahwah, N.J., said the agreement valued Lafayette American at $13 a share. Lafayette's stock gained 50 cents to close at $11.25 on the Nasdaq. Hubco stock fell $2, to $20.50. Lafayette American said it did not expect to close its 19 branches after the deal. The bank had assets of about $735.4 million on Dec. 31. Hubco has 62 branches and $1.8 billion in assets.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 22 about corruption charges against senior Indian Government officials misstated the position of Chandan Mitra, a journalist who speculated on the damage to the country's leading political parties. He is the current editor of The Hindustan Times, not the former one.

title: Value Siberia Logging
description: To the Editor:

title: Millions of Secrets Burden Energy Agency
description: American makers of nuclear weapons have been classifying virtually everything for so long that the Energy Department now has more secrets than it can cope with, and the department and its contractors may have released information they should have kept secret, officials said today.

title: With Firefighter's Death, Brooklyn Loses a Son
description: Louis Valentino was a son of Brooklyn. He jogged the streets of Red Hook, loved sandwiches with eggplant and peppers, and worked as a lifeguard at Coney Island.

title: Weekly Earnings Off Slightly in December
description: Average weekly earnings of United States workers, after adjusting for inflation and seasonal factors, fell two-tenths of 1 percent in December after declining a revised seven-tenths of a percent in November, the Labor Department said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GERALDINE A. FERRARO will be a regular co-host on the CNN political talk program "Crossfire," defending liberal positions in debates with her conservative counterparts, John Sununu and Robert Novak, The Associated Press said this week.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;McDonnell Douglas Seen In Talks With Fokker
description: Representatives of Fokker N.V. and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation would not comment yesterday on a report in the Dutch newspaper Volkskrant that the two companies met last week. Fokker, the struggling Dutch aircraft maker, has been looking for a partner since its German parent, Daimler-Benz A.G., cut off a cash lifeline last month. Other potential investors that have been identified in news reports include the Samsung Group of South Korea, Bombardier Inc. of Canada, British Aerospace, Taiwan Aerospace and Aerospatiale S.A. of France.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;U.S. Loans for Flood Victims
description: Federal disaster loans are available for homeowners and businesses in four New Jersey counties hit hard by flooding in January: Warren, Hunterdon, Morris and Sussex. The A.P. said the Small Business Administration would take applications for loans for physical damage until April 5 and for economic losses until Nov. 5.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;QUAKER OATS CO. (OAT,N)
description: The Quaker Oats Company reported a loss of $47.8 million for its second quarter, reflecting a $40.8 million pretax charge to revamp its troubled Snapple beverage line and realign its European beverages and Pacific foods businesses.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CITIBANK EXPLORES ELECTRONIC PLAN FOR WELFARE
description: Citibank said yesterday that it was leading a team to develop and operate a program to issue food stamps and public assistance benefits electronically. The team selected by the Northeast Coalition of States included Bank of Boston, I.B.M., Lockheed Martin and Deluxe Data. The company said the coalition included New York, Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Vermont. The program, called Electronic Benefits Transfer, would issue plastic debit cards to participants, which could be used to withdraw cash from automated teller machines and to purchase food and other commodities, Citibank, a unit of Citicorp, said. The pilot program is scheduled to begin in 1997.

title: Haitian Taking Office, With Daunting Job Ahead
description: The task facing Rene Preval beginning Wednesday is one no Haitian envies. As the successor to President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, he inherits what one diplomat here calls "the hardest job in the Americas": trying to lead a country that historically has been the poorest and most blatantly misruled in the hemisphere.

title: Bonn Admits Currency Plan Faces Problem
description: At a time of increasingly troubled debate over Europe's future, German officials powering the drive for integration have begun to acknowledge publicly what other Europeans have long been saying: that their blueprint may turn out to be too ambitious.

title: Class Notes
description: In the midst of a noisy chaos stands Cyndy Hall, looking positively pleased with the direction that her Friday morning science project has taken.

title: Borden Putnam, 73, Commissioner of Commerce
description: Borden R. Putnam, New Jersey's first Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development and a pivotal figure in the state's economic growth during the 1980's, died on Monday at his home in Franklin Lakes, N.J. He was 73.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: No Salvation From the Governors
description: The nation's governors voted unanimously at their conference yesterday for reforms of welfare and Medicaid that are harsher toward the poor in key respects than anything Congress has passed or that the Republicans privately negotiated with President Clinton in their ill-fated budget talks. This unfortunate outcome is the price for achieving the governors' primary goal of protecting state treasuries. What they did not achieve is a proposal that would guarantee essential security for the impoverished. A civilized, wealthy society should do no less.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Chechen Chief Threatens Attacks Against Europe
description: In an interview broadcast today on Russian television, the leader of the Chechen separatists said that the West was backing Moscow's war to keep Chechnya part of Russia and threatened to stage attacks against Western Europe.

title: Prosecutor Investigating Commerce Chief Expands Inquiry to Son
description: A special prosecutor looking into the activities of Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown is making a criminal investigation into payments of $160,000 to Mr. Brown's son by an Oklahoma natural gas company.

title: yCosmetics Romance the Bull;As Industry Lures Investors, Can Revlon Also Rise?
description: As Wall Street weighs the value of the planned public offering of Revlon Inc., it is clear that the $6 billion cosmetics industry has never looked lovelier -- at least to investors.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SAMSONITE TO TAKE CHARGE FOR REORGANIZATION
description: The Samsonite Corporation, the luggage maker, said yesterday that it would consolidate its manufacturing operations and some administrative functions, resulting in a $2.4 million charge in the fourth quarter, which ended on Jan. 31. The consolidation would involve moving all domestic hard-side luggage manufacturing to Samsonite's Denver plant. The company also plans to consolidate finance, accounting, management information systems and human resource functions with existing departments in Denver. The move is expected to save Denver-based Samsonite about $3.3 million a year. The company's stock jumped $2.375 yesterday, to $12.375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Americans seem to have an insatiable appetite for rankings. Students are ranked by academic achievement, entrepreneurs by wealth, songs by popularity.

title: Atheists Insulted
description: To the Editor:

title: California Town Joins Trend in Its Effort To Reinvent the CommunitySchool District
description: It was the milk train that ran between this woodsy village on the shores of the Pacific Ocean and Watsonville, a city 10 miles south, that first brought the schoolchildren of the two communities together.

title: Sports of The Times;Giant Leap For Gervin, Thompson
description: TOGETHER again. George Gervin and David Thompson, linked by acrobatics, linked by drugs, linked by sobriety, linked by one magnificent day in 1978, are now forever linked by their election to the Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Connecticut's Streak Gets Longer, and Wider
description: Halfway through Connecticut's winning streak, which reached 21 tonight, Coach Jim Calhoun paid his players a subtle compliment. He described his contentment by saying, "I find myself yelling less and watching more."

title: It Only Seemed That Cold
description: The coldest temperature ever recorded in New York City was not 15 below zero, as had long been reported, but 14 below -- roughly speaking.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the origin of the 1913 fire that gutted Jack London's house in Glen Ellen, Calif., misstated the publication date of his essay "The House Beautiful." It was 1906, not 1960.

title: Dealers Plan Huge Used-Car Chain With No Bargaining
description: A group of the nation's biggest car dealers said today that it planned to open 100 huge used-car dealerships, a move that it hopes will significantly change the way Americans buy used cars.

title: Pretoria to Lose U.S. Aid
description: The United States will start phasing out aid to South Africa beginning in fiscal year 1997, J. Brian Atwood, Administrator for the United States Agency for International Development, said today. He said that aid cuts were inevitable once a three-year, $600-million-program expires after fiscal year 1996.

title: Atheists Insulted
description: To the Editor:

title: Two-Month-Old Fire Besieges a Little Town
description: One day in December, the sound of an explosion at a 500,000-bushel corn bin shot over this little prairie town like a boom from a cannon, and flames began lapping at the grain inside. That was nearly eight weeks ago, and the fire is not out yet.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;GANNETT CO. (GCI,N)
description: The Gannett Company said yesterday that earnings rose 4 percent in the fourth quarter, exceeding expectations, because of strong results from its television and radio business.

title: Horse Racing;At 6, Cigar Is a World-Class Horse With a Worldwide Mission
description: From the unhurried order surrounding Barn 7 at Gulfstream Park, you would never think it was a racing stable facing the longest, most challenging and by far the richest itinerary in thoroughbred history.

title: Wine Talk
description: APPLE pie, steak, fried chicken, Coke and Pepsi, bacon and eggs, beer, corn on the cob, hot dogs and maybe chocolate-chip cookies. A grocery list? More of an American gustatory hall of fame. The sorts of things they used to tell American servicemen they were fighting for.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Gold Is Lower Again on Signs High Price Is Curbing Demand
description: Gold prices fell yesterday for a second consecutive session on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange on signs that six-year-high prices had begun to curb demand from retail buyers and jewelers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Goals Are Set For New Media
description: A task force formed by agencies and advertisers to address new media has issued goals to insure consumers' privacy in interactive marketing transactions and communications.

title: Apple Computer Talks With Sun
description: Despite widespread public speculation that Apple Computer Inc. had broken off merger talks with Sun Microsystems Inc. last week, executives from the two companies met secretly at a Palo Alto, Calif., law firm over the weekend, people familiar with the discussions said today.

title: Foreign Affairs;Revolt of the Wannabes
description: As a barometer of global affairs, the annual Davos World Economic Forum is as good an indicator as you can find. The meeting brings together top industrialists and political figures from every corner of the world. Each year, one or two individuals stand out as trend-setters. One year it was Nelson Mandela, then Shimon Peres and Yasir Arafat, then Russian reformers. And that is why this year's Davos Forum was so interesting. Because this year the star -- the man everyone wanted to interview -- was a Communist: Gennadi Zyuganov, head of Russia's resurgent Communist Party.

title: Critics to Allow Vote on Health Insurance Bill
description: After months of intense lobbying over the issue, Senate Republicans agreed today to schedule debate and a vote in the spring on a bipartisan bill that would guarantee health insurance coverage for people who leave employer-sponsored plans.

title: Farm Bill Is Stalled, but Dole Promises Action
description: Senate Republicans narrowly failed today to shut off debate on legislation to revamp Federal farm programs, but the majority leader, Bob Dole, vowed to keep an anxious Senate in session to forge a compromise deal.

title: China to Buy 72 Advanced Fighter Planes From Russia
description: Russia and China have secretly concluded a broad agreement to upgrade the Chinese Air Force by completing the long-stalled sale of 72 high-performance SU-27 fighter planes to Beijing as a prelude to licensing the production of Russia's premier supersonic warplane in China.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Patterson's New Role
description: The former heavyweight champion FLOYD PATTERSON, at 61 looking almost fit enough to climb back in the ring, promised yesterday to make the welfare of retired fighters his priority as he began his first full term as the state's Athletic Commission chairman.

title: Value Siberia Logging
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL;February Is Already Bulls' Cruelest Month
description: Suns 106, Bulls 96

title: Some Rwandan Exiles Can't Go Home Again
description: After a year in Rwanda, Lazare Bimenyimana, a Hutu potato farmer, limped back into the Kibumba refugee camp this morning with a scarred face and broken hands, telling the kind of story that has made it hard to persuade Rwandan refugees here to return home.

title: Business Travel;A historic reminder of how far commercial aviation has come.
description: FIFTY years ago this week T.W.A.'s Star of Paris lifted off from Washington, stopped atLa Guardia Airport in New York and set off for Paris with 36 passengers including businessmen, diplomats, two fashion designers and a doctor delivering penicillin. Cruising at a blistering 300 miles an hour, and after refueling stops in Gander, Newfoundland, and Shannon, Ireland, the graceful four-engine Lockheed Constellation touched down at Orly Airport in Paris almost 20 hours after leaving New York.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Auto Palace, Avon, Mass., an auto parts chain, to Haggman Inc., Magnolia, Mass., to handle its account, previously at Cuneo Sullivan Dolabany, Boston. The billings were estimated at $1 million to $3 million.

title: INSIDE
description: China Buys Russian Jets

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Yankees Finish Trade
description: When the Yankees acquired TIM RAINES, the veteran left fielder, from the Chicago White Sox on Dec. 28, they said the deal was for "future considerations." After considering it for nearly six weeks, the Yankees yesterday sent the White Sox a minor league pitcher who was a replacement player last spring.

title: We Can't Afford Voodoo 2
description: The experienced Republican Presidential candidates are amazed at the surge of Steve Forbes. They shouldn't be. They prepared the way for Steve Forbes. Indeed, they made him inevitable.

title: Syria to Stay In Israel Talks as U.S. Urges
description: The Syrians have agreed to continue peace talks with Israel in Maryland on Feb. 26, despite concern that early Israeli elections would slow or disrupt the negotiations, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said here today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Kopf Zimmermann Revamps Office
description: Kopf Zimmermann Schultheis Advertising in Hauppauge, L.I., said yesterday that it had reorganized its office in Fairfield, Conn., which had been known as KZS/Ely Group Advertising, into a partnership named KZS/Brady Lee. The office will be headed by two partners: Brian Brady, 41, who had been vice president and account supervisor at KZS/Ely Group, and Bernie Lee, 47, who had been executive vice president at the Diamond Promotion Group in New York. KZS/Brady Lee will continue an affiliation with the Doug Ely Design Group, a design company also based in Fairfield.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Strong Results Lift Shares of Time Warner
description: Time Warner Inc. cheered Wall Street yesterday with stronger-than-expected financial results and indications that it was closer to resolving its battle with U S West over the ownership of Time Warner's cable operations.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ELIZABETH TAYLOR has filed for divorce from LARRY FORTENSKY, whom she married in 1991 at a lavish ceremony at Michael Jackson's California estate.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Cellular Tool Against Abuse
description: A woman trying to elude an abusive man often doesn't have the luxury of time to find a phone to call for help.

title: Companies Aren't Snapping Up a Tax Break
description: How many big American companies would look a gift horse in the mouth?

title: Whose Money?
description: To the Editor:

title: Aegean Dispute Wasn't Over Mere Rocks
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL: KNICKS NOTEBOOK;Tucker Held in Attack on Officers
description: Bothered by a strained lower back, Anthony Tucker has spent his first season with the Knicks on the injured list. The reserve forward's future with the Knicks became more uncertain today after an arrest early this morning in Manhattan.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Offer Charles Smith To Toronto
description: The Knicks are in the midst of working out a trade that would send forward Charles Smith to the Toronto Raptors, according to executives of two rival Eastern Conference teams. In exchange, the Knicks would acquire the 6-foot-8-inch guard Willie Anderson and another player, probably center Victor Alexander.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: A Distinctive Sound Originating in Russia St. Petersburg Philharmonic Carnegie Hall

title: Metrostars Get Vermes, Zaun
description: Peter Vermes and Jeff Zaun, former standouts at Rutgers, were among the eight players the New York/ New Jersey Metrostars selected in yesterday's first draft of Major League Soccer, which begins play in April.

title: Newbury Journal;Going Out On a Limb Over Plans For a Road
description: It was a typical morning at the not-yet-built Newbury bypass, the $160 million road that the British Government hopes to construct to ease the traffic in this car-clogged town 50 miles west of London.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Put Up a Fight, but the Rangers Prevail
description: For the first time in a while, the Islanders were able to make Nassau Coliseum an unfriendly place for the Rangers.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;'Law and Order' Meets 'Homicide'
description: The opening scene of tonight's "Law and Order" episode was shaped by the New York City Transit Authority. When the show's producers wanted to film a scene about a toxic bomb that goes off in the subway (a scene that would have been shot just after a real token booth was set on fire), the T.A. denied them permission to stage the incident at the Transit Museum.

title: Site of Fatal Roof Collapse Violated Building Codes
description: The Brooklyn building whose roof collapsed during a fire on Monday afternoon, killing a city firefighter, was illegally constructed, violated city fire and building codes and was apparently being used as a "chop shop" to dismantle stolen vehicles, city and police officials said yesterday.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Declined in 1995
description: Japan's trade surplus in goods and services fell 15 percent in 1995, the second straight annual decline, the government said today.

title: T.W.A. Plans To Hire 2,100
description: Trans World Airlines Inc., which emerged from bankruptcy-law protection within the last year, said today that it planned to hire a total of 2,100 pilots, reservation sales agents and flight attendants in 1996.

title: Locking Up the Vote
description: Why do George Pataki and other Republican governors want to undermine the National Voter Registration Act, the decade's greatest civil rights advance? Do they fear that if the disproportionately disfranchised minority and poor voters are signed up, the Democrats' base will be enhanced?

title: BOXING;Harlem Middleweight Is a Step Closer to His Goal
description: A taxi ride from Harlem, where he lives and wants to again bring the world middleweight championship, Lonnie Bradley knocked Randy Smith flat on his face last night at the 69th Regiment Armory and retained a lesser version of the crown.

title: Student Arrested in Setting 19 Fires in One Week at Florida State
description: What began as a small fire in a dormitory oven and turned into a series of 18 more fires in one week on the campus of Florida State University in Tallahassee ended yesterday in the arrest of a freshman.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: An Evening in Old Vienna, Oom-pah-pah, Oom-pah-pah New York Pops, with Hermann Prey Carnegie Hall

title: COMPANY NEWS;MICROSOFT PURCHASE INVESTIGATED BY U.S.
description: The Microsoft Corporation's acquisition of a fledgling World Wide Web software company, Vermeer Technologies Inc., is being investigated by Federal antitrust regulators, the Justice Department said yesterday. The investigators are looking at whether the purchase will hurt competition on the Internet's World Wide Web. It is unusual because it involves such a small company in the emerging and competitive market for Web software, antitrust lawyers said. Since last year, Federal officials have been examining the company's entry into the market for on-line information services. The Justice Department investigation of the Vermeer acquisition was first reported yesterday by The Wall Street Journal.

title: Bratton Is Near a Contract For the Story of His Life
description: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton is about to find out if the pen is mightier than the sword -- or at least more lucrative. He is preparing to write his autobiography.

title: City Opera To Present 'Gloriana' And 'Visit' In 1996-97
description: The New York City Opera is to present the New York premiere of Gottfried von Einem's "Visit of the Old Lady" and the first professional American staging of Britten's "Gloriana" as part of its 1996-97 season. The season, which opens on Sept. 11 with a new production of Verdi's "Falstaff," is the final one planned by Christopher Keene, the company's general director, who died in October.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Aikman Has Surgery On Throwing Shoulder
description: Dallas quarterback TROY AIKMAN underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right elbow yesterday in Birmingham, Ala. In a 75-minute procedure, Dr. JAMES ANDREWS removed loose bodies, bone spurs and scar tissue. It was not clear whether Aikman would participate in today's Super Bowl victory parade in Dallas, and no timetable was set for his return to throwing. However, he said before the surgery that he hoped to be ready by training camp in July.

title: Gene Factor Seen in Blacks' Diabetes
description: Black Americans appear to have a genetic predisposition to diabetes that may be set off by obesity or other health habits, and therefore simple changes in a person's way of life can lower the risk, diabetes experts say.

title: Aegean Dispute Wasn't Over Mere Rocks
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Stocks Lift The Market
description: A recovery in technology stocks accelerated yesterday, lifting the market broadly higher.

title: THE NEEDEST CASES;Donors Taking Up Government's Slack
description: Some people have had to reduce their annual gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund this year, but others have gone in the opposite direction, intent on being more generous as the government becomes less so.

title: A New Report Becomes a Weapon In Debate on Censoring TV Violence
description: A new report suggesting that violence pervades television entertainment shows is shaping up as a central point of confrontation in a political battle between advocates of the V-chip -- a device that can block transmission of violent programs into homes -- and the broadcast networks, which adamantly oppose enforced censorship of their programs.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Tagliabue Summons No Support for Antitrust Exemption
description: Twice, Paul Tagliabue, the National Football League commissioner, has testified before a United States Senate committee to the need for legal protection to keep teams from hopscotching the country. Twice, he got a favorable reception.

title: Aggressiveness and Delinquency In Boys Is Linked to Lead in Bones
description: CRIMINALS may indeed be made, not born, and one of the ingredients could be childhood exposure to lead, according to the findings of a four-year study of young boys that is being published today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Calculus for the Literacy, if Not for the Numbers
description: A TOUR OF THE CALCULUS By David Berlinski Illustrated. 331 pages. Pantheon. $27.50

title: Combining Hormones Lowers Estrogen Risk
description: Menopausal women who take estrogen alone run a higher-than-normal chance of developing cancer of the uterus, but combining estrogen with the hormone progestin can counteract the risk, a study confirms.

title: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
description: Stock prices advanced here today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 192.34 points, or more than nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 20,943.49. On Tuesday, the index rose 20,751.15 points.

title: High Court Backs New Districts in Georgia
description: The Supreme Court today cleared the way for a new map for Georgia Congressional districts with only one having a majority of black voters. It is to be used in this year's elections.

title: Nutmeg and Cinammon, We Hardly Knew You
description: FINDING new uses for familiar spices can be like discovering that a dependable but boringly predictable friend can actually blow a wild and wailing saxophone.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Technology Issues Send Dow to 9th Record of '96 A recovery in technology stocks lifted the stock market broadly higher as the Dow Jones average hit its ninth record of the year, rising 52.02 points to 5,459.61. The rally was led by Intel, Micron Technology and I.B.M. The Nasdaq and Standard & Poor's indexes also advanced. [Page D8.]

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Reminder of a Girl's Killer
description: Nearly six months after a 13-year-old girl was found sexually assaulted and stabbed to death, yellow ribbons went up yesterday in her neighborhood as a reminder that her killer has not been found, the A.P. said. The girl, Shaline Seguinot, disappeared Aug. 4. Her body was found three days later in weeds behind her school.

title: Personal Health
description: DONNA BOGUSLAV, a registered nurse who specializes in eating disorders, was working at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York when a young woman who resembled a concentration camp victim was brought in by ambulance. Emergency medical technicians had found the 24-year-old woman, a former model, lying on the floor of her apartment barely conscious. They had been summoned by her out-of-town parents.

title: John Testrake, 68, T.W.A. Pilot Who Became Hero in Hijacking
description: Capt. John L. Testrake, the Bible-reading T.W.A. pilot whose display of calm, quiet courage made him an international hero during a 17-day hijacking ordeal between Beirut and Algiers in 1985, died yesterday at a hospice in St. Joseph, Mo. He was 68 and had been suffering from cancer.

title: Don't Vilify Internet
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Core Curriculum Plan Today
description: New Jersey will take a step toward setting specific standards for students today when Education Commissioner Leo F. Klagholz presents a proposed core curriculum to the state Board of Education. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;A Variation on a Veal Marsala Dish
description: At first glance this meal seems utterly traditional. But some small changes make it lighter than the usual renditions. The Marsala-flavored dish is made with chicken instead of veal, and the mashed potatoes are creamed with buttermilk, and not with milk or cream. Chicken Marsala

title: Judge Finds Wit Tested by Criticism;Issuer of Drug-Search Ruling Draws Angry Opinions
description: Inside Judge Harold Baer Jr.'s lair at the Federal Court House in lower Manhattan, a dozen stuffed bears preside on a bookshelf. One rides a tricycle; another carries a scale of justice. Not long ago, a voice on his answering machine said: "The bear is not in his lair."

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Compuserve Is Joining Push To Broaden Internet Access
description: Compuserve, reaching for a more computer-savvy audience and a global Internet presence, said yesterday that it had begun offering an Internet-only service to customers worldwide.

title: Sara Lee Settles U.S. Charges
description: The Sara Lee Corporation agreed today to pay $3.1 million to settle Federal charges that it tried to avoid antitrust scrutiny by failing to report the acquisition in 1991 of shoe-care products from Reckitt & Colman P.L.C. of Britain.

title: No Headline
description: I am sure that if I go back and claim my house, I would be put in prison and my family would disappear. It is as if the whole world is against us."

title: New Farm Proposal, Same Old Lack of Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INSPEC GROUP P.L.C., London, a specialty chemicals company, plans to buy Allied Signal Inc.'s specialty chemicals business, which is based in Arizona and Kansas, for $28.7 million.

title: Abundance Of Snowfall, And Daring, Proves Deadly
description: Buried under four feet of snow, Michael Merick clung to life for three hours until a search dog found him, just as daylight faded from a Rocky Mountain slope west of here.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.N. Chief Urges Reducing U.S. Dues
description: Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said today that he favored reducing the United States contributions to the United Nations budget from 25 percent to 15 or 20 percent.

title: Aegean Dispute Wasn't Over Mere Rocks
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;BAXTER INTERNATIONAL (BAX,N)
description: Baxter International Inc.'s earnings were stronger than expected in the fourth quarter, benefiting from its medical technology businesses.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: Weighing Risks of Firefighting Eleven New York City firefighters have died in the last two years, three in the last six weeks alone. That string of deaths has given rise to considerable discussion. But the only point on which firefighters in a Flatbush firehouse could agree was that the work they do was dangerous, and that dying would always be a part of it. [Page A1.]

title: Oil Crisis Odds
description: To the Editor:

title: Eating Well;A New Goal Beyond Organic: 'Clean Food'
description: A GROWING number of Americans are taking their health and well-being into their own hands, in part because they have lost faith in the institutions that are supposed to improve their lives.

title: TV SPORTS;A Thousand Times, Yes: Albert, the Video Game
description: Wonder what sportscasters do with their free time? Some rest their voices. Read a book. Spend time with their families. And NBC's Marv Albert? Yesterday, he spent hours laboriously reciting words and phrases, changing inflections and seeking dramatic motivation, as the voice of a new basketball video game.

title: Whose Money?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reforming the United Nations
description: Even Americans who ardently support the United Nations will welcome two important developments this week at the financially strapped world organization. Some 10 percent of the U.N.'s permanent staff of 10,000 in New York is to be laid off by 1998, according to Under Secretary General Joseph Connor, the chief financial officer. This finally addresses the longstanding, and justified, complaint that the U.N. payroll, 54,000 worldwide, is bloated.

title: New Farm Proposal, Same Old Lack of Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: E. F. Trefethen Jr., 86, Executive Who Had Role in Hoover Dam
description: Eugene F. Trefethen Jr., an industrialist and philanthropist who played a role in the building of the Hoover Dam and the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge, died last Wednesday at his home in Napa, Calif. He was 86.

title: One Fell Swoosh: Can a Logo Conquer All?
description: Phil Knight is a sports fan. He jumps up and down at meets and matches, and he describes his favorite athletes as an avid art collector might describe a new acquisition. At 57, with a nimbus of curly blond hair and a ready, slightly nervous laugh, he's almost endearing in his passion and his willingness to share it.

title: New Managers to Take Over Troubled Psychiatric Hospital
description: Reacting to a series of humiliating incidents at Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital in Parsippany -- most recently the suicide of a patient while staff members on duty were sleeping -- state officials announced today that they would install a management team to take over the troubled state institution.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the New Jersey section on Sunday with an article about music of other cultures misstated the location of a concert by Women of the Calabash on Friday night at 8. It is in Lenfell Hall at Fairleigh Dickinson University in Madison, not Princeton.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Maybelline's new campaign stresses the cosmetics industry's latest credo: The meek need not apply.
description: AN extensive campaign for Maybelline Inc. that begins tomorrow is going to roar "Great!" almost as often as Tony the Tiger does.

title: ON HOCKEY;Animosity Takes a Holiday on Island
description: When the Islanders and the Rangers took the ice last night at Nassau Coliseum, the voice on the public address system roared, "Let's get ready to rumble!" Such big-time wrestling hokum shouldn't be necessary in a local rivalry that has had much bile and boiling blood over nearly a quarter-century.

title: City Workers' Local Backs New Contract
