description: The biggest local in New York City's largest municipal employees union announced last night that its members had overwhelmingly voted to approve a proposed five-year contract with the city, with a margin that some union officials said might be enough to insure approval of the pact by the union as a whole.

title: Corrections
description: A listing yesterday with an article about 50 years of plutonium exports by the United States carried two erroneous headings in some editions. One group (comprising Brazil, Colombia, Denmark, India, Iran, New Zealand, Pakistan, South Vietnam, Taiwan, Thailand and Uruguay) got one-tenth of a kilogram, not "one kilogram." (A kilogram is about 2.2 pounds.)

title: A Plan to Put Washington In Maryland
description: Frustrated by the District of Columbia's fiscal crisis and the city's lack of representation in Congress, a new citizens group has begun a campaign to give most of Washington back to Maryland.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Fordham Keeps Pace Till Halftime
description: The Fordham team with the pinkish uniforms turned John Calipari and Massachusetts an embarrassing shade of red for one half last night. The first-ranked team in the country is not supposed to stumble against a school with a 2-16 record, but the Rams frustrated the Minutemen for 20 minutes on a wild evening at Madison Square Garden.

title: GOVERNORS RAISE HOPES FOR ENDING BUDGET DEADLOCK
description: The nation's governors endorsed bipartisan proposals today for overhauling the Federal Medicaid and welfare programs, prompting optimistic talk of breaking the monthslong impasse over balancing the Federal budget. But the proposals also drew questions from the White House and Congress and criticism from advocates for the poor.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Operating Income Up at Sprint But It Has Overall Quarterly Loss
description: The Sprint Corporation said today that fourth-quarter income from continuing operations was $278 million, beating analysts' estimates, but the company suffered an overall loss for the quarter after restructuring and accounting charges.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Spanish Socialist Slain; Basque Rebels Blamed
description: A gunman assassinated a Spanish Socialist Party regional leader today in the northern city of San Sebastian, and the police and political leaders blamed Basque separatists for the killing.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DOCUMENTUM PUBLIC OFFERING STIRS ENTHUSIASM
description: The shares of Documentum Inc. shares rose strongly on their first day of trading. Documentum stock, priced at $24, closed at $30 in trading of almost 2.1 million shares yesterday. Earlier it traded as high as $34. Documentum sold 1.8 million shares to raise $43.2 million. The company plans to use the money for general purposes. Documentum, based in Pleasanton, Calif., makes software that speeds and automates the creation and distribution of complex documents.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Nursing Home Freezes Out
description: A nursing home was evacuated yesterday afternoon after a frozen pipe burst, the A.P. reported. More than 110 residents of the Southern Ocean Nursing and Rehabilitation Center on Route 72 were moved to two sites after the heating system was turned off as a precaution, said a spokeswoman, Jean Ritchie. Most returned last night after the pipe was fixed.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Beanpot

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Youthful Intensity With a Touch of Humor Alban Gerhardt, cellist 92 Street Y

title: AT LUNCH WITH : Jeff Foxworthy;2,000 Ways You Might Be a Redneck
description: HAROLD'S BARBECUE is Jeff Foxworthy's kind of place.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Penguins Stop Bruins Jaromir Jagr scored his 42d goal and 100th point of the season in a wild four-goal third period that carried the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 6-5 victory over the Boston Bruins last night, keeping the Bruins without a victory in Pittsburgh for more than six years. The Bruins are 0-10-1 in Pittsburgh since a 5-2 victory on Jan. 2, 1990. It was the second time in less than a month that the Bruinq blew a third-period lead to lose in Pittsburgh. (AP) RED WINGS 4, PANTHERS 2: Host Detroit won the battle of division leaders as Steve Yzerman and Vyacheslav Kozlov each scored twice and the Red Wings took a victory over Florida. (AP)

title: Fed Survey Shows Banks Are Tightening Up on Loans
description: Big banks are making it tougher for businesses and consumers to get loans, the Federal Reserve said today, at least partly because they fear a weakening economy will make it less likely that they will be repaid.

title: Oil Crisis Odds
description: To the Editor:

title: Travelers-Aetna Venture Widens
description: Two more investors have joined Travelers Group Inc. and the Aetna Life and and Casualty Company in their joint property-casualty insurance venture.

title: New Farm Proposal, Same Old Lack of Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE scene: Northbound Riverdale bus.

title: About New York;Russian Poet Waxes Lyrical On Queens
description: YEVGENY YEVTUSHENKO, the Russian poet and world traveler, brimmed with manic excitement, inspired to near-rhapsodic joy as he beheld the land that is his latest muse.

title: Aegean Dispute Wasn't Over Mere Rocks
description: To the Editor:

title: New Farm Proposal, Same Old Lack of Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: IN THE BACKGROUND;Forbes Inc. Critics Turn to the Candidate
description: Last November, as Steve Forbes moved through a crowd of admirers at a Republican luncheon in Colorado Springs, he stuck out his hand to greet one of the strangers. Along with a handshake, he received a letter accusing his company of mismanaging a real estate development here in southern Colorado.

title: A BILLION AT RISK: A special report.;Public Money Foots the Bills For 'Privatized' Foreign Aid
description: Business does it better. That is the rallying cry on Capitol Hill and in statehouses across the country, where legislators are turning over to private companies traditional government functions ranging from running jails to exploring outer space.

title: Missing Picassos: A Mystery at Kennedy
description: It is not every day that a traveler walks up to a customs counter at Kennedy International Airport, unzips a portfolio from his carry-on luggage and tries to declare two portraits by Picasso and an oil by Pissarro depicting fin de siecle Paris.

title: Evidence Is Reinstated In a Brooklyn Rape Case
description: A Brooklyn judge who was criticized for dismissing evidence against a rape suspect reinstated that evidence yesterday, saying his original ruling was based on wrong information from prosecutors and defense lawyers.

title: POLITICS: THE CAUCUSES;Buchanan Wins in Louisiana In Blow to Gramm Campaign
description: Patrick J. Buchanan won the Louisiana Republican Presidential caucuses tonight in a stunning upset over Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, shaking the Senator's campaign and devastating his strategy to emerge from here as the leading conservative in the race.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Jailed Mob Boss Indicted
description: A 25-year sentence on Federal racketeering and murder conspiracy charges didn't stop Michael Taccetta from running the Lucchese crime family's New Jersey operation from jail cells across the country, officials say.

title: Cold-Weather Spell Warms the Hearts of Energy Suppliers
description: For Alfred Allegretti, January's weather was fabulous. February's few days of numbing cold have been really beautiful.

title: Governors' Welfare Plan Seeks to Close Gap on Bill
description: The welfare legislation endorsed today by the nation's governors would give states vast new power to design their own cash assistance programs and to devise ways of moving poor people from welfare to work.

title: It's a Boy, and a Girl, a Girl, a Girl and a Boy
description: For years, Pnina and Shmuel Klaver tried to abide by the Torah commandment to "be fruitful and multiply," but they had difficulty conceiving after their first two sons. On Monday, however, their prayers were answered fivefold.

title: Journal;The G.O.P.'s Bum Rush
description: If the Washington press corps had spent as much time getting to the bottom of Whitewater as it has trying to identify the author of "Primary Colors," our long national nightmare, the Alfonse D'Amato telethon, would be over. And what's the great puzzle anyway? Anonymous is someone who has an intimate knowledge of the '92 campaign, an intensely ambivalent relationship with Bill Clinton, a proven literary track record and a lot of time on his hands. Who else could it be but Al Gore?

title: Jaguar Idle for a Week
description: Jaguar Ltd. has shut its automobile production line for a week because of slumping demand, the company said today. Jaguar idled 2,200 of its production staff of 3,500 in its Birmingham and Coventry plants. The workers will draw 80 percent pay while not working. "They are laid off for just this week," said Colin Cook, Jaguar corporate affairs manager. Earlier this month, Jaguar, a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, reported that it sold 39,725 cars in 1995, a 30 percent increase over the previous year.

title: Chess
description: Anatoly Karpov made one move in his last-round game in the prestigious Koop Tjuchem International Tournament in Groningen, the Netherlands, and then offered a draw. When his opponent, Peter Leko of Hungary, quickly accepted, the International Chess Federation titleholder was assured of victory.

title: World News Briefs;New Polish Premier Replaces Accused Spy
description: A new Prime Minister of Poland and his Cabinet were sworn in today, replacing a Government toppled by allegations that the former Prime Minister passed state secrets to Moscow.

title: 6 Hurt in Escalator Mishap
description: Six people suffered minor injuries yesterday morning when a man lost his balance on a down escalator and dropped several heavy boxes on other riders at a subway station in Queens.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GENCORP OFFERS EARLY RETIREMENTS IN REVAMPING
description: Gencorp Inc., a maker of aerospace and automotive products, said yesterday that it was offering early retirement to 100 employees and eliminating its office of chief executive in a reorganization aimed at making the company more competitive. As part of the plan, four Gencorp officers, including two in the four-member office of chief executive, will retire early. The moves will result in a charge against earnings of an undisclosed amount.

title: Jordan Now Succeeding in Mending Gulf Ties Frayed by Iraq
description: With a toughened stand against Iraq, King Hussein of Jordan has brought his country close to full rapprochement with Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, which had refused to forgive Jordan for supporting the Baghdad Government during the Persian Gulf war.

title: Carpets That Fly . . . and Some That Crash
description: THE thermometer read 15 degrees last Sunday afternoon, but that was not the reason my fingers had turned blue. The culprit was an old Kerman carpet, supposedly worth $28,000, being sold at an auction of Oriental rugs and textiles held at the fashionable Mark Hotel on the Upper East Side. Two spit-moistened fingertips and one surreptitious rub later, I had navy blue stains that vanished only after steady scrubbing.

title: Building Ignored Until Fatal Fire
description: The Brooklyn building that collapsed during a fire Monday and killed a firefighter was illegally built more than 18 years ago, and was never inspected by city fire or building inspectors, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Defenders Gather Steam
description: To the Editor:

title: Multiple Births: A Wake-Up Call
description: TIME was when every living supertwin -- that means every triplet, quadruplet, quintuplet and sextuplet in the world -- could count on a birthday card from Miss Helen Kirk.

title: Packard Bell Is in Accord With NEC and Groupe Bull
description: Cash-short Packard Bell Electronics Inc. received an infusion of new capital today from the NEC Corporation of Japan and said it had agreed to merge with Groupe Bull's Zenith Data Systems unit.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Former Head Of Gartner To Be a Rival
description: With a group of well-known backers and ambitious plans, Gideon Gartner is returning to the small but lucrative niche of the publishing business that he helped create: research on information technology for corporate customers.

title: Smith Barney Facing Defections As a Second Top Banker Quits
description: Michael Levitt, one of a group of high-profile deal makers that Smith Barney Inc. recruited from Morgan Stanley & Company three years ago, has resigned.

title: Constitutionality of State's Kosher Laws Is Challenged
description: Almost three years ago, a New York State kosher inspector walked into a butcher shop in Commack, L.I., spotted a heap of supposedly kosher poultry that he said lacked the proper tags, and slapped the merchant with an $11,100 fine.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SOCCER;Metrostars Look to L.I.U.
description: After selecting two former players from Rutgers on Tuesday, the Metrostars of the new Major League Soccer yesterday drafted four former stars from Long Island University who have been playing in various leagues in the New York metropolitan area.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Smith Has Businesslike View
description: He was brought in four seasons ago as perhaps the final piece of a championship puzzle. One account of his acquisition from the Los Angeles Clippers blared, "From now on, Dave Checketts and Ernie Grunfeld will be known as co-executives of the year."

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Caesars Is Fined $5,000
description: Caesars Atlantic City Hotel Casino dismissed a security guard who found a customer's bank card and used it to withdraw $100 from an automatic teller machine. But that was not enough, state regulators said yesterday, fining the casino $5,000 for not properly reporting the episode, the A.P. said. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: German Tourist Plane Crashes; 189 Feared Dead
description: A Boeing 757 carrying 189 people, mostly tourists on their way home to Berlin and Frankfurt from the Dominican Republic, crashed into the Atlantic late Tuesday about 13 miles offshore. At least 105 bodies were recovered, American officials said, but The Associated Press quoted a Dominican civil defense official, Domingo Antonio Vargas, as saying as many as 126 bodies had been found by late yesterday.

title: The New Communists Are Surely Confusing
description: To the Editor:

title: From Mr. Spud to Mr. Chips;The Potato Tycoon Who Is the Force Behind Micron
description: From practically anywhere in this city, you can see the mansion on the hilltop, with its 100-foot flagpole stabbing the sky. Up there, anyone can tell you, lives Jack Simplot, the billionaire who has dominated the local economy for seven decades and is responsible for the jobs of more than 14,000 people in this part of America.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;New German Partner Joins British Telecom
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. lined up a new partner yesterday for its German venture and disclosed plans for increased investment. The new partner is the German utility RWE A.G. It will join the alliance that British Telecom formed last year with Viag A.G. to position the British company for the German residential market when it is opened to competition in 1998.

title: Aristide Hands Power to Successor in Haiti
description: In subdued, even somber ceremonies here today, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide ended a turbulent five-year term by becoming the first elected head of state in nearly 200 years of Haitian history to peacefully transfer power to a popularly chosen successor.

title: Market Place;Mutual fund investors primarily took world tours last month.
description: USING the investment vehicle that served them so well in the United States stock market last year -- mutual funds -- individual investors turned their attentions overseas last month, putting a record amount of money into funds that invest both here and abroad and pushing foreign markets up sharply in the process.

title: New York State Gives Guidelines to Schools
description: The State Board of Regents issued school districts new guidelines intended to improve the level of instruction, an early step in a sweeping plan to revamp the basic curriculum across the state.

title: BASEBALL;Players Present a Counter To Owners' Latest Proposal
description: For the first time in nearly a year, owners and players have exchanged proposals in their halting effort to forge a new collective bargaining agreement. They took nearly three months to make the exchange, but that is relative progress.

title: Atlanta's Olympics Face Ticket Tangles
description: As the organizers of the summer Olympics here prepare to open telephone sales for about 3.7 million tickets still available for the Games, many people are angry and frustrated by their inability so far to buy tickets.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;2 Big Water Mains Break
description: Some 750,000 people in northern New Jersey found themselves with little or no water yesterday after two large water mains ruptured, causing some schools to close, hospitals to postpone operations and firefighters to resort to portable water tanks. The break occurred under Main Street in New Milford in almost exactly the same spot where a water main ruptured seven years ago. [Page A1.]

title: On Environment, G.O.P. Hasn't Alienated Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;TRW IN TALKS TO SELL CREDIT INFORMATION UNIT
description: TRW Inc. is in talks to sell its credit information business for as much as $1 billion to an investment group that includes Bain Capital Inc. and the Thomas H. Lee Company, according to a person involved in the discussions. TRW's Information Systems and Services unit is one of the nation's leading providers of credit reports on consumers and businesses. It had sales of $604.2 million and an operating profit of $86.8 million last year. TRW, Lee and Bain Capital all declined to comment about the possible deal, which was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal. TRW's stock closed unchanged at $86.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Company are closely held buyout firms in Boston.

title: CHINA SOLD PARTS FOR NUCLEAR ARMS, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY
description: China secretly sold nuclear-weapons technology to Pakistan last year and could face the loss of billions of dollars in business deals under United States law, Administration officials said today. But, they said, President Clinton may waive the penalties to ease tensions with Beijing.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: 3 Are Acquitted of Murder in a High-Profile Florida Drug Case
description: Federal prosecutors have suffered a setback in a high-profile Florida case in which they sought the death penalty against three men accused of killing while running a long-term drug-trafficking enterprise.

title: But Not a Drop to Drink, or Flush, or Wash With
description: It was only a quarter to eight in the morning, and a large sign in the window said "No Water," but the Grand Union supermarket here was packed. Terri Aued decided to brave the crowd.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MARSH & MCLENNAN TO SELL BRITISH INSURANCE UNIT
description: The Marsh & McLennan Companies, the New York-based insurance and financial services company, said it planned to sell its British subsidiary, the Frizzell Group Ltd., to the Liverpool Victoria Friendly Society for L188 million ($290 million). Liverpool Victoria, a life insurer owned by its policyholders, said the acquisition would provide new distribution channels and a broader range of products. Frizzell, based in Bournemouth, on England's south coast, sells car and household insurance and provides banking and financial services in Britain. It is wholly owned by Marsh & McLennan, the world's largest insurance broker. Shares in Marsh & McLennan were up $1.125, to $92.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Cleveland's Negotiators And N.F.L. Meet Again
description: Negotiators for the city of Cleveland and the National Football League met again yesterday to discuss the outlines of a plan to ease the Browns' move to Baltimore and bring another team to Cleveland. The league wants the solution in hand when team owners vote tomorrow in Chicago on the Browns' relocation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the theater in London referred incorrectly to the status of two productions. "Company" has not closed, and will continue its run at the Donmar Warehouse through March 2; "Volpone" closed at the Olivier Theater yesterday, not Jan. 27.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Ocean Spray Picks Campbell Mithun
description: Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc. yesterday added Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis to its agency roster by naming that shop to handle advertising for all new beverage and food products. The billings were not disclosed; total billings for the juice drinks and other products that Ocean Spray now markets, which are handled by North Castle Partners in Stamford, Conn., were estimated at $30 million to $40 million.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SONY SENDS TOP JAPANESE OFFICIAL HOME FROM U.S.
description: The Sony Corporation is moving the highest ranking Japanese executive at the Sony Corporation of America back to Tokyo in a further realignment of its United States management. Kyoji Hoshikawa, executive vice president at the American unit, served as the main liaison with Japanese headquarters at a time when Sony suffered big losses at its Hollywood movie studio. A Sony spokesman said that Mr. Hoshikawa, who spent nearly six years in the United States, was returning as part of a regular rotation. As previously reported, Sony's new president, Nobuyuki Idei, is sending Tadasu Kawai, now head of Sony of Canada, to be his personal deputy at the Sony Corporation of America.

title: Essay;Who's Losing Russia?
description: The lights are going out all over Russia. Because believers in democracy -- not a majority, but a plurality backed by a free press -- are split into sullen factions, they may deliver Russia back to Communist or some other form of tyranny.

title: TRACK & FIELD;Americans Finish 1-3 in Moscow Meet
description: Randall Evans won the 50-meter sprint at the World Class track meet today and a fellow American, Andre Cason, finished third. A Ukrainian, Sergei Osovich, was second.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;Two Loners Not Above Pilfering
description: Neither the Scottish composer Judith Weir nor the Danish composer Poul Ruders, both in their 40's, fit into any contemporary music camp. They boldly help themselves to whatever sources and styles suit their needs. Yet each has forged a distinctive compositional voice. These are composers more concerned with authenticity than originality, as two recent CD's of their works make clear.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SOROS TRIMS STAKE IN NEWMONT MINING
description: The billionaire investor George Soros has cut his stake in the Newmont Mining Corporation to 9.1 percent from 10.67 percent. Mr. Soros sold 1.33 million common shares at $56.50 a share to $59.53 a share, between Jan. 22 and Monday, according to a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Soros reported holding the 10.67 percent stake last Nov. 14. A Soros associate, Stanley Druckenmiller, who files jointly with Mr. Soros, cut his stake in the company to 1 percent, from the 1.5 percent that he previously held. Newmont, based in Denver, explores for gold and has refining arrangements with domestic and foreign refiners. The company's shares closed today at $57, down $2.75.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In the movie "Mr. Holland's Opus," OLYMPIA DUKAKIS plays a high school principal. This week she returned to class, but not to play a fictional role.

title: Theft Was Genuine, But the Art Was Not
description: It was portrayed as perhaps the biggest theft ever at Kennedy International Airport: two Picassos and a Pissarro -- with a combined worth of more than $10 million.

title: BASEBALL;Winfield Expected to Retire
description: Dave Winfield, the senior player in the major leagues with 23 years of service, has scheduled a news conference in Manhattan today at which he is expected to announce his retirement.

title: On Environment, G.O.P. Hasn't Alienated Voters;Flowers in Amber
description: To the Editor:

title: Migrant Workers Take AIDS Risk Home to Niger
description: A life of hope, born of hardship, is beginning for Abdraymane Goumar, 27, a peasant who set out the other day from a barren village for the long-dreamed-of promise of a big city that lies three days away by tortuous bus ride.

title: Morrison Knudsen Issued S.E.C. Subpoena
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun issuing subpoenas in its previously disclosed investigation of the Morrison Knudsen Corporation, the financially troubled construction and engineering company.

title: Educators in 2 States Issue New Learning Standards;Officials in New Jersey Release Standards To Improve What the Public Schools Teach
description: New Jersey released a revision of its public school curriculum today, listing standards in seven fields of study that education officials hope will reverse what they called a longstanding decline in learning.

title: Bratton Issues Apology Over Youths in Lineup
description: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton apologized yesterday to the families of two black teen-agers who were detained by detectives for three hours last month and forced to act as "fillers" in a lineup involving a robbery suspect.

title: U.N. Is Now Expected to Extend Angolan Peacekeeping Mission
description: Encouraged by promises from the Angolan guerrilla leader Jonas Savimbi that he will speed up the demobilization of his forces, the Security Council is expected to extend a peacekeeping mission in Angola for three months. The vote is expected on Thursday.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Limits on Unit Proposed
description: A special panel appointed by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to review the operation of the State Commission of Investigation has recommended extending the commission's life for six more years but curbing its responsibilities and independence. Under the proposal the agency, which was created to investigate organized crime and official corruption, would confine its inquiries to state, county and local government operations. It would be required to refer all evidence of criminal wrongdoing to the State Attorney General's office and get the Attorney General's permission to conduct hearings and issue reports.

title: Guy Madison, a Movie Actor And TV's Wild Bill, Dies at 74
description: Guy Madison, a film and television actor who starred in the 1950's television series "The Adventures of Wild Bill Hickok," died on Tuesday at Desert Hospital Hospice in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 74 and lived in Morongo Valley, Calif.

title: Getting To Know Lincoln Through His Stuff
description: LOUISE TAPER first fell for Abraham Lincoln more than 20 years ago, when she read a biographical novel about the marriage of the 16th President. As a way of getting to feel close to him, she said she longed to own something of Lincoln's. At the time, she was raising two small children and had little money to spend on artifacts. So she got a job with a manuscript dealer in Los Angeles, who agreed to pay her in documents instead of money.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: APARTMENT INVESTMENT AND MANAGEMENT CO., a real estate investment trust, bought two apartment complexes, the Peachtree Park complex in Atlanta and Villa Ladera complex in Albuquerque, N.M., for a total of $28.1 million.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Seton Hall Just Loses Its Way in Piscataway
description: Anything that could go wrong for Seton Hall's basketball team did tonight in a 70-61 Big East loss to Rutgers.

title: Rowland Budget Retreats From Sharp Cuts of Last Year
description: Stepping back from the sharp cuts he offered last year, Gov. John G. Rowland today proposed a budget that features a modest reduction in overall spending and increased aid for the elderly, children and the state's ailing cities.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Barbeques Galore, Irvine, Calif., to Kalis & Savage, Pacific Palisades, Calif., to handle advertising and direct mail for the chain of barbecue specialty stores, previously handled by Moiselles & Associates, Los Angeles. The billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: CLOSE TO HOME;Where's Poppa? Talking to the TV
description: La Belle Aurore, Paris, 1940. A crazy time to fall in love.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Minister Is Robbed and Shot
description: A minister who was robbed and shot at least six times after he left his East Orange church was in critical condition yesterday at University Hospital in Newark. Police officials in East Orange said two men attacked the Rev. William Barnett, 56, pastor of the Citadel of Hope Mission, after he drove parishioners home from an evening service Tuesday night. According to Lieut. Robert Kolb, the suspects took a bag containing church donations and one gunman chased Mr. Barnett and shot him as he ran to the porch of a home and then crawled to a nearby street.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;125,000 Salute the Cowboys
description: More than 125,000 fans lined a downtown parade route today to hail the Super Bowl champion Dallas Cowboys, who glided by on silver and blue floats during a Texas-sized salute.

title: North Korea Tells Groups To Halt Drive For Flood Aid
description: Retreating from a landmark policy decision to seek international assistance, North Korea has told foreign relief agencies not to organize new appeals for flood victims who by some accounts are on the verge of famine.

title: On Social Policy, Governors Quietly Split the Difference
description: The welfare and Medicaid proposals endorsed by the nation's governors this week lack detail and have a long way to go if they are ever to become law. But if approved, such changes would revolutionize social policy by shifting large amounts of money and decision-making power to the states.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Polymorphic Event by Merce Cunningham
description: You don't go to a Chinese restaurant for french fries. Yet even if you know what kind of cuisine to expect, the specials of the day may delight or surprise.

title: After the First Votes, Ecstasy and Agony
description: Only about 21,500 voters, 5 percent of the state's Republican registration, turned out for the Presidential caucuses in Louisiana on Tuesday, and the party's two top contenders -- Bob Dole and Steve Forbes -- were not even on the ballot. But a day after the first caucuses of the 1996 election season, Patrick J. Buchanan was talking like a man with a big headstart on the field, having won 13 of the 21 delegates at stake.

title: The Pop Life
description: Chili Peppers

title: Panel Issues 28 Subpoenas in Travel Office Inquiry
description: Locked in a battle of wills with the Clinton Administration, a House committee issued 28 subpoenas today for documents related to the dismissals of the White House travel office staff.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Schering Profit Off 13%; Strong Mark Is Cited
description: Still grappling with the negative effects of the strong mark, the German pharmaceutical company Schering A.G. said yesterday that its profit fell 13 percent in 1995 but forecast that the company could match 1994's record results this year. Schering, the world's largest maker of oral contraceptives, said its profit slid to 249 million marks ($168.7 million), from 285 million marks in 1994. Revenue edged down 1 percent, to 4.65 billion marks ($3.15 billion) from 4.69 billion marks.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Johnson And Lakers Put Brakes On Nets' Run
description: Jayson Williams had been waiting for more than a decade for this game, since the cold morning when he and his high school teammates could not use their gymnasium because of a closed practice held by the Lakers. That day, when the Lakers emerged, Williams asked Magic Johnson for an autograph. "Not now, kid," Johnson said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Bridge
description: When one of the world's great player-writers announces that he has found a new situation in defensive play, attention must be paid. He is Mike Lawrence of Berkeley, Calif., who has not only won two world team titles but has also been the most prolific writer of bridge books in the last decade.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Ewing Gets A Big Lift From Davis And Ward
description: The Knicks may want to reconstruct their franchise in the next few months, but they do not want Hubert Davis and Charlie Ward to go anywhere. On nights when Patrick Ewing could use some ice on his right elbow from carrying this team offensively, it is easy to see why.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Hershey Expands DDB Needham Role
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation said yesterday that it had further expanded its relationship with the DDB Needham New York unit of the Omnicom Group by awarding that agency the account of Hershey's Sweet Escapes, a new line of reduced-fat chocolate products. The billings were not disclosed.

title: Winter's Rock-Salt Rainbows
description: EVERY time it has snowed or frozen over in recent weeks, the sidewalks of many New York City neighborhoods have been transformed into carnival shades of blue, red and green. Last week was no exception.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Senate Approves a Bill Phasing Out Farm Subsidies The Senate approved legislation that would end Depression-era programs that pay farmers not to plant and would replace many crop subsidies with fixed payments that would decline over seven years.

title: Bosnia Peace Agreement Shows Increasing Signs of Wear and Tear
description: The euphoria that greeted the deployment of the NATO-led forces in Bosnia has been replaced in recent days by the growing realization that the Bosnian peace accord is fraying in places.

title: No Link Seen Between Fat and Breast Cancer
description: A new study has failed to find any relationship between the amount of fat a woman eats and her chances of developing breast cancer.

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Stocks were trading higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues stood at 21,118.30, up 174.81 points, or more than eight-tenths of 1 percent. On Wednesday, the Nikkei gained 192.34 points.

title: Currents;Gifts to Evoke the Past And to Inflame Passions
description: FOR those who like things nostalgic, the International Gift Fair at the Jacob Javits Convention Center, which ended on Jan. 25, was a shopper's Elysium. The best offerings resonated with honest sentiment -- particularly welcome in this hearts-and-roses season of manufactured love.

title: No. 1 Georgia Wins
description: Tracy Henderson scored 25 points and led a late run tonight that sent No. 1 Georgia past No. 17 Mississippi, 90-85, in a women's college basketball game.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KODAK IN TALKS TO BUY CHINESE PHOTO COMPANIES
description: The Eastman Kodak Company is negotiating to buy controlling stakes in China's three biggest makers of photographic film, executives at two of the companies said yesterday. The Chinese companies under consideration by Kodak are the Henan Baoding Photographic Film Company, the Xiamen Fuda Photographic Materials Company and the Shantou Era Photo Materials Industry Corporation, said Ling Gang, a manager at Xiamen Fuda. The move would allow the Rochester company to bypass China's high import duties and gain broader distribution in China. A Kodak spokesman, Charlie Smith, said the company had been in discussions with Chinese Government officials and photo executives.

title: Dole Aide Nominated
description: President Clinton nominated a top aide on Senate majority leader Bob Dole's staff today to a seat on the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. David D. Spears, the state director of Dole's offices in Kansas, was nominated to succeed Sheila Bair on the commission, which regulates the commodity futures and related options markets. The nomination requires Senate confirmation.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Saturday with an article about fatal accidents involving school buses was published in error. The article reported that drivers of privately operated buses are not required to take special driver-training programs, but the picture showed a publicly operated bus, for the East Ramapo, N.Y., school district, dropping children off at a private school, the Yeshiva of Spring Valley. Drivers of such publicly operated buses do take the special training courses.

title: World News Briefs;Lesotho's Crown Prince Takes Throne as King
description: Crown Prince Letsie David Mohato took the throne as King Letsie III for the second time today, replacing his father, King Moshoeshoe II, who died in a car accident last month.

title: POP REVIEW;Oh, Life Can Be So Hard
description: At arena rock concerts, audience members often bat balloons and beach balls back and forth over their heads. At Alanis Morissette's concert on Tuesday night at Roseland, the first of three sold-out shows that conclude tonight, the crowd bopped inflated condoms in the air. It was an appropriate response to the action onstage, where an all-male band that looked and often played like macho 1980's arena-rock balladeers supported this idiosyncratic 21-year-old Canadian singer who offers a powerful voice, frank lyrics about love and sex and a determination to assert her individuality.

title: For a Modern Mezzo, All the Web's a Stage
description: When Cecilia Bartoli makes her Metropolitan Opera debut tonight as Despina in Mozart's "Cosi Fan Tutte," many of her most ardent admirers will probably be in the house, cheering her on. But what of the Bartolites who are left out in the cold: those who could not get tickets to the sold-out performance, or who won't be in New York for the occasion?

title: Sharman Douglas, 67, Socialite And Friend of British Royals
description: Sharman Douglas, a socialite whose life was defined by her friendship as a youth with Princess Margaret and her ensuing lifelong friendship with Britain's royal family, died on Saturday at New York Hospital. She was 67 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Why Shouldn't Religious Groups Make Movies?
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Corralling the Brutes And Boobs of the Mob
description: THE GOOD GUYS How We Turned the F.B.I. 'Round -- and Finally Broke the Mob By Jules Bonavolonta and Brian Duffy

title: A Premature, Puzzling 2d Break in 7 Years
description: The water pipe that broke early this morning, disrupting water supplies to Bergen and Hudson counties, also ruptured in the same spot seven years ago.

title: The Delicate Balance in Bosnia
description: The interests of peace and the interests of justice do not always work in tandem in Bosnia. That is clear from a sudden yet predictable crisis over the detention of suspected war criminals that now threatens to disrupt the uneasy peace between the Bosnian Government and Bosnian Serbs.

title: Feeling Tired and Run Down? It Could Be the Lights
description: Researchers say they have found that normal levels of indoor lighting, and not just very bright light, can reset the human biological clock, a finding they say indicates that many people in industrialized countries may be constantly sleep deprived and in a permanent state of jet lag.

title: BASKETBALL;UConn Women Rout Storm
description: Nykesha Sales scored 21 points on 10-for-10 shooting tonight, leading No. 3 Connecticut past St. John's, 85-41.

title: Sports of The Times;Big Dawg Barking Up Wrong Tree
description: IN the formal chamber of the august House Judiciary Committee Tuesday, a beefy man in a brown football jersey, wearing orange shoes and a dog collar took his seat, placing on the witness table before him a big orange bone and a dog-faced hat.

title: For Your Hi-Fi Valentine, Say It With Banana Plugs
description: CRYSTAL goblets, cashmere sweaters, Godiva chocolates. Such are the trappings of romantic excess -- the stuff of Valentine's Day. It's that time when you pull out the stops to make someone you love feel really special. So, here's a hint: Hi-fi buffs have feelings, too.

title: SENATE APPROVES BILL TO PHASE OUT FARMING SUBSIDIES
description: The Senate today approved far-reaching legislation that would end Depression-era programs paying farmers not to plant certain crops and that would replace many crop subsidies with fixed payments, which would gradually decline over the next seven years.

title: 2 Water Mains In North Jersey Are Ruptured
description: About 750,000 people in northern New Jersey found themselves with little or no water today after two large mains beneath Main Street here ruptured before dawn, causing some schools to close, hospitals to postpone surgery and firefighters to resort to portable water tanks.

title: No Headline
description: Every time we turn on a light, we are inadvertently taking a drug that affects how we will sleep and how we will be awake the next day." DR. CHARLES A. CZEISLER, sleep researcher. [A18:3]

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK;Shades of Pewter In a Wintry World
description: I haven't moved from this table for two days," Robert Dash said as he stared glumly out the window at a gray sky. It was 10 degrees in Sagaponack, and his garden was buried in snow.

title: Open Attitude on Homosexuality Makes Pariahs of Some Churches
description: Lakeshore Avenue Baptist Church, a 136-year-old congregation in a middle-class neighborhood on the edge of downtown, has taken pride over the years in supporting local civil rights causes. In the 1950's, for example, a former minister persuaded local banks to give mortgages to black families so they could move into the tidy neighborhood around the cream-colored church building.

title: Aviation Agency Needs Management Continuity
description: To the Editor:

title: SKIING;Skiers Get Reminder Of Nature Underfoot
description: Tom Cardamone recalls a moment when he and his daughter Kate, who was 4 years old at the time, were riding up the chairlift at Buttermilk Mountain in Aspen, Colo. It was a quiet passage through a tall forest of spruce and fir. Only the click, click, click of the chair as it passed each lift tower was there to remind them of the civilization nearby.

title: World News Briefs;Peres Reportedly Sets Israeli Election for May
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel reportedly told Secretary of State Warren Christopher today that Israeli elections would be held on May 28, diplomats said.

title: HORSE RACING;Cigar's Newest Challenger Is a Mare
description: In the 37 years they have been running the Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park, no female has ever won. But this year, when the entries were drawn and the post positions assigned today, it was the mare Heavenly Prize who was given the best chance to run down the mighty Cigar and break his 12-race winning streak.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Selanne Is Dealt to Ducks
description: The Winnipeg Jets, who will move to Phoenix next season, sent the high-scoring forward TEEMU SELANNE to the Mighty Ducks yesterday for defenseman OLEG TVERDOVSKY and center CHAD KILGER plus Anaheim's third-round draft pick this year.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Issues End Day Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday, as the market showed its disappointment with a sale of new 10-year notes.

title: Youth Hospitalized for Amnesia Is Identified
description: A teen-age girl who disappeared from a town in Florida on Jan. 3 was recognized last night at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan, where she had been hospitalized since Jan. 18, apparently suffering from memory loss, the authorities and relatives said.

title: Merger Rumors Lift Phone Stocks
description: Shares of the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the Nynex Corporation climbed yesterday on speculation that merger talks between the two companies had intensified.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: SPORTS BUSINESS;Mere Companies Chasing an Icon
description: Nike has raised the ante; are they trying to force us all out?" wondered Charlie Peiffer, president of Prince, the racquet makers. "I see them as a muscling powerhouse, Procter and Gamble in the sporting goods business, acting tough, getting people to do what they want. And when it comes time to work with other companies, as in the Play Tennis America program, they're not involved. Reebok and Adidas play their part. Not Nike."

title: Turkey and Chechnya
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday about Elizabeth Taylor's filing for a divorce from Larry Fortensky misstated the number of her divorces. This would be the seventh, not the eighth; she was widowed once.

title: Don't Allow Censorship Of Irish History Exhibit
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNIVERSAL HEALTH SERVICES TO BUY A TEXAS HOSPITAL
description: Universal Health Services Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Northwest Texas Hospital in Amarillo, Tex., for $120 million. The hospital management company said the hospital, which has 360 beds, generated annual revenue of about $140 million. The purchase includes the hospital and related assets. The Amarillo Hospital District will pay Universal Health $8 million a year for the first four years and $6 million a year for up to an additional 36 years to help support the cost of medical service to poor patients. In addition, the Amarillo district will receive, through 2003, 15 percent of any operating income totaling more than $24 million. Universal Health, based in King of Prussia, Pa., owns and operates 29 hospitals.

title: Economic Scene;California propositions are antilawyer, and no joke.
description: MANY people talk of cutting lawyers down to size. The Alliance to Revitalize California has a plan to do it.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Sign Nelson And Bolster Bullpen
description: Jeff Nelson, the side-arming right-hander with the wicked slider who has been so effective against the Yankees in his career, is assured of being a Yankee until 1997. Nelson signed a two-year, $1.85 million contract yesterday and avoided arbitration.

title: Why Shouldn't Religious Groups Make Movies?
description: To the Editor:

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Soybean Prices Turn Down As Demand Is Surprisingly Low
description: Soybean prices fell yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as rising stockpiles of soybean meal and soybean oil show that demand has been weaker than expected.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Jan. 19 about an exhibition of Joseph Cornell's work at C & M Arts in Manhattan misstated the evidence for when the artist created "Object 1941" and when it was first shown. The work was seen at least as early as 1943, at Peggy Guggenheim's Art of This Century Gallery in Manhattan, not in 1949.

title: Maine's High Court Allows TV at Trial
description: The Maine Supreme Court has granted CBS News permission to place hidden television cameras in a jury room to film traditionally secret jury deliberations in a civil trial.

title: William Larsen, 68, A Character Actor
description: William Larsen, a veteran character actor on Broadway, Off Broadway and in regional theater, died on Jan. 21 at his home in Friendswood, Tex. He was 68.

title: POLITICS;In Their Own Words
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN

title: Cardinal Deal To Buy Pyxis In Stock Swap
description: Cardinal Health Inc., a big drug wholesaler, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Pyxis Corporation, which makes automated pill dispensers for hospitals. The deal would involve a tax-free stock swap valued at $867 million, based on yesterday's closing price of Cardinal shares.

title: Citibank in St. Petersburg
description: Citibank N.A., a unit of Citicorp, opened a branch in St. Petersburg today, becoming the first United States bank operating in the city, the bank said today. The St. Petersburg branch will be under the direct control of Citibank T/O, the Russian subsidiary in Moscow opened two years ago that is one of 13 foreign banks allowed to work with residents.

title: Off-Duty Officer Assists in L.I.R.R. Arrest
description: An off-duty Port Authority police officer helped the Long Island Rail Road police arrest a slashing suspect on the platform of the Jamaica Station in Queens on Monday, railroad officials said yesterday. It was the first incident involving the arrest of an armed person with the assistance of an off-duty officer since the railroad initiated a new policy to permit police officers to ride free.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;3 Join Board of Education
description: Three new members were sworn in for six-year terms yesterday on the State Board of Education: Donald C. Addison Jr. of Trenton, Chief of Senior and Community Services for Mercer County; Wendell E. Daniels of Lakewood, an assistant prosecutor for Ocean County, and Thomas P. McGough of Florham Park, a vice president of the Beneficial Management Corporation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Ruder Finn Acquires Harrison
description: Ruder Finn Inc., a public relations agency in New York, said yesterday that it had acquired the E. Bruce Harrison Company in Washington in an effort to strengthen its services in public affairs and environmental public relations. The terms were not disclosed.

title: INSIDE
description: Murdoch Cuts On-Line Unit

title: The Man Who Helped Kelly Put His Best Foot Forward
description: Few movie directors have the track record of Stanley Donen. At the age of 71, he looks back on a series of musicals and comedies that endure for their wit, style and sheer panache.

title: BASKETBALL;Boston College Shows Storm New Depths
description: The painful season at St. John's is no longer calculated merely by a succession of final scores. It can be measured by the angry sounds coming from the home team's dressing room in Alumni Hall, a place that once sent Boston College teams, among others, screaming out onto Union Turnpike. Now the shouting takes place behind closed doors, punctuated by the sounds of objects being thrown and coaches' voices working to establish calm.

title: Political Feud Over Accord With G.E. Turns Personal
description: An unusually vitriolic dispute broke out today between a Republican Congressman and a Democratic Assemblyman over a deal that the Pataki administration reached to settle pollution charges against an upstate plant owned by the General Electric Company.

title: Clinton's Budget Available on the Internet
description: For those interested in taking a closer look at President Clinton's budget proposal for the 1997 fiscal year, the White House Office of Management and Budget has posted a copy on its Internet site.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MINORCO TO SELL ITS STAKE IN SANTA FE ENERGY
description: Minorco, faced with an estimated $2 billion in mining expenditures in the coming years, plans to sell its 9.6 percent stake in Santa Fe Energy Resources Inc. Santa Fe, an oil and gas exploration and production company based in Houston, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to register 8.71 million shares held by a Minorco subsidiary called Minorco (USA) Inc. Minorco, which is based in Luxembourg, described the stock sale as another step in its effort to concentrate on core metals, paper and agribusiness operations. Santa Fe shares fell 37.5 cents to close at $9.125.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Aetna Posts Weaker Results for Quarter
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company yesterday reported weaker results for the fourth quarter and took a $218.1 million charge for asbestos cleanup claims in a unit it plans to sell.

title: Russell Colley, Designer Of Spacesuits, Is Dead at 97
description: Russell Colley, a thwarted women's fashion designer who used his consolation career as a mechanical engineer to become the Calvin Klein of space wear, died on Sunday at the Ohio Masonic Home in Springfield, Ohio. He was 97.

title: Village Voice, Circulation Down, to Be Free to Manhattan Readers
description: Correction Appended

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Metro Matters;Few but Forbes Could Survive Petition Ordeal
description: WHAT if Steve Forbes wins, becomes the Republican Presidential nominee? Where will New York's Republicans be then?

title: Calendar: Exhibitions, A Talk and an Auction
description: Creating Landscapes Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); (212) 753-1722.

title: POLITICS: THE SCENE;Forbes? The Enemy Camp Turns Joyful
description: The very idea that President Clinton might eventually run against Steve Forbes and his flat-tax platform sends Margo McNabb, career Democrat, into a Joycean ecstasy of Molly Bloom dimensions.

title: More Bad News on Foster Care
description: The Federal Government has filed a civil lawsuit contending that New York City bilked it of millions of dollars for foster care services that were not delivered. Washington says that most of the alleged transgressions occurred during the Dinkins administration. But it is Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, already strapped for money to cover the municipal deficit, who will have to pay up if the Government wins the case. City officials insist that the suit is more about bookkeeping errors than fraud.

title: Mitchell Rogovin, 65, Civil Liberties Lawyer
description: Mitchell Rogovin, a Washington lawyer who moved deftly in the highest levels of Government and politics yet remained an advocate of openness and accountability for public officials, died yesterday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 65.

title: Protest, Cyberspace-Style, for New Law
description: President Clinton hailed it as a political triumph and one of the most important pieces of legislation in years. But to thousands of computer users and advocates of free speech and civil rights, today will be a day of protest in cyberspace and in the courts when the President signs the Telecommunications Reform Bill.

title: Educators in 2 States Issue New Learning Standards;New York Regents Establish New Guidelines To Bolster Level of High School Instruction
description: The State Board of Regents today issued a set of guidelines that school districts across the state are to use to improve the level of instruction, an early step in a sweeping plan to revamp the basic curriculum for school districts.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: A Different Valentine

title: HOCKEY;The Devils' Best Shot Disappears Into Wregget's Glove
description: Mario Lemieux missed the game between the Penguins and the Devils tonight, but it had just about everything else to satisfy what hockey fans crave. The sellout crowd of 19,040 saw an impressive display of Jaromir Jagr's skill, plenty of ferocious hitting, superb goaltending and even a look at a rare penalty shot.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Adelphi University's response to a state investigation of its spending referred imprecisely to the salary and benefits of its president, Peter Diamandopoulos. The total of $523,000 for 1993-94 included a one-time future bonus of $149,000. The university said the 1994-95 total, which it declined to disclose, did not include such a bonus.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Henry Bibby, Former Knick, Is New Head Coach at U.S.C.
description: The University of Southern California dismissed its head basketball coach, CHARLIE PARKER, yesterday and replaced him on an interim basis with the former U.C.L.A. star and ex-Knick HENRY BIBBY.

title: Brian Weil, 41, Photographer Who Founded Needle Exchange
description: Brian Weil, a photographer who devoted much of his career to documenting life on society's margins and who helped found New York City's first needle exchange program, died over the weekend at his home in Manhattan. He was 41.

title: Manolo Fabregas, Actor and Director, 75
description: Manolo Fabregas, an actor, producer and director who was a popular figure in theater, films and television in Mexico, died on Sunday at his home here. He was 75.

title: Priest From Yonkers Is Named a Bishop
description: Pope John Paul II has named Msgr. Edwin F. O'Brien, a native of the Bronx and a former Army chaplain in Vietnam, as an auxiliary bishop for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

title: HOUSTON THEATER;2 Redgraves Paired In Roman Shakespeare
description: When air is icy and skies forbidding, it is natural to gravitate toward sources of light and heat: a fireplace, the sun reflected off the Caribbean or, of course, Vanessa Redgrave, the brave, brilliant English actress.

title: Tiniest Nuclear Building Block May Not Be the Quark
description: Scientists at Fermilab's huge particle accelerator 30 miles west of Chicago reported yesterday that the quark, long thought to be the simplest building block of nuclear matter, may turn out to contain still smaller building blocks and an internal structure.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Lloyds Chemists Endorses Bid by Gehe
description: Britain's Lloyds Chemists P.L.C. told its shareholders yesterday to accept a L584 million ($898 million) bid by German drug wholesaler Gehe A.G. in the absence of a higher offer. But Lloyds said it would also hold discussions with Unichem P.L.C. to determine whether the British pharmaceutical distribution and retailing company would increase the L500 million offer it made last month.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Sears Shows Strength in 4th-Quarter Earnings Amid Slowness in Retailing
description: In a quarter expected to be dismal for retailers, Sears, Roebuck & Company proved to be an exception yesterday, reporting a strong improvment in fourth-quarter results.

title: On Environment, G.O.P. Hasn't Alienated Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: The Trickle-Up Economy;Poor Areas Fear a Disaster if Welfare Is Cut
description: Shortly after 9 A.M., the security screens roll up at a handful of discount furniture stores at the intersection of Fulton Street and Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn. At the Krusty Bakery, coffee is sold through a bulletproof glass partition, and elsewhere, mothers roam the aisles of cut-rate clothing stores. A closed bank building has become a big billboard for a 99-cent sale. Veteran street vendors hawk hats and perfume.

title: BASEBALL;Here's the Windup, Here's Acevedo's Pitch
description: When the Mets' highly touted crop of young pitchers reports to Port St. Lucie, Fla., a week from today, all eyes will rightfully be on Bill Pulsipher, Jason Isringhausen and Paul Wilson.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;GPA Says Creditor May Cause Bankruptcy
description: The GPA Group, the Irish aircraft leasing company, said yesterday that it might be forced to seek bankruptcy court protection from creditors if a key debt holder did not approve its plan to refinance $2.7 billion worth of debt. The Public School Employees Retirement System of Pennsylvania has still not approved the company's plans to reorganize its debt. GPA said in December that it would sell two-thirds of its aircraft lease portfolio to pare debt.

title: Harvard Lures Scholar to Join a 'Dream Team' on Social Policy
description: William Julius Wilson, the sociologist whose writings on race, class and poverty have influenced policy makers, including President Clinton, has taken a top appointment at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government.

title: Right's Rise Confronts Austria With Its Nazi Past
description: Late last September, under the guise of a war veterans' get-together, a group called Kameradschaft 4, or Comradeship 4, organized a gathering of supporters from across Europe in the small southern Austrian village of Kumpendorf. It was no ordinary reunion.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Anheuser-Busch Shutting Its Eagle Snack-Food Unit
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies said today that it had given up a four-month effort to sell its Eagle Snacks unit and would instead close the nation's No. 2 snack-food company and dismiss its 1,750 workers.

title: With Hopes for the Wurst, Kohl Publishes German Specialties
description: Never a person to let his bulk stand in the way of his ambitions, Helmut Kohl, the German Chancellor, has deployed his reputation for epicurean enthusiasm to promote a cookbook in which he and his wife, Hannelore, chronicle 350 traditional German specialties gleaned from a cuisine best known for dumplings, beer and wurst.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;A campaign in California aims to reduce sex and pregnancies among teen-agers.
description: SILHOUETTED in a doorway, a teen-age couple embrace. In the next scene, the boy has vanished and the girl is holding a squalling baby. A voice-over says: "Now you see him. Now you don't. If you're going to have sex, be ready to go it alone."

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;From a Buyout to Welfare to a New Job
description: In 1994, when Barbara H. learned that New York City would offer buyouts to thousands of city workers, she remembers thinking that this would mean good things: a new job for her and extra money for the family.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;MATTEL INC. (MAT,N)
description: Mattel Inc. said yesterday that its profits more than doubled in the fourth quarter amid strong demand for its Barbie, Fisher Price, Hot Wheels and Disney toys.

title: On Environment, G.O.P. Hasn't Alienated Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Low Mark on Environment
description: A coalition of environmental and public-policy groups yesterday gave Governor Whitman a grade of C- on how she has handled environmental issues. The biggest problem, according to Bill Wolfe, a policy specialist with the New Jersey Environmental Federation, is cuts she has made in the budget of the Department of Environmental Protection.

title: POLITICS: IN THE PACK;Unbowed but Disappointed, Gramm Pushes On in Iowa
description: When Senator Phil Gramm returned to his chartered jet between visits to voting sites in Louisiana on Tuesday night, the stewardess, Lisa Dinsmoor, complimented him on his extensive police escort.

title: Yale Clerical Workers Strike as Talks Stall
description: Clerical workers at Yale University went on strike this morning, setting up picket lines that led many professors to hold classes off campus in churches, movie theaters and private homes.

title: Authorities Break Credit-Card Fraud Ring
description: Over the last four years, from a modest apartment in Jamaica, Queens, Olushina Godwin Adekanbi built a multimillion-dollar enterprise that became the largest credit-card fraud ring in the nation, investigators said yesterday.

title: 8 Die in Plane Crash In Baja California
description: A small plane carrying Mexican state government officials slammed into the side of a canyon on Tuesday and exploded, killing all eight people aboard, the police said today.

title: Corrections
description: A chart with the Market Place column in Business Day on Tuesday, about the rising price of a seat on the New York Stock Exchange, mislabeled the years shown. The prices shown were end-of-the-month figures from January 1980 through Monday.

title: Surprise Strike Hits 8 Schools In Brooklyn
description: The Giuliani administration's effort to have private companies clean and maintain dozens of New York City public schools hit its first big snag yesterday when custodial helpers at eight Brooklyn schools staged a surprise four-hour strike that deprived more than 10,000 students of heat and hot water and sent many home.

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL;Players Sign on Dotted Line With Colleges of Choice
description: Dozens of area high school football players put their pens where their mouths were and turned oral commitments into written ones yesterday, the first day for officially signing national letters of intent with colleges.

title: Pope Returns In Jubilation And Triumph To Nicaragua
description: Pope John Paul II made a triumphal return to Nicaragua today, 13 years after he was taunted by supporters of the Sandinista Government, and celebrated the restoration of peace and the authority of the traditional Roman Catholic Church.

title: CHRONICLE
description: No, GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS insisted yesterday at a breakfast at the Plaza, he did not write "Primary Colors," the roman a clef about the 1992 Presidential campaign that has fueled endless guessing about the author's identity.

title: Swiss Say Pre-Holocaust Accounts May Hold Only $32 Million
description: Swiss banks have determined they may have $32.2 million in pre-World War II accounts that could have belonged to Jews who perished in the Holocaust.

title: Liberties;What About Bob?
description: A cold wind and new breeze blew on Inauguration Day 1997. Even a capital accustomed to making history was giddy at turning this astonishing page of history.

title: China Easing Rules on Foreign Currency
description: In a move toward full convertibility of its currency, China plans to loosen some controls on foreign-exchange transactions by companies as of April 1.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Ralph I. Straus, 92, Adviser to Government
description: Ralph I. Straus, a prominent New York City merchant and philanthropist and a frequent consultant to the Federal Government on foreign economic policy, died on Monday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 92.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Defenders Gather Steam
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THE CAUCUSES;Louisiana Catapults Buchanan Into Iowa
description: With Senator Phil Gramm thrown off stride and Patrick J. Buchanan heartened by the results of Tuesday's Louisiana caucuses, the Republican Presidential hopefuls plunged today into the final round of campaigning before the closely watched Iowa caucuses next Monday.

title: U.S. Trade Gap Narrows Again In Export Boom
description: Strong exports and a weakening economy at home brought the nation's trade deficit to its lowest total in nearly two years in November, as the gap shrank by 13.5 percent, to $7.06 billion. It was the fifth consecutive month of improvement.

title: Former Aide To Clinton Testifies He Took Files
description: Webster L. Hubbell, a former top aide to President Clinton and a law partner of Hillary Rodham Clinton, said today that he removed an array of files on Mrs. Clinton's legal work and on financial institutions linked to the Whitewater venture from the Rose Law Firm in Little Rock, Ark., shortly before Mr. Clinton's inauguration as President.

title: Tentative Pact At United Air
description: United Airlines and the union that represents its 20,000 flight attendants said today that they had reached tentative agreement on a new contract.

title: Black Artists in Ballet Are Subject of Symposia
description: Black dancers, choreographers, teachers and company directors will explore the involvement of black artists in American ballet in two free symposia on Monday and on Feb. 26 from 4 to 8 P.M. at the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the Performing Arts Library at Lincoln Center. The discussions are presented in conjunction with "Classic Black," an exhibition at the library through April 27.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STOCK OF DYNATECH UP ON NEWS IT WILL SELL UNITS
description: The Dynatech Corporation's stock jumped as much as 14 percent yesterday after the company said it would sell seven units to focus on communications technology and would buy back as many as a million of its shares. Dynatech ended up $1.875 at $21.125. Dynatech, which is based in Burlington, Mass., said it planned to sell seven broadcast video equipment and data transmission operations, plus four medical and diagnostic operations that were earmarked for sale last month. The 11 businesses have total annual sales of $180 million. Dynatech said it expected the sale of the 11 businesses to net about $100 million. After the sale the company will have three core businesses: communications test instruments, industrial and scientific communications systems, and nonbroadcast video technologies.

title: U.S. Plays Down Possibility of Attack On Taiwan by China
description: WASHINGTON  President Bill Clinton said Wednesday that he was confident there would be no Chinese military actionagainst Taiwan, and he urged both sides to resolvetheir recent tensions peacefully.

title: Belgrade Journal;Scathing 'Conscience' of Balkans Spares No One
description: During the Balkan war, most artists and writers in what was once Yugoslavia used their talents to glorify the ideologies that fuel violence or have found themselves silenced.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;News Corporation Plans Big Cutbacks at On-Line Unit
description: The News Corporation is joining the growing roster of communications companies that are shelving their on-line services and placing their bets on the Internet.

title: Coming Soon: Car Loans on the Internet
description: I.B.M. and the Chase Manhattan Bank plan on Saturday to announce a system for processing car loans over the Internet, the first move in what auto-industry officials predict will be a rapid overhaul of the way Americans borrow money to buy cars and trucks.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Lack of Fluency Not Illegal
description: Not speaking English fluently is not a crime, a judge ruled yesterday. The Municipal Court decision, reported by The Associated Press, came in the case of a Queens truck driver who was cited by a state trooper for failing to speak English clearly when he was stopped for a routine safety inspection.

title: It Takes a Village to Destroy a Child
description: The crime is so heinous it makes me shake with anger. In the early evening hours of Oct. 13, 1994, two boys, 10 and 11 years old, dangled and then dropped 5-year-old Eric Morse from the 14th floor of a Chicago public housing complex, because Eric wouldn't steal candy for them.

title: Mail-In Democracy
description: Democrats are naturally happy that one of their own, Ron Wyden, was elected to fill Bob Packwood's vacant Senate seat in Oregon. But the method by which Oregonians cast their votes may turn out to be more significant than the outcome. They voted by mail. The participation rate was unusually high, and while the system may not work as well in every state as it did in Oregon, the results require thoughtful consideration by anyone who cares about expanding democracy.

title: In a Rebuff To Kerkorian, Chrysler Picks Fund Manager
description: In a rebuff to Kirk Kerkorian, one of its largest shareholders, the Chrysler Corporation announced tonight that it had chosen a prominent mutual fund manager to fill an open seat on its board.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AUTOZONE TO BUY ALLDATA FOR $56 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Autozone Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Alldata Corporation for $56.8 million in common stock. Alldata develops and markets software that provides automotive diagnostic and repair information to more than 15,000 repair shops nationwide. Autozone said it would operate Alldata as unit that would continue to be based in Elk Grove, Calif. Autozone, based in Memphis, has a chain of retail stores. Autozone's stock closed at $27.625, up 75 cents a share.

title: Fixing Communications Law
description: First Amendment advocates rushed into court yesterday to block the "indecency" provisions of a new telecommunications bill that President Clinton has signed into law. The plaintiffs charge, correctly, that the law imposes needlessly restrictive and unconstitutional bans on the transmission, over computer networks, of indecent and abortion-related materials. If the advocates succeed, the courts will knock out what is plainly wrong with this new law. The rest of it is sound telecommunications policy.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about plans by The Village Voice to begin free distribution in Manhattan misspelled the surname of a longtime contributor. He is Jules Feiffer, not Pfeiffer. It also misspelled the given name of the poet who was among the paper's early contributors. He is Allen Ginsberg, not Allan.

title: Respect the Dying's Wishes Before Our Own
description: To the Editor:

title: Also of Note1
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: MARATHON;Parenthood On the Run
description: Gwyn and Mark Coogan are the first married contenders in the United States Olympic marathon trials, though daily life can feel more like a frantic relay race in which their 26-month-old daughter, Katrina, plays the part of the baton.

title: Another Chinese Provocation
description: Every week seems to bring a new Chinese challenge to President Clinton's stewardship of American foreign policy. There have been Chinese military threats against Taiwan, Chinese repression of dissidents and Chinese indifference to trade agreements with the United States. Now comes word from the Central Intelligence Agency that Beijing has secretly sold sensitive nuclear weapons technology to Pakistan.

title: Horse Racing;Triple Crown Contenders Out in Force
description: That was Cigar out there on the track at Gulfstream Park this morning, jogging one mile while waiting to be anointed Horse of the Year for 1995 on Friday and then shooting for his 13th straight victory in the Donn Handicap on Saturday. But he was surrounded by many of the stars of the future, the waves of 3-year-old horses training for their next steps on the road to the Kentucky Derby.

title: Corning Chief Plans to Retire In the Spring
description: As expected, James R. Houghton announced yesterday that he would retire in April after 13 years as chairman and chief executive of Corning Inc. His retirement means the end of, or possibly a long hiatus in, the control of the company by the Houghton family, which has spanned five generations.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Jack Simplot, the Idaho billionaire who is the largest shareholder in Micron Technology Inc., referred incorrectly in some editions to his action at the company's September 1994 board meeting. Mr. Simplot remained a director of Micron; he did not resign.

title: Beijing's Abuses Are Noticed on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Peace Plea Traps Yeltsin in Political Maze
description: Russia's war for Chechnya reached a dangerous new impasse today, after more than a thousand peaceful protesters in Grozny, the secessionist republic's capital, were surrounded by special forces army troops.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;COLGATE-PALMOLIVE CO. (CL,N)
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company said yesterday that earnings fell about 11 percent in the fourth quarter, partly because of the peso devaluation and recession in Mexico.

title: Art and Science United in Amber
description: ACCIDENTS of death provide the raw material from which scientists reconstruct the history of life. Some creatures die by a stream and are almost immediately buried in silt, their bones preserved as mineralized fossils to be discovered someday and recognized as the fabulous dinosaurs of yore or an early human ancestor. The fate of others can be more exquisitely beautiful and often more revealing. They die trapped in the resin of trees and spend an eternity entombed in amber.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Steelers Add a Coach
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers named the former Minnesota Vikings tight end MIKE MULARKEY as tight ends coach yesterday.

title: Patronage Workers Say Democrats Required Kickbacks
description: Eleven years ago, a group of Nassau County employees won a Federal class action suit forcing the county's Republican Party to return $1.3 million in illegal kickbacks to county workers.

title: COMPANY NEWS;JUPITER NATIONAL SHAREHOLDERS VOTE SET ON MERGER
description: Jupiter National Inc. said yesterday that its majority shareholder, Johnston Industries, planned to merge the company with one of Johnston's units. Jupiter National said Johnston was offering Jupiter's minority stockholders $33.97 for each share. Johnston offered $29.50 each last July, but the offer was later withdrawn. The merger is set to be submitted for approval by Jupiter's shareholders at a special meeting to be held on March 12. Under the terms of the agreement, the merger must be approved by a two-thirds vote and by holders of a majority of the shares voted at the meeting, excluding shares held by Johnston. Jupiter National makes cotton and polyester textiles. Its stock rose 75 cents, to $33.125.

title: On My Mind;Speak Up, Candidates
description: The 1996 Presidential candidates are keeping themselves so deliberately remote about important international problems threatening American interests that the campaign is becoming one itself.

title: Home Video
description: Before 'Usual Suspects'

title: Inside Art
description: The Hazen Estate

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;It Had to End This Way for Smith and Knicks
description: If only Charles Smith had converted one of those four layups against the Chicago Bulls three years ago during the closing seconds of Game 5.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Times Co. Income Fell 18.8%, To $33 Million, in 4th Quarter
description: percent in the fourth quarter, reflecting one-time charges and higher paper costs.

title: FILM REVIEW;Estranged And Fuming Outside Paris
description: Hate" ("La Haine") was shown as part of the 1995 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Caryn James's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 12. The film opens today at the Sony Village VII, Third Avenue and 11th Street, East Village.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN MOBILE SATELLITE CORP., Reston, Va., said it planned to raise about $130 million in a public offering of up to 4.6 million common shares.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFS;Just the (Prize) Ticket To Help a Campaign
description: Giving new meaning to the term "Presidential sweepstakes," Morry Taylor has come up with a new gimmick to try to ignite his flagging campaign. Recently, the campaign mailed questionnaires to 100,000 registered voters asking their views on a variety of issues like trade, term limits and returning more power to the states.

title: It's Bigger Than a Cardboard Box;7 Homeless Men Find Comfort in S.I. Borough Hall
description: They all had slept in public spaces before -- park benches, a cardboard box in Chinatown, the ferry terminal. But for the seven homeless men on the foldout cots in the marble hallways of Staten Island's Borough Hall Wednesday night, this public space was different: there were murals and mahogany, as well as the scent of old grandeur and maybe a bit of political opportunism.

title: Jobless Claims Drop by 21,000
description: The number of first-time claims for jobless benefits dropped by 21,000 last week, continuing to fall from heights reached in the aftermath of the January blizzard.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Deal Smith, and His Salary, to San Antonio
description: Charles Smith has found himself a more hospitable home and the Knicks freed themselves of his burdensome contract tonight in a four-player deal with the San Antonio Spurs that will bring J. R. Reid, Brad Lohaus and yet another first-round draft choice to New York.

title: Art in Review
