description: Robert Beck Spsan Inglett Gallery 100 Wooster Street, near Spring Street, SoHo Through Feb. 17

title: Art in Review
description: 'Expressions of Trust' 'Recent Gifts to the Permanent Collection' Museum of American Folk Art 2 Lincoln Square Through Feb. 25

title: In America;Politics of Meanness
description: You have to wonder about the Republicans. From what region of exceedingly bad karma did they recruit their latest crop of Presidential candidates and Congressional leaders?

title: Abroad at Home;A Forbes in Our Future?
description: A political analyst said the other day with a certain awe in his voice: "You know, Forbes really could be the nominee. And if he is willing to pop $40 million of his own money in the six weeks before Election Day, he could be President."

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Surfing Along to Keep Life Distant
description: REMOTE By David Shields 206 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The program for the concert that JULIUS RUDEL conducted at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening noted that Mr. Rudel has been wielding his baton for 150 years.

title: NYC;These Clothes Make the Man And the City
description: IF you're of the opinion that all is glitter and stardust in sending chiseled male models down a runway dressed in, oh, let's say a double-breasted lame jacket worn over charcoal wool stretch pants, you've got another think coming.

title: U.S. Investigates Fires at Black Churches
description: The Justice Department is conducting a civil rights investigation of fires at predominantly black churches in Alabama and Tennessee, Attorney General Janet Reno said today.

title: Home Ownership Rate Up
description: The rate of home ownership in the United States jumped last year to 65.1 percent of all households in the fourth quarter, the highest rate since 1981, the Department of Housing and Urban Development said today. The rise from 64.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 1994 was the sharpest in at least 30 years and represents a gain of more than 1.4 million additional homeowners, H.U.D. said. The home ownership rate grew last year in all regions of the country except the West. The gains included minorities, households under age 35 and households with less than median family income, H.U.D. said.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Casino Official Is Indicted
description: A casino official was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Newark on charges of laundering $124,000 by converting the money into chips at eight other casinos.

title: TV WEEKEND;Illicit Love in Outback (Again)
description: According to a legend invoked by the novelist Colleen McCullough, a thorn bird does not sing until it impales itself on the sharpest spine of a thorn tree. Ms. McCullough's 1977 novel "The Thorn Birds" was an international best-seller, and a 1983 television adaptation remains, after "Roots," the second highest-rated mini-series ever. Now, beginning Sunday on CBS and continuing on Tuesday, the Wolper Organization, in association with Warner Brothers Television, brings us "The Thorn Birds: The Missing Years." This bird does indeed impale itself, but without ever getting to sing a song.

title: Memories of Wartime Brutalities Revive Czech-German Animosity
description: In his book-lined study here, Ivan Klima, the Czech author, recalls the days a half-century ago when surviving Jewish families like his finally fled the concentration camps to find their land awash in killing and chaos. He was then 14 years old and, even in the final days of the Second World War, he said, so many Czechs were shot by their Nazi German occupiers "for nothing" that humanity seemed lost.

title: For Children
description: The Annual Herman's Winter Festival North Meadow, Central Park East 97th Street and West 97th Street entrances (212) 822-4587 Ages 4 and up Tomorrow

title: Art in Review
description: Alfred Jensen Max Protetch 560 Broadway, at Prince Street SoHo Through Feb. 17

title: In the War on Drugs, No Honorable Surrender Is Possible
description: To the Editor:

title: In English, Cup Is ABC's
description: ABC Sports reaffirmed its commitment to soccer yesterday by obtaining the English-language broadcast rights in the United States for the 1998 World Cup in France.

title: Atlanta Grand Jury Clears 2 Officers in Killing of Unarmed Man
description: In a case that Mayor Bill Campbell said had created a "crisis of confidence" in the city police, a grand jury here today cleared two plainclothes officers in the shooting death of an unarmed 23-year-old man who they mistakenly believed was involved in a robbery two months ago.

title: Respect the Dying's Wishes Before Our Own
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Jeffrey 1995. Orion. $97.51. 92 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: Citing Cost, Clinton Will Not Expand B-2 Fleet
description: President Clinton has decided against expanding the fleet of B-2 bombers because the planes are too expensive, the White House announced today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CORPORATE EXPRESS TO BUY A SUPPLIES DISTRIBUTOR
description: Corporate Express Inc. agreed yesterday to buy computer supplies distributor Richard Young Journal Inc. for $81.8 million worth of stock. Corporate Express said it would pay for Richard Young Journal with 3 million shares of its stock, which closed at $27.25 on Wednesday. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Corporate Express rose 62.5 cents, to $27.875. Corporate Express, a leading supplier of office products and services based in Broomfield, Colo., said Richard Young Journal generated revenue of $136 million in the year ended Sept. 30, 1995, through its eight distribution centers nationwide.

title: PUBLIC EMPLOYEES VOTE 5-YEAR DEAL IN NEW YORK CITY
description: New York City's largest municipal employees' union announced yesterday that its 120,000 members had approved a five-year contract with the city that promises job security and bolsters Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's efforts to maintain labor peace as he reduces the size of city government.

title: Teachers End Walkout
description: Teachers here in California's second-biggest school district returned to work today after negotiators reached a tentative agreement to end a weeklong strike.

title: Baboon Cells Fail to Thrive, But AIDS Patient Improves
description: Preliminary tests show that few, if any, baboon bone marrow cells have grown and functioned after being transplanted into a 38-year-old man with severe AIDS, his doctors said yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Mashburn May Be Out For Rest of the Season
description: JAMAL MASHBURN, out with an injured left knee since Dec. 12, will probably miss the rest of the season for the Dallas Mavericks after deciding yesterday to have surgery next week.

title: Where Hearts Once Flowered
description: OH, no," said my husband, picking up the room-service menu at the Gramercy Park Hotel. "Look at this."

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Help Companies That Treat Workers Well, Kennedy Says
description: Attacking corporate behavior in what he called the nation's "quiet depression," Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that the Government should use tax breaks and penalties to encourage companies to look out for their workers.

title: Clause to Curb Protests Splits Archdiocese And Teachers
description: Contract talks between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and several hundred high school teachers have taken a contentious turn with the archdiocese's insistence that the teachers accept new language on the "religious mission" of the church or face dismissal.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: A Grand Night for Singing

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;A Bill on School Uniforms
description: President Clinton likes the idea of uniforms for public school students and so does the State Assembly.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PETER YARROW of the Peter, Paul and Mary trio, who spent 11 hours on a train during the Blizzard of '96 last month, intends to recreate the experience -- or at least the more pleasant parts of it -- on Monday.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Jewish Group Rejects Swiss Bank Survey
description: Jewish leaders pressed today for a United States inquiry into Swiss banks holding the unclaimed accounts of Holocaust victims, saying the banks may have more than the $32 million they report.

title: Beijing's Abuses Are Noticed on Campus;No U.S. Project Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Anonymous' Gets $1 Million In a Film Deal
description: Anonymous," the mysterious author who has sprung onto best-seller lists and set Washington's gossip circles abuzz with the book "Primary Colors," can now add film credits to his or her name. Whatever it is.

title: Anti-Nazi Martyr Needs No Legal Redress
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;HASBRO INC. (HAS,A)
description: Hasbro Inc. said fourth-quarter earnings rose 12 percent, beating estimates on Wall Street.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BARNEYS REACHES FINANCING AGREEMENT WITH ISETAN
description: Barney's Inc. reached an agreement with the Isetan Company, its estranged Japanese ally, that will allow the luxury retailer to draw on as much as $100 million in financing. Isetan agreed to withdraw its objection to the debtor-in-possession financing as part of a settlement under which the Japanese company will receive $3.3 million from Barneys through April 19. Isetan had filed papers in bankruptcy court aiming to force Barneys to pay about $3 million in rent that Isetan said it was owed on three Barneys department stores in New York, Chicago and Beverly Hills, California. Judge James L. Garrity Jr. of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan approved the settlement at a hearing yesterday.

title: 25 and Under
description: Brazilian Niche

title: Art in Review
description: Tim Maul Betsy Senior Gallery 375 West Broadway (near Broome Street), SoHo Through March 16

title: ARCHITECTURE REVIEW;A Modernist Steps Out Of the Shadows
description: Talent alone can't explain the inequality of artistic achievement. Timing, luck and even ruthlessness have to be taken into account. That's the subtext of "Lilly Reich: Designer and Architect," a haunting new show at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Steelers Are Upset That Jets Might Want O'Donnell
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers must know something that no one else does: the player the Jets want as their next quarterback.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LITTON INDUSTRIES BUYS SPERRY MARINE
description: Litton Industries Inc. will purchase Sperry Marine Inc., a maker of navigation and guidance systems, for about $160 million, the companies said yesterday. Litton, which makes military electronics systems as well as destroyers for the Navy, will give Sperry's owner, the investment partnership J. F. Lehman & Company, two million shares of common stock and will assume Sperry's $52 million debt. Additionally, it will purchase the company's preferred stock, worth about $7 million. Sperry is based in Charlottesville, Va., and its operations will remain in Virginia. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of Litton closed unchanged at $49.25 before the deal was announced. Sperry's 1995 sales totaled $145 million. Litton's sales last year were $3.32 million.

title: BASKETBALL;Dayton Center Dies After Collapsing at Home
description: Dayton center Chris Daniels, one of college basketball's top field-goal shooters, died today shortly after being taken to a hospital. Daniels, 22, was pronounced dead at 5:31 A.M. at Miami Valley Hospital, said a hospital spokeswoman, Pam Hoskins.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Stock prices were lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 183.48 points, or 0.87 percent, at 20,934.82. On Thursday, the Nikkei closed at 21,118.30, above the psychologically important level of 21,000 for the first time in 19 months.

title: In Deal Ending Takeover Effort, Chrysler to Sell Non-Auto Lines
description: The Chrysler Corporation settled its 15-month battle today with Kirk Kerkorian, the Las Vegas billionaire who had been unhappy with the auto maker's stock price and was campaigning for the company to give shareholders some of the billions of dollars it had in reserve. Mr. Kerkorian lost the fight over the funds, but won a Chrysler board seat for his representative.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Chinese efforts to regulate access to the Internet misidentified the director of the Center for Modern China in Princeton, N.J. It is Chen Yizi, not Liu Binyan.

title: BOXING;De La Hoya Longs for Macho-Man Image
description: Sometimes, the game is about more than money. Corny, maybe, but often it's about love.

title: Communications Bill Signed, And the Battles Begin Anew
description: President Clinton today signed a sweeping bill to overhaul the telecommunications industry, starting a new round of warfare between the giant media and communications companies even before the ink was dry.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PRIME HOSPITALITY TO BUY 18 HOTELS FOR $64 MILLION
description: The Prime Hospitality Corporation agreed yesterday to buy 18 hotels for $64 million in cash. Prime Hospitality said the hotels are 16 Wellesley Inns, a Holiday Inn Express, which is a unit if Bass P.L.C. and a Days Inn, which is a unit of Hospitality Franchise Systems Inc. The hotels are located in Florida, New York, New Jersey, Virginia, Maryland and Pennsylvania. The acquisition will give Prime ownership of all 30 Wellesley Inns.

title: ART REVIEW;Fine Art and Outsiders: Attacking the Barriers
description: There's something to be said for an exhibition that bites off more than it can possibly chew, even when it grabs from as many different plates as "A Labor of Love," the latest exegesis in museological chaos from the New Museum of Contemporary Art.

title: John Loudon, 90, Ex-Head Of Royal Dutch/Shell Group
description: John H. Loudon, who headed the Royal Dutch/Shell Group when it was the world's second largest oil company and guided it through times of turmoil in the Middle East, died on Saturday. He was 90.

title: Whatever Happened to Venezuela's Middle Class?
description: The snapshot that emerged from Luis Sandoval's pocket showed the 34-year-old former administrator for a manufacturer of heavy machinery standing in a driveway by his sparkling white Chevrolet Impala, his wife and daughter by his side.

title: In or Out of Presidency, Aristide Is Still the Issue
description: Rene Preval had not even been sworn in as Haiti's President before posters began appearing, urging his charismatic predecessor, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to return to office as soon as the Constitution permits. "Au revoir, President Titid," the banners said, using Mr. Aristide's nickname. "We'll meet again in 2001."

title: GOLF;Weather Is Perfect; The Scores Even Better
description: What happens when you take the best field of golfers assembled on the West Coast so far this year, put it on two perfectly conditioned golf courses and mix in some of that sublime Southern California weather -- you know, 74 degrees, gentle breeze?

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Stiffer Bail Is Sought
description: Federal prosecutors are not happy with the behavior of Somerset County's former prosecutor, who has been free on bail since his indictment last fall on charges including blackmail and tax evasion. The prosecutors said Nicholas Bissell should come up with an extra $50,000 cash bail on top of the unsecured $200,000 bond he has already posted.

title: A New Round of Sparring Over a Whitewater Witness
description: Citing newly discovered notes from a 1994 White House meeting, Republicans on the Senate Whitewater panel said today that senior Clinton aides tried to influence the testimony of a former Arkansas regulator who is a crucial witness in the Whitewater investigations.

title: Livery Cab Driver Is Shot
description: A livery cab driver was found dead in his vehicle in southern Brooklyn last night, one day after another driver was found slumped inside his car several blocks away, the police said.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Dangerous Minds 1995. Hollywood. $103.92. 99 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: Art in Review
description: Jacques-Henri Lartigue James Danziger Gallery 130 Prince Street, SoHo Through Feb. 24

title: Insurance Pays Clinton Lawyers
description: Nearly $900,000 of President Clinton's legal bills in a sexual harassment lawsuit have been paid from two insurance policies he bought in Arkansas and then forgot, White House aides said today.

title: Retail Chain Sales Show Modest Gain
description: Sales at the nation's biggest retail chains rose tepidly in January, according to figures released yesterday, but analysts said the horrible winter in the Northeast and Midwest held down the numbers.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Smoking, Swaggering All-Around Bad Guy
description: In "Broken Arrow," the Hong Kong-born directing dynamo John Woo sets a tourist trap for his audience -- twice. It works this way: In the desert landscape where the film's he-men battle over stolen nuclear warheads, a seemingly harmless stranger appears. Is he just a tourist? Or is he more dangerous than he looks? Count on this much: It won't take long to find out. Mr. Woo has a way of settling any note of ambiguity with the fast, furious bravado that turns his superkinetic action films into fireball ballet.

title: Man Kills Ex-Officer and Drops Dead, Police Say
description: A former New York City police officer was shot to death yesterday in his Brooklyn apartment by the father of a former colleague he had recently been arrested for stalking, the police said.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Honoring a Beloved Mother
description: When Kazuo Ohno presents a solo program, he makes every movement peem a memory, or even a dream, of dancing. He combines immediacy with retrospection so that past and present intersect onstage. Mr. Ohno appeared to be summoning up a ghost in "My Mother (Watashi no Okasan)," the hourlong work he offered on Tuesday night at the Japan Society.

title: School Custodians Accept New Contract
description: School custodial helpers and a private company that provides custodial services at eight Brooklyn schools reached an agreement yesterday on a new labor contract, a day after a walkout that left 10,000 students and their teachers without heat for several hours.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Noteworthy new restaurants usually send out press releases to announce that they are open. Even when they don't, the word generally gets around. So I was surprised to walk down 38th Street a couple of weeks ago and discover Cinque Terre, a restaurant I had heard nothing about.

title: POLITICS: POLITICAL MEMO;Lesson in Gramm: Money on Its Own Can't Buy Success
description: Senator Phil Gramm, who liked to boast that his ticket to the Republican Presidential nomination was assembling the best-financed and best-organized campaign, today found his aides fending off questions about where the next dollars would come from.

title: FILM REVIEW;Why Must the Show Go On? That Is the Question!
description: Joe Harper (Michael Maloney), the mastermind behind one of the most precarious shoestring productions of Shakespeare you could possibly imagine, is not the sort of director a professional actor would be inclined to entrust with his soul. A wild-eyed, desperately unemployed 33-year-old English actor, Joe describes his life as one long nervous breakdown that began "when I was 7 months and had just begun to get a grip."

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an obituary of a Scottish photographer misspelled his given name. He was Brodrick Haldane, not Rodrick.

title: Romance, Past and Present
description: Wednesday is Valentine's Day. Here is a sampling of events this weekend and on Wednesday in New York City in celebration of the holiday:

title: Barnett Banks To Merge Units
description: Barnett Banks Inc. is planning to streamline its operations, merging its 32 banking units into five.

title: POLITICS: THE CAUCUSES;Issues New, Iowa Returns to Spotlight
description: After an eight-year hiatus, Iowa has returned to center stage in the country's Presidential contest, and in the intervening years, prosperity and confidence have swept across the state like a prairie wind.

title: Justice Department Approves L'Oreal Bid for Maybelline
description: L'Oreal S.A., the French cosmetics giant, received approval yesterday from the Justice Department for its acquisition of Maybelline Inc., clearing the way for the $758 million buyout.

title: Lidiya Chukovskaya, Champion of Dissidents And Chronicler of StalinistAbuses, Dies at 88
description: Lidiya Chukovskaya, the Russian writer who risked her life to record the horrors of Stalinism and speak out against the persecutions of dissidents in the Soviet Union, died on Wednesday at her home in Moscow. She was 88.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Walk on the Wild Side, Taken Many Miles Farther
description: England's rotting industrial heartland as pictured in Paul Anderson's film "S'opping" looks like a theatrically forbidding circle of hell. Every trash can contains a blazing fire, and hissing clouds of steam rise from the streets like avenging poisons from a terminally polluted landscape. The film's opening scene is a long aerial shot of mile upon mile of urban wasteland crowned by a smoke-belching nuclear power plant.

title: Restaurants
description: My first paying job as a cook was making desserts for a restaurant called Food. It was on Prince Street, but the plaster-spattered artists who came in tended to talk more about pipe wrenches than problems with their galleries. They'd sit drinking coffee while people walked past the windows triumphantly carrying industrial pallets. The wood was good and free, a bonanza for those of us who were converting raw space into livable lofts. Had someone come in and announced that SoHo was destined for chic, the entire dining room would have erupted in laughter.

title: Levi Strauss Makes Buyback Bid Valuing Company at $14 Billion
description: After several months of planning and tense negotiations, Levi Strauss Associates Inc., the world's largest apparel manufacturer, has offered $265 a share to buy back the shares owned by employees and some members of the family that controls the company.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;In courting black consumers, some marketers don't have to check their calendars  anymore.
description: CONSUMERS could be excused for thinking the Madison Avenue calendar includes an annual winter festival of black advertising that begins in mid-January with earnest advertisements from mainstream marketers "saluting the legacy" of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. -- timed for the holiday in his honor -- and continues through February with campaigns "celebrating Black History Month."

title: OLYMPICS;Taiwan Officials Not Invited
description: Atlanta Olympic officials said today that members of the Taiwanese Government will not be invited to this summer's Olympic Games, a prospect that had raised the possibility of a boycott by China.

title: Respect the Dying's Wishes Before Our Own
description: To the Editor:

title: HOCKEY;Fish Isn't Only Thing Hurled At Garden
description: It was a little bit wet and wild last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Isabel Kambert, 103, Opera Singer and Creator of Sweater Designs
description: Isabel Kambert, an opera singer who escaped Nazi Germany with liverwurst sandwiches stuffed with folded 10,000-mark notes, and who later in New York became known as Mme. Isabel after creating the fashion for decorated cashmere sweaters, died on Wednesday at the home of a niece, Eva Ballantine, in Kingston, N.Y.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Fiscal Monitor for Camden
description: In a city that needs all the help it can get, an inept city government awash in political patronage wastes millions of dollars every year, a harsh new state audit says.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Coffee Surges as Brazil Receives Top Price for Decades-Old Beans
description: Coffee prices surged yesterday on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York after auctions of Government stockpiles in Brazil drew high prices, showing an internal shortage in the world's largest coffee producing country.

title: Apple Vows To Remain Independent
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it intended to remain an independent company under its new chairman, and it blamed recent "speculation" about a potential merger for making the company's dire financial outlook even bleaker.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Telecom Profit
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said yesterday that its third-quarter pretax profit rose 26 percent, mainly because it spent less on staff cuts. Pretax profits rose to L829 million, or $1.3 billion, in the period ended Dec. 31, from L660 million a year earlier. Without the decline in staff-reduction costs, the company said, its operating profit would have been "broadly at the same level" as a year ago. Lower prices for phone calls and the costs of signing up new mobile phone customers ate into earnings. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;New Tajikistan Premier Vows Economic Reform
description: A carpet factory manager became Prime Minister of Tajikistan today and promised to step up the pace of economic reforms in the impoverished Central Asian country.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * West Hollywood Convention and Visitors Bureau to Lois, Colby/Los Angeles, a unit of Lois/USA, to handle its advertising, which had been inactive. The billings were not disclosed. * Harrah's Entertainment, Memphis, to Targetbase Marketing, Irving, Tex., a unit of the M/A/R/C Group, as the first agency to handle direct marketing for the casino gambling company. The billings were not disclosed. * IVF America, White Plains, to Christopher Thomas Associates, Garden City, L.I., to handle its direct consumer advertising account, previously handled in-house. The billings were not disclosed.

title: ART REVIEW;Abstraction, Without the Mess
description: THE subtitle of the big survey of abstract art opening today at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is "Total Risk, Freedom, Discipline." Is it me, or is there a kinky ring to the phrase? Or maybe it's just that the title (it comes from a remark by the artist Eva Hesse) only seems risque compared with the exhibition, which is so unkinky: a by-the-book distillation of this giant, disorderly, thrilling subject.

title: Indictment in Bomb Case
description: A third Nevada man has been indicted in connection with the attempted bombing of Internal Revenue Service offices here in December.

title: Mortgage Rate Unchanged
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.02 percent this week, unchanged from a week earlier, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.33 percent, down from 5.37 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages, a popular option for those refinancing mortgages, averaged 6.51 percent this week, down from 6.52 percent a week earlier.

title: BASKETBALL;Ewing Wants Oakley And Starks To Stay
description: As the Knicks parted with Charles Smith today and considered unloading other high-salaried players, their franchise player was contemplating a future without two other players whom he deems as key components to the club.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFS;Without Front-Runner, A TV Forum Collapses
description: A forum of Republican Presidential candidates, set for Friday night on public television, collapsed today when Senator Bob Dole declined to participate and the remaining contenders pulled out. There now appears no chance that the candidates will meet in a forum before the caucuses on Monday.

title: BASEBALL;Union Makes an Offer on Players' Taxes
description: Baseball's players association has proposed taxing all players' salaries in the first three years of a six-year agreement, but the plan would delay imposing a luxury tax on payrolls until the fourth year.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Hackers 1995. MGM/UA. $97.51. Laser disk, $34.98. 104 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.

title: About Real Estate;Apartments Built to Rent Rise on River At Jersey City
description: Pilings are being driven deep into a slice of Jersey City's waterfront for the foundation of Riverside Tower, the first new residential construction at the huge Newport complex in six years.

title: The States Won't Be Cruel
description: In Washington, this has been a season of stubbornness and sulks and partisan slights. But this week the nation's governors proved that there is a political force more powerful than disagreement: consensus.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BASEBALL;Winfield Bows Out With Words of Warning for Game
description: Dave Winfield, whose career links the eras of Henry Aaron and Ken Griffey Jr., began his countdown to the Hall of Fame yesterday by warning baseball that it has to return to the game that once readily commanded the attention of budding athletes and fans.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about negotiations to let Iraq resume limited oil sales misstated the year of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. It was 1990, not 1989.

title: Agencies Are Told to Ready $500 Million More in Cuts
description: New York City's budget director sent a directive to city agencies yesterday ordering all of them to propose cuts to their budgets that together will total $500 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about coming telephone sales of tickets to Olympic events in Atlanta misstated a rule for using new Visa cards to buy tickets. A Visa spokesman said that since new cardholders must be told of their terms and conditions in writing, at least 24 hours would pass before they could order by telephone.

title: Market Place;There is no clear victor in the Chrysler-Kerkorian battle, which was an odd affair from the start.
description: KIRK KERKORIAN is going to take in a lot of money as a result of his battle with Chrysler management, which ended in a settlement yesterday. But Chrysler has prevailed on the issue it painted as the most important: keeping adequate cash on hand in case a recession arrives.

title: COMPANY NEWS;I.B.M. CUTS PRICES ON SOME PENTIUM-BASED MODELS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation cut prices for its portable and PC300 commercial computers by as much as 30 percent, reflecting lower prices for the Intel Corporation's Pentium chips inside. Microprocessors control most functions in computers. I.B.M. said the suggested United States price of its top commercial desktop machine, featuring a 166 megahertz Pentium chip and a 1.2 gigabyte hard disk, will drop 12 percent to $3,019. A model with a 133 megahertz chip sell for $2,499, about 17 percent below the old price. I.B.M. cut the price of a 75-megahertz model to $1,339.

title: Chang No. 1 In Davis Cup
description: The United States Davis Cup team has reconvened for the weekend without Andre Agassi, who held the No. 1 spot that has been bequeathed to Michael Chang.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ROCKWELL PLANS SEMICONDUCTOR WAFER PLANT EXPANSION
description: The Rockwell International Corporation announced yesterday that it planned a $1.2 billion expansion of its Colorado semiconductor wafer fabrication plant. Phase I of the new plant is expected to create 600 jobs by December 1997. Rockwell's Phase I investment is about $675 million; the Phase II investment is expected to be greater than $500 million. Rockwell is the world's No. 1 supplier of facsimile modems, with about 80 percent of the global market, and personal computer data modems, with a market share of about 65 percent.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Unemployment At High in January
description: German unemployment rose to a record in January, the Federal Labor Office said yesterday. It attributed the rise to worsening economic conditions and a traditional winter slowdown. Seasonally adjusted unemployment rose 59,000, to 3.851 million -- its sixth rise in a row -- and sent the adjusted jobless rate to 10 percent for the first time in the Federal Republic's history. The unadjusted jobless total surged to 4.159 million, or 10.8 percent -- a rise of 368,000 from December.

title: The Spoken Word
description: "LIVING THE DREAM: 2 MILLION STRONG!" Riant Theater, 161 Hudson Street, West Village. A tribute to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and other African-American leaders, incorporating poetry, dance and song; conceived and directed by Van Dirk Fisher. Weekends through Feb. 25. Fridays and Saturdays at 8 P.M. and Sundays at 3 P.M. Tickets: $12. Reservations: (212) 925-8353.

title: ART REVIEW;Taking Spiritual Flight in the Material
description: In Japan, spring is the time for pilgrimage, and Buddhist temples on the ancient holy routes come in all shapes and sizes, from cavernous urban halls to small country shrines perched over the sea. Whether one's excursion is lengthy or brief, its purpose devotion or leisure, doesn't matter much. Everybody greets the adventure with joy.

title: Arm Surgery for Whitman
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said today that she would undergo surgery on her right shoulder next week to repair a diseased rotator cuff that has plagued her for more than a year.

title: Art in Review
description: Gary Lang 'Hague Project' Crosby Street Project 113 Crosby Street, near Prince Street, SoHo Through March 2

title: Mexican Police Are Accused of Torture
description: The police tortured and beat suspected leaders of an Indian rebellion last year, and judges accepted the confessions although they knew they were coerced, a human-rights group asserted today.

title: POLITICS: IN THE PACK;A Gleeful Buchanan Takes Message to Iowa
description: Today, at least to her husband, Shelley Buchanan of Washington was the "Cajun Queen, the Belle of the Bayou."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Disney Clears F.C.C. Review Of Its Merger
description: The Walt Disney Company's $19 billion acquisition of Capital Cities/ABC Inc. cleared its final regulatory obstacle today, with conditions.

title: Subterranean Chain of Events Broke 2 Water Mains
description: Two water main breaks that left 750,000 residents of northeastern New Jersey with little or no water may have stemmed from a chain of events -- a leaky pipe, repairs, underground shifts, water shutoffs and surging pressures -- that began a month ago and reached a crisis just before the geysers erupted in the early morning darkness Wednesday, an engineer investigating the matter said yesterday.

title: Slow Pace Is Expected For Israel And Syria
description: Senior American officials say they are gloomy about the prospect of rapid progress in the Syrian-Israeli peace talks, which are to resume in Maryland for a third round on Feb. 26.

title: In Missouri, Good Times or Bad?;Working but Not Spending in a Microcosm of the Nation
description: Churning out goods from pickup trucks to refrigerator magnets, factories across this Midwestern heartland are hiring so many workers that labor shortages are developing in some areas.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Probe Into Naval Base Theft
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation and Navy investigators are looking into whether civilians are stealing military goods from a naval base in Monmouth County, the F.B.I. said yesterday. The A.P. quoted an F.B.I. spokesman as saying the investigation had not uncovered evidence of live ammunition or weapons being stolen from the Earle Naval Weapons Station. The spokesman declined to discuss what material was taken.

title: People Over 50 Urged to Get A Cancer Test
description: Men and women over the age of 50 should have regular screening for colorectal cancer, the second leading cause of cancer-related deaths, Federal health officials said today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Giants Sign a Cepeda
description: The San Francisco Giants have reached minor league contract agreements with 35-year-old MEL HALL and MALCOLM CEPEDA, the 23-year-old son of the former Giants star ORLANDO CEPEDA.

title: FILM BOX;After a Hollywood Woman of Affairs
description: Heidi Fleiss's business was no General Motors, but maybe she wielded enough power in Hollywood to deserve a documentary that recalls "Roger and Me." So Nick Broomfield's "Heidi Fleiss: Hollywood Madam" is a lively, bawdy, bizarrely fascinating first-person chronicle of Mr. Broomfield's efforts to track her down.

title: BASKETBALL;Barkley Reaches Milestone Vs. Nets
description: The Nets set out on this trip hoping to get back into the Eastern Conference playoff race, but instead they have become the National Basketball Association's version of Zelig, winding up in the background of some of this month's most memorable events.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;I.M.F. Approves $1 Billion for Russia
description: The International Monetary Fund has approved a $1.05 billion loan for Russia, the last installment of a $6.3 billion line of credit approved by the agency last April.

title: In the War on Drugs, No Honorable Surrender Is Possible
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Chrysler and Kerkorian Settle Their Differences Chrysler and Kirk Kerkorian settled their 15-month battle. The billionaire investor had been unhappy with the auto maker's stock price and pressed the company to give shareholders some of the billions of dollars it had in reserve. Mr. Kerkorian lost the fight over the money but won a seat on the Chrysler board for a representative. Also, he agreed to go along with the majority of shareholders in any votes for the five years, and said he would not try to take control.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Media Merger Planned By British Companies
description: MAI Group P.L.C. and United News and Media P.L.C. said yesterday that they would merge, creating a $4.4 billion British media company. MAI's shareholders are to be offered 64 United Media shares for each 100 ordinary shares held. United News will own 50.7 percent of the unnamed new company.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Good Publicity, as It Turns Out, Can Hurt
description: Good publicity can infuriate your colleagues, as Stephen M. Waters, a Morgan Stanley managing director who resigned this week, found out.

title: In New Figures, Productivity Growth Slows
description: In the first presentation of its recalculated productivity numbers, the Labor Department reported yesterday that American industry's gains in efficiency have been less in the 1990's than the corporate re-engineering, downsizings and layoffs have seemed to suggest.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Absolut Supporting Magazine Feature
description: The production costs for an editorial feature in the coming issue of New York magazine, in an unusual arrangement, are being paid for by the marketer of Absolut vodka.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Sony Profit Up in Quarter; Forecast for Year Lowered
description: The Sony Corporation said today that group pretax profit rose 25 percent in its fiscal third quarter, aided by the popularity of the company's video-game machine and movies, but it lowered its earnings forecast for the full fiscal year because of slowing demand for computer equipment and recorded music in the United States.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Withdrawing' Ronald Feldman Fine Arts 31 Mercer Street, at Grand Street SoHo Through Feb. 17

title: U.S. Suit Says Hotels Ignored Disability Law
description: The Justice Department sued the Days Inn hotel chain today, charging that at least five of its hotels failed to accommodate disabled travelers as required under a 1990 law.

title: No Headline
description: Every computer has a fixed set of priorities. The safety of the king, active pieces, open diagonals and so forth. We humans don't have in our head a fixed list; we feel the most important things to evaluate."

title: Late Advance Drives Dow Above 5,500
description: Stocks continued to rise yesterday, pushing stock indexes to record highs for the fourth consecutive session, even as the market confounded professional investors who have been baffled by its recent gains.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Fokker Is Facing Cutoff Of Government Aid
description: Fokker N.V., the Dutch jet maker now under court protection from creditors, came under more pressure to find a corporate partner when the Dutch Government said yesterday that it would not make another emergency loan to the company. The current emergency credit expires the end of this month.

title: Matamoros Journal;Canaries Sing in Mexico, but Uncle Juan Will Not
description: The sun is blazing on the street outside, but it is dark inside the Piedras Negras Restaurant, and it takes visitors a moment before they can clearly see the two bodyguards, wearing cowboy boots and beepers, slouched in chairs facing the entrance.

title: TV WEEKEND;Sex, Beauty, Home and Travel Tips on Bugs
description: No, "Alien Empire" is not another sci-fi show about outer-spaceniks. The creatures on display in these three buzzing hours are real, although some seem improbable, and the scien'e has nothing fictional about it.

title: INSIDE
description: No Gain From Baboon Cells

title: COMPANY NEWS;CIGNA SAYS PENNSYLVANIA APPROVES RESTRUCTURING PLAN
description: The Cigna Corporation said yesterday that the Pennsylvania Department of Insurance had approved a plan to restructure the insurance company's domestic property and casualty business. Approval is still pending in California, Connecticut, Illinois, Indiana, New Jersey, Ohio and Texas. The restructuring splits Cigna's property-casualty business into one company for the continuing profitable business and a separate company for the unprofitable, discontinued business. Cigna would provide the runoff operation $500 million in new capital and financial support, after a $1.2 billion pretax increase in the company's net reserves in the third quarter. Shares of Cigna rose $2.625 yesterday to close at $120.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;French Cut Key Rate
description: The Bank of France cut its intervention rate yesterday to 3.90 percent from 4.05 percent, and economists said more rate cuts looked certain. The independent central bank left unchanged at 5.60 percent the 5-to-10-day lending rate, which sets the ceiling for money market operations. The bank last cut official rates Feb. 1, when it lowered the intervention rate, the floor for money market operations, to 4.05 percent from 4.20 percent. The Government is counting on lower interest rates to help revive flagging economic growth. (Reuters)

title: Afghanistan to the Fore
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET REVIEW;Trying Out a Tricky Role
description: Theme and Variations" has had an odd history, and the anomalies of the ballet could be plainly seen in a first-rate role debut by Miranda Weese, the New York City Ballet's exquisite wunderkind, on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Chairman and Vice Chairman Named to Run SUNY's Board
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday that he was appointing a new chairman and vice chairman of the State University of New York Board of Trustees, further consolidating his control over the governing board for the 64-campus system.

title: Medicaid Plans East Fiscal Ills For New York
description: After a long year of budget debates in Washington, the Medicaid and welfare proposals endorsed this week by the nation's governors would represent by far the best fiscal deal yet for New York State's own fragile financial plan.

title: FILM REVIEW;Of Beauty, in the Ideal And Only Skin Deep
description: One of the characters in Ted Demme's "Beautiful Girls" has made his room a shrine to fashion models, plastering their pictures all over his walls. Sure, he knows these images are a little rosy and dishonest, but they make him feel good anyway.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Therapy Helps a Protective Mother Cope
description: Colene C. described her childhood in Guyana as a strict one, in which parents made the rules and children silently obeyed them. That is the way it was for Ms. C. and her five siblings, and that is the way it would be for her own son, Noel, she decided.

title: Greek Premier Already in Hot Water
description: No sooner did Greek and Turkish warships pull back from last week's showdown over a barren islet in the Aegean Sea than the talk here turned from war to treason -- the most serious of many charges leveled against Greece's new Prime Minister for his handling of the crisis.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNILEVER TO REVAMP, CLOSING A U.S. PLANT
description: Unilever N.V. said yesterday that it would restructure its European foods businesses and close its Lever Brothers powder laundry detergent operation in St. Louis, taking charges in the fourth quarter of $344 million. In a statement late yesterday, Unilever declined to provide details of the restructuring. The British-Dutch consumer products company said its Lever Brothers American subsidiary would transfer production of Surf, All and Rinso powder detergent from St. Louis to its Cartersville, Ga., plant by the end of the year. It will continue to make dishwashing liquids and fabric softeners in St. Louis. About half of the 450 employees at the St. Louis plant "could be affected" by the closing, the plant's manager, Jim Hartman, said. He would not be more specific. A Unilever spokesman, John Gould, said the company would have no further comment on the revamping until the company released its fourth-quarter results on Feb. 20.

title: Executive Changes
description: CREDIT SUISSE , Zurich, named Robert C. O'Brien chief executive of Credit Suisse North America, New York.

title: Lawyer for Warhol Estate Must Repay $1.35 Million
description: The last shoe dropped yesterday-- perhaps -- in the nasty battle over fees owed to the lawyer Edward W. Hayes by the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts. The Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court decided that Mr. Hayes was entitled to only $3.5 million for his work as the lawyer for the estate of Andy Warhol.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Beyond Rangoon 1995. Columbia Tri-Star. $97.51. Laser disk, $39.95. 99 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about the Senate's passage of farm legislation misidentified the affiliation of Randy Jones, one lobbyist shown. He represents the National Council of Farmer Cooperatives, not the National Farmers Cooperative Counsel.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;N.F.L. Maps Out Cleveland-to-Baltimore Route
description: Art Modell's team no more the Cleveland Browns -- will run to daylight in Baltimore next season while Cleveland will get a replacement National Football League franchise by 1999 that will be called the Browns, according to an agreement reached tonight between the league and the city of Cleveland.

title: Texas Caters to a Demand Around U.S. for Jail Cells
description: After tripling the size of its prison system in five years and clearing out a huge backlog of inmates it had held in county jails, Texas has embarked upon an improbable correctional venture: It has become the nation's leading importer of prisoners from other states.

title: Respect the Dying's Wishes Before Our Own
description: To the Editor:

title: A Town's Gun Permits Bring Cash and Controversy
description: Eugene Byrd, the police chief of this town of 833 people in the Sacramento River Delta, has issued 775 permits to carry concealed weapons over the last several years, generating a sizable part of the town's budget and a giant controversy.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Government Securities Prices Rise
description: Prices of government securities rose yesterday following a bond auction that traders described as fairly successful.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Wilkins Gets Raise
description: The Houston Astros learned yesterday that they failed in their effort to cut RICK WILKINS's salary in arbitration.

title: Navy to Hunt 'Black Box' From German Tourists' Plane Crash
description: The Navy said here today that it had shipped equipment to the Dominican Republic to help find the flight data recorder of the Boeing 757 that crashed offshore on Tuesday night, killing all 189 people on board.

title: Man Questioned In Fatal Blaze, Investigators Say
description: Investigators were questioning a suspect last night in connection with the fire that killed a firefighter in a Brooklyn building identified by officials as a "chop shop" for stolen cars, a police spokesman said.

title: Pass the Tissues: Collins Is Accused of Having No Shame
description: Alexis was ambushed.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HILLS STORES NAMES A NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The Hills Stores Company yesterday named Gregory K. Raven president and chief executive to replace E. Jackson Smailes, who resigned. Mr. Raven, who is 46, was formerly chief financial officer of the Revco D.S. drugstore chain. The departure by Mr. Smailes comes seven months after he replaced Michael Bozic, who resigned after Dickstein Partners, an investment company, won control of the Hills board in a takeover battle. Robert J. Stevenish resigned as the company's chief operating officer in September. The retailer also said it might look to acquire another regional discounter to lift its earnings and stock price. Mark Dickstein stepped down as chairman yesterday. But he will continue to serve on the board.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Hershiser to Play in '96
description: The Cleveland Indians said OREL HERSHISER will report for spring training next month, even though he auditioned for an analyst job on network television. "Orel wants to play for at least two more years," said General Manager JOHN HART. "He was apologetic. He said he definitely wants to keep pitching."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Some Agency Moves In Hispanic Market
description: There were two developments yesterday involving agencies that specialize in advertising aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFS;Dole on Foreign Policy: Head 'Screwed on Right'
description: Making the bottom-line case for his Presidential candidacy, Senator Bob Dole told a packed Rotary Club luncheon today, "I think my head's screwed on right."

title: Sports of The Times;Winfield Had to Do It In New York
description: DAVE WINFIELD is so smooth that he announced his retirement yesterday without ever mentioning the absentee owner. Not by name. Not obliquely.

title: Respect the Dying's Wishes Before Our Own
description: To the Editor:

title: Exchange to Trade in Electricity Contracts
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange said yesterday that it would begin trading in its two new electricity futures contracts on March 29.

title: The Chess World Braces For One Landmark Match
description: In the rarest of occurrences in the chaotic chess world, Gary Kasparov, the reigning world champion, is to take the stage at the Philadelphia Convention Center tomorrow afternoon to begin a match against an opponent who has no complaints about him.

title: Thousands Flee Their Homes In Northwest Oregon Floods
description: A combination of melting snow and ice, plus unusually heavy rains over the last two days, have brought flooding and massive mudslides to northwestern Oregon, leading to road closings around the state, at least three deaths and the evacuation of more than 15,000 people by today.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;State House, Not White House
description: By and large, New Jersey voters like Governor Whitman and they like her exactly where she is, in Trenton, rather than Washington.

title: Back to Work
description: The monthlong strike of building workers that ended this week was an interesting test of labor muscle in New York City under a new A.F.L.-C.I.O. president who promised a reinvigorated union movement. The strike left no outright winners. The building owners did not get the 48 percent drop in starting wages they initially demanded (and probably never expected), nor the six-year phase-in for workers to receive top wages. But the workers settled for a 20 percent drop in starting salaries and a two-year wait for management to contribute to pension funds.

title: In the War on Drugs, No Honorable Surrender Is Possible
description: To the Editor:

title: As Repairs Lag, New Jerseyans Endure Another Dry Day
description: Like dozens of northern New Jersey communities, this small town up the hill from Giants Stadium was on edge today. Schools were darkened, "911" lines clogged, and elderly residents nervously gauged the steam levels in their heating systems.

title: Candidates Weigh Cost Of Office To Families
description: When Mayor Jan Jones of Las Vegas, Nev., was deciding whether to run as a Democratic candidate for Congress this year, it was not the polls, the fund raising or the national political terrain that ultimately mattered. It was what to do with the kids.

title: Edward Adamson, 84, Therapist Who Used Art to Aid Mentally Ill
description: Edward Adamson, a pioneer in using art to treat mental illness, died last Saturday at his London studio. He was 84.

title: Fidelity Discloses a Big Shift to Cash by Magellan Fund
description: Reminding market watchers that he is a flexible investor, Jeffrey N. Vinik, manager of the $53 billion Fidelity Magellan fund, sharply reduced the fund's stock holdings in December, to their lowest level since he took over the fund in July 1992.

title: Teachers End Walkout
description: Teachers here in California's second-biggest school district returned to work today after negotiators reached a tentative agreement to end a weeklong strike.

title: Drug Makers Settle Suit on Price Fixing
description: Fifteen big drug companies formally agreed yesterday to pay more than $408 million to settle a class action lawsuit charging them with conspiring to illegally fix prices that they charged to thousands of independent pharmacies.

title: 5 Beach Workers in Florida Are Slain by Ex-Colleague
description: A man who had been dismissed from his city job cleaning beaches here opened fire on his former colleagues early this morning, killing five of them and critically injuring another before turning the gun on himself, police officers said.

title: Ford to Sell 19.8% of Loan Unit to Public
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would sell nearly 20 percent of its consumer finance company, the Associates First Capital Corporation, in an effort to sharpen its focus on car and truck manufacturing.

title: The Neediest Cases;Some Give With Grateful Nod to Past
description: A year after Hitler came to power, Eric W. Zielenziger left Berlin, his birthplace, and moved to the Netherlands. It was 1934, and he was 14.

title: New Uniforms for 49ers
description: The San Francisco 49ers are going to have new uniforms, the team announced this week at a trade show in Atlanta. The team will replace the old fire-truck red with the burgundy color of wine to go along with the traditional gold.

title: POP REVIEW;So There'll Always Be an English Rocker
description: Some expatriates go native; others cling to the old homeland ways. Spacehog, a band of Englishmen formed in New York, revels in a British rock heritage that extends from the Kinks to the Clash, with special attention to glam-rock. At Irving Plaza on Thursday night, the four musicians, all from Leeds, pouted and bantered in ways learned from three decades' worth of English rockers. At one point, they urged fans to shout, "Get on with it!"

title: MARATHON;Just Call Bowman Alternative Runner
description: Andrea Bowman doesn't particularly like running 26.2 miles. She has a stress fracture in her left foot and a sore Achilles' tendon in her right foot. She spent four days in the hospital last week recovering from food poisoning. Given the expected heat and the hilly course, it will be difficult to finish Saturday's Olympic marathon trials, much less to finish first.

title: About New York;Fighting Drugs With a Bible And a Bellow
description: THE drug dealers who used to keep the Rev. Betty Neal awake at night in the late 1980's with their music and mayhem knew that whenever they were arrested, they'd soon be back on the street.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Taiwan Says China Plans War Games Near Coast
description: Taiwan said today that China had begun moving troops toward the coast facing the island, but security officials tried to assure the public that the movement was part of widely expected military exercises. "There is no sign of mass troop gathering," the Defense Ministry said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BOWATER RAISES DIVIDEND AND SEEKS 10% OF ITS STOCK
description: Bowater Inc. increased its dividend 33 percent yesterday and authorized the repurchase of as much as 10 percent of its common stock outstanding. Bowater, the pulp and paper maker based in Greenville, S.C., has 35 million shares outstanding. Bowater increased its quarterly dividend to 20 cents a share from 15 cents. The dividend is payable on April 1 to shareholders of record on March 11. Bowater said it would repurchase as many as 3.5 million of its shares in the next 12 months. At current prices, repurchasing 3.5 million shares would cost Bowater $140.9 million. Bowater shares rose $1.625, to $40.125, on the Big Board.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an order to New York City agencies to prepare $500 million in new budget cuts misspelled the surname of the city's budget director in some editions. He is Joseph J. Lhota, not Llota.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;20% of Italian Bank Up for Public Sale
description: The foundation controlling Instituto Bancario San Paolo di Torino S.p.A., Italy's largest bank, said yesterday that it planned to sell 20 percent of the company to the public to take advantage of tax breaks. At current market prices, 20 percent of San Paolo is worth about 1.6 trillion lire ($1 billion).

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Samuel Ramey With a Medley Of Mephistopheles
description: Maureen Forrester, the great Canadian contralto, used to joke that almost all the roles in opera for her voice type were "mothers, maids, witches or bitches."

title: CRASH ON NEW JERSEY TRANSIT: COMMUTING;Railroad Revises Weekend Schedules for Two Lines
description: After coping all day with scattered delays and disruptions, New Jersey Transit last night revised its weekend schedule for the Main and Bergen lines, the rail arteries affected by yesterday's fatal collision.

title: GOVERNOR VETOES ARBITRATION BILL SOUGHT BY POLICE
description: Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed legislation today that would have helped New York City's powerful police and fire unions win larger pay increases, agreeing with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani that the bill would cause huge financial problems for New York City.

title: Africa Ills: Insight on Cure But Avoiding the Medicine
description: When a handful of heads of state and finance ministers from all over Africa gathered in this dusty capital this week, the ostensible purpose was to trade ideas on how to launch an economic takeoff for the world's poorest continent.

title: House of Satch Gets New Gig
description: In 1943, Louis Armstrong was on the road when his wife, Lucille, told him she had bought a house, their first, a simple three-story building sheathed in aluminum siding in Corona, Queens.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HORSE RACING;Steward Resigns Over Alleged Slur
description: The Jockey Club steward, CLINTON PITTS, resigned his job at the New York Racing Association tracks yesterday, following an allegation that he used an ethnic slur.

title: OLYMPICS;I.O.C. Moves to Forestall Chinese Fears
description: The International Olympic Committee moved yesterday to defuse the possibility of a Chinese boycott of the Summer Olympics by saying that Government authorities from Taiwan would not be invited to Atlanta.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Falla and Other Spaniards In a Philharmonic Tribute
description: On paper, the New York Philharmonic's tribute to Manuel de Falla this week, commemorating the 50th anniversary of his death with an effusion of Spanish music, looked short on works by Falla himself. But in the central program, on Thursday evening, the music sorted itself out justly, with Falla's great ballet score "El Amor Brujo" rising in bold relief amid a number of slighter but attractive creations.

title: Police Arbitration Bill Deserves Pataki's Veto;Daring to Amend
description: To the Editor:

title: HOCKEY;Rangers-Devils Game An Evaluation on Ice
description: During an 82-game regular season that lasts from early autumn through midspring, good hockey teams might play only a dozen games that are peak tests. These are the confrontations that give a fair feeling for how they match up against the best opposition and where they might be headed.

title: A Trial That's a Little Bit Gothic
description: Joan Collins, known best for her role as Alexis Carrington on "Dynasty" but also for several best-selling books, was offered $4 million by Random House for two novels in 1990. Now, in a Manhattan courtroom, the publisher is suddenly taking the high road, suing Miss Collins for breach of contract because it says it found the material she handed in unacceptable. In court last week, Joni Evans, the former Random House editor, mercilessly called it "melodramatic" and "a little bit Gothic" -- words that sound something like the promotional blurbs for a lot of romance fiction.

title: Leaders of the Bosnian Serbs Sever Relations With NATO
description: Bosnian Serb military commanders, in a move senior NATO officials called a clear violation of the Bosnia peace accord, have severed all communication with NATO to protest the imprisonment of two Bosnian Serb officers.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CAPE COD POTATO CHIPS FOUNDER IN REPURCHASE BID
description: Steve Bernard, founder of Cape Cod Potato Chips, said yesterday that he was negotiating to buy back the company, which he sold to the Anheuser-Busch Companies in 1985. Mr. Bernard said he expected to reach an agreement before the plant's scheduled closing in April to avoid interruptions in employment and manufacturing. Terms were not discussed. This week Anheuser-Busch said it intended to close its unprofitable Eagle Snacks unit -- which includes Cape Cod -- after unsuccessful efforts to find a buyer.

title: Actuaries Do More Than Crunch Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE IRISH TROUBLES;In the Words of the I.R.A.: 'Blame Lies With Major'
description: Following is a statement sent to the Irish television tonight, signed "P O'Neill," the name used on most statements by the Irish Republican Army (in Gaelic, Oglaigh na hEireann).

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.H.L.;Selanne Feels Betrayed by the Jets
description: TEEMU SELANNE, the 25-year-old right wing who was traded Wednesday from the Winnipeg Jets to Anaheim, said in an interview published yesterday in Helsinki, Finland, that he had been "badly let down" by the Jets' owner, RICHARD BURKE.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CISCO SYSTEMS SHARES REACH AN ALL-TIME HIGH
description: The shares of Cisco Systems Inc. reached an all-time high yesterday as analysts raised their earnings expectations for the company. The moves came after Cisco, the world's leading producer of computer-networking equipment, said late Thursday that its second-quarter earnings rose 74 percent on stronger-than-expected sales. In reaction, analysts at Robertson, Stephens & Company and Merrill Lynch raised their earnings estimates. Cisco shares rose as much as $4.875 to touch an all-time high of $93.75. They closed at $91.25, up $2.375, on trading of 10.1 million shares.

title: CRASH ON NEW JERSEY TRANSIT: THE RESCUE;With Swamp as Foe, Workers Improvise Evacuation Methods
description: It was eerily quiet when Debby McGorty pulled her police cruiser up to the jumbled train cars, and the silence scared her. There was no screaming or wailing, nothing but big silvery cars knocked off their rails and the front of a massive locomotive crushed like a child's toy.

title: Envoy Agrees To Reimburse His Campaign
description: The United States Ambassador to the Vatican, Raymond L. Flynn, has agreed to reimburse his mayoral campaign committee $9,000 for private expenditures, including a family trip to Disney World.

title: An Asian Challenge To World's Jet Makers
description: SINGAPORE  For the first time, Asia-Pacific aerospace companies will join together to challenge Western dominance in the manufacturing of advanced jetliners by producing planes that will compete internationally with aircraft made in the United States and Europe.

title: Police Arbitration Bill Deserves Pataki's Veto;The Heights, Maligned
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Will Extradite A Fugitive Banker
description: The United States Government has cleared the extradition of a fugitive banker and his wife who are charged in Germany's biggest postwar real estate fraud, Germany's chief prosecutor said on Thursday.

title: Officer Ousted At Pier 1
description: The board of Pier 1 Imports Inc. voted today to dismiss its chief financial officer, Robert G. Herndon, for failing to oversee the company's investments properly, the company said today.

title: CRASH ON NEW JERSEY TRANSIT: THE CAUSE;Train Passed a Signal, and Investigators Wonder What Went Wrong
description: Train 1254 was not supposed to be there.

title: Journal;The Idiot Chip
description: In the annals of dumb solutions to serious problems, history will have a ball with the V-chip, the antidote to trash TV that became the law of the land on Thursday when Bill Clinton signed the telecommunications bill. Far from making television safer for children, the V-chip will merely postpone and confuse the issue until well into the next century -- even as it provides politicians with convenient cover. By embracing the V-chip, Democrats and Republicans alike can posture as if they care about children without actually having to do anything to improve their cultural lot. Let Mr. V-chip do the job instead!

title: Familiarity of Funeral Weighs on Firefighters
description: Once again, the bagpipes wailed, the family wept and thousands of white-gloved firefighters saluted as a fire truck carried the coffin of a fallen colleague.

title: Gallery Acted in Good Faith on Greek Artifacts
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday chronicling Dave Winfield's baseball career referred incorrectly to a job once held by Howie Spira, a freelance radio reporter and admitted gambler. Mr. Spira worked for a former agent for Winfield; he never worked for the agent who has represented Winfield since 1984.

title: CRASH ON NEW JERSEY TRANSIT: THE ENGINEERS;For 2 Railroad Families, Sorrow and Questions
description: The sorrow could be heard in the recorded message left yesterday on the answering machine of D. Terry Abbott, leader of the 280 New Jersey Transit engineers who belong to the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about a strike of custodial workers in several Brooklyn schools misidentified the school shown, where two students talked outside with their father. It was Public School 8, not 10.

title: CRASH ON NEW JERSEY TRANSIT: THE OVERVIEW;3 Killed as Trains Collide in New Jersey
description: Two silvery New Jersey Transit commuter trains carrying more than 700 passengers in opposite directions in the morning rush collided yesterday in a thunderous roar of sideswiping steel and grinding sparks at a junction on a lonely marshland in Jersey City, just over the horizon from New York City.

title: CRASH ON NEW JERSEY TRANSIT: THE SCENE;Just Another Day on Train Turns to Morning of Torn Metal, Chaos and Fear
description: This morning, like every morning, William Jackson sat right behind the driver in the first window seat on the first car on the 8:24 out of East Rutherford, N.J. Before the train reached Hoboken, Karen Chambers was plunging through as many pages of her medical thriller as she could. Robert Farkas would not have been on board at all, except that a flat tire stopped him on the way to the 7:30 train.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Man Is Guilty in Fatal Crash
description: Michael Homentosky was found guilty yesterday of aggravated manslaughter in the death of a 39-year-old Randolph woman last February when he ran a red traffic light at 82 miles an hour.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BRADLEES TO CUT 450 JOBS AS PART OF A REVAMPING
description: Bradlees Inc., the discount retailer, plans to eliminate about 450 positions as part of a restructuring aimed at saving the ailing retail chain $19 million annually, the company said yesterday. The company said it would consolidate several store management positions at all 134 Bradlees locations. Bradlees said the company was trying to position itself for future growth and establish an organization and cost structure that was in line with industry standards. The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last June.

title: No Time to Cut Head Start
description: A new report reconfirms the long-term benefits of early childhood programs like Head Start that Congress is trying to cut. Lawmakers should study it before slashing these programs.

title: Legislator Pushes Curbs On California Cougars
description: The gated communities in the Sierra foothills have been able to keep most strangers out of their cloistered cul de sacs. But in recent years, there has been one visitor they have not been able to avoid: a native Californian, the mountain lion.

title: More on the Crash
description: THE VICTIMS -- The crash claimed the lives of a lawyer from Fair Lawn who was a regular passenger and of two New Jersey Transit engineers, both seasoned veterans of the railroad. Page 30.

title: Texas Executes a Killer of Two as the Victims' Family Watches
description: Leo Jenkins was executed today while relatives of the brother and sister he killed watched from a few feet away, the first time Texas has allowed the survivors of murder victims to witness a lethal injection.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Penn's Ivy Streak Stopped
description: Brian Gilpin's two free throws with eight seconds left yesterday propelled Dartmouth to a 54-53 victory over Pennsylvania, breaking a 48-game winning streak by the Quakers against Ivy League teams.

title: BASEBALL;New Talks Have Old Air of Mistrust
description: When baseball's negotiators renewed their efforts to attain labor peace, they were determined not to hold their talks in public and inflame each other and the game's fans with their rhetoric. Good intentions, however, don't always succeed.

title: 3 Die in Blast in Chechnya; Protesters Insist That Russians Leave
description: An explosion ripped through a crowd in Grozny today as besieged protesters in the Chechen capital demanded that Russian troops leave the secessionist republic.

title: One Gun a Month Is Plenty
description: States with tough handgun laws have seen the effectiveness of those laws severely diminished by professional gun-runners. People who profit from the gun trade travel to less restrictive states like Georgia or Florida, where they buy several dozen cheap pistols for resale on street corners. To shut this deadly "iron pipeline," which operates up and down the East Coast, gun-control advocates in Congress are pushing a simple, common-sense reform. It would limit a customer's gun purchases in every state to one a month.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD Bailey Sets World Mark

title: John Pfeiffer, 75, Impresario of Classical Records
description: John F. Pfeiffer, an executive producer at RCA Red Seal who recorded many of the great classical musicians of the century during a 47-year career, died on Thursday at his office in Manhattan. He was 75 and lived in Manhattan.

title: DANCE REVIEW;It's a Ballet, But Not One With Tutus
description: Anyone who still needs to be disabused of the notion that ballet is synonymous with tutus might try "The Waltz Project," Peter Martins's ingenious ode to modern times at the New York City Ballet.

title: Eligio Panti, 103, Maya Healer With Modern Ties
description: Eligio Panti, a traditional healer whose ancient herbal remedies attracted the attention of modern medical scientists and drew thousands of patients to the door of his humble hut in Belize, died on Sunday in his home in the village of San Antonio. He was 103 and widely regarded as the last Mayan master healer in Belize.

title: Westchester Girl Is Killed in Bus Accident
description: A 14-year-old girl was run over and killed by a school bus Thursday afternoon when her coat apparently became caught in the bus's door as she alighted, the police said today.

title: Lilco Plan Wins Support Of Leaders In Suffolk
description: In a breakthrough for Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to disband the Long Island Lighting Company, Republican leaders in Suffolk County said for the first time today that they endorsed the proposal.

title: Then the Hard Part: Settling With Iacocca
description: The tense negotiations between Kirk Kerkorian and the Chrysler Corporation dragged on for nearly two months with some progress. Then came the tough one: What to do about Lee A. Iacocca.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ANN TAYLOR STORES FILLS KEY EXECUTIVE POSITION
description: The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation said yesterday that it had named the Donna Karan Corporation's former chief financial officer, J. Patrick Spainhour, as its president and chief operating officer. The appointment of Mr. Spainhour, 45, comes as Ann Taylor faces declining sales as a result of the sluggish retail environment and problems with its merchandise assortment. Ann Taylor's sales at stores open for more than a year fell 17 percent in January from January of last year -- its eighth straight monthly decline. Ann Taylor's chairman and chief executive, Sally Frame Kasaks, said the company would benefit from Mr. Spainhour's experience in merchandising operations, logistics and information systems technology.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stock Market Extends Record-Breaking Advance Record highs have had no chance to grow old in this stock market: the Dow Jones industrial average broke its previous record close every day this week. The Dow rose a total of 167.63 points, the most points ever in a week for the closely watched index.

title: CRASH ON NEW JERSEY TRANSIT: THE RAILROAD;Agency Had Enviable Safety Record
description: The crash of two commuter trains yesterday cast a spotlight on New Jersey Transit, the fourth largest public transit agency in the nation, and its executive director, Shirley A. DeLibero.

title: POLITICS: THE RIVALS;Returning to Iowa, Dole Stresses Moral Values
description: Back in Iowa for a final push before voters hold their caucuses on Monday, Senator Bob Dole today emphasized his conservative roots in a series of campaign stops across eastern and southern Iowa, asserting that "moral and cultural issues are America's greatest challenges."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bundesbank Is Cool To Another Rate Cut
description: Germany's high unemployment rates are not reason enough to cut interest rates further, the chief economist of the German central bank said yesterday. The unemployment problem "will go on for months," the economist, Otmar Issing, said. But "that is not an argument for further monetary easings."

title: COMPANY NEWS;LCI IS NAMED CARRIER FOR BELL ATLANTIC AND NYNEX
description: LCI International Inc. of McLean, Va., said yesterday that it had been named by the joint mobile venture of the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the Nynex Corporation to provide long-distance service from Maine to the Carolinas under a multiyear contract. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. LCI International said it had more than 60 million circuit miles of digital fiber optic line and carried more than 4.9 billion minutes over its network last year. Bell Atlantic Nynex Mobile, based in Bedminster, N.J., is a wireless service provider and has more than three million customers in a service area that covers about 55 million people, LCI said.

title: POLITICS: THE RIVALS;Forbes Steps Up Defense Against Attack Ads
description: Steve Forbes spent much of his day today defending himself against what his aides described as a growing barrage of personal attacks, including a new round of campaign advertisements from Senator Bob Dole that Mr. Forbes is untested and unprepared to occupy the Oval Office.

title: Country Station Goes Pop
description: At an unspecified time this afternoon, 103.5 FM is to become the latest New York City radio station to change its music format in a bid for higher ratings.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAYTAG TO SHUT KITCHEN RANGE PLANT IN INDIANAPOLIS
description: The Maytag Corporation said yesterday that it would close its 860-employee kitchen range plant in Indianapolis as part of a restructuring that will result in a $50 million charge against earnings this year. The nation's fourth-largest appliance maker said it expected $35 million in annual savings to result. Maytag's chairman and chief executive, Leonard Hadley, said in a statement that Maytag would consolidate its Jenn-Air kitchen range production at its plant in Cleveland, Tenn., and close its Jenn-Air plant in Indianapolis. In the restructuring of its home appliance business, Maytag is creating a single business unit where two units have been operating.

title: Roof Collapses at L.I. Plant, Killing Worker
description: One man was killed and two others were injured when the snow-laden roof of a recycling plant crashed down on them this morning, six weeks after a truck had hit a major support beam in the center of the building, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Bosnian Serbs Said to Hold Forced Laborers
description: Hundreds of people are being forced into what amounts to slave labor in dozens of towns and villages in Serb-held areas of Bosnia, according to the International Committee of the Red Cross.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.F.L.;Cowboys Cut Holmes and Kennard
description: The Super Bowl-champion Dallas Cowboys have released the troubled cornerback CLAYTON HOLMES and the overweight center DEREK KENNARD.

title: A Toy Fair, a Feud and the Industry's General Angst
description: O.K., so Barbie is not going to find happiness with G.I. Joe. But can they coexist at the toy show?

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday about the importance of money in the Republican Presidential primaries omitted part of a quote by Charles Black, the top campaign strategist for Senator Phil Gramm, in some copies. The passage, referring to voters' reactions to Steve Forbes's vast fortune, should have read:

title: POLITICS;In Their Own Words
description: STEVE FORBES Speaking yesterday in Manchester, Iowa:

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn and Wheat Prices Surge; Exports Expected to Cut Supply
description: Corn and wheat prices jumped on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after the Agriculture Department said surging exports would put inventories later this year at their lowest level since the 1970's.

title: No, Prayer Doesn't Always Cure. But Neither Does Medicine.;Legal Duty to Inform
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY
