title: Horse Racing;Cigar Looks for a Weekend of Victories
description: On the day he was acclaimed Horse of the Year on one coast, Cigar was preparing to open his final year at the races on the other coast today as the great bay champion headed into Saturday's Donn Handicap with a 12-race winning streak.

title: Morgan Stanley Executive Shift
description: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. announced an executive change yesterday as part of an overall consolidation of the operations that invest for institutional investors.

title: Beliefs
description: Last Tuesday, the Public Broadcasting Service's affiliates in New York, Boston and many other cities featured a two-hour "Frontline" documentary about the killings of two abortion clinic workers on Dec. 30, 1994, in Brookline, Mass.

title: Du Pont Heir Is Ordered to Be Tried in Wrestler's Murder
description: After hearing the victim's widow describe how she watched her husband die, a judge today ordered John E. du Pont, an heir to the du Pont family fortune, to stand trial on charges of first-degree murder.

title: TENNIS;A Good Start For Defenders Of Davis Cup
description: The defending champion Americans brought their Davis Cup today via armored truck, failed to bring their fans via bus and won two matches in spite of the indifference.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about a rise in multiple births misstated the location of the organization Mothers of Supertwins. It is in Brentwood, L.I.

title: Municipal Employees Say 'Yes'
description: The approval of a five-year labor contract by New York City's biggest municipal union spares Mayor Rudolph Giuliani another potential setback in his struggle to restore the city to solvency. But the city's financial difficulties are so grave that Mr. Giuliani will probably have to confront all the unions with new demands to help balance the budget. At the least, he must try to do better in dealing with teachers, police officers and other members of the work force without contracts. He also needs to push the bureaucracy for ways to cut costs.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Tajikistan Says It Impeded A Press by Islamic Rebels
description: Tajikistan said today that Government troops had stemmed an advance by Islamic rebels in heavy fighting in a remote mountain region 125 miles east of the capital, Dushanbe.

title: Rome Journal;A Host With the Most, or Too Much?
description: A casual viewer, randomly flicking channels of an evening, might well conclude that television entertainment in Italy is one big gaudy variety show, and its host is almost always Pippo Baudo.

title: Putting the Dance Into Dance History
description: Ann Barzel doesn't remember exactly what drove her to look up the encyclopedia entry for dance as a 9-year-old girl in Des Moines more than seven decades ago. But that was the start of a lifelong passion that led Ms. Barzel, who is 82, to begin collecting dance memorabilia.

title: McVeigh Subpoenas 4 in Suit on Bombing
description: A lawyer for Timothy McVeigh, who is accused in the bombing of the Federal office building here, asked a judge today to subpoena four men he says might have information about the explosion.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;At Rutgers, a Strike Threat
description: About 75 Rutgers University professors, teaching assistants, students and laborers picketed a Board of Governors meeting yesterday, warning the board that "we are on track for a strike," said Mary Gibson, the president of the Rutgers Council of the American Association of University Professors. An estimated 4,100 faculty members and other workers have been without a contract since June 30.

title: HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL REPORT
description: New Jersey Girls

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-6

title: Trump and Le Cirque Are Players in Two Major Restaurant Deals
description: Two major restaurant deals were signed yesterday by high-profile New Yorkers who are promising to open their lavish new ventures sometime in the fall.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Lose Ward to Cubs
description: Duane Ward, "a phone call or two away" from being signed by the Yankees 10 days ago, in the words of General Manager Bob Watson, signed a minor league contract with the Chicago Cubs yesterday and was invited to their spring training camp.

title: Police Arbitration Bill Deserves Pataki's Veto;How Much Productivity?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;ACE TO BUY TEMPEST REINSURANCE OF BERMUDA
description: Ace Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Tempest Reinsurance Company of Bermuda for stock valued at about $605 million. Tempest was formed in 1993 by the General Re Corporation of Stamford, Conn., to reinsure against property catastrophes. Reinsurance is protection that insurance carriers buy to reduce their own risk. General Re initially invested $100 million in Tempest and then began seeking investments from other companies. General Re will not retain any interest in Tempest after Ace's purchase. Ace, an insurance concern also based in Bermuda, will exchange about 13.3 million shares in the deal. Its stock rose $2.75, to $48.25, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: Police Arbitration Bill Deserves Pataki's Veto
description: To the Editor:

title: Murder Charge for Man Held in Blaze That Killed Firefighter
description: Just hours after the body of Firefighter Louis Valentino was laid to rest in a flag-draped coffin yesterday, New York City officials announced that murder charges had been filed against the man accused of starting the fire that led to the firefighter's death.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Layoffs at Trump's Casino
description: Trump's Castle Casino Resort laid off 27 employees yesterday in a move to shave $1 million a year from its payroll. The layoffs, effective immediately, were mostly among management employees and followed a six-week "line by line review" of the hotel's 3,600 jobs, said Roger Wagner, president of Trump's Castle. No dealers were dismissed.

title: South Africa Campuses Reap Racial Enmity
description: Timing their protest with a meeting of the directors of Witwatersrand University, a group of black students and university workers gathered recently in the administration building on campus here.

title: New Hampshire Bank Deal
description: The CFX Corporation agreed today to acquire the Milford Co-Operative Bank in a stock swap valued about $26.5 million. The transaction values Milford Co-Operative shares at $39 each. The stock jumped 41.7 percent, or $10 a share, on the news to close at $34.

title: Medical Research Is Hurt By Secrecy, Official Says
description: In recent years, going against a long tradition of openness in science, many researchers have accepted secrecy as a common working practice. This change, a leading Government official said this week in a medical journal, is impairing progress in cancer research and other fields.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Grupo Sidek Debt To Be Revamped
description: Grupo Sidek S. A., the big Mexican company, and its primary operating units have reached a preliminary agreement with bank lenders to restructure about 70 percent of their $2.12 billion debt, the companies said yesterday. During the revamping, Grupo Sidek and its units will defer scheduled principal payments and will make interest payments "to the extent of available cash," the companies said.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Pope's Plea for Peace Bears Fruit in Guatemala
description: Pope John Paul II made a final plea for peace in Guatemala at the end of his five-day tour of Central America, and President Alvaro Arzu responded by announcing that formal peace talks with leftist rebels would reopen this month.

title: CRASH ON NEW JERSEY TRANSIT: THE SURVIVORS;The Unhurt Just Wonder At Fortuity And Habit
description: George Burger, a 43-year-old actuary, went to work today.

title: BASKETBALL;No Hard Feelings For Smith
description: The Charles Smith news conference began about 1:15 P.M. The J. R. Reid session followed at 2:15 across the foyer on the third floor of the hotel. Each spoke of the inevitability of being traded. Both admitted that the changes would be beneficial to them.

title: Pearson to Buy a Publisher From News Corp.
description: Moving to expand its educational publishing operations in the United States, the British-based media company Pearson P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire HarperCollins Educational Publishing Inc. from Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation for $580 million.

title: Bridge
description: Experts are sensitive to vulnerability in a contested auction, and this is an important aspect of the theory of overcalling. Favorable vulnerability suggests adventure, unfavorable vulnerability indicates caution.

title: No, Prayer Doesn't Always Cure. But Neither Does Medicine.
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a fatal fire in a Bronx apartment building misidentified the units of two firefighters. Thomas McHugh is battalion chief of the 17th Battalion, not Rescue Company 17; Tony Lamagna is a firefighter at Engine Company 41, not Rescue Company 41.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DIAMOND MULTIMEDIA INCREASES ITS OFFER FOR HAYES
description: Diamond Multimedia increased its offer yesterday for the modem maker Hayes Microcomputer Products Inc. by 14 percent, to $140 million in cash and stock. It was the second time in a week that Diamond Multimedia had raised its bid. The offer to bring Hayes out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy is almost double the $73 million offer first made by Diamond in September. The company did not disclose the reason for the latest increase. Diamond is offering $112.7 million in stock and $27.3 million in cash to equity holders. It continues to offer $85 million in cash to creditors. The new offer from Diamond has been approved by the committee of unsecured creditors. It still needs approval by the Bankruptcy Court in Atlanta.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;U.S. Assails Japan Over Music Copyrights
description: The United States complained yesterday to the World Trade Organization that Japan was failing to comply with an accord to protect foreign music copyrights, costing American producers $500 million a year. The move starts a process than could lead to trade sanctions against Japanese exports to the United States.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Youth Program Is Canceled
description: Because three youths allegedly committed murders while they were enrolled in the state-operated, community-based Juvenile Intensive Supervision Program, Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz scrapped the program yesterday, citing "tragic and dramatic failures that have blotted out its successes."

title: TRW Credit Reporting Unit To Be Sold for $1 Billion
description: TRW Inc. said today that it was selling its consumer credit reporting business for more than $1 billion to an investment group led by Bain Capital Inc. and the Thomas H. Lee Company. TRW's Information Systems and Services unit is one of the nation's leading providers of credit reports on consumers and businesses. It had sales of about $540.1 million last year, or about 5 percent of TRW's $10.2 billion overall revenues.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;From Pop To an Opera On Football
description: For 20 years, Mike Reid, a former All-Pro football player with the Cincinnati Bengals, has been writing chart-topping country and pop songs for Bonnie Raitt, Willie Nelson and Ronnie Milsap, among others, picking up two Grammy Awards along the way. But in recent years, Mr. Reid, who holds a music degree from Penn State, has expanded his reach as a composer, writing a dance score, chamber works and now a one-act family opera, "Different Fields," about a star wide receiver struggling to find himself.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;N.F.L. Gives Modell a Ticket to Baltimore
description: Where've you guys been for the past three months?" Art Modell asked reporters today, in his first public appearance since November, following the National Football League owners' decision to let the team formerly known as the Cleveland Browns move to Baltimore. "It's good to be back."

title: Audubon Magazine Pulls Article Critical of Clinton's Policy
description: Just as the March-April issue of Audubon magazine was about to go to press, an article describing President Clinton's environmental policies as "inconsistent" was suddenly killed by John Flicker, president of the National Audubon Society.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Residency Rule Challenged
description: The Essex County Prosecutor, Clifford J. Minor, filed a complaint in Superior Court yesterday, hoping to block an order by the County Executive, James W. Treffinger, that would require about 40 percent of the workforce in the Prosecutor's office to move to Essex County or be dismissed.

title: Don't Call Them Volunteers
description: President Clinton has been sounding more like a New Republican than a New Democrat lately, calling for an end to big government. But his oratory is belied by his record, especially his proudest legislative accomplishment: the Americorps national service program.

title: Record Floods Might Worsen Along Rivers In Northwest
description: The sun shone in an azure sky, but evacuations continued today as the worst flooding in decades raged in the Pacific Northwest. Surging rivers have resulted in five deaths in Oregon and one in Washington so far, officials said, and more than 20,000 residents have been evacuated in those states and in Idaho and Montana.

title: NATO's Plans Threaten Start II
description: The Senate's ratification of the Start II treaty is supposedly a sign that the United States respects its nuclear disarmament commitments and that it intends to push Russia to do the same. But many in Moscow think the real objective is to disarm Russia as soon as possible.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Lincoln's birthday is Monday.

title: No Big Bank to Call Its Own;Does Los Angeles Need a Financial Powerhouse?
description: A pall descended over this usually upbeat city after Wells Fargo & Company of San Francisco succeeded in its hostile takeover of the First Interstate Bancorporation, the last big bank based here. Coming on top of a series of natural and man-made disasters, and the departure last year of the area's two professional football teams, it seemed like the final insult.

title: Observer;Movie Fan Tells All
description: John Updike's fascinating New Yorker piece on Lana Turner takes me back to the age when Hollywood unashamedly viewed women as sex objects. In that socially unenlightened time there was always a new sex goddess under production in the film factories.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Even Whitman Can't Help
description: Even if he were to choose Gov. Christine Todd Whitman as his running mate, Bob Dole as the Republican Presidential candidate in November would lose decisively to President Clinton in New Jersey, a new poll indicates.

title: BOXING;De La Hoya and Chavez Pave the Way to a Payday
description: Oscar De La Hoya led the way, and Julio Cesar Chavez followed with a fight that lasted only six seconds longer. Now they get each other in what may be the most anticipated non-heavyweight fight in nearly a decade.

title: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;Fight for Religious Right's Votes Turns Bitter
description: The battle for the loyalties of religious conservatives, as the Iowa caucuses approach, erupted today into a contentious showdown between Senator Bob Dole and his leading rival for the Republican Presidential nomination, Steve Forbes.

title: MUSIC REVI@W;The Met's New 'Cosi,' With Bartoli's Debut
description: Cosi Fan Tutte" is at once the most satisfying and elusive of Mozart operas. Its several aspects never quite fit together; indeed, clarifying one layer necessitates ignoring another. The layers superimposed evoke an enigmatic blur.

title: Sri Lanka Drove Tamils to Embrace Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Dec. 26 and in some copies on Dec. 25 about Giraud Chester, an author and television executive, misstated the name of a company he joined in 1964. The company was called Mark Goodson-Bill Todman Productions, not Mark Goodson Television Productions. (This correction was delayed by editing lapses.)

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Very Messy Machinations In Savannah
description: Pity po' Savannah. The Georgia port city was dissected quite skillfully, and sympathetically, in John Berendt's "Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil," the best-selling nonfiction book abopt the mysterious death of a young man. Now the city has fallen into the soapy paws of Spelling Television. The producers, Aaron Spelling and E. Duke Vincent, are responsible for such television milestones as "Dynasty," "Beverly Hills 90201" and "Melrose Place."

title: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;Downbeat Days for Salesman Gramm
description: Beyond the silos and off the Interstate, Senator Phil Gramm kept to his rounds, bearing his Presidential notions into town here like a humbled traveling salesman lugging an increasingly heavy sample case.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Arrest in Minister's Assault
description: A suspect was arrested yesterday in the Tuesday night assault on an East Orange minister, the Rev. William Barnett, 56, who was shot six times and robbed as he left his church.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daimler-Benz in Talks With Microsoft
description: Daimler-Benz A. G., Germany's largest conglomerate, and the Microsoft Corporation agreed yesterday to explore areas where they could cooperate on developing a sweeping range of technology markets.

title: Bonds Mixed as Profit Taking Cuts Short Potential Rallies
description: As concerns eased somewhat over the credit market's ability to absorb the week's $44.5 billion in new notes and bonds, prices of Treasury securities finished mixed yesterday in a choppy trading session.

title: MORE IRISH TROUBLES: THE OUTLOOK;In the Unraveling of a 17-Month Peace Effort, Disappointment, but Not Surprise
description: Five days ago, while the seekers of an Irish peace still seemed to be inching fitfully toward compromise, George J. Mitchell warned British television viewers that the quest for peace was in danger of unraveling.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Dawgs Keep the Pound, Too
description: The National Football League has thrown rabid Cleveland fans a bone.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Despite Record, Nets Find Reason to Hope
description: The Nets head into this weekend's All-Star break having lost three straight games and eight of their last 11 to fall to 18-29. They were only 1-4 on a Western trip that ended Thursday night with a 107-102 loss to the Suns.

title: Felice N. Schwartz, 71, Dies; Working Women's Champion
description: Felice N. Schwartz, who was active for more than three decades in the advancement of women in the workplace, and whose writing focused debate over the career model known as the "mommy track," died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 71.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;In Japan, Finance Ministry Is Lightning Rod for Anger
description: The most powerful people in Japan, it is sometimes said, are not those in the Prime Minister's residence or the corporate board rooms but those eating in the cafeteria of the Finance Ministry. But that may begin to change.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FMC GOLD WEIGHS SALE OF ONLY PART OF THE COMPANY
description: The FMC Gold Company said yesterday that it was considering selling part of the company, rather than the whole thing, because there was greater interest in its individual assets. The mining company, which is 80 percent owned by the FMC Corporation in Chicago, hired Wood Gundy Inc. of Toronto in September to sell the entire company. FMC Gold said the recent upturn in gold prices had allowed FMC Gold to evaluate other options. FMC Gold has hired J. P. Morgan & Company to assist Wood Gundy in soliciting proposals. FMC Gold's shares were up 12.5 cents yesterday at $5.875.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.F.L.;Bills' Smith Has Knee Surgery
description: Buffalo Bills defensive end BRUCE SMITH underwent arthroscopic knee surgery yesterday and should recover before the team opens training camp.

title: GOLF;Clements On Brink Of a Dream Victory
description: The story of his golfing life is written between the lines on Lennie Clements's face, tales of near misses in the crow's-feet by his eyes and of blown opportunities in the premature gray hair on his head. He is 39 years old, and for the last 16 years he has plodded along on the PGA Tour, one of the thundering horde of serviceable players, a man who could always play, but not well enough to win a golf tournament.

title: INSIDE
description: As a Firefighter Is Buried, Murder Charges Are Sought

title: Farrakhan Said to Pledge Support to Sudan
description: The leader of the Nation of Islam, Louis Farrakhan, was quoted today as saying American Muslims backed the Sudan against "unjust plots."

title: Excerpts From Pataki's Veto Message
description: Following are excerpts from today's veto message of the police arbitration bill by Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: MORE IRISH TROUBLES: THE SCENE;Near the Blast, Shock Spreads As Quickly As the Shards
description: It was about 6:55 P.M. when the security guards at the Beaufort Court, one of the sea of buildings in the Canary Wharf complex here, were told there had been a bomb threat and were ordered to evacuate offices.

title: No Headline
description: My eyes were closed, I was relaxing, and then I was sharply awakened. It felt like a very big earthquake, just a tremendous shaking. I realized something really bad had happened and my fear was that the train was going to roll over."

title: CRASH ON NEW JERSEY TRANSIT: ONE VICTIM;Passengers' Bitter News: 'David Didn't Make It'
description: The morning mood inside the first car of the New Jersey Transit train mixed familiarity and anonymity. There were nods and hellos, with first names all that were asked or required.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.F.L.;Colts Will Not Re-Hire Marchibroda
description: TED MARCHIBRODA brought the Indianapolis Colts a measure of success and respectability, although apparently not enough to save his job as coach.

title: President Finds a Way to Fight Mandate to Oust H.I.V. Troops
description: On the eve of signing a $265 billion military budget bill, President Clinton today directed the Attorney General not to defend in court a provision requiring the Pentagon to discharge troops who have the virus that causes AIDS. The White House said the President viewed the provision as "abhorrent" and unconstitutional.

title: Crown Heights Defendant Arrested Again
description: Lemrick Nelson, the Brooklyn man awaiting trial on Federal civil rights charges stemming from the killing of Yankel Rosenbaum during the 1991 Crown Heights disturbances, was arrested on Thursday night and charged with criminal possession of a weapon, a concealed box cutter, the police said.

title: Bomb Wounds 100 in London As I.R.A. Truce Is Said to End
description: Just an hour after reports that the Irish Republican Army had abandoned its 17-month-old cease-fire, a powerful bomb exploded in East London tonight, wounding about 100 people, shaking skyscrapers and leaving the Northern Ireland peace effort in tatters.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK;One Big No-Show At All-Star Party
description: Michael Jordan and Dennis Rodman were noticeably absent from today's All-Star Game news conference with the national media.

title: Queen of Adjective' Recalls Begging for Help
description: After being loudly ridiculed by publishing industry experts during three days of testimony, Joan Collins and her lawyers struck back in kind yesterday. They accused Random House of initially being so dazzled by Miss Collins's starlight that the publishing house gave her an exorbitant contract with an outlandish clause.

title: Mine Company Accepts Offer of $2.4 Billion
description: Diamond Fields Resources Ltd., a Canadian company that recently discovered large reserves of nickel, copper and cobalt in Labrador, agreed yesterday to be acquired by Falconbridge Ltd. in a stock and cash deal with a minimum value of $2.4 billion.

title: Sports of The Times;A Wayward Listing of Ships at Sea
description: EVERYONE is in a semi-buzz about the trade that sent Charles Smith of the Knicks to San Antonio. This, then, is the beginning of a great dismantling of the Knicks: first Smith, then Harper, then Oakley, then Starks.

title: October 1987 Without Tears
description: It was more fun at the stock exchange than it was in 1987, and it was almost as active.

title: Glaxo Selling Migraine Drug
description: The pharmaceutical company Glaxo-Wellcome has agreed to sell its migraine treatment 311C90 to Zeneca P.L.C., the two British companies said this week.

title: Mercer Ellington, 76, Leader of Father's Band

title: Apartment Hunting on the Grand Canal
description: PERHAPS because Venice is such a dreamlike city, I've always been fascinated by the details that attach it to everyday life: the milk boat, the hidden supermarket, the fresh fish stands that disappear by noon. For years my husband and I wanted to live in Venice, not just visit -- but the monthlong rentals listed in the brochures we had received from several American real estate brokers were beyond our price range. Luckily we had found several brokers in Venice on previous visits. Their faxed replies to our inquiries were charming, and spoke of slightly cheaper, more intriguing options: "The apartment is very nice, with furniture in Style. There is also a washdisher."

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Chicago to Show Lincoln Collection

The exhibition will open tomorrow, on Lincoln's Birthday.

title: SPOTLIGHT;Feudin' and Fightin'
description: About midpoint in THE BIG COUNTRY (1958), there's a terrific panoramic shot of Gregory Peck and Charlton Heston fiercely slugging it out against a sweep of land and sky. The photography, impact and surprise of this moment pinpoint the classy visual frame that encloses a fairly routine western story. Hooray for William Wyler's razor direction. It's kind of Hatfield-McCoy clash over water rights. A pro like Wyler keeps it humming with an able cast: Burl Ives (especially good as a leathery patriarch), Carroll Baker, Jean Simmons, Charles Bickford, and Chuck Connors - SAT. at 10 P.M. on FAM.

description: GENE KELLY WAS NOT A hoofer. His genius as a dancer, for all its common-man bravura, borrowed from more than a single tradition. His view of dance was ecumenical, making impossible any narrow definition of his own gifts as performer, choreographer and director.

title: SAFE-SEX LIES
description: Daum is right on. Her risk of getting AIDS is even smaller than she thinks. Heterosexual AIDS statistics are generally compiled at the university or county hospital clinic level, from a disadvantaged population that is very distinct from the one with whom she is likely to come into contact. There is also the unspoken truth that the terrible loss of life and health among openly homosexual men might be ignored by the general population from whom donations to AIDS causes are requested if the specter of death for us all was not raised.

But it's more complicated on Washington Street, where traffic lights are few and far between. There are no lights on Washington between Bethune and Christopher Streets, a distance of six blocks.

It has also created a new and important fault line for cultural clashes that could define the wars of the next century.

title: GOLF;Clements's Dream Is a Round Away

He saw Jack Nicklaus and Tom Watson, and he used to dream about what it would be like to one day hole the winning putt at Torrey Pines.

description: A chart of the Republican primary and caucus schedule last Sunday misstated several dates and some cumulative tallies of delegates. A corrected chart appears on page 26.

title: The London Bombing
description: A terror bombing in London on Friday evidently signaled the end of the Irish Republican Army's cease-fire, declared in September 1994. The bombing, which killed at least one person, injured more than 100 and rocked the eastern dock area of the city, gives violent pause to what has been a fitful but hopeful effort to bring peace to Northern Ireland. There is no justification for such a wanton attack against civilians. All parties to the Irish conflict must rededicate themselves to finding a peaceful resolution of this long and brutish conflict.

description: It is not a Davis Cup until a McEnroe shows up.

Nonetheless, fungi -- the kingdom of organisms that includes molds and yeast -- have been quietly positioning themselves as the newest threat to human health, and epidemiologists are concerned.

description: Armani, High and Low, Heads for Madison Ave.

title: WEDDINGS;Sara R. Snow and Timothy P. Cabot
description: Sara Rose Snow, a daughter of Viscountess Hampden of Glynde, England, and the late Peter Snow, was married yesterday to Timothy Pickering Cabot, a son of Lady Thomson of Princeton, N.J., and London and of Lewis Cabot of Boston and South Harpswell, Me. The Rev. Dr. Peter Lynn performed the Anglican ceremony in the St. Mary the Virgin Chapel at Glynde Place, the Hampden family seat.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;Magnum Opus
description: It was time," says the octogenarian photographer Eve Arnold, "to make an archive . . . to make order out of the chaotic files that have been my life." For a photojournalist who has published eight previous books and accumulated more than 40 years' worth of slides, negatives and prints, that is a tall order. EVE ARNOLD: In Retrospect (Knopf, $50) is a chronological memoir of Ms. Arnold's professional life along with the photographs by which she wants to be remembered. From images of Malcolm X, Marilyn Monroe and Margaret Thatcher to those of anonymous veiled Afghan women and of toddlers in a Chinese nursery, the shots she has chosen show not only the high points but also the broad sweep of her undertakings. Throughout her career, she has worked for Magnum, the photographers' cooperative founded by Robert Capa, Henri Cartier-Bresson, George Rodger and David Seymour, usually on assignment for publications like Life and London's Sunday Times. Her style, despite her confession to "dithering and nerves," is authoritative and humanist -- energized, as she says, by the unfamiliar. Being there is paramount to a photojournalist's success, and Ms. Arnold gives a lively account of the obstacles she surmounted -- rough terrain, illness, intractable bureaucrats. Although few of the book's images hold the transcendent power of her color picture of an old Chinese woman whose beautifully lined face emerges from the textured black of her clothes and the surrounding shadow, all attest to her enterprise and tenacity, along with her ability to establish rapport with her subjects. As Ms. Arnold looks back, she seems justifiably pleased with her accomplishments and wonders about her next project. Now that she has achieved order, she might try another kind of memoir, a distillation of her memories that brings more of the woman herself into focus. Rosemary Ranck

title: Tunnel Vision
description: Birdsong By Sebastian Faulks. 402 pp. New York: Random House. $25.

title: In the Region/New Jersey;Fair Lawn and Clifton Upgrading Lagging Corridors
description: TIME has not been a friend to neighborhood commercial corridors. Once places where residents flocked to do business, they have been drained of some of their luster and prosperity as malls and strip centers siphoned away patrons. A roller-coaster economy over the last decade has also taken a toll.

description: After mailing out more than 900,000 tax-assessment notices to New York City property owners last month, the Department of Finance is now trying to make it as convenient as possible to prove that the agency's valuations are wrong.

The Government issued regulations last week not to block Internet use but to steer the flow of electronic information through officially controlled ports that can be monitored.

title: February 4-10;Soon, the Defense

description: EVERY restaurant on Long Island seems to be offering a romantic candlelight dinner special for Valentine's Day. A man can get carried away with the need to impress the woman of his dreams and reserve a table at the most expensive-sounding place he can find. This is a big mistake. The higher the prices, the greater the probability of a complete disaster.

And for decades, local politicians have defended this influence on the grounds that their states act as the nation's living room, where candidates and voters get together over coffee to talk about issues.

title: SUNDAY VIEW;Real Women Don't Eat Pie in the Sky Anymore
description: THERE ARE EARNEST BOOKS out about sisters and sisterhood; there are earnest television shows; there are movies that range from folksy pious ("How to Make an American Quilt") to funky pious ("Waiting to Exhale") to sprightly period-piece pious ("Sense and Sensibility"). These sisters think and talk about themselves, think and talk about one another, and think and talk about the lovers in (or missing from) their lives. As do we all. But in my experience, you grow tired of yourself and your sisters (I use the word in its broadest sense) when that's all there is.

A large population of migrating birds count on these eggs for meals on their flights along the coast. And people show up to see the birds.

title: Undersea Wonders Off Sinai's Sands
description: IT wasn't until I reached the reef at Ras Mohammed, at the tip of the Sinai Peninsula, that I understood to what extent life in that forbidding desert begins at the water's edge. From placid turquoise shallows, the bottom dropped beneath me in a sheer coral cliff, and I was afloat in what seemed an endless royal blue sea, surrounded by fish of every imaginable shape and color.

title: Fish Dealer Accused of Perjury In Fulton Market Crackdown
description: Two months ago, Ross Gangi Jr. complained publicly that New York City officials were preventing him from making a living at the Fulton Fish Market because his father had been falsely labeled the market's Mafia boss.

title: Waterfowl, Too, Braving the Harsh Winter
description: EVERY day this winter Sigrid Owen has been feeding the wildlife that congregate around a pond in East Hampton. This year, she has been using nearly twice as much cracked corn as last year. The winter, which started early, has been harsh, she said, especially on the waterfowl that are dependent on freshwater ponds for their food source.

title: River Levels Dropping in Northwest as Residents Assess Damage
description: While most rivers across the flood-ravaged Northwest had done their worst and were dropping, one kept rising today and overwhelmed an affluent suburb south of Portland, swamping some homes to the roofs.

title: The Bombing in London Revives Old Fears in Belfast
description: On the day after the Irish Republican Army ended its 17-month cease-fire with a lethal bombing attack in London, anxiety has returned for the people of Belfast.

title: Bellevue's Emergency
description: AT 9 O'CLOCK ONE RECENT morning, an emergency gong resounded throughout Bellevue Hospital. Members of the medical staff raced through hallways and down littered back stairwells toward the emergency room. "Get them to send some boot covers down from the O.R.!" a doctor called out. The cramped space, crowded with residents yelling and hauling equipment, resembled the engine room of a submarine. Oxygen tanks were piled by the door. Canisters of atropine, a drug used to control muscle spasms, were stacked in metal carts. Everyone donned blue plastic coats, masks with Plexiglas shields, rubber gloves and boot covers, then turned toward the emergency-room door, waiting for casualties to barrel through.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: CONFRONTING AUTHORITY: Reflections of an Ardent Protester By Derrick Bell. Beacon, $12. The author, Harvard Law School's first full-time black professor, took an unpaid leave from the faculty in 1990, intending to return only after the school hired a woman of color. This book is not only a chronicle of his protest, which ultimately led to his dismissal, but also a call to arms for battles of conscience. "I found Mr. Bell's conclusion convincing," Laura Kalman said here in 1994.

title: SAFE-SEX LIES
description: I have been working on a college campus for more than 10 years and have watched plenty of students come to terms with sex in the 90's -- some the hard way. Yet, while there are many who, like Daum, will disregard the message, others are dealing with it. For them, sex in the era of AIDS is still hot, erotic, satisfying and anxiety free.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;Strip Club (and Battle) Go On
description: Steam Heat, a striptease club on Flatbush Avenue, has withstood court rulings, community protests and well-connected opponents since it opened last April. Not once, in the face of its many losses, has one of its nude dancers had to halt a performance.

title: ART;'Photography Is About the Self'
description: HOW DO I KNOW WHAT TO PHOTOGRAPH? I AM AT A point where images find me; I don't go looking for them. I interact with the process of photography sometimes by anticipating, at other times by trusting and waiting, or by willing things to happen. Does this shape what happens? We don't know. Physical laws do not determine what happens. A photograph is created by a machine, but the product of it is real; the moment had to exist in the real world in order to take a picture of it. No other process demands that kind of veracity.

title: CHOICE TABLES;Atlanta Stirs the Pot for the Olympics
description: AS Atlanta prepares for the 1996 summer Olympic Games, which open July 19, local businesses are straightening their ties and buffing their doorknobs in anticipation of a summer windfall. This includes the city's burgeoning restaurant industry, which has nearly doubled in the last six years. But will the Olympics indeed toss gold into its coffers?

title: S. .H. Bayles, 85, Prominent Executive In Advertising World
description: S. Heagan Bayles, a founder of SSC&B, a major New York advertising agency, died of cancer on Jan. 30 at his retirement home in Fort Lauderdale. He was 85.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: JAMACIA;Security and Sanitation Are Priorities in a New Business District
description: Michael Orlando manufactures display cases for merchandise, and when he moved his company to Jamaica in 1993, he followed in the footsteps of nearby businesses and hired security guards. But thieves have still managed to steal from Mr. Orlando's company, Ultimate Display Industries, in its isolated location at 180th Street and 110th Avenue. And to his chagrin, people use the adjoining vacant land as a dump for rusty cars and old furniture.

title: Mr. Delany's Cosmic Neighborhood;For This Author, New York Stands In for the Universe
description: Samuel R. Delany thumps down the rickety-rackety stairs of his fifth-floor walk-up and drops off his garbage on Amsterdam Avenue like anybody else. He buys bus tickets at the Port Authority. He stops for an afternoon pick-me-up at a bar nearby, a New York guy doing everyday things.

title: Not Just Another Country
description: To assert that America is exceptional, as analysts have been doing since Tocqueville, is to dwell on paradox. In "American Exceptionalism: A Double-Edged Sword," Seymour Martin Lipset motes that while the United States is the most litigious society in the world -- spending four to eight times as much on lawsuits as Germany, England, Italy, France, the Netherlands or Japan -- it is simultaneously one of the most lawless, vexed by crime rates triple those of other industialized nations. Hence America's double-edged sword: on one side of the blade, "a high sense of personal responsibility, independent initiative and voluntarism"; on the other side, "self-serving behavior, atomism and a disregard for communal good."

title: February 4-10;Rags to Riches
description: Levi Strauss, the company that put rivets on the bottoms of a generation and set new standards for the treatment of its tens of thousands of workers, may soon be changing. A few members of the Haas family, descendants of the founder, have launched a plan to buy back the shares of employees and some family members.

title: Lawyer for McVeigh Seeking Subpoenas
description: A lawyer for Timothy J. McVeigh, one of two defendants awaiting criminal trial in the bombing of the Federal Building here last April, asked a judge on Friday to subpoena four men who, the lawyer said, might have information about the blast.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: MIDWOOD;Acrobat Circus: All-Human Fun
description: JUGGLING and balancing, with clowning and derring-do, Le Cirque Eloize of Montreal will bring its antics to Brooklyn College next Sunday.

title: APPEARANCE];Counter Intelligence
description: Elizabeth Hurley for Estee Lauder, Cindy Crawford for Revlon, Kirsty Hume for Chanel -- their flawless faces smile out at us from glossy advertisements. The implicit promise is that if we use that lipstick, that foundation, we too will look like these beautiful women. This is a promise that we no longer believe.

title: Coverage of Loft Tenants Ignores Landlord's Role...
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S DOING IN:;Lima
description: At the beginning of the 1990's, few foreigners dared set foot in Peru for fear of terrorism, cholera and street crime, all of which were rampant throughout this Andean nation. But now, with Peru undergoing a dramatic turnaround in its political and economic situation, tourists are arriving in droves. Last year, a record 485,000 foreigners visited Peru, a 26 percent increase over 1994. Cholera is under control, terrorism is in decline with the capture of the leaders of the Shining Path movement, and the economy is on the rebound.

title: DANCE;Two Rising Stars, On Different Arcs
description: JUST ABOUT EVERY dance season brings a handful of newcomers who make a distinct impression on audiences and critics alike. This year, the New York City Ballet has two young dancers who are particular standouts. One is Miranda Weese, a 20-year-old dancer of sparkling glamour who made her debut last month in Peter Martins's "Jeu de Cartes." The other is Jennie Somogyi, 18, a dancer who embodies both grandeur and innocence and who made her debut in the same month in George Balanchine's "Who Cares?" Anna Kisselgoff, writing in The New York Times, has said that Ms. Weese reminds her of Balanchine's "most witty muse, Tanaquil LeClercq," and she singled out Ms. Somogyi for projecting "an overwhelming boldness through the sheer power and clarity of her dancing."

title: In the Super Bowl of Sports Stuff, the Winning Score is $2 Billion
description: With all the mystical assurance of an ancient seer reading entrails, Steve Mann planted his feet on an upper rim of Atlanta's Georgia Dome last week, hefted a little metal toy truck and declared: "Baseball is dead."

title: BEST SELLERS: February 11, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Rutgers Is Tough, But Falls A Bit Short
description: Give Rutgers credit. For a basketball team outmatched today against Villanova's talent, experience and height, and for a team whose record dropped to 6-14 over all and 3-9 in the Big East, the Scarlet Knights played better and with more intensity than anyone had a right to expect.

title: Reluctantly, Clinton Signs Defense Bill
description: President Clinton signed a $265 billion defense authorization bill today while promising he would not enforce a "blatantly discriminatory" provision of the bill requiring the Pentagon to discharge troops who have the virus that causes AIDS.

title: SOAPBOX;The Icicles That Loom Over Me
description: THERE'S a big icicle hanging off my windowsill, and another, even bigger, hanging from the eaves just above me. Getting longer every day. I'm dying to give them a good whack and send them crashing four floors down into the courtyard of my little co-op building. I don't though.

title: THEATER;Race and Racism Among Hard Hats
description: IN "Distant Fires," a play about pettiness and backstabbing among the hard-hatted, a construction crew not only does its work but also indulges in goldbricking on the roof of a 10-story building, mid-summer, in Ocean City, Md.

title: The View From: Rye;A Day for More Thoughtful Card Buying Than Christmas
description: THE snow was piling up outside, but inside the Peegee Podgee card and gift shop here, Valentines cast a warm pink and red glow everywhere. There were hearts made of paper, cardboard, lace and shiny foil, chocolates and heart-shaped boxes, T-shirts, balloons, jewelry and ornaments, all with a romantic motif.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: COUNTRY DANCING

title: Other People's Words
description: INTERPLAY A Kind of Commonplace Book. By D. J. Enright. 237 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.

title: New Releases
description: SPEECH: 'SPEECH' Chrysalis/EMI

title: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;Buchanan Tries to Trim G.O.P. Field
description: Patrick J. Buchanan today appealed to anti-abortion advocates and other social conservatives to unite behind his campaign, arguing that he is the only anti-abortion candidate who can defeat Senator Bob Dole and Steve Forbes, whom he called insufficiently committed to ending abortion.

title: TELEVISION VIEW;'Seinfeld,' an Odd Place That's Just Like Home
description: THE COMMODIFICATION OF popular entertainment is as old as show business itself. Recent archeothespic investigations at the Globe Theater in London, for example, suggest that while on-site sales of Shakespeare's Tomorrow and Tomorrow and Tomorrow Perpetual Desk Calendar were quite strong, the post-performance numbers for his "My Progenitors Went to 'Coriolanus' and I Received Naught but This Motley Jerkin, Withal!" T-shirts were not what they might have been.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Spring Camps Open Without Anderson
description: The Cincinnati Reds played the Philadelphia Phillies in the first game of their 1970 spring training exhibition schedule, and it was a day Sparky Anderson will not forget.

title: Skiing Bolivia Is High Comedy
description: CHACALTAYA is Bolivia's only ski resort and, at more than 17,000 feet in altitude, unquestionably the world's highest. Its only run would hardly intimidate the most shrinking of novices if it were, say, three miles lower. But even bunny runs have a way of becoming booby traps the closer they get to outer space. In this rarefied atmosphere, skiing is no ordinary test of skill.

title: February 4-10;Peace in Northern Ireland Explodes With a London Bomb
description: For several months now, the prospect of a permanent peace in Northern Ireland has looked bleak. There have been reports that the Irish Republican Army -- or at least hardline factions in it -- were ready to turn back to violence.

title: Fred S. Keller, 97, a Professor and Behaviorist
description: Fred Simmons Keller, an analyst of human behavior and professor emeritus of psychology at Columbia University, died on Feb. 2 at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 97.

title: Education;Curriculum Changes: A Sampler on Science and the Arts
description: The revision of the statewide public-school curriculum, issued last week, lists 56 standards for the arts, health and physical education, literacy, mathematics, science, social studies and languages, and 880 "indicators" to determine whether standards are being met. The State Board of Education is expected to approve a final version in the spring, and testing on the new standards would start in two to five years.

title: THE NEXT GENERATION;Meet Hunterdon's Youngest Candidate
description: NAME Mike Babula

title: More Required Co-op Reading
description: To the Editor:

title: Limited Partnerships Come Up From the Canvas
description: IF you're still fuming over the money you socked into limited partnerships during the 1980's, take heart. Getting rid of the hapless investments isn't as much of a losing proposition as it used to be.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE;Luxury Club's Demise Was Sudden but Slow
description: When the Atrium Club opened in 1975 on a swank block of 57th Street near Park Avenue, Gerald R. Ford was President and the idea of a luxurious social club with a top-flight gymnasium and a dining room was the buzz of chic Manhattan. But when it closed abruptly on Feb. 1, perhaps the most surprising thing about the Atrium Club was that its death took so long -- and that it came without notice.

title: FROM THE DESK OF: RICHARD G. GELDARD;I'd Rather Use a Checkbook
description: RECENTLY, I began and ended a brief affair with on-line banking.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;What to Do When the Missiles Get Stolen
description: Broken Arrow John Travolta, Christian Slater, Samantha Mathis, Delroy Lindo Directed by John Woo R 110 minutes

title: U.N. Avoids Evidence in Bosnia Killings;No 'Belated' U.S. Role
description: To the Editor:

title: MARKET WATCH;In Soap And Stock, Revlon Cuts Prices
description: Sometimes you should take what you can get, even if it's not what you hoped for.

title: Westchester Q&A: James F. Butler;Growing Herbs and Cooking With Them
description: THE snow may still be accumulating, but James F. Butler of White Plains is already getting ready for spring.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UNION SQUARE;Bold Lines For Tower On 14th St.
description: When local residents learned about a mixed-use building planned for the south side of Union Square, they worried that a nondescript behemoth would mar the historic square. The Municipal Art Society shared those fears and approached the developer, the Related Companies, which agreed to hold a design competition for the project.

title: LIVING TOO LONG
description: Not long ago, I sat down with a 93-year-old friend. We were at the bedside of her 100-year-old husband, who is dying from a severe pneumonia, resistant to our medical interventions because of his significant frailty.

title: CD-ROM's;Then and Now in a Small and Distant Land
description: The War in Vietnam: a Multimedia Chronicle (Windows and Macintosh.) Produced by CBS News and The New York Times. New York: Macmillan Digital USA. CD-ROM, $49.95.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE;'Everybody's Little Angels' Fulfill Tough Wishes
description: Visiting Manhattan from Dallas, the socialite had a party in two hours and a crisis on her hands, or rather her feet. Her shoes just would not do.

title: Southampton Fearp Changes Planned for L.I.R.R. Station
description: FOR nearly two years, Southampton Villag' officials worried that the Long Island Rail Road would knock down their historic station to accommodate an elevated platform. When they saw the bulldozer a few weeks ago, some feared the worst.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Nursing Home Fire in Stamford Kills 3 Residents and Hurts 7
description: A fire at a nursing home in Stamford, Conn., killed three elderly residents yesterday evening and injured at least seven others, fire officials said.

title: At the Apollo, Past Meets Future
description: GRACE BLAKE has a dream mission. Or is it a nearly impossibl' task?

title: THEATER;Frank Langella Stamps 'The Father' as His Own
description: THE FATHER," August Strindberg's taut psychological drama of paternal paranoia, is not a play that customarily causes audiences to cry out in shock. So leave it to Frank Langella to find the gasps.

title: Ian Grey's Blind Date
description: IAN GREY is 39 years old and single. He's 5 foot 10, has raven hair, a boyish face and pale blue eyes. He has kicked around a bit. He's been a rock musician, a songwriter and an amateur hairdresser; now he's a freelance writer and aspiring novelist. His turn-ons are film noir, Peter Lorre and black coffee. He does not like computerized film editing or loud restaurants. He wears briefs and believes in love at first sight. He's a cat person. And a Libra.

title: Sports of The Times;The Old School Still Looks Great
description: THEY dunk now. This was my first reaction when I walked into the old gym, decades later, and saw Jamaica High School on the layup line. Dunks. Stuffs. Hands over the rim. Whoops of appreciation when Danny Sampson and Somoye Blijden jammed the ball home.

title: CD-ROM's;Good Heavens
description: HUBBLE SPACE TELESCOPE CD-ROM ARCHIVE Set of two CD-ROM's (one disk in Windows and one in Macintosh). Westlake Village, Calif.: Brentwood Interactive/Spectrum Multimedia Productions in association with Vidcom. $29.95.

title: WEDDINGS;Laura Cherensky, James McEwen 3d
description: Laura Ellen Cherensky and James Wallace McEwen 3d, both magazine publishers in New York, were married on Friday in Washington, Conn. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel performed the ceremony at the Washington Club Hall.

title: SAFE-SEX LIES
description: I have been affiliated with the Gay Men's Health Crisis for almost 10 years, during which I have been a volunteer and a board member. Thus, I read Daum's article with more than casual interest. Now that I know what Daum feels does not work, I would be interested to learn what she feels would work for her and her peers. Those of us involved in preventing the spread of H.I.V. and AIDS would welcome her suggestions.

title: BENEFITS
description: Champagne and Shakespeare

title: DINING OUT;Rustic Digs, Live Music, Eclectic Menu
description: MICHE MACHE continues to metamorphose. The first change was a move from South Norwalk to North Stamford. In the process the cuisine changed from New American to Southwestern.

title: GARDENING;Chasing Winter Blahs With Seeds at Hand
description: THE winter months can seem long indeed to the younger set. If there is snow, outdoor play is fine. But after the snow melts, boredom tends to set in, and with it, bad tempers. Plant projects about now could prove to be child-pleasers.

title: POSTINGS: 20 Housing and Civil Courtrooms;New Courts In Queens Halfway Complete
description: Imagine awaiting selection as a juror in a pleasant and comfortable assembly room, with a telephone near at hand and a handsome lounge nearby. Perkins Eastman Architects of Manhattan, architect for the new Queens Civil Courthouse in construction in Jamaica, promises these pleasures and more when the courthouse opens, probably in June of next year.

title: Military Has No Room For the H.I.V. Positive
description: To the Editor:

title: EVENING HOURS;Fun, and for Good Purposes
description: Aiding Associated Black Charities, immunology, homeless animals and an educational superhighway and celebrating art from Zaire.

title: Bird of Prey
description: MARABOU STORK NIGHTMARES By Irvine Welsh. 264 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $21. RATHER than a benign fairy-tale creature that delivers babies, the marabou stork is an ugly, viciously predatory African bird that preys on flamingos (in particular), devouring not only eggs and young but sometimes even adult birds. "Marabou Stork Nightmares" is an ugly, vicious novel about predatory young men who prey on women (in particular), devouring not only their humanity and identity but sometimes even their lives.

title: EDUCATION;Schools Lick Their State-Aid Wounds and Worry About '97
description: When New Jersey schools learned last month how much money they would get from the state for the 1996-97 school year, it marked an end to New Jersey's most recent unsuccessful attempt to equalize spending among the 608 districts.

title: Sunday February 11, 1996;A QUESTION FOR: Claire Gaudiani
description: Since 1988 she has been the president of Connecticut College, where she is initiating a campaign to transform Valentine's Day into a celebration of community and civic obligations.

title: Streetscapes/Congregation B'nai Jeshurun;Future Uncertain, a 1919 Synagogue Begins Repairs
description: FORCED out of their building by a ceiling collapse five years ago, Congregation B'nai Jeshurun at 257 West 88th Street has only now begun to repair its synagogue.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;Checkmating Adversity With the Dark Knights
description: In a neighborhood where many children skip school, more than 100 students stay late into the afternoon at Mott Hall School on 131st Street. They are not hanging out or competing in sports. These students are playing chess at the school, which is the home of the best junior high chess team in the country.

title: Changes Please Jurors
description: QUITE pleasant!" was Josephine Vanasselt's description of her recent experience as a juror. "It went quickly, and I'm quite happy that things were settled," Mrs. Vanasselt said.

title: What Snow? It's Time For Summer Rentals
description: ON the cold concrete terrace overlooking the ocean, the storm howled mercilessly and the real-estate agent was blown back to the shelter of the eaves, shouting out the statistics on the rental house.

title: WESTCHESER GUIDE
description: POPE AS PLAYWRIGHT

title: PRO BASKETBALL;They'll Pass the Ball, but Not the Torch
description: If the National Basketball Association wanted to start a 30-and-over division, finding players would hardly be a problem.

title: Matisse Everywhere
description: PAULA HAYWARD, the pastry chef at Cafe Matisse, grew up in Bermuda, where her mother made ice cream and butter from the fresh milk she procured from the family's cow. No wonder Ms. Hayward's banana-rum cheesecake is so creamy.

title: THEATER;A Composer's Death Echoes in His Musical
description: THERE'S A SOLO SONG AT the beginning of "Rent," a new rock musical inspired by the opera "La Boheme," that the cast and crew can hardly bear to hear. It's a muted ballad called "Glory," sung by an HIV-infected punk rocker as he picks at an acoustic guitar in a ratty loft:

title: WEDDINGS;Juliet L. Packer, William M. Kutik
description: Juliet Law Packer, a writer for the ABC-TV soap opera "The City," was married yesterday to William Martin Kutik, a marketing consultant. The retired Episcopal Bishop of Western Massachusetts, Andrew F. Wissemann, the bride's uncle, officiated at the Cosmopolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg took part in the ceremony.

title: Wall St.'s Top Woman Slips In the Back Door
description: MURIEL SIEBERT is probably the best-known woman on Wall Street. In 1967, she became the first woman to buy a seat on the New York Stock Exchange. Several years later, she became the first woman to own and operate her own brokerage firm, Muriel Siebert & Company, a discount broker. Appointed by Gov. Hugh Carey as New York State Superintendent of Banking in 1977, she later drew the governor's ire in opposing the merger of Marine Midland Bank with the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation.

title: Delta Blues
description: MISSISSIPPI An American Journey. By Anthony Walton. Illustrated. 279 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24. TO understand the world, William Faulkner once said, you have to understand a place like Mississippi. Anthony Walton began working on this fine and brave book five years ago, when he was 30. In his incessant confrontations with racism in the North, he was having doubts about whether he wanted to be an American. He was too contentedly bourgeois, he confesses, to look toward Africa, and besides did not know his tribe. The more he thought, the less he could deny it: "I was from somewhere. Mississippi was my heritage and background, and if I wanted to decipher the tangle of contradictions and illusions around me, I was first going to have to learn to decipher myself." He adds: "If I was going to have to live out the fate of being black and American, I felt I needed to know what that meant. And that meant Mississippi."

title: Electric Vehicles On Greenwich Roads
description: THE first electric car that Fred Whitridge ever drove had cut-glass windows and a tiller rather than a steering wheel. That was 15 years ago, when his wife's 85-year-old grandmother let the couple take a spin in her 1914 Rauch & Lang town car, after giving Mr. Whitridge about a minute's worth of instruction.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: THE SHAPE OF WILDERNESS By Shelley Berc. Coffee House Press, paper, $12.95.

title: New Releases
description: THE TONY RICH PROJECT: 'WORDS' LaFace

title: Backtalk;All Those Dogs, All Those Tales
description: I've had the good fortune to have covered dog shows from coast to coast and in 14 foreign countries. Of them all, the Westminster show year after year stands out above the others.

title: A CORRECTION;G.O.P. Primary Schedule
description: Republican primary voters, caucus goers and party officials will send 1,990 delegates to the party's national convention in August. A candidate needs one more than half, 996 delegates, to be nominated. The process of nominating, electing and allocating delegates varies from state to state and is subject to change.

title: Run for the Zoning Board? You'd Never Get Elected
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Reformers, Take Your Mark
description: YOU put off shoveling your walk, and a neighbor slips on the ice. He sues, he wins. If insurance doesn't help, can you take a tax deduction? Forget it.

title: HOCKEY;Isles Beat The Clock As Well as The Ducks
description: Eric Fichaud thought about it as he was being assaulted in goal. Indeed, the memory of last week could not be dismissed while the Islanders' three-goal edge was slipping away today against the grandly named Mighty Ducks.

title: ART REVIEW;Contradictions and Questions, Unresolved
description: MAREN HASSINGER'S "Treachery and Consolation," at the Trans Hudson Gallery here, is nothing if not good theater and, as such, may reflect the sculptor's experience as a performance artist. More likely, though, this is a matter of the work's having been made for the warehouse-size premises, where it rubs shoulders with a divertissement by Beom Kim.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;New Life for Soul-Food Venture
description: Three years ago, Van DeWard Woods, vice president of Sylvia's Restaurant and the son of its founder, Sylvia Woods, tried to spin off a line of soul-food products like Sylvia's Hot and Sassy Sauce, salad dressings, and seasonings. But the venture was understaffed and undercapitalized. About eight months ago, Mr. Woods was forced to halt production and seek more financing.

title: San Francisco's Other Bridge Is Found in Need of Costly Repairs
description: It is the other bridge in San Francisco. Unlike its famous neighbor, the Golden Gate Bridge, the Bay Bridge is decidedly unsexy. It does not gracefully arch over the Pacific Ocean, linking gorgeous headlands. Blue Angels do not fly over it during Fleet Week.

title: SAFE-SEX LIES
description: What exactly is Daum's beef? That she was deprived of the days when sex was a carefree adventure? That wearing a condom is a drag? That a possible outcome of having irresponsible sex can lead to a death so hideous and heart wrenching that it gives her nightmares?

title: WEDDINGS;Catherine Stewart, Rupert Moore
description: Catherine Marshall Stewart, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Marshall Stewart of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday in London to Rupert Alexander Beckwith Moore, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Moore of London. The Rev. David Martin performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Brompton Oratory.

title: Also Inside
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 The distance travelled to New York: The route of flowers, from faraway field to your hand.

title: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;Unofficially, The President Goes to Iowa As Candidate
description: As the Republican Presidential candidates made their final push to win the Iowa caucuses, President Clinton ventured confidently into the state today to rally Democrats to his vision of an era of possibilities and insure that his own campaign themes are not eclipsed.

title: THE NATION;It's Reaganomics, Alive and Irresistible
description: IN the minds of voters, the most important distinction between Bob Dole and Steve Forbes may not be that one has been a Washington insider for decades and the other has never held elective office. It may not even be that one must abide by rigid spending limits while the other has a seemingly limitless fortune to spend on his campaign.

title: World News Briefs;Taiwanese Urges Peace As China Moves Troops
description: President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan, in a speech that he said was his definitive word on relations with China, emphasized the need for peace today, one day after China began moving troops toward its coast for what defense officials here described as military exercises.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;A Beggar's Request That Began a Tradition of Giving
description: On Christmas Day in 1911, a prosperous businessman finished his turkey dinner and decided to go for a stroll on the streets of New York.

title: Publishing's Grim Reaper
description: To the Editor:

title: Aboard An Extended Shoreline East
description: SHORELINE commuters from the New London area now have an option to battling traffic on Interstate 95. The Department of Transportation has extended the Shoreline East commuter rail service, which makes stops between New Haven and Old Saybrook, to New London.

title: Food;Hen Party
description: DURING THE LAST FEW DAYS, JOHANNA had been battling an irresistible urge. For months, she had attended meetings, faithfully intoning, "My name is Johanna, and I am addicted to giving dinner parties." In the sanctuary of these meetings, she confessed to feeling powerless over her need to dazzle a roomful of guests. She further explored the negative way her Cecil B. De Mille-like productions were affecting the rest of her life.

title: And Forces You to Hunt For a Study of Gay Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: THING;Obscure Rose Gets Big Break In the Movies
description: WHAT The little-known Sterling Silver has blossomed into a star for its prominent role in the film "Bed of Roses." In the movie, a lovelorn botanist uses bushels of Sterlings ("Every one in the city," one character says) to woo a reluctantly romantic New York workaholic.

title: MUSIC;A Cosmopolitan Voice for Universal Longing
description: THE recording on Frederick Urrey's answering machine begins in English, then suddenly changes into Finnish. The Finnish is for his wife's sake, but he is much happier in German, the language of the Schubert songs he is to sing in New Brunswick on Saturday.

title: A LA CARTE;Delights for Your Sweetie on Valentine's Day
description: A CASCADE of Champagne, chocolate, oysters and other foods of love will be accompanied by flickering candles, long-stemmed roses, piano music and jazz bands this Valentine's Day at Island restaurants. Special three- and four-course, fixed price St. Valentine's Day dinners, at prices that range from $25 to $60, are being offered as an addition to regular a la carte menus.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;Adventures For Women
description: THE president of the Adventure Travel Society, Jerry Mallett, believes that women are now the driving force behind adventure travel. Mr. Mallett, whose organization, with headquarters in Englewood, Colo., numbers 300 adventure-tour operators among the 10,000 he estimates to be active in this country, cited the impact of the social change in the 1970's and 80's. Women "have learned they don't have to do home ec," he said. "They can do track."

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: WHAT JAMIE SAW By Carolyn Coman. 126 pp. Arden, N.C.: Front Street. $13.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: Balkan Odyssey'
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;Who Calls Signals? On Giants, It's Brown
description: It could be only a matter of days before the Giants sign Dave Brown to a multiyear deal. The Giants are lucky. They are one of a few teams who will have their quarterback situation settled sooner rather than later.

title: Steinway Sources
description: To the Editor:

title: HORSE RACING;Cigar's Odyssey Begins With a Romp
description: Cigar, 1995's Horse of the Year, opened his 1996 campaign today with a smashing performance, winning the Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park by two lengths over his stablemate, Wekiva Springs, for his 13th victory in a row.

title: Hard Time
description: THE OXFORD HISTORY OF THE PRISON The Practice of Punishment in Western Society. Edited by Norval Morris and David J. Rothman. Illustrated. 489 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $39.95.

title: Shift of Holocaust Books Is a Disservice to Poles...
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MILL BASIN;Businesses Say A Zoning Curb Is Misguided
description: Residents on one side of Strickland Avenue are close to curbing the growth of their neighbors across the street. But those neighbors -- businesses that abut the still water of Mill Basin -- say they are being penalized because of community opposition to megastores.

title: WEDDINGS;Caroline Young, Daniel Sobelsohn
description: Caroline Sue Young, a daughter of Phyllis and Dr. Bruce K. Young of New York, was married last evening to Daniel Ethan Sobelsohn, a son of Ruth and Bernard Sobelsohn of Encino, Calif. Dr. Ronald Sobel, the senior rabbi at Temple Emanu-El, performed the ceremony in the Cotillion Room at the Pierre in New York.

title: Seoul-Tokyo Dispute
description: In a growing dispute over an island claimed by both Japan and South Korea, President Kim Young Sam of South Korea has canceled a meeting scheduled for Monday with Japanese legislators.

title: SPOTLIGHT;Small World
description: There are 20 million species in the exoskeletal city. And each one has a story, according to Alien Empire, a three-part, BBC-produced Nature series that delves into the lives of the insect world.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Against UConn, Seton Hall Gets That Sinking Feeling
description: Seton Hall had the unenviable distinction last season of being the only team to play and lose three games to the University of Connecticut women's basketball team en route to the Huskies' unbeaten season and their first national championship.

title: IN BRIEF;Casino Addition to Preserve Historic Theater's Facade
description: The facade of the Warner Theater, one of the last architectural remnants of Atlantic City's grand hotel era, will survive into the next century as the Boardwalk entrance to a 620-room expansion of Caesars Atlantic City casino hotel.

title: Apocalypse Soon
description: The End of the Age By Pat Robertson. 374 pp. Dallas: Word Publishing. $21.99. AS annus mirabilis 2000 approaches, we'd best start to deal with it: there will be Elijahs on every street corner, cable channel and Web site urging us to repent, repent, for the end is at hand. There's just something about an impending millennium that brings out the gloom and doom.

title: Corrections
description: The Minding Your Business column on Jan. 14, about estate planning, referred incorrectly to some features of a charitable lead trust, which lets people give money to charity while offsetting estate taxes. The trust is indeed required to pay taxes on any capital gains, but it receives a deduction for the amount it distributes each year to charity. While most such trusts are designed to avoid estate and generation-skipping taxes, a part of the assets may in fact be subject to these taxes, depending on the amount contributed, the estimated rate of return and the specified life of the trust.

title: HOCKEY;'Angels' Have A Devil Of a Game
description: In a contrived effort to add a bit of spark to a good, but grim, hockey team, the Devils have come up with the nickname Hell's Angels for their best forward line.

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;New Collectors Heat Up The Winter Season Buying
description: WHILE LONGTIME buyers were active everywhere last month during the winter antiques season in New York, it was the new collectors who reinvigorated the market for Americana. They paid some of the highest prices, and when they did not buy, their bids pushed up the prices, for what were some of the freshest goods seen in years.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: MIDTOWN Japanese Lacquerware In Many Modern Varieties

title: Some Advice to Heed, If Not Now, Tomorrow
description: HOW can American business become more productive? Think paper clips. About 20 billion are sold each year, but studies suggest that only about 20 percent are used as intended. The vast majority are twisted and mutilated, often in mindless reveries during downtime.

title: QUICK BITE;Hot Off the Griddle, Biker Style
description: How hot is hot? In terms of taste, answers vary. But there is a unit of measurement to gauge, in parts per million, concentrations of casaicin, the incendiary substance that occurs naturally in hot peppers. Jalapenos range from 2,500 to 10,000 Scoville units, but a typical habanero smolders between 200,000 and 300,000 S.U.'s, a level that can burn skin and eyes.

title: COPING;Cats, Dogs, the Dole and Payment Plans
description: I WAS laughing my head silly," Beverly Kidd said. "I particularly loved that headline 'Center Has Gone to the Dogs.' And Max is sooo happy. He finally got his revenge."

title: SAFE-SEX LIES
description: I appreciate Meghan Daum's honesty about her difficulty in practicing safer sex consistently ("Safe-Sex Lies," Jan. 21). I am glad her difficulties don't include a desperate search for medication to control intractable diarrhea, fears that her insurance company will not pay for treatments that keep her from going blind and panic over telling her children that she cannot care for them much longer. Many of the H.I.V.-infected people I work with used to have the same issues as Daum does. Now they have others.

title: For Nicknames, A Life of Their Own
description: The article ("What's in a Name? Old Industrial Fame," Jan. 21) contained a small error. Waterbury's Scoville plant is not vacant. It's nonexistent, having been razed months ago.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: SUNDAY The annual conference of the National Association of State Treasurers opens in Washington at the Capitol Hill Hyatt Regency.

title: Dog Show;Westminster: The Show of Shows
description: It is like the Super Bowl, except that you can't walk up to football players before and after the game and watch them get their hair styled. It is like the World Series, except that baseball players aren't rewarded with a bit of liver before they go to bat. It is like the Kentucky Derby, except that thoroughbred horses could not race once or twice a week year round, and certainly wouldn't fret if they did not

title: Balkan Odyssey'
description: To the Editor:

title: Coral Reefs
description: To the Editor: Your Dec. 24 articles about the squid surveys in Little Cayman ("Here's looking at You, Squid") and the thriving coral reefs in Bonaire ("Bonaire's Bountiful Depths") did an excellent job of describing wonders that divers experience. What the articles omitted, however, is background on why site like the Marine Park in Bonaire and Marive life surveys are so important.

title: GOLF;Nicklaus's Next Open Is to Be His Last
description: The greatest streak in the history of professional golf and one of the most imposing in any sport -- Jack Nicklaus's string of consecutive major championship appearances, which now stands at 136 -- will come to an end this year.

title: Ideas & Trends;Single Motherhood: Stereotypes vs. Statistics
description: NOTHING evokes fears that traditional family values are declining more than the steeply rising number of children born out of wedlock. The discouragement of illegitimacy is a major goal of proposed welfare changes that are edging closer to approval in Washington.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-19

title: Judge Upholds Penalty on Dow Chemical
description: A judge on Friday rejected a request by the Dow Chemical Company to throw out a $14 million jury award to a woman who said leaky breast implants had made her seriously ill.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: THE POET DYING Heinrich Heine's Last Years in Paris. By Ernst Pawel. Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: GERI BARISH is laughing. She laughs so hard that tears form under her bright red glasses. She is telling the story of how she found out that her house had burned down.

title: Russians Open Fire to End Chechen Protest
description: Local police officers backed by Russian troops fired tear gas and guns today in an attempt to break up a rally of least 1,000 protesters in the center of Grozny, the Chechen capital.

title: Study Finds Decline in Domestic Violence
description: A researcher said today that the number of women killed in domestic violence declined 30 percent from 1968 to 1993. In St. Louis and Chicago, two cities he studied, only 8 percent of all murders involved domestic partners. In 1970, the rate was 15 percent.

title: The Tree of Life Grows in Mexico
description: AN hour west of Mexico City, in a seemingly unrelated world of clean air, cornfields and a country pace, artisans in the town of Metepec shape clay into an unusual and delightful form: trees. Most represent stories -- against a backdrop of clay trunks and branches, Adam and Eve face temptation by the serpent, Noah tends to his Ark, or more modern scenes unfold in a world of painstaking intricacy.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 28 about Angkor, Cambodia, misstated the name of the builder of the Bayon, a temple at Angkor Thom. It was Jayavarman VII, not Jayavarman II.

title: Mayor's War Chest, and Who Filled It
description: Although New York City's mayoral election is 21 months off, the fund-raising race is well under way, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is demonstrating that the incumbent has the power to attract campaign contributions from a host of people, industries and interests.

title: Culinary Career Training By the Day
description: SO the time has come for a career change, and you've always wanted to be a chef. Or perhaps you love to cook and long to work alongside a professional. Whatever the motivation, you can now fulfill your fantasy here at the Rye Town Hilton Chef's Apprentice for a Day Program, where for $125 you can work alongside the hotel's chefs for a full 12-hour shift, or less if you choose. The hands-on experience includes a chef's outfit and an exceptional three-course lunch with the staff at the chef's table in the kitchen.

title: 2 Die in Clash With Police in Bangladesh
description: The police fired rubber bullets and tear gas and swung bamboo canes today to disperse anti-election protests that left two people dead and at least 90 wounded in Dhaka, the capital, and around the country.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Rumson, N.J.;Abundant Space, And on the Water
description: FLANKED by the Shrewsbury and Navesink Rivers and just a mile west of the Atlantic, Rumson has been a magnet for wealthy New York financiers for more than a century.

title: Word for Word/The Personals;Seeking Fine Mind/Body. Dog Lovers a Plus.
description: WITH its promise of young love, Valentine's Day may be the first harbinger of spring. Buds are not yet visible on trees, but personal ads sprout everywhere, evidence that no matter how many seasons of deprivation pass, the mating sap rises eternal.

title: Big Freeze of '34
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: EVERY KNEE SHALL BOW The Truth and Tragedy of Ruby Ridge and the Randy Weaver Family. By Jess Walter. Regan Books/HarperCollins, $24.
