title: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;Touring the World, With an Index as Your Guide
description: Q. What can you tell me about index funds that invest in major corporations in Europe, Asia and South America, much like the funds here in the United States?

title: New Lobbying Rules, From Bagels to Caviar
description: People who lobby Congress have to know the rules. But the advent of tougher lobbying restrictions has generated a whole new set of them. So lobbyists by the scores now find themselves pondering the Toothpick Rule, the Gravy Rule and, above all, the Bagel Rule.

title: That First Job
description: It's not a first romance, but a first job can live long in memory: That strange stint for a fruit-basket company in 1980. That summer selling shoes, when you picked up the secrets of the trade from gruff, lovable old Jack. The year after college, when you opened the mail for the Esperanto Society and worked on that (still undone) novel.

title: No Headline
description: Breakfast is sort of a funny meal. Coffee and doughnuts are O.K. Croissants are probably all right. But I get a lot of questions about bagels and what you can put on them. Lox may be pushing it."

title: On the Farm, Fertile Times
description: WHEN the Senate voted last week to phase out farm subsidies, some investors might have assumed the move would depress agricultural stocks. But, while the possible impact would be gradual, Wall Street analysts say such a change would probably turn out to be good news instead.

title: For One Teacher the Reward Is a Math Problem Solved
description: SUSAN KORNSTEIN can hide her 1995 Edyth May Sliffe Award for Distinguished High School Mathematics Teaching, but she can't hide her love for math or teaching.

title: PUBLIC INTEREST;Manhattan Community Board Meetings
description: DISTRICT 1 -- Battery Park, TriBeCa. Next meeting Feb. 20, 5:30 P.M. Stuyvesant High School, 345 Chambers Street and West Street; (212) 442-5050. Agenda:T.B.A.

title: As Funds Shrink, Is Special Ed Too Special?
description: IN a class full of squirming, chattering children, Ryan Lamson is a quiet exception. Born with limited muscle coordination, he cannot speak and depends on a walker. But rather than send him to a special program, his parents wanted Ryan to attend regular kindergarten at the Village School here.

title: U.N. Meeting on Urban Crises Draws Criticism on Financing
description: Four months before an international conference on urban crises around the world, organizers of the meeting are short of money and under fire from several Western countries demanding an investigation into conference accounts.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;What to Do When the Missiles Get Stolen
description: Bed of Roses Mary Stuart Masterson, Christian Slater Directed by Michael Goldenberg PG 87 minutes

title: Commercial Property/Equitable Life's Switch;A Short Move, but to a Wholly Different Mindset
description: LATER this year, employees of the Equitable Life Assurance Company will start moving into 1290 Avenue of the Americas, Olympia & York's huge building on 52d Street. Physically, some will just trek across the street, while others will come from a few neighborhoods away. Metaphorically, they will travel much farther.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL: 1997 Ford F-150;America's Best Seller Gets a Sequel
description: I HAVE long considered myself a mechanical sort, but vacuum cleaners are beyond me. That is why I traded in the cranky Kenmore for a new model and why I was sitting in this truck outside the store, awaiting a guy from the stockroom. And there he was, muscles bulging, toting a huge Bissell box, with a strange look on his face.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Mercker and Alicea Avoid Arbitration
description: The Baltimore Orioles avoided an arbitration hearing with KENT MERCKER by signing the left-hander yesterday to a one-year contract with an option for a second season. Mercker, 28, will receive $2.8 million plus incentives in 1996. He was traded to Baltimore on Dec. 17.

title: Runaway Cougar Scares and Excites Delaware Suburbs
description: Amanda Colton, a fifth-grader at P. S. du Pont Elementary School here, thinks her show-and-tell presentation might be the best that her school has seen in years. Amanda is the proud owner of a cougar paw print that was found four feet from her house and is now molded in putty.

title: INSIDE
description: Cooperation From Russia Yevgeny M. Primakov, the new Russain Foreign Minister, said Russia desired a close working relationship with the United States. Page 14

title: Water Is Restored After Main Breaks
description: Water service was restored today to all northern New Jersey communities affected by two major water main breaks that occurred here three days ago.

title: THE NEXT GENERATION;Casting Call to Curtain Call, With Just Days in Between
description: The Missoula Children's Theater may bill itself as one of the country's largest, even though the number of children in its touring company is zero. So how can this nonprofit company from Montana call itself large?

title: Romare Bearden's Iaages of the Black Experience, in Prints
description: "Romare Bearden as Printmaker" University Center, Adelphi University, Garden City. To Feb. 19. 877-4460.

title: ON THE STREET;The Men's Shows (Off the Runway)
description: There was no dominant look being worn by the men attending last week's men's-wear collections for next winter.

title: Historical Shows on Trial: Who Judges?
description: IN A TENSE POLITICAL CLIMATE, with budgets being cut sharply and Congress watching the Smithsonian Institution and every other Government program like a hawk, the secretary of the Smithsonian felt he had no choice but to insist that the head of one of the institution's divisions keep the controversial views of a prominent researcher on his staff quiet.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE;Drug Bazaar Sweep or Swap?
description: Washington Square Park once offered, in Henry James's words, "a kind of established repose which is not of frequent occurrence in other quarters of the long, shrill city." In recent decades, Villagers and tourists seeking the park's repose have been just as likely to be greeted with a steady chorus of "smoke, smoke" and "sense, sense," from drug dealers hawking marijuana and sensimilla, a potent strain of the drug.

title: Turtle Eggs = Prison for 2
description: Two Florida men have been sentenced to prison for digging up eggs from the beach nests of endangered turtles and planning to sell the eggs to local bar owners as a delicacy in drinks.

title: The Nation;States Rally Round a Cry For Less
description: THE governors who came up with a compromise last week to try to resolve the Federal budget impasse were not on a humanitarian mission to bring peace to Washington by pulling combatants from the Capitol's mud-wrestling pits. The governors' goal was power: to gain freedom from longstanding rules that tightly restrict how they can spend Federal money on welfare and other programs.

title: ON THE MAP;Address Unknown: House Numbers Are Few in Alpine
description: According to Stanley W. Bradley's "Crossroads of History: The Story of Alpine, N.J.," when Giovanni da Verrazano's sailors had filled their casks from a waterfall cascading down the great cliffs at the mouth of the vast, uncharted river, they put back out to sea without so much as marking the spot. Today, 472 years after the Italian explorer had Europeans' first recorded encounter with the North American mainland, there remains a conspicuous absence of markings in Alpine, where 1,700 modern-day settlers live atop the Palisades, high above the Hudson. Most of the houses in this affluent borough are not numbered. For mail, everyone has a post office box in the airy atrium at the borough hall.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Whitaker Charged With Assaulting Officer
description: PERNELL WHITAKER, the World Boxing Council welterweight champion, was arrested and briefly jailed early yesterday in San Antonio after scuffling with three off-duty officers during a party for the National Basketball Association's All-Star weekend.

title: February 4-10;Publishable or Perishable
description: What, exactly, is literary art? Yes, the age-old debate is back, slippery as ever. And it popped up in the strangest place last week: a Manhattan courtroom, normally the domain of cold, hard, provable facts.

title: FUNDS WATCH
description: A Banner Year For Money Funds

title: THE NEW JERSEY TRANSIT CRASH: THE DISPATCHER;A Calm Passenger With a Cellular Phone Guided the Police to the Wreck
description: The first call, from a cellular telephone, came in with such clarity that Kerri L. Taylor, the Secaucus police dispatcher who answered, was taken by surprise.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS;Dear Deli, Pleas Come Back
description: Love letters are not what you expect to find taped to the front door of a waterlogged neighborhood deli. But love letters are what you find stuck to the glass of Samad Deli, on Broadway between 111th and 112th Streets, which has been shuttered since a fire shortly before New Year's Day.

title: WEDDINGS;Mitsue Sakamoto, Morikazu Suzuki
description: Mitsue Sakamoto, a doctoral candidate at Yale University, was married yesterday to Morikazu Suzuki, an assistant vice president in New York with the treasury department of the Sumitomo Bank Ltd. The Rev. Yuri Ando performed the ceremony at the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: New Releases
description: KRIS KROSS: 'YOUNG, RICH AND DANGEROUS' Ruffhouse/Columbia

title: Westchester Settings Inspire Author of 'The Juror'
description: THE most famous Westchester juror these days is Annie Laird, a single woman who is Juror No. 224 in a criminal trial.

title: Finding Volunteers: Extra 90's Problems
description: Running Short on Volunteers" [Jan. 28] made some very interesting points with regard to the changing status of volunteers today. Budget cuts, changing roles, two-income families, limited time, etc. all play a role in the difficult task of recruiting and keeping a healthy volunteer force.

title: THE NATION: Old MacDonald Has a New Policy;Sowing Confusion on the Farm
description: THE universe, the British scientist J. B. S. Haldane once said, is "not only queerer than we suppose but queerer than we can suppose." The same could be said of American farm policy.

title: CHATTER;Placing Limits on Welfare
description: Governor Whitman has proposed a five-year limit on welfare payments. What do you think? How would you rate her performance so far?

title: Publishing's Grim Reaper
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WORLD: The China-and-Taiwan Problem;How Politics Torpedoed Asian Calm
description: TEN months ago, China and Taiwan were on the verge of opening their seaports to each other's shipping and inaugurating direct air service across the Taiwan Strait for the first time in nearly 50 years of barely suspended civil war. Now suddenly, pistols are drawn and the threat of military confrontation hangs in the air like grenade smoke.

title: EDUCATION;Only $8.50 a Pupil, but for the First Time It's for Computers
description: School superintendents were brooding last week as many learned that state aid to their districts would shrink in 1996-97. But there was one pleasant surprise: for the first time, New Jersey's $4 billion education budget will include separate funds for technology.

title: Confederacy Museum Provokes Dismay With Period-Costume Ball
description: The White House of the Confederacy, where Jefferson Davis plotted to save the South, was a hilltop landmark in one of this city's most aristocratic neighborhoods. Now, the Victorian mansion hunkers behind a 12-story hospital, out of sight and out of mind for most Richmond residents.

title: THE NIGHT;Honoring Lorraine Hansberry
description: LAST Sunday, the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, a branch of the public library in Harlem, presented a benefit tribute to Lorraine Hansberry, the author of "A Raisin in the Sun." It was an evening of art, politics, idealism and intellectual glamour.

title: POP VIEW;Rapper and Rocker: Meditations on Death
description: HOW MANY PEOPLE HAVE you killed in your lifetime?

title: Plan for Montauk Golf Course Raises Concerns
description: A PLAN for the possible development of a golf course on the site of Camp Hero State Park, a former military installation within the Montauk State Park complex, has raised concerns among townspeople and environmental groups in the area.

title: U.N. Election Fever;Ready. Set. Don't Run!
description: IN a season of Presidential primaries and caucuses, hard-hitting television spots, raucous bus convoys, pancake breakfasts and snowbound photo-ops, it is easy to miss the other election of 1996.

title: JERSEY;Fighting Crime the Small-Town Way
description: THERE'S a lot of talk now about how big-city crime has been reduced by "community policing," the idea that officers should routinely interact with citizens and not just roar off in a patrol car to respond to emergencies.

title: BOOK NOTES;Prolific Author of Books for the Young Leaves an Unpublished Legacy
description: WHEN she died of breast cancer last month at 48, Pam Conrad of Rockville Centre, a writer of books for children and young adults, had written more than her 19 published books. She left 11 unpublished works, 4 o' which were written after her illness had been diagnosed, more than three years ago.

title: FOOD;Sea Scallops Make a Juicy Partner With Endive and Fennel
description: SEA SCALLOPS pair beautifully with the flavors of cooked endive, radicchio and fennel. They are especially good glazed with orange juice and balsamic vinegar and served with braised fennel, which has a delicate anise flavor. I also like to serve them on a bed of slivered sauteed endives, sprinkled with lemon juice, or with grilled radicchio, which like endive loses its bitterness when cooked.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 14 about Siberia referred incorrectly to the sentences imposed on the Decembrists, a group of officers who led a rebellion against Czar Nicholas I in December 1825. A reader's letter received on Jan. 24 points out that all were given 10 or more years at hard labor, in addition to exile; none drew hard-labor sentences of only a few months. The article also misstated the title of Sergei Trubetskoy, a leader of the group. Another reader's letter, received on Jan. 22, points out that he was a prince, not a count.

title: The G.O.P.'s Grand New Struggle
description: Heavy, heavy, heavy is the mantle of inevitability. Just ask poor Bob Dole, the latest victim of the voters' quadrennial struggle to escape an arranged marriage. Inevitability panic is often associated with the Democrats, but Republicans are not immune. Witness the serial levitations from the Republican pack. First Steve Forbes, a trust-fund poster boy, surfs along as the lets-lower-my-taxes-even-if-we-have-to-raise-yours candidate. Then the Louisiana caucuses coughed up Pat Buchanan as the latest and most unlikely in a long line of Huey Long reincarnations. Now Lamar Alexander, who brags that he is less tired than Mr. Dole and less naive than Mr. Forbes, is moving up in Iowa.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Modell Wants Colts Name
description: With Cleveland managing to hold onto the Browns' nickname, Art Modell would like to call his team the Colts when it moves to Baltimore.

title: U.N. Avoids Evidence in Bosnia Killings
description: To the Editor:

title: City Guides
description: To the Editor: Ralph Schoenstein's "I'll Fake Manhattan" (Dec. 17) came as no surprise, but reflects my continuing disappiontment in the low standard of our nation's major sight-seeing company, Gray Lines.

title: SPOTLIGHT;For Love Alone
description: Vivien Leigh made a striking doomed heroine in ANNA KARENINA (1948), yet Britain's elaborate serving of the Tolstoy novel (directed by Julien Duvivier) couldn't dislodge Greta Garbo (Hollywood, 1935). Sor one thing, Garbo had a better leading man - and stronger plot motivation - in Fredric March, as the dashing home-wrecker Count Vronsky; Kieron Moore was pallid. As Anna's icy spouse, Basil Rathbone and (then) Ralph Richardson could have shaken hands across the Atlantic. Ms. Leigh projects passion and despair; her suicide scene is superb. Still, her Anna doesn't dominate the picture, on and off camera. Garbo's did - WED. at 11:30 P.M. on AMC

title: I.R.A. ISSUES CLAIM OF RESPONSIBILITY FOR LONDON BOMB
description: The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility today for the powerful bomb blast in East London on Friday night, saying the attack had been carried out on "direct instructions from the army leadership." More than 100 people were wounded in the explosion, and the police said tonight that they had found two bodies in the rubble.

title: Germany Honors G.I. Who Fought Art Looting
description: The war was over, and to the victors the spoils.

title: Coral Reefs
description: To the Editor: I was delighted to see the article about Bonaire, my favorite dive island. I've visited with my dive-buddy wife and many nondiving friends a dozen times over the years.

title: Phone Scarcity Complicates Fire Alarm Plan
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and fire officials first proposed shutting down New York City's fire alarm boxes more than a year ago, they said it would reduce false alarms and save $5 million a year. New Yorkers, they added, would be better served by the city's modern, expansive telephone system than by its antiquated network of 16,300 alarm boxes.

title: Liberties;Dot, Dot, Dot
description: Something darn strange is going on.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY;Living Large
description: There are plenty of pictures of extravagant houses in Priscilla Roosevelt's LIFE ON THE RUSSIAN COUNTRY ESTATE: A Social and Cultural History (Yale University, $45), but it's the extravagant human imagery that sticks in the mind: the young servants who skated on felt pads across the floors at Baturin, keeping acres of parquet at a perpetual high gloss; the entire Turkish cemetery, brought back as war booty, that Field Marshal Yury V. Dolgoruky transformed into the Slavic equivalent of garden gnomes; the eccentric bachelor, recalled by Baron Vrangel, who built a half-dozen houses on his country property, each in a different international style, fitted them out with appropriately attired harems and installed living statues outside, frozen in poses as Roman gods. Unfortunately for him, Venus and Hercules conspired: while she threw sand in his face, Hercules leaped down and clubbed him to death. The Bolshevik Revolution performed roughly the same function for the aristocracy as a whole, and with it disappeared a society that had become, in just over 200 years, what Ms. Roosevelt (a fellow of the Institute for European, Russian and Eurasian Studies at George Washington University) describes as "the crucible of Russian high culture." She takes pains to avoid turning her lushly illustrated exploration of that culture into Merchant-Ivory in sables, including enough talk of serfs, small landowners and members of the intelligentsia to remind us that the labors of a very great many enabled a very lucky few to sample hothouse pineapples in the dead of winter and enjoy private 40-man horn orchestras, in which each musician produced just a single note. For the rulers of Russia's rural fiefdoms, Ms. Roosevelt writes, life was "a study in contrasts, paradoxes and extremes." Small wonder, then, that in the 1750's, when Prince Nikita Trubetskoy commissioned his Baroque mansion in the hills above the Moscow River, he chose to call it Neskuchnoe -- "not boring." Alida Becker

title: SPOTLIGHT;Southern Gothic
description: Why are a distinguished bevy of Hollywood belles frankly hamming it up in a Gothic plantation yarn dripping moss and gore? Because horror was the trend - box-office gold - back in 1964, when Robert Aldrich directed Bette Davis, Olivia de Havilland, Agnes Moorehead, Mary Astor and poor Joseph Cotten in HUSH...HUSH, SWEET CHARLOTTE. The bulky old Louidiana mansion where they all collide is chilling in itself. Who comes closest to swallowing the camera? Viva Moorehead, rigged up like Mammy Yokum! And dig that hat - TUE. at 9:30 P.M. and TUE./EARLY WED. at 1:30 A.M. on AMC

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: VERONICA By Nicholas Christopher. Dial, $22.95.

title: YOUR HOME;Deductible Charges In a Co-op
description: CO-OP shareholders across the country have received, or will shortly receive, notifications of how much of their total maintenance payments can be deducted from their Federal income tax returns. Some will find they can deduct as much as 70 percent. Others, however, will discover they can deduct as little as 20 percent.

title: MAKING IT WORK;The Terminus of a Rose
description: AT 6 A.M., it's not pretty. On 28th Street from Seventh Avenue to Broadway, you, the retailer, have to pick your way between the icy puddles and the double- and triple-parked trucks. It's cold. You jump inside yet another wholesale shop, its shelves and cement floors covered in boxes and flowers and flower debris. Party planners, other retailers, grocers are checking out "product." The salesmen -- grizzled guys in from Long Island -- all seem loud.

title: Sunday February 11, 1996: HONEST, ABE;Ninescore And Seven
description: Abraham Lincoln, born 187 years ago tomorrow, is everyone's favorite Republican. But how many G.O.P. Presidential hopefuls are aware that one of the 16th President's legacies is the first Federal income tax? A progressive one at that. Lincoln, who died on April 15, signed the 1861 tax measure to help finance the Civil War. Even fewer folks probably care that he received a patent for a device to prevent ships from running aground. And while Ford's Theater has become a secular shrine in Washington, only a true trivialist knows that the house where John Wilkes Booth machinated, at 604 H Street N.W., is now a Chinese restaurant.

title: Our Towns;18 Minutes That Put a Day In Perspective
description: KAREN McCARTHY stepped out of the PATH train here Friday night and cursed her timing. All these crowds.

title: The Official G.I.'s Guide to Staying Out of Trouble
description: THE United States Army has given its troops a few useful phrases for their stay in Bosnia:

title: L.I. VINES
description: Chardonnay Reserve Pugliese Vineyards, Cutchogue, 1994. About $13.

title: Snags in Air Crash Inquiry
description: Investigation of the crash of a jetliner into the Atlantic that killed all 189 people aboard has been hobbled by a shortage of salvageable wreckage and dozens of missing bodies.

title: The Threshold of Suffering
description: FACING THE EXTREME Moral Life in the Concentration Camps. By Tzvetan Todorov. Translated by Arthur Denner and Abigail Pollak. 307 pp. New York: Metropolitan Books/ Henry Holt & Company. $27.50.

title: VOWS;Jane Perlov and Robert Maas
description: INSPECTOR JANE PERLOV, the first female commanding officer of the Police Department's 30th Precinct in Harlem grew up in a sprawling Upper West Side apartment filled with oil paintings, Oriental rugs, bookcases and overstuffed armchairs that make reading Victorian novels in one sitting easy.

title: On the Road in Iowa
description: On the final weekend before the caucuses, Iowans got an eyeful of political activity. Senator Phil Gramm looked for help from Charlton Heston. Patrick J. Buchanan emphasized his anti-abortion credentials. Senator Bob Dole worked to maintain hislead over Steve Forbes. But the Republicans did not have the stage to themselves: President Clinton dropped by.

title: Florida Killer Said Victims Were Racists, Police Say
description: A man who killed five former co-workers left a suicide note saying he wanted "to punish some of the cowardly, racist devils" responsible for dismissing him from his city job, the authorities said today.

title: SOAPBOX;Governor, Meet My Mother
description: GOVERNOR WHITMAN calls her proposal to overhaul New Jersey's welfare system "tough love at its best." I call it shortsighted, and I speak from experience.

title: The State of Politics and the Baileys
description: WITHOUT question, Connecticut's best known political family in this century is named Bailey.

title: Rio Frets as Michael Jackson Plans to Film Slum
description: In the sweltering heat of a summer afternoon in the hillside slum of Santa Marta, a toddler cools herself under the water dripping from a rag that dangles from a wire stretched high above her head. Raw sewage runs down the hills, sending nauseating odors like curses through the neighborhood. Drug dealers stand at checkpoints along winding alleys.

title: Patients Most Wee, Most Vulnerable
description: SHE was barely bigger than two adult hands cupped together, her pink flesh as transparent as the plastic wrap that cocooned the warming table she lay on. Fat strips of white tape, crisscrossed her delicate cheeks and neck, snugly holding the clear, green plastic cone that pushed oxygen in and out of her lungs. It was one of about a half-dozen lifelines hooked up to a red-blinking, green-bleeping overhead monitor.

title: A Mail-In Ballot For New York, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday February 11, 1996: WHOOPEE TI YI YO;Getting the Boot
description: Howdy, cowboy. You look a mite discomforted. Dying in your boots? Walk out on the streets of Laredo. There's a new boot out there that's as much sneaker as work shoe. Rope a few dogies, bust a bronc, break for a quick b-ball game, ride the fences, take a doodah down Broadway -- do it all with your boots on, because they're for range rovers and downtown dandies alike. "If you grew up in sneakers," says Neale Attenborough, president of the Laredo Boot Company, "you're not going to want the traditional clunky boot." So Laredo, which is actually in Nashville, has unclunked it with a line called Performair, featuring lightweight leather uppers, urethane "molded air" soles and insoles made of ethyl vinyl acetate, every cowboy's favorite substance. The 12-inch-high Western model shown above, complete with pointy toes and 1 1/2-inch heels, is due in stores this spring for $129. Its six-month-old, midcalf cousin, the Roper, has already become a favorite on the rodeo circuit.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Flaky Golf

title: CYBERSPACE AND ART;A Danger To the Eyes
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Winter Overhauls, Spring Thrills
description: Walt Jocketty is like a child who knows he's getting a cornucopia of toys for his birthday, but he still has to wait several days before he can open it and begin playing with them. Unlike the child, though, Jocketty knows what's in his sack. He just can't wait to see how the ingredients fit and play together.

title: Flight to Russia
description: To the Editor: A letter to the editor on Dec. 3 complained of an unpleasant experience on Finnair en route to Russia. I am writing to give Finnair credit for the especially courteous service I recieved in May.

title: Li Sung Li, North Korean Nuclear Scientist, 91
description: Li Sung Li, a scientist known as the father of North Korea's nuclear energy program, died on Thursday after a long illness, the North's official radio reported. He was 91.

title: Lester L. Luntz, 72, A Dentist-Detective
description: Dr. Lester L. Luntz, a pioneer in the field of forensic dentistry, died on Tuesday at his home here. He was 72.

title: In the Region/Connecticut;Just 10 Miles From Foxwoods, a 2d Indian Casino
description: HIDDEN in the rolling hills of southeastern Connecticut, just east of Interstate 395, an enormous Indian gambling casino is taking shape. It will be called the Mohegan Sun Casino and Resort and it will open in Montville in October, four years after the highly successful Foxwoods Resort Casino began operating in Ledyard, 10 miles to the east.

title: MUSIC;The Three B's Plus Other Familiar Work
description: A FEW 20th-century pieces infiltrate the repertory, but for the most part it's golden oldie time on the classical scene this week, with Bach, Mozart, Haydn and Beethoven leading the way, Mendelssohn, Brahms and sundry romantic-era colleagues following not too far behind.

title: THE NEW JERSEY TRANSIT CRASH: THE ROUTINE;For Engineers, a Kinship Born of Solitude
description: Late Friday night, about an hour apart, four engineers brought their trains to a halt here, at the end of the New Jersey Transit Bergen Line. On the way across the marshes west of Hoboken, N.J., they had passed the wreckage of two trains run by longtime colleagues who were now dead, along with one passenger.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LONG ISLAND CITY;Group Tells Citibank: Nice Tower, Ugly Sign
description: After working as a writer in Rome for 36 years, George Armstrong concedes that his esthetic and architectural standards might be a little high. Still, Mr. Armstrong left Italy and moved back to the United States about three years ago, willingly forsaking Bernini and Michelangelo for a neighborhood graced by sights like the Swingline stapler factory.

title: John D. Mattus, AIDS Patients' Advocate, 44
description: John D. Mattus, an entrepreneur and advocate for people with AIDS, died on Jan. 31 at his home in Manhattan. He was 44.

title: Build a Road and What Do You Get?
description: To the Editor:

title: CD-ROM's;From T. R. to O. J.
description: OUR TIMES The Illustrated History of the 20th Century. Edited by Lorraine Glennon. Illustrated. 713 pp. Book: Atlanta: Turner Publishing. $65.

title: Fiscal Fraud Cited in Pact With Hospital
description: An audit of the city's contract with Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons to provide medical care at Harlem Hospital has found "widespread fiscal mismanagement," including $3.76 million that was fraudulently billed, misspent or unaccounted for by the medical school during the last fiscal year.

title: New Releases
description: SOUNDTRACK: 'HEAT' Warner Brothers

title: BOOKEND;My Life: A Proposal
description: TODAY marks the beginning of the 10th year I've spent on my novel "Dripping." Still convinced it will encompass everything I've learned from Chekhov, those exquisite small epiphanies in which nothing happens and all is revealed. To think there are those who don't realize how hard it is to achieve this mixture of mysterious everyday realism and emotional reticence! Especially in a passage like this:

title: The Killing Of a Somali Jars Canada
description: Three years after Canadian peacekeepers tortured and killed a Somali teen-ager, an investigation into one of the most jarring episodes in recent Canadian history is spurring charges of cover-up, conspiracy, interference and incompetence high in the military command.

title: Americans Keep On Trucking, and Big Pickups Still Pull Their Weight
description: In the 1980's, Americans packed their expanding families into a new breed of light truck, the mini-van. In the 90's, they've explored the wilds of suburbia in knobby-tired all-terrain vehicles. But through it all, the pickup market has steadily grown -- up 62 percent from 1980 to 1995, according to data from Ward's Auto Infobank, which compiles information on the auto industry.

title: FILM VIEW;Down To the Sea On Film
description: IN THE MOVIE "WHITE SQUALL," which stars Jeff Bridges as the captain of a prep school training ship, we encounter the sea in the most horrifying of her moods. The white squall of the title -- a rare and dreaded freak of nature -- is brilliantly recreated, a tantrum that we can barely conceive of, an act of wind and water that claims the ship, the captain's wife, another crew member and four students. The storm is so violent and sudden it is deemed a fantasy in the courtroom scene that ends the film: a courtroom scene in which the captain is charged with failing to adequately command his boat.

title: THE DYING ROOMS';A Neutral Observer's Perception
description: To the Editor:

title: Multiple Births Don't Always End Happily
description: To the Editor:

title: State Would Make School Boards Pay Some Costs for the Disabled
description: IF Gov. George E. Pataki's budget is adopted as proposed, it would shift $21 million a year in spending for disabled Long Island preschoolers to school districts.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;You Do? Congratulations. Next!
description: NEITHER Donna Thomas of Pennsauken nor her fiance, Philip Simpson of Moorestown, is a gambler. But they plan to be married at Harrah's on Wednesday at noon.

title: VIEWPOINT: ELI M. NOAM;The Airwaves as a Toll Road
description: WHEN President Clinton signed the telecommunications act into law on Thursday, one of the major unresolved issues was whether television broadcasters should pay for their licenses for next-generation digital TV. Senator Bob Dole insists that they should. And the most-discussed way would be through an auction in which they would bid, just like mobile phone operators, for the spectrum they plan to use.

title: She Made Them Dance
description: One seldom has cause, these days, to complain that a new biography of a woman makes insufficient use of the gender card, but Carol Easton's life of Agnes de Mille is one of those rare occasions. In the 1940's, de Mille was, by her own account, "the best-known choreographer in America -- not the best, but the best known." Dance is a woman's field, but as de Mille pointed out, it was ceded to women only because men didn't consider it important enough to reserve it for themselves. Furthermore, the area in which she made her deepest mark was not concert dance, the women's preserve, but musical comedy a genre more dominated by men -- men who, furthermore, regarded dancing as employment for the backer's girlfriends. De Mille's struggle to be taken seriously in that world is a classic women's tale.

title: FRENCH CULTURE;A Sign Of Good Taste
description: To the Editor:

title: Block Grant Plan Will Hurt Drug Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday February 11, 1996: HEY, KID!;Want Some Candy?
description: With 12-year-old felons far too common, the notion of children being seen and not heard has become a bit of a stretch. But a Seattle lawyer named Simmie Baer gives that Victorian injunction modern application: it's what she, as head of the public defender's juvenile division, tells kids to do when they get arrested. "Don't talk," she says. "It's the little bit of power you have."

title: Thomas Harris, 83, Elections Official And Labor Lawyer
description: Thomas Everett Harris, a veteran labor lawyer who was one of the original members of the Federal Election Commission and served as its chairman, died on Tuesday in Alexandria Hospital in Alexandria, Va. He was 83 and lived in Alexandria.

title: LIVES;How I Lost Money in the Bull Market
description: I was born a United States citizen, but last year I became a true American. I went from renting my space in the marketplace to owning it. I started buying stocks.

title: As Europe's Borders Fall, the Old Art of Bootlegging Thrives
description: On the docks at Calais, just across the wintry water from here in France, a line of innocuous white vans with British license plates waited the other day to board the Pride of Dover car ferry for the 90-minute trip to England.

title: A Sweet Deal for General Electric
description: The General Electric Company is one of New York State's biggest employers, providing 13,000 jobs at 7 major sites. It is also one of state's biggest polluters. According to a state report released last year, its silicone factory at Waterford caused more toxic ground pollution than any other plant in the state for the seventh straight year.

title: Chile
description: To the Editor: I'd like to second Margo Kaufman's observation about the postcard paucity in Chile ("Through the Dust, Alpine, Beauty" Dec. 17) I was at the airport in Santiage three years ago and saw only empty postcard racks. I wanted to photograph them to justify any lack of correspondence.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;Goldfinger's Inner Circle
description: THE bass was bumping so loud from Goldfinger's pawnshop that the plate glass window was rattling like a box of Chiclets. Inside, two men strained to hear while Borngod Allah, hands and braids flailing, bellowed about a deal done wrong.

title: Yellowstone Wolves Get An Ally in Tourist Trade
description: Loping through the snowy wilderness of the Continental Divide near here, a lone gray wolf is an advance scout for the latest battle in the West's "wolf wars."

title: Through the Gorge to Petra
description: DON'T rush to reach Petra. The approach is what establishes the mystery of the city carved from rose-red rock: the endless, winding, sometimes eerie passage. It was this forbidding corridor that struck awe into the ancient traders whose caravans paused here on their trek across the deserts, and it is this gorge that still makes the entry to Petra less a passage than a transition.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Generic Oppression, Anger and Protest
description: IT'S been 30 years since the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X had their say, and "nothing's changed," Winston Jones bellows. "The sickness still ain't cured." But "violence is not the answer," Freeman Charles replies.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;What to Do When the Missiles Get Stolen
description: White Squall Jeff Bridges, John Savage, Scott Wolf, Jeremy Sisto, Eric Michael Cole Directed by Ridley Scott PG-13 128 minutes

title: Tarrytown Church Acts on Bell Tower
description: STARTING last fall when parishioners at the 160-year-old Christ Episcopal Church here cast their eyes upward, it was not only for divine guidance. They were also contemplating the 2,000-pound towar bell, which posed the increasingly perilous threat of crashing down on them.

title: Correction
description: A front-page picture caption on Jan. 28 about an art class for cancer patients at Stamford Hospital misidentified a woman holding pins made by the class. She was Jean Hall, a cancer survivor who still attends classes, not Jo Woodhall.

title: World News Briefs;Zaire Plans to Close Rwanda Refugee Camps
description: Zaire said today that it would gradually begin closing 40 camps holding a million Rwandan refugees, prompting some refugees to leave the camp that is expected to be shut down first.

title: ART;Eclectic Exhibition by Neighbors in Rye
description: THOUGH hardly a SoHo, Kirby Lane North here is a creative enclave and is the subject of an exhibition at the Rye Arts Center, one of two under review.

title: Odd Man Out
description: With the best and the brightest coming on strong, navy pinstripes just won't cut it.

title: Chile
description: To the Editor: At the Miami airport on our way home from Chile, we enjoyed reading "Close to Nature in Chile's Lake Country" (Dec. 17), about the area that we'd so recently visited.

title: HOME CLINIC;Steam to Heat House Can Provide Comfort and Dependability
description: STEAM heating is the hydronic heating system that uses steam to carry the heat from the furnace into the rest of the house.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: EAST;Without Much Celebration, Fordham Earns a Victory
description: Fordham 68, Dayton 58

title: World News Briefs;Burmese Refuse To Extradite Drug Lord
description: The Burmese Government has refused to extradite a reputed opium lord to the United States, where he is wanted on heroin trafficking charges.

title: Connecticut Q&A: William J. Cibes Jr.;The Many New Threads of Higher Education
description: WILLIAM J. CIBES JR., the president of the Connecticut State University System, is probably better known to the public as former Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s budget director, the one who, more than anyone else, linked himself to the state income tax that the General Assembly adopted. Indeed, Mr. Cibes, when he ran unsuccessfully for the Democratic nomination for Governor in 1990, was the only candidate who openly advocated a state income tax.

title: Computer Lesson
description: A mere 12 years ago, Apple Computer brought forth the Mac and changed history. But Apple, reeling from unprecedented losses, has been struggling to stay independent. At the very best, it must make itself over, probably through downsizing, which threatens to leave its Mac Revolution sadly incomplete.

title: DIARY
description: AGRICULTURE

title: City Hall: Wrecker's Ball or New Life?
description: STAMFORD, which was founded in 1641, is a city with a considerable past. But little of it is evident downtown or when driving in and out of a city where over the last three decades scores of landmarks have been torn down in a seemingly unending urban renewal project. To many people, the redevelopment has shown little regard for history and has left the city barely recognizable, even to those who grew up there.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;What to Do When the Missiles Get Stolen
description: Shopping Jonathan Pryce, Marianne Faithfull, Jude Law, Sadie Frost, Sean Pertwee Directed by Paul Anderson No rating 87 minutes

title: Cuttings;Here are the Seeds. Can a Garden be Far Behind?
description: Last summer, as I cut a few precious stems of golden yarrow and Shasta daisies from the pots on my Brooklyn roof, I realized how much I miss growing armloads of cut flowers. This year, I'm determined to have enough to fill every room.

title: How a Girl Became An Ordinary 4th Grader
description: LINDA and JAMES CARROLL of Miller Place noticed that their daughter Jenny had problems when she was as year old. "She just wasn't reaching the milestones she was supposed to," said Mrs. Carroll.

title: SIGNOFF;Memories Of a Czar, Not Only Of the End
description: ALMOST 80 years after their execution, the last Czar of Russia and his family continue to fascinate. And with good reason. The story of the fall of the Romanov dynasty has all the makings of a romance novel: historical sweep, ill-fated love, mysticism, mystery and violent death.

title: The Insurance Cost Of Long-Term Care
description: To the Editor:

title: February 4-10;A Quark Divided
description: Since 1963 when the quark theory of matter was born, physicists have regarded quarks -- the particles that make up the protons and neutrons within the nuclei of atoms -- as indivisible. Like electrons, quarks were thought to be "point particles," without external dimensions and without internal structures. But experimenters at Fermilab in Illinois, which operates the world's most powerful accelerator, have turned up evidence that the quark itself may contain still smaller components.

title: Yoshinari Yamashiro, Steel Executive, 72
description: Yoshinari Yamashiro, the chairman of the NKK Corporation, Japan's second-largest steelmaker, died Tuesday evening at the Keio University hospital in Tokyo. He was 72.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: AGUA SANTA: HOLY WATER By Pat Mora. Beacon, $17.95.

title: John Paynter, 67, Authority on Marching Bands
description: John Philip Paynter, who became a leading authority on marching and concert bands in 43 years as director of bands at Northwestern University near Chicago, died last Sunday in Glenview Hospital at the age of 67. A resident of Glenview, Ill., he had been admitted on Jan. 23 after suffering a stroke.

title: Holiday tomorrow
description: Lincoln's birthday is tomorrow.

title: Q. & A.
description: Refusing Section 8 Tenants

title: Proving to Mr. Dithers That It's Time for a Raise
description: CATHY HOOT used to subscribe to the Dagwood Bumstead theory of getting a raise: throw yourself at the boss's mercy. It didn't always work.

title: Pupils Get a Jump on Kindergarten
description: WITH shy smiles and tentative glances, parents filed into classrooms at the Church Street Elementary School here, ready to meet offspring engaged in computer games, a sand table, arts and crafts, blocks, puzzles and imaginative play in a dress-up corner.

title: Talking Sports With the Babe
description: BACK on the air after a commercial, Nanci Donnellan spun her chair around to face the control room and paused for an introduction to her s'ow: "And now, the woman who thought Super Bowl XXX was a film playing at a Times Square movie house. . . ."

title: SHOWDOWN AT YAZOO INDUSTRIES
description: I found Lisa Belkin's "Showdown at Yazoo Industries" (Jan. 21) compelling. Having survived one of the most successful strikes in recent years (the Association of Professional Flight Attendants, in November 1993), I read the article with the fervor of one who belonged to an underdog (largely female) union.

title: In the Region/Long Island;Retail Industry Gloom Fails to Deter Major Projects
description: DESPITE slumping sales, rising bankruptcy filings and consolidations by large store chains that are threatening to create substantial retail vacancies by the end of the year, developers are moving forward with major retail projects on Long Island.

title: MUSIC;Sarah Lawrence Offers Odd Couple
description: GUILLAUME De MACHAUT and Duke Ellington would seem to be an exceedingly odd couple as composers, but how often does the viola da gamba specialist Judith Davidoff share a program with the jazz vocalist Katchi Cartwright?

title: ART;At Yale Gallery, Buddhist Works From Asia
description: MID-WINTER days seem especially conducive to contemplation. An exhibition that fosters this sensation, and educates at the same time, is "Compassion and Transcendence in Buddhist Art," a show of 30 works from the permanent Asian collection of the Yale University Art Galley. While viewers gain a deeper understanding of the principles of compassion and transcendence, they also travel a bit. The show features distinctive art forms from China, Japan and Tibet.

title: A Machine That's Got Moxie
description: After turning the game into a positional battle with a pawn sacrifice that splintered Gary Kasparov's formation and exposed his king, the I.B.M. chess computer, Deep Blue, went over to the kind of sharp tactical play what machines are supposed to go for. And the result was spectacular.

title: February 4-10;Big Brother is Watching
description: From one coast to the other, American police departments have begun to set up video cameras and listening devices to monitor and record what goes on in the nation's streets.

title: TELEVISION;ABC Sends a Young Point of View Into the Field
description: Anderson Cooper recalls being stuck at an airport in Rwanda in 1994, weighed down by luggage and video camera, and watching enviously as a CBS News crew left a plane, got into a waiting car and sped off. "At that point, the highest priority in life was a vehicle," he said.

title: DINING OUT;An Old Friend on the Japanese Frontier
description: THE sign above the door at Inaka East in Manhasset reads "since 1995," but lovers of Japanese food will recognize an old friend. This is not a 1990's Asian palace where Japanese fare is an afterthought or a s'ngle page on a voluminous multinational, largely Chinese menu.

title: Trainer's Guide to How to Make Money and Influence Animals
description: THEY ambled into class, the shaggy and the fine haired, the long nosed and the blunt nosed, the rambunctious and the timid. Taking seats on the floor, they waited quietly until the teacher began her lesso', regarding her with limpid, puppy eyes. Something about the young woman made the young dogs listen. That's why Sarah Hodgson, author, inventor, animal trainer and entrepreneur, is something of a phenomenon at the age of 29.

title: Blockade of Oil Wells in Mexico Could Imperil Election Reforms
description: A blockade of dozens of oil wells in southern Mexico by local Indians and members of an opposition political party has cost Mexico more than $8.5 million in lost revenues over the last 12 days, officials say, and is creating a political standoff that threatens national electoral reforms.

title: Foreign Affairs;Three Little Words
description: Watching the Republican primary campaign reminds me of something that I've been feeling for some time now: The Republicans have no foreign policy.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;Cairo Cancels Exhibition Planned for 5 U.S. Cities
description: A PLANNED exhibition of ancient Egyptian artifacts in the United States has been canceled after a dispute between Egyptian and American organizers over financial arrangements for what authorities in Cairo had hoped would be a five-city tour.

title: Franz Reichsman, 82, Medical Professor
description: Dr. Franz K. Reichsman, an expert in psychosomatic medicine, died on Jan. 30 at a nursing home in Vernon, Vt. He was 82 and had suffered a number of strokes over several years.

title: The Sun Shines Again In Brazil and Argentina
description: THE stock markets of Argentina and Brazil staged startling comebacks in the first month of 1996, and they have now recovered all the losses suffered after stocks were dragged down by Mexico's financial crisis.

title: Salman Rushdie and the Zogoibys
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bulldozer Hits a Roadblock
description: JACQUES CHIRAC HAS JUST WON A SEVEN-YEAR term as President of France, and Paris, where he has been Mayor for 18 years, is holding a street party. Young people tooting horns and waving banners with Chirac's apple-tree campaign symbol pour into the Place de la Concorde for a celebratory rock concert. Chirac, a conservative neo-Gaullist promising "fundamental change" to a country profoundly unsettled by years of high unemployment and economic uncertainty, is sprayed with Champagne as he thanks supporters for helping him win nearly 53 percent of the vote. Then he gets into a gray Citroen sedan and heads back to the Hotel de Ville, pursued by television cameramen on motorcycles. Noisy celebrations continue thropgh the warm spring night.

title: SAFE-SEX LIES
description: Though I am not brave enough to disclose certain personal experiences in the way that Daum does, I think I'm safe in saying that she accurately and eloquently speaks for an awful lot of us in that peer group. An older colleague derided the article as self-absorbed and self-pitying, complaining that the answer to the woes described is, simply, abstinence. Yet, he admitted that he had lived in the blissful era of free love -- free of AIDS. He was perfectly willing to devalue our sense of loss.

title: The L.I.R.R. Should Listen to Its Riders
description: I have been a Mail and Ride subscriber for several years. I love the convenience of obtaining a monthly ticket without having to stand on line. However, I also love my Sayville stationmaster. His service is far greater than just selling tickets to regular commuters.

title: Sunday February 11, 1996: DUELING WARHOLS;15 Minutes, and Then Some
description: Let's do a movie," Andy Warhol was fond of saying. This year, two film makers are resurrecting the true King of Pop, who died in 1987, with movie moments extending well beyond the artist's requisite 15 minutes. In "I Shot Andy Warhol," directed by Mary Harron and scheduled to be released in early April, Jared Harris portrays Warhol in the days leading up to his shooting by Valerie Solanas, the feminist revolutionary. Coincidentally picking up where "I Shot" leaves off, Julian Schnabel, celebrity artist of the 80's, makes his directorial debut with "Build a Fort, Set It on Fire," a bio-pic about the graffiti artist Jean-Michel Basquiat that is due this summer. The superstar-everything David Bowie plays the Wigged One.

title: The Invisible Family
description: REMEDIOS DEVERA CEASED TO EXIST three hours after sunrise on the morning of July 18, 1994. Her rebirth began at the end of a long driveway in a tract of cheap plantation housing, carved out of a cane field high above the Pacific on the lush Hamakua Coast of Hawaii.

title: CD-ROM's;Pieces of the Frame
description: THE NATIONAL GALLERY COMPLETE ILLUSTRATED CATALOGUE Compiled by Christopher Baker and Tom Henry. Illustrated. 790 pp. London: National Gallery Publications/ Yale University Press. $75. With CD-ROM (Windows and Macintosh), $150.

title: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;In Political Quest, Forbes Runs in Shadow of Father
description: There are moments during the indignities of his Presidential campaign when Steve Forbes wonders what "Pop" would have thought of it all.

title: Serbs Appear To Ease Stand On NATO
description: The Bosnian Serbs appeared today to back away from the hard-line position that they might sever ties with the NATO-led forces deployed to oversee the Bosnian peace agreement. NATO officials said that despite an order from the Bosnian Serb military commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic, to cut all contact with peacekeeping troops, there was continued cooperation at the military unit level in several areas.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK;The Clippers' Barry Hits the High Notes In His Jam Session
description: With Alonzo Mourning bowing to him and the league's fraternity of All-Stars standing and high-fiving at courtside, Brent Barry, the gangly son of the Hall of Famer Rick Barry, took flight from the free throw line tonight with the ball held high above his head like a torch.

title: The Usual Spats Over Nominees For Foreign Films
description: THIS YEAR SEEMS typical when it comes to the Oscar race for best foreign-language film. That is to say, complaints and conspiracy theories are rampant. And, as usual, they center on why certain films were not nominated by their respective counpries and how difficult it is to change the eligibility rules. The five selected films will be announced on Tuesday, along with other Oscar nominations.

title: U.S. Warns Against Tests for Breast Implants
description: The Government warned doctors this week about unapproved tests for women worried about their silicone breast implants and urged the use of more traditional tests like magnetic resonance imaging, or M.R.I.

title: Leonard Braun, 73, Public Transit Official, Dies
description: Leonard Braun, a former vice chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and Federal transportation official, died on Monday at North Shore University Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. Mr. Braun, a resident of Great Neck, L.I., was 73.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Joseph Mindell, 86, Broker and Author
description: Joseph Mindell, an early proponent of using monetary indicators like interest rates and the money supply to make stock market decisions, died on Feb. 4 at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York. Mr. Mindell, a resident of Manhattan, was 86.

title: MARATHON;A New Face Emerges In Marathon
description: When Jenny Spangler drew away from the field at Mile 16 of the United States Olympic women's marathon trials, the favorites were unsure how to respond. Spangler wore No. 61 on her bib today, which meant that 60 runners had faster qualifying times. Surely, she would tire and fade like a pair of old jeans. The other contenders knew nothing about her, including her name.

title: Salman Rushdie and the Zogoibys
description: To the Editor:

title: LIVING TOO LONG
description: My wife is "Aunt Millie's" daughter, whom Michael Norman artfully inclu'es in the "cousins" who worry about her health ("Living Too Long," Jan. 14). Michael's claim that he alone is concerned for Mom's "soul" and "her state of being" is belied by my wife's daily calls, her availability whenever necessary and frequent contact with her grandchildren and extended family on both coasts.

title: VILLAINS ON FILM;Putting Iago In Perspective
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudi Arabia Economy Is Looking Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Matching Instruments to Period Music
description: SEVERAL members of the Orchestra of the 18th Century from Amsterdam crashed our rehearsal!" exclaimed Thomas Crawford, the normally mild-mannered conductor of the Fairfield Orchestra. "The word is out!"

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, an article on page 18 of the Arts and Leisure section today about nominations for the Academy Award for best film in a foreign language in 1995 misstates the history of two nominated films. "Underground," the entry from Yugoslavia, was not shown to an Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences committee in a 25-minute version; after a postponement over a legal conflict, it was shown to the committee, and rereleased in Europe, in a version 25 minutes shorter than the original. "French Twist," the entry from France, was not chosen at the expense of "Wild Reeds"; "Wild Reeds" was the French entry a year ago.

title: Also Around Town
description: POSTER ART - Henryk Tomaszewski, the Polish artist, will be honored with a retrospective exhibition of his posters. The School of Visual Arts, 209 East 23d Street; tomorrow through March 1; Monday-Thursday 9 A.M. to 8 P.M., Friday and Saturday 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; free; (212) 592-2011.

title: Developer Threatens To Sue Over Indian Site
description: AFTER three months of public hearings, which probed the archeological and cultural value of an ancient Indian site here, the developers who want to build town houses on the land brought a more pressing concern to the fore last week: the threat of a lawsuit.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Jan. 28 with an art review of "American Vanguards" at the Nassau Museum in Roslyn Harbor misidentified two works. The center image was Marsden Hartley's "Musical Theme (Oriental Symphony)." The work on the right was Stuart Davis's "Music Hall."

title: COVER STORY;Brandy, Pop Star, Plays a Teen-Ager, Though Not Just Any Teen-Ager
description: By the time she turned 16 last year, the pop star Brandy Norwood had a platinum-selling debut album, a No. 1 hit single, an opening act on Boyz II Men's national tour and a heap of effusive press clips. (Vibe magazine described her voice as "a spine-chilling vibrato laced with rhythm-and-blues and gospel inflections.")

title: FILM;Into the Municipal Maelstrom
description: Ken Lipper, New York City's (and maybe the world's) best-connected screenwriter, tells a story about his introduction to the relentless deal-making that goes on behind the scenes in municipal politics, the milieu of his new film, "City Hall."

title: O'Rourke's Raise Draws Much Ire
description: LATE last year, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke convinced county legislators and many constituents that dramatic measures must be taken to downsize government. That meant privatizing some county services, eliminating 800 jobs, consolidating departments and reducing travel, meal and car expenses. Mr. O'Rourke's goal: a saving of $2.6 million.

title: BASEBALL;Mo Vaughn's Chilly Winter
description: For most major league ballplayers, the vacation is about to end. Yet for Mo Vaughn, it has just begun, in the gymnasiums and batting cages of Fort Myers, Fla., refuges where Vaughn is seeking not only to gear up for the 1996 season but also to unwind from one of the most intense and intriguing off seasons in his career.

title: Doilies and Lace, the Makings of Valentines
description: ALMOST 100 valentines make up an exhibition called "Wilt Thou Be Mine," at the Bush-Holley House through Feb. 23. The house in the Cos Cob section of Greenwich -- the site of the first Impressionist art colony in America in the late 19th century and now a national historic landmark -- is the home of the Historical Society of the Town of Greenwich. The exhibition is made up of pieces that come the society's archives and from private collections including that of the town historian, William E. Finch Jr.

title: IN BRIEF;2 Bills Intended to Stanch The Flow of Jobs
description: Like much of the Northeast, New Jersey has been losing jobs for the last decade, most recently the 7,000 cut by AT&T. Last year, Mercer County alone lost 6,000.

title: The Big City;Fab Dads and Wanton Wives
description: MEN AND WOMEN SHARE ONE GREAT EROTIC fantasy, but they don't like to admit 't to each other. Those supposedly intimate cards they send on Valentine's Day are just store-bought sentiments to please the recipient. To glimpse their real desires, you have to examine the stories they write for themselves and read privately all year. You have to deconstruct the narratives shaped in the twin capitals of eros: the offices of Harlequin and Penthouse in midtown Manhattan.

title: Russia Wants No Return of Cold War, Official Says
description: Yevgeny M. Primakov, the new Russian Foreign Minister, said today that Russia continued to desire a close working relationship with the United States and had no intention of trying to resurrect the Soviet Union.

title: The L.I.R.R. Should Listen to Its Riders
description: We West Hempsteaders take strong exception to the conclusion ["L.I.R.R. Moving to Drop 32 More Ticket Windows," Jan. 14] that "local opposition has been somewhat subdued." It's not that affected community residents haven't been shouting. It's that the Long Island Rail Road, putting profit before people, hasn't been listening!

title: More Card Holders Get the Gold Treatment
description: IT started as a game two years ago for Kirsten Dieringer and her pals at Michigan Technological University in Houghton. Tired of chomping only on pizza and convinced she would soon graduate into poverty, Ms. Dieringer decided they all needed some quick financial muscle. A race was begun to see who could rack up the most gold credit cards before graduation.

title: Word & Image;What Quo for the Quid?
description: IT IS PRIMARY SEASON and Lincoln's weekend, so let's start with him and the Republican Convention of 1860. Carl Sandburg reporting:

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: WINTER GAMES By John Feinstein. Little, Brown, $21.95.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;A Little Book That Led Five Men to Fame
description: IT'S STILL NOT ENTIRELY CLEAR what it meant for the history of architecture, but the day in 1972 when Peter Eisenman, Michael Graves, Charles Gwathmey, John Hejduk and Richard Meier banded together to produce a spare, black-and-white book called "Five Architects" was surely the beginning of high-end architectural marketing.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST NEW YORK/BUSHWICK;With Pool Drydocked, a Champion Team Struggles
description: By the time Omar Santiago sat back on a tiled bench and talked about setbacks for the Bushwick High School swimming team, a teammate was cutting through the pool under an elegant mosaic at Fort Hamilton High School.

title: Habitats/The Burnt-Out East 82d Brownstone;How a Visionary Couple Transformed a Mess
description: AS they were climbing up the stairs to see the fire-ravaged wreck on East 82d Street, Bob and Cheryl Bodian ran into another couple walking down the brownstone steps.

title: Colombians Enter the Heroin Market
description: After a decade-long effort to diversify their drug empire beyond cocaine, Colombian traffickers are well on the way to supplanting Asian dealers as the predominant source of heroin in the New York region.

title: THE NEW JERSEY TRANSIT CRASH: THE OVERVIEW;Tedious Sifting for Cause of Deadly Train Wreck
description: Federal and state investigators interviewed trainmen, conducted drug and alcohol tests on dead engineers and surviving conductors, and examined tracks, signals, data recorders and wreckage yesterday for clues to the cause of a deadly collision of two commuter trains on a windswept marshland in New Jersey.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;Quiet, Tender Moments Of Urban Melancholy
description: IF YOU DO NOT KNOW Roy DeCarava's name, you are probably in the majority. His only previous retrospective in a New York museum was 25 years ago at the Studio Museum in Harlem, although he has had shows since then in other cities, and even one in Sweden. A book of his photographs was published in 1981, and "The Sweet Flypaper of Life," his 1955 collaboration with Langston Hughes, was reprinted in 1984. Other than that, not much. He has been very particular about the conditions under which he would exhibit his work, so perhaps this neglect is not entirely th' fault of an ignorant world.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;Haute Kosher: Perfect Business for Gluttons for Punishment
description: Bugs are not kosher (no matter what the Bible says about edible grasshoppers), and just one insect can render suspect a whole box of purportedly kosher lettuce. Bison are kosher, and deer, too, but only if they are slaughtered a special way and their lungs look flawless.

title: 20 Trapped in Japan Tunnel After Avalanche
description: With the temperature sinking dangerously low, rescue teams in northern Japan searched frantically early today for a way to free about 20 people trapped in a crushed mountain tunnel without triggering a second rock slide.

title: Health Care Stays Hot; Will the Fever Break?
description: HEALTH care stocks just haven't stopped.

title: New Releases
description: PHANTOMS: 'REZIREKSYON' Phantoms (212-592-0468)

title: ATLANTIC CITY;At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

title: For Brighter Cable Future, Look to the Marketplace
description: To the Editor:

title: Radically Chic
description: QUEEN OF BOHEMIA The Life of Louise Bryant. By Mary V. Dearborn. Illustrated. 365 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95.

title: February 4-10;A Roman Catholic Conquest
description: Pope John Paul II returned to Central America last week to a much warmer welcome than he received on his first visit in 1983, staging a Roman Catholic reconquest of a once war-torn region.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Romance, Lost and Found
description: Valentine's Day is an oddly timed holiday, falling as it does in the darkest hour of winter, when autumn breezes have retreated to inaccessible reaches of memory and the warmth of spring is still unimaginable.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Syracuse Returns Favor By Ripping Georgetown
description: Syracuse 85, Georgetown 64

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Looking at Whales In Two Programs
description: This spring, two programs bring together whales and their human observers.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST NEW YORK/BUSHWICK;Orphan Park Seeks Adoption
description: You would never know from the looks of it now, but there was a time when elderly men and women sat on the benches at Snediker Park and, at twilight, read stories to the neighborhood children. Students from an elementary school up the street used the park to play basketball and jump rope. There was a seesaw and some swings, and even a wading pool with a modest fountain.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers to Let Spit Issue Rest
description: The Rangers are leaving Islander Coach Mike Milbury's spitting image on the ice. They said today that they plan no formal complaint about what he did Thursday night and the league said it planned no action.

title: ON POLITICS;Parting Shots? Not From This Pundit
description: There is an old description of reporters as people who view the battle from afar and then come down from the hills to shoot the wounded. Political columnists are not so crass. We like to offer lots of free advice and constructive criticism to the wounded first. Then we shoot them.

title: 7 Thais Enter Guilty Pleas For Detention In Sweatshop
description: Seven people accused of luring dozens of garment workers from Thailand and keeping them in virtual slavery at a clandestine factory in suburban Los Angeles pleaded guilty on Friday to violating Federal civil rights laws.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: ENDLESS HIGHWAY By David Carradine. Journey Editions/Tuttle, $24.95.

title: DINING OUT;A Mix of Casual and Leisurely in Yonkers
description: CAFE MORELLI (erstwhile Reggia Morelli) suggests by its new name that it is ready to compete with the many Italian "lite" dining spots that have been opening all over the county. Most of these are the informal of the informal -- pizza-and-pasta establishments attracting the budget minded with the promise of a host of choices, cooked quickly, eaten quickly.

title: THE NEW JERSEY TRANSIT CRASH: THE HAZARDS;Union and Safety Experts Call Split Shift Dangerous
description: The engineer at the center of the investigation into the fatal New Jersey Transit collision was working an overtime shift at the end of a nighttime split schedule that union officials and some safety experts say is inherently dangerous.

title: No Frills' For Prisoners? Wardens Balk
description: Taking bodybuilding equipment, cable television and other amenities away from prisoners is a popular concept these days, especially among politicians. But most of the people who run the nation's prisons think the approach is misguided, a new survey suggests.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;A Young Challenger Takes on Nadler -- and in a Way, Gingrich
description: Fueled by youthful enthusiasm, grand ideals and a distaste for Newt Gingrich, a 30-year-old former assistant district attorney is preparing to take on Representative Jerrold L. Nadler in the Democratic primary on Sept. 10.

title: Ideas & Trends;Indians Take On the U.S. In a 90's Battle for Control
description: FACED with an order last month from the United States Attorney to shut down their casinos, the leaders of some New Mexico Indian tribes responded as adamantly as reigning sovereigns of foreign powers. Unless they are allowed to continue running their lucrative gambling halls, they threatened, New Mexicans might wake up one morning to a nightmarish gridlock: highways crossing Indian land would be closed, including New Mexico's two interstates.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Midseason Ski Report, East and West
description: With the sort of capricious weather usually associated with April, the 1995-96 ski season got off to an odd start as buckets of snow fell on the East Coast, while resorts out West opened with less than the usual supply of snow. But the situation changed last month.

title: MAIN STREET, JAPAN: For Better or for Worse;Who Needs Love! In Japan, Many Couples Don't
description: Yuri Uemura sat on the straw tatami mat of her living room and chatted cheerfully about her 40-year marriage to a man whom, she mused, she never particularly liked.

title: Correction
description: A credit with the Letters column on Feb. 4 misattributed a picture of the rap entrepreneur Suge Knight and his artists Tupac Shakur and Snoop Doggy Dogg. The photographer was Michael O'Neill, not Joseph Pluchino.

title: February 4-10;The Girth of the Modern
description: After two years of contentious negotiations, the Museum of Modern Art bought the neighboring Dorset Hotel and two adjacent brownstones in a $50 million transaction that will nearly double the size of the museum.

title: After a Dismal '95, Small Markets Surge
description: SOME of the world's smallest markets have come roaring back this year. Leading the charge have been Latin American stocks, though their brethren in Southeast Asia have also contributed to the impressive gains racked up by emerging-markets funds.

title: CLASSICAL VIEW;. . . And Pit: Change Is The Essence
description: WITH ITS 1996-97 SEASON ALREADY planned, the New York City Opera could have left its public in suspense longer than it did. Christopher Keene, its general director, died in October, and a new administration was fully in place by the end of January.

title: Flick From Headline Heaven, Tabloid Style
description: IF MY LIFE WERE A newspaper," says Peter Koper, "this would be splashed on page 1: 'Screenwriter Haunted by Headless Headline.' " Why? Because it took him more than a decade to turn a famous 1982 New York Post headline, "Headless Body in Topless Bar," into a screenplay of the same name.

title: Water Fund's $25 Million Shift Under Attack
description: A SHOWDOWN involving Suffolk County responsibility and allegations of trickery may lead to a test of public support for environmental programs.

title: Good Eating;Journey to the East Via East Broadway
description: CANTON * (212) 226-4441; 45 Division Street; $(c) no credit cards

title: Minimum-Wage Earners
description: To the Editor:

title: City That Picks Winners Leans Toward Democrats
description: One evening last week at American Legion Post No. 166, as 100 members of the Alliance Republican Club finished their $7 chicken and mashed potato dinners, their fellow Republican, Congressman Ralph Regula, rose to speak.

title: Essay;Chunnel Vision
description: Zipping along at 186 m.p.h. from Paris to London, traveling between those capitals in the same three hours as the Metroliner takes to go from New York to Washington, even a neo-Luddite has to salute the progress of technology.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Engineer Had Safety Offenses
description: The engineer whose train appeared to have run a red light before a crash that killed him and two others in Jersey City on Friday had been cited twice before for passing red signals, and once for derailing a train, Federal investigators revealed yesterday. In addition, he might have had a problem distinguishing colors, officials said. The engineer, John J. DeCurtis, was suspended in 1986 and 1989 for running a red signal, said James M. Hall, chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: Kirstein Memorial
description: A memorial tribute to Lincoln Kirstein, co-founder and general director emeritus of the New York City Ballet and the School of American Ballet, is to take place on Sunday at 6:30 P.M. at the New York State Theater. The event, which is open to the public, will include the performance of excerpts from George Balanchine's "Mozartiana" and "Orpheus," and children from the school will perform the Garland Dance from "The Sleeping Beauty." Peter Martins, Paul Cadmus, Kitty Carlisle Hart, Philip Johnson, Beverly Sills and Jamie Wyeth are the scheduled speakers. Information: (212) 870-5690.

title: Forbes's Rise Shows Power of Ideas, Not Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters;Ex-Prosecutor Builds Case for Children
description: GIVING up his law practice and moving back into the maelstrom of government is not exactly what Nicholas Scoppetta, former prosecutor and City Investigation Commissioner, thought he would be doing at the age of 63. "If someone had told me five years ago I'd be heading up the child welfare agency today, I would have said, 'What have you been smoking?' "

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Attempt to Block Testimony
description: After Francis Richard Bennett decided to recant statements implicating two brothers-in-law in the murder of the wife of one of them, he hired two lawyers to negotiate his appearances on television talk shows. The lawyers, Cornelius W. Daniel and Francis X. DeSevo, are now trying to block a prosecutor's attempt to get them to testify about what they learned from Mr. Bennett, the A.P. reported.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Stronger, Steadier Jaspers Contain Iona
description: The last time Manhattan and Iona played, the Jaspers weren't in the greatest shape. Forward Heshimu Evans was on fire -- not from the field, but from the flu. The veteran backcourt of Ted Ellis and Keaton Hyman had been suspended for the season for disciplinary reasons. And the guard tandem of Tarik Thacker and Scott McDowell was a little shaky to say the least.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DOROTHY S. RIDINGS, 56, the president and publisher of The Bradenton Herald, a newspaper in Florida, has been named the president and chief executive of the Council on Foundations.

title: POLITICS;Closing Arguments
description: LAMAR ALEXANDER

title: ADVERSARIES BACK THE CURRENT RULES CURBING POLLUTION
description: After a year in which industry and environmental groups have been at war over Republican-led efforts to roll back Federal environmental regulations, a Presidential panel with adversaries from both sides has reached a rare consensus that while the existing system can be improved, it must not be weakened.

title: Markets Closed in Tokyo
description: Financial markets were closed here today in observance of a national holiday, Foundation Day. On Friday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 183.48 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 20,934.82.

title: Japanese Try to Reach 20 Trapped in a Road Tunnel
description: Rescue workers blasted the side of a mountain with dynamite today in an unsuccessful attempt to reach some 20 people trapped in a collapsed highway tunnel. They said they would try again.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;The Seeds of Hate Some Americans Are Sowing
description: A FORCE UPON THE PLAIN The American Militia Movement and the Politics of Hate By Kenneth S. Stern 303 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24.

title: Israeli Leader Launches Election Race
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres formally confirmed his intention today to hold national elections in May instead of October, launching a race that will focus intensely on peace and personalities.

title: THEATER REVIEW;When Communists Clashed With Nazis and the Klan
description: Emily Mann's "Greensboro: A Requiem," which opened at the McCarter Theater here on Friday night, is an ambitious, panoramic theatrical documentary that has the potential to become a theatrical event.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Euro or No, Europe Needs to Cut Deficits
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Schedules Regular Bill Sales
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Privatized Foreign Aid Isn't a Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad at Home;Prohibition Folly
description: It is 1933. More and more people are calling for repeal of the 18th Amendment, which imposed Prohibition, because it has caused crime and corruption.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Media Companies Make Purchases
description: There were two acquisitions Friday by large media companies.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Doctors Gone Amok, Inventing New Tumors
description: It's not as if doctors, hospitals and pharmaceutical companies don't have enough problems, as politicians proceed apace with their social engineering. They also have to deal with Robin Cook's novels and their television adaptations. Mr. Cook, himself a physician, weaves tales about the business of medicine that can induce severe shudders.

title: HOCKEY;Ducks Stop The Devils' Progress
description: Just when it looked like the Devils had returned to last year's standard of play, the Stanley Cup champions fell to the lowly Ducks of Anaheim, who look anything but mighty these days.

title: Rig Count Up by 2
description: The number of oil and gas rigs operating in the United States increased by two last week, to 695, Baker Hughes Inc. said. There were 706 rigs operating nationwide a year ago. Of the rigs running last week, 407 were exploring for natural gas and 281 for oil. Seven rigs were listed as miscellaneous. The rig count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and natural gas.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Charger Is Arrested
description: SHAWN LEE, a 300-pound San Diego Chargers defensive tackle, was charged with assault and resisting arrest outside an Upper West Side nightclub at 3:30 A.M. yesterday after a dispute with another patron, said a police department spokeswoman, Officer NOREEN MURRAY. Lee, 29, of Raleigh, N.C., was in the China Club, at 2130 Broadway at West 75th Street, when he became involved in a dispute with VADIN GRANIN, 24, of Elmwood, N.J., Murray said.
