Granin followed Lee and a companion outside and continued to harass them, Murray said. Lee then threw Granin against a wall, gashing his head, she said.

title: POP REVIEW;A Man Who Can Rap And Also Has Muscles
description: On Friday night at Madison Square Garden, it looked like the same old Red Hot Chili Peppers: shirtless, sweaty, rowdy and pumping out funk vamps. But 13 years into its career, the group has learned some new tricks and has upgraded its old ones.

title: Book Chain Is Stymied In Canada Plan
description: Opening a front in the long war between Canada and the United States over cultural protectionism, Ottawa has killed the plans of a giant American bookstore chain, Borders Group Inc., to open a superstore in Canada.

title: HORSE RACING;Cigar Goes Forward With a Streak, a Strut
description: On the day after he ran his winning streak to 13 races, Cigar showed no signs of weariness today as he began to prepare for longer distances, higher weight and vastly more money.

title: A Practitioner Of Bare-Fisted Public Relations Takes Punches
description: Two weeks after CBS pulled a "60 Minutes" report on the tobacco industry from broadcast in November, Mike Wallace and his fellow correspondents met at the apartment of Ed Bradley to figure out how they should respond to the mushrooming controversy. Among the options they discussed was hiring a bluff, bearded public relations man named John Scanlon.

title: Forbes's Rise Shows Power of Ideas, Not Money
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: GYMNASTICS;Women's Team Strong
description: This past weekend's American Classic may not have made clear just who is going to April's individual-event world gymnastics championships, but one thing was apparent: The talent in the United States women's program runs deeper than ever.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Stern Is the $30 Million Man
description: David Stern, who has presided over the National Basketball Association the past 12 years, will carry the league into 2000.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bronfman Said to Offer Biondi Top Post at MCA Frank J. Biondi Jr., left, who was ousted last month as president and chief executive of Viacom, has been offered the chief executive's job at MCA, several people close to the discussions said. Mr. Biondi and Edgar Bronfman Jr., the chief executive of Seagram, which owns 80 percent of MCA, would not comment. The president of MCA is Ron Meyer, whom Mr. Bronfman hired from the Creative Artists Agency. [Page D2.]

title: Bomb in Bahrain
description: A bomb exploded in the lobby of a luxury seafront hotel in Bahrain today, reportedly wounding four people, and an Islamic organization claimed responsibility.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Otherworldly Simplicity, Inner Voices and Sheen
description: It is difficult to describe exactly what happens when Radu Lupu's fingers meet the piano. There are no flamboyant gestures, dazzling technical feats, startling interpretive notions. No grand personality hurls the music at the listener. What happens first is that the piano gives out a narcotically beautiful tone; solitary lines or open intervals take on a luminous sheen. Subtle dynamic shadings, lucid inner voices, well-turned rhythms and songful phrasings follow -- beyond that, nothing, or something uncannily like the music itself.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Modulating Handel's 'Orlando' For Ears Of the 90's
description: Separate languages sometimes use the same vocabularies. Time does this, creating new meanings for words that ancestors used quite differently. So in a sense, any production of Handel's "Orlando" will be an act of translation, a transfer of meaning from Handel 1733 to Handel 1996. Negotiating this transfer on Friday were the musicians and singers of Les Arts Florissants under William Christie. The opera was played at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in the first of four performances.

title: Demand Saps Supply Of Restored Water
description: Most residents of northern New Jersey were finally able to take showers and wash dishes by Saturday after three days without water, but that surge in demand meant several hundred others still had little or no water yesterday.

title: Arkansas Rapist Threatens Women and Casts Unwanted Attention on SomeOfficers
description: To frightened women in eastern Arkansas, he is a police impostor and sexual predator who has raped once and may do so again.

title: World News Briefs;South Koreans Protest Japan's Claims to Islands
description: South Korean citizen groups held anti-Japanese rallies in Seoul today to protest renewed Japanese claims to two islands.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Colts Plan On Infante
description: LINDY INFANTE, the Colts' offensive coordinator, will probably be named the team's head coach this week to fill the vacancy left by TED MARCHIBRODA, an Indianapolis television station reported yesterday.

title: Fire at Home for Elderly Kills Three in Stamford
description: An intense fire burning along a hallway in an assisted-care home for the elderly killed three residents Saturday, but fireproof doors and the residents' emergency training prevented more deaths, fire officials said today.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;UMass Routs Temple As Travieso Steps Up
description: The Mullins Center was more than filled, with bodies wedged into aisles and entryways, for reasons that have more to do with what was than what is. Temple once provided the model for what basketball has become at the University of Massachusetts, plus the emotion to transform a once-apathetic campus into a village of hoopheads.

title: 17 Are Killed And 93 Hurt By Car Bombs In Algiers
description: Two powerful car bombs killed 17 people and wounded 93 others in Algiers today as bloodshed from an Islamic insurgency continued.

title: The Outsider From Illinois
description: In Presidential elections, a candidate's lack of experience is sometimes sold as an asset. Campaign managers have promoted Wendell Willkie, Ross Perot and Steve Forbes as candidates who have strength and doctrinal purity just because they have never held elective office. Veteran politicians like Lamar Alexander scuttle to hide their years in Washington, while Bob Dole suffers because he has had too much experience and has been too long in the public eye.

title: Forbes's Rise Shows Power of Ideas, Not Money
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Fight to Open Death Records
description: When 5-year-old Timothy Wiltsey disappeared in 1991, his mother, Michelle Lodzinksi, of South Amboy, said her son had vanished at a carnival in Sayreville. Her account was not corroborated, and when Timothy's skull was found nearly a year later in a vast marsh in Edison, the mystery intensified.

title: Ex-Chief Executive at Viacom Is Said to Be Offered Job at MCA
description: Frank J. Biondi Jr., ousted last month as president and chief executive of Viacom Inc., has been offered the position of chief executive at MCA Inc. by Edgar Bronfman Jr., the chief executive of the Seagram Company, which owns 80 percent of MCA, several people close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: Go Team' Works Painstakingly Fast
description: At the crack of dawn, the investigative Go Team was already at work.

title: Privatized Foreign Aid Isn't a Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week. Some reports were delayed by last month's partial shutdown of the Government.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Ashby, Padres Agree
description: The right-hander ANDY ASHBY, who had the third-best earned run average in the National League last year, avoided arbitration when he agreed to a $5 million, two-year deal with the San Diego Padres yesterday. Ashby posted career-bests with a 12-10 record, 2.94 e.r.a. and 150 strikeouts last season. (AP)

title: Equity Issues Set For This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: 19-Year-Old Gets Life in Robbery Killings
description: A jury convicted one of two young men accused of herding restaurant employees into a walk-in freezer during a robbery and killing three of them.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;Candidates Look for Last-Minute Dazzle in Iowa
description: From high schools to hotel ballrooms, from pubs to pulpits, from tarmacs to television studios, Republican Presidential candidates fanned across Iowa today in a final drive to wake up voters who appeared overwhelmed and seemed to have soured on the tenor of the race.

title: Market Place;As America Online's share price has soared, so has the growing number of short-sellers.
description: LAST Thursday, Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation cut back its on-line service sharply, conceding that the future of electronic publishing is on the Internet. And the News Corporation is just the latest of several big companies to have reached that conclusion -- the most notable being Microsoft, which scrapped its plans for an on-line service and put Microsoft Network mainly on the Internet's World Wide Web.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Boy Sets Fire, Hurting Sister
description: A 9-year-old Camden County girl was critically injured over the weekend in a fire that was accidentally set by her 11-year-old brother while the two were home alone, but hospital officials said she is expected to recover.

title: Attacking No-Fault Notion, Conservatives Try to Put Blame Back inDivorce
description: Matrimonial wrongdoing, like adultery or desertion, was once required for courts to grant a divorce. But in the last 25 years, every state has adopted a form of "no-fault" divorce, which has been widely credited with making divorces easier, quicker and less fraught with moralistic blame.

title: In Kasparov vs. Computer, The Chess Scorecard is 1-1
description: Relentlessly pressing the slight advantage he held from the outset, the world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, defeated his inanimate adversary, the I.B.M. computer Deep Blue in the second game of their six-game match at the Pennsylvania Convention Center here.

title: Forbes's Rise Shows Power of Ideas, Not Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Number of Religious Broadcasters Continues to Grow
description: To judge by the numbers, these are expansive days for Christian radio. Two decades after evangelical Protestant voters emerged as a force in national politics, conservative Christian broadcasters are continuing to carve out a greater share of the radio market.

title: Pataki Bans Logging
description: In a move that further bolstered his standing with environmental groups, Gov. George E. Pataki killed an administration plan yesterday that for the first time would have allowed commercial logging in one of New York's state parks.

title: Pataki Kills Logging Plan In State Park
description: In a move that further bolstered his standing with environmental groups, Gov. George E. Pataki killed an administration plan yesterday that for the first time would have allowed commercial logging in one of New York's state parks.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;My, What Big Hands! (And a Talent to Match)
description: Keyshawn Johnson squeezes his long frame into a booth at a restaurant here, wearing a look of exasperation. He was told about the rigors of the National Football League scouting combine, the pinching, the pulling, the tugging. Test after test after test. He even had his hands measured (his were the largest of any receiver's). No one can be prepared for this sort of thing.

title: Forbes's Rise Shows Power of Ideas, Not Money
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Cardinals Hire Fassel
description: JIM FASSEL, the former offensive coordinator for the Giants, has been hired for the same position by the Arizona Cardinals. The new head coach, VINCE TOBIN, selected Fassel late Saturday. Fassel, 46, was the Giants' quarterbacks coach under RAY HANDLEY in 1991 and their offensive coordinator in 1992. Since then he has been the offensive coordinator for the Broncos and the quarterbacks coach for the Raiders. (AP)

title: BASEBALL;Checkbook Optimism: Yankees Ready for 1996
description: Every glorious spring training unearths new hopes and new dreams for each major league team. Another new year, another new opportunity to chase a World Series title. The Yankees are no exceptions to this tradition. In fact, the Yankees have accented their newness with a slew of roster alterations that go beyond a routine face lift. Especially for a team that made the playoffs last season.

title: Some new tools should make it far easier to put multimedia displays onthe Web.
description: SOPHISTICATED tools for multimedia publishing on the World Wide Web are racing to market.

title: In America;Affront To Black People
description: Lurking in the background of the Steve Forbes Presidential campaign is a lawyer from North Carolina who is described by campaign officials as an "informal adviser" and friend of the candidate. His name is Thomas Ellis and he is an affront to black people everywhere.

title: INSIDE
description: Deadly Algeria Bombings

title: New Fairway Market in Permit Dispute
description: Less than two months after the owners of Fairway Market, the venerable Upper West Side produce store, opened a sprawling supermarket in West Harlem, city officials say the owners may have to divide their warehouse-style retail space or stop selling to the public because they do not have the proper permits.

title: Zhirinovsky, With Vows And Gifts, Woos Voters
description: He was in black tie. She wore a white, off-the-shoulder dress and gold shoes. They arrived in a troika drawn by three gleaming white horses.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the candidate Steve Forbes in some copies misattributed a reference to him as "Richie Rich." The comment was made by Senator Phil Gramm, not Pat Buchanan.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Bill Would Curtail Junk Mail
description: Twenty-three Democratic and Republican legislators are co-sponsoring a bill to cut down on junk mail. The measure, introduced last week, would require a company to obtain a person's permission before selling his or her name, address or telephone number to another company.

title: Political Strife Takes 2 Lives In Bangladesh
description: Two people were killed and nearly 150 people were injured today in political violence across Bangladesh as opposition groups tried to prevent a general election scheduled for Thursday.

title: Taking In the Sites;Valentine Aid For Lovers On the Web
description: A bouquet of World Wide Web sites promises users the chance to point and click their way to sudden charm, leaving no excuse for being lonely or inept this Valentine's Day.

title: A Pact With Russia Limits Gun Imports
description: The United States Trade Representative, Mickey Kantor, said today that he had reached an agreement with Russia that will prevent imports of cheap Russian handguns.

title: World News Briefs;Palestinians Bar Israelis From Bethlehem in Protest
description: Palestinian police barred Israelis from Bethlehem and the main road going through it to the southern West Bank today to protest Israeli security measures at a Jewish pilgrimage site, witnesses said.

title: Forbes's Rise Shows Power of Ideas, Not Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Murder Defendant Linked to the Mob Will Share a Bright Spotlight atHis Trial
description: In a Federal courtroom in Brooklyn, a prominent lawyer and a murderous mobster turned major Government informer will tangle in an organized-crime trial opening today.

title: MEDIA: PRESS;Some distinguished journalists believe newsroom cynicism is hurting the country.
description: HAS journalistic cynicism gone too far?

title: An Actor-Biographer Plays Alter Ego To Orson Welles
description: Simon Callow's new biography, "Orson Welles: The Road to Xanadu," weighs in at 640 pages. It is, as the author admits, "Orsonic in scale," and that's only the first volume. The book ends with the release of "Citizen Kane." The second volume, a work in progress tentatively titled "Beyond Adrenalin," will deal with the rest of Welles's life, beginning in 1942 "when he ran out of all his luck."

title: CHRONICLE
description: DOROTHY J. CAIN of Freeport, L.I., yearned to do something special for her son, Airman 1st Class SEAN CAIN, 20, and his fiancee, LORETTA DIXON, 19, who is from Murray, Neb.

title: Patents;Where less can be much more: invention and technology's race to devise lower-fat junk food.
description: THE McDonald's Corporation announced last week that it was scrapping its low-fat hamburger, the McLean Deluxe, which just wasn't popular enough with burger buyers. But it is unlikely that this turn of events will stop food producers from pursuing the perfect method of removing fat from meat.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bruno's Chain Begins a Review
description: One advertiser has begun a review of its account, and another has made a change.

title: Frank Remington, Who Shaped Laws and Football, Dies at 73
description: Frank J. Remington, a University of Wisconsin law professor who made his classroom the pivot point of a far-reaching legal career that ranged from revising the nation's criminal laws to keeping college athletic programs honest, died on Friday at his home in Madison. He was 73.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Muster, Ranked No. 1, Dismisses His Critics
description: THOMAS MUSTER of Austria, the sulky lefty whose monopoly of the clay circuit culminated in last year's French Open championship, yesterday assumed the ATP Tour's No. 1 ranking for the first time in his injury-riddled career, but not without a controversy.

title: Holiday Today
description: Today is Lincoln's birthday.

title: Going Back To the Borough;Former Bronx Residents Reunite in Myriad Ways
description: Before the Cross-Bronx Expressway ripped through the old Jewish neighborhoods, and before Spanish replaced Yiddish as the lilting chatter of Old World grandmothers, there were Rosanne and Myrna, Myrna and Rosanne, the inseparable duo of Eastburn Avenue.

title: DANCE REVIEW;He Retired His Tap Shoes To Set Others Dancing
description: Nobody invited Stanley Donen to Hollywood; by his own account, he barged right in. A good thing, too, as a tribute to him by the Film Society of Lincoln Center reconfirmed.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Overcome Fatigue With Focus
description: Ray Ferraro could tell the Rangers were facing a game of more than usual significance against the Tampa Bay Lightning today. All the center had to do was look around the locker room before the game.

title: Police Shoot Man in Queens In Confusion Over 'Stolen' Car
description: A 29-year-old man was shot in the face by a police officer last night after the officer summoned him as he sat in his sister's car in front of his house in Far Rockaway, Queens, the police said.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK;Victory Not Enough for O'Neal
description: Shaquille O'Neal was not in a ducky mood tonight. He was perturbed he was not voted the most valuable player of the National Basketball Association All-Star Game. Deep down, he believed he, not Michael Jordan -- his main rival on Madison Avenue -- should have been hoisting the trophy.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;New York Planning Tourism Campaign
description: The New York City Economic Development Corporation has begun a search for agencies to handle advertising and public relations for its initial national and international campaign to promote tourism as well as recruit businesses to the city. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Governor Pataki's Brave Veto
description: By vetoing an arbitration bill that was hotly sought by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, Gov. George Pataki has once again saved the New York Legislature from its own spinelessness in matters where the police unions are concerned. The bill would have moved New York City police contract arbitration from a city-run board to the state Public Employment Relations Board. Supporters of the measure made it clear that they believed the state unit would award higher pay to city police, who are now working without a contract.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;When American Sports Underwent a Revolution
description: Of all the takeovers in American society since World War II, are any more dramatic than the takeover of the country's most popular sports by black athletes? For baby boomers the notion of a baseball or football field or basketball court or boxing ring without black champions must be unimaginable. But for decades what was unimaginable was that black and white athletes would be showing their stuff on the same teams in the same arenas for the same fans.

title: Russians Hunt for Bombs as Chechen Protest Ends
description: Russian soldiers searching for mines and bombs swept the central square of the Chechen capital, Grozny, today after demonstrators for independence ended a tense weeklong standoff.

title: Medicaid Cuts Keep Many AIDS Patients From New Treatments;Cost Is Even Higher
description: To the Editor:

title: What Is a Book Publisher to Do When a Parody Hits Home?
description: Martha Stewart -- doyenne of gracious living and good crystal -- has little in common with Karen Finley, a performance artist whose fabled use for chocolate is not the stuff of old family recipes.

title: Medicaid Cuts Keep Many AIDS Patients From New Treatments
description: To the Editor:

title: Irish Peace Effort Is Stalled In Aftermath of Bombing
description: In tones suggesting the difficulty of keeping the Northern Ireland peace discussions on track, the Irish Prime Minister today sharply criticized Britain's approach, and the Irish Republican Army's political representatives said the effort had collapsed.

title: As Patrons Age, Future of Arts Is Uncertain
description: Hit by soaring costs and cutbacks in financial support of all kinds, many cultural institutions in New York City and around the country face another and, in some respects, more insidious threat to their health: the aging of the audiences they most depend upon to attend and bankroll arts performances.

title: Forbes's Rise Shows Power of Ideas, Not Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Kevorkian and the Issue of Assisted Suicide Will Go on Trial forSecond Time
description: For the second time since he began his crusade for doctor-assisted suicide, Dr. Jack Kevorkian is scheduled to go on trial this week in a case that prosecutors hope will end his practice of helping people die and that Dr. Kevorkian hopes will help nullify laws against the practice.

title: BOXING;Medical Suspension Creates Concern
description: As concern grew in the boxing community that Tommy Morrison had tested positive for H.I.V., the former World Boxing Organization heavyweight champion remained sequestered at home in Oklahoma yesterday.

title: Cautiously, Kasparov Outlasts the Computer
description: Probing, tacking about and then grinding his way through stubborn opposition, Gary Kasparov bounced back yesterday to defeat the king of the chess computers, Deep Blue, in the Philadelphia Convention Center. After losing the first game to a virtuoso performance by the I.B.M. machine on Saturday, Kasparov leveled the score at one-all.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;For Vehicles, a Phantom Fund
description: Last year, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman persuaded lawmakers to beef up the state's vehicle inspection program. The law required the State Treasurer to contribute $11.50 from each motor vehicle registration fee to a Motor Vehicle Inspection Fund. But the money has not been collected, and the reason is simple: the program does not exist. The Division of Motor Vehicles has not even solicited bids from contractors to build the new inspection system, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: POLITICS: CALIFORNIA;Buchanan Is Second to Dole In Straw Poll Of the G.O.P.
description: It was certainly no more than, well, a straw in the wind, but on the eve of the Iowa caucuses, Senator Bob Dole emerged the winner today of a big, though anything-but-scientific, straw poll of California Republicans.

title: BASEBALL;For Mets' Prospects, It's Step Forward or Move Aside
description: Perhaps no one player illustrates the changing fortunes of the Mets better than Butch Huskey.

title: Most Forced Laborers Reported Freed
description: A representative of the International Committee of the Red Cross said today that most of the Muslims and Croats performing forced labor in Serb-held areas of Bosnia had been freed.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Takeover Team Criticized
description: A management team is taking over the troubled Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital this week. But State Senator Richard J. Codey, a West Orange Democrat, complained last week that two team members work for the state agency that ultimately bears responsibility for Grey stone's problems. On Feb. 3, in the most recent of many troubling incidents, a patient committed suicide while two staff members were sleeping. The head of the team is Joseph Jupin Jr., the chief executive of Trenton Psychiatric Hospital, also a state mental hospital. Another member, Floretta Graham, is a deputy assistant director of the mental health division of the State Department of Human Services.

title: El Mozote Journal;Where Countless Died in '81, Horror Lives On in Salvador
description: Even after 14 years, it is clear something terrible once happened here. Shards of bone no longer protrude from the earth, but the church just off the plaza is still in ruins and stained with smoke, and munitions cartridges and bullet casings still litter the ground.

title: New Scandals in Japan
description: Hobbled by a stagnant economy, precarious banking system and weak political leadership, Japan is heading into another election this year or next. Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and his main challenger, Ichiro Ozawa, are blunt-spoken younger men who declare themselves in favor of deregulation and reform. But recent events suggest that prospects are not good for changing the closed and corrupt ways that Japan does business.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;It's More 'Chiller Theater' For Storm
description: For all the good that Derek Brown did here this afternoon, there was still the chance that he might wind up the goat.

title: I. K. Dairo, 65, Innovator in Nigerian Juju Music
description: Isaiah Kehinde (I. K.) Dairo, a Nigerian musician who was an important innovator in juju music, died on Wednesday in Efon-Alaiye, Nigeria, where he lived. He was 65.

title: The Meteoric Rise of Web Site Designers;Corporations With Cyberfever Demand a Cutting-Edge Presence on Line
description: Until a year ago, Matt Pacetti, a 25-year-old graphic designer, had never been on the World Wide Web, but now he is the design director of Avalanche Systems, a 30-person agency in Manhattan that has created Web sites for NBC, Elektra records and Super Bowl XXX.

title: Bosnian Serbs Now Say They Will Keep Ties to NATO Force
description: Bosnian Serb government leaders said today that an order by the military commander, Ratko Mladic, to sever ties with the NATO-led peacekeeping force until the Bosnian Government released two senior officers was "invalid" and had been rescinded.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Seton Hall, Minus Hurley, Flattened by West Virginia
description: Seton Hall's basketball team took the day off today. Unfortunately for the Pirates, they had a Big East game against West Virginia, and the Mountaineers gave them a 77-59 beating that was much more punishing than the 18-point margin would indicate.

title: Immigration Bills' Deadlines May Imperil Asylum Seekers
description: Oumar A., a gangly 25-year-old man from Mauritania, said the police in his country hung him upside down by his feet, beat him and burned him with a heated hammer, while in the next cell they tortured and killed his father, an opponent of the military-dominated Government.

title: Marriage Presumption
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: God saved me because He needed someone to tell the story of what happened. I wish He hadn't, though, because it is very painful to have to think of it all the time." RUFINA AMAYA, the only known survivor of a 1981 army massacre of peasants in El Salvador. [A4:3]

title: School Privatizers, in Retreat
description: Costly but failing urban school systems seemed a perfect target for private firms that promised to boost student performance, eliminate waste and manage schools for a profit -- at no additional cost to the taxpayers. But the largest firm of its kind, Education Alternatives Inc., has fared dismally so far. E.A.I. projects in Dade County, Fla., Baltimore and Hartford have ended with E.A.I. ousted for disappointing performance, leaving the company and the privatization movement in retreat.

title: Zaire's Gamble: Persuading Refugees to Leave, or Else
description: By announcing this weekend that Zairian troops will seal off a Rwandan refugee camp near Goma from the outside world in the coming days, Zaire is gambling that it can make life uncomfortable enough for the thousands of Hutu refugees living within its borders to persuade them to return home without firing a shot.

title: Venezuelans See Clashes Resuming
description: After weeks of anti-Government protests, Venezuelans put aside their rancor over collapsing living standards during Pope John Paul II's visit this weekend, but the country was bracing for more conflict as he flew back to Rome tonight.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;How Compromise Built Cleveland a New Stadium
description: Cleveland's decision to end its legal battle to keep the Browns from moving to Baltimore came down to a very practical realization: If the city did not compromise, it would kill any chance of building a new stadium for a new team.

title: Moving Motors Through Modems
description: Even here, at the annual National Automobile Dealers Association convention, most of the talk this weekend was not about cars but about computers.

title: A World Wide Web Screening Program
description: The researcher credited with starting the World Wide Web says he will offer a free screening program to people who want to keep objectionable material from entering their computers from the Internet.

title: Q&A / Russell J. Cheetham : East Asia's 'Huge Opportunity'
description: Rapid growth has made East Asia a powerhouse for global trade and economic activity. Russell J. Cheetham, the World Bank's vice president for East Asia and the Pacific, discussed prospects for the region with Michael Richardson of the International Herald Tribune.

title: World News Briefs;Farrakhan, in Iran, Hails 17 Years of Islamic Rule
description: The Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan attended a rally marking the 17th anniversary of the Islamic revolution in Iran today in Teheran, the capital, and told the crowd their country had become a model religious democracy.

title: GOLF;Love Saves His Best For the Final Stretch
description: From way back in the pack, Davis Love 3d got right back in the flow today, rolling like a big Pacific wave over a couple of hometown heroes and storming from four strokes behind to a two-stroke victory in the Buick Invitational at Torrey Pines Golf Course.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Weekend Exercise Co., San Diego, to Mad Dogs and Englishmen, New York, to handle advertising for the Marika line of women's athletic wear, previously handled by Citron Haligman Bedecarre, San Francisco. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: Euro or No, Europe Needs to Cut Deficits
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THE COMMERCIALS;Pointing Up Contrast, Lugar Points to His Campaign Ads
description: In his latest campaign commercial, Senator Richard Lugar of Indiana urges Iowa voters to choose him for this one reason: his campaign commercials.

title: Discovering Generosity As a Long-Distance Joy
description: As Johnny Suzuki knows, you do not have to live in New York to support The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Mr. Suzuki, who lives in Japan, had his contribution in the mail days after the drive began last November, writing, somewhat ambiguously, that his overseas gift was "for fellow American folks who need help and who helped us in time of need."

title: POLITICS: BOB DOLE;In No-Frills Message, Modesty Vies With Pride in Service
description: When Bob Dole was mingling at a reception in New Hampshire the other day, Dennis Bobilya, 36, a college professor, shook his hand and asked him point-blank: "Why do you want to be President? I guess that's the $86,000 question."

title: Sports of The Times;The Core of the Game In One Word: Pass
description: IF Magic Johnson's return has delivered any unambiguous message, it is that basketball is about none of the topics generally covered at All-Star Weekend. It is not about global growth, or sizable increases in cable ratings or logos being plastered on shirts and shoes.

title: A Braking System That Thinks for Itself
description: On trains equipped with automatic brakes and computerized signals visible in the cab, the vehicles themselves let engineers know when they are exceeding the speed limit or passing a red signal.

title: Bridge
description: Cover the East-West hands shown in the diagram and plan the play in six spades, remembering that East has opened one diamond and West has led the deuce of that suit. Then look at the East-West cards and see if your play works. If not, consider what would work.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Nissan takes its sport utility vehicle on safari, even if the customers are more likely to stick to the road.
description: TO be sure, the sport utility market has become a jungle. But who knew the Nissan Motor Corporation and TBWA Chiat/Day would take that so literally?

title: Officer Shoots Man Outside Queens Home
description: A 29-year-old man was shot in the face by a police officer last night after the officer summoned the man as he sat in his sister's car in front of his house in Far Rockaway, Queens, the police said. The police noticed the parked car because its license was listed as belonging to a stolen vehicle on a police data base. The man's sister said she told the police several times in recent weeks that the car had been recovered.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week: 2-12

title: DOG SHOW;Going to the Dogs And Loving It
description: At last count, Barbara Miller lived with 11 dogs the number has been as high as 20. Dogs, she confesses, are her passion. "I hug, I kiss, I love," she said last Thursday. On the phone, she may often be heard "talking dog to dog people," which has more to do with breeding than barking.

title: POLITICS: STEVE FORBES;Candidate of the Flat Tax Is a Bit of a Flat Campaigner
description: A hostile, 35-mile-an-hour wind slashes across the empty parking lot behind the Kinney 4-H building at the North Iowa Fairgrounds. A grain elevator rises in the distance, flanked by a crumbling drive-in movie theater.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Monday about Chinese efforts to regulate access to the Internet misidentified a New York-based publication that is available on the Internet. It is Beijing Spring, not China Spring.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;The East Revolves Around Two Stars
description: Michael Jordan won the most valuable player award. Shaquille O'Neal felt he was snubbed. But led by their combined efforts, the Eastern Conference walked away with an easy victory in tonight's National Basketball Association All-Star Game.

title: Publishers, Joan Collins And That Fine Print
description: When the eyebrow-raising trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan ends, as it is expected to later this week, the British actress Joan Collins may be forced to repay a $1.2 million advance she received several years ago and forgo the total of $4 million promised for the two books she had agreed to write.

title: Engineer in Fatal Train Collision Had a Record of Running Signals
description: The New Jersey Transit engineer whose train appears to have run a red light just before a collision that killed him and two others Friday had been cited twice before for passing red signals, and once for derailing a train, Federal investigators revealed yesterday. In addition, they said, he might have had a problem distinguishing colors.

title: A Mixed Message on War Crimes
description: The Bosnian peace agreement seems to have weathered its first serious challenge, a dispute between the Bosnian Government and Bosnian Serbs over the handling of war crimes investigations. A sensible resolution outlined yesterday by Assistant Secretary of State Richard Holbrooke offers hope that the commitments from all sides to end the Balkan war will nourish the peace accord in the difficult days ahead.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: No U.N. Dues Linkage
description: To the Editor:

title: In Settlement, Toy Maker to Give Refunds
description: The $20 billion United States toy industry showed its happiest face to the world yesterday, announcing record retail sales figures for 1995 at the start of its biggest annual trade show. But the Federal Trade Commission dampened the festivities with the news that it had won its first consumer-refund settlement for deceptive advertising in the toy industry.

title: Killing on S.I. Leads to a Ban On Some Youths In Group Homes
description: The discovery last month was grisly: a 71-year-old Staten Island man found beaten to death on his bedroom floor. The arrests that followed were equally unsettling: three boys, one 15 years old, the others 16, accused of walking out of their foster-care group home, breaking into the man's house and killing him.

title: New Umbrella Group Created For Tobacco-Free Children
description: Anti-tobacco groups announced yesterday the creation of a new umbrella organization based in Washington to sponsor, coordinate and encourage efforts to stop children from smoking, sniffing and chewing tobacco.

title: POLITICS: IN THE PACK;A Strong Second-Place Gives Heart to Buchanan
description: With a focused and conservative appeal, Patrick J. Buchanan gathered the right wing of this state's Republican Party behind him today and did "far better than anyone predicted" -- as he exuberantly put it tonight -- for the third time in this year's Republican Presidential season.

title: Plant Census Raises the Alarm And Leads to Restoration Effort
description: MORE than 100 years ago, a scenic area of woods, wildflowers and rocky granite outcrops was set aside as the Middlesex Fells, a conservation area just north of Boston. But researchers now say that despite a ban on development since 1894, more than 150 of the park's plant species have disappeared.

title: Facing Foes, Rohatyn Ready To Withdraw As Fed Choice
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker who has lobbied for the No. 2 seat on the Federal Reserve Board, drafted a letter to President Clinton today, withdrawing from consideration after concluding that his nomination would face insurmountable opposition from Senate Republicans, senior Administration officials said tonight.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bond Prices Post Gains; Trading Light
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher in light activity yesterday, as concern seemed to ease about accommodating the huge supply of new debt securities from last week's Government quarterly refunding and as the lack of fresh economic data left traders without strong direction.

title: Market Place;Hilton's new chief has been there, done that. Can he do it again?
description: EXECUTIVES like to think they make a difference at a company, but few have had the impact of Stephen F. Bollenbach. Since it was announced a week ago Friday that Mr. Bollenbach was leaving the Walt Disney Company, where he was chief financial officer, to become chief executive of the Hilton Hotels Corporation, Hilton stock has soared $16, or 21.7 percent, to $89.875.

title: S. Ward Casscells, 80, Arthroscopy Pioneer, Dies
description: Dr. S. Ward Casscells, who helped revolutionize sports medicine as a pioneer in arthroscopic surgery, died on Thursday at the home of a son in Houston. He was 80.

title: Gannett to Sell Its Polling Unit To Competitor
description: The Gannett Company said today that it had agreed to sell its Louis Harris & Associates polling unit to the Gordon S. Black Corporation, also a provider of polling and marketing services.

title: A Quiet Trip On the 7:58 To Hoboken
description: This morning, the usually bustling 7:58 New Jersey Transit local from Waldwick to Hoboken was a different trip.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: In Step With Stravinsky, Even Without a Conductor Orpheus Carnegie Hall

title: COMPANY NEWS;ESSILOR PLANS TO BUY BENSON EYECARE FOR $225 MILLION
description: Essilor International S.A. of Paris said yesterday that it would buy the Benson Eyecare Corporation, which is based in Rye, N.Y., for about $225 million and spin off to Benson shareholders everything but its Dallas-based Omega Laboratory Group unit. Omega, with $150 million in annual sales, is the largest United States independent wholesale lens-grinding chain. Under the agreement, Benson will also sell its Orcolite plastic lens-making unit to the Monsanto Company of St. Louis for about $53 million. Under the agreement with Essilor, Benson shareholders will receive $6.25 in cash for each share. They will also receive one share in a new company, BEC Group Inc., for every two Benson common shares. BEC will consist of all of Benson's non-Omega businesses.

title: Stocks Surge Again; Dow Exceeds 5,600
description: Continuing a remarkable run that has some Wall Street analysts making nervous comparisons to 1987, the stock market raced ahead again yesterday with the Dow Jones industrial average finishing above the 5,600 mark for the first time.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.F.L.;Moon Spouse-Abuse Trial to Begin
description: WARREN MOON is to appear in court today in Richmond, Tex., to face a spouse-abuse charge pursued by prosecutors despite pleas from the quarterback's wife to drop the case.

title: Arafat Takes Oath of Office
description: Yasir Arafat took the oath of office today as the first leader of the Palestinian self-rule government.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: With Detentions Up, Border Is Still Porous
description: It is a few minutes before midnight, and Fernando Quiroga is crouched in the carrizo cane along the banks of the Rio Grande. The air smells sweet, and the light of a half-moon casts a faint glow on the river.

title: Man, 35, Kills Ex-Girlfriend And Himself
description: A man with a history of violence toward his former girlfriend walked into the Queens car dealership where she worked and shot her to death yesterday before killing himself, the authorities said.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Bank Venture in Canada
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation and the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce said today that they had agreed to combine their Canadian institutional trust and custody businesses in a joint venture. The new venture, which will be equally owned by the companies, will serve Canadian institutional investors with domestic and global assets as well as foreign financial institutions investing in Canada. It will administer about $95 billion in assets under the name CIBC Mellon Global Securities Services. Mellon Bank, with assets of $41 billion, is based in Pittsburgh. Canadian Imperial, which is based in Toronto, is Canada's second-largest financial institution.

title: Bosnian Croats Resist Peace Accord
description: The priest in the familiar brown, hooded robe and rope cinch of the Franciscan order was making his rounds in this village recently, trailed by local children and a cat, when he stopped to explain to a visitor why Croats here in western Bosnia will never share power with the Bosnian Government.

title: ALBANY OVERRIDES A VETO BY PATAKI ON PAY FOR POLICE
description: The New York State Legislature voted today to override Gov. George E. Pataki's veto of a bill that will help New York City's police officers and firefighters win larger pay raises, utterly rejecting the pleas of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his ally on this issue, Mr. Pataki.

title: Revision for Gray's Anatomy? New Muscle Found Deep in Skull
description: Centuries of studies of the human body would suggest that all major anatomical structures have been identified. But a group of Maryland researchers say they have discovered a previously undescribed muscle in the human head.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WARNER AND MAI PLAN THEME PARK AND STUDIO COMPLEX
description: Warner Brothers and MAI P.L.C. will announce today a plan to build a theme park and studio complex near London, The Financial Times reported today. Warner, a subsidiary of Time Warner, will invest L225 million, or $338 million, in the park, Warner Brothers Movie World, and will include studio tours, the newspaper reported. Officials of both companies could not be reached for comment. The park, in Hillingdon, about 16 miles west of London, would be Warner Brothers' second in Europe. The unit plans to open a $270 million Warner Brother Movie World near Bottrop, Germany, this spring. MAI, which operates regional television services in Britain and owns financial companies, agreed last week to merge with United News and Media, publishers of The Daily Express and The Sunday Express in Britain, for $4.5 billion.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: College Gets Tougher on Verifying Learning Disabilities of AidApplicants
description: Three years ago, when it came time to choose a college, Benjamin Freedman, whose dyslexia was diagnosed when he was 14, picked Boston University because of the support services it offered for students with learning disabilities.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOWLING;Three Voted Into the Hall of Fame
description: MIKE AULBY of Indianapolis and DAVE HUSTED of Milwaukie, Ore., were elected yesterday to the Professional Bowlers Association Hall of Fame on their first ballot. LARRY LICHSTEIN, longtime director of the Professional Bowlers Services Corporation, was elected in the meritorious service category.

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. BANCORP TO BUY CALIFORNIA BANCSHARES
description: U.S. Bancorp has signed an agreement to acquire a California Bancshares Inc. of San Ramon, Calif., for $327 million, the companies announced yesterday. Under the acquisition agreement, each share of California Bancshares common stock will be converted into 0.95 share of U.S. Bancorp common stock. U.S. Bancorp, which is based in Portland, Ore., will add the 36 California Bancshares branches to its U.S. Bank of California operations. U.S. Bancorp is one of the 30 largest bank holding companies in the nation, with assets of about $32 billion. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of U.S. Bancorp fell $1.313, to $32.938, while California Bancshares jumped $2.563, to $30.313.

title: BLOOD AND OIL: A Special Report.;After Nigeria Represses, Shell Defends Its Record
description: Correction Appended

title: The Chess Column
description: Because of the match between Gary Kasparov and the chess computer Deep Blue, the column by Robert Byrne does not appear today. It will resume next week.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;The Computer Ate My Homework
description: ON Valentine's Day in 1946, a half-century ago tomorrow, scientists in Philadelphia unveiled the Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer, Eniac. The first electronic computer weighed 30 tons and filled a room.

title: Forbes's Taxes Are His Business
description: Steve Forbes doesn't want to make his tax returns public. I don't blame him. There is a long tradition in this country of treating our tax returns as confidential information, and candidates for Federal office are not required to release them.

title: Maurice Kelley, 92, Authority on Milton
description: Maurice Kelley, an authority on the poet John Milton and emeritus professor of English at Princeton University, died on Feb. 5 at the Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. He was 92 and lived in Princeton.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When Ms. magazine became an advertisement-free publication in 1989, it eliminated its Women of the Year awards.

title: Review/Fashion;Men's Wear on the Move
description: Men's fashion is on the kind of creative roll that used to be the norm for women's clothing design.

title: SWIMMING;Austpalian Fails Drug Test
description: The Australian swimmer Samantha Riley, a leading contender for this year's Atlanta Olympics, failed a drug test, the sport's domestic governing body confirmed today. Australian Swimming said swimming's international governing body, FINA, was investigating a positive drug test involving a headache tablet taken by Riley, the world record-holder in the 100-meter breast-stroke.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Toy Soldier's Real Heart
description: The title role in George Balanchine's "Steadfast Tin Soldier" makes no great demands for technique or acting. What must be expressed, through movement alone, is the beating of a warm and possibly wistful heart tucked deep inside the stiff tin body of a toy soldier so capable of love that he gives the heart away to a pretty paper doll and thereby causes her death.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Teachers Threaten to Strike
description: A union representing thousands of New Jersey state college teachers said yesterday its members would go on strike if no bargaining agreement is reached by Feb. 29. Some 3,200 faculty and professional staff at nine state colleges have been working without a contract since June 30. Their union, the Council of New Jersey State College Locals, said salaries and merit increases were among the issues in dispute, the A.P. reported. TERRY PRISTIN

title: On My Mind;Who Can Defeat Bill Clinton?
description: If President Clinton is re-elected, will he again appoint his wife to take over a major area of American Government policy?

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;U.S. Postal Service Shifts Assignments
description: The United States Postal Service said yesterday that it had shifted assignments among its roster agencies on parts of its account, with billings that trade publications estimated at about a third of the total Postal Service billings of $90 million.

title: Ruth Freeman Meyer, 93, a Philanthropist
description: Ruth Freeman Meyer, a philanthropist who attended Syracuse University's School of Management and remained a booster her whole life, died on Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. A resident of Manhattan, she was 93.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Klockner Loss Narrows
description: Klockner-Werke A.G. posted a smaller first-quarter loss yesterday and said a reorganization of its operations might enable it to break even in its current fiscal year. The net loss for the quarter that ended on Dec. 31 narrowed to 14 million marks ($9.5 million) or "about 50 million marks" less than a year ago, said its chief executive, Heinz-Ludwig Schmitz. Klockner-Werke has 114 subsidiaries in three main divisions: auto parts, plastic foils, and bottling and packaging equipment. Mr. Schmitz said all units were candidates for sale. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Chancellor Crew Takes Over Two Bronx School Districts
description: Saying he suspected widespread corruption, Dr. Rudy Crew, the New York City Schools Chancellor, announced yesterday that he had seized control of two Bronx school districts that are among the lowest-performing in the city and would soon order an investigation of at least a third of the city's districts.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EMCOR TO SELL JAMAICA WATER UNIT FOR $178.8 MILLION
description: Emcor Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Jamaica Water Supply Company unit to New York City and the Water Authority of Western Nassau County for $178.8 million. New York will pay $148 million for Jamaica Water's supply system assets in Queens, plus $5.6 million to discharge of some capital lease obligations for water meter leases, Emcor said. Nassau County will pay $23.2 million for water supply system assets in Nassau County, plus about $1.7 million to discharge water meter lease obligations. Jamaica Water is the city's last privately owned supplier, serving about 500,000 residents of Queens. The transaction is expected to close in the second quarter.

title: Study Examines Race and Justice in California
description: Almost 40 percent of black men in their 20's in California are imprisoned or on probation or parole on any given day, a study released yesterday says.

title: No Headline
description: One of the problems that has led to this state is the constant search for blame and the constant looking to the past to assign responsibility, and it is an endless no-win process."

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Saturday, "Unforgotten Crimes in Nigeria," misstated the share of Nigeria's oil exports produced by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group. Shell produces roughly half of Nigeria's oil output.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;General Motors plans to redesign its Epcot Center exhibit as part of a bigger brand campaign.
description: THE General Motors Corporation plans to replace its exhibit at the Epcot Center attraction at Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla., as part of an ambitious revamping of its car and truck advertising and marketing by emphasizing brands.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Singapore Delays Sale Of Shares in Utility
description: Singapore's Government has postponed selling shares of Singapore Power to the public for at least two years, saying the company's profits were lower than expected. "S.P. is not earning adequate returns," Yeo Chow Tong, Singapore's industry minister, said yesterday. Mr. Yeo said the Government would raise electricity prices to bolster the company's finances.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: United States

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CABARET
description: Styles of Jazz Past Echoing Across the Decades John Pizzarelli, guitarist Algonquin Hotel

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Net Down at Foster's
description: Foster's Brewing Group Ltd. of Australia said yesterday that its after-tax profit fell 18.7 percent, to $165.5 million (Australian), or $125.38 million (United States), in the six months that ended on Dec. 31. The results were depressed by the absence of the Courage brewing business, which Foster's sold to Scottish and Newcastle P.L.C. last May. A year ago, the company earned $203.5 million (Australian). Quarterly sales fell to $1.19 billion (Australian), or $901.7 million (United States), from $2.23 billion (Australian). (AP)

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Alcan Aluminium Sheds Some British Assets
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd.'s British subsidiary, British Alcan Aluminium P.L.C., has sold some of its businesses for $300 million, the company said yesterday. Included in the sale were 12 businesses in Britain and the United States that produce aluminum foil, high-pressure gas cylinders, wire, cable and other products. These businesses had combined sales of more than $750 million in 1995 and about 4,200 employees.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: SWISS REINSURANCE CO., Zurich, will buy one million common shares of Enhance Financial Services Group Inc., a New York-based reinsurance company, for $24.4 million.

title: Philadelphia Police Imperil More Cases
description: The District Attorney's office has identified 43 new cases it wants reversed because of corrupt police officers, bringing the total in the 39th Police District to 99.

title: Today's Man Trims Down
description: Today's Man Inc., which filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this month, said today that it had closed its seven stores in Illinois and an outlet center in Sunrise, Fla., eliminating 235 jobs. With the closings, the company, a men's clothing retailer, is left with 28 stores in the Philadelphia, New York and Washington markets.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Saab Profit Off 34% In Fourth Quarter
description: Saab Automobile A.B., the Swedish car maker owned by Investor A.B.and the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter pretax profit fell 34 percent. Nevertheless, the auto maker, which had a loss for the first nine months of 1995, rallied to a full-year profit.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Jan. 15 and in some editions on Jan. 14 about Kenneth S. Halpern an architect, referred incorrectly to his appointment as director of a New York City planning office. He was the first director of the newly consolidated Manhattan Office of the Department of City Planning, not the borough's first planning director.

title: U.S. Shows China a Worrying Lack of Fortitude;Firm on Taiwan
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;WARNACO BUYS CYGNE DESIGNS UNIT FOR $12.5 MILLION
description: Cygne Designs Inc., a supplier of private-label apparel, said yesterday that it would sell its intimate apparel and sleepwear business to Warnaco Inc., makers of intimate apparel. Warnaco will pay $12.5 million in cash for the division, which Cygne acquired in 1994, and will assume some of its liabilities. Warnaco will make a further payment of $1.5 million once the value of the unit, GJM, is confirmed. Cygne will take a $33 million charge as a result. Warnaco is trying to strengthen its sleepwear business as well as relationships with Asian manufacturers.

title: COMPANY NEWS;T.W.A. TO BUY 10 BOEING AIRCRAFT AND LEASE 10 MORE
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it would purchase 10 of the Boeing Company's 757-200 aircraft and lease 10 more to replace its aging L-1011 jets. The carrier said three of the new aircraft are to be delivered this year and 12 next year. Two more of the planes are to be delivered in 1998 and three more in 1999. The airline also has options for another 20 757's. Since it emerged from bankruptcy, T.W.A has said it was planning to replace three-engine jets like the L-1011's with twin-engine aircraft. T.W.A's L-1011's average age is about 20 years.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hong Kong Landlord To Spin Off China Unit
description: The Henderson Land Development Company, one of Hong Kong's biggest landlords, said yesterday that it would spin off its China projects into a separate company. Henderson committed itself to selling its China division when it sold $460 million in bonds in October 1993.

title: TV SPORPS;With a Dunk at Every Turn, College Ratings Take a Dip
description: Yogi Berra's restaurant-going advice -- "Nobody goes there anymore, it's too crowded"-- applies more than ever to televised college basketball. There are so many games available, I can't watch anymore. Yes, I should. But college hoops is hemorrhaging games -- watch UMass in Cambyvision! -- and I can't stand it.

title: U.S.-Industry Blueprint Is Drawn To Smooth Way for AIDS Vaccine
description: To help speed development of an AIDS vaccine, Federal health officials today released a blueprint for encouraging greater cooperation between industry and the Government.

title: Observer;Who Are Those Guys?
description: After Bing Crosby died, one of his sons published a book denouncing the old crooner as a terrible dad. This followed a book by Joan Crawford's daughter denouncing her mother as a terrible mom.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders' Effort Matches The Crowd
description: Ineffective goaltending by Eric Fichaud, a listless performance by the skaters and a failure to convert scoring opportunities in the early stages were the main reasons the Islanders lost by 4-1 to the Ottawa Senators tonight before a "crowd" of 7,567 at Nassau Coliseum.

title: BASKETBALL;Misfiring Orangemen Build a Victory With Fewer Bricks
description: When they met last month at the Carrier Dome, Syracuse outlasted Rutgers by a point in a well-played, well-executed, well-shot game. In other words, a game that bore no resemblance to tonight's at the Louis Brown Athletic Center.

title: Stocks Fall in Japan
description: Stocks traded lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 150.59 points, or seven-hundredths of 1 percent, at 20,784.23. Financial markets in Japan were closed on Monday for a national holiday. On Friday, the average lost 183.48 points, or nearly nine-tenths of 1 percent.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;H & R Block Plans To Review Account
description: H & R Block said yesterday that it had placed in review its corporate advertising account, with billings estimated at $12 million to $15 million. The account has been handled by Bernstein-Rein in Kansas City, Mo., for the last 12 years.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;3d Blast Fails to Remove Boulder in Japan Tunnel
description: A third dynamite blast failed today to remove a huge boulder that trapped 19 people in a highway tunnel in northern Japan. Crews were planning another blasting attempt, but little hope was held out of finding anyone alive.

title: U.S. to Continue Contacts With Sinn Fein
description: Taking a more conciliatory posture than either the British or Irish Governments, the White House kept the door open today to further contacts with Sinn Fein, despite the London bomb blast set off last week by the Irish Republican Army.

title: Malaysia Will Open and Expand Higher Education
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Malaysia is liberalizing its higher-education system by allowing foreign universities to set up branch campuses in the country and the Malaysian private sector to enter the field, greatly expanding the number of university places available locally.

title: Sports of The Times;'I Love Everything About This'
description: MARETH KIPP and I are kindred spirits. Sort of.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rutgers Quiet on 2 Arrests
description: Rutgers University officials were not commenting yesterday on the arrest of a pre-medical student and a youth counselor in a university-sponsored program. The two were stopped Sunday for speeding on the George Washington Bridge, and the police said they found 30 grams of cocaine, six packets of heroin and a loaded automatic handgun in their vehicle.

title: Same Gene May Shape Face, Heart and Hands
description: AS though they were blessed with a kind of diagnostic clairvoyance, doctors have long been able to gaze into a patient's face and see reflections of ills in far-flung regions of the body.

title: Cigna's Plan To Split Units Is Approved
description: The Cigna Corporation cleared the final regulatory hurdle to its plan to split its domestic property and casualty business yesterday as regulators in seven states approved the proposal.

title: BASKETBALL;Manhattan's Center Aims At No. 1 With Jump Shot
description: When strangers called out, "Gina, you're No. 12!" early in the season, she did not know what they were talking about. Whether she was strolling through the Manhattan College campus in Riverdale, the Bronx, or working on a pivot move in Draddy Gymnasium, Gina Somma kept hearing a countdown.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Troupe With Its Heart In Music
description: The Veriovka Ukrainian National Dance Company from Kharkov, with its fine dancers, singers and instrumentalists, offers a new perspective on the variety of folk ensembles that developed in the former Soviet Union.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Lincoln's Birthday will probably always have special resonance for BILL LACY, the president of Purchase College, the State University of New York school.

title: BOXING;Morrison Confirms He Tested Positive
description: Tommy Morrison, the former World Boxing Organization heavyweight champion who was planning to fight Mike Tyson later this year, acknowledged yesterday that he had tested positive for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Farberware Weighs Leaving the Bronx
description: Farberware, the cookware-maker whose plant in the Bronx employs 700 workers, is being sold to a Massachusetts company, whose chairman said it might be too costly to keep manufacturing in the Bronx, according to a published report.

title: Overriding Of Veto Is First Since 1976
description: The Mayor from New York City warned state lawmakers again and again that the bill they were considering would almost certainly plunge the city into fiscal chaos. The Governor agreed and vetoed it, only to have his veto overridden by the New York State Legislature in a historic rebuff.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HONEYWELL TO BUY DURACRAFT FOR $283 MILLION
description: Honeywell Inc. will acquire the Duracraft Corporation, a manufacturer of such home products as heaters, vaporizers and humidifiers, for $283 million in cash, the companies said yesterday. Honeywell will pay $43.50 a share for Duracraft. Duracraft employs about 3,300 people worldwide and operates manufacturing plants in Tennessee, Portugal and Shenzhen province of China. It had sales of $143 million in 1994. Honeywell employs 50,000 people in 95 countries and had 1995 sales of $6.7 billion.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Country Dying of Laughter. In 1,079 Pages.
description: INFINITE JEST By David Foster Wallace 1,079 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $29.95.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Publishers and Netscape Plan News Network
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation and a group of news organizations, including Reuters, ESPN and The Los Angeles Times, plan to announce Tuesday an Internet news network that can be displayed automatically in the screen-saver software of a personal computer.

title: Don't Go Away Mad, Just Go Away;Can AT&T Be the Nice Guy As It Cuts 40,000 Jobs?
description: Top executives at the AT&T Corporation have pored over 10,000 resumes in the last few months, the first wave of more than 100,000 they expect to review by summer.

title: Scientists Close In on Hidden Lair Of the Ocean's Fabled Giant Squid
description: THE lair of the giant squid is a staple of novels and horror movies, and perhaps of nightmares. But for biologists it is a mystery.

title: Some Japanese Remain Abroad to Gain 'Returnee' Status
description: A Japanese mother, preoccupied with preparing her young son to take entrance exams for private elementary schools, is talking with her friend who plans to marry soon.

title: Sudan Pays High Price for Ties to Islamic Militants
description: Americans no longer occupy the American Embassy here. Every last diplomat left by airplane last week in a protest at what Washington says is the sanctuary that Sudan provides to some of the world's most violent terrorist groups.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Full Water Pressure Restored
description: For the first time since two major transmission lines ruptured early Wednesday, United Water Resources reported yesterday that full water pressure had been restored to all of its 750,000 customers in Bergen and Hudson counties, including residents of the last water-deprived pocket, in Hillsdale.

title: Almost Anyone Is Better Than Yeltsin
description: The time has arrived for a fundamental Western reassessment of President Boris Yeltsin, because he has abandoned everything that the West appreciated in him.

title: A Wal-Mart Experiment On Internet
description: In a move certain to accelerate the acceptance of computer-based shopping, Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's largest retailer, said yesterday that it would begin trials next month of a system for selling its merchandise over the Internet. The Microsoft Corporation will supply the software for the experiment.

title: POLITICS: THE SETBACK;Forbes Calls 4th-Place Finish New Hampshire 'Springboard'
description: Subdued but undaunted, Steve Forbes looked at his fourth-place finish in the Iowa caucuses this evening and declared it "a good springboard" for his Presidential campaign in New Hampshire.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Computer Chip Orders Post an Unexpected Drop The semiconductor industry's leading indicator -- a comparison of orders and shipments of computer chips -- fell to an unexpected low in January, a sign that demand for chips is growing more slowly than the supply. The report is likely to pressure technology stocks and possibly lead to a selloff.

title: Haskell Lazere, 75, Executive Who Led Jewish Committee
description: Haskell L. Lazere, who was executive director of the New York chapter of the American Jewish Committee from 1969 to 1989 and helped found various human rights coalitions in New York City, died on Saturday at his home on the Upper East Side. He was 75.

title: In Hong Kong, a Sudden Demand for Putonghua Lessons
description: HONG KONG  That Hong Kong's leaders and their future overlords in China have trouble communicating is hardly in doubt. The two sides think and function differently in areas ranging from finance to the arts to social control.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Britain Acted Wisely In Expelling Saudi
description: To the Editor:

title: By Design;White Is Forecast for Spring
description: The blanket of white may be gone from the streets, but white is the color of spring fashion for clothes and makeup. The idea is not rice-powder whiteface, but a subtle glaze of white on eyelids and lips.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Empowered by Respect, Mother Rebuilds Family
description: As a young girl, Yolanda Rivera passed many hours hiding in closets or at the local firehouse. Both places offered protection from her father, an abusive alcoholic.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: GOLF;Nicklaus Announces End of His Streak
description: JACK NICKLAUS, the most successful golfer the game has k'own, confirmed yesterday that the United States Open at Oakland Hills in June "will probably end my streak of consecutive major championships" at 138, a decision that was anticipated since being reported on Sunday.

title: Police Admit Mistakes In Shooting in Queens
description: A day after a Queens man was shot by an officer, police officials apologized yesterday for stopping the man's car and apprehending him in the first place, saying a computer error had mistakenly identified the car as stolen. They also acknowledged that the man, Lebert Folkes, was shot accidentally after what they said was a struggle to remove him from his car.

title: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;Dole Tops the Field in Iowa Caucuses
description: Senator Bob Dole won the Iowa Republican Presidential caucuses tonight, but Patrick J. Buchanan established himself as a robust contender by surging to second place, followed by Lamar Alexander.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Zimmer's Making It Official
description: Ever since United States Senator Bill Bradley announced that he would not seek re-election, it has been no secret that Representative Richard A. Zimmer, Republican of Delaware Township, wanted to replace him. Today, Mr. Zimmer, who has served in the House since 1991, will announce his candidacy at Morristown National Historical Park. The other contenders for the Republican nomination are Richard A. Du Haime, a Passaic County freeholder, and State Senator Richard J. LaRossa of Trenton. Mr. Zimmer is considered the front-runner to take on Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of Hackensack, in November.

title: Giuliani Fails on Vote to Override
description: By overriding Gov. George E. Pataki's veto of a bill that was dear to New York City police officers today, the Legislature seemed to signal that it had little regard for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his lobbying strategy in the capital.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Minimalist's View Of 20th-Century Life
description: Say what you will about Steve Reich: what he does, he does well. Of all the composers associated with the American Minimalist school, he is the one who has operated with the greatest rigor and consistency. Each of the works presented on an all-Reich program on Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall offered the provisionally pleasing spectacle of a difficult set of musical goals accomplished with staggering precision. Whether his goals seem desirable is a matter of taste, not technique. The technique is steady as a rock; the taste is up for grabs.

title: Patterns
description: Tocca to Onward Kashiyama

title: Q & A
description: Dustbusters

title: Bosnia Limits War-Crimes Arrests After NATO Delivers 2 Suspects
description: Trying to defuse the latest threat to the Bosnian peace effort, the Bosnian Government announced today that it would no longer arrest people on suspicion of war crimes without authorization from the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague.

title: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;Victory Laced With Caution
description: In the quarter-century since George McGovern gained a bit of visibility by finishing a surprisingly close second in this state's nominating caucuses, then little known, Iowa's political voice has grown immeasurably louder. But the message is difficult to understand and often misunderstood.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Jan. 14 about Red Thunder Cloud, a storyteller and speaker of the Catawba Indian language, misstated his relationship with the Catawba Nation of Rock Hill, S.C. The nation's chief, Gilbert Blue, said that while Mr. Thunder Cloud was of Catawba ancestry, his name was not on the nation's membership rolls.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;First Gates, Now Clinton
description: Last November, the Christopher Columbus School in Union City was featured in a videotape in which William H. Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, described how he envisioned the future of education. Now the middle school is getting more recognition. President Clinton and Vice President Gore will visit the school on Thursday, a spokesman for United States Representative Robert Menendez, Democrat of Bayonne, said yesterday. Christopher Columbus has set up a computer network that links its students and teachers in class and at home.

title: BASKETBALL;Shifting Course for the Red Storm
description: This was supposed to be Felipe Lopez's team for as long as he wanted to stay at St. John's. Zendon Hamilton was viewed as a long-term project -- even though he was a highly recruited prospect out of high school.

title: Terriers Take Beanpot With Record
description: Boston University set a record tonight for most goals in the championship game of the Beanpot tournament while overwhelming Northeastern.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Gold Prices Continue to Retreat On Indications of Ample Supply
description: Gold prices dropped yesterday for the fifth time in six days as falling borrowing rates pointed to adequate supply.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mexico Renews Its Intention To Sell Parts of Oil Monopoly
description: Despite growing popular opposition across Mexico to the move, Government officials reiterated their commitment today to selling key pieces of the huge state-owned oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, while hinting broadly that they might limit foreign investment to insure that domestic companies get a chance to participate in the privatized businesses.

title: After the I.R.A. Bomb, Reviving the Peace Effort
description: In the three days since the Irish Republican Army resumed its campaign of violence by detonating a huge bomb in East London, political leaders in Britain and Ireland have fallen all over themselves reiterating their continued dedication to achieving peace in Northern Ireland.

title: Covent Garden Spactacle Is Not Only Onstage
description: Most opera- and balletgoers probably suspect that people in the performing arts are touchy, tense and arrogant, and that putting together a season's worth of world-class productions is much harder than it looks. But if there were any lingering illusions about the inner workings of stately Covent Garden, they have been wholly shattered in the last few weeks.

title: NYC;When Police Presume Too Much
description: AUGUST state legislators, including nearly all those from the city, made it official yesterday when they moved faster than a three-card monte player to override the Governor's veto of a sensitive labor bill. New York's police officers and firefighters, they affirmed, are special, a breed apart from all other municipal workers, deserving enhanced arbitration privileges even though Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani says that the changes may break the bank.

title: Reprieve for Allegany State Forest
description: Gov. George Pataki of New York did the right thing in rejecting a plan to allow commercial logging in Allegany State Forest. In doing so, he reiterated the importance of preserving mature stands of forest and protecting lands entrusted to the state. Now he should take the next step and support legislation in the Assembly to ban all commercial logging in state forests.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMCAST BUYS NEXTEL STAKE FOR $100 MILLION
description: The Comcast Corporation exercised its right to acquire 8.2 million shares of the wireless telecommunications concern Nextel Communications Inc. for about $100 million, Nextel said yesterday. Comcast's share purchase, which represents about a 4 percent stake in Nextel, is related to Nextel's $357 million acquisition of Dial Page Inc., which was completed late last month. Comcast had a right to buy up to 9.7 million Nextel shares initially, but that number was lowered to 8.2 million shares after taking into account the number of shares actually issued in connection with the Dial Page acquisition. Comcast was one of Nextel's first big investors.

title: Abstract Art's Guide
description: To the Editor:

title: 16 People Are Hurt In Texas Gang Fight
description: A disagreement between two rival gangs escalated into gunfire at an apartment complex early today, wounding 16 people.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Finding Connections Between the Unconnected Edward Aldwell, Pianist Weill Recital Hall

title: Who's Avoiding Living-Room Politics?
description: To the Editor:

title: Death Penalty Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Poetry, Soaring and Pure, From a Resurrected Songbook Benita Valente and William Stone Weill Recital Hall

title: A Case of Marital Discord Hits a Nerve
description: On Saturday morning, as he was about to leave for Sabbath services, a burly Hasidic businessman in a half-finished housing development here heard an insistent knock on his door.

title: Reporter's Notebook;Editor to Joan Collins: Don't Quit the Day Job
description: Just because the prose relies heavily on the word "throbbing" and the product is intended to become smeared with sandy suntan lotion, the creative process isn't necessarily absent from the writing of commercial fiction. That theme defiantly emerged in a Manhattan courtroom last week in the contract dispute between Random House and Joan Collins, the actress-author.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;Prison Makes Rap Tougher
description: 2Pac: 'All Eyez on Me'

title: Corrections
description: The "Most Wanted" table in Business Day yesterday, listing the best-selling music albums for the week of Jan. 29 through Feb. 4, misstated the label of one album, "Boys for Pele," by Tori Amos. It is Atlantic Records, not Arista.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF DEPARTMENT 56 FALL AFTER EARNINGS REPORT
description: Shares of Department 56 Inc. plunged 41 percent yesterday after the company, a distributor of collectibles, reported lower than expected earnings and said that orders would fall. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of the company fell $15.625, to $22.375. It was the most active issue with trading volume of almost 5.7 million shares.
