The company, which also distributes specialty giftware, said orders in the current quarter would slip 10 percent after it terminated about 50 customers for violating its merchandise guidelines. Department 56 said net income in the three months ended Dec. 31 increased to $5.5 million, or 25 cents a share. But analysts had expected earnings of 27 cents a share, according to the First Call Corporation.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Gunman Is Sought in Theft
description: The authorities were searching for a man who shot and critically wounded an armored car guard at a supermarket yesterday and fled with a bag of money. Shooting erupted shortly after the guard, Serge Oros, picked up a bag containing an undisclosed sum of money at the Acme supermarket, said Ann Todd, an F.B.I. agent. Acme offered a $5,000 reward for information leading to the gunman's arrest, The Associated Press reported.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Holyfield May Fight Czyz at the Garden
description: BOBBY CZYZ of Raritan, N.J., is close to agreeing to face the former heavyweight champion EVANDER HOLYFIELD at Madison Square Garden on May 10 as part of a heavyweight tripleheader.

title: Law to Ease Disclosures on Child Abuse
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation today loosening laws requiring secrecy in child abuse investigations.

title: Beverly Sills, at 66, Stars in Her Grandest Role
description: Somewhere under Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Beverly Sills is lost. Upstairs in Avery Fisher Hall, a German film crew is waiting to interview her for a 70th-birthday tribute to Kurt Masur, the New York Philharmonic's music director, who is to present her on camera with a hand-carved Bohemian Nutcracker.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Are They Opposites? Do They Attract?
description: It probably did not occur to the planners of the 92d Street Y's Schubertiade that they might run out of fresh themes to explore before the series ended on Schubert's bicentennial in 1997. And in past seasons, they have come up with topics that were either enlightening or provocative. But four hours' worth of lectures on the commonplace, unarguable topic of Beethoven's influence on Schubert on Sunday afternoon -- the second day of this year's installment -- left a listener wondering how such a promising series had come to such a pass.

title: H.I.V. Positive, Whoever They Are, Deserve No Moral Censure
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Pay Scale Set for Wickman
description: Although the Yankees spent yesterday arguing against a $2.6 million raise for their 27-year-old center fielder Bernie Williams they averted arbitration with their 27-year-old reliever Bob Wickman and settled on a one-year, $800,000 contract.

title: SWIMMING;Long Island Swimmer Testifies Before Board
description: After two days of testimony from 50 witnesses, the board of the United States Swimming Federation last night began deliberating the eligibility of a 15-year-old Long Island swimmer who tested positive last summer for an anabolic steroid.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt ACF Industries, St. Charles, Mo., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell as much as $250 million of securities. Jefferies & Co. will be the lead underwriter.

title: Sports of The Times;The Knicks Have an Office-Temp Look About Them
description: THEY put J. R. Reid and Brad Lohaus in the other gym, the way the British put pets from overseas in quarantine for six months. The two new Knicks could not practice with the 10 old Knicks yesterday until their physical examinations became official.

title: Disputed Medieval Map Called Genuine After All
description: Correction Appended

title: COMPANY NEWS;JURY CONSIDERS VERDICT ON BREAST IMPLANTS
description: After nearly three and a half months of testimony, a jury began considering yesterday whether the Dow Corning Corporation's insurers should have to cover its claims for breast-implant litigation. The jury's verdict will dictate whether up to $1 billion worth of claims will have to be paid by any or all of the 43 insurance companies that sold product liability insurance to the silicone maker from 1962 to 1985. If Dow Corning wins, the money will go toward settling and defending the company against lawsuits by thousands of women who say they suffered a variety of ailments and diseases from breast implants.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.F.L.;Bills Will Not Offer Reed a Contract
description: The Buffalo Bills will not offer a contract to ANDRE REED before Friday, allowing their best wide receiver to begin searching for a new team.

title: Fighting Irish
description: On March 13 a show, "Gaelic Gotham: A History of the Irish in New York," is scheduled to open at the Museum of the City of New York. If the show does go on, however, it may not be the extraordinary exploration once envisioned of an ethnic group that has lived in this city for more than 350 years. A contretemps between Marion Casey, the show's former guest curator; Robert R. MacDonald, the museum's director, and experts on Irish-American history has diminished hopes for the exhibit, heightened tempers and raised once again a question that repeatedly rends this diverse country. Who should speak for or about a people?

title: Police Apology Is Offered In Queens Man's Shooting
description: The first thing Lebert Folkes says he wants to know is why Police Officer Christopher Strom, a nine-year veteran, shot him after ordering him out of his car in front of his Queens home on Sunday night. Then, he says, he wants to know where to find a good lawyer.

title: 2 Arrested in Thefts of From Synagogues
description: A burglar who preyed on New York City synagogues and a man accused of being his fence were charged yesterday with being partners in burglaries that took at least $100,000 in sacred Torahs and other religious objects, the police said.

title: French Bishop Supports Some Use of Condoms to Prevent AIDS
description: The chairman of a French Roman Catholic bishops' committee suggested in a report published today that the use of condoms could be justified in some cases to prevent the spread of AIDS, contradicting the Vatican's general condemnation of most methods of birth control.

title: Grand Jury Raises Possibility That Grace Violated Criminal Law
description: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that a Federal grand jury had raised the possibility that the company violated criminal laws while seeking to persuade the Federal Food and Drug Administration to allow Grace to resume imports in 1991 from its dialysis products factory in Dublin, Ireland.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Swiss Reinsurance Buys 3.6% Stake in Fortis
description: Swiss Reinsurance, the world's second-largest reinsurance company, will buy a 3.6 percent stake in Fortis A.G. for 5 billion Belgian francs ($328 million). Fortis, the Belgian insurance and banking company, sold 1.35 million new shares to the Zurich-based company, bringing the total number of issued shares to 37.6 million.

title: POLITICS: ON TELEVISION;Calling Results of Caucuses Before They Even Begin
description: In a striking confluence of old-fashioned democracy and computer-age data gathering, Senator Bob Dole was declared the winner of the Iowa caucuses last night, five minutes before they began.

title: New Directions for the N.A.A.C.P.
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has an opportunity to chart important new directions at its board meeting in New York this week.

title: POP REVIEW;Love, Melancholy and Improvisational Salsa
description: It wasn't until halfway through the sold-out Concierto de Amor at Madison Square Garden, when the singer Gilberto Santa Rosa appeared, that the show began. Until then the music had been for adolescents: pretty people, some wearing braces, making nondescript music just fine for warming up a party. But Mr. Santa Rosa is different: he sings as an adult, and brings an entire improvisatory tradition to the music.

title: Train Crash Puts Focus on Safety Measures
description: Seeking to prevent just the sort of collision that occurred on Friday in New Jersey, Federal regulators imposed stiff penalties five years ago on violations by railroad engineers, including the kind of error that put two blots on the record of one of the engineers killed in Friday's crash.

title: Competition and Pressure to Perform Cited : Americans Hit the Books
description: EVIDENCE is mounting that secondary school students in the United States are signing up for more courses and taking heavier loads in the core academic areas of English, mathematics, social studies and science.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CABARET
description: A Succession of Moods, From Upbeat to Nostalgic Rosemary Clooney Rainbow and Stars

title: CHRONICLE
description: TOM SELLECK, the actor best known as Magnum, P.I., is taking on a new role. With his father and two brothers, he is planning to demolish an old General Motors plant in the San Fernando Valley that closed in 1992 and build a $100 million shopping complex.

title: Hair-Growth Drug to Be Sold Over the Counter
description: Balding Americans will be able to buy the hair-growth drug Rogaine by spring without stopping to see a doctor first.

title: Tenant Finds Video Camera in Mirror
description: While entering her darkened basement apartment in North Merrick early this morning with her boyfriend, a young Long Island woman noticed a mysterious red light shining in the middle of a mirror on her bedroom wall, the Nassau County police said today.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Atomic Bomb History on CD-ROM: Color but No Context
description: CD-ROM multimedia, that ultimate hybrid, keeps borrowing old forms as it tries to become something more than an interesting concept with great potential.

title: WHX Offers $1.67 Billion for Teledyne
description: The WHX Corporation, the parent of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, announced yesterday that it was offering $30 a share, or $1.67 billion, in a second bid to acquire Teledyne Inc., a producer of aviation electronics and specialty metal parts.

title: SFX in Deal For 16 Stations
description: SFX Broadcasting Inc. agreed yesterday to pay $105.3 million for the assets of the closely held Prism Radio Partners L.P., including 16 radio stations in five markets.

title: Japanese Troops in Golan
description: The first Japanese troops to serve in a full peacekeeping role formally joined United Nations forces in the Golan Heights today.

title: Louis Ward, 76, Manufacturer Built Fortune in Candy Business
description: Louis L. Ward, a businessman who built Russell Stover Candies Inc. into the nation's largest manufacturer and distributor of gift-packaged candy, died on Saturday at his home in Kansas City, Mo. He was 76.

title: In French Lyces, Bilingual Degrees
description: SEVRES, France  An experiment to give high school students a bicultural as well as a bilingual education has been adopted by many schools in France in the past 25 years and has become a fixed feature of the national educational system.

title: Stocks Soar; Dow Passes 5,600 Mark
description: Continuing a remarkable run that has some Wall Street analysts making nervous comparisons to 1987, the stock market raced ahead again yesterday with the Dow Jones industrial average finishing above the 5,600 mark.

title: Troubles Are All Too Human;At Pet Hospital, Fiscal Woes and Stormy Relations
description: It began in 1910 as an effort by society matrons to help bedraggled horses on the Manhattan docks and became the world's largest pet hospital. This self-described Mayo Clinic for Animals treated everything from a puppy that swallowed a 12-inch knife to an 800-pound circus tiger, using technology only slightly behind that of advanced human hospitals.

title: G.O.P. Displays Its Debt Hypocrisy
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadian Bribe Inquiry Said to Look at Boeing
description: The Boeing Company and a former senior sales executive are under criminal investigation in Canada on suspicion that a former Boeing subsidiary paid more than $1 million in bribes and fees to sell five airplanes to Bahamasair in 1990, people with knowledge of the investigation said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Back-to-Back Challenges
description: Mary Lee Fitzgerald, a former State Education Commissioner, chose Lincoln's birthday to announce that she is seeking the Democratic nomination to challenge United States Representative William J. Martini, a freshman Republican from Clifton. William D. Pascrell, Mayor of Paterson and a State Assemblyman, said he would announce his candidacy tomorrow.

title: AT&T and MCI Stocks Rise on Joint Talks to Enter Local Service
description: Warmed by the prospect of two old foes coming together, investors drove up the shares of AT&T and MCI Communications yesterday, after MCI confirmed a report that they were in discussions about teaming up to build local telephone networks.

title: Editor in Chief of Reader's Digest Resigns
description: Reader's Digest Association Inc. said today that Kenneth Y. Tomlinson had resigned as editor of Reader's Digest magazine, two weeks after the company announced that it would lay off up to 1,000 employees.

title: Report Warns About Cutting Remedial Aid
description: The elimination of remedial courses at colleges and universities by states facing budget constraints could block many poor and minority students from obtaining advanced training, a report by a higher education group reported today.

title: Apple Suspends Quarterly Dividend for First Time
description: Apple Computer Inc. has for the first time suspended payment of its quarterly dividend, the company said in a filing today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Francisco M. Garcia, Band Leader, 49
description: Francisco M. Garcia, leader of the 1960's pop quartet Cannibal and the Headhunters, died on Jan. 21 at Kaiser Permanente Medical Center. He was 49.

title: U.S. Shows China a Worrying Lack of Fortitude
description: To the Editor:

title: DOGS;It's Terrier vs. Boxer for the Top Spot
description: The 120th annual Westminster Kennel Club show, the world's most exclusive dog show, opened in Madison Square Garden yesterday with group victories by a Skye terrier, a boxer, a papillon and a Dalmatian. The Skye and the boxer appear to be strong contenders when the best in show is crowned tonight.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Niger's Military Rulers Set Election Timetable
description: Niger's new military leaders announced a timetable today to return to democratic rule, with presidential, parliamentary and local elections in the last quarter of this year.

title: Supply-and-Demand Balance Weakens for Semiconductors
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator fell sharply in January, a trade organization reported today, providing a disturbing sign that the demand for computer chips is growing more slowly than the supply.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bankers Trust Picks Its Three Finalists
description: Bankers Trust said yesterday that it had narrowed a review on its account, with billings estimated at $6 million, to three finalists. The account had been handled by Merkley Newman Harty in New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group, from April 1993 until the agency declined to participate when the review began in November.

title: New Spynet Links C.I.A. And Envoys
description: In a sign that it is re-thinking its role, the Central Intelligence Agency will give American diplomats in Bosnia and other trouble zones computer access to secret information that may help them solve political and military problems.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Rolling and Tumbling About: Perfect Work for a 9-Year-Old Danspace Project St. Mark's Church Alison Salzinger gave her dancers lots to do in "Drift," the program of four short works that she offered on Thursday night as an attraction of the Danspace Project. The performers proved admirably nimble. But although it is conceivable that some strong emotional or intellectual passion inspired Ms. Salzinger to create these pieces, the presentation was interesting primarily as a display of formal ingenuity.

title: No Headline
description: West Pressing Sudan

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;11 Die in 300-Car Crash On Foggy Italian Road
description: At least 11 people were killed today when 300 cars smashed in a chain-reaction that left twisted metal and gasoline-fed flames across a main highway in northern Italy. Hundreds of people were hurt, some seriously.

title: POLITICS: THE SCENE;A Quirk in the Democratic Process
description: Rick Halvorsen said a few words for Lamar Alexander. Monte Shaw spoke in favor of Senator Bob Dole. David Dryer spoke for Senator Phil Gramm. No one came forward to lobby for Steve Forbes.

title: HOCKEY;Healy Plays the Role Of the Good Soldier
description: The return of Mike Richter to the Rangers finally appears to be imminent. "You may see him Thursday, you may not," Coach Colin Campbell said of the goalie, who suffered a pulled groin muscle Dec. 30. "We'll see how he feels. I thought you were going to see him Saturday."

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about plans by The Village Voice to begin free distribution in Manhattan referred imprecisely to another Greenwich Village weekly, The Villager. While it was overshadowed after the founding of The Voice in 1955, it continues to appear; it has not ceased publication.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Inflation Slows
description: Inflation in western Germany slowed to a 7 1/2-year low in the 12 months that ended in mid-January, the Government said yesterday. Consumer prices in western Germany rose one-tenth of 1 percent in the final month and 1.4 percent in the 12-month period, the Federal Statistics Office said. The annual inflation rate was the lowest since August 1988. Many economists expect inflation in western Germany to slow to about 1 percent in the first half of this year in light of flagging German growth. The Government expects the economy to grow 1.5 percent this year, down from 1.9 percent in 1995. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Adolf Galland, Top Aviator For the Nazis, Is Dead at 83
description: Just before sunrise on Sept. 1, 1939, minutes after the first shots of World War II were fired by invading German troops, a 27-year-old Luftwaffe pilot began dropping bombs from his Henschel 123 biplane on Polish infantry positions near the frontier town of Panki.

title: Foreign Affairs;Those Funny Russians
description: A couple of jokes being told by Russian delegates at last week's Davos economic forum bear repeating. One was: What is the difference between an optimist and a pessimist in Russia today? Answer: A pessimist believes that things in Russia can't possibly get any worse. An optimist believes that they can.

title: An Empty Village
description: To the Editor:

title: Child and 2 Adults Die in a Queens Fire
description: A 3-year-old girl and two adults died yesterday when flames dashed through a three-story house in South Jamaica, Queens, that officials said had been illegally converted into five units.

title: Correction
description: An article on Saturday about Random House's lawsuit against Joan Collins misstated the agreement between the two parties. Miss Collins was initially paid a $1.2 million advance on a two-book contract and was to have received $4 million more for the completed manuscripts.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;For Return From an Injury, Pianist Switches to Mozart
description: Murray Perahia returned to Carnegie Hall on Monday night, playing the piano with the Philadelphia Orchestra under Wolfgang Sawallisch. His absence these past few seasons has been troubling. Various explanations have been given for the hand injury that laid Mr. Perahia low, but it is hard not to suspect that his determined forays into the heaviest piano literature played a part.

title: About New York;Helping People Say 'Be Mine' for Nearly 50 Years
description: VALENTINE'S DAY? Bill Schifrin thinks it's for the single guys who utter "commitment" in the same breath as "institution" -- as in mental. But he has another institution in mind, too.

title: U.S. Is Seeking Forum to Calm Asia Tensions
description: Defense officials of China, Japan, the United States and other Asia-Pacific nations should meet regularly to promote understanding and head off military crises, Defense Secretary William J. Perry said today.

title: A Table at Rao's? Forgetaboutit
description: JIMMY CIGAR is at the back table.

title: Making Shopping Easy
description: To The Living Section:

title: Russian Protest Builds Over Chechnya
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart in some editions yesterday listing state legislators who voted against overriding Gov. George E. Pataki's veto of a bill on arbitration for New York City police and firefighter contracts misstated the position and the party affiliation of one Assemblyman. Denis J. Butler of Queens, who is a Democrat, voted to override the veto.

title: At Ford Foundation, a New Chief and a New Style
description: When the trustees of the Ford Foundation looked for a new leader to succeed Franklin A. Thomas, the foundation's longtime president, they did not reach for a big-name politician, a corporate titan or an Ivy League president. Instead, they promoted the ultimate insider: Susan V. Berresford, a Ford vice president who had spent most of her career at the foundation's headquarters on East 43d Street in Manhattan and had worked closely with Mr. Thomas in his 16 years at the helm.

title: Doctors Found to Fail in Diagnosing Addictions
description: JUST a small fraction of the millions of people who are dependent on alcohol and illegal drugs get help from their doctors, a national panel of experts has concluded.

title: TENNIS;Capriati Out of Paris Open
description: Jennifer Capriati pulled out of the Paris Open today, just before she was scheduled to play her first competitive match in 15 months. Capriati strained a muscle near her right hip and lower back while practicing earlier in the day.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;No Lame Ducks for Harper
description: With their midseason dealing apparently done, the Knicks are about to become a for-better-or-for-worse team. These Knicks are players who will only be together until the loss of a playoff series parts them.

title: POLITICS: THE MONEY Ads for Forbes Played Role in Outcome but Not the One He Intended
description: By some accounts, Steve Forbes's $4 million advertising campaign here was a colossal waste of money. By others, it was the most decisive factor in the Iowa caucuses; the decision just didn't happen to go Mr. Forbes's way.

title: Officers at Nabisco Ordered to Testify in Suit
description: A Federal Judge in North Carolina yesterday compelled the top two executives of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation to testify this week in a lawsuit involving Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn, the investors who are seeking a rapid spinoff of RJR Nabisco's food business from the company's tobacco operations.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Proposals for Charity Care
description: The New Jersey Hospital Association said its members have already provided $60 million in unreimbursed care to poor patients since funds set aside for charity care ran out Dec. 31. Three Democratic Assembly members, led by Neil M. Cohen of Elizabeth, the deputy minority leader, said they had come up with a solution to the crisis and would propose today that $200 million for charity-care reimbursements be made available from the state's general fund.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;BOC Profit Up 13%
description: BOC Group P.L.C., Britain's largest industrial gas maker, said yesterday that its pretax profit rose 13 percent in the first quarter despite an unexpected slowdown in demand in December. Danny Rosenkranz, chief executive of BOC, attributed some of the decline in December to weather-related distribution problems. The company said pretax profit in the quarter that ended Dec. 31 rose to $154 million, from $137 million in the comparable period a year earlier. BOC makes oxygen, nitrogen and an array of gases. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Highlights of the Report by the Regional Plan Association: Centers;Strengthening The Urban Cores
description: The long-term vitality of the region as a whole is inextricably tied to the health of its urban downtowns, from the central business district of midtown Manhattan to the urban cores of Bridgeport, Conn., and Newark, the Regional Plan Association said in its report. These business centers must not only be desirable places to live and work in the 21st century, but must also be better linked with each other through a more interconnected transit system.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Andy Fenning, who as president of J. Walter Thompson Portugal is responsible for the JWT Lisbon and Abrinicio, Publicidade e Marketing agencies, was named to the new position of executive vice president and strategic development director at the J. Walter Thompson Co., a unit of the WPP Group; he will move to New York. Assuming his duties at JWT Lisbon and Abrinicio will be the managing directors of each agency, Manuel Patarrana and Luis Preto da Silva.

title: First the Feast, Then the Fast
description: MARDI GRAS, or Fat Tuesday, will be celebrated next week. It is a time for indulging in rich foods, especially fried treats, on the day before Ash Wednesday, the beginning of the 40-day Lenten period of abstinence in the Christian calendar.

title: Fiber's Benefits Backed in War on Heart Ills
description: IF findings on dietary fat are confusing to many Americans, conflicting findings on dietary fiber may make them want to throw away their diet plans in disgust. Are oat-bran muffins good or not? Is it the fiber that matters or the fat?

title: ROCK REVIEW;British Band With Home-Grown Influences
description: As the American audience for contemporary British pop bands like Oasis, Pulp and Blur grows, the quality of the performances by these groups is also improving. Perhaps it's a case of reciprocal positive energy. That was the case when Blur played a strong set with two generous encores on Saturday at Roseland. Unlike the band's past New York shows, this one did not include its cynical "Magic America" song.

title: Stocks Rise in Japan
description: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 159.36 points, or nearly eight-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,943.59. On TuesDay, the Nikkei fell 150.59 points, or 0.72 percent.

title: Dog Show;Brady, the Clumber Spaniel, Takes His Final Bow
description: For three years, Brady has been traveling from dog show to dog show, maybe 100 a year, beating more dogs than any other clumber spaniel in history.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Referee Gets H.I.V. Test
description: A day after TOMMY MORRISON announced he had tested positive for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, the referee in his fight with LENNOX LEWIS last fall decided to take an H.I.V. test of his own. The results were negative.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Rock Opera A la 'Boheme' And 'Hair'
description: The subject of the work is death at an early age. And in one of the dark dramatic coincidences theater occasionally springs on us, its 35-year-old author died only weeks before its opening. Yet no one who attends Jonathan Larson's "Rent," the exhilarating, landmark rock opera at the New York Theater Workshop, is likely to mistake it for a wake.

title: Congressman Announces Plans to Seek Bradley Seat
description: A key race for the United States Senate heated up today as Richard A. Zimmer, a Republican Congressman, formally announced that he would seek the seat being vacated by Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat who decided not to seek a fourth term.

title: TV Newsman Gave To Forbes Campaign
description: Chuck Scarborough, the anchor of WNBC-TV's Channel 4 newscast, has donated $1,000 to Steve Forbes's Presidential campaign.

title: Report Warns That New York Area Could Decline
description: The New York metropolitan region -- the nation's pre-eminent urban center, and a worldwide symbol of opportunity -- faces the threat of a long-term economic decline in the 21st century unless residents and politicians summon the will and resources to begin a multibillion-dollar campaign of transportation improvements, education reforms and urban rejuvenation, a major planning group said yesterday.

title: Beuel Journal;It's a Woman's World (And Men Pay Lip Service)
description: This is the time of the year when a visitor here for the day from another planet might conclude that German women are ferocious and promiscuous, and about as benevolent toward men as black widow spiders; that German men wear polyester ties and ride around in groups on ornate flatbed trucks, and that the children are all curbside beggars who subsist entirely on handout candy.

title: At the Nation's Table: Westley, Calif.;Vegetable Snack Mix A Child Can Love
description: Two-year-old Nicolette Stephens gobbles colorful dried vegetables as if they were M & M's.

title: Goldman, Sachs Capital Rises
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, the biggest investment-banking partnership in the world, has confirmed in a regulatory filing that its capital bounced back last year from a decline in 1994.

title: Judge Greene Is Disconnected
description: Last week, when the new telecommunications act was signed into law, Judge Harold Greene finally lost the job he has held for 12 years -- almost single-handedly deciding what telephone companies could and could not do.

title: COMPANY NEWS;INTERNATIONAL PAPER TO TAKE EARNINGS CHARGE
description: The International Paper Company said yesterday that it expected its reorganization to reduce first-quarter earnings by $500 million, or $1.35 a share, before taxes. International Paper, based in Purchase, N.Y., said the reorganization was expected to save the company $70 million in 1996, before taxes, and $100 million in 1997. The company plans to use about half of the $500 million to consolidate its imaging-products business, which supplies film, paper and equipment for photo-processing. The rest of the charge covers the sale or closing of plants in the company's other two businesses -- print and packaging and industrial papers. A spokesman said details of plant closings and layoffs had not been determined.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Jan. 4 about the increasing personal and social tolerance of adultery misstated the law on adultery in Connecticut. It is not a crime.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Ekes Out a Gain But Stocks Generally Fall Broad stock indexes dropped from their record levels, pulled down by a slump in semiconductor stocks. But the Dow Jones industrial average gained slightly, to its seventh record in a row. The spurt has lifted the average 4.2 percent in the last week. The Dow ended up 1.08 points, at 5,601.23, while the S.& P. 500 index eased 0.94, to 660.51. [Page D8.]

title: Restaurants, Like Hearts, Are Aflutter
description: IT seems that all a restaurateur should have to do for Valentine's Day is to stock up on oysters, roses and Champagne. Most restaurants have been booked solid for tonight for weeks.

title: Three Days' Immersion (Well, Nearly) in Chocolate
description: SMEARED with melted mousse and looking somewhat dazed, Joan McDonough pointed to the slogan on her T-shirt: "In the beginning there was the word and it was chocolate."

title: Review Faults Maternity Care at Woodhull
description: A significant number of problems in deliveries at Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center can be traced to mistakes or poor care by the hospital, a state review of medical records has found.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Let the Bidding Begin
description: When the National Football League free-agency signing period begins Friday, it will resemble the Oklahoma land rush. Owners have counted their bankrolls, general managers have scrutinized the dreaded salary cap and coaches have checked off their list of the top players on the open market. They are all poised to make a mad dash and stake claims to those who could help them build a playoff contender.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Inmate Wants to Be Executed
description: John M. Martini, a 65-year-old convicted kidnapper and murderer, is weary of life in jail and wants New Jersey to carry out the death sentence imposed on him in 1990 after he was convicted of abducting and killing an old friend.

title: COMPANY NEWS;JUDGE RULES CIGNA REORGANIZATION CAN PROCEED
description: The Cigna Corporation may proceed with reorganizing its United States property and casualty business, pending an appeal by opposing insurers and policyholders, a Pennsylvania judge ruled yesterday. Judge James Colins of the Commonwealth Court denied a request for a stay. Last week, Pennsylvania regulators approved Cigna's plan to split the business. Under the plan, one unit would keep the most profitable policies and the other would phase out coverage on policies with the largest claims. Cigna also said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 51 percent, exceeding analysts' expectations, because profits from its property and casualty unit. The earnings were released after shares of Cigna closed $3 higher at $121.625.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DETECTION SYSTEMS INC., Fairport, N.Y., which makes devices such as infrared detectors and smoke alarms, said it had bought Radionics Inc. from Expamet International P.L.C. of London for $17.7 million.

title: Food Notes
description: Onions, Sweet Onions

title: N.J. Transit May Drop Split Shifts at Night in Wake of Crash
description: New Jersey Transit said yesterday that it has done away with the nighttime split shift worked by an engineer who was killed in last Friday's train crash, and was considering doing away with all similar shifts in the wake of questions about the safety of such schedules.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;In Love With the Lore (or Lies?) of Love Affairs
description: The Love Affair as a Work of Art By Dan Hofstadter 314 pages. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. $24.

title: Stiffer Punishment For Hiring of Aliens
description: Moving to fulfill his promise to tighten enforcement of immigration laws, President Clinton signed an executive order today barring Federal contractors who knowingly hire illegal aliens from obtaining additional Government contracts for one year.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Libya Congress Demands Answers on Oil Revenues
description: Libyan legislators have harshly criticized their Government during stormy debates in the Congress, demanding to know what happened to billions of dollars in oil earnings.

title: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;Deficit Looks Tiny as Issue
description: For nearly two years, the Republican economic rallying cry has been loud, insistent and single-minded: The biggest problem ailing the American economy is the Federal budget deficit, and the country cannot prosper until it is wiped out. But a Presidential campaign season has a way of rewriting political agendas, and Republicans have learned that what once seemed to play well in Washington does not ring many bells elsewhere.

title: Governors' Plans on Welfare Attacked
description: Civil rights groups today assailed proposals endorsed by the nation's governors last week to give states vast new authority over welfare and Medicaid. They said that "African-American children will be disproportionately harmed" by the changes.

title: COMPANY NEWS;OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM ANNOUNCES LAYOFFS
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it would dismiss 450 workers at its Occidental Chemical Corporation subsidiary and eliminate the subsidiary's international division. The layoffs and reorganization are expected to result in annualized savings of about $100 million, Occidental said, and no charge against 1996 earnings is expected. The latest moves are part of Occidental's reorganization of worldwide oil and gas operations, announced in October. Last month, the company dismissed 400 workers at its Midcon Corporation subsidiary, to save about $50 million.

title: BASKETBALL;Villanova Set For Seton Hall
description: Villanova (21-3 over all, 11-2 in the Big East 6) is riding an eight-game winning streak. Kerry Kittles is averaging 19.9 points a game. The Wildcats will face Seton Hall tonight at the duPont Pavilion.

title: Israel, Fearing Attack, Closes Off West Bank and Gaza
description: The Israeli Government closed off the West Bank and Gaza Strip until further notice on Monday night, saying that it had intelligence information that Muslim militants were planning a terrorist attack.

title: FILM REVIEW;The Free-for-All World Of Appropriation Art
description: By their own reckoning, members of the Bay Area recording and performance group Negativland got themselves into trouble by having too much fun. Their prank began with a pirated audiotape of Casey Kasem, the normally boosterish-sounding disk jockey and radio personality, as he cursed a blue streak while trying to record a spot about the band U2. Sensing opportunity at hand, Negativland enthusiastically mixed these mutterings with samples from a U2 song, then put out a 1991 single on the SST label with a picture of the U-2 spy plane on its cover.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Chanel lets its hair down, hoping to put a casual but chic face on a campaign for its new fragrance.
description: HOW youthful and contemporary does Chanel Inc. want the image for Allure, its new women's fragrance, to be? On a scale of one to five -- CK One, that is, to Chanel No. 5 -- the goal seems to be a two and a half.

title: U.S. Judge Says Removing Alarm Boxes Harms Deaf
description: In another setback to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to remove 16,300 fire alarm boxes, a Federal judge ruled yesterday that the plan violated the civil rights of the city's 65,000 deaf and hearing-impaired residents.

title: Dean Accused of Sexualy Abusing Student
description: A high school administrator responsible for disciplining students surrendered to the authorities today on charges that he molested a student and threatened to suspend her if she did not comply with sexual demands.

title: Corrections
description: A caption on Monday with a sports picture showing Shaquille O'Neal with his arms upraised during the National Basketball Association All-Star Game last Sunday omitted an explanation of the gesture. O'Neal was giving the sign of the Omega Psi Phi fraternity, to which he belongs.

title: Lawsuit Tests Lethal Power of Words
description: With his V-necked sweater, reading glasses, and sunlit office cluttered with manuscripts, the amiable owner of Paladin Press seems to fit right in at this liberal university town, sometimes called "the People's Republic of Boulder."

title: Dream Team's Foes For Atlanta Are Set
description: The United States Olympic men's basketball team was placed in Group A with Croatia and Lithuania in the draw held today by the Atlanta Olympic organizers and FIBA, the sport's world governing body. Argentina, China and Angola round out the competition for the latest edition of the United States Dream Team. Group B will consist of Brazil, Yugoslavia, Greece, Puerto Rico, Australia and Korea.

title: FILM REVIEW;Goodbye Santo Domingo, Hello Manhattan
description: Underneath its sugar coating, "Nueba Yol," a comic fable about a young Dominican widower who visits New York City and discovers it is not the paradise paved in dollar bills that he had imagined, offers a fairly hardheaded dose of urban reality. At almost every turn, Balbuena (Luisito Marti), a happy-go-lucky Dominican Everyman who mortgages his house in Santo Domingo to buy a visa, finds his boundless good will either ignored or exploited by others.

title: INSIDE
description: Identifying War Criminals

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Kiwi Air PicksA Unit of Interpublic
description: Kiwi International Air Lines said yesterday that it had named Long Haymes Carr in Winston-Salem, N.C., to handle its account, which had been at Gianettino & Meredith in Short Hills, N.J., since July 1992. The billings were estimated at $8 million.

title: Charlie Conerly, 74, Is Dead; Giants' Quarterback in 50's
description: Charlie Conerly, the quarterback who led the New York Giants to the 1956 National Football League championship and held virtually all of the club's career passing records until Phil Simms surpassed them, died yesterday in Methodist Hospital in Memphis. He was 74.

title: Fat and Breast Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Lotus Wins Software Case
description: A court has ordered a Singaporean accountant to pay the Lotus Development Corporation $2.3 million for selling pirated copies of the company's software. Lotus, which spent five years pursuing the case, said today that the award was one of the highest ever for software piracy.

title: Top Colleges Filling More Slots With Students Who Apply Early
description: For many high school seniors, applying to college used to mean filling out forms in December, getting word in April and choosing a campus in May. But now, more and more top colleges are grabbing the nation's best students using early admissions programs, and they are filling significant portions of their freshmen classes before Christmas.

title: Martin Balsam Is Dead at 76; Ubiquitous Character Actor
description: Correction Appended

title: A Valentine Lost at 3, Kept in Mind for 51 Years
description: THE memories of first love are warped and yellowed like the old photographs.

title: WCBS-TV Director Shot in Harlem Holdup
description: A news director for WCBS-TV Channel 2 was shot twice during an attempted robbery in Harlem early yesterday, the police said.

title: Housing Authority to Strip Paint in Project Stairwells
description: The chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, Ruben Franco, announced yesterday that the city would immediately begin stripping the paint from the stairwell walls in housing projects across the city because the use of a fire retardant had not solved the problem of dangerous stairwell fires.

title: Pay for New Apple Chief Seen Topping $10 Million
description: However shaky the future of Apple Computer Inc. may be, Gilbert F. Amelio, the company's new chairman and chief executive, is sure to be financially secure.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Willis and Whitman Confer
description: As his stretch limousine waited outside the State House, the actor Bruce Willis met with Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday to talk about a project. Not a project of the star-studded Hollywood kind, but rather his planned multimillion-dollar investment in Penns Grove, an economically distressed Delaware River community in Salem County. Mr. Willis, who graduated from Penns Grove High School and grew up in nearby Carneys Point, bought 11 waterfront acres in Penns Grove last year. State officials said he plans to build a pier, a marina, open air markets, a hotel and a restaurant on the site. TERRY PRISTIN

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;News Service for Idle Computer Screens
description: Pointcast Inc., a privately held information services provider, introduced a free personalized Internet news and information service today that is displayed as a screen saver on a personal computer.

title: In Nail-Biting Last Chapter, Our Heroine Gets Her Million
description: In a vote for verbal quantity over literary quality, a Manhattan jury said yesterday that Random House has to compensate the actress-author Joan Collins for a manuscript that its editors have already declared to be unreadable and unpublishable.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Petroleum Reports 4th-Quarter Loss
description: The British Petroleum Company lost $263 million in the fourth quarter after taking a special charge to cover losses on two refinery sales. The company had a profit of $651 million in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenue in the quarter rose to $14.55 billion, from $13.64 billion. Without the special charges of $1.06 billion, the company would have earned $792 million. The company said it set aside the money to pay for the sale of money-losing refineries in Lavera, France, and Lima, Ohio.

title: Personal Health Sorting out contradictory findings about fat and health.
description: MANY health-conscious Americans are beginning to feel as if they are being tossed around like yo-yos by conflicting research findings. One day beta carotene is hailed as a life-saving antioxidant and the next it is stripped of health-promoting glory and even tainted by a brush of potential harm. Margarine, long hailed as a heart-saving alternative to butter, is suddenly found to contain a type of fat that could damage the heart.

title: Business Travel;Those headed to Atlanta for the Summer Olympics can still find rooms in private  homes.
description: ALMOST all 60,000 hotel rooms in Atlanta have long been sold out for each of the 17 days of the 1996 Summer Olympics, and because of the hotel shortage, Delta Air Lines no longer requires a Saturday night stay for buyers of discount tickets. But Atlanta officials say thousands of rooms are still available in private houses, apartments and condominiums.

title: What Mr. Forbes Can Do About Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: Lehman to Expand Its Mergers Group
description: Lehman Brothers Inc. has set plans to expand its mergers-and-acquisitions department to 100 investment bankers from 30 in a drive to pierce the upper tier of advisers amid a deal-making boom.

title: Dancing to Buchanan's Tune
description: As the endless caravans of Republican Presidential candidates spread out through New Hampshire this week, it is hard to reconcile this party with the finely tuned election machine that took over Congress a little over a year ago. Bob Dole has made being front-runner look like a dance competition as he tries to pick up the beat from Pat Buchanan. Lamar Alexander rides a new momentum, courtesy of the 17,000 Iowa Republicans who gave him a third-place showing in Monday night's caucuses. Steve Forbes lost, at least temporarily, his status as the leading Anybody But Dole. Having spent more than $400 per voter to come in fourth, Mr. Forbes will not qualify for any awards as investor of the week.

title: POLITICS: THE STATES;Kansas Cancels Presidential Primary for 1996
description: Kansas has bowed out of the primary business for 1996.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Bank Drops Inquiry Fee
description: Two weeks ago, First Fidelity Bank began trying to discourage certain customers from asking tellers about how much money they had in their accounts. The bank said customers whose accounts had dipped below the required minimum balance would be limited to two inquiries. After that they would be charged 75 cents for each question directed at a teller.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID T. SCHIFF, an investment banker, was elected chairman of the Wildlife Conservation Society yesterday, succeeding Howard Phipps Jr., who is stepping down after 20 years.

title: The Economics of Never-Never Land
description: I sometimes wish that I could bring myself to have faith in supply-side economics. True believers like Steve Forbes live in a never-never land in which there are no hard choices or painful tradeoffs, budget deficits will be cured by growth and poverty will vanish as the rising tide lifts all boats. Alas, like the great majority of grown-up economists, I just cannot manage the necessary suspension of my critical faculties.

title: BASKETBALL;Wallace's Best Move Was One He Didn't Make
description: This basketball season at Syracuse, from the start, was different for John Wallace because it began on his terms.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Expectations Of Rate Cuts Lift Bonds
description: With the bond market still holding fast to its expectations of further interest-rate cuts by the Federal Reserve, prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, with a weak regional report on business conditions generating only a muted response.

title: Market Place;Buffett Plans Cheap Stock But Not Quite A Penny One
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., which has the most expensive shares in the world, says it will offer a new, lower-priced share to investors. The catch is that the shares will have less in the way of voting rights and will not have the right to control how Berkshire makes corporate donations, a right that Berkshire shareholders currently have.

title: SWIMMING;U.S. Group Banishes Swimmer For Steroids
description: Before the sun came up yesterday morning, it may have set on the Olympic swimming career of Jess'ca Foschi.

title: Culturally Illiterate Are Now in Charge
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;This Is Chili: Beans, Corn, Tomatoes and Beer
description: This pretty chili blends the black beans, the yellow of the corn and the red of the tomatoes. Beer adds a pleasant, slightly yeasty flavor, but nonalcoholic beer works well, too.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Oil Prices Gain on Low Stocks During Cold in U.S. and Europe
description: Crude and heating oil prices rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as frigid weather in the United States and Europe increased heating needs while stockpiles remained lower than last year.

title: Apparent Defection From North Korea That Hurts to the Heart
description: If North Korea's "Great Leader" did not have enough problems, with hunger spreading throughout the world's last Stalinist state, his former wife was reported today to be in hiding and apparently planning to cooperate with Western intelligence agencies.

title: White House Rebukes G.O.P. For Scuttling Nominee to Fed
description: The White House, giving up on the nomination of Felix G. Rohatyn to be the Federal Reserve's vice chairman, attacked Congressional Republicans yesterday for blocking the appointment of an "obviously qualified" candidate, and poisoning the atmosphere in Washington.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Agreement to Defer Pay
description: To avoid layoffs and save $1 million, East Orange signed an agreement yesterday with 800 city employees to defer two weeks of their salary. Beginning Feb. 26, one day's pay will be withheld from each biweekly paycheck until June 30. The money will not be available to the workers until they retire or leave the city payroll, said LeRoy J. Jones Jr., the city's business administrator.

title: No Business Just Show;Community Theater Giving Unpaid Glory To Suburban Actors
description: Offstage, Christopher Arena clambers up telephone poles for Nynex. Eileen McMahon teaches college students to write. Joyce Slous sells real estate.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Eckersley Is a Cardinal
description: The St. Louis Cardinals reunited DENNIS ECKERSLEY with his former Oakland manager and pitching coach yesterday, acquiring the relief pitcher from the Athletics for the minor league reliever STEVE MONTGOMERY.

title: A Vote on Israel's Future
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres has set Israel's next elections for May, five months ahead of schedule. In this way, he hopes to capitalize on the sharp swing of sentiment toward his Labor Party that began after last November's assassination of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin. He also hopes for a new mandate for the next phase of peacemaking with Syria and the Palestinians.

title: Highlights of the Report by the Regional Plan Association:Environment; Preserving Space For Work and Play
description: While many aspects of the region's environment have improved over the last 25 years, several decades of suburban expansion and urban shrinkage mean that the threats are now such diffuse sources as lawn chemicals and the exhaust from expanding fleets of commuters' cars.

title: POLITICS: THE CAUCUS;Dole Ends the Race in Iowa As a Scalded Front-Runner
description: In his third outing in the Iowa caucuses, after more than three decades of tilling the political soil here, Senator Bob Dole of neighboring Kansas took only slightly more than a quarter of the votes Monday night, running powerfully only among older and wealthier voters, those who made up their minds a long time ago and those looking for Washington experience.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Jacor to Buy Citicasters in $770 Million Radio Station Deal
description: Seizing on the recent deregulation of the radio industry, Jacor Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire another large radio station owner, Citicasters Inc., in a deal worth $770 million.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When CHARLES GUGGENHEIM, a Washington-based film maker, called his daughter-in-law ELISABETH SHUE to congratulate her for receiving an Academy Award nomination yesterday morning, he did not know that he, too, would be an Oscar contender this year.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Astros Sign Bankhead
description: SCOTT BANKHEAD and the Houston Astros agreed yesterday to a minor league contract and the pitcher was invited to spring training. The 32-year-old right-hander started last season with the Yankees and pitched in 20 games, going 1-1 with a 6.00 earned run average. The Yankees released him July 25. (AP)

title: Rail Crash Victims Need Law's Protection;Crew Fatigue
description: To the Editor:

title: Balkan College for Albanians Fights to Stay Alive
description: Europe's newest institution of higher learning holds classes in storefronts, private homes, former cafes and even mosques -- the rooms often cold and illuminated only by weak bulbs. Most library shelves are empty. This is Tetovo University, with a faculty of 150 dedicated to the education of 1,254 ethnic Albanians in their mother tongue.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Reuters Says Profit Rose 17% in 1995
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the world's largest distributor of financial information, said yesterday that its pretax profit rose 17 percent in 1995 as use of its market trading and information management systems increased. Pretax profit was $928 million last year, compared with $790 million in 1994.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the conversion of Louis Armstrong's Queens house into a museum misstated the construction date. It was 1910, not 1925.

title: School Consultant Job Is Company's 2d Chance
description: A sprawling school district in Dutchess County in New York voted Monday to hire Education Alternatives Inc. as a budget consultant, awarding the for-profit company its first contract in a non-urban district, and its first in New York State.

title: Real Estate;A philanthropist invests in downtown Portland, Me., hoping to help stem the flight to the suburbs.
description: THIS picturesque port city has been benefiting from investments by one of the state's top philanthropists, Elizabeth B. Noyce, who has turned her attention to commercial real estate.

title: Looking for Real Food
description: To The Living Section:

title: Hunt for Bosnia War Criminals Stepped Up
description: The Defense Department announced today that NATO troops in Bosnia would be provided with fuller descriptions and new, clearer photographs of people suspected of war crimes. The move would make the arrests of suspects at NATO checkpoints more likely, even if it does not end the confusion over the depth of the alliance's commitment to bring war criminals in Bosnia to justice.

title: Pataki Plans to Limit Homeless Shelter Rules
description: The Pataki administration is planning to eliminate an array of regulations that have long been used to force New York City to meet fire, safety and health standards in its shelters for single homeless adults, state officials said. It will also propose lifting rules on the number of people in shelters.

title: Phil Regan, 89, Entertainer Known as 'The Singing Cop'
description: Phil Regan, who earned the nickname "the singing cop" as he worked his way from the New York City Police Department to roles in Hollywood films, died on Sunday at the Samarkand Retirement Community here. He was 89.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BELL ATLANTIC MOVES INTO LONG-DISTANCE MARKET
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation became the first of the seven regional Bell telephone companies to file applications to offer long-distance service outside its region. It filed yesterday with regulators in North Carolina, Florida, Illinois, South Carolina and Texas. The company's newly formed long-distance unit, Bell Atlantic Communications Inc., said it expected to enter each state as it got approval from regulators, which could take several months. The move came less than a week after President Clinton signed a sweeping telecommunications bill that lets Baby Bells and long-distance companies enter each other's markets.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NICKELODEON NAMES A NEW PRESIDENT
description: Tom Freston, the chairman of MTV Networks, a unit of Viacom Inc., promoted Herb Scannell yesterday from executive vice president of Nickelodeon to president. He succeeds Geraldine B. Laybourne, who resigned on Dec. 15 to become president of Disney/ABC Cable Networks, a unit of the Walt Disney Company. Also yesterday, Mr. Freston promoted Jeff Dunn, 40, from executive vice president of strategy and business development to the newly created position of chief operating officer for Nickelodeon.

title: A Sad Spectacle in Albany
description: Republican state senators barely took time to drink their morning coffee before racing to the Capitol on Monday and overriding Gov. George Pataki's veto of a special-interest bill sought by New York City's police unions. The Democratic-dominated Assembly, with the support of much of the Republican minority, quickly followed suit.

title: HOCKEY;Richter Awaits Start Of His Second Season
description: Mike Richter stopped several hundred pucks in practice today at Playland Ice Casino. Then he walked into the Ranger locker room and stumbled awkwardly over the big leg pads of Glenn Healy, who has started the last 16 games in goal.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Salvador Ex-Rebels Seek Extension of U.N. Mission
description: The former guerrilla army of El Salvador today proposed extending the term of a United Nations mission overseeing the 1992 accords that ended a 12-year civil war.

title: Dublin Reopens Door to I.R.A. Contact on Ulster
description: Prime Minister John Bruton of Ireland said today that his Government would resume formal contacts with Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, despite the I.R.A. bombing in London last Friday.

title: At the Nation's Table: Austin, Tex.;Elegant Variations On the Empanada
description: For Ash Corea there is no such thing as a simple empanada. The savory half-moon-shape turnovers indigenous to Latin America are typically stuffed with meats, fish or poultry. But at Ms. Corea's Empanada Parlour in Austin, Tex., she experiments with fillings like sweet potato seasoned with cilantro pesto, and turkey, bok choy and peas spiked with curry powder.

title: The Food Is Fancy But the Prices Are Not
description: KATHERINE SWEATT, a building manager who lives on the Upper East Side, intended to drive to New Jersey to buy turkey breasts, among other items, but then she decided to try the new Fairway store at 12th Avenue and 133d Street.

title: Chrysler Stock Rise Was Aim Of Kerkorian
description: In the discussions leading up to last week's peace pact between the Chrysler Corporation and Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor was offered the chance to sit on Chrysler's board. He turned it down, leaving that task to an aide.

title: Blaze in Jersey City Kills 7-Week-Old Twins
description: A three-alarm fire swept through a four-story apartment building early this morning, killing 7-week-old twins and leaving all 38 tenants homeless.

title: Chairman of Equitable Retires, Prompting Change at Insurer
description: Richard H. Jenrette, who revived the fortunes of the Equitable Companies, said yesterday that he was retiring as chairman and chief executive, prompting a series of executive changes at the giant insurance and investment management group, and at its investment banking subsidiary, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc.

title: For Now, Psychologists Can't Prescribe Prozac
description: To the Editor:

title: Czechs, Now 'Naively' Seeking Direction, See Dangers in Cults
description: PRAGUE  Six years after the collapse of communism, the Czech people are braving the ups and downs of life in a democracy. Increasingly adrift and searching for direction,they are turning to cults and marginal religious groups.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.F.L.;Eagles Sign Zordich
description: Strong safety MICHAEL ZORDICH opted against testing the free-agent waters, signing a new three-year deal with the Philadelphia Eagles yesterday. Terms were not disclosed.

title: BASKETBALL;It May Ba Time for Iona to Start Worrying
description: The sudden spiral in Iona's season and the recent revival in St. Peter's season continued tonight as the Peacocks overwhelmed the Gaels, 86-57.

title: BASEBALL;Mets' Brogna Hits the Scene With Some Lofty Goals
description: Rico Brogna is a fitting prototype to the Mets' youth movement: 20-something yet disciplined, even tempered and cerebral.

title: Sharp Rise in Use of Methamphetamines Generates Concern
description: A startling rise in the use of methamphetamine in California and the Southwest has raised fears among law-enforcement officials that the trend toward dangerous stimulants could spread across the country much as crack did in the 1980's.

title: Wine Talk
description: MOUTON," said the Baroness, "was my father's danseuse."

title: HOCKEY;Gretzky-to-Rangers Talk May Not Be Just Rumors
description: Another firestorm of Wayne Gretzky trade rumors spread across the United States and Canada last night, with the Rangers cited as the team most interested in acquiring the aging, unhappy Los Angeles Kings star.

title: Our Towns;The Weekend Warriors of Love Battle Bravely On
description: SOME enchanted evening.

title: Association Benefited From Links To Politics
description: Since 1929, when it issued its first master plan for the 31 counties in and around New York City, the Regional Plan Association has provided long-range blueprints for the region. Though it had no money to carry out those plans, it did hold the attention of governors, mayors, developers and corporate planners who could carry out its vision.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DISCREET LOGIC STOCK DIVES ON EARNINGS REPORT
description: The stock of Discreet Logic Inc. lost more than half its value yesterday after the company said its earnings would be between 2 cents and 4 cents a share for its second quarter, ended Jan. 31, compared with 7 cents a share for the comparable period a year ago. Discreet's products are used for creating and editing special visual effects for film and video. The company said earnings were hurt by delays in the release of Silicon Graphics Inc.'s supercomputer, Onyx Infinite Reality, because Discreet's systems run on the computer. Also, the company said David Macrae had resigned as president and chief executive. Richard Szalwinski, its chairman, was named acting chief executive. Discreet's stock fell $12.50, or 53 percent, to $11.25.

title: Zaire Troops Surround Rwanda Refugee Camp in Step to Shut It
description: Zairian troops surrounded a large camp of Rwandan refugees early today, beginning what United Nations officials described as an intensive campaign to persuade 190,000 Hutu refugees from Rwanda to return home.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about revisions in the public school curriculum in New Jersey misidentified an office held by Nicholas Sacco, who raised questions about some aspects. Besides being an elementary-school principal in North Bergen, Mr. Sacco is a State Senator, not an Assemblyman.

title: Dow Rises, but Broad Stock Measures Fall
description: Broad measures of stocks fell yesterday, led by a slump in semiconductor companies, but the Dow Jones industrial average managed a small gain, for its seventh consecutive record.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LAWSUIT BY PIER 1 ACCUSES MONEY MANAGER OF FRAUD
description: Pier 1 Imports Inc. has filed a lawsuit against a money manager and his firm, accusing them of poor investments in which the company eventually lost $19.3 million. Pier 1 said in the suit filed in Fort Worth on Monday that Jay Goldinger and his firm, Capital Insight Brokerage of Beverly Hills, Calif., had engaged in fraud, negligence and conspiracy. It also accused Refco, a Chicago brokerage firm that handled trades for Mr. Goldinger, of conspiracy and negligence. Last week, Pier 1 dismissed its chief financial officer, Robert G. Herndon, saying he had failed to monitor and control the investments. The company was seeking unspecified damages, lawyers' fees and court costs. Neither Mr. Goldinger nor his lawyer were available for comment. Joe Collins, a lawyer for Refco, said the firm had done nothing wrong.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: The Fiercely Faithful -- A special report.;From Cold War, Afghans Inherit Brutal New Age
description: When the crowds were summoned to the main stadium in Herat earlier this month, they went as Romans did to the Coliseum, to watch the grim ritual of death.

title: Index of Pay and Benefits Rose 2.9% in '95
description: For the sixth consecutive year, the raises that American workers receive have been smaller, or no higher, than those of the year before, according to 1995 figures released today by the Labor Department.

title: POLITICS;In His Own Words
description: LAMAR ALEXANDER He spoke at a news conference in Concord, N.H.:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Award in Harassment Case
description: A Federal jury ordered Atlantic City yesterday to pay $700,000 in punitive damages to a sergeant who won a sexual harassment lawsuit against the Police Department, The Associated Press reported. The Sergeant, Donna Hurley, contended that her fellow officers created a hostile work environment by drawing her picture on bathroom walls and, on one occasion, hanging a sanitary napkin marked with sergeant's stripes from the ceiling. Earlier this month, the panel awarded Sergeant Hurley $575,000 in compensatory damages.

title: Oscar Nominations Are Just One Surprise After Another
description: The 68th annual Academy Award nominations were announced this morning and, like a good movie, the selection was a thorough surprise. "The Postman" ("Il Postino"), a small Italian film about a mailman whose eyes are opened to the world when he meets a famous poet, was nominated for best picture. So was another little foreign film, the Australian-made "Babe," a comic fable about a pig who yearns to be a sheepdog.

title: Don't Limit Foster Care Aid to Grandparents
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Hearing on Divorce Claims
description: Mary Brennan wants a divorce. But she also is seeking damages for the emotional and physical abuse she says she suffered during her four-year marriage to Joseph Orban. In most states -- but not in New Jersey -- she would be entitled to have a jury determine if she should receive damages for domestic violence.

title: Highlights of the Report by the Regional Plan Association: Government;Overhauling The Bureaucracy
description: A new Tri-State Infrastructure Bank would provide the financing mechanism for the plan's capital spending agenda, raising money through a regional gasoline tax of up to 20 cents a gallon, increased charges for use of the region's bridges and tunnels during periods of congestion, and fees tied to the use of water and sewerage systems.

title: Chess Match Remains Tied After a Draw
description: Energetically fighting off the blockade strategy set up by Gary Kasparov, the chess computer Deep Blue came away with a draw yesterday in Game 3 of their exhibition match at the Philadelphia Convention Center. The I.B.M. computer and the world chess champion are now even at 1 1/2-1 1/2 in the six-game match.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ATARI AGREES TO MERGE WITH DISK-DRIVE MAKER
description: The Atari Corporation and the closely held JTS Corporation agreed yesterday to merge in a stock swap worth about $75 million. Atari, a pioneer in the home video game industry, plans to issue 40 million shares to JTS, in a bid to expand into disk-drive manufacturing. Based on Atari's closing stock price of $1.875 on Monday, the transaction would be worth about $75 million. The merged company, to be called the JTS Corporation, would continue to develop the Atari video game console and software and sell specialty disk drives. Shareholders of Atari would own 60 percent of the new company, but it would be led by JTS executives. Shares of Atari rose 18.75 cents, to $2.06, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: The Neediest Cases;Paying Debts of Kindness By Making Contributions
description: Is this the 25th or the 30th year I've been contributing to your Neediest Cases Fund?" asked Florence Lane in a letter. She could not remember for sure, but either way, her $25 donation this year was welcome. She joins nearly 10,000 other individuals who have brought the total so far to $4,270,092.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Round Table Pizza Franchise Corp., San Francisco, to Butler, Shine & Stern, Sausalito, Calif., to handle the broadcast creative portion of the restaurant company's account, previously handled by Bertram Wooster, San Francisco. The billings were estimated at $7.5 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Five Foreign Companies Barred by Singapore
description: Singapore has barred five foreign companies from new Government contracts for five years after they were named in what is being called the country's biggest corruption case, a Government official said yesterday. The companies -- BICC Supertension Cable (1980) Ltd, a unit of BICC P.L.C. of Britain; the Tomen Corporation and the Marubeni Corporation of Japan; Siemens A.G. of Germany, and Pirelli Cables, a unit of Pirelli S.p.A. of Italy -- were barred after the conviction of Choy Hon Tim, former deputy chief executive of the Public Utilities Board.

title: BASEBALL;Yanks Pay Wetteland And Williams Plenty
description: With construction and maintenance workers scurrying to add the finishing touches to the Yankees' new $20 million spring training home before 37 pitchers and catchers report on Wednesday, the snazzy Legends Field crept toward completion today. So did the Yankee roster.

title: Pataki Vetoes Police Bill, Then Drops The Fight
description: The day after Gov. George E. Pataki became just the second New York governor in this century to have a veto overridden, his critics, supporters and advisers alike agreed that he had chosen not to use all of his powers to prevent the Legislature's vote.

title: Surgeon Wins The Dismissal Of 6 Charges
description: A Federal judge today threw out 6 of 21 counts against a prominent transplant surgeon, including all charges related to the manufacture and sale of an unapproved drug linked to nine deaths.

title: Cupid to Take a Curtain Call
description: IF dropping a diamond into a drink at some fancy restaurant on Valentine's Day does not seem worthy enough for your beloved, consider this: tonight an unsuspecting Brooklyn woman will walk out of "Beauty and the Beast" at the Palace Theater with a sparkling engagement ring on her finger.

title: Sports of The Times;Paying A High Price For Stardom
description: SHE is a whisper of a woman, barely more than 5 feet tall and weighing 90 pounds. In the armchair that practically swallowed her whole yesterday afternoon, Yekaterina Gordeyeva seemed so frail, so vulnerable, so much smaller than the image of a globally famous skater on the brightest stage. And yet it is she who is here, who carries on, trying to make some sense of a bigger, stronger athlete's body gone tragically bad.

title: 6 Billion Bid So Far in Latest F.C.C. Auction For Airwaves
description: Small," it turns out, can be very big.

title: Bosnian Serbs Angered by Extradition of 2 Officers to War CrimesTribunal
description: Bosnian Serb leaders said today that the extradition of two of their military commanders to the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague caught them by surprise and further aggravated tensions with the NATO force in Bosnia.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;4th Blast Destroys Rock Blocking Tunnel in Japan
description: Work crews in northern Japan finally succeeded today in blasting to rubble a giant rock that had crushed a highway tunnel. But it may still take days of digging to reach a trapped bus and its occupants.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ex-Daimler-Benz Chief Resigns From Board Post
description: Edzard Reuter, who retired last year as head of Daimler-Benz A.G., said yesterday that he was also giving up his post on the supervisory board of the financially troubled company. Mr. Reuter gave no reason for his decision, which he disclosed during a news conference called with Chancellor Helmut Kohl on another topic. Mr. Reuter stepped down as chairman of the Daimler-Benz board last May and took a seat on the supervisory board.

title: The Main Contenders for the 1995 Academy Awards
description: Nominees for the 68th annual Academy Awards were announced today by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. The awards are to be presented on March 25. These are the major nominations: PICTURE "Apollo 13" "Babe" "Braveheart" "The Postman" ("Il Postino") "Sense and Sensibility"

title: POLITICS: THE NEXT STEP;DOLE OPENS DRIVE IN NEW HAMPSHIRE WITH NEW THEME
description: Senator Bob Dole opened the seven-day sprint to the nation's first Republican primary here today by reaching for a new economic message tailored to the populism of Patrick J. Buchanan, who finished a close second to the Senator in the Iowa caucuses.

title: Mobil in $935 Million Offer for Ampolex
description: The Mobil Corporation said today that its Australian unit was offering $4.25 (Australian) a share for Ampolex Ltd. in a takeover bid worth more than $935 million (United States).

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Inverse Relation of Heat and Light
description: The predilection of television news for treating politics as war by other means was the main target at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism last month. Speakers at the Alfred I. DuPont-Columbia University Forum, an annual bewailing of journalistic sin, blamed the media for scanting the substance of public issues and playing up their adversarial aspect: Who assaulted whom today? They called on news directors to exchange polarization for deliberation. The charge was easily documented, the solution somewhat wishful.

title: Hearts And Glowers
description: With the tragic separation of Charles and Diana, not to mention Michael Jackson and Lisa-Marie Presley, Valentine's Day requires some serious rethinking.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;Letterman Joins Team
description: DAVID LETTERMAN, a longtime Indy-car fan, confirmed last night he has become a minor partner of BOBBY RAHAL's auto racing team.

title: No Headline
description: How can my views be too extreme when Bob Dole is echoing me on every issue?"

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sweden Cuts Key Rate
description: Sweden's central bank yesterday cut its main money-market rate for the third time this year, sending a signal that it does not see inflation accelerating and that it is determined to improve the slowing economy. The central bank, known as the Riksbank, cut 15 basis points from its repurchase rate, to 8.30 percent. That is the rate at which the bank auctions two-week certificates of deposit to financial institutions and companies. Lowering the rate makes borrowing cheaper, encouraging spending and investment. So far this year the bank has taken 61 basis points off the rate. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Rail Crash Victims Need Law's Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Pirates' Sale Is Approved
description: Kevin McClatchy's purchase of the Pittsburgh Pirates for $90 million was unanimously approved today by major league owners, making the newspaper heir from Sacramento, Calif., only the third Pirate owner in the last 45 years. At 33, McClatchy will be the majors' youngest owner. He inherits $70 million in debt and the majors' worst drawing team.

title: At the Nation's Table: Waitsfield, Vt.;Farmhouse Pizza With a Pure Heart
description: In the early 1980's, George Schenk, who was trained as a biologist, set out to make great pizza -- well, at least as good as the brick-oven pizza he grew up eating in New Haven, which in some circles is better known for pizza than universities.

title: TV Network Says It Is Barred From Kremlin for Reports on Yeltsin
description: In an election-year skirmish between President Boris N. Yeltsin and the press, the Government has barred Russia's most prominent independent television network from the Kremlin, the network's editors said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Lois/USA to Buy Eisaman, Johns
description: Lois/USA Inc. in New York said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Eisaman, Johns & Laws in Los Angeles and to merge the agencies owned by both companies to form Lois/EJL, with combined billings estimated at $400 million. Lois/USA will acquire the stock of Eisaman, Johns, which is privately held, for cash and securities; additional terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Major League Baseball

title: POLITICS: BOWING OUT;Poor Showings In 2 Contests Lead Gramm To Withdraw
description: Reeling from back-to-back defeats in Louisiana and Iowa, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas decided today to quit the race for the Republican Presidential nomination, ending an extravagantly planned and financed campaign and making him the first casualty of the primary season.

title: Pataki Administration Plans to Seek Repeal of Array of Regulations forCity's Shelters
description: The Pataki administration is planning to eliminate an array of regulations that have long been used to force New York City to meet fire, safety and health standards in its shelters for single homeless adults, state officials said yesterday. It will also propose lifting the regulation that limits the individual city shelters to no more than 200 people a night.

title: POLITICS: THE SCENE;Bugle Call For Dole: Reveille, Or Taps?
description: With a tight smile and a harrowing margin of victory in Iowa, Senator Bob Dole addressed the New Hampshire Legislature this morning, observing with more wonder than certainty, "Maybe there's one more bugle call out there."

title: Book Notes
description: Political Satire Tops List

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Meeting President Is a Cowboy Habit
description: President Clinton greeted the Super Bowl champion Dallas Cowboys for the third time at the White House today and picked up a casual endorsement from the team owner, Jerry Jones.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WEYERHAEUSER CALLS OFF DEAL WITH ROSEBURG
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company terminated its agreement to sell its Klamath Falls, Ore., holdings to the Roseburg Forest Products Company, Weyerhaeuser said yesterday. The proposed sale would have included more than 600,000 acres of predominantly pine forest, nursery and seed-orchard facilities and three manufacturing plants.
