Weyerhaeuser, of Tacoma Wash., said in November that it intended to sell those holdings to Roseburg for $303 million plus the value of its working capital. Weyerhaeuser said yesterday that it was "not able to reach final agreement with Roseburg on certain aspects of the transaction," and added that it was having talkswith a parties interested in its Klamath Falls holdings.

title: ON COLLEGES;Penn State's Program Is a Source of Pride
description: Coach Jerry Dunn raised his eyebrows the other day when a visitor suggested that Penn State's basketball season was about to "get real."

title: Journal;Bashing to Victory
description: What happened in Iowa may be old news now that the horse race gallops on to New Hampshire. But for anyone who saw the gay-bashing rally that ended the caucus campaign on a chilling note Saturday night, Iowa cannot be forgotten so easily.

title: Aide's Travel-Office Statements Under Scrutiny
description: The General Accounting Office has asked Federal prosecutors to investigate possible false statements by a former Presidential aide concerning Hillary Rodham Clinton's role in the dismissals at the White House travel office.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;17 and Uh-Oh: Nets Snap Pacers' Home Streak
description: With a little over six minutes left in tonight's game, the Nets had played the Indiana Pacers to a standstill. Before the All-Star Game break, the Nets would have failed to execute down the stretch and lost a tight game.

title: AN ON-LINE SERVICE HALTS RESTRICTION ON SEX MATERIAL
description: Citing a desire to leave Internet censorship to individual tastes rather than government decree, the on-line company Compuserve Inc. said yesterday that it would restore worldwide access to most of the 200 sex-related computer data bases it had recently blocked under pressure from German prosecutors.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LOEWEN SETTLES SUIT FOR $30 MILLION
description: The Loewen Group, operator of a chain of funeral homes, reached a $30 million out-of-court settlement on Monday with the Provident American Corporation, a Pennsylvania insurer. In the latest court case, Provident American said that in 1991 it entered a 10-year agreement with Loewen to be the preferred carrier for insurance that fixes funeral costs. Provident officials charged that Loewen had broken the agreement by awarding the business to the Forethought Companies, a unit of Hillenbrand Industries. Provident American had sought actual damages of $58.8 million to $132 million in addition to unspecified punitive damages.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions yesterday about polls on Monday night that predicted the outcome of the Iowa caucuses included erroneous data from Voter News Service for the times at which two television networks projected Senator Bob Dole's victory, and included an imprecise reference from that service to the time of another network's special report. CBS projected the victory at nine seconds past 8 P.M., Eastern time, and NBC at 8:12; ABC projected Mr. Dole near the beginning of a special report that began at 8.

title: U.N. and Iraq Report Progress in Talks to Allow Limited Oil Sales
description: Talks between Iraq and the United Nations that could lead to limited Iraqi oil sales for the first time since the Persian Gulf war neared the end of an initial round today, with diplomats saying that the two sides are as close as they have ever been to an agreement.

title: Hiring Goals Canceled
description: Judge Edward J. Schwartz of Federal District Court here has eliminated hiring goals for black and Asian-American employees of San Diego County.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Uproar Over a Debt Crisis
description: As an uproar swells over hundreds of billions of dollars in bad debt in the Japanese financial system, it is increasingly clear that the country's mob, or Yakuza, and its friends, is near the heart of the crisis.

title: Highlights of the Report by the Regional Plan Association: Mobility;Improving Links With the Suburbs
description: Because of the network of rail lines and highways already in place, the Regional Plan Association estimates that a mere 25 miles of new rail lines and a "handful" of miles of new highways would "bring the region together, and put almost all of it within everyone's reach."

title: Highlights of the Report by the Regional Plan Association: Work Force;Advocating Full Participation
description: Access to lifelong adult education and retraining in the rapidly changing world of work will be central to prosperity in the next century, the plan contends. But shifting population patterns will also mean that minority residents and immigrants -- the fastest-growing segment of the population -- will need to be helped past the barriers of language and discrimination that now hinder their full participation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Health page yesterday about benefits of fiber in the diet reversed the estimated effects of fat and fiber intake on heart attack risk. A person with a 50 percent chance of having a heart attack might be able to reduce that to 40 percent by eating 10 more grams of fiber, not fat, a day, and then to 32 percent by eating 10 more grams of fiber.

title: Corrections
description: A caption in Science Times on Tuesday with a picture of a researcher and a carcass of a giant squid misstated the researcher's given name. He is Dr. Steve O'Shea, not David.

title: Health Executive Tells Senators Medicare Fraud Is Widespread
description: A health industry executive, testifying at a Senate hearing with his identity concealed, said today that Medicare fraud by doctors and hospitals was widespread, especially on the use of experimental medical devices.

title: Muster Stumbles In First Round
description: Two days after attaining a controversial No. 1 ranking, Thomas Muster of Austria was upset in the first round of the Dubai Open by the lightlp regarded Sandon Stolle of Australia. The 25-year-old Stolle, ranked No. 161, defeated Muster, 6-1, 3-6, 7-6 (7-0), today on the Dubai hardcourts.

title: Market Place;The two big 'ifs' holding down Turner Broadcasting shares.
description: LAST week, boasting strong earnings, Time Warner Inc. not only painted a rosy picture of its fiscal health, but also indicated that the two thorniest problems facing its planned purchase of Turner Broadcasting System -- Government clearance, and a lawsuit by its erstwhile partner, U S West -- were moving toward resolution.

title: BASEBALL;Cone to Be Clubhouse Leader
description: David Cone has advised two of the new Yankees, Joe Girardi and Kenny Rogers, about dealing with the news media and conceded that he could be one of the players who helps replace Don Mattingly's leadership skills. George Steinbrenner even called Cone Mr. Yankee.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Storing Left-Over Seeds

title: Agreement to Unify Some Unix Versions
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company and Santa Cruz Operation Inc., a software publisher, said yesterday that they would work together to unify several versions of the Unix computer operating system.

title: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
description: Stocks traded lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 57.40 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to 20,886.10. On Wednesday, the Nikkei rose 159.36 points.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Who Needs an All-Star? Not the New Nets.
description: The Nets tried the star system with Derrick Coleman and Kenny Anderson, and it failed.

title: Improper Kidney Dialysis Found to Limit Drug
description: Dialysis patients may not be receiving an adequate amount of blood cleansing on artificial kidney machines to get the full benefit of an expensive drug they need to prevent anemia, researchers report.

title: A Prominent Chicago Family Changes Course
description: The decision by the Gidwitz family to sell control of Helene Curtis Industries to the British-Dutch giant Unilever P.L.C., announced today, is as likely to be avidly discussed in social and political circles here, as on the business circuit.

title: Versailles Journal;Proud Castles Stripped, and France Is Scandalized
description: The women's prison of Versailles, just a short walk from the sprawling palace of Louis XIV, is a dour place for a Japanese heiress to be spending the winter. But Kiko Nakahara is getting little sympathy in France.

title: Sports of The Times;Conerly: The Toughest Of the Giants
description: HE had a face like old leather and an almost silent spirit that was even tougher. Charlie Conerly set the Giants standard at quarterback before Y. A. Tittle and Fran Tarkenton were obtained in trades, long before Phil Simms and Dave Brown arrived.

title: POLITICS: IN CONGRESS;Running for the House in '96: The Shoe's on the Other Foot
description: This is Jim Davis, running for Congress, a Vietnam vet." It is Taco Tuesday at South Omaha's V.F.W. Post 2704, and before the polka band, the Jolly Yanks, gets started, the post commander, Ed Reyes, is introducing the new Democratic candidate for Congress to some of the regulars.

title: SKIING;Bringing a Big Vision to New England's Slopes
description: It has been 25 years since Leslie B. Otten was splicing wire as a ski-lift mechanic and management trainee at the Killington, Vt., resort. But he had a grand vision for skiing even then, and he was far from becoming a ski bum. He knew he was in it for the ride up the mountain, and he was going to the top.

title: BASEBALL;Talented Rotation Has Mets Optimistic
description: The last two springs, Manager Dallas Green had built-in reasons for why the Mets might not be ready to be one of the National League's prime-time teams: not enough experience, not enough speed, not enough pitching.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Zaire Steps Up Pressure on Rwandans to Go Home
description: The main commercial strip in the Kibumba refugee camp, a muddy string of shops and bars along a dirt road known as Rue Ruhunda, was dead today, the second day of a clampdown on all commercial activity here by Zairian troops.

title: Resuscitating Musicals With a Bit of Fresh Air
description: Walter Bobbie, the artistic director of Encores: Great American Musicals in Concert, laughed as he summarized the ridiculous plot of "Du Bapry Was a Lady": "A nightclub washroom attendant wins the Irish Sweepstakes and suddenly has a dream in which he turns into Louis XV. It's the most disposable idea for a musical."

title: Washington's Mayor Wants to Cut City's Work Force by 25%
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. today offered his vision of the future for the nation's capital, an ambitious plan to reduce the size of the city work force by 25 percent and to privatize some operations that have contributed to the city's financial crisis.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 8 about right-wing politicians in Austria misspelled the name of the village where a meeting of war veterans took place last fall. It is Krumpendorf, not Kumpendorf.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Tough Giant Question: Who Gets the Money?
description: When Giants cornerback Phillippi Sparks ran into some of his teammates at the Super Bowl last month, he told them how much he looked forward to returning to the team. Not only that. He also told some of them he looked forward to getting his first big contract as a professional football player.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COOPERS & LYBRAND FOUND LIABLE IN FRAUD CASE
description: Jurors in Pittsburgh found Coopers & Lybrand L.L.P. liable yesterday for failing to uncover $500 million in fraud at the Phar-Mor Inc. discount drugstore chain. Four corporate investors in Phar-Mor sued the New York accounting firm, contending in Federal District Court that it should have looked closer to uncover fraudulent inventory entries engineered by Phar-Mor's former president, Michael I. Monus. The investors were Sears, Roebuck & Company, Westinghouse Electric, Debartolo Realty and the Equitable Life Assurance Society. Phar-Mor, which is based in Youngstown, Ohio, ultimately laid off 16,000 people, closed 200 stores and sought protection from creditors in Federal Bankruptcy Court. Coopers & Lybrand will appeal the verdict. Another jury will decide later what damages Coopers & Lybrand should pay. Mr. Monus was sentenced to nearly 20 years in prison last year. Patrick Finn, the former financial officer, testified against Mr. Monus and was sentenced to 33 months in prison.

title: Currents;Offices of Yore
description: AS the computer replaces typewriters, pens and inkwells, the paraphernalia of the vintage office is becoming obsolete -- and more and more collectible.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12

title: East's Coal Towns Wither In the Name of Cleaner Air
description: Charles Riley weaves his pickup through snow-coated hills spotted with the small farms and scattered homes of his fellow coal miners. He points to the mountainous gob heap of castaway shale and rock, to the tall concrete portals in the flanks of hills, to the five-story superstructure of the new, 320-foot elevator shaft.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;For His Final Inquiry, The Murder of a Diva
description: Public television's "Mystery" is being abandoned by some of its strongest characters. Jane Tennison (Helen Mirren) of "Prime Suspect" has already moved to "Masterpiece Theater." "Poirot," with David Suchet as the title character, is ending production in England, though some of the last installments have yet to be seen here. And tonight at 9, "Inspector Morse" reaches the end of its eight-year series with the two-part "Twilight of the Gods." (An occasional one-shot special, however, is not out of the question.)

title: Man Is Slain by an Officer At a Project in Paterson
description: One year after a white housing police officer shot and killed a black youth, an event that led to violent protests, another officer has fatally shot another man suspected of a crime.

title: CNN to Carry Debate
description: The Republican contenders in Tuesday's New Hampshire Presidential primary are scheduled to have a 90-minute debate on Thursday night. It will be carried live around the nation via CNN from the studios of WMUR beginning at 8 P.M. Eastern time.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Indonesia Phone Stake
description: PTT Telecom, the Dutch national telephone company, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $304 million in cash for a 17.3 percent stake in PT Telkomsel, one of three mobile-phone service providers in Indonesia. PT Telkom, Indonesia's domestic phone company, owns 51 percent of Telkomsel, while PT Indosat, an international phone company, owns the remaining 49 percent. A majority of both are owned by the Indonesian Government. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Fraud Figure's Actions Dim Recovery by Investors
description: Three years ago, Steven Hoffenberg stepped into the spotlight by proposing to rescue a failing New York City tabloid with money from his Towers Financial Corporation, which turned out to be a Ponzi scheme that defrauded investors of $450 million.

title: Man Accused of Beating Son, 11
description: A Brooklyn father was arrested yesterday on charges that he had beaten his 11-year-old son with an electrical cord, the police said.

title: Liberties;Playing Holly Gocheaply
description: Barneys is disappointed in me.

title: DOG SHOW;Clumbers: Dog of Kings, Commoners and Ribbons
description: Edward VII had them. His son, George V, had a kennel full of them at Sandringham, and one, named Harry, was his constant companion. George V's son, George VI, kept the kennel going, even during World War II, but he was not that keen on them.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Testimony Begins in Moon's Abuse Trial
description: The selection of four women and two men for a jury was concluded on Tuesday despite the initial failure of Felicia Moon to appear at the courthouse here. She has repeatedly said she forgives her husband and does not want to take the stand. Distraught that officials are pursuing charges against her husband against her will, Mrs. Moon fled with one of their four children to avoid the spectacle of the impending trial. Moon persuaded her to return after reaching her on a car phone.

title: Gibson Dismisses Chief and Takes Company Off Selling Block
description: Gibson Greetings Inc., the country's third-largest greeting card company, said last night that it had dismissed its chief executive officer and taken the company off the selling block.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Settling Backpack Brouhaha
description: The State Commissioner of Education will step into the fray over whether an eighth grader in Basking Ridge should be required to leave her backpack in her locker, an Education Department spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: Port Authority Plays No Favorites in Regional Transportation
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THE PRIMARIES;New England Finds G.O.P. Trying Out New Tactics
description: Searching for an edge in the tight primary race here, the Republican candidates for President tested new tactics today.

title: College Hockey
description: Beanpot

title: Fun at the Toy Fair: Babies That Fly!
description: A FUNNY thing happened to Barbie and Mr. Potato Head on the way to the 1996 American International Toy Fair: they were pressed onto computer disks. The line between traditional toys and computers is blurring as toy manufacturers find themselves working harder to hold their audience.

title: Insanity Drove A Man to Kill At 2 Clinics, Jury Is Told
description: A lawyer for John C. Salvi 3d acknowledged today that Mr. Salvi killed two women and wounded five other people in attacks on two Brookline abortion clinics in 1994. But the lawyer, in his opening statement at Mr. Salvi's trial, said Mr. Salvi acted because he was driven by schizophrenic delusions and urged the jury to find him "not guilty by reason of mental illness."

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was not the usual New York publishing crowd that assembled for a party given by STEVEN T. FLORIO, the president and chief executive of Conde Nast. Rather, the guests in the model room of the New York Yacht Club, on West 44th Street, were the 20 officers and 125 crew members of the nuclear submarine New York City. Many of the crew members were in their 20's and had never been to New York before.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;U.S. Group Sets Lumber Import Complaint
description: United States sawmills will file a trade complaint on Thursday against imports of Canadian softwood lumber, an industry spokesman said today.

title: Currents;Lacquerwape Of Japan: From Function To Art Form
description: IN "Rainbows and Shimmering Bridges: Contemporary Japanese Lacquerware," an exhibition opening today at the Japan Society, an ancient craft has been applied to new, bold forms.

title: Fidelity Cuts Chrysler Stake
description: Fidelity Investments, a unit of the FMR Corporation, sold about 5.5 million shares of stock in the Chrysler Corporation in the fourth quarter of last year, ceding its position as the company's largest shareholder, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: COMPANY NEWS;INTUIT WARNS OF FLAWS IN TAX SOFTWARE, AGAIN
description: For the second consecutive year, Intuit Inc. is warning customers of errors in its popular tax preparation software that could lead to miscalculations on returns. The company said yesterday that fewer than 1 percent of users of Turbotax and Macintax should be affected by the bugs, which have led to wrong entries involving the depreciation of cars and real estate, self-employed taxpayers and contributions to individual retirement accounts. Intuit, which is based in Menlo Park, Calif., is offering users help in working around the flaws and will also make available free, corrected versions of the programs. Different flaws were found in the same programs last year.

title: 130 Arrested In Drug Sting In Hempstead
description: A sting operation in the village of Hempstead has led to the arrest of 130 drug dealers and the seizure of hundreds of bags of crack and heroin and a large cache of weapons, state and Nassau County law enforcement officials said today.

title: Did Children Slave To Make This Rug?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: In all sports and games, it is rare for the favorite to stumble fatally at the start. In bridge, it is most likely to happen in New York City, because the standard of play is particularly high, with many little-known experts eager to challenge the best.

title: Unilever Agrees to Buy Helene Curtis
description: Helene Curtis Industries agreed yesterday to be acquired by the British-Dutch consumer-products giant Unilever P.L.C. for $70 a share, or $770 million in cash, marking yet another big consolidation in the highly competitive global personal- and beauty-care products industry.

title: Clinton Tours Flooded Areas of Pacific Northwest and Vows Speedy Aid
description: President Clinton toured flood-damaged sections of Oregon, Washington and Idaho today, promising speedy Federal assistance to the muddy victims of the worst winter storms to hit the Pacific Northwest in 30 years.

title: INSIDE
description: Colombia's Leader Charged

title: Drug Makers Raised Prices For Retailers 4.6% in 1995
description: Manufacturers' prices of the 500 most widely used prescription drugs rose 4.6 percent last year, the National Association of Chain Drug Stores, a trade group, said yesterday.

title: Investigators Question Mrs. Clinton on Law Firm Billing Records Found at White House
description: Federal investigators questioned Hillary Rodham Clinton for more than two hours this morning about a copy of long-sought law firm billing records that the White House turned over to investigators last month.

title: Attitude at $27 a Foot
description: Architects often say time and budget constraints can inspire them. Last year, when Tony Elliott, the founder of the Time Out Group in London, decided to start a New York edition of the magazine, he had three questions for Margaret Helfand Architects of New York. Could the firm design -- in 12 weeks -- editorial offices for 70 in a narrow 10,000-square-foot NoHo loft? Could it express the street-smart Time Out attitude? And could it be done for $27 a square foot in a city where prices average about four times as high?

title: European Topics : Genetically Altered Tomatoes Make Their European Debut
description: Last week, about 800,000 cans of tomato puree went on sale in British supermarkets. Nothing special, except that the contents of these tins were genetically altered, the first such foodstuff to reach Europeanconsumers.

title: Excess Inventory of Computer Chips Seen as Mixed Signal
description: After four years of double-digit growth, the semiconductor industry is asking whether it can defy gravity much longer. The answer is far from certain, considering the conflicting fortunes of two bellwether companies.

title: Bosnian Serbs Said to Detain Muslim Men
description: Bosnian Serb officials said today that they had detained several Muslim men who had wandered into areas under their control.

title: Bausch & Lomb Lens Deal
description: Bausch & Lomb said today that it had acquired Award P.L.C., a maker of daily-disposable soft contact lenses based in Scotland. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FIELD CONTAINER CO., Elk Grove Village, Ill., said it had bought the decorative gift box product lines of Cleo Inc. and Paper Magic from CSS Industries, Philadelphia, for undisclosed terms.

title: New Hampshire Passion Play
description: If Iowa's Presidential caucuses tested the candidates' appeal to the religious right, next week's New Hampshire primary shapes up as a test of economic platforms. So the focus will be on the flat-tax fantasies of Steve Forbes and especially the faux populism of Pat Buchanan. Although both men are capable of veering toward the wacky, it is a debate worth having.

title: Tyson to Close Plant
description: Tyson Foods Inc., the poultry producer, said this week that it would close its Boaz, Ala., plant on April 19, eliminating 275 jobs. The company said the closing was part of its consolidation but that it would offer jobs at other Alabama plants to as many of the affected employees as possible. The company said work currently done at the plant would be shifted to other Tyson plants.

title: Malfunctioning Brain Cell Appears to Set Off Obesity
description: One of the keys to obesity may be cells in the brain that are unable to decode signals from the body about how much fat it is carrying, researchers say.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;CAMPBELL SOUP CO. (CPB,N)
description: The Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that increased sales of soups and Mexican-style sauces lifted earnings by 11.7 percent in the second quarter, which ended on Jan. 28.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;COLUMBIA/HCA HEALTHCARE CORP. (COL,N)
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation reported a 23.7 percent gain in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, bucking a sluggish market for health care companies.

title: POLITICS: BOWING OUT;Big Budget, Early Start and the Candidate Are Figured in the Collapse of Gramm's Bid
description: He peaked too early.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Whenever CHARLES C. GULBRANDSEN passes through Grand Central Terminal he looks up -- and there is his grandfather's artistry.

title: Sudan, Denying Terrorism Role, Vows to Resist World Pressure
description: Top Sudanese officials, facing increasing international pressure for allowing terrorist groups to operate in the country, are making an attempt to cooperate with Security Council demands on one hand while threatening retaliation on the other.

title: BOXING;New York To Screen Fighters for H.I.V.
description: The New York State Athletic Commission said yesterday that it would screen boxers annually for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. It has not yet determined how to implement prefight testing, which is mandatory in Nevada, where last week the Tommy Morrison tested positive for the virus and was immediately suspended.

title: Husband Guilty as Bomber
description: A man was convicted by a jury today of mailing a pipe bomb that blew off several of his wife's fingers and injured one of her co-workers.

title: Columbia Loses Harassment Suit
description: A Federal jury in Manhattan found on Tuesday that Columbia University failed to properly investigate a former employee's sexual harassment complaint against her supervisor, and so must pay her $450,000.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SWIMMING;Group Supports Foschi Ban
description: The international swimming federation yesterday welcomed the two-year suspension of JESSICA FOSCHI for steroid use.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Mayor to Run for Congress
description: Accusing United States Representative Bill Martini, Republican of Clifton, of taking orders from Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House, and "sitting on his hands," Mayor William J. Pascrell Jr. of Paterson said yesterday that he would try to replace the first-term incumbent, The A.P. reported. Mr. Pascrell, who is also an Assemblyman, will face Mary Lee Fitzgerald, a former State Education Commissioner, in the June 4 primary.

title: Calendar: Faberge's Art, Story Quilts And Graphics
description: Faberge Eggs Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street; (212) 879-5500.

title: World News Briefs;North Korean Defector Slain at Russian Embassy
description: A North Korean sergeant who killed three Korean guards when he forced his way into the Russian mission in Pyongyang seeking political asylum was shot dead today, the Itar-Tass news agency said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Cline, Davis & Mann Shifts Management
description: Cline, Davis & Mann in New York has realigned top management.

title: Changes To Union Divide Harvard
description: To many Harvard University alumni, the Great Hall of the Freshman Union -- with its 14-foot-high fireplaces and its antler chandeliers reportedly donated by Teddy Roosevelt -- is the heart of the university. To the administration, seeking to consolidate its humanities departments, now spread across the campus, it is space going to waste. For both sides, it has become a battlefield.

title: Currents;Where Fat-Free Doesn't Mean Flair-Free
description: HEALTH food has adopted big-city ways.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Same Teams, New Night: Nets Sparkle
description: As good as Tuesday night's 9-point victory in Indiana felt, the Nets didn't exactly have a whole lot of time to savor it.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Europe Tightens Curbs On Foreign Films on TV
description: The European Parliament voted yesterday to strengthen the limits on the number of foreign films shown on television in European Union countries. The parliament, which has powers to decide jointly with governments on changes to the union's 1989 Television Without Frontiers law, said a requirement that channels devote at least 51 percent of their air time to European work should be enforced by "legally effective means." Until now, they have only been obliged to meet the requirement "where practicable."

title: COMPANY NEWS;BECHTEL PROPOSES AN OIL PIPELINE FROM CASPIAN SEA
description: The Bechtel Corporation is negotiating to build a 500-mile oil pipeline between the Caspian and Black Seas, the company said yesterday. The pipeline, through the former Soviet republics of Georgia and Azerbaijan, is expected to cost hundreds of millions of dollars and may also involve the building of a port operation and refinery on Georgia's Black Sea coast. The pipeline would transport oil from the Caspian Sea, which is landlocked, to international markets. The Caspian is thought to have several billion barrels of recoverable oil.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Satellite Failure May Hurt Murdoch TV Plan
description: A Chinese rocket carrying a television satellite exploded seconds after its launching yesterday, dealing a potential blow to Rupert Murdoch's ambitions to offer satellite programming in Latin America.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about the quandary posed by a family for someone considering a political campaign misspelled the given name of the Mayor of Las Vegas. She is Jan Jones, not Kam.

title: Gramm Moves Aside As Others March On
description: A year after Phil Gramm began assembling a $21 million offensive to become President, the Texas Senator quit the race, and the debate over what went wrong began.

title: Ernest Samuels, 92, Author Of Henry Adams Biography
description: Ernest Samuels, whose monumental prize-winning biography of Henry Adams was hailed as a model of painstaking scholarship and subtle interpretation, died on Monday at his home in Evanston, Ill. He was 92.

title: The Neediest Cases;Still Time, And a Need, For Giving
description: There was a slight tone of distress in the letter, dated Jan. 8, from Irene Libchaber of Manhattan.

title: The Pop Life
description: The Spiritual as a Cause

title: What's Next, Tail Fins?;Fast Speeds and Big Cars Send Gas Consumption Up
description: Gas guzzling is back.

title: In Wary London, 'Here We Go Again'
description: The disruptions had gone on for so long, most London residents were used to them: bomb threats in the subways, police officers searching cars in the financial district, theaters evacuating audiences, train stations without garbage cans, lest they be used to hide explosives.

title: To Curb Drug Use Takes More Than Education;No to Legalization
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;Voting Slow as Violence Stifles Bangladesh Ballot
description: Though the army was out in force to put down any more election violence, turnout at the polls this morning was very light, election officials said. In the latest attacks, on Wednesday, bombs killed 4 people and injured nearly 150.

title: Psychotherapy Found to Produce Changes in Brain Functions Similar toDrugs
description: Psychotherapy can produce changes in brain function similar to those seen with psychiatric medication in patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder, a study has found.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Congressional Voting Record
description: New Jersey's delegation to the House of Representatives has the nation's eighth-best voting record in the eyes of the League of Conservation Voters.

title: In New Vision By Planners, An Open War On Old Ideas
description: The Regional Plan Association, an old and respected urban planning organization that usually draws little attention to itself, has declared open war on some treasured ideas about the New York metropolitan region.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasuries Lose Steam; Prices Fall
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for the first time in three sessions as talk of selling by hedge funds and other distractions drove buyers to the sidelines in the absence of economic reports.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;The Oldies Recycled: Not All Gold
description: Classical artists switch record labels these days faster than you can say Baltimore Browns . . . er, Baltimore Whatever. And in the process, they seem to be revisiting triumphs of the not-so-distant past.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Rebuff on 'Megan's Law'
description: A state appeals court yesterday rejected a class-action lawsuit by prison inmates convicted of sex offenses who do not want to register with prison officials under "Megan's Law," The Associated Press reported.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GENERAL RE PLANS ITS EIGHTH BUYBACK OF SHARES
description: The General Re Corporation said yesterday that its board had authorized the repurchase of up to $300 million of the company's common stock, the eighth such move under a longstanding plan. Since 1987, General Re has repurchased about 22.7 million shares, leaving 81.7 million shares outstanding at the end of 1995. The company's shares fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $148.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Based on that price, the authorization will cover the repurchase of about two million common shares. The reinsurer, based in Stamford, Conn., also raised its quarterly dividend by 4 percent, to 51 cents a share, from 49 cents. General Re will pay the new dividend on March 29 to stock of record on March 21.

title: POLITICS: THE ECONOMY;Republicans and Democrats Jumping on the Issue of Corporate Responsibility
description: Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts has always been considered a standard Republican fiscal conservative. But last month he gave his State of the State address a populist twist when he spoke of the "nagging fear" caused by corporate downsizing and lectured businesses that "you still have a responsibility for the good of the community in which you reside."

title: AT HOME WITH: Elmore Leonard;It's No Crime To Talk Softly
description: THERE'S a tendency in this country to confuse appearance with reality. It's like that when you meet Elmore Leonard.

title: SKIING;Accident Mars Training Run
description: Officials took responsibility for an accident in downhill training today at the world Alpine skiing championships, where a Russian, Tatyana Lebedeva, and an American ski official each broke a leg.

title: BASEBALL;Wetteland Recalls Game 5, When He Never Got the Nod
description: The nagging, four-month old question about not being summoned to secure the most important save for the Yankees in 14 years caused John Wetteland to lower his head, stare at the carpet and slide his fingers through his blond hair. There was silence for five seconds. Then he stood up. Then he spoke.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MERRILL LYNCH TO BUY BROKERAGE HOUSE IN SPAIN
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it would pay 3.7 billion pesetas ($29.7 million) for the assets of FG Inversiones Bursatiles S.A., the biggest independent brokerage house in Spain. Merrill Lynch, the world's largest securities company, said its European unit would acquire the Spanish company's broker-dealer, corporate finance and asset management businesses, with net assets valued at 1.3 billion pesetas. The purchase of FG Inversiones, which had a profit of 1 billion pesetas in 1995, is Merrill's second recent takeover in Europe. In July, the company bought Smith New Court P.L.C. in Britain for $842 million.

title: Colombian President Is Charged With Fraud
description: Setting in motion a legislative inquiry that could lead to the impeachment of President Ernesto Samper, the country's chief prosecutor tonight formally charged the Colombian leader before the Congress with the crimes of illegal enrichment, fraud, falsifying documents and cover-up.

title: Rhone-Poulenc Retirement
description: Rhone-Poulenc S.A., the French chemical and drug company, said that Peter J. Neff, the president and chief executive of its United States chemical subsidiary, Rhone-Poulenc Inc., would retire at the end of 1996.

title: Helms Rival to Run Again
description: The former Mayor of Charlotte, N.C., Harvey Gantt, who lost the 1990 election to Senator Jesse Helms after a racially charged advertising campaign by the incumbent, has announced that he will try again to run against Mr. Helms.

title: To Curb Drug Use Takes More Than Education
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Seniors Savor Home-Arena Farewell
description: In the minutes leading up to tonight's Big East game between fourth-ranked Villanova and unranked Seton Hall, a brief ceremony was held to honor Villanova's senior players.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Barings Bondholders To Sue Ex-Chairman
description: Bondholders of the former Barings P.L.C. voted yesterday to sue Peter Baring, the former chairman, along with other officials and advisers. They seek to recover L100 million ($153 million) lost when the British merchant bank collapsed a year ago. The bondholders said they also planned to name Andrew Tuckey, the former deputy chairman; Peter Norris, former head of investment banking, and three advisers -- BZW Securities, Hoare Govett Securities and Cazenove & Company.

title: 30 Days or Else
description: It sounds so reasonable. Applicants for political asylum must file a claim within 30 days of entering this country. But it isn't. A lot of people could be tortured or killed.

title: Correction
description: A letter published Monday from Edward Deutsch on foreign aid in the form of enterprise funds rendered two sentences incorrectly. The sentences should have read: "Even when the funds are not wildly profitable, they recycle aid dollars by taking return on investment and seeding other small projects. They have also acted as a catalyst for the entry of other private Western venture funds."

title: POLITICS: IN THE LEAD;Dole Stepping Carefully In New Hampshire Race
description: If Bob Dole hears the footsteps of the ghosts of New Hampshires past, he is not admitting it.

title: To Curb Drug Use Takes More Than Education;Reduce the Harm
description: To the Editor:

title: Changes Ahead At Citibank
description: Citicorp plans to close or automate 33 Citibank branches in the New York area in a reorganization that could affect other branches in the next two years. Citibank also said this week that it would spend $100 million to renovate the New York- area branches it keeps.

title: Economic Scene;Is it science or voodoo? Seeking economics' true role.
description: GEORGE BUSH had a problem with the vision thing, which helped seal his fate as a one-term President. Economists have a similar problem, contend Robert Heilbroner and William Milberg, colleagues at the New School for Social Research and authors of "The Crisis of Vision in Modern Economic Thought" (Cambridge University Press). And while the voters haven't specifically been asked what they think of economists, they have indirectly expressed their views on the subject by bolstering the fortunes of Pat Buchanan and Steve Forbes, Republican candidates who have made campaign issues of their contempt for mainstream economics.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Ginza Will Get A Tiffany's
description: Tiffany & Company said yesterday that it would open its first stand-alone store in Japan on the Ginza, Tokyo's renowned, and expensive, retail and entertainment area.

title: Essay;Cap Over the Wall
description: Whoever wins next Tuesday in New Hampshire," said Bob Dole after his victory in an Iowa squeaker, "will probably be the Republican nominee."

title: Tribe Says Developer Threatens Sacred Site
description: For more than 1,000 years, archaeologists say, the Mohican Indians lived on land in the Catskills community of Leeds, N.Y. The tribe has long since left the area, settling in Wisconsin, but its lawyer returned yesterday to fight plans to build a Wal-Mart superstore on a 30-acre cornfield the tribe considers sacred.

title: Mexico and Insurgent Group Reach Pact on Indian Rights
description: Leaders of the Zapatista rebel movement said today that they would sign an agreement with the Government expanding the rights of Indians in Mexico, clearing the way for a peace accord in the two-year-old armed conflict in Chiapas, in the south.

title: Visa and Microsoft to Plan Home Banking System
description: Visa International and the Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that they had agreed to work together to offer a complete system for home banking and bill-paying services.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DALLAS UTILITY SEEKS TO LEASE ITS UNDERGROUND CABLES
description: The Central and South West Corporation of Dallas said yesterday that it had filed with Federal regulators to enter the telecommunications market, making it the first public utility seeking to take advantage of the new law opening the telecommunications industry to competition. The Federal Communications Commission has 60 days to act on the plan, which would open portions of the company's fiber optic and cable network to providers of telephone, Internet, cable television and other services. The underground lines now connect the company's computers with customer monitoring devices.

title: Could Norman Bates Live Here?
description: THE "Psycho" house will soon be getting some serious competition.

title: Save the Harlem Fairway
description: Uptown Fairway, a discount supermarket in Harlem, is in trouble with the city Buildings Department for operating with the wrong kind of permit. The store is a huge success. It has energized a waterfront area that previously resisted all government attempts at revitalization. It has created 150 jobs, 100 of them filled by neighborhood residents. Its enthusiastic customers include many members of the Giuliani administration. It sells turkey breasts for $1.69 a pound.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Victory No. 22 Is a Breeze
description: Connecticut put away another Big East opponent tonight, making West Virginia the Huskies' 22d victim in a row. The score was 87-69 in what was one more stroll through the gym against a lesser team for UConn (23-1, 13-0 in conference play). The Mountaineers fell to 9-13, 4-10.

title: Dow Corning Wins a Big Insurance Suit On Implants
description: The Dow Corning Corporation won an important legal victory yesterday that could help speed its emergence from bankruptcy, as a Michigan jury found that the company's insurers were liable for covering costs from lawsuits involving its silicone breast implants.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Wendy's International is joining Broadway with a promotional campaign for 'The King and I.'
description: THEATER lovers might not ordinarily associate a Broadway revival of the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical "The King and I" with either a fast-food chain or a local television station. But in the era of promotional-partnership polka, anything is possible. And so, not only the show's producers, but also hamburger advertisers and television executives are all singing -- in the words of the musical's signature song -- "Shall We Dance?"

title: A Million White Men
description: To The Home Section:

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Brace for Attack From the 'New' Canadiens
description: When the Rangers play host to the Montreal Canadiens tonight at the Garden, they will face a team that has struggled over the last year but appears to be on the verge of returning to the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Lady Caroline Blackwood, Wry Novelist, Is Dead at 64
description: Lady Caroline Blackwood, a writer of wry, macabre novels and essays, and a beguiling Anglo-Irish aristocrat who married the painter Lucian Freud and the poet Robert Lowell, died yesterday in the Mayfair Hotel in Manhattan, where she stayed the last few weeks while she was ill. She was 64.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GENZYME AGREES TO BUY GENETRIX LAB IN STOCK DEAL
description: The Genzyme Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy Genetrix Inc., a genetic testing lab based in Phoenix, for about $36.7 million in stock. Genetrix will be merged with Genzyme's Integrated Genetics diagnostic services business, helping Genzyme to cut costs and offer services in a broader geographic area, said Henri A. Termeer, the chairman and chief executive of Genzyme. The annual genetic testing revenue for the combined operation was estimated at $75 million. Genzyme, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., makes drugs and provides other health care products and services. The deal is expected to be completed in March.

title: Court Fight Disputes Legacy of Anne Frank
description: BASEL  The Anne Frank Fund in Basel and the Anne Frank Foundation in Amsterdam are locked in a court battle over the legacy of the martyred Jewish girl.

title: POLITICS: ON THE MOVE;Fueled by Success, Buchanan Revels in Rapid-Fire Oratory
description: It was a blue-collar, red-meat moment in Patrick J. Buchanan's lyrically combative stump speech, and the crowd cheered each scrap as he spoke as the Republican Presidential candidate most eager to disparage Big Business.

title: To Shore Up Ratings, '60 Minutes' Will Cover Breaking News Stories
description: CBS's longest-running and most popular program, "60 Minutes," will switch to a new format in the next few weeks that adds coverage of breaking news stories and weekly commentary by a corps of columnists, including Molly Ivins, Stanley Crouch and P. J. O'Rourke.

title: Simpson Guest Is Questioned In Civil Lawsuit
description: Brian (Kato) Kaelin testified behind closed doors today about O. J. Simpson's activities just before Mr. Simpson's former wife and her friend were slain.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;A Bank Note, So Very Swiss and Computer-Drawn
description: The Swiss central bank has given the ordinary cash-paying Swiss the first of a new series of bank notes so technologically advanced that it has become a Swiss parlor game to spot the more than 20 anti-counterfeiting features.

title: POP REVIEW;Lenny Kravitz's Great Big Show
description: Lenny Kravitz's two-hour concert on Tuesday night at Roseland should have taken place in an arena. After all, it had most of the trappings of a good arena-rock show: spectacular light displays, an incredible sound system, a drum solo long enough to allow beer-guzzlers to run to the bathroom and a fervor and charisma (Mr. Kravitz's) strong enough to reach the back row of the top balcony anywhere.

title: Wrongful Death Suit Begins in Slaying of Doctor at Bellevue
description: On Jan. 7, 1989, Dr. Kathryn Hinnant, a pathologist from South Carolina, was in an office in Bellevue Hospital Center, preparing a lecture to medical students, when she was raped and murdered. She was 33 years old and five months pregnant.

title: A Panel Is Formed On Meatpacking
description: Dan Glickman, Agriculture Secretary, appointed a panel today to determine whether large meatpackers use their market power to hold down prices for cattle and hogs.

title: Corrections
description: A map in Science Times on Tuesday, about new findings on the authenticity of the Vinland Map, said to be the earliest map showing any part of the Americas, misidentified the ocean off the coast of Newfoundland in some copies. It is the Atlantic, not the Pacific.

title: Events: Architecture In Both Word and Deed
description: Architectural 'Show and Tell' Wood Auditorium in Avery Hall, Columbia University, Broadway at 116th Street; (212) 854-3414.

title: Peacekeepers Will Assist With Evidence, But Their Powers Stop Short of Detention : NATO Sets Guidelines On War Crime Arrests
description: BRUSSELS  The North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed Wednesday on detailed guidelines that give allied troops limited powers to help international bodies capture war criminals and collect evidence about atrocities in Bosnia.

title: Lincoln Didn't Lack for Erudition
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Canon Profit Way Up
description: Canon Inc., the Japanese maker of printers and cameras, reported yesterday that its profit rose strongly in 1995 because of brisk sales of printers and semiconductor manufacturing equipment. The company's current profit jumped 48.9 percent, to 80.24 billion yen ($764 million), surpassing a record of 77.13 billion yen ($734 million) set in 1992. Current profit is pretax, including gains and losses made on securities investments and other nonoperating activities. (Reuters)

title: Won't You Sit a While?
description: Lilly Reich: Designer and Architect," at the Museum of Modern Art, focuses on Miss Reich's exhibition designs and her use of raw materials -- silk, wood, glass -- as elements of display.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;'Miserable' Over a Snowball
description: The life of a man accused of throwing a snowball on the field at a Giants game in December has been turned upside down since the incident, his lawyer said yesterday. "It's miserable," the lawyer, ROBERT BALLARD JR., said of the last seven weeks of JEFFREY LANGE's life. "He's lost his job. He can't find another one."

title: Rowland Seeks to Cut Welfare for Parents of Truant Children
description: Borrowing yet another idea about welfare from his Republican colleague in Wisconsin, Gov. John G. Rowland wants to withhold welfare payments from parents whose children have had too many unexcused absences from school.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Montana Quits NBC Analyst Job
description: Joe Montana resigned yesterday after one season as an analyst for NBC's National Football League studio show, saying he wanted to spend more time with his family. He joined the program on a part-time basis straight from retiring as a player, but his contributions were undistinguished.

title: Mr. Fisk Builds His Green House
description: THIS election year is full of pronouncements about the futur'. But perhaps none is as startling as the architectural apparition now rising amid the prickly pear on a scraggly stretch of land outside Austin. It is here that Pliny Fisk 3d -- ecologist, designer and professional renegade -- is building his experimental Advanced Green Builder Demonstration house, a brave strange-looking leap into the eco-future.

title: COMPANY NEWS;THINKING MACHINES EMERGES AS SOFTWARE COMPANY
description: The Thinking Machines Corporation, a pioneer in the development of supercomputers, has emerged from bankruptcy protection -- reorganized as a software company. A plan approved by the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Boston eliminated the company's debt by giving some creditors shares in the company and allowing others to license or sell patents it holds. The company, based in Bedford, Mass., said it had received a $10 million investment from a group led by the New York-based merchant banking company of Ladenburg, Thalmann Group. The money will be used for marketing and product development.

title: Architecture With Punch
description: To The Home Section:

title: COMPANY NEWS;LEADER NAMED FOR ABC'S 24-HOUR NEWS CHANNEL
description: Jeff Gralnick, the executive producer of NBC's "Nightly News," is returning to ABC to head the network's planned 24-hour news channel. The channel, which is expected to be started later this year, is designed for cable and other distribution systems. Mr. Gralnick, 58, will be responsible for its news content and production. He left ABC in 1993, after serving as vice president and executive producer for special broadcasts. At NBC, he was credited with leading the "Nightly News" past the "CBS Evening News" into second place in the ratings. NBC said that David Doss, senior producer at the "Nightly News," would head the newscast until a new executive producer was announced.

title: World News Briefs;Seoul Opens War Games At Isle Claimed by Japan
description: South Korea began a military exercise today around the tiny islands over which it is locked in a territorial dispute with Japan, a Defence Ministry spokesman said.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;400 Defense Jobs to Be Lost
description: Under the latest downsizing plan disclosed by the Pentagon yesterday, New Jersey will lose a net total of 403 military reserves and National Guard members. The Defense Department will eliminate 469 positions from the Air Force Reserves in New Jersey, 299 from the Naval Reserves and 72 from the Air National Guard. It will add 380 spots in the Army Reserves and 57 in the Army National Guard.

title: Traffic Alert
description: President Clinton is scheduled to visit two schools in Union City, N.J., this morning, then travel to Manhattan to attend fund-raisers this afternoon and evening. Motorists are advised to avoid Route 3 between the Meadowlands and Union City in the morning. In the afternoon, they should avoid the F.D.R. Drive and the midtown Manhattan area above 42d Street, and after 9 P.M., the F.D.R. Drive and lower Manhattan south of 14th Street. The visit is not expected to affect the evening rush.

title: Officer Lauded for Drug Fight Now Faces Charges
description: When 22 people accused of belonging to a drug gang called Natural Born Killers were charged last June with drug sales amounting to $3.6 million a year, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan asked a police officer assigned to his Homicide Investigation Unit, an elite anti-drug-gang outfit, to take a bow at a press conference.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Spirit of Experiment and a Cameo by Baryshnikov
description: That Erick Hawkins, with his fusion of ethics and esthetics, offered a radical new perspective on dance, is a given. Like a Zen guide leading his disciples to enlightenment, he choreographed dances that stressed harmony and ceremony.

title: Giuliani Warns of Austerity Plan If Police Win Costly Pay Raises
description: Angered and alarmed that the police union had pushed its arbitration bill through the State Legislature, the Giuliani administration warned yesterday that it was considering several sharp measures -- including the use of one-person patrol cars and reductions in overtime -- to offset the new law's potential costs.

title: 4 NETWORKS PLAN A RATINGS SYSTEM FOR THEIR SHOWS
description: After years of resisting as censorship any attempt to regulate the content of television programs, the four broadcast networks are seeking to establish their own ratings system, similar to the Motion Picture Association of America's code for movies.

title: Harm in Twinship
description: To The Home Section:

title: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;Belichick Isn't Moving to Baltimore
description: In what could be his final break with Cleveland, Art Modell dismissed Coach Bill Belichick yesterday, saying that the team's relocation to Baltimore offered "a new beginning, a fresh start."

title: A Guilty Verdict For Mrs. Baird's
description: Mrs. Baird's Bakeries Inc., the largest family-owned bakery in the nation, was found guilty today of fixing the price of bread in some small towns in Texas.

title: Del Ennis, 70, Star of Phillies' 1950 Whiz Kids
description: Del Ennis, a slugging outfielder for the Philadelphia Phillies and a star on the 1950 National League pennant-winning team dubbed the Whiz Kids, died last Thursday at his home in Huntingdon Valley, Pa. He was 70.

title: Bronx Board 9 Sues Over Its Suspension
description: Two days after being suspended by the New York City Schools Chancellor, the members of a Bronx school board who are accused of corruption asked a court yesterday to reinstate them.

title: 2 More Inches in a Winter That Feels Like 2 Years
description: First came the tease of almost balmy weekend temperatures, then a deep freeze that felt like millions of needles in human skin, and yesterday yet another snowfall, welcome only in its failure to compete with the great January blizzard.

title: Groups Criticize Governors' Welfare Plan
description: Five conservative groups and an architect of the Republican bill to overhaul the welfare system said today that a compromise plan endorsed by state governors last week did not do enough to discourage unmarried women from having children.

title: Recovering From Crash, Chess Computer Gets a Draw
description: Garry Kasparov got what he wanted yesterday in Game 4 of his exhibition match with the I.B.M. grandmaster computer, Deep Blue, at the Philadelphia Convention Center: a slightly superior position. But Kasparov, the world champion, still could not overcome the machine's indefatigable resistance.

title: At UConn, President Quits After 6 Years
description: Harry J. Hartley, the president of the University of Connecticut, submitted his resignation today after six years in the job.

title: Imam's Progress, Secular and Sacred;Guiding a Harlem Congregation Past Crises of Debt and Faith
description: On his deathbed, Ali Rashid, the imam of the Malcolm Shabazz Mosque in Harlem, scribbled down the name of his successor. It was the same name he had secretly added to mosque documents months before his death: Izak-El M. Pasha.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Scanlon Leaves Drug Group's Board
description: John Scanlon, the longtime public relations executive, has temporarily left the board of the Partnership for a Drug-Free America, citing a potential conflict with a new client, the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation.

title: After Cancer Struggle, Olympic Nightmare
description: Every two weeks, Kevin Hall, a top-ranking small-boat sailor, injects a vial of testosterone into his upper thigh. Mr. Hall and his doctors say that because of his struggle with testicular cancer, he needs the injections to maintain normal levels of the male hormone in his body.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Learning to Love One's Neighbor
description: AUDEN By Richard Davenport-Hines Illustrated. 406 pages. Pantheon Books. $30.

title: G.M. Unit in China
description: The General Motors Corporation's Delphi Automotive Systems unit has formed a majority-owned venture to build brake components and systems in China. The venture with the Zhejiang Asia-Pacific Machine and Electric Group Company is expected to have a total investment of about $20 million. Zhejiang Asia-Pacific, also known as Yatai, is one of the largest brake manufacturers in China and the dominant drum brake supplier to the Chinese truck automotive market, Delphi said.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;The Jets Jump Into Free-Agent Market
description: The Jets took the first step yesterday in showing the National Football League how serious they are about shedding their lowly status. Although the market in this year's new free agents legally opens tomorrow, the Jets jumped in early by signing the veteran tackle David Williams, a former first-round draft choice who played for the Houston Oilers for seven seasons.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Following The Break, The Knicks Blow a Fuse
description: Midway through the third quarter, John Starks, hands on his hips and a look of disbelief on his face, walked over to the timekeeper's table to inquire about a disturbing on-court development. "What's the score?" he said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Burnett Takes Stake In Media Company
description: The Leo Burnett Company in Chicago said yesterday that it had acquired an equity stake in Giant Step Productions, a company in Chicago that specializes in developing marketing programs for the Internet, CD-ROM's and other interactive media. The terms were not disclosed.

title: Arms for Iraq: P.M. Is Sullied by Dirty Secrets
description: On the eve of the release of a report on Britain's sales of military equipment to Iraq -- a report commissioned by Prime Minister John Major -- Mr. Major and his fellow Tories are wrapping up a campaign to discredit it.

title: Chief of North America Unit Is Named by Deutsche Bank
description: In a surprise announcement, Deutsche Bank North America said yesterday that Carter McClelland would succeed John A. Rolls as president.

title: Jump in Fatal Heart Attacks Is Tied to Quake
description: Emotional stress caused by a strong earthquake in Los Angeles in 1994 appears to have set off a burst of fatal heart attacks in people with cardiac disease.

title: New-Old Couples Retake Vows
description: Five years ago, the idea came to Ella Black: married couples need to share some special occasion, a calebration of themselves that goes beyond dinner a deux.

title: The Divorce Debate
description: Led by conservative Christian groups, a new movement is afoot to toughen state divorce laws. Its main target is the "no-fault" divorce statutes adopted by every state over the last 25 years to make divorces easier, quicker and less freighted with destructive recrimination.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hanson Earnings Fall
description: Hanson P.L.C., the conglomerate based in Britain, said yesterday that its pretax profit in the quarter ended Dec. 31 fell 4 percent, with lower profit in chemicals offsetting gains from the company's energy business. Hanson earned L262 million ($403 million), versus L272 million a year earlier. Sales rose to L3.28 billion from L3.16 billion. Last month, the company said it would split into separate, publicly traded companies in four areas: energy, chemicals, building materials and tobacco. (AP)

title: Judith Eisenstein, 86, Author and Composer
description: Judith Kaplan Eisenstein, an author, musicologist and composer, died yesterday of a heart attack in Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md., where she was being treated for a broken hip. She was 86 and lived in Silver Spring, Md.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Feb. 8 about Brian Weil, a photographer who helped found New York City's first needle exchange program, misstated the number of clients served by the New York Harm Reduction Educators, an organization providing needle exchanges and H.I.V. medical and counseling services. It is 14,000, not 1,200.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BURR-BROWN'S ORDERS DROP AND THE STOCK FALLS
description: The stock of the Burr-Brown Corporation, a maker of electronic components, fell 23 percent yesterday after the company said orders for the first six weeks of the current quarter were weaker than expected. The company's shares fell $6.875, to $22.625, in Nasdaq trading after several analysts issued warnings about the order rate. John Carter, Burr-Brown's chief financial officer, said orders for semiconductors were a little soft in January but were expected to pick up this month. He said the drop could have an effect on first-quarter profits but that it would not be "anything major."

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Eyes Open at Port Authority
description: The chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that he would appoint a committee to review the agency's policy on the use of its helicopter and cars. In a memo to fellow commissioners, Chairman Lewis M. Eisenberg said the authority cannot "close our eyes to criticism and/or demonstrate an unwillingness to change if in fact, mistakes have been made in years past (or today)."

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Adviser or 'Garbage' Man?
description: One day after Representative Richard A. Zimmer officially announced that he would seek the Republican nomination for the United States Senate, the Democratic Party attacked his media consultant, Stuart Stevens. Mr. Stevens should be fired, the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee said, because of an ad he produced in 1990 for Senator Daniel R. Coats, Republican of Indiana, who had introduced legislation to ban states from exporting garbage. The ad depicted a fat, cigar-smoking garbage dumper from "New Joisey."

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn and Wheat Prices Reach 15-Year Highs on Low Supply
description: Corn and wheat prices surged to 15-year highs yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as growing demand for exports threatened to overwhelm United States inventories.

title: What I.R.A. Achieves
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TV Networks May Rate Their Programs' Content ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox are discussing the creation of a ratings system for the content of programs, similar to the one used for movies. The talks end years of protest that any attempt to regulate the content of their programs amounted to censorship.

title: Italians Fail to Form Cabinet, Setting Back Hopes for Reform
description: Hopes for a reform of Italy's political system collapsed today after the Prime Minister-designate, Antonio Maccanico, abandoned his two-week-old effort to form a new Government. His action indicates that parliamentary elections are likely, perhaps as early as this spring.

title: ON HOCKEY;Addition by Distraction: Great One, Great Deal
description: As they seek to equal a franchise record of 24 home games without a defeat tonight, the Rangers face a distraction greater than the rejuvenated Montreal Canadiens. Swirling all around them is the speculation: Are they are about to acquire an unhappy Wayne Gretzky from the Los Angeles Kings?

title: How a Tortilla Empire Was Built on Favoritism
description: Every day, at the same hour, in the same place, Rosa Arroyo de Soria walks three rutted and dusty blocks to buy tortillas -- the unleavened corncakes that are sustenance and soul for more than 96 million Mexicans. Each tortilla costs half a cent.

title: No Headline
description: When the voter speaks, I listen, especially when the voter is saying someone else's name." SENATOR PHIL GRAMM [B15:1.]

title: Faith and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Death Wish Is Sanctioned For a Killer
description: The 65-year-old Death Row inmate, stooped, graying and bound at the ankles by jailhouse chains, shuffled toward the witness stand in State Superior Court. Two uniformed guards helped him into the chair next to Judge Bruce A. Gaeta.

title: Judge Rebuked After a Woman Is Slain
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday criticized a Brooklyn judge for freeing a violent felon who later killed his former girlfriend at a Queens car dealership, a slaying carried out several weeks after she had sought protection from the courts.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;British to Adopt an American-Style Tax Filing System
description: While many Americans may daydream about tax returns they can file on a postcard, the British are about to give up their system of having the taxman simply send them a bill, as they move toward the thicket of forms and rules common in the United States.

title: With Prices Low, Gasoline Guzzling Makes a Comeback
description: More Americans are driving bigger cars and trucks longer distances -- and at faster speeds -- with scarcely a thought for mileage conservation or pollution.

title: Payment Offer in Rikers Abuse Suit
description: New York City has offered to pay about $1.6 million to 15 men who say they were beaten and abused by corrections officers while they were inmates at Rikers Island from 1991 to 1993, according to people familiar with the negotiations.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Lewis Wins in Arbitration
description: With SCOTT BORAS arguing each one, the players have won all three baseball salary arbitration cases that have been decided this winter. MARK LEWIS of Detroit is the latest winner. ROBERT CREO, the arbitrator, yesterday awarded Lewis the $670,000 salary he sought over the Tigers' bid for $450,000. The third baseman batted .339 in 171 at-bats over 81 games for the Cincinnati Reds last season, playing for a $190,000 salary. Boras previously won $3 million for BERNIE WILLIAMS of the Yankees and $1.55 million for RICK WILKINS of Houston.

title: The End of Taiwan?
description: No one wants a war in the Taiwan Strait. Not President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan, whose hopes for re-election on March 23 depend on convincing voters he can still manage relations with Beijing to the island's advantage. Not Jiang Zemin, China's President, who just a year ago emphasized China's patience in pursuing peaceful reunification. Not Bill Clinton, who doesn't want his handling of China to be an issue in this year's Presidential campaign.

title: Currents;Ordering: A Landmark, Well Done
description: A CENTURY ago at Delmonico's, at the corner of Beaver and South William Streets in the financial district, American society sat down to eat novel dishes like lobster Newburg and baked Alaska amid the elegant decor of marble columns, stained oak woodwork and floors of tiny white tiles.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Records Contradict Moons' Statements
description: Court records show that the wife of Warren Moon, the quarterback who is on trial in a case of spousal abuse, filed for a divorce and a restraining order to protect her from her husband in 1986.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Symbol for Chechens Is Demolished by Troops
description: Russian soldiers today demolished Chechnya's ruined presidential palace, a potent symbol of Chechen resistance to Russian troops where thousands of demonstrators had gathered last week.

title: POLITICS: IN THE PACK;Alexander, the Contender, Says He Avoids the Negative
description: In the three days since he became a contender, Lamar Alexander has asserted in every speech that voters in Iowa rewarded him on Monday for rising above the negative tactics employed by his rivals.

title: Democrats Win Race Seen as a State Forecast
description: Democrats won an Assembly seat in a heavily Republican district in Rochester tonight during a special election widely viewed as a referendum on Republican policies in New York State.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For millions of young teen-agers who are fans of the English band Take That, Valentine's Day was far from joyous, London newspapers reported yesterday.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Stage Late Scoring Burst but Come Up Short
description: The Islanders, many of whom are auditioning in front of their head coach and general manager, Mike Milbury, for jobs next season, almost staged a thrilling comeback performance from a 4-0 deficit against the Calgary Flames at Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: BASKETBALL;Rutgers Gets Room To Rally
description: After a third straight half of miserable shooting, Rutgers had little to feel good about in the locker room at halftime, except this: Despite making only 33 percent of its field goal attempts to 61 percent by St. John's, it trailed by only 6 points.

title: Haute Culture in a Hip World
description: Age may put an end to playing football and entering beauty contests, but it does not keep older Americans who love the performing arts from their theatrical haunts. "They'll go until their dotage," says Richard Peterson of Vanderbilt University, the co-author of one of two dismaying studies on demography and the arts soon to be released by the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks traded lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 83.42 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,802.77. On Thursday the index fell 57.40 points.

title: Labor Leader Plans Little Steps to Big Economic-Political Goal
description: Aides to John J. Sweeney swear that as the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s new president he has the vision thing, but Mr. Sweeney certainly seems to try his best to hide it. In his soft, matter-of-fact voice, he talks not in visions but in bits and pieces.

title: POLITICS: THE SPOUSES Wives of the 1996 Candidates Are Also Targets of Scrutiny
description: Leslee Buhler Alexander stumped her way through this pretty, snow-covered and mostly shuttered summer resort by Lake Winnipesaukee today, telling anyone who would listen about her husband's campaign for President and about the backseat life of the wife of a professional politician.

title: On My Mind;Making of Buchanan
description: Every day the American press probes into actions by Presidential candidates that are legal but raise critical ethical questions about the American political system.

title: Freed Attacker's 2d Arrest Heightens Criticism of Judge
description: Lorin Duckman, the Brooklyn judge who has been sharply criticized for his handling of a domestic violence case that ended in murder, allowed a Brooklyn man to go free last summer just hours after a jury found him guilty of attacking his ex-girlfriend.

title: In America;The Company They Keep
description: Larry Pratt has taken a sudden leave from the low-rent, low-class Presidential campaign of Patrick J. Buchanan. Just a leave, mind you. He has not been fired. He has not even been criticized by the candidate. From Mr. Buchanan's mean-spirited, far-right, demagogic perspective, there is very little wrong with promoting the madness of the militia movement and hobnobbing with white supremacists.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Airtours Buys Concern
description: Airtours P.L.C., Britain's largest package-tour company, said yesterday that it had bought Simon Spies Holding A/S, Denmark's largest tour operator, and other assets for L60 million ($92.4 million). The Airtours subsidiary Scandinavian Leisure Group, the largest organized tour operator in Scandinavia, bought Spies Holding from the Conair Consolidated Aircraft Corporation. The price included L10 million for Spies Holding and L50 million for three Airbus A300 aircraft, spare parts, ground equipment and a hangar at Copenhagen airport. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: U.S. Delays Opening Site For Dumping Atomic Waste
description: Seeking to resolve one of the most difficult scientific conflicts involving the nation's plan for disposal of low-level radioactive materials, the Clinton Administration has ordered more testing on the proposed nuclear waste dump in the eastern Mojave desert of California.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Valve Caused Pipes to Burst
description: Officials of the company whose broken water lines left 750,000 people with little or no water last week said they have zeroed in on one valve as the cause of the problem. "Workers were trying to turn this 30-inch valve off slowly to stop a leak in a joint coupling," said Rich Henning, a spokesman for United Water New Jersey. Instead, the valve snapped, creating the surge of pressure that burst two pipes, he said. Although both pipes have been repaired, only one is operating.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: To Wong Foo, Thanks for Everything, Julie Newmar 1995. MCA/Universal. $100.71. Laser disk, $34.98. 109 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Taiwan, Nervous About China, Reasserts Role on Disputed Isles
description: In anticipation of military maneuvers by China, Taiwan's leaders visited front-line troops today and told them to heighten their readiness but to avoid any provocation.

title: Restaurants
description: You're Patria people, aren't you?" our waiter asks. "I can always tell."

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-14

title: FILM REVIEW;Lots of Beautiful Models Admiring Themselves
description: This could come as a terrible shock to the hard-core fashion groupies for whom the documentary "Catwalk" is intended, but watching even the most gorgeous models can turn out to be an awful bore. That becomes clear during this feature-length gush over Christy Turlington, who preens at the center of Robert Leacock's wildly uncritical look at the Milan, Paris and New York fashion shows.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Getting Help When Anger Turns Inward
description: When Jerome W. was 13 years old, he tried to kill himself. He thought that pressures in his life had grown so large that ending his life was the only solution.

title: Art in Review
description: Bianca Sforni Paul Kasmin Gallery 74 Grand Street SoHo Through March 9

title: Abroad at Home;The Angry Man
description: Pat Buchanan is not likely to be the Republican nominee in the end. Too many influential voices in the party think that would deliver the election to President Clinton. But his strong showing in the Iowa caucuses still matters a lot.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: BASEBALL;Mets Hoping Wilson Will Live Up to Promise
description: Paul Wilson, Jason Isringhausen, Bill Pulsipher. For now, that is the order in which their lockers are situated in the clubhouse at the Mets' spring training complex. Someday soon that could be the order of the team's starting rotation, perhaps as early as this season if Wilson can live up to all the hype surrounding his arrival.

title: NBC Extends Golf Contracts
description: NBC Sports yesterday extended its rights to televise the Ryder Cup and the P.G.A. Seniors Championship through 2005.

title: Fed Nominee Offered No New Direction;Proved to Be Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Magazine Disputes Army View of Photo
description: Esquire Magazine has disputed an assertion by Army officials at Fort Bragg, N.C., that the magazine staged photographs of soldiers posing with Nazi materials for an article about neo-Nazi skinheads in the Army.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: HOCKEY;Who Needs Gretzky? Robitaille Keeps the Streak Alive
description: No Gretzky. But thanks to Luc Robitaille, there is still a streak.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Sadist's Kinky Update Of the Old Truth or Dare
description: You reveal your kink and I'll reveal mine. Adult show-and-tell is the game that a group of hostages are forced to play in "Headless Body in Topless Bar," a psychological thriller with a big streak of prurience that opens today at the Quad Cinema.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Unzipped 1995. Miramax. $100.71. 76 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Data Recorder Deepens Train Crash Mystery
description: Information collected by a recorder on a New Jersey Transit train in the seconds before last week's fatal collision is garbled in places, investigators said yesterday, and it appears to contradict some of their early beliefs about what happened, suggesting that the job of reconstructing the accident will be difficult.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Gill to Have Hand Surgery
description: Kendall Gill will have surgery today on his left hand, which he fractured during the Nets' 88-87 victory over Indiana on Wednesday night. The New Jersey guard will be in a cast for four weeks, and although no timetable has been set for his return, he will probably miss 15 to 20 games.

title: ART REVIEW;Multiple Uses For Faberge
description: TO get the most out of "Faberge in America," the blockbuster in a jewel box that is beginning its 5-stop, 16-month national tour at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, I recommend the multiple-personality approach.

title: BASEBALL;Gooden And Key Share Hope Of Spring
description: A tarpaulin covered the new and still unused Legends Field, umbrellas were as plentiful as soggy Yankee caps and Manager Joe Torre was forced to improvise on his first day of workouts as a drizzle that became a downpour made indoor baseball fashionable today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LEVERAGED BUYOUT FIRM TO BUY ANDROS FOR $87.5 MILLION
