description: Genstar Capital Partners II L.P. said yesterday that it would acquire Andros Inc., a maker of equipment used in environmental and medical monitoring devices, for $18 a share, or about $87.5 million. Genstar, a leveraged buyout firm based in Foster City, Calif., plans to begin a tender offer within the next week to buy shares directly from Andros stockholders. The board of Andros, which is based in Berkeley, Calif., has approved the merger agreement. The shares of Andros rose $2.75, to $18.25, in Nasdaq trading yesterday.

title: Peter Muirhead, 84, Educator Who Helped Many Go to College
description: Peter P. Muirhead, an educator who helped shape and administer groundbreaking Federal legislation on education, died on Monday at his winter home in Stuart, Fla. He was 84 and lived in Alexandria, Va.

title: Plea Deal Keeps 'Sammy Bull' Off Stand
description: For weeks, the anticipation had been building in legal and mob-watching circles.

title: Of Parcels and Children
description: To the Editor:

title: On Staten Island, Good Turn for the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Maker Lawsuit Gets Preliminary Court Approval
description: A Federal judge granted preliminary approval today to a proposed $409 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit that charged drug companies with conspiring to fix prices on sales to independent pharmacies.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about genetic defects involved in facial deformities misidentified the embryonic structure that gives rise to the nervous system. It is the neural tube, not the notochord.

title: Board Delays Ban on Affirmative Action, but Discord Persists
description: The University of California's deeply divided Regents compromised today and set spring 1998 as the date for putting into effect their much-disputed ban on race and sex preferences in undergraduate student admissions.

title: Injured in '88, Officer Awakes in '96
description: Ever since the day seven and a half years ago when former police Officer Ken Cox resuscitated his wounded partner Gary Dockery, Mr. Cox has tortured himself with questions, wondering whether he had done the right thing.

title: Art in Review
description: Jocelyn Taylor Deitch Projects 76 Grand Street SoHo Through Feb. 24

title: COMPANY NEWS;DIGITAL AND CIRRUS LOGIC END PLAN FOR JOINT OPERATION
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation and Cirrus Logic, a computer chip maker, yesterday ended plans to operate a joint semiconductor manufacturing venture after Cirrus said it was cutting its capital spending. The companies announced an agreement in December that would have enabled Cirrus to produce semiconductor chips at Digital's plant in Hudson, Mass. Digital had been seeking a partner to defray the cost of the plant. But earlier this week, Cirrus, based in Fremont, Calif., warned of a fourth-quarter loss because of lower-than-expected orders. Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., said negotiations this week failed to persuade Cirrus to continue with the plan.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Airbus Industrie Plans Jumbo Jet
description: Airbus Industrie plans to develop a jumbo passenger aircraft to take on its main rival, the Boeing Company, and its popular 747 jetliner, a top partner in the European consortium said today.

title: Judge Blocks a Law On Smut on Internet
description: A Federal judge temporarily blocked enforcement of a new law that makes it a felony to transmit indecent material over the Internet or on-line computer services if the material may be seen by children. The judge ruled that the term "indecent" was unconstitutionally vague and was not defined in the new law, the Communications Decency Act.

title: Sheldon Beren, 73, Oil Executive And Leader of Jewish Education
description: Sheldon K. Beren, an oil executive who championed Orthodox Jewish education, died on Monday at the Texas Medical Center in Houston, where he was being treated for cancer. He was 73 and lived in Denver.

title: Pastor, 28, Is Charged in Rape of Girl, 16
description: The 28-year-old pastor of a Korean Presbyterian Church in Forest Hills, Queens, was arrested yesterday and charged with third-degree rape, third-degree sodomy and endangering the welfare of a child as he tried to renew a relationship with a 16-year-old girl.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of Manhattan shows closing soon:

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Volatile Day Sinks Prices Of U.S. Bonds
description: Technical selling and a large supply of new corporate and global issues combined to drive Treasury prices lower in volatile trading yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Johnson & Johnson's latest campaign is part of a novel trend: beauty ads with some basis in fact.
description: ADVERTISING for skin care, beauty and cosmetics brands has long been more likely to make glamorous, emotional appeals than offer dispassionate presentations about product performance. That was because, in most instances, marketers recognized they were selling hope in a jar, as Charles Revson liked to proclaim, rather than anything that they could prove under regulatory scrutiny actually worked.

title: NATO Troops Arrest Some Foreigners Among Muslim Troops
description: French NATO troops raided a house near Sarajevo today, arresting 11 Muslim soldiers, including some foreigners, and confiscating "a large number of weapons, ammunition and explosives," a NATO statement said. NATO officials called the presence of foreign troops and the arms cache "a serious violation" of the Bosnia peace agreement. The 11 soldiers are being held by NATO forces pending further investigation.

title: Author! Author?
description: To the Editor:

title: Diner's Journal
description: Remember the Ascot scene in the movie version of "My Fair Lady"? The one where everyone goes suddenly silent when they see Eliza Doolittle? That's what I felt was happening when I walked into the new Bobby Van's Steakhouse. The big no-nonsense room was brightly lighted and filled with the scent of frying onions, grilling meat and spilled gin. But as I walked through the door, I felt everyone stop in mid-gesture and stare. Looking around, I realized that I was the only woman in the room.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Washington's Birthday, which is Feb. 22, will be observed on Monday.

title: Fraud Figure Is in Custody In Arkansas
description: Steven Hoffenberg, the flashy New York financier who ran what securities regulators have called the largest Ponzi scheme in history, turned himself in to Federal agents in Little Rock, Ark., yesterday after failing to meet new bail terms imposed earlier this week.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Unilever-B.A.T. Deal
description: Unilever Group agreed yesterday to acquire a Chilean tomato products business for $102 million from a unit of B.A.T. Industries Ltd. Unilever, the British and Dutch consumer products giant, will buy Santiago-based Consorcio Agro-Industrial de Malloa S. A. from the B.A.T. unit Empresas CCT S. A. Malloa, with 700 employees, is one of Chile's leading food companies, and has annual sales of about $80 million. Unilever acquired similar tomato products companies in Brazil and Argentina in 1993 and 1994. (Dow Jones)

title: U.S. to Call Balkan Leaders to Parley on Violations of Accord
description: American officials, believing that the Bosnian peace accords are beginning to unravel, decided on Monday to call an international conference in Rome this weekend "to read the riot act" to the Presidents of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia and to get them "to recommit" to the accords, a senior American official said today.

title: Fed Nominee Offered No New Direction
description: To the Editor:

title: Milnerton Journal;This $40 Crank-Up Radio Lets Rural Africa Tune In
description: Even in relatively rich South Africa, half the homes have no electricity. Go far enough off the beaten track and there are villages with no place to buy even a little AAA battery. So in much of Africa, the portable radio is of little use.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Sparks Signs, But Hampton Is Unhappy
description: In the era of free agency and the salary cap, a general manager can get a lot of gray hair. Yesterday was one of those days for George Young.

title: Ryotaro Shiba, 72, Historical Novelist
description: Ryotaro Shiba, a writer known for his long historical novels, died on Monday after suffering from internal bleeding and lapsing into a coma two days earlier. He was 72.

title: AIDS Deaths Continue to Rise In 25-44 Age Group, U.S. Says
description: AIDS has become the third leading cause of death among American women 25 to 44 years of age, and the leading cause among white men in that age group, Federal health officials said yesterday.

title: Colombia's Chief Is Charged But a Tangled Inquiry Looms
description: The patio was radiant with Andean sun, wineglasses were clinking, and at the center of a crowd of diplomats at a United States Embassy reception today was Colombia's President, Ernesto Samper, smiling and seemingly serene.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Space, Wind and Other Universal Mysteries
description: Much of Erick Hawkins's choreography has an atmosphere of mystery and suggestion that encourages the viewer to enter and roam within the worlds of the dances. Such a piece is the 1991 "Intensities of Space, and Wind," presented by the Erick Hawkins Dance Company on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: A Winter Guide for Parents
description: COLD causes shrinkage, especially of living quarters. By February, any dwelling that houses small children seems cramped, whether it's a two-bedroom apartment or a rambling house in the suburbs. Holiday toys are old hat, playgrounds are out of the question, snow days have lost their novelty. Weekends -- let alone the prospect of next week's vacation, an entire week when New York City schools (and many others) will not be in session -- are enough to make a New York parent's life feel like one long Munchian scream.

title: AUTO RACING;Earnhardt and Irvan Continue to Dominate at Daytona
description: Dale Earnhardt and Ernie Irvan today won their 125-mile qualifying races for the Daytona 500 on Sunday, proving that although teamwork is fine at pit stops, it is every man for himself on the last lap at the Daytona International Speedway.

title: 2 Companies Drop Wireless Auction Bids
description: Two of the leading bidders in the Federal Government's auction of new wireless communication licenses have dropped out, either unable or unwilling to keep up as bidding reached $6.2 billion today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;A FOR-PROFIT SPINOFF OF INTELSAT IS PROPOSED
description: The Comsat Corporation and the Federal Government yesterday proposed to revamp Intelsat, the global satellite consortium, by spinning off a publicly traded, for-profit affiliate from it. The plan is subject to approval by the members of Intelsat, a consortium backed by 136 governments. The group, which is based in Washington, owns and operates the world's most extensive global communications satellite system. Comsat is the largest owner. Under the plan, Intelsat's roughly $3 billion in assets -- made up largely of more than 20 satellites -- would be split about evenly between the new affiliate and the current owners. Initially, the existing Intelsat would own all the new company's stock. The proposal calls for 60 percent of the stock to be sold to outside investors within a year. Intelsat lost a satellite Wednesday when a Chinese rocket carrying one exploded and crashed seconds after takeoff in southwestern Sichuan province.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Some thieves specialize in cash and others in jewels; at least two prefer books.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Navy Locates Recorders From Dominican Crash
description: United States Navy searchers today located the two "black boxes" from the Boeing 757 that crashed shortly after takeoff from the Dominican Republic on Feb. 6, but Government officials said there still was no agreement on who would pay to salvage the devices.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Sharing Plan for Schools
description: The State Senate Education Committee unanimously approved a bill yesterday that would offer incentives for public school districts to band together and share services. Many districts have been reluctant to merge with other districts for fear of losing state aid. Under the plan, the state would create a Regionalization and Shared Administrative Services Fund financed with penalties collected from schools found to spend too much on administration, The Associated Press reported.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Copycat 1995. Warner. $99.98. Laser disk, $39.98. 123 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Officials Fault City's Inaction In In Abuse Case
description: Bolaji Odebayo did not wind up dead. But from the accounts of school officials, prosecutors and neighbors, the 11-year-old Brooklyn boy -- burned, broken, petrified -- appears to have fallen victim to some of the same failures and misjudgments by city investigators as Elisa Izquierdo and other abused children who did not survive.

title: Home Video
description: 'Pride and Prejudice'

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Who Gets Credit for the Deal?
description: Donald J. Trump, who operates three Atlantic City casinos, has been fighting a pending bill that he said would give an unfair advantage to his rival, Stephen A. Wynn, the Las Vegas hotel and casino magnate. The measure would allow Mr. Wynn to obtain a tax cut to recoup the cost of cleaning up the landfill in Atlantic City, where he plans to build a new casino. The contaminated site sits on city-owned land and was awarded to Mr. Wynn free.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about Valentine's Day misstated the given names of a painter whose works one couple were viewing at the Metropolitan Museum. He was Pierre Auguste Cot, not Pierre-August.

title: U.N. Can Live Up to Its Rhetoric on Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Steven Slepack, 46, a Street Balloon Virtuoso
description: Steven Slepack was as bright as anyone who ever came out of Brooklyn, and when he won a full science scholarship to the University of Hawaii he appeared well on his way to a successful career as a marine biologist.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SUMMER OLYMPICS;Torch Runners Named
description: Former President JIMMY CARTER, the country-music superstar GARTH BROOKS and SHAQUILLE O'NEAL of the Orlando Magic will join a cast of thousands of less famous people to bring the Olympic flame to Atlanta. Olympic organizers yesterday named 5,500 "community heroes" and 800 Olympians to participate in the torch relay, which begins April 27 in Los Angeles and will pass through 42 states.

title: Hasidic Volunteers Help Find Suspect in Beating
description: A combination of basic detective work by a Hasidic volunteer patrol and the chance presence of a police car outside a Lower East Side bagel shop led to the capture yesterday of a Hasidic man whose estranged wife was found beaten unconscious on Saturday in her Monsey, N.Y., home.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Rocket Hits Wall Of Embassy in Athens
description: An anti-tank rocket hit an ouside wall of the United States Embassy in Athens tonight, damaging three cars, the authorities said. There were no injuries.

title: Campaign Scapegoat
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;ARCO to Produce Oil With Algerians
description: ARCO signed a contract yesterday worth more than $1 billion with the Algerian state oil company Sonatrach to share production in the country's second-largest oilfield.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A One-Man Comedy Built on Ghastly Injuries
description: L.A. is a great place to live," says Art Metrano, the short, stocky man with the mischievous, vaguely familiar face as he stands in the center of the stage. "Where else can you smell the air and see it coming at you?" He says life isn't fair: "If it were, Elvis would be alive and all those impersonators would be dead."

title: Issue of Lone-Officer Patrols Reignites a New York Debate
description: From the barrios of Los Angeles to the cobblestone streets of Beacon Hill in Boston, officers in most large American police forces routinely patrol urban neighborhoods in one-officer cars.

title: Candy Maker Is Cutting Back
description: Leaf Inc., the maker of Milk Duds and Good & Plenty and one of the largest confectionery companies in the nation, said today that it had cut 20 jobs at its headquarters here and that it would sell several of its well-known candy brands.

title: So Blacks Have Reason To Run From Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Voters Are Few in Bangladesh As a Dozen Die in Clashes
description: A boycott by the major opposition parties in Bangladesh helped insure a scanty turnout today in a general election that was marked by widespread clashes between Government and opposition supporters.

title: U.S. Aid Cutbacks Endangering Population Programs, U.N. Agencies Say
description: In the latest tactical victory by a resurgent anti-abortion movement in the United States, Congress has forced a drastic cut in aid that is the mainstay of family planning programs around the world.

title: No Foreign Promises
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Spill Threatens the Coast of Southwest Britain
description: The coast guard declared a full environmental alert today to prevent an environmental disaster after a fully laden oil tanker ran aground off the southwest coast, spilling almost 50,000 barrels of crude oil into the sea, officials said.

title: FILM REVIEW;Those Muppet Puppets As Wacky Swashbucklers
description: To plunge into the world of "Muppet Treasure Island" is to land in a place where the loquacious puppets from Jim Henson's Creature Shop often seem more real than their human companions.

title: BOXING;Morrison Speaks and Proves Full of Remorse
description: Barely 45 minutes after he learned that a second test had confirmed that he has the virus that causes AIDS, Tommy Morrison expressed remorse today over a "time in my life I lived a permissive, fast, reckless life style."

title: COMPANY NEWS;FIDELITY NATIONAL BIDDING TO ACQUIRE GIANT GROUP
description: Fidelity National Financial Inc. began a bid yesterday to acquire Giant Group Ltd. for $12 a share, or about $57.3 million. Fidelity National, an insurance holding company that already owns 14.6 percent of Giant, said the offer was contingent upon Giant's abandoning its recent proposal to exchange Giant preferred stock for common stock of Rally's Hamburgers Inc. That plan by Giant, which is based in Beverly Hills, Calif., would raise its stake in Rally's, a fast-food chain, to as much as 84.9 percent from about 47.5 percent. In addition to its interest in Rally's, Giant also makes cement. Fidelity National said it might appeal directly to Giant's shareholders in a hostile bid if talks with Giant's board were not successful.

title: Yeltsin, Seeking a Second Term, Points to Communism as the Foe
description: Casting himself as Russia's best hope for protecting democracy and market reforms from a lurch back to the past, President Boris N. Yeltsin announced today that he would seek a second term in the presidential election in June.

title: New Bomb in London
description: Responding to telephone warnings that used Irish Republican Army code words, the police destroyed a bomb left in London's West End.

title: Worth a Raise?
description: Boiling mad over the passage of a sweetheart arbitration deal for New York City police officers, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has denounced the State Legislature and made unkind remarks about the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. He has reason to be upset, since the new law could mean big salary increases in the midst of a budget crisis. But he might also give thought to the long term -- to how the city could try to get a higher caliber of officer for its money.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SPINOFF OF SPRINT'S CELLULAR UNIT GETS TAX-FREE STATUS
description: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that it had passed the last hurdle to spinning off its cellular-telephone business by getting approval from the Internal Revenue Service to make the spinoff tax-free for shareholders. The company plans to spin off the cellular unit, called the 360degrees Communications Company, in the first quarter to comply with a Federal law that prohibits the overlap of Sprint's cellular business with its new operations in so-called personal communications services. Sprint shareholders will get one share of 360degrees Communications for every three Sprint shares they own.

title: Eva Hart, 91, a Last Survivor With Memory of Titanic, Dies
description: Eva Hart was 7 years old and bound for a new life in Canada when her father woke her in the middle of the night, carried her outside in a blanket and told her, "Hold Mummy's hand and be a good girl."

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN GREETINGS SAYS IT STILL WANTS TO BUY GIBSON
description: The American Greetings Corporation said yesterday that it still wanted to acquire Gibson Greetings Inc., even though Gibson said on Wednesday that it was no longer for sale. Also on Wednesday, Gibson Greetings dismissed its chairman and chief executive, Benjamin J. Sottile. American Greetings, the nation's second-largest maker of greeting cards, after Hallmark Cards Inc., said it planned to discuss buying Gibson with Mr. Sottile's successor. Gibson hired investment bankers about seven months ago to help arrange its sale but said it had ruled out American Greetings as a buyer because of antitrust implications. The shares of Gibson, which is based in Cincinnati, fell $1.50, to $14, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Runaway Train Injures 9
description: A runaway freight train slammed into a railroad office building in East St. Paul late Wednesday night, injuring nine men, and the authorities said today that they suspected sabotage.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: A Palpable Absence

title: POLITICS: THE STAFF;Buchanan Co-leader Quits Under Fire
description: A co-chairman of Patrick Buchanan's Presidential campaign quit today after reports that he had appeared many times at meetings also attended by white supremacist organizations and right-wing militia leaders.

title: Father Bruno Hussar, 84, Dies; A Font of Jewish-Arab Amity
description: The Rev. Bruno Hussar, the founder of Neve Shalom/Wahat al-Salam, a community in Israel dedicated to improving understanding between Arabs and Jews, died on Feb. 8 in the French Hospice in Jerusalem after a brief illness. He was 84.

title: Executive Changes
description: BASS P.L.C., London, appointed Timothy M. Lane president and chief executive of its Holiday Inns Worldwide hotel division, effective on March 1. He succeeds Bryan D. Langton, chairman, president and chief executive, who will continue as chairman until his retirement in December. Mr. Lane was previously president of the restaurant division of Pepsico Inc. in Asia and the Middle East.

title: Chemicals in Food? A Panel of Experts Finds Little Danger
description: Americans trying to avoid cancer-causing substances in foods would benefit most from eating fewer calories and fats and more fruits and vegetables, a prestigious scientific panel concluded in a report issued yesterday. The panel suggested that people should worry far less about the risk of cancer from pesticide residues and food additives.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;2 Canadian Banks Buy or Raise Stakes in Bancomer and Inverlat
description: Two of Canada's largest banks, the Bank of Montreal and the Bank of Nova Scotia, are betting on a recovery of Mexico's economy and currency by investing in Mexican financial-services companies.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Battling Beach Restoration
description: A coalition of budgetary and conservation groups yesterday said the United States Army Corps of Engineers' project to restore the New Jersey beaches is a waste of money and should be phased out, for a Federal saving of $1.7 billion.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Judge Sets N.F.L. Salary Cap
description: A judge issued a temporary restraining order today that set the salary cap for the National Football League for 1996 at $40.8 million. That is $2.1 million more than the owners had sought.

title: Donaldson Executives
description: As expected, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. named its chief executive, John S. Chalsty, chairman yesterday, succeeding Richard H. Jenrette, who is retiring. Donaldson, Lufkin's chief operating officer, Joe L. Roby, succeeds Mr. Chalsty as president. Mr. Chalsty will remain in control of the day-to-day operations of the firm. The appointment came two days after Mr. Jenrette announced his retirement as head of the Equitable Companies, the insurance concern that owns 80 percent of Donaldson, Lufkin's shares. Claude Bebear will succeed Mr. Jenrette as Equitable's chairman.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Takeover Offer for BET
description: BET P.L.C., a British cleaning, security and catering concern, said yesterday that Rentokil Group P.L.C. had approached it with a takeover offer. Details of the offer were not disclosed, but analysts estimated that Rentokil's bid could be around L1.9 billion, or $2.9 billion. BET said its directors would meet to discuss the offer today. BET's American depository receipts gained $2.125 yesterday, to $11.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. (Dow Jones)

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;School Assignment for Police
description: In recent days, a teacher in Camden was beaten and his car was vandalized and another teacher was threatened by a knife-wielding seventh grader. Incidents like these prompted school officials to announce a security plan yesterday that called for posting police officers at several schools, video monitors and computerized identification badges, the A.P. reported.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Games Lose State Financing
description: Last year's Garden State Games pumped $2.8 million into Edison's economy, according to Mayor George Spadoro. The Mayor, a Democrat, criticized Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday for eliminating state financing for the games.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Turner Broadcasting Planning A Sports News Cable Channel
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. plans to create a 24-hour-a-day sports news cable channel by the end of the year, a Turner executive said yesterday, one that would combine elements of the Cable News Network and Sports Illustrated magazine.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Investor A. B. of Sweden To Sell Scania Stake
description: Investor A. B., an investment company controlled by the Wallenberg family of Sweden, plans to sell a 70 percent stake in the truck maker Scania this spring, the company said yesterday. Investor said 50 percent of Scania shares would be offered to investors around the world while another 20 percent would be offered to shareholders in Investor itself. The sale will probably be in April. Plans are to list the stock on the New York Stock Exchange and on the Stockholm Stock Exchange.

title: An Idea That Needs a Shrewd Game Plan
description: The unadorned flat tax proposed by Steve Forbes would move the American tax system to new terrain. One thing both supporters and opponents agree upon is that getting there would not be half the fun.

title: Wally Findlay, 92, Art Dealer to a Social Elite
description: Wally Findlay, an art dealer to socially prominent collectors in New York City, Palm Beach, Chicago and Paris, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 92.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daimler-Benz Aerospace Reports $2.9 Billion Loss
description: Daimler-Benz Aerospace A. G. reported yesterday that it had lost 4.3 billion marks, or $2.93 billion, last year, largely reflecting expected losses on its investment in the Dutch airplane maker Fokker. DASA, as the aerospace unit of Daimler-Benz A. G., Germany's biggest industrial company, is known, lost 438 million marks in 1994.

title: Newsman Also Gave To Bush and Specter
description: Chuck Scarborough, the WNBC-TV news anchor who was reprimanded by his station for giving $2,000 to two Republican Presidential candidates, also donated $1,000 to the Bush-Quayle re-election campaign in 1991 and $500 to United States Senator Arlen Specter in 1992, according to Federal election records.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 8 about the acquittal of three men in Miami on murder charges linked to drug trafficking misspelled the surname of a lawyer in the Federal public defender's office who represented one defendant. The lawyer is Reuben Cahn, not Kahn.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;A Returning Coleman Looks to Save Sixers
description: For both Derrick Coleman and the Philadelphia 76ers, this has been a season of extraordinary frustration. The 76ers (10-37) have been awful. The team's owner, Harold Katz, reportedly came close to firing John Lucas as coach and hiring Chris Ford.

title: Market Place;Alza has taken the wraps off its drug pipeline, pleasing analysts.
description: FOR years, the Alza Corporation, the leading producer of skin patches for drug companies, has had a secretive culture that has left Wall Street mostly in the dark about the company's prospects.

title: For Children
description: A Children's Celebration of the Chinese New Year Harry De Jur Playhouse Henry Street Settlement Abrons Arts Center 466 Grand Street Lower East Side (212) 598-0400 Ages 4 and up Tomorrow

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTELCOM GROUP INC., Denver, will spend $10 million to acquire a 60 percent stake in a partnership with Linkatel Communications Inc. and Copley Press Inc., to operate a 50-mile fiber-optic network in San Diego.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Judge Approves Settlement Of Drug Price-Fixing Suit A Federal judge gave preliminary approval to a $409 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit that charged drug makers and wholesalers with conspiring to fix prices on sales to independent pharmacies. The decision cleared the way for notice of the settlement to be mailed to the 40,000 pharmacies in the class.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Marchibroda to Baltimore
description: ART MODELL got the coach he wanted, and TED MARCHIBRODA got the job he coveted. Marchibroda signed a three-year contract yesterday to become coach of the National Football League franchise that Modell is shifting from Cleveland to Baltimore. Marchibroda was coach of the Baltimore Colts from 1975 to 1979, the final glory days of a franchise that left town in 1984.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PRICE IS REDUCED FOR PURCHASE OF FISONS DIVISION
description: Thermo Instrument Systems said yesterday that it had reduced by "slightly more than 20 percent" the amount it would pay to acquire the scientific instruments division of Fisons P.L.C. The price cut, apparently in excess of $60 million, came after the Federal Trade Commission approved the acquisition yesterday on the condition that Thermo Instrument's purchase exclude "substantially all" of the mass spectrometer and high-resolution mass spectrometer businesses of Fisons. Thermo Instrument, a subsidiary of the Thermo Electron Corporation, agreed to buy the Fisons unit for about $320 million on March 1, 1995.

title: Seoul Sinks Imaginary Foe (aka Tokyo) at Islet
description: In a warning to Tokyo, South Korean military forces today practiced repelling imaginary enemy vessels around disputed islets in the Sea of Japan.

title: About Real Estate;A Manhattan Realty Firm Links Up With U.S. Chain
description: The two Manhattan offices of Hunt-Kennedy Real Estate have affiliated with Coldwell Banker, a national real estate chain. The partners who own the venture say that in addition to a national system of referrals and advertising, the structure will allow them to offer equity in the business to their top agents.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: For Maryland's Democrats, a 27-Candidate Primary Is Guesswork
description: They are ministers and lawyers, elected officials and engineers, entrepreneurs and professors. One is still in law school, one is a well-known local bartender and one never said exactly what he did but that his uncle had been a street sweeper in the area, adding, "Many of you probably knew him."

title: Art in Review
description: Projects' Oliver Herring and Leonilson Museum of Modern Art 11 West 53d Street Manhattan Through March 12

title: Milwaukee Daily's Parent Rebuffs Bid Inquiry
description: A New York investment group has approached Journal Communications Inc., which owns the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel and other media and printing interests, to discuss a possible purchase at a price of about $1 billion, but it has been rebuffed, Journal Communications said last night.

title: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;Forbes's Three-Pronged Approach
description: There are two new 30-second television advertisements that have begun appearing in New Hampshire for the final week before the primary. One is titled "Education" and the other is "Parents." They are being broadcast along with a third commercial, called "Healthcare," that was also shown in Iowa.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: Art in Review
description: Elliot Schwartz and Eve Sonneman Sidney Janis Gallery 110 West 57th Street Manhattan Through Feb. 24 (Sonneman) and March 6 (Schwartz)

title: Fresh Data Indicate Economy Could Be Heading for a Stall
description: Evidence mounted today that the economy, whose growth has been slowing markedly in recent months, could be approaching a stall.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BTR BUYS AN AUTO-PARTS BUSINESS FROM GENCORP
description: BTR P.L.C. said yesterday that it had bought a unit of Gencorp Inc. that makes vibration-control equipment for automobiles. The price was put at $80 million. BTR, a British company with interests ranging from Formica laminates to Hawker Aerospace, and Gencorp, a maker of products for the aerospace and automotive markets, have been in talks for more than a month. The vibration-control unit, with operations in Wabash, Logansport and Peru, Ind., has annual sales of more than $150 million and employs 1,200 people, BTR said.

title: POLITICS: ON THE MOVE;For Buchanan, the Voice Is His Weapon of Choice
description: Much has been made of the millions spent by Steve Forbes, the publisher, to advertise himself for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: College Football Gets Tie Breakers
description: Overtime will be part of major college football this fall. The National Collegiate Athletic Association football rules committee voted today to require a tie breaker in all games.

title: FILM REVIEW;Dangerous Dealings In the Heart of New York
description: There's a fine, revealing scene at the end of "City Hall" in which a young idealist and a seasoned politician recognize that they're not as far apart as they once imagined. It's a moving encounter, gracefully acted and believably staged, cognizant of the real and gritty New York in which this story is supposed to unfold. "City Hall" could have used much more of the same.

title: Inside Art
description: Beyond Painting

title: Mortgage Rate Below 7%
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 6.94 percent this week, the lowest level in more than two years, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The average was down from 7.02 percent last week and the lowest since 6.86 percent in the week that ended on Oct. 28, 1993. On one-year adjustable- rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.19 percent, down from 5.33 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 6.44 percent this week, down from 6.51 percent a week earlier.

title: In Quick Tour, Clinton Touches Critical Base
description: The Clinton-Gore campaign and the two men who happen to head it came barnstorming into New York and New Jersey yesterday, shaking the money tree, touching political bases in a pair of states vital to their re-election and offering a vigorous defense of Felix G. Rohatyn and pro-growth economic policies.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMPOLEX CALLS $936 MILLION TAKEOVER BID TOO LOW
description: Ampolex Ltd., the Australian oil and natural-gas exploration company for which the Mobil Corporation made an offer this week, signaled yesterday that it would try to squeeze a higher price out of Mobil, which said that it had secured almost 14.9 percent of Ampolex. The Ampolex board described Mobil's $936 million offer, which was unsolicited, as "currently deficient." Ampolex stock finished at $4.18 (Australian), or $3.16 (United States), a share yesterday, matching the Mobil bid of $4.25 (Australian) a share early in the session. Mobil's stake brings it near the 15 percent threshold that would cause the Foreign Investment Review Board of Australia to scrutinize it. A takeover would be subject to approval by the review board. The Ampolex board advised shareholders to take no action for now.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Tuesday with an article about accusations that Royal Dutch/ Shell had condoned a Nigerian Government crackdown against members of the Ogoni people misstated the volume of Nigeria's oil production. It is 1.8 million barrels a day, not 1.8 billion.

title: James J. Shanahan, 88, College President
description: The Rev. James John Shanahan, a Jesuit priest who, as its 15th president, led St. Peter's College in Jersey City through a period of robust growth, died on Monday at the Murray-Weigel Home at Fordham University in the Bronx. He was 88.

title: U.N. Can Live Up to Its Rhetoric on Women;Big Costs, Big Job
description: To the Editor:

title: ART REVIEW;Torn Between Rodin And Pristine Geometry
description: Don't look a gift horse in the mouth. "The Figure in American Sculpture: A Question of Modernity," at the National Academy of Design, offers an amazingly rich selection of little-known art from the years between 1898 and World War II. No one interested in the development of American art will want to miss this show, which includes works by liperally dozens of talented and in many cases little-known sculptors.

title: 25 and Under
description: Americans seem to have an innate fear of Ethiopian food: "Isn't that the food you eat with your fingers?" people ask hesitantly, as if it were a vile practice.

title: Travis Bickle, Still Asking If Someone's Talking to Him
description: On its 20th anniversary, the prophetic masterpiece of the 1970's looks better than ever. Hindsight underscores the amazing prescience of Martin Scorsese's "Taxi Driver," a film that anticipated such profound changes in our national mood. Since its debut, "Taxi Driver" and Travis Bickle, a tortured innocent dpiven over the brink into shocking violence, have come to seem far less marginal than they did in 1976. The spiritual perils invoked by Paul Schrader's daring, cautionary screenplay have come closer to home.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Oakley to Miss Six Weeks With a Broken Thumb
description: The Knicks' tumultuous season took a turn for the worse today when it was learned that Charles Oakley, the team's starting power forward and symbol of perseverance, will be sidelined for six weeks with a broken right thumb.

title: Mexican Diplomat at U.N.: New Advocate for Women
description: Not long after Rosario Green arrived at the United Nations a couple of years ago, she was distracted one day while walking along a corridor by the sound of crying. A woman in a telephone booth was telling a friend she was being harassed by her boss and she did not know where to turn.

title: A Study Finds Minors Buying More Cigarettes
description: Although states and businesses say they have been stepping up efforts to deny teen-agers access to tobacco products, a new survey to be released today by the Government concludes that teen-agers actually found it easier to make such purchases in 1993 than in 1989.

title: Art in Review
description: Dominique Figarella Caren Golden Fine Art 39 Wooster Street (near Broome Street) SoHo Through Feb. 24

title: I.R.A. Bomb Destroyed in Central London
description: Responding to telephone warnings that used Irish Republican Army code words, the police today destroyed a bomb that had been left in a telephone booth in the heart of London's crowded West End.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SOFTBANK BUYS A STAKE IN CYBERCASH
description: The Softbank Corporation of Japan said that it had bought a 9.9 percent stake in Cybercash Inc. for $15.2 million. Cybercash, based in Reston, Va., makes technology intended to make it easier to shop over the Internet, using encryption software to safeguard credit-card data. Softbank, a rapidly expanding distributor of software and publisher of computer magazines, said it saw the stake as a way to enter the Internet business. Softbank bought the shares yesterday, on their first day of trading on the Nasdaq market. Cybercash shares rose 64 percent from the offering price, to $28.25.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a lawsuit against the owner of Paladin Press, publisher of a paperback called "Hit Man: A Technical Manual for Contractors," misidentified the publisher of another book, "The Anarchist Cookbook." That book is published by Barricade Books of New York; it is distributed by Paladin Press.

title: 2 Companies File Suit Against AT&T
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation and The DSC Communications Corporation have filed a $3.5 billion lawsuit against the AT&T Corporation, accusing the company of stifling competition by building important telephone equipment to incompatible standards.

title: Judge Blocks Law Intended To Regulate On-Line Smut
description: A Federal judge temporarily blocked enforcement yesterday of a new law that makes it a felony to transmit indecent material over the Internet or on-line computer services if the material may be seen by children.

title: 3 Democrats Win Contests
description: Democratic candidates won decisive victories yesterday in special elections to fill a State Assembly and a State Senate seat in the Bronx and a State Senate seat in Brooklyn.

title: POLITICS;Excerpts From the G.O.P. Presidential Debate in New Hampshire
description: Following are excerpts from the debate among eight Republican Presidential candidates last night in Manchester, N.H., as recorded by The New York Times. The comments are in response to questions about each candidate's stance on trade policy, Social Security and health care.

title: POP REVIEW;The Life of Ray Davies Through Word and Song
description: In "20th-Century Man: An Evening With Ray Davies," on Wednesday night at a Westbeth Theater Center decorated to look like an English pub, Mr. Davies of the Kinks chronicled his life in song and spoken word. His account, based on his recent autobiography, "X-Ray" (Overlook Press), took him from normal child to misfit teen-ager to upstart musician to exploited songwriter to wistful old-timer. There was one stage, however, missing from this chronology: the glory years of a star. For Mr. Davies, a life in the limelight was derailed in the late 60's when he was temporarily banned from touring America and embroiled in a series of lawsuits over music publishing.

title: MARATHON;More of a Mission Than a Race
description: He won the 1988 Olympic trials, running only his second marathon, and in the span of 2 hours 12 minutes 26 seconds, Mark Conover's career was catapulted from the shadows of anonymity to the spotlight of the Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea.

title: Report on Port Authority Says It Favors New Jersey
description: Adding statistical weight to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's assertion that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey slights New York City, Mark Green, the city's Public Advocate, said yesterday that the authority favors New Jersey in its capital spending and transportation services.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Ex-Aide to Japanese Premier Is Accused, Without Proof, of Soliciting a Bribe
description: A property tycoon told a nationally televised parliamentary hearing today that a former personal secretary to Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto had tried to solicit a $400,000 bribe several years ago. The tycoon, Kichinosuke Sasaki, gave no evidence and his credibility could be regarded as shaky because he is in trouble for not paying huge back debts. Mr. Hashimoto and his former aide did not respond directly to the charge, but Mr. Hashimoto told reporters that he planned to question his aide, Toyoki Kobayashi.

title: Dial, Pressed By Investors, Will Become 2 Companies
description: After making at least 17 substantial acquisitions since he became chief executive of what is now the Dial Corporation in 1981, John W. Teets has found that conglomerates are no longer in fashion.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;30-Year Sentence for Woman
description: Michelle Gomez, who was convicted of killing a Newark police detective in what prosecutors described as a jealous rage, was sentenced yesterday to the maximum term of 30 years in prison. She will be eligible for parole in 15 years.

title: ART REVIEW;Keeping History Fluid For Needs of the Present
description: Memory: Luba and the Making of History" at the Museum for African Art is everything an exhibition ought to be. Visually riveting and built on a theme as philosophically complex as it is poetic, it has the pace and pull of an unfolding epic.

title: INSIDE
description: Scrutiny After Abuse Case

title: Level Field or Uneven Results?;Tallying Up the What Ifs in the Flat-Tax Proposals
description: A year ago, it is safe to say, not one American in 100 knew much about the flat tax. But after Steve Forbes spent tens of millions of dollars from his fortune espousing it endlessly in the Republican Presidential campaign, the flat tax has become fodder for talk radio and stand-up comedy.

title: NYC;Is H.I.V. Test Fair to Boxers? Is Anything?
description: EARNEST, lean Regilio Tuur, looking like a strip of copper wire with muscles, was no-nonsense as he shadowboxed outside the bloodstained ring at Gleason's Gym near the Brooklyn waterfront. But he permitted himself an ironic laugh when his workout was over and he talked about how his craft had changed.

title: Giuliani's Approval Rating Climbs in Poll
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's approval rating, after dropping last fall, has climbed sharply, evidently lifted by the perception of a large majority of New Yorkers that he has successfully fought crime, according to a new poll published yesterday by Quinnipiac College.

title: Art in Review
description: American Moderns Salander-O'Reilly Galleries 20 East 79th Street Manhattan Through March 2

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Granada Increases Stake In Yorkshire Tyne-Tees
description: The British leisure and media company Granada Group P.L.C. increased its stake yesterday in Yorkshire Tyne-Tees Television Holding P.L.C. to 19.99 percent from 14 percent. Yorkshire shares gained earlier yesterday on speculation that Granada was buying up shares as a defensive move to ward off a possible bid by a rival, MAI P.L.C.

title: British Report on Iraq Arms Deal Declares Parliament Was Misled
description: The results of a three-year investigation into a scandal over Britain's sale of military equipment to Iraq in the late 1980's were made public here today, and deepened the pall over the embattled Government of Prime Minister John Major.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Feb. 3 about a hearing in the Government's efforts to regain stock worth more than $20 million that it said was being held improperly by the lawyer F. Lee Bailey in a drug forfeiture case referred imprecisely in some editions to the role of a fellow lawyer, Robert L. Shapiro. Mr. Shapiro, a co-counsel in the drug case, testified as a Government witness about his understanding of the agreement under which Mr. Bailey came into control of the stock. He was not competing for control of the stock.

title: Cecil Head, Expert In Bridge, Dies at 85
description: Cecil Head, one of the nation's leading bridge players half a century ago, died in his hometown, Fort Branch, Ind., last Wednesday. He was 85 and died of congestive heart failure, said his wife, Olivia.

title: Terrorism Ruled Out In Colombia Crash
description: Terrorism, engine failure and problems with other components have apparently been ruled out in the crash of an American Airlines jet in Colombia in December.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Jets See Signing Tackle As a First Step Back
description: The Jets yesterday offered tackle David Williams as Exhibit A that they will be aggressive in the free-agent market and are able to lure good players to New York despite finishing with the worst record (3-13) in the National Football League.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Fox Restates Support Of TV Rating System
description: The Fox Network said yesterday that it would provide ratings for the content of its programs, similar to those provided for films by the Motion Picture Association, regardless of whether such a system is devised by all major broadcasters.

title: Notes Offer View of White House Concern About Whitewater
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton was so adamant against the appointment of an independent counsel on Whitewater that senior Clinton aides believed that not even the President could change her mind, according to notes released today by Republicans on the Senate Whitewater committee.

title: The Foreign Policy Campaign
description: Bob Dole played the foreign policy card in New Hampshire on Wednesday, trotting out Jeane Kirkpatrick to stand at his side as he attacked President Clinton's handling of Bosnia and Haiti. A new Dole television ad hit the air the same day savaging Pat Buchanan as a dangerous isolationist.

title: This Time, Parks Mean Business;Aggressive Pursuit of Profit Is Path for Strapped Agency
description: Last fall the Parks and Recreation Department turned Central Park's drives into a test road for BMW's. It is renting out DeWitt Clinton Park to a dinner-theater production. Last week, it signed a deal allowing a sporting goods company to advertise on basketball backboards. It is looking into endorsing a soft drink -- the Official Beverage of City Greenswards? -- and is even imagining its own credit card, complete with a holographic image of the park of your choice.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Shell Has Good Year, But Drop in Quarter
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, Europe's largest oil company, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 24 percent, excluding one-time items, as surprisingly weak chemical earnings and higher refining costs offset stronger oil profit. While the quarter was good enough to make 1995 the most profitable year ever for Shell, the chemical business plunged in the final three months. Operating profit fell 91 percent, to L17 million.

title: Energy Secretary Does Battle With House G.O.P.
description: Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary made headlines early in her tenure by declassifying secrets from the cold war and expressing remorse that the Government had used Americans as guinea pigs in radiation experiments.

title: U.N. Can Live Up to Its Rhetoric on Women;Isolationist Mind-Set
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistan Didn't Buy Nuclear Arms Parts
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM REVIEW;Uh-oh, Dreamboat Is Wild And Crazy
description: Sometimes chemistry works and sometimes it doesn't," says Martha Alston (Ellen DeGeneres), trying tactfully to ditch an unwanted beau. "Sometimes you get an explosion -- or a really bad smell." Unlike the mismatched lovers they play in "Mr. Wrong," Ellen DeGeneres and Bill Pullman actually do have good chemistry, but they don't have a movie to show it off. Good-humored but mostly flat, "Mr. Wrong" wastes an amusing premise and two likable stars.

title: FILM REVIEW;Boor Wins Fame as the Bad Boy of Golf
description: Adam Sandler's new comedy, "Happy Gilmore," takes a gleefully puerile view of what constitutes a working-class hero. The movie's title character is a failed hockey player who accidentally discovers he is a whiz at golf and becomes the bad-boy sensation of the professional circuit.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Honors
description: The Association of Independent Commercial Producers, New York, named Robert M. Greenberg, chairman and chief executive at R/GA Digital Studios, New York, the chairman of its fifth annual show, "The Art and Technique of the American Television Commercial." The show is scheduled to begin June 12 at the Museum of Modern Art in New York.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Cautious Support For TV Rating Plan
description: Agency executives involved in media decisions reacted positively, though cautiously, to the plans disclosed yesterday by the four broadcast television networks to establish a ratings system for their programming. The networks are responding to criticism of the violence and sexual content of their programs, and are eager to avoid a Government-led ratings system.

title: From a Grave in Rwanda, Hundreds of Dead Tell Their Tale
description: The smell of the dead hangs all around the stone walls of the Kibuye Roman Catholic Church, a rank odor that seems out of place on this peaceful and wooded promontory above the glassy water of Lake Kivu.

title: HOCKEY;Caution for Ranger Fans: No Trade Talks
description: For Ranger fans who are waiting for the Great One, Neil Smith basically had this message yesterday: Don't hold your breath.

title: 2 Waste Haulers to Change Contract Policies
description: Waste Management Inc. and Browning-Ferris Industries, the two largest solid-waste haulers, agreed today to change their contract practices to settle Justice Department charges that they tried to block smaller trash haulers from entering markets in Georgia, Louisiana, Tennessee and Iowa.

title: Solid-Waste Management Plan Wins Council Approval
description: The City Council yesterday overwhelmingly approved a new solid-waste management plan that will speed up the city's timetable for recycling "mixed paper" and will require residents in all five boroughs to recycle items like cereal boxes, milk cartons and junk mail by the middle of next year.

title: Chief Resigns At On-Line Joint Venture
description: Scott Kurnit resigned yesterday as the chief executive of News Corp. Internet, the on-line service jointly owned by MCI Communications and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation.

title: Sports of The Times;Morrison Didn't Pay Attention
description: TOMMY MORRISON listened when Magic Johnson graciously called on the telephone the other day. But Tommy Morrison had tuned out when Magic Johnson announced he was H.I.V. positive four years ago.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: No Headline
description: No responsible scientist in the food system would deny there are substances in the food supply that in theory could be nasty if consumed in excessive amounts, but bodies aren't piling up because of lethal substances in food."

title: Art in Review
description: Cathy de Monchaux Sean Kelly 43 Mercer Street (near Broome Street) SoHo Through March 9

title: Maria A. Rudzinska, 92, Zoologist and Professor
description: Maria A. Rudzinska, a protozoologist who used electron microscopy to uncover the eating habits of the parasite that causes malaria, died last Friday at her home in Manhattan. Dr. Rudzinska, who was an emeritus professor of parasitology at Rockefeller University, was 92.

title: TV WEEKEND;The Trip to Dignity In 3 Short Stories
description: African-American authors get a rare and exquisitely made showcase tomorrow on HBO'S "America's Dream," with half-hour adaptations by Ron Stacker Thompson and Ashley Tyler of three short stories: Richard Wright's "Long Black Song," John Henrik Clarke's "Boy Who Painted Christ Black" and Maya Angelou's "Reunion." The executive producers are Danny Glover and Carolyn McDonald.

title: AN ASSEMBLY PLAN WOULD DISMANTLE CITY SCHOOL BOARD
description: The Democratic leaders of the State Assembly yesterday proposed abolishing New York City's Board of Education, as well as its 32 community school boards. They called instead for a new board, most of whose members would be chosen in elections, and for a chancellor with broad powers and even greater independence from City Hall.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Players Win 4th Straight
description: On the first day of spring training, the players continued to pitch a shutout in salary arbitration.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Brunswick Selects Fallon McElligott
description: The Mercury Marine division of the Brunswick Corporation in Fond du Lac, Wis., yesterday named Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis to handle advertising and integrated-marketing assignments, which had been awarded only three months ago to Cramer-Krasselt in Milwaukee. Billings were estimated last year at $4 million, but Brunswick said they were expected to grow in 1996 to an estimated $20 million. The decision came after a review that included another finalist, Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis.

title: Trenton G.O.P. Leaders Agree on a Charity Care Plan
description: On the day the state first missed its monthly payment to reimburse hospitals for providing medical treatment to the poor, Republican legislative leaders agreed today to pay for the state's charity care program by continuing to use surplus revenues from the unemployment insurance fund.

title: A Plan to Save the New York Region
description: In the last couple of years, the political leadership in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut has been enthralled by tax cuts as the primary means to revitalize economic growth. Now comes a different idea from the Regional Plan Association, which called this week for no less than $75 billion in public expenditures to upgrade urban centers, open spaces, highways, rail lines and schools throughout the New York metropolitan area. At stake, the association said, is whether the New York area is to prevent the loss of hundreds of thousands of jobs and remain relevant to the highly competitive economic forces sweeping the globe.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Philips Profit Fell in 4th Quarter
description: Philips Electronics N. V. said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 30 percent as higher earnings from semiconductors made up somewhat for a decline in consumer electronics. For the full year, profit rose to 2.52 billion guilders, from 2.13 billion in 1994. While analysts welcomed the higher-than-expected fourth-quarter profit, they cautioned that slower growth in semiconductors could raise worries about 1996 earnings.

title: Islamic Party Closer to Coalition in Turkey
description: Turkey's leading Islamic party came closer to taking a share of power today after talks on forming a cabinet with a conservative party.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Judge Frets About Excess of Rights
description: GUILTY The Collapse of Criminal Justice By Harold J. Rothwax 238 pages. Random House. $23.

title: POLITICS: THE DEBATE;G.O.P. RIVALS CLASH OVER ATTACK ADS
description: In a nationally televised forum five days before Tuesday's primary, the Republican Presidential candidates quarreled over trade, health care and welfare tonight and vied for the title of most true conservative. But they spent much of their time attacking one another over attack advertisements.

title: Use a Police Raise to Enforce City Residency
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: One of the great classics of the game, written half a century ago, is available from Baron-Barclay Bridge Supplies, (800) 274-2221, for $15.95 including mailing. It is "Right Through the Pack" by Robert Darvas and Norman de Vere Hart, in which each card has a delightful story to tell.

title: U.S. and Canada in Deal That Ends Lumber Dispute
description: The United States and Canada reached an agreement to curb Canadian softwood lumber exports in a deal that resolves a 13-year trade dispute between the countries, the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said today.

title: World News Briefs;Zairian Troops Surround 2d Rwandan Refugee Site
description: Zairian troops surrounded a second refugee camp in eastern Zaire today, stepping up pressure on the one million refugees in the country to return to Rwanda, where many fear reprisals for the 1994 genocide there.

title: BASEBALL;Pitchers Spending More Time At Plate
description: Everyone knows that the Mets' young pitching staff is coveted for its talented throwing arms. That will always be the major criterion by which these players are judged. Yet one of the areas of emphasis during this spring training is to earn some respect for their bats as well.

title: Man Sentenced in Albany Hostage Drama
description: A man convicted of holding students hostage at the State University at Albany and shooting one of them was sentenced today to consecutive terms totaling 15 2/3 to 47 years.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Teacher in Sex Assault Case
description: A 49-year-old school music teacher was charged with sexually assaulting two female pupils, ages 8 and 7, while tutoring at their homes in separate incidents last week. William Miranda, a teacher at the Brookside and Hillside schools in Allendale, was arrested after one of the girls told her parents, said Frank Puccio, first assistant prosecutor for Bergen County. Mr. Miranda was ordered held at Bergen Pines County Hospital for psychiatric evaluation.

title: World News Briefs;10 in Gabon Die of Ebola After Feast of Chimp Meat
description: At least 10 people who feasted on chimpanzee meat in a remote region of Gabon have died of the Ebola virus, according to World Health Organization experts who flew to Gabon this week to investigate the deaths.

title: Nazaret Cherkezian, Ex-TV Producer, 71
description: Nazaret Cherkezian, a retired television producer and telecommunications specialist, died on Monday at his home in McLean, Va. He was 71.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALLIED SIGNAL INC., Morristown, N.J., a technology and manufacturing company, sold its Jayhawk performance chemicals plant in Galena, Kan., to Allco Chemical Corp., a unit of Inspec Group P.L.C. of England, for $28 million.

title: Plan Would Have Social Security Put Some Money in Stock Market
description: A Federal advisory panel appointed by the Clinton Administration plans to recommend a radical change in policy for Social Security: investing billions of dollars of payroll contributions in the stock market.

title: COMPANY NEWS;REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES SET TO BEGIN EXPANSION
description: Republic Industries of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said yesterday that it would buy certain electronic security and solid waste companies for stock currently valued about $81.6 million. The security companies, known as Denver Burglar Alarm, provide alarms to about 27,000 residential and commercial customers in Colorado. The waste companies, which are controlled by Dwight C. Schaubach, provide waste collection and recycling services in Virginia and North Carolina and also transport medical waste. Republic is headed by Wayne Huizenga, the former chairman of Blockbuster Entertainment. It will exchange a total of 2.9 million shares in the purchases. The shares closed up 25 cents yesterday at $28.375.

title: HIGH SCHOOL REPORT
description: C.H.S.A.A.

title: Iridex's Initial Offering
description: The Iridex Corporation sold 2.55 million of its common shares for $23 million, or $9 each, in its first public stock offering, the company said yesterday. Proceeds from the sale will be used for working capital and other general corporate purposes, including the expansion of research and development and sales and marketing activities. The company, based in Mountain View, Calif., provides photo-coagulator systems used to treat eye disease. The company's shares closed at $10.25 yesterday in Nasdaq trading.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;Pell Quits Coaching
description: After one year as the football coach for a Florida high school team, the former Florida Coach CHARLEY PELL is calling it quits. Pell, 54, has decided to return to private business in Anniston, Ala., where he is vice president of an employment placement agency called Temporary Resources. Pell was fired at the University of Florida in 1984 because of numerous National Collegiate Athletic Association violations. (AP)

title: Novonikolskoye Journal;Fleshing Out the New Russian Brand of Capitalism
description: Now as in Soviet times, there are pleasure domes for the privileged elite, secluded in a silver birch forest behind tightly guarded gates. Only the privileged elite has changed.

title: Ex-Officer Is Alert After Surgery but Not Talking Again
description: Gary Dockery, who began talking this week after seven and a half years of silence in a coma-like state, was alert but not speaking today as he continued to recover from lung surgery.

title: Journal;The Pratt Fall
description: How stupid do they think we are? If we are to believe Pat Buchanan, he didn't have a clue until the day before yesterday that his campaign co-chairman Larry Pratt, commandant of Gun Owners of America, had any connections to the most racist, anti-Semitic and heavily armed organizations of the American far right.

title: In Iowa Town, Strains of Diversity
description: At the Toui Lo market, one of two Asian stores here in Storm Lake, Laotian women were shopping, picking over jumbo tiger shrimp laid out in cardboard boxes or selecting bags of rice off the shelves. At the Lamp Lighter motel, across the street, Sunil and Geeta Patel, a couple from India, checked in guests while Hispanic maids cleaned the rooms.

title: A Failure to Teach and Protect;How a School for Child Welfare Workers Fell Apart
description: Nearly a decade ago, at a moment when New York City was seized with anguish about child abuse, an academy was opened in Queens to train workers responsible for investigating cases of neglect and abuse. The new school had its own multimillion-dollar budget and was expected to be a model for the rest of the country.

title: NEC Plans to Increase Production of Chips
description: The NEC Corporation said today that it planned to double its output of 16-megabit dynamic random-access memories, or D-RAM, chips -- a key component in personal computers -- to 18 million units a month.

title: New Chief Outlines Strategy to Revive Apple Computer
description: The new chairman and chief executive of Apple Computer Inc., Gilbert F. Amelio, said today that the personal computer maker could straighten out its business strategy quickly and that the company could make needed changes without huge layoffs as has been widely expected.

title: Heavy Floods Can't Cure Southern Africa Drought
description: This has been a summer of storms in South Africa. In December, 150 people died in flooding along the Umsindusi River. On Thursday, nearly 16 inches of rain fell in an hour in Johannesburg, and as the storm rushed east, 40 people were killed when cars were washed away and pedestrians foolishly braved swollen rivers and submerged roads. Near the northern border, a herd of cattle was said to have been swept away.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Auto Ruling Favors Independent Traders
description: The European Court of Justice ruled on Thursday that independent traders might sell cars across the European Union. Car dealers for Nissan, Ford Motor, Peugeot, Citroen, Honda and Renault -- all based in France -- had challenged parallel import sales by unauthorized resellers of new cars.

title: No Headline
description: It's a real mess in there."

title: COMPANY NEWS;$605 MILLION PURCHASE OF FORUM GROUP PLANNED
description: Marriott International Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Forum Group Inc. for $605 million in cash and debt in a move that would make Marriott the nation's second-largest owner of housing communities for the elderly. Marriott, which mainly manages hotels, now operates 27 elderly housing communities that offer residents private apartments, common dining facilities, on-site medical attention and recreational activities. Forum operates 42 similar facilities. Shareholders of Forum, based in Fairfax, Va., will receive $13 a share in cash, or $302 million. Marriott will also take on $303 million of Forum's debt.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Radical Overhaul Proposed For Social Security System A Federal advisory panel will soon recommend a radical change in Social Security, saying that billions of dollars of worker contributions should, for the first time, be invested in the stock market. The panel is also discussing whether some of the payroll tax revenue for Social Security should be diverted to individual accounts, so workers could invest it as they wish.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;All Is Right In Garden, Thanks To Sixers
description: There are times when the Knicks look so marvelous in the open floor -- with Charlie Ward seemingly converting layups out of his ear and everyone else draining 3-pointers from the corners -- that all their worries disappear.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Moon's Wife, on Stand, Blames Her Temper
description: Warren Moon's wife took the witness stand today and portrayed herself as a temperamental woman who had provoked her husband.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Juliet's Valentine: Can Anyone Guess Who It Could Be?
description: The New York City Ballet celebrated Valentine's Day on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater with works suitable for the occasion. The most unabashedly romantic of them was Sean Lavery's version of the Balcony Scene from Prokofiev's "Romeo and Juliet."

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Sparky to Lead Parade
description: SPARKY ANDERSON won't be in uniform on opening day, but he will be in a parade. The 61-year-old former Cincinnati Reds and Detroit Tigers manager has agreed to be grand marshal of Cincinnati's annual opening day parade on April 1, organizers said yesterday. The Tigers let him go after last season, his 26th as a manager in the majors. (AP)

title: Clinton on Abortion: Then, and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Play'rs Clinch the Arbitration Pennant
description: The players lost their unbeaten record in this year's salary arbitration yesterday, but they nevertheless assured themselves of their first winning record over the clubs since 1990.

title: Mr. Buchanan Stumbles
description: As he surges upward in the polls, Patrick J. Buchanan requests that he be taken seriously as a Presidential candidate. But he flunked an early test of his leadership and judgment this week by failing to repudiate the actions and views of Larry Pratt, a co-chairman of his campaign who was forced to step aside after disclosures that he had been consorting with white supremacist organizations and right-wing militia leaders. Instead, Mr. Buchanan dismissed the allegations and heatedly defended Mr. Pratt as a "very loyal supporter."

title: A Code of Honor
description: A few months after the Persian Gulf war, on an empyreal California afternoon, I met with a young priest, a newly commissioned doctor and a Marine major who smiled when he smoked. I was a first lieutenant, new to command.

title: A Blaze in Inwood Kills a Woman, 67
description: A 67-year-old woman was killed last night when a two-alarm fire raced through her apartment in the Inwood section of Manhattan, fire officials said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STOKELY SET TO LEAVE FROZEN VEGETABLE BUSINESS
description: Stokely USA Inc., a major producer of canned vegetables, said yesterday that it would sell its struggling frozen vegetable operations and exit that business to cut costs and help profit margins. The company said it expected to take a one-time charge in the quarter ending on March 31 to cover the divestiture. Stokely USA has three frozen vegetable processing plants in Grandview, Wash., Walla Walla, Wash., and Green Bay, Wis. Leaving the frozen vegetable business will reduce Stokely's working capital needs by about $40 million, its president, Vern Wiersma, said. Stokely had sales of $65.5 million in the third quarter, which ended on Dec. 31.

title: Tax Plan Spurs New Sugar Battle in Florida
description: After failing to get rid of Federal price supports for sugar, environmentalists in Florida are now battling it out with sugar cane growers over a proposed tax that would raise money to help restore the Everglades.

title: Bond Prices Suffer a 3d Day of Steep Losses
description: Treasury prices fell sharply for a third consecutive session yesterday, weighed down by talk of selling by large funds and by concerns that the supply of securities might be larger than the demand. Trading was choppy in a session that ended early ahead of the Washington's Birthday holiday weekend.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Life Terms in Gang Killings
description: Six men from Chinatown must each serve four consecutive life terms for killing four gang rivals in an assault on their smuggling safe house in Teaneck. The six are not eligible for parole for at least 120 years under the sentences imposed yesterday by State Superior Court Judge William C. Meehan, who presided over the trial in which all six were found guilty of murder, attempted murder, burglary and weapons charges. Prosecutors said the victims were shot and stabbed to death.

title: Fast and Fierce, 12th Storm Batters the Region
description: Bullying winter roared up the Northeast corridor and battered the New York region and coastal New England again yesterday with snowfalls that disrupted commerce, education, nonemergency governmental services, intercity travel, commuting and end-of-the-week routines for millions.

title: AUTO RACING;Earnh'rdt Wins Early At Daytona
description: Dale Earnhardt continued his winning ways today in another preliminary to the Daytona 500 on Sunday. For other drivers, that would augur well. But with Earnhardt's history here, he ought to start worrying about Sunday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KUHLMAN GETS 82% OF COMMUNICATION CABLE CORP.
description: The Kuhlman Corporation said yesterday that it had bought 82 percent of the Communication Cable Corporation for $14 a share, or $32 million, winning a three-month bidding war with Pentair Inc. for the wire and cable maker. Kuhlman, which makes transformers, wire, cable and springs, bought about 2.3 million shares of Communication Cable, based in Sanford, N.C. Kuhlman first made a bid for Communication Cable in November and later sweetened its offer twice after Pentair made higher bids. Kuhlman's final $14-a-share bid is 17 percent higher than its original offer of $12.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CRAY RESEARCH SELLS PRINTED CIRCUIT BOARD PLANT
description: Cray Research Inc. said yesterday that it had sold its printed circuit board plant in Chippewa Falls, Wis., to Johnson Matthey P.L.C. of London for $40 million. Johnson Matthey will provide Cray Research with high-performance printed circuit boards from the plant, which Johnson Matthey plans to expand to supply other customers. The sale is part of Cray's plan to cut expenses. Cray, based in Eagan, Minn., said that the plant was not operating up to capacity and that the Johnson Matthey sale and supply agreement would drive down the amount Cray spent on printed circuit boards.

title: Judge Tells F.E.C. to Prove PAC Suit
description: A judge has told the Federal Election Commission to bring more proof to court if its lawsuit against the political action committee formerly headed by Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich is to remain alive.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Lloyds TSB Profit Falls
description: Lloyds TSB Group P.L.C., Britain's largest domestic bank, said yesterday that its pretax profit dropped 7.9 percent in 1995. A charge of L425 million for the merger of Lloyds Bank and TSB Group P.L.C. last year offset the benefits of surging earnings and restrained costs. Excluding the reorganization charge, Lloyds TBS profit rose 15 percent, to L2.08 billion ($3.20 billion), from L1.79 billion in 1994. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;Seeking a Defining Moment, Candidates Are at a Loss for Words
description: And here's my little dog, Leader," said Senator Bob Dole, suddenly proferring family pictures to a rival during the nationally televised Republicans' debate.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Peter Graf to Stay in Jail
description: PETER GRAF, taken into custody six months ago to keep him from fleeing a tax evasion investigation, will remain jailed, a German court ruled yesterday. STEFFI GRAF's father, 57, was arrested Aug. 2 for allegedly failing to pay taxes on up to $27 million of his daughter's tennis earnings. He is jailed in Mannheim. The state high court was required to review Graf's status after six months in confinement. Graf has to remain jailed because he is the prime suspect in the tax evasion case and might try to flee if released, a court spokesman said. (AP)

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.B.A.;Union Post for English
description: The former National Basketball Association star ALEX ENGLISH was appointed interim executive director of the N.B.A. Players Association on Thursday while the union continues its search for a new leader. English, who played for Milwaukee, Indiana and Denver from 1976-91, was the National Basketball Association's leading scorer in the 1980's and an eight-time All-Star. He is a former president of the Players Association. The union dismissed SIMON GOURDINE as executive director last month. (AP)

title: Alabama Executes Killer
description: A man was executed in the electric chair early today for helping to abduct, sexually assault and kill a teen-age girl 19 years ago.

title: Diaz Resigns From Police Complaint Board
description: A Bronx minister who has been widely denounced for anti-gay remarks resigned from the city's Civilian Complaint Review Board yesterday, a day after he was accused of pressuring a man in a polling place to vote for his son in a special election for a State Assembly seat.

title: POLITICS: THE ROUNDUP;Toward Bitter End in New Hampshire, Candidates' Favorite Issue Is Each Other
description: Rolling off their contentious televised debate, the Republican Presidential contenders took their quarrels over trade, taxes and negative commercials to the streets and airwaves of New Hampshire today, as their increasingly bitter contest entered its final weekend.

title: HOCKEY;Devils Tie Sabres, But Lose Broten
description: The Devils, desperate for points, used Scott Stevens tonight against the Buffalo Sabres even though the captain has a fractured right cheekbone and a damaged nerve on the right side of his face.

title: Health Plan in Cutbacks
description: Community Health Plan is eliminating 82 administrative jobs in an effort to hold down costs, officials announced on Thursday. The health maintenance organization, which serves residents in 27 New York counties as well as areas of Vermont and western Massachusetts, is also telling its managers to freeze hiring and salaries for 1996. The organization has more than 396,000 members with annual revenue in 1994 that exceeded $460 million.

title: News Summary
description: Internationa l2-5

title: Aqueduct Card Is Canceled
description: Even before snow fell yesterday, the racing program was called off at Aqueduct.

title: 12 Killed in Fiery Amtrak Collision in Near Washington
description: A Chicago-bound Amtrak train creeping through a snowstorm smashed into a local train just outside Washington yesterday afternoon in a fiery crash that left commuter coaches crumpled like accordians. Twelve people were killed and more than 20 were injured, officials said.
