title: Prudential in Talks on Accusations Some Customers Were Misled
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America said yesterday that it was in talks with a task force of state regulators to settle accusations that its agents misled customers in at least 28 states.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Jets Waste No Time Wooing O'Donnell
description: The Jets made another positive move to burnish their tarnished image yesterday when they telephoned Neil O'Donnell's agent to discuss the possibility of the Super Bowl quarterback joining the team.

title: With Fare Up, Subway Use Drops Sharply
description: After years of working to make New York City's subways cleaner, safer and faster, the Transit Authority reported yesterday that subway ridership in 1995 reached its highest level in 21 years, but then began a sharp decline after the November fare increase.

title: Shell Remains Silent on Nigeria Abuses;U.S. Stalling
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Stocks Retreat From Rally

title: Holiday Closings
description: All financial and commodity markets and banks in the United States will be closed on Monday in observance of Washington's Birthday. Most overseas markets will be open.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Sports Authority Cuts Budget
description: Citing declining revenues and the costs of negotiating new leases to keep the Nets and Devils from moving out of state, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority cut its 1996 budget yesterday by nearly $1 million, The Associated Press reported. Staff will be reduced through attrition, and some expenses will be cut, the authority said.

title: Rig Count Up to 707
description: The number of oil and gas rigs operating in the United States jumped by 12 this week, to 707, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. There were 724 rigs operating nationwide a year ago. Of the rigs running this week, 417 were exploring for natural gas and 285 for oil. Five rigs were listed as miscellaneous. The rig count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil or natural gas.

title: Bias Affronts All
description: To the Editor:

title: Shell Remains Silent on Nigeria Abuses;Ogoni Movement
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Presses Ouster of Abuse Case Judge
description: For the third consecutive day, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani criticized a Brooklyn judge, Lorin Duckman, yesterday over his handling of a domestic violence case in which a woman was killed, saying Judge Duckman should be removed from the bench as soon as possible.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: COMPANY NEWS;CYLINK SHARES UP SHARPLY IN FIRST DAY OF TRADING
description: Shares of the Cylink Corporation soared yesterday on the company's first day of trading. Five million shares of the company, which supplies computer network security products, were sold to investors for $15 each yesterday in the company's initial public offering. The stock closed at $22.50, after trading as high as $28 on the Nasdaq stock market. Almost 5.2 million shares traded. Cylink, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., had expected the shares to be sold for $12 to $14 each. The size of the offering was increased from the originally planned 4.3 million shares, which had been expected to bring $8 to $10 each.

title: Stocks Off Third Day in Row as Blue Chips Retreat 48.05
description: Pulling back from their record highs for the third straight day, stock prices fell yesterday on investor concern about declines in bond prices and fears that this year's rally had pushed values too high.

title: Hokies or UMass Will Lose Streak
description: Virginia Tech calls it the biggest basketball game in school history. The Hokies have won 17 straight at home and may be the lasp roadblock in top-ranked Massachusetts' pursuit of perfection.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.B.A.;No. 11 to Be Retired
description: ISIAH THOMAS will have his No. 11 jersey retired by the Detroit Pistons at the Palace of Auburn Hills tonight, when the Pistons play the Toronto Raptors. During his 13 seasons with the Pistons, Thomas led Detroit to back-to back championships (1989-1990) and he was an All-Star every season. Thomas, 34, a vice president and part owner of the Raptors, still holds the record for most points scored during one quarter in the finals (25 points).

title: POLITICS: THE ELECTORATE;Some See CLinton as Voctor in G.O.P. Debate: 8 Rivals Left Viewers Unimpressed
description: Before the debate started, Bill Cote defined the stakes. For Bob Dole, he said, "it's on the line tonight because he did so badly in Iowa, and he looked so old answering the State of the Union."

title: COMPANY NEWS;DOMTAR TO SELL ITS DECORATIVE-PANELS BUSINESS
description: Domtar Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its North American decorative-panels business to Genstar Capital Partners II L.P. of Foster City, Calif., for $94 million. The Montreal-based Domtar said the sale would complete its exit from the building-materials business to focus on its forest-product operations. In November, the Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific Corporation agreed to buy Domtar's gypsum-wallboard business for $350 million. Genstar Capital is a closely held investment fund that concentrates on acquisitions of manufacturing and service businesses.

title: POLITICS: BOB DOLE;In His Own Words
description: Speaking at a Chamber of Commerce breakfast yesterday morning in Portsmouth, N.H.:

title: Claudia Inc.;A Model Seeking a Life After 30 Keeps an Eye on the Balance Sheet
description: Claudia Schiffer could be the real-life Barbie. Tall, long-legged, curvaceous, with flowing blond hair, a wholesome face -- and a wholesome life to match -- she doesn't drink, smoke or pose nude.

title: Italy Cannot Form Cabinet And Plans Elections in April
description: Confronted by the failure of Italy's leading parties to agree on constitutional reforms, President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro signed a decree tonight dissolving both houses of Parliament, thus setting the stage for general elections on April 21.

title: P.A. Must Move To Build Rail Tunnel
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO Links Bosnia Government To Training Center for Terrorists
description: Angry NATO officers said today that a building near Sarajevo that they raided on Thursday had been a terrorist training center, run with the connivance of the Bosnian Government.

title: BASEBALL;Vaughn and Red Sox Agree on a Rich Deal
description: A contract dispute that had Mo Vaughn talking about playing in New York two years from now ended yesterday when the Boston Red Sox and their multitalented first baseman settled their economic differences and agreed to a three-year, $18.6 million contract.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;New York Doctor Slain In Colombia by Gunmen
description: Gunmen killed a young doctor today, just weeks after the victim's father, an army general, resigned, citing his belief that accusations that President Ernesto Samper had accepted money from cocaine traffickers were credible.

title: Football Is Back
description: Siena College's lowly football team, canceled last month after posting only two victories in three seasons of Division I-AA, has been given a reprieve.

title: Snowstorms Keep Skiers Off the Slopes
description: This winter's abundant snowfall has been too much of a good thing on the weekends for ski resorts in the hills and mountains north and west of New York City, according to resort owners.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Backpack Ban Is Upheld
description: Saying that flouting school rules can lead to chaos, the State Education Commissioner, Leo Klagholz, ruled yesterday that a Bernards Township eighth grader must comply with her school's ban on carrying backpacks. The decision countered a recent ruling by a state administrative law judge, who had said that Elyse Meredith, 13, was correct in continuing to defy the school decision to prohibit backpacks as a safety hazard.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;6 Get Hall of Fame Niches
description: The pop music pioneer Les Paul, of Mahwah, was among the new inductees to the New Jersey Inventors Hall of Fame at ceremonies Thursday night. In the early 1950's, Mr. Paul contributed to the development of the electric guitar and multitrack tape recording. The other living new inductee to the Hall was N. Joseph Woodland, of Raleigh, N.C., formerly of Ventnor, who invented the bar-code identification system. Four dead New Jersey inventors were also inducted: Harry F. Olson (1901-1982), for innovations in microphones; Charles Frederick Wallace (1885-1964), who developed a standard process for chlorinating water; Richard Dehmel (1904-1992), inventor of the flight simulator, and Arnold J. (Red) Morway (1906-1985), a developer of industrial lubricants.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Comsat's Operating Net Falls; A Revamping Is Considered
description: The Comsat Corporation, the satellite communications company that has in recent years moved into professional sports and entertainment, reported today that its operating profit plunged by one-third in the fourth quarter and said that it had hired an investment bank to look at a possible revamping.

title: Whitman Undergoes Surgery on Shoulder
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman underwent successful surgery on her right shoulder this morning to repair a damaged rotator cuff that has plagued her for more than a year.

title: Americorps Volunteers Save on Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: McLean Stevenson Dies at 66; Star of TV's 'M*A*S*H' Series
description: McLean Stevenson, who played the amiable, slipshod Lieut. Col. Henry Blake on the television series "M*A*S*H" for three seasons, died on Thursday at the Tarzana Regional Medical Center in Tarzana, Calif., near Los Angeles. He was 66.

title: Wonderland, Shmonderland: L.I. Has Had It With Winter
description: Whatever charm today's snowfall might have had was lost on the people of Franklin Avenue here, where the consensus, was somewhat akin to, "Give it a rest."

title: New Bid May Undo Deal for Manhattan Site
description: Less than a month after Bear, Stearns & Company contracted to buy an entire block in midtown Manhattan, a co-owner of the property, the al-Babtain family of Saudi Arabia, announced plans yesterday to acquire the site for itself.

title: Defining 'Army': Who Is a Croatian Croat? Who Is a Bosnian Croat?
description: When the Croatian Army officially withdrew from this village on Jan. 23, it was replaced by about two dozen soldiers who declared that they are members of the military police from the army formed by Bosnian Croats and that they have no connection with the army of Croatia.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about the actor Martin Balsam omitted a survivor. She is Mr. Balsam's companion, Renee Landau.

title: How Colleges Gain on Early Admissions
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: RICHARD LUGAR;Low-Key Entry in Wait For Others to Destruct
description: Joey Siu was puzzling over a newfangled piece of hardware at a General Electric factory near here when a courtly gentleman strode up and uttered a few greetings that got lost in the industrial babel. Mr. Siu did not know who the man was, but he was wearing a blue suit, so Mr. Siu assumed he was important.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about discussions by the four broadcast television networks on a rating system for the violence and sexual content of programs misstated the date of a meeting to which network chief executives had been invited by President Clinton. It is Feb. 29, not Feb. 28.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Woman Flees Abusive Spouse With Courage and Some Help
description: The courtship that began at a nightclub continued beyond the altar.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a lawsuit by the family of a doctor who was murdered at Bellevue Hospital in 1989 misstated the given name of the assistant corporation counsel representing New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation, the defendant in the suit. He is Joshua Pollack, not Jeff.

title: NASA Delays Launching
description: Equipment trouble forced NASA to delay today the launching of a spacecraft intended to fly to an asteroid.

title: Film Crew Member Is Said To Save Child From Fire
description: A film crew member is being credited with saving a 4-year-old boy whose younger brother and sister died in a three-alarm fire in their apartment house here Thursday night.

title: Schools Under Siege
description: A day after the Democratic leaders of the State Assembly proposed the abolishing of New York City's Board of Education and its 32 community school boards, more than a few elected officials spoke yesterday almost mystically, as if they could foresee the first revamping of the nation's largest school system since the 1960's.

title: P.A. Must Move To Build Rail Tunnel
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC REVIEW;How a Staging Evolves, Like 'Madama Butterfly'
description: The Metropolitan Opera's current production of "Madama Butterfly," which has returned to the repertory, is a study in the way stagings evolve at the house these days.

title: Observer;Celebrity And Sausage
description: After paying a soap-opera star a million or so to write some novels, the Random House publishing people sued to make her give it back. Said the stuff she turned in wasn't quality, and otherwise heaped contumely on her authorial reputation.

title: Cuttings;Florescent Lights and Vivaldi Keep Seeds Happy
description: Even if you're growing only a single pot of leeks (Otina, a French variety so mild it can be pulled pencil-thin for salads) or your favorite tomato (Black Prince) or an unusual climber with green flowers (Hablitzia tamnoides, from the Caucasus), it's a spring ritual to start your own seeds.

title: Ernst Weber, 94, Who Oversaw Polytechnic University's Growth
description: Dr. Ernst Weber, an electrical engineer who helped turn the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn into one of the nation's foremost science-engineering centers, Polytechnic University, died on Thursday at the Tryon Estates retirement community in Columbus, N.C. He was 94 and had moved from Mount Vernon, N.Y., 25 years ago.

title: Elizabeth McCall Cain, Socialite, 76
description: Elizabeth McCall Cain, a figure in Manhattan's social world who was active in arranging benefits for educational and cultural institutions, died on Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital. She was 76 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Religion Journal;In Fight Against Bigotry, Good News in a Bad Time
description: In religion, as in other areas of American life, any sign of a decline in bigotry is something to cheer.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Industrial Output Plunges, With Bad Weather Cited
description: Output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities took its biggest plunge in January since the nation was struggling to emerge from the last recession nearly five years ago, a Government report showed today. But bad weather was cited as a major factor.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Game 4 of the chess match between Gary Kasparov and the computer Deep Blue misstated the time used by the machine. It was 1 hour 59 minutes, not under an hour.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;In 'Winterreise,' the Notes, Yes, but Also a Story to Tell
description: It is in no way adequate to say that the superb Austrian baritone Wolfgang Holzmair sang Schubert's song cycle "Die Winterreise" on Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall. In truth, he inhabited it. Vocally and dramatically, Mr. Holzmair trod every painful step of Schubert's lovelorn winter journey, arriving finally at the desolate "Leiermann" with scarcely a trace of color or emotion.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Dial Corporation's decision to split into two companies misstated the affiliation of Scott Graham, a securities analyst. He works for the brokerage firm of Oppenheimer & Company, not Paine Webber Inc.

title: On Riverside South, It's Time to Break Ground
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET REVIEW;A Leaping, Speeding Continuum
description: Anyone who has seen David Parsons's enormously popular modern-dance troupe in the last 10 years knows that Mr. Parsons specializes in keeping dancers on the move.

title: Agency's Head Assails Abuse Case Work
description: The head of the city's child protection agency, now legally empowered to publicly discuss its cases, released a preliminary, but sharply critical report yesterday on how the agency handled the case of an 11-year-old Brooklyn boy whom prosecutors allege was brutally beaten by his father.

title: Refiner to Buy Circle K Stores In Expansion
description: The Tosco Corporation, a large independent petroleum refiner, took a big plunge into retailing gasoline yesterday, announcing that it had agreed to acquire the Circle K Corporation in a deal worth at least $710 million.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;School Gets Gift of $500,000
description: A retired public elementary school teacher who insists on remaining anonymous is donating $500,000 to Rowan College's School of Education, college officials said. The woman is an alumna of Rowan, which was formerly Glassboro State College. The school changed its name in 1992 after the New Jersey industrialist Henry M. Rowan gave it $100 million -- the largest donation made to a public college.

title: Ms. Ciller Troubles the Waters
description: Greek and Turkish nationalist hotheads were equally to blame for the two countries' near war over some uninhabited Aegean rocks last month. But Athens and Ankara have followed sharply different courses since President Clinton's personal telephone diplomacy persuaded both sides to withdraw their flags and forces.

title: Shell Remains Silent on Nigeria Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathryn M. Hemphill, Golfer, 84
description: Kathryn Marie Hemphill, a top golfer in the 1930's and 40's, died on Wednesday. She was 84.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Rosario Green, the newly appointed coordinator for women's issues at the United Nations, misstated the date on which another senior United Nations official, Sylvana Foa, became the organization's chief spokeswoman. It was Jan. 1, not this month.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;A Memoir of Glen Tetley, Man of Dance
description: In "Glen Tetley: A Profile," which is being broadcast tomorrow night at 11 on Channel 13, Michael Blackwood has created a documentary as understated and thoughtful as Mr. Tetley himself. A tremendous amount of information is packed into this portrait of the internationally known American choreographer, whose work has been performed in New York City by American Ballet Theater. His life and 50 years of performing and choreographing unfold in a single hour, together with a judicious sprinkling of reminiscences that give a sense of the worlds in which Mr. Tetley grew as an artist.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Capriati Accepts Berth
description: After an aborted comeback attempt in Paris, JENNIFER CAPRIATI yesterday accepted a wild-card invitation to play in Essen, Germany, next week. Capriati was scheduled to play her first tournament since November 1994 at this week's Paris Open. Minutes before she was set to play, she withdrew because of a pulled muscle she sustained in practice earlier that day. (AP)

title: I Want My HDTV
description: After an eight-year cooperative effort between the Government and industry, the United States leads the world in the development of digital high-definition television.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Report Recommends Breakup of N.T.T.
description: A Japanese subcommittee responsible for drafting a report on the future of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation recommended that the telecommunications giant be broken up in the year ending March 31, 1999, an official at the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications said yesterday.

title: Gerhard Dessauer, Physicist, Dies at 85; Worked on A-Bomb
description: Dr. Gerhard Dessauer, a nuclear physicist who worked on the Manhattan Project developing the atomic bomb and at the Bikini Atoll test site before pursuing a career at E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, died on Sunday at his home in Savannah, Ga. He was 85.

title: About New York;Zoning Forbids Wide Variety And Low Price
description: EACH weekend, hungry hunter-gatherers venture forth from the city, climbing hills and crossing rivers, eventually returning in triumph with meat and vegetables. Plus a few humongous boxes of corn flakes or Pampers.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;BET Rejects Rentokil Offer
description: Rentokil Group P.L.C. said yesterday that its takeover bid for BET P.L.C., totaled L1.8 billion ($2.77 billion), but BET, a business services company, quickly rejected the offer. Rentokil disclosed its offer one day after BET said that Rentokil had approached it. Rentokil's offer criticized BET's management for poor earnings growth even after embarking upon a three-year turnaround project in 1991. A deal would combine Rentokil's bug-killing, plant-watering, office-cleaning and guarding companies with BET's guards and personnel services.

title: POP REVIEW;Mirror, Mirror, Who's That Narcissist?
description: The Time played Tramps on Tuesday night with all the equipment of a hard-working funk band: drums, keyboards, bass and guitar. Its definitive prop, however, was silent; a mirror that Jerome Benton held up to a preening Morris Day. In the Time's early-1980's heyday, when the Minneapolis band was endorsed by Prince, Mr. Day made himself funk's ultimate narcissist, showing off his wardrobe and admiring himself as he lamented, "Gigolos get lonely, too." He cheerfully parodied an image that, a decade later, gangsta rappers would attempt to project as real.

title: Deborah Henry, 44, Broadway Dancer
description: Deborah Henry, a Broadway dancer who appeared in "A Chorus Line" and in a number of touring musicals, died on Feb. 5 at her family's home in Memphis. She was 44 and lived in Union City, N.J.

title: POP REVIEW;Rap Group Is of 2 Minds, One Brainy and One Not
description: Cypress Hill, the top-selling Los Angeles rap band that has made a career of marijuana advocacy, was a jumble of contradictions when it performed on Thursday night at the Palladium. In "Insane in the Brain," it roused its audience with chants of "Is everybody insane right now?" After concertgoers affirmed that their brains were indeed mush, the band dedicated its next song to the "strong-minded" and proclaimed that there better be no weak-minded people in the crowd.

title: POLITICS: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN;Some See Clinton as Voctor in G.O.P. Debate: Buchanan, Beset by Many Critics, Still Unbowed
description: Patrick J. Buchanan's toughest opponent in the Republican Presidential campaign here in New Hampshire may well be himself. Columns, comments and acquaintanceships, past and present, seem to be rising against him.

title: MARATHON;Marathoners May Face Chill Today
description: If the hilly course for the Olympic marathon trials on Saturday will mimic the Summer Games in Atlanta, the weather most decidedly will not.

title: A Professor Helps Smithsonian Catch The Curator-Thief
description: Wearing a small tape recorder-transmitter under his tweed jacket, the Michigan college teacher slipped through the crowds at the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum, the showcase of historic aircraft, rockets and flight memorabilia here that the Smithsonian says is the most visited museum in the world.

title: Chess Computer Turns Down A Chance to Draw and Loses
description: Audaciously refusing a draw offer, the powerful I.B.M. computer Deep Blue went on to bungle an even position yesterday and lose Game 5 of its exhibition match with the world champion, Garry Kasparov, at the Philadelphia Convention Center.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;The Good News on Mexico: It's Bad but It Was Worse
description: These days in Mexico, when the Government announces that the economy shrank by 6.6 percent in the fourth quarter of 1995, it is considered good news.

title: Fearing Reprisal, Publisher Drops Book on Greece
description: Anastasia Karakasidou's first book, a 300-page study of ethnicity and identity in the northern Greek province of Macedonia, seemed poised for publication after surviving months of grueling academic review at Cambridge University Press and winning high praise from academic specialists for its insights and fairness.

title: HOCKEY;Robitaille Answers Rumors With Goals
description: Al Davis would have been proud if he had heard Luc Robitaille's reasoning on how to prevent a trade.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Unichem Raises Bid For Lloyds Chemists
description: Unichem P.L.C. raised its offer yesterday for the drugstore chain Lloyds Chemists P.L.C., topping a rival bid by Gehe A.G., a German drug wholesaler, by 5.6 percent. The new Unichem offer values Lloyds Chemists at L617 million ($949 million). Gehe's bid totals L584.3 million, but the company said it was considering increasing its offer.

title: Sports of The Times;Cool Papa Is Anointed By Wheaties
description: IN front of 60 captivated listeners, Connie Brooks told the story yesterday about how she and Cool Papa Bell sat in the kitchen of their St. Louis home over breakfast one morning and let their imaginations soar. At least she did.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TURNER BROADCASTING APPROVES SPORTS CHANNEL
description: As expected, the board of the Turner Broadcasting System Inc. approved plans yesterday to create a round-the-clock sports cable channel this year. The channel, to be called CNN/SI, will be a partnership between Turner's cable news channel CNN and Sports Illustrated, the magazine owned by Time Warner Inc. The new network will broadcast sports news, not live sports events. The new channel will be based in Atlanta, Turner's home, and will begin broadcasts in December. The channel would be a product of the proposed merger of Atlanta-based Turner and Time Warner. Time Warner agreed in September to take over Turner in a $7.5 billion deal, which is still being reviewed by Federal regulators.

title: Official Urges That Inquiry Into Shooting Be Free of Bias
description: The president of the Paterson branch of the N.A.A.C.P. urged today that an "independent" voice be involved in the investigation of the fatal shooting of a black man by a white police officer this week.

title: Howard Johnson Hotels Changing Color
description: HFS Inc.'s Howard Johnson hotel group said this week that it would require franchisees to upgrade their properties, which may include getting rid of the hotels' distinctive orange roofs. HFS, the world's largest hotel and real estate brokerage franchisor, said the upgrading included a new sign with a bright blue background and a rating system that designates properties as either full-service hotels or limited-service inns.

title: Tales of Horror From Last of the Subway Victims
description: For the first time at his three-week-old-trial, Edward J. Leary appeared to be shaken yesterday, as he heard a 14-year-old boy and a 39-year-old woman describe the subway firebombings that left them permanently wounded -- their faces scarred, their legs weakened, their memories haunted.

title: BASEBALL;Perez May Become Odd Man Out
description: Poor Melido Perez. He inexplicably missed the first workout for pitchers and catchers on Thursday, so he is already behind on the Yankees' spring training news. He might also be shocked after some pertinent information about the starting rotation finally reaches him.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Du Barry Was No Lady, In 1939 or Even Today
description: One of the roughest books that ever headed uptown from Minsky," Brooks Atkinson wrote in these pages 56 years ago. The subject was the last musical to open on Broadway in the 1930's, and he wasn't alone in finding a glaring blue streak in the production. The New Yorker dismissed a show-stopping duet as mere "dirt without wit."

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;A Reunion for the Life-as-Art Set
description: Is "The Real World" real? No, says Heather, one of the most articulate participants in the MTV series, "real people pay rent." And that cuts to the heart of the television matter.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN WATER WORKS IN PENNSYLVANIA ACQUISITION
description: The American Water Works Company has acquired waterworks, reservoirs and land from Pennsylvania Enterprises Inc. for $409 million, the two companies said yesterday. With the purchase, an American Water Works subsidiary, the Pennsylvania-American Water Company, will supply another 400,000 people in northeastern Pennsylvania, including the cities of Scranton and Wilkes-Barre. The purchase includes 10 water treatment plants, 36 reservoirs and about 8,000 acres of watershed land. American Water Works, based in Voorhees, N.J., said it was the biggest asset sale in the history of the water utility business in the United States.

title: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;With a Commercial Crossfire, G.O.P. Race Stays Negative
description: After complaining for weeks that he had been a victim of negative advertising, Senator Bob Dole has introduced a pair of blistering new commercials directed at his leading opponents.

title: Clinton Points to Competition As Way of Curbing Inflation
description: Wading deeper into the campaign debate over economic growth, President Clinton said today that "a lot of people" now believe that global competition can help hold down inflation, lessening the need for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.

title: David Rae Smith, 65, City Opera Baritone
description: David Rae Smith, a baritone with the New York City Opera since 1962, died on Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 65.

title: New York 2020
description: It is the year 2020 and residents of the once vibrant New York region are stuck in apartments they cannot unload in crumbling urban centers. Suburbanites are faring no better. This is one bleak scenario presented in "A Region at Risk," a five-year study by the Regional Plan Association.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.B.A.;Gill's Hand Surgery Is Called Successful
description: KENDALL GILL had three pins inserted into his broken left hand yesterday and the prognosis is for a full recovery. Gill had the surgery at NYU Medical Center in Manhattan and he will have to wear a cast for the next four weeks, GARY SUSSMAN, a Nets spokesman, said.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Hewlett's Shares Surge on Strength of Earnings Report
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that its earnings spurted 31 percent in the latest quarter. The increase was far bigger than expected and sent the company's shares soaring nearly 10.5 percent on a day when the broad market fell back.

title: The Whitewater Paper Chase
description: The excitement of Iowa and New Hampshire has diverted attention from the Senate Whitewater Committee and its investigation into the Rose Law Firm's migrating files. Naturally this pleases the White House and its allies, who hope to use the interregnum to let their "so what" arguments take root. David Kendall, the Clintons' private attorney, says that the curious paper trail is just "one of the meaningless mysteries of Whitewater."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Fund's Acquisition
description: Edinburgh Fund Managers said yesterday that it would buy Dunedin Fund Managers for L83.3 million ($127 million), doubling its assets under management and making it the second-largest fund manager in Scotland. The takeover of Dunedin and its 150 employees will increase funds of Edinburgh Fund Managers under management to more than L8.2 billion and raise its share of the British unit trust industry to about 8 percent. Edinburgh beat out a rival Scottish fund manager, Ivory & Sime P.L.C., for Dunedin. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL;Player Has Amnesia
description: Five days after being elbowed in the jaw, Penn State center STACEY HRIVNAK is suffering from amnesia and still doesn't recognize her parents, teammates or coach. "She knows only what we tell her," Coach RENE PORTLAND said. "At this time, the kid's in trouble."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Swan Killer's Punishment
description: A Wayne teen-ager convicted of taking part in the stoning death of a swan on Packanack Lake last July is "going to shovel a lot of manure," said Superior Court Judge Edward Gannon, who sentenced the youth to 100 hours of community service at the Passaic County Sheriff's Department stable. The male swan was killed while trying to protect his mate and their five offspring.

title: Britain Errs on Saudi
description: To the Editor:

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Washington's Birthday, which is Feb. 22, will be observed on Monday.

title: World News Briefs;Agronomist Is Selected As Haiti's Prime Minister
description: President Rene Preval today appointed an agricultural economist, Rony Smarth, to be Prime Minister.

title: Both Sides See Victory in Shareholder Vote on RJR Nabisco Spinoff
description: The squabble between the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation and the investors Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn took a strange turn yesterday as the company announced that it had won, by a narrow margin, a nonbinding shareholder vote on the desirability of a rapid spinoff of the company's food business from its tobacco operations.

title: Region's Governors Draw Own Blueprint for Welfare
description: A single mother with two children getting by on a $577 monthly welfare check in New York City would, under Gov. George E. Pataki's new welfare plan, have her cash benefits reduced to $424 and be forced off the rolls within five years.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VENTURE STORES EXPECTS SURPRISINGLY HIGH PROFITS
description: Venture Stores Inc., a general merchandise discount store chain, said yesterday that it expected surprisingly strong fourth-quarter profits. The stock rose $1.625, or more than 44 percent, to $5.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Earlier this month Venture Stores announced plans to close 10 struggling stores and cut 390 sales support jobs. Venture, based in O'Fallon, Mo., said it expected to report profits of $24.7 million to $25.9 million, or $1.42 to $1.49 a share, in the quarter ended Jan. 27. This excludes an after-tax charge of $20.8 million, or 78 cents a share, to pay for the restructuring.

title: Charges in 1974 Killing Raise Tensions in Chile
description: For two decades, Sofia and Maria Angelica Prats have tried to determine who was responsible for the bombing in 1974 that killed their father, Gen. Carlos Prats Gonzalez, a former Chilean Army commander who opposed the military coup led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: Denatured
description: THE VALUE OF LIFE Biological Diversity and Human Society. By Stephen R. Kellert. 263 pp. Washington: Island Press/Shearwater Books. $24.95.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;Fewer Patrols in 24th Precinct
description: For months, residents of the 24th Precinct, which is bordered on the south by 86th Street, and covers the northern Upper West Side and Manhattan Valley, have noticed that there seemed to be fewer police officers around. The recent shooting of 9-year-old John Paul Valentine on his way to Public School 145, on West 105th Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, brought the issue painfully to the fore. Most residents thought, mistakenly, that officers had been assigned to insure safe passage for the school's pupils.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: A WORKING MOTHER By Agnes Owens. Bloomsbury/Trafalgar Square, $17.95.

title: Creature Features
description: THE RAREST OF THE RARE Vanishing Animals, Timeless Worlds. By Diane Ackerman. 184 pp. New York: Random House. $23. MONK seals, short-tailed albatrosses, golden lion tamarins and monarch butterflies do not realize how lucky they are to have the indomitable Diane Ackerman as their advocate. After reading "The Rarest of the Rare," a collection of essays about these disappearing species (some of the pieces were originally published in Life, National Geographic, Parade, Cond Nast Traveler and The New Yorker), this reader was left wondering which was more impressive, Ms. Ackerman's meticulous prose or her intrepid spirit in seeking out her subjects in their respective habitats, whether rain forest, wind-swept islands or underwater caves.

title: BASEBALL;For Howe, Resentment Lingers Over Treatment
description: Steve Howe leaned against a cinder-block wall a few feet from the manager's office at Legends Field this morning. The office has a new inhabitant in Joe Torre, and his presence made the pitcher gleeful.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: TIME ON FIRE My Comedy of Terrors. By Evan Handler. Little, Brown, $21.95.

title: Don't Give Me Fahrenheit; Tell Me How It Feels
description: I spent most of my childhood just north of Oshkosh, Wis., a city we saw as a center of cosmopolitan sophistication, in a town called Neenah, where winter was winter. Deep snows and sub-zero temperatures were a routine part of life. And when the weatherman reported that it was 20 or 30 degrees below zero, we suited up like astronauts and put on ski masks like bank robbers -- no skin exposed, period.

title: Burning Happiness
description: THE DIARIES OF SYLVIA TOWNSEND WARNER Edited by Claire Harman. 384 pp. North Pomfret, Vt.: Virago/Trafalgar Square. Paper, $19.95.

title: For Arts Audiences, the Question Is Relevance
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 7 of the Arts and Leisure section today about an exhibition in London on Sergei Diaghilev and the Ballets Russes misstates the date and the place of the troupe's founding. Diaghilev established the Ballets Russes in 1909, not 1911 -- in Paris, not St. Petersburg; the company never performed in Russia.

title: DANCE;Brazilian Dance Goes to Its Roots: Africa
description: ONE MINUTE TO SHOW TIME. The dancers of the Bale Folclorico da Bahia -- regal in straw and sabers, bells and miles of tulle -- represent the African gods that came with blacks brought here as slaves. Soon the deities will swagger and swirl and flicker like flames, but now they join hands in a circle and lower their heads. "Our Father, wh' art in heaven," they begin.

title: World News Briefs;U.N. Group Tries to Stem Ebola Outbreak in Gabon
description: Health officials said today that they are hoping that a vast public information campaign in Gabon can head off a lethal Ebola epidemic after 10 people died in the West African country this week.

title: Crime
description: John Marshall Tanner isn't happy unless he's miserable -- an exemplary quality in a private detective. In FLESH WOUNDS (Scribner, $22), the broody hero of Stephen Greenleaf's first-class noir series gives himself the masochistic pleasure of going to Seattle to do a job for an old flame. Although Tanner is still in love with this woman, he agrees to search for her fianc's missing daughter, a stunning figure model who has run afoul of an exploitative photographer described as "a carnivore."

title: For Arts Audiences, the Question Is Relevance;Making Music
description: To the Editor:

title: In Louisiana, Card Game Reveals the Cajun Spirit
description: The 68-year-old man in the robin's-egg-blue three-piece suit eased a long, thin cigar out of his wrinkled face and reflected on the best hand of bourre he had ever played. It was not in Acadian Louisiana, where the card game was born on the bank of the bayou, but in an officer's club at a United States Air Force base in chilly Newfoundland.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Terminal's Hideaways

title: The Last Blank Spot On the Map
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Federal Funds for a Farmingdale Project;An 1896 L.I.R.R. Station Restoration
description: Restoration is to begin next April on the century-old Farmingdale station of the Long Island Rail Road, which is on the National Register of Historic Places. The station's original section dates to 1896, but an extension housing electrical equipment was added in 1910 when the station also became a stop on a trolley line between Halesite-Huntington and Amityville.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;Mehl Plans to Retire
description: LEO MEHL, Goodyear's worldwide director of racing and one of the most influential figures in motor sports, will retire after March 1. Although his company's tires dominate the sport, Mehl, 59, sat in his office at the Daytona International Speedway yesterday, recalled a different era.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Robert J. Sternberg;Intelligence in All Its Interactive Aspects
description: ROBERT J. STERNBERG, 46, who is IBM Professor of Psychology and Education Psychology at Yale University, got his undergraduate degree at Yale, his Ph.D. at Stanford, then returned to Yale, where he has been ever since.

title: People's Banks' Help Rescue Poor Indonesians
description: Sunlight squeezed through the woven rattan walls of Ibu Pesur's hut as she sat on its earthen floor whipping a wooden shuttlecock back and forth on a rough-hewn loom. Unfurling before her stretched a panel of fabric, a chromatic splash against the dull dirt floor.

title: Bosnia to Deport 2 Iranians Caught in a Raid by NATO
description: Two Iranian instructors picked up at a suspected terrorist training camp on Thursday will not face charges, NATO officials said today.

title: NEWT'S FIERCEST FIGHT
description: Jason DeParle's article on Newt Gingrich is an excellent and objective report on a potentially great leader with core convictions ("Rant/ Listen, Exploit/Learn, Scare/ Help, Manipulate/Lead," Jan. 28). While the comparison to Winston Churchill is premature, it does have possibilities.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;'American Originals' At National Archives
description: The National Archives in Washington is featuring some of the most important American historical documents in a free exhibition called "American Originals." The rotating exhibition comprises about 50 original documents and photographs and will run through December 1998. In addition, the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution and the Bill of Rights are on permanent display in the Rotunda,

title: POLITICS: PARTY ISSUES;MANY REPUBLICANS FEAR PARTY RIFTS MAY COST ELECTION
description: Many prominent Republicans say they fear that the rancor in the Presidential contest has so magnified tensions among social and economic conservatives that the party risks unraveling much like the Democrats did in their failed efforts to win the Presidency in most of the 1970's and 1980's.

title: Unveiling the Panoramas of the Universe for Young Readers
description: Seymour Simon would like to be a golden plover for a day, soaring across the sky on its 12,000-mile migration from northern Alaska to southern Argentina and back.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOUGLASTON;After 40 Trees Are Flattened, Volunteers Donate a Virtual Forest
description: When Dan Donohue learned that someone driving a stolen Jeep had mowed down 29 saplings in Alley Pond Park -- the second such incident in a month -- he was furious. Then he turned his anger into action.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe for farfalle casserole on Feb. 4 omitted an ingredient. A corrected version appears today in the "In the Kitchen" column.

title: O'Donnell No Trump
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: George Trevelyan, Baronet, 89; Eclectic Proponent of 'New Age'
description: Sir George Trevelyan, a British baronet who was prominent in the New Age movement, died on Feb. 7 at 89. He had a home in Badminton, near Bristol, in western England.

title: CHINA: NEW YORK ... OR SINGAPORE?;The 21st Century Starts Here
description: It is better not to be in Shanghai during a heat wave. I was there during the first week in September when a heat wave struck, the hottest September day in 48 years: 87 degrees at night and as humid as a steam bath. Schools closed, as did many museums, which lacked air-conditioning. In one small museum, the former residence of Zhou Enlai, I was followed from room to room by an attendant with an electric fan. At night, in the old neighborhoods of Nantao, or what used to be the walled Chinese City, families slept in the streets, stretched out half naked on bamboo chairs.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: JURY DUTY By Laura Van Wormer. Crown, $24.

title: WEDDINGS;Toby Goldstein, Shmuel Brikman
description: Toby Goldstein, a daughter of Seema and Jacob Goldstein of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Shmuel Menachem Mendel Brikman, a son of Shalumith and Kalmen Brikman, also of Brooklyn. Rabbi Kalman Marlow, the head rabbi of Beth Din Lubavitch, a rabbinical court, performed the ceremony at Lubavitch World Headquarters in Brooklyn.

title: ART;A Family and Its Gallery Click on the Future
description: IT'S not surprising that the town that was home to Albert Einstein should have an art gallery well positioned in cyberspace. The Williams Gallery here has a home page and many artists who work with computers. But the director, Mary Lou Bock, takes the long view. For her, esthetics is the thing, not any innovative way that art is made. She shows traditional work alongside paintings and prints whose imagery is digitized, sometimes making pointed side-by-side comparisons. "But you get drawn in a direction," she says, referring to the lure of the World Wide Web.

title: A Struggle to Save a Shattered Legacy
description: The Rev. Marko Malovic, dressed in a brown Franciscan habit, parked his stocky frame in front of the semicircular wooden bookshelves that spiraled up along the heavy stone wall of a medieval church tower.

title: The Race for Russian President
description: Say this for the Russian presidential campaign -- it will be mercifully short. The race began in earnest last week, and four months from now, in June, Russians will vote. That may be the only good thing about an election season that seems likely to offer voters little enlightenment and an avalanche of shallow slogans and misguided promises that could stunt their country for years to come.

title: How Trinity Aims to Stay Competitive
description: FOR Edwin Robles, a 37-year-old Hartford police officer, the boarded-up, decaying Victorian brick house in the Frog Hollow neighborhood is a dream come true. "It's appealing to me because I like antique structures," he said. "It's part of Hartford's old past. And I want to be part of something good in the area."

title: LIVING TOO LONG
description: It is possible to experience oneself as "Living Too Long," as Michael Norman reports (Jan. 14). Contrary to the implication of his article, however, the relationship of that experience to age is quite loose. Pablo Picasso apparently did not feel that life was meaningless in his early 90's; nor did George Abbott at 100, at which age he received a prestigious medal from his alma mater, the University of Rochester.

title: North to Alaska
description: GOING TO THE SUN By James McManus. 342 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $23.

title: HOWARD STERN AND THE HIGHBROWS
description: Michiko Kakutani is to be commended for confronting the hypocrisy of the highbrows who condemn Howard Stern for sins less serious than their own (Culture Zone: "Howard Stern and the Highbrows," Jan. 28). However, she lapses into pop sociology when she laments that Stern is a "telling image of what our culture is rapidly becoming." Far from being a symptom of society's failures, Stern is our leading satirist. If he seems vulgar or obscene, so in fact were his predecessors -- Juvenal, Swift and Rabelais.

title: China: Jerry-built ... or built to last?;Boom-at-a-Glance
description: All the World's a Market Since China began its economic reform, its gross domestic product (G.D.P.), measured yuan, has grown nearly tenfold, from 447 billion yuan in 1980 to 4.4 trillion yuan in 1994. In U.S. dollars, the G.D.P. rose from $298 billion in 1980 to $508 billion in 1994. It is an economy that has far outstripped the competition. Here, a few significant G.D.P. growth rates (in percentages): In 1994, China's trade surplus was $5.2 billion. One of its best customers is the United States, whose trade deficit with China is fast becoming a rival of its better-known deficit with Japan.

title: AN ECONOMIC BASKET CASE;In North Korea the Threat is Total Collapse
description: JUST two years ago, the Clinton Administration's biggest fear about North Korea was its determination to develop nuclear weapons -- a determination that could have led to war with the South. That worry was allayed after North Korea promised not to pursue atomic weaponry, in exchange for help with more benign nuclear power plants. But now, the United States has a different worry -- that North Korea is in so much trouble economically that it could fall apart. Rather than eliminate a threat, a sudden collapse could touch off internal chaos, a flood of refugees and -- if things got truly desperate -- war with the South.

title: NEWS AND TOPICS;As Small Airports Struggle, Local Governments Start Investing
description: Like many small private airports in New Jersey, Lakewood Airport has been scraping by for years, making do with a taxiway that's pockmarked and gravelly, a beacon that hasn't worked for eight years and runway lights that flicker at 25 watts.

title: VIDEO VIEW;Film Scoring is an Art. Repeat, Film Scoring Is an Art.
description: JUST WHEN CLASSICAL record labels were searching for material that would yield greater profits than the mainstream repertory yet not seem crassly commercial, what should fall into their laps but the entire film-score business!

title: HOCKEY;Kings and Stars In 3-Man Trade
description: The Los Angeles Kings traded defenseman Darryl Sydor and a 1996 fifth-round draft pick to the Dallas Stars today for defenseman Doug Zmolek and right wing Shane Churla.

title: Also Inside
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 Blue-Collar Blues: As hockey gathers glitz at the Garden, class resentment boils in "Blue Heaven."

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: FABLES AND DISTANCES New and Selected Essays. By John Haines. Graywolf, $24.95.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;UMass Stays Unbeaten With Camby in Control
description: If there was going to be a snow-filled pothole along the road to an undefeated regular season for the University of Massachusetts, this was going to be the time and place. Virginia Tech had been waiting for this afternoon since it decided to move to the Atlantic 10 this season from the Metro Conference. The storm had forced the UMass itinerary to Plan B, a detour to Greensboro, N.C., late Thursday that disrupted the Minutemen's plans. A hostile crowd, a 10th-ranked opponent, a stressful trip.

title: February 11-17;What Next, Early Tuition?
description: Getting into Harvard, Princeton or Yale has never been easy. Now comes word that the odds for most applicants may be even worse than before. A growing number of top colleges in and out of the Ivy League are giving away many of the seats in their freshman classes before Christmas to applicants who apply by November, leaving significantly fewer slots for regular applicants in the spring.

title: A Jetway, Please
description: To the Editor: I recently returned from a trip to Israel. Leaving the United States, we entered the El Al Boeing 747-400 on a comfortable jetway. Going home from Ben-Gurion International Airport in Israel we had to climb three flights of stairs on a portable ramp to enter the aircraft.

title: Nerds' Revenge: A How-To Manual
description: IN August, the Netscape Communications Corporation held one of the most successful initial public stock offerings in Silicon Valley history. In a single day, the year-old company, with just $17 million in sales, was valued at more than $3 billion. And the stock kept climbing.

title: Crime Statistics on Web
description: Data on the nation's homicide and drug-use rates and other crime statistics are now available on the Internet computer system, the Justice Department said on Friday.

title: Kasparov Figures Out the Way: Slow Strangulation
description: Garry Kasparov used an old-fashioned mode of play yesterday to truss up most pitifully and then dispatch the I.B.M. computer Deep Blue in the final game of their match at the Philadelphia Convention Center.

title: Liberties;Memo: Be Ruthless
description: TO: Delegates to the Republican National Convention RE: The Next Revolution

title: THEATER;This Silent Man Has Playwrights as Groupies
description: DURING THE EARLY REHEARSALS OF "The Heidi Chronicles," the play that would eventually earn her a Pulitzer Prize, Wendy Wasserstein was tormented by doubt. Not over the play. Over what the director, Daniel Sullivan, really thought of it.

title: Mr. Darwin, the Cars Are Mutating
description: Evolve or die: It is as true in the automotive world as in a tropical jungle. And the evolution of the Honda species has proved, over the years, a prime example of natural selection.

title: Accused Trash Haulers Seek to Oust Prosecutor
description: In a counterattack against the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, a garbage-haulers' trade association is trying to have him disqualified as the prosecutor in a racketeering case against the group.

title: LOOKING AHEAD;Three Plans Later, How a Region Has (and Hasn't) Changed
description: When the Regional Plan Association introduced its third long-range plan for the metropolitan area last week, it sparked a debate among officials and civic leaders in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut about just how many of the goals were realistic. As the debate continues, it is likely to center on how successful the states were in adopting recommendations that the research group put forth in two previous reports, published in 1929 and in 1968.

title: Tax Efficiency Vs. High Returns
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;U.N. Chief to Propose Burundi Standby Force
description: Fearing an explosion of ethnic violence in Burundi similar to the killings that shook Rwanda in 1994, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali will call for the creation of a preventive force of up to 25,000 troops.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Jan. 28 about former Senator Ralph Yarborough of Texas referred incorrectly in some editions to the vote on the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by members of Congress from the South. Five Senators and, in the final vote, 12 Representatives from the South approved the measure; Senator Yarborough was not the only Southerner to vote for it.

title: Dentist Is Cleared at Trial
description: A jury concluded on Friday that a dentist did not give his patient the AIDS virus even though the dentist was found to have been negligent in the handling and cleaning of his instruments, a court official said.

title: POLITICS: THE OUTSIDER AS INSIDER;Forbes, Too, Can Play Politics Game
description: One August evening in 1993, Steve Forbes invited about 100 New Jersey municipal officials aboard his $14 million yacht, the Highlander. As the ship cruised down the Hudson River and past the Statue of Liberty, partygoers strolled the teak decks and enjoyed drinks and a buffet supper in the elegant staterooms.

title: JERSEY;On the Warpath Again, but Tactfully
description: SIX weeks into her retirement as Mayor of Oradell, Carolyn Hague looked restless in the sunny den of the house that she and her husband have shared since their marriage more than 50 years ago.

title: Clinton Backing Vast Effort To Restore Florida Swamps
description: President Clinton has decided to endorse a huge project to protect the Everglades by spending hundreds of millions of dollars to take farmland out of production and restore a more natural flow of fresh water across Florida's swampy southern half, according to senior Administration officials.

title: TELEVISION VIEW;'Friends' In High Places
description: WHAT DOES "FRIENDS" HAVE IN common with "Twin Peaks"? It's possible, though not likely, that one day Bob, the crazed "Twin Peaks" murderer, will crawl out of the past wearing a modified-shag Rachel haircut and order a double espresso at the friends' too cutely named hangout, Central Perk. The real answer to that riddle, though, is less bizarre and more illuminating. Like "Dallas" and "Twin Peaks," "Friends" has become an inescapable pop-culture phenomenon. The show is like a Bazooka-gum bubble blown to such gigantic size it belongs in the Guinness Book of World Records.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Riding the Retail Lane

title: Labor Leaders Say Union Is Rejoining A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: In a move that is expected to increase the political clout of one of New York's largest, most liberal unions, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is planning to announce on Tuesday that the city's main hospital workers' union will rejoin the labor federation after leaving it five years ago, union officials said.

title: AUTO RACING;Earnhardt Has It All, Except the Daytona 500
description: It is tempting to say that Dale Earnhardt could not come any closer to his first Daytona 500 victory without actually getting it. Tempting, that is, until you realize that he has only come as close as leading the race into Turn 3 of the final lap.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;3-Star Seething at Work Site
description: The name Arcadia may suggest pastoral peacefulness, but the atmosphere is anything but that at Anne Rosenzweig's three-star restaurant at 21 East 62d Street.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORYDeals and Discounts
description: TWO FOR THE ROUTE Two airlines starting Las Vegas service are planning special introductory fares. Delta is to start nightly nonstop service on April 1 to Las Vegas from Kennedy International Airport in New York with an introductory one-way fare of $79; early this month a spokesman for the carrier did not know how long the fare would be in effect. The flight is to depart New York at 11:50 P.M., arriving in Las Vegas at 2:15 A.M. The return flight is scheduled to leave at 10:25 P.M., landing at Kennedy at 6 the next morning. There are no advance-purchase requirements, and the fare is nonrefundable. Information: (212) 239-0700 or (800) 221-1212.

title: Revolutionary Thinking
description: John Patrick Diggins is a Distinguished Professor at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, where he teaches American history. He is the author of the forthcoming "Politics and the Spirit of Tragedy."

title: Spacecraft Is Off on 3-Year Voyage to Asteroid
description: The space agency launched a spacecraft today on a three-year voyage to an asteroid that may contain clues to the birth of the solar system.

title: Tokyo Apologizes on AIDS
description: Japan's Health Minister has apologized for the Government's failure to prevent transfusions of H.I.V.-infected blood in the early 1980's.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe for farfalle casserole on Feb. 4 omitted an ingredient. A corrected version appears today in the "In the Kitchen" column.

title: N.J. LAW;If a Spouse is Charged With Battering, Should a Judge or a Jury Decide?
description: In New Jersey, a woman who has been battered has more legal options than in many other states. She can get a restraining order against her partner at any time of day or night. She can obtain immediate financial relief so that she does not have to depend on her abuser. And often she can sue her partner in a jury trial for the damage he inflicted.

title: Chronicling Women Free of Men
description: WHEN THE DUTCH film "Antonia's Line," a gentle story about five generations of women directed by an outspoken feminist, was shown at the Cannes International Film Festival last spring, a gimmick was used to help it stand out among its competitors: only women could attend the first screening.

title: Drivers Seek Higher Speed In Michigan By Going Slow
description: A band of people gathered today at a highway rest stop here on the outskirts of Detroit to protest Michigan's speed-limit law by following it.

title: Bon Jovi's Latin Lyrics And a Churchgoer's Joy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Ratings Game At the Cineplex
description: THE TIME: A RECENT SATURDAY afternoon. The place: the Cross County Multiplex, a 10-screen theater with all-weather carpeting and a video-game nook featuring Tekken 2. The theater happens to be in Yonkers but could just as easily be in Any Burb, U.S.A.

title: Return to L.A.
description: DRIVING UNDER THE AFFLUENCE By Julia Phillips. 321 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $24.

title: Signs of an Invigorated Luxury Market in Chicago
description: The most exclusive block of downtown Chicago's most exclusive street, Lake Shore Drive, is acquiring some new luxury apartments.

title: POSTINGS: Aimed at Brokers, Open to the Public;Residential Specialists Share Their Insights
description: Trying to salvage a foundering residential real estate deal? Market a brownstone worth millions? Or maybe you're just curious about the history of residential construction in the city?

title: GARDENING;Even House Plants Like Slowing Down a Bit
description: THIS is a story about an ivy-leaved geranium. It has a happy ending, and instead of the usual "Once upon a time," the story begins at a garden center.

title: Tanker Runs Aground a 2d Time Near Welsh Port
description: Fearing an explosion, the police ordered residents to leave the area near this headland today after an oil tanker ran aground for the second time.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: WORD FOR WORD/Wei Jingsheng;Letters to Deng, From the Pit of Repression
description: WESTERNERS sometimes tell Chinese officials that it is counterproductive to lock up dissidents, but in the short run repression often works. Case in point: Wei Jingsheng, China's best-known campaigner for democracy, whom the authorities have succeeded in silencing behind bars.

title: WEDDINGS;Margaret C. Moroff, Paul S. Reuter
description: Margaret Carol Moroff, a daughter of Libby and Dr. Saul Moroff of New York, was married yesterday to Paul S. Reuter, a son of Marilyn and Dr. Stanley H. Reuter of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. The Rev. Robert L. Brashear, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: The Indispensable Man
description: Founding Father Rediscovering George Washington. By Richard Brookhiser. 230 pp. New York: The Free Press. $25.

title: February 11-17;Gas-Loving, Go-Go Americans
description: Small Is Beautiful," the classic little book on the economics of the 1970's by E. F. Schumacher, offered a central warning: energy was the most vulnerable resource. "If energy fails, everything fails," he warned. Yet Americans have already forgotten that era of fuel rationing, long gas lines and compact, fuel-efficient cars.

title: Corrections
description: A listing on Jan. 14 with an article about Siberia misstated the number of ways to get there. A letter from Alaska Airlines received Feb. 1 points out that travelers can fly to Siberia from the West Coast of the United States; they are not limited to traveling through Moscow or St. Petersburg.

title: POLITICS: ALEXANDER'S IDEAS;Alexander Builds His Hopes On Some Radical Departures
description: Steve Forbes has his flat tax. Bob Dole chants the mantra of the balanced budget. Patrick J. Buchanan is known for his protectionist positions on world trade.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: America's Culture Gaps;The Tribulations of the Not-So-Living Arts
description: DURING the last 10 years, a low-grade fever has been evident in the arts. It lies just below awareness, like a dull toothache that can still be ignored. The promotion of concerts and dance series continues; the biggest stars draw crowds and sell subscriptions; administrative staffs of institutions raise funds for endowments, and long lines form for every major museum show.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST SIDE;An 'Ethnographer' Ventures to the Depths of Hell's Kitchen
description: Richard Curtis is the Margaret Mead of Hell's Kitchen, a "street ethnographer." Like the renowned anthropologist known for her work in Samoa, Mr. Curtis likes to say "we catch people in their natural settings."

title: BASEBALL;Sandberg Finds the Baseball Flame Still Burns
description: Of the 1.9 million fans who paid to see a baseball game at Wrigley Field last year there were undoubtedly some who had a fleeting fantasy: to step out into the bright sunshine against the famous ivy-covered panoramic backdrop and play ball.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;U.S.C. Player Quits
description: A sophomore point guard, CAMERON MURRAY, who had recently asked the University of Southern California's interim coach, HENRY BIBBY, not to start him, quit the team on Friday. Murray averaged 8.2 points, 5.1 assists and 2.7 rebounds. The freshman DAMION DAWSON replaced him. (AP)

title: MARKET WATCH;Internet Dreams: From 10~ To $30
description: When it comes to creating instant wealth, no place can match Wall Street. With a good idea, you can become a millionaire almost immediately, even if your company has no revenues and a lot of competition. If, that is, you are in a hot industry.

title: THE CRAFTY COMMUTER;Trouble Spots to Avoid on Roads and Highways This Week
description: A look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency.

title: WEDDINGS;Ann N. Rowan, Thomas Dickson
description: Ann Naomi Rowan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rowan of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas Webb Dickson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Dickson of Little Silver, N.J. The Rev. David Yocis performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien.

title: Strong Quake in Indonesia
description: A powerful earthquake struck Indonesia today, killing at least 10 people and setting off 20-foot tidal waves that destroyed more than 600 homes.

title: The Training's for a Real Job (Cooking)
description: THINGS had gotten bad for Alston Duncan. A single parent with a young son, he was laid off from his job as a cook in a nursing home and after searching in vain for another job that would enable him to have child care, he wound up on welfare, a client of the Aid to Families With Dependent Children program.

title: THEATER;Ayckbourn's 'Time of My Life'
description: WHEN the plays of Alan Ayckbourn quantitatively surpassed the plays of Shakespeare theater chroniclers stopped counting. And now that the Ayckbourn oeuvre reaches well beyond 40 plays, even the more substantively-minded theater historian may have given up trying to figure out why an English playwright whose prolificacy is matched by his success on home ground, is less than a passing fancy for American theatergoers. Too threatening? No boffo laughs? No matter.

title: Plan for Lilco Encounters A New Obstaclte
description: DAYS after gaining conditional support from Suffolk Republican leaders for Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to cut electric rates 12 percent, the Long Island Power Authority has lost support in Nassau County.

title: GARDEN;Even House Plants Like Slowing Down a Bit
description: THIS is a story about an ivy-leaved geranium. It has a happy ending, and instead of the usual "Once upon a time," the story begins at a garden center.

title: HOCKEY;Messier Ties Score, Then Breaks the Tie
description: A dangerous matchup in Pittsburgh loomed right around the corner. The Rangers were playing without two of their top five scorers. They had the lowly Ottawa Senators on their platter tonight.

title: SOAPBOX;On the Wings of a Dream
description: GROWING up in Linden, my brother and I played at opposite ends of 18th Street. The street was three blocks long, bordered on the east by Rosenbaum's Dairy Farm and on the west by a small airport. The dairy farm no longer exists. The airport prospered, along with the vision that held my brother captive for 50 years.

title: For Odd Couple of Politics, Debating Begins at Home
description: When Thomas and Melinda Wilde first met through a dating service in 1989, she was dubious about their prospects.

title: A Florida Retirement in Your Own Backyard
description: FELICE and Jack Isreeli consider themselves lucky. Two years ago, when they were about to leave on a trip to Africa, Mrs. Isreeli said, "I just happened to see a small announcement in the paper about Sterling Park at the Osborn, the new independent retirement community that was going to be built in Rye in our own backyard, and it sounded like something for us."

title: Adjuncts Need More Pay, Not More Empty Promises
description: To the Editor:

title: SPOTLIGHT;Cookoo Cavaliers
description: With a n'yuk, n'yuk here and a woo, woo there and here a slap and there a poke, the Three Stooges will embark on a long day's journey into mirth and mayhem at NOON on MONDAY when THE FAMILY CHANNEL serves up a seven-hour THREE STOOGES MARATHON.

title: February 11-17;Zaire to Refugees: Go Home
description: Last week, nearly two years after hundreds of thousands of refugees flooded into the rocky plains around Goma, Zairian soldiers cut off one of the largest refugee camps, keeping residents from work in the surrounding community and shutting down camp bars, brothels and businesses.

title: New & Notewortht
description: THE CUNNING MAN By Robertson Davies. Penguin, $12.95. The narrator is a physician, but no ordinary one: interested in religion and psychology as much as he is in medicine, Dr. Jonathan Hullah is prompted to look back on his own life when he is confronted by the sudden, bizarre death of a priest. "This is a wise, humane and consistently entertaining novel," Isabel Colegate said here last year.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;A Flagging Tradition? Says Who?
description: MARTIJN SANDERS DID not really need to explain his choice of orchestras. As director of the Concertgebouw in Amsterdam, he had assembled three of the most prestigious ensembles in the world for a great Mahler festival last May, the Vienna Philharmonic, the Berlin Philharmonic and the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra, and he bould have let the quality of the performances speak for itself.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Ratifies Mfume As President
description: The board of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People AACP yesterday ratified Kweisi Mfume as its new president in a unanimous vote aimed at putting to rest the recent years of power struggles and scandals that have damaged its recruitment, fund-raising and effectiveness as the nation's oldest and best-known organization advocates for blacks.

title: BASKETBALL;Still Searching For the Truth
description: In a questionnaire once distributed by the public relations department of the Chicago Bulls, each player was asked to describe himself in three or four words. Craig Hodges wrote, "Searching for the truth."

title: Unwanted Movies
description: To the Editor: Paula DiPerna's article "Mastering the Modern Hotel Room" (Dec. 31) was on target. As a frequent traveler, I have encountered many of the problems she listed. However, she left out the X-rated movies that are still programmed on the television set when one checks in.

title: THE WORLD;The West in Afghanistan, Before and After
description: ABDUL RAQIB is a man who walks through minefields for a living. An old Soviet army bayonet in one hand and an American-trained sniffer dog in the other, Mr. Raqib goes hunting for some of the 10 million land mines left when Soviet troops were trying to maintain the Kremlin's grip on Afghanistan and United States-backed Muslim guerrillas were fighting to dislodge them.

title: Colombian Leader Opens the Way to Resignation
description: Facing charges of fraud, obstruction of justice and accepting campaign donations from drug traffickers, President Ernesto Samper has opened the way for his eventual resignation.

title: POLITICS: A TERRITORIAL CONVENTION;Help Comes From Afar, Delivering 4 Delegates for Dole Campaign
description: Regardless of how Senator Bob Dole's campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination turns out, he can count on at least four delegates for this summer's Republican National Convention -- thanks to the territory of Guam.

title: For Many Kindergarteners, It's 'Buenos Dias'
description: NANETTE COLN, a Spanish teacher, entered the classroom.

title: IN BRIEF;More Buses, not Trains, For Route 9 Corridor
description: After two years of intense debate, New Jersey Transit last week scuttled plans to extend commuter rail service to Freehold and Lakewood, choosing to provide more bus service and more road improvements along the Route 9 corridor. The reasons, officials said, were money and local opposition.

title: CHINA: OPPORTUNITY ... OR TRAP?;Tricks of the Peanut Butter Trade
description: Less than 100 yards from the peanut butter factory he has traveled across China to see, Michael McCune is stuck. His car has come to a halt in a narrow, muddy alley lined with old wooden shacks that look as if they've been there for centuries. McCune, a hulking 25-year-old American with a John Travolta dimple on his chin, cranes his neck to look for the factory gate. But the passageway is barely 10 feet wide and his view is blocked by a cart that has stopped to unload its wares -- an extensive collection of broken machine parts -- one by one. Hard to tell how long this chore will take; time moves slowly in rural China.

title: More People Grow Food In Cities, Report Says
description: From the garbage dumps of Calcutta to the rooftops of Mexico City and dirt strips along roads in Jakarta and Nairobi, millions of people are farming the world's cities, feeding their families and supplying markets with vegetables, fruit, fish and even meat, a study has found.

title: The View From: Stamford;In Greenery, a Lift to the Spirits and an Antitoxin, Too
description: HOUSE plants brighten a winter day, bring cheer to a sickroom, relieve the drabness of the average office. But that's not all they do. The creators of an exhibition now on view at the Champion Greenhouse in Stamford say plants can significantly reduce air pollution in homes and workplaces by renewing stale air and filtering out harmful gases.

title: Haskins Merits Hall
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Perfect Pardon
description: ATTICUS By Ron Hansen. 247 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $22.

title: CLASSICAL VIEW;Horsepower In Place Of History
description: A PIANIST CAN BARELY TURN AROUND without finding Sviatoslav Richter peering over one shoulder or the other. He is the keyboard's inspiration and its source of guilty consciences. Heavy is the magnificence of this career; Mr. Richter's message, delivered unsmilingly, is a sermon on the shortcomings of others. Now there is more to feel guilty about: a new armful of Melodiya recordings from the Russian pianist's concerts and broadcasts in the old Soviet Union.

title: Westchester Q & A: Prof. Giles Scofield;Hardest Choices of the Health Care Crisis
description: AS Prof. Giles Scofield of Pace Law School in White Plains sees it, "The savings and loan scandal will look like a day at Disneyland compared to today's health care crisis."

title: Singer With Insights Honed in Chappaqua
description: WHEN Dar Williams, the folk singer who grew up in Chappaqua and is now on a concert tour of the United States opening for Joan Baez, wrote the song "You're Aging Well," she was 25. Ms. Baez, 54, who along with Bob Dylan helped popularize folk music, heard the song and liked it so much that she recorded it with Ms. Williams at the Bottom Line in Greenwich Village on her new release, "Ring Them Bells."

title: 12 Killed in Fiery Amtrak Collision in Near Washington
description: A Chicago-bound Amtrak train creeping through a snowstorm smashed into a local train just outside Washington yesterday afternoon in a fiery crash that left commuter coaches crumpled like accordians. Twelve people were killed and more than 20 were injured, officials said.

title: As Fiery Crash Ended Dreams, Survivors Fled
description: About six weeks ago, Thomas Loatman learned that a commuter train could take him home to Washington from his Job Corps training center near Harpers Ferry, W. Va. He told his father about it in a letter.

title: Buchanan on Air
description: To the Editor:

title: Snow Attacks A City Record (And Its Spirit)
description: As the latest drove of storm-delayed travelers rose achingly from the floors of airport lounges and skiers schussed down a fabricated slope in Central Park, the snowstorm that ended early yesterday brought New York City to the brink of a record and ushered in single-digit wind chills.

title: ART;Paris on His Mind
description: WHY PARIS? WHY DID I, or any African-American artist or writer, go to Paris?

title: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF;Harlem: Its Origins and Its Struggles
description: IT was the place to find Fats Waller and Langston Hughes, Marcus Garvey and Father Divine, W.E.B. Du Bois and several Adam Clayton Powells. It was a center of cultural ferment, the most famous black community in America.

title: SPOTLIGHT;On the Road and Off
description: THE GREAT RACE (1965) is a long, bulging movie comic strip -- generally fast, funny, festive and bright -- culled from the good old days of sneering culprits, daredevil heroes, brave beauties and flying custard pies. A scrambly, international marathon of early-1900 autos, it carries the likes of Tony Curtis, Natalie Wood, Dorothy Provine and Peter Falk, under Balke Edwards's blithe direction. The show-stealer is a sneering, villainous Jack Lemmon (above with Mr. Falk). Expect a few lulls but not many -- WEDNESDAY at 1:15 P.M. on AMC. For the record, a song called "The Sweetheart Tree" copped an Oscar as the year's best and then disappeared.

title: THEATER;A Company Opens With 'Daytrips'
description: WHAT'S new? A professional theater company is starting up in Westchester. What to do? Catch it fast before it takes off for North Carolina.

title: Backtalk;Why 'The Last American Hero' Quit
description: For the first time in its 38 runnings, the Daytona 500 will take place today without Junior Johnson's participation, as either a driver or car owner. Two months ago, Johnson announced that he was selling his racing teams and getting out of the sport. His departure was handled as subtly as Richard Petty's retirement was overproduced. Johnson, 64, won 50 major races as a driver and 139 as an owner. But more than that, he came to symbolize stock-car racing's back-country, moonshine-running origins. Forty years ago, he was convicted after helping his father produce untaxed whiskey; President Reagan eventually granted him a full pardon. He inspired Tom Wolfe's Esquire magazine article "The Last American Hero," later made into a movie, and Bruce Springsteen's "Cadillac Ranch."

title: ART;More Fuel for the Debate on Abstraction
description: IT could be a "Jeopardy" question: what was "Art of Tomorrow" in the 1930's and "Art of This Century" in the 1940's but now is "Art of Today"? The answer is abstraction, first as it was billed by Hilla Rebay, guide to the collector Solomon Guggenheim, then as his niece, Peggy, labeled it and her gallery in Manhattan and as it is presented at the Castle Gallery at the College of New Rochelle here.

title: THE GREAT OUTDOORS;Root, Branch and plenty of Burlap: How to Move 20 Tons of Tree
description: Moving a tree is always a delicate task. The roots must be carefully pruned, then wrapped in a burlap ball, then gently transplanted and given tender care in rich, moist soil.
