But moving the purple-leafed beech from the Ledgewood Circle in Roxbury promises to be a delicate task of Brobdingnagian proportions.

title: A Quiet, Clean, Solitary Winter in Yellowstone Park? Vroom! Cough!Think Again.
description: It was 30 degrees below zero and 30 miles from the nearest plowed road. But in the snowbound visitors center at Old Faithful, cash registers rang merrily with sales of geyser postcards, and the restaurant had a 10-minute wait for a lunchtime table.

title: Variety of Indian Restaurants Make Debuts
description: TWO years ago, there were four or five Indian restaurants on Long Island, all but one of them in Nassau County. Today, there are that many in Hicksville alone and more are on the way.

title: Why Stalkers Go Free
description: Men who threaten to kill their wives and girlfriends often succeed -- even with police, the courts and prosecutors looking on. That tragic truth was underscored again last week when a Brooklyn woman was murdered by a man who had stalked, beaten and threatened her. The killer, a three-time felon, had been served with an order of protection to keep him away from his victim. Days before the killing, he was released from jail despite protests from prosecutors who sensed the murder coming.

title: Long Island Q & A: Bonnie Jacobson;Help for Men and Women to Communicate With Each Other
description: DR. BONNIE JACOBSON, founder of the New York Institute for Psychological Change in Manhattan, often counsels couples who are seeking to repair or to enhance long-term relationships.

title: SKIING;Austrian Captures Downhill In a Glide
description: Patrick Ortlieb of Austria won the downhill today at the world championships, using his strength and 220-pound frame to beat Kristian Ghedina of Italy and Luc Alphand of France on a long and progressively slower course.

title: Corrections
description: The "In Search of . . ." page last Sunday, about "Romance, Lost and Found," omitted credits for three poems. "Last Chance: Atlantic City 3:45 A.M.," by Laura Boss, was reprinted from "On the Edge of the Hudson" (Cross-Cultural Like Any Other Day" was used with the permission of the author, Maria Mazziotti Gillan.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST SIDE;Planners Consider a New Commodity: Times Square Air
description: Now that redevelopment is a reality in the heart of Times Square, city planners are focusing more intently on the neighborhood's next frontier: Eighth Avenue. They are debating whether a major expansion of air rights would prime the development pump along the avenue, which remains a bleak corridor of cheap low-rise hotels and porn shops.

title: Spellman Girls Lose Title
description: A disqualification in the next-to-last event, the 1,600-meter relay, cost Cardinal Spellman of the Bronx the girls' title, and Archbishop Molloy of Queens won its first indoor boys' crown in six years yesterday at the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association Track and Field Championships at the Armory Track and Field Center.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT;BROOKLYN UPDATE
description: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN -- Steam Heat, the all-nude club on Flatbush Avenue Extension that has withstood court rulings for nearly a year, may finally have to shut its door.

title: MUSIC;One Concerto, Two Artists, 25 Opportunities
description: IN bygone days, musical premieres were exciting, anticipated events. Even now, it's not hard to get a first hearing. But that second one is a big reach, and from then on the chances decrease exponentially.

title: 8 Trainees From Job Corps Among Train Crash Victims
description: The victims of a head-on collision here on Friday evening between a fast-moving commuter train and an Amtrak train included eight young trainees from a Federal Job Corps program, officials said today.

title: BROADWAY STARS;'Real' Producers Are Long Gone
description: To the Editor:

title: COPING;Where the Money Is: A View From Atlanta
description: MARVIN EDWARDS is missing New York. "It didn't totally dawn on me I was black until I came down here," he said, a few minutes after he picked up on my accent. "There's prejudice in New York, but people are more concerned with making the dollar than keeping you from making it. Down here, there's still a lot of white people see you as a threat -- "sididdy." You know the word? It means uppity."

title: Buddha Puts Katonah on the Map
description: WHEN the staff of the Katonah Museum in Westchester County began planning five years ago for its current exhibition, there was a sense that the show would be special. But no one expected more than 1,000 visitors to stream through the galleries on opening day last month, nor the avalanche of interest that followed.

title: Better Commute Still Wins Friends
description: WITH more than a year to go before the deadline, more than 500 companies in southwestern Connecticut had filed plans to reduce their employees' use of automobiles, as required by the Federal Clean Air Act. Then the rules changed.

title: Don't Skip Dessert
description: FOR desserts in an Italian restaurant, these are sensational," I say to my companions at Tuscany Grill.

title: WEDDINGS;Janet C. Scanlon, Bruno Perreault
description: Janet Catherine Scanlon, a daughter of Mary Jane and Peter R. Scanlon of Jupiter, Fla., was married yesterday to Bruno Denis Perreault, a son of Suzanne Gamache Perreault of Sherbrooke, Quebec, and the late Jean D. Perreault. Msgr. John F. McDermott performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York.

title: HOME REPAIR;Steam Heat Can Offer Comfort and Dependability
description: STEAM heating is the hydronic heating system that uses steam to carry the heat from the furnace into the rest of the house.

title: Croton Acquires Land to Preserve Shoreline
description: THE village of Croton-on-Hudson and two nonprofit groups specializing in protection of open space for the public have announced the purchase of a 30-acre strip of land along the Hudson River that had been considered a site for two large developments.

title: DINING OUT;The Mediterranean, All Shores Included
description: MEDITERRANEAN cuisine has become the catch term of the 1990's, in large part because of the healthy foods and cooking styles of that part of the world. But often the term refers mostly to the foods of Spain, France and Italy, with perhaps lip service to a dish or two from North Africa.

title: Man Tops Machine, And Tells It About It
description: After a stunning loss in the opening round of a six-game match with the world's strongest chess computer, the reigning chess champion, Gary Kasparov, ended the suspense in characteristic fashion, picking up his watch just before the 40th move of yesterday's match.

title: A Dissident Joins the Establishment
description: When he first arrived in Israel 10 years ago this month, Natan Sharansky rejected all the many efforts to get him to take sides, whether left or right, religious or secular.

title: N.J. LAW;To Reel In Elusive Tax Dollars, a Variety of Bait and Hooks
description: When Governor Whitman took office two years ago, she promised to cut taxes, and she did. Now, to help replenish the treasury, her administration has promised to go aggressively after every single dollar of the taxes it is owed.

title: ON THE MAP;Honoring a President, the Jersey City Way
description: At Lincoln Park in Jersey City, there is an astounding bronze statue of the 16th President, born on Feb. 12, 1809, and fatally shot on April 14, 1865, five days after the Civil War officially ended.

title: WEDDINGS;Alison A. Sellin, D. K. Weiskopf 3d
description: Alison Anne Sellin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Neil Robert Sellin of New York, was married yesterday to Daniel Kraemer Weiskopf 3d, the son of Mary Jane Weiskopf and Mr. Weiskopf 2d, both of New York. The Rev. Frederick Hoesli officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York. The Rev. Thomas Bowers, an Episcopal priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;Jackson Browne vs. Madison Avenue
description: WHEN A POP SONG IS TURNED into a jingle, its integrity as a personal artistic statement is inevitably tainted. But what happens when a jingle is shoehorned into a pop song? In "Information Wars," the most provocative cut on Jackson Browne's new album, "Looking East" (Elektra), Mr. Browne, a 47-year-old Los Angeles singer and songwriter, mounts an attack on America's television culture that includes an ingenious collage of variations on familiar advertising slogans. Reiterated without their brand names, the slogans are turned against themselves in a way that reveals the Orwellian seductiveness of television.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Marbury Gets Best Of Duncan Matchup
description: The best teams the Atlantic Coast Conference has to offer this season don't possess the power or polish of recent years. Yet in a league that's known for its top-to-bottom balance, the internal competitiveness may be fiercer than ever. That was borne out again here this afternoon at Alexander Memorial Coliseum, as Georgia Tech survived a last jumper by Wake Forest and a follow shot that went in just after the buzzer to emerge with a 64-63 victory.

title: INVESTING IT;Can Retirees' Safety Net Be Saved?
description: SOCIAL SECURITY is going bankrupt -- again.

title: A Study Finds Progress in Linking Public Schools to the Internet
description: Half the nation's public schools have hooked up to the Internet, with bigger, richer suburban schools leading the way. Schools with many minority or low-income students are connecting, too, but at a slower pace, a Government survey said today.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: WEST SIDE

title: FOOD;East Feeds West
description: Since people rarely emigrate when they're happy, it stands to reason that disasters in other parts of the world have enriched the American table. Certainly, the obverse is true. Immigration policies that are restrictive have done nothing to enhance the nation's diet, as chop suey would attest.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;The Brave New World of the A.T.M.
description: BANKING in New York City is deep in a time of change, with banks closing branches throughout the city in the name of higher profits. Fewer and fewer friendly (or not-so-friendly) human tellers are around to cash checks and chat with customers. In their place are the lighted screens of automated-teller machines, their conversation limited to simple questions and commands but their functions ever more complex.

title: DIRTY LAUNDRY
description: If Rafkin is indeed being paid "$20 to $45 per hour" to clean a house, I, for one, would most certainly leave a "ridiculous" message on her answering machine complaining that she "left two Cheerios in the sink."

title: Our Towns;At a Shelter, The Men Feel Misunderstood
description: LUNCHTIME at Camp La Guardia, and pork chops top the menu. The main cafeteria is packed. Men sit down with their trays at square folding tables, forming clusters of easy conversation, making themselves at home.

title: Inside 'City Hall'
description: City Hall," the new film starring Al Pacino as a popular, populist Mayor, is a wholly realistic portrait of gritty city politics. But it is friction. Here are a few examples of who's really who and what's really what.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;When the Manager Is a Hard Act to Follow
description: WHEN a fund loses a star manager, chaos does not have to reign. Just look at the smooth transition this year when John Neff passed the baton of the Vanguard Windsor fund to his longtime co-manager.

title: Clinton Urged To Cite Mexico For Drug Flow
description: Armed with a flood of intelligence showing that Mexico has become a huge conduit for cocaine, methamphetamines, marijuana and heroin sold in the United States, Federal narcotics officials are urging the Clinton Administration to drop Mexico from a list of countries making progress against drug trafficking.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A dazzling sleeper from New Zealand, a memorable American melodrama and two find adaptions of classics are at the top of the movie line up on television this week.

title: Is Diamond Toning Down? And What of 'Black Radio'?
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER;Now, a Few Words With the Audience
description: LAST Sunday at the McCarter Theater, the dialogue began after the play was over. An insert in the program left out the title, but a symposium called "The Politics of Hate" followed the matinee of "Greensboro: A Requiem." And while the subject was thought up and four speakers were lined up for the occasion by Janice Paran, the McCarter's literary manager, the event was presented under the banner of Talking Stages.

title: Another Tribal Nation? And Another Casino?
description: THERE still may be a casino in the cards for financially hard-pressed Bridgeport. State and local officials are trying to find a future without gambling after legislation was defeated that would have authorized a state-regulated casino to be owned by the Mashantucket Pequots.

title: Don't Mess With Sears
description: To the Editor:

title: VIEWPOINT: MARK R. MITCHELL;Stumbling Back Into Vietnam
description: IN offices throughout Ho Chi Minh City and in the grimy bars where prematurely grizzled expatriates exchange gossip, the consensus is that America is sinking into yet another quagmire in Vietnam. Unlike savvy old-timers from Asia and Europe, newly arrived American businessmen are venturing into a murky business world without the knowledge or adaptability to compete.

title: A Game We Couldn't Lose
description: Human worth hung in the balance again this weekend. Among the array of graver and more material contests now facing civilization, struggles from Sarajevo to New Hampshire, the one decided yesterday in Philadelphia stands out in its symbolic weight. In the chess match between Garry Kasparov, the world's best living player, and I.B.M.'s Deep Blue, an otherwise undistinguished supercomputer, humanity's collective self-esteem was once more on the line.

title: The Icicle Man Cometh And Seeks Compassion
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTING IT;Lots of Data, Many Gaps In On-Line Research
description: I SAT, fingers poised, at my desk at home in New Jersey. The challenge was clear: Could I be an investor using only my computer keyboard?

title: U.S. Says Dead G.I. Didn't Follow Orders
description: The soldier who was the first American military casualty in Bosnia was killed when he broke the rules and tried to defuse a land mine, according to a military investigation released today.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;Doing What Comes Naturally
description: Peter Serkin is not comfortable being called a champion of new music.

title: STYLE;Delia at the Delano
description: I'm Delia, and I live at the Delano in Miami. There's no other hotel like it. Kelly Klein's new picture book about underwear is in the gift shop. I've read it. After all, I'm almost 8 and my parents say I have the soul of a publicist.

title: THE NATION;Left, Right, Left: The Primaries Turn Politicians Around
description: A NEW Bob Dole showed up in this state last week. Not the one who shuttles on corporate jets from his condominium in the Watergate to his condominium in Bal Harbour, Fla. This Bob Dole was heading for the eastern front in the class war, marching shoulder to shoulder with the working stiff.

title: An Endowment Turns a Big Land Gift to Texas Into a Bonanza
description: Forty-thousand acres of rugged West Texas ranch land have been donated to the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department in what officials say is by far the largest land gift to the state.

title: February 11-17;Stocks Too Bullish? Maybe.
description: On Oct. 19, 1987, the stock market crashed. Presumably, prices were simply too high.

title: WEDDINGS Molly Cargill, William Spruance 5th
description: Mary Ryan Cargill, a daughter of Therese C. Russell of Southport, Conn., and the late William S. Cargill, was married yesterday to William Corbit Spruance 5th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Spruance of Dayton, Ohio. The Rev. L. Kathleen Liles performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport.

title: THE NATION;Contract With America Includes Cash Bonuses
description: THE dozens of Republican freshmen who swept into office a year ago promised to change the way business is done in Washington, and they have done so in many respects -- from casting politically dangerous votes on Medicare to working incredible, party-free hours. But when it comes to campaign finance, their only radical idea is that political action committees should give to Republicans instead of Democrats.

title: In N.J. Senate Race, Measurable Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM;Once More Into the Fray For John Cassavetes
description: HOME VIDEO HAS always had a talent for revivals. Gather the films of a star or a renowned director, clear the rights, track down pieces of negative (inevitably scattered from Hollywood to Prague, or so it seems), box the special editions, alert the cognoscenti to the second coming, or whatever coming this particular revival happens to be, and stand by for a warm response from fans and a public that increasingly likes to collect tapes.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Mets Saving Money For Younger Players
description: The Mets are the envy of many teams in the cost-conscious major leagues after assembling a young, competitive club that will carry a team payroll in the $20 million range. That's minuscule compared with the Yankees and the Braves, whose payrolls will top $50 million this year.

title: THEATER;Two Contestants, an Enigmatic Struggle and a Play
description: TWO MEN, ONE CALLED THE DEALER, the other The Client, cross paths in some desolate corner of a large city. The Dealer refuses to divulge what he is offering, and The Client refuses to admit that he has a need. Yet they cannot walk away from each other. The Dealer needs to know what The Client is seeking, and The Client insists on knowing what The Dealer can offer. Each has desires that exist because the other cannot satisfy them.

title: February 11-17;Forget Crack, Here's Ice
description: Called by any nickname -- speed, crank or ice -- methamphetamine is a dangerous drug, triggering jittery binges fraught with violence and paranoia. The stimulant's resurgence on the West Coast, with an attendant rise in overdoses, hospital admissions and homicides, worries the Drug Enforcement Administration enough that it invited law enforcement officials to Washington last week to discuss how to stop methamphetimine from turning into a national epidemic. Some good news: the drug has yet to catch on in New York, giving the police here time to brace for its arrival. CHRISTOPHER S. WREN.

title: Balkan Chiefs Air Problems Of Peace Plan In Rome Talks
description: In an effort to prevent the unraveling of the Balkan peace accord, officials of the United States and its NATO allies began a two-day meeting here today with the Presidents of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia.

title: No Offense
description: MULTICULTURAL MANNERS New Rules of Etiquette for a Changing Society. By Norine Dresser. 285 pp. New York: John Wiley & Sons. Paper, $14.95.

title: Alcatraz House, a Timeworn Landmark, Cries Out for Help
description: Alcatraz was never known for its accommodations, but the warden's house was an exception: 3 floors, 17 rooms, built in 1929 in Mission Revival style, with a spectacular view of San Francisco Bay from the summit of the prison island.

title: Son Takes the Reins From His Father
description: NOT many sons have overpowered their father in the family business. But not many men are dynamos like Michael Smith of J. Richard Smith Advertising in Melville.

title: CHATTER;Presidents, Best and Worst
description: Tomorrow is Presidents' Day. Which President do you admire most? Least? Why?

title: February 11-17;Train Crashes in D.C.
description: A Chicago-bound Amtrak train, the Capitol Limited, collided Friday with a Maryland commuter train just outside Washington, killing at least 11 people. Most of the dead were Job Corps students on their way home for the holiday weekend. More than 20 people were injured.

title: NEWT'S FIERCEST FIGHT
description: Are those men pictured holding toys for Gingrich to sign the same men making decisions for the nation? The image is disturbing.

title: WEDDINGS;Elizabeth Harder, Mark L. Ameres
description: Elizabeth Rhodes Harder, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James D. R. Harder of New York, was married yesterday to Mark Louis Ameres, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ludwig A. Ameres of Ramsey, N.J. The Rev. Bernard Camire officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Jean Baptiste in New York.

title: ON POLITICS;Make New Friends And Keep the Old
description: On the day last week that Governor Whitman was campaigning in New Hampshire for Bob Dole, several of her old friends showed up at the State House to endorse another Presidential candidate, Steve Forbes, her lifelong friend and close adviser.

title: SAFE-SEX LIES
description: You will undoubtedly receive a Santa's sack of negative mail regarding Meghan Daum's "Safe-Sex Lies" (Jan. 21). I hope her detractors realize that most of us who spent all of the 1970's under the age of 10 do protect ourselves on a regular basis, firing a series of Joe Friday-like questions in the dark, trying to keep our passions in check long enough to examine the veracity of each response. But passion is an odd creature and doesn't always conform to a rigid checklist of rules.

title: Editorial Notebook: New Hampshire, 1996;Where Fresh Faces Begin to Wrinkle
description: The Republican Presidential contenders in New Hampshire are showing grave signs of candidate wilt. Turn on the spotlight and they droop like overheated begonias.

title: NEWT'S FIERCEST FIGHT
description: We are told that Gingrich has "won -- again, again and again," but also that only 3 of the 31 Contract With America bills have become law. And behind all the posturing and bold pronouncements we see the paradigm of a cynical, poll-driven politician, uttering management-training mantras, conducting market research on manipulative advertising slogans and substituting code words for any substantive ideology. Surely, this nation deserves better leadership.

title: World News Briefs;I.R.A. Says It Planted Bomb Found in London
description: The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility today for planting a bomb in London on Thursday, less than a week after a bomb attack ended its 17-month cease-fire.

title: WEDDINGS;Marcella Hardart, Matthew Wickline
description: Marcella Byrne Hardart, a daughter of Mrs. Thomas R. Hardart of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and the late Mr. Hardart, was married yesterday to Matthew John Wickline, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Alvin Wickline of Mentor, Ohio. The Rev. William Byrne performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: The Capitalist;President and C.E.O.
description: A FEW WEEKS AGO I WAS CHASING around Iowa after Morry Taylor, the chief executive of Titan Wheel International and one of two businessmen seeking the Republican Presidential nomination, the other being the better-known Steve Forbes. For some reason I never fully understood, one morning Taylor and I wound up inside the National Soil Tilth, one of many red brick Iowan eyesores that belong to the United States Department of Agriculture. What came to pass was a nice illustration of what happens when the business mind confronts the Government bureaucracy.

title: MARATHON;Kempainen Shows Will in Winning Trials
description: At the 24-mile mark of today's Olympic marathon trials, Bob Kempainen took a 20-yard lead over Mark Coogan and Keith Brantly. Then he took ill. His stomach upset by a sports drink, Kempainen threw up once, then twice. The second time, he slowed and began to wobble. For a moment it appeared that the unthinkable might happen. That two miles from the finish, Kempainen would have to abandon the race and any chance of qualifying for the Summer Games in Atlanta.

title: DIARY
description: FILTERS (I) Offensive Yes, Indecent No

title: FOOD;Pears, Dried Cranberries and Chocolate for Inspiring Desserts
description: AT this time of year, produce stands are filled with berries, peaches and apricots from other climates, but for desserts these are expensive and not necessarily satisfying choices.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: UNSECULAR MEDIA Making News of Religion in America. By Mark Silk. University of Illinois, $19.95.

title: YOUR HOME;Denying A Request For Keys
description: A FEW months ago Loraine Ballard changed the locks on the door to her Manhattan co-op. Shortly thereafter, the co-op's board asked for a duplicate set of keys. Ms. Ballard balked at the request.

title: BASKETBALL;Casino Owner Is a Globetrotter for a Moment
description: For 40 years, Bob Stupak dreamed of playing for the Harlem Globetrotters. Even though he is of average height and has no detectable basketball skill, Stupak dreamed on. Yesterday his dream came true. All it cost was a $100,000 donation to the United Negro College Fund.

title: Last Crash Is Fourth This Month
description: The crash that killed 11 people here on Friday night was the fourth major train accident so far this month, but Federal officials said today that the accidents appeared to have no common thread.

title: CHINA: APPEASE ... OR CONTAIN?;Speak Softly, Carry a Veiled Threat
description: In Somerset Maugham's novel about novelists, "Cakes and Ale," one of the characters belittles Henry James for having "turned his back on one of the great events of the world's history, the rise of the United States, in order to report tittle-tattle at tea parties in English country houses." Today, as we talk about peace plans in Bosnia, elections in Haiti and hostages in Chechnya, there is a danger of similarly neglecting the defining international political event of this era -- the rise of China to world power.

title: WEDDINGS;Jordan Bruns, John Richards Jr.
description: Hilliard Jordan Bruns, the daughter of Chase and Eugene Bruns of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to John Thorpe Lawrence Richards Jr., the son of Nancy and John Richards, also of Alexandria. The Rev. Geoffrey Michael St. John Hoare performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Alexandria.

title: FRUGAL TRAVELER;Club Hopping Around Hip Austin
description: SEVERAL months ago, while I was reading "The Texas Monthly Guidebook to Austin" on a New York subway, a man nudged me and asked, "Are you really going there?" When I said yes, he told me he'd once lived in Austin, and he got so fired up describing its virtues that he almost missed his stop.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Copenhagen, Cultural Capital
description: Copenhagen plays host this year to a cultural calendar of more than 400 events celebrating artists from around the world and home-grown talents like Hans Christian Andersen as the Danish city serves as Europe's official 1996 Cultural Capital.

description: When Congress approved the Goals 2000 education program two years ago, most state governments were delighted.

description: GUARDIAN Poems. By Cleopatra Mathis. Sheep Meadow Press, $19.95.

title: Life at the Top in Costa Rica
description: IN the cool dawn light, I was hurriedly packing, tucking mosquito nets and flashlights into our duffel bags. My husband, our 6-year-old son and I had awoken to a rooster crowing outside our hotel on the outskirts of San Jose, Costa Rica's capital, ready to leave room service for the rain forest. Visions of butterflies and jaguars beckoned, as we were whisked through the still deserted streets for our charter plane to Corcovado National Park, one of the largest, least accessible, and most biologically significant of any tropical forest park in Costa Rica and one of the last refuges in the world for such threatened species as the jaguar, the ocelot and the tapir.

title: Traveler's Guilt
description: To the Editor: Susan Allen Toth's essay on traveler's guilt ("Conscience Makes a Poor Companion," Jan. 7) reminded me of a problem I've run into: people who, on learning that you are about to embark on a trip to country X, give you a small letter for a friend of theirs and ask you to mail it when you get there.

title: Notable Quotables: Why Images Become Icons
description: TIRED OF THE SAME OLD TELEPHONE RING? Now you can purchase, through a special television offer, a device that plays the first four portentous notes of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony, complete with lyrics. "AN-swer the PHONE," sings the electronic baritone. "AN-swer the PHONE!"

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Amtrak Adds Incentives For Frequent Riders
description: Amtrak has introduced two incentive programs for frequent riders of the Metroliner and the Empire service in New York State. Members of the programs, called Executive Privileges, qualify for rewards by taking at least four one-way trips each quarter; qualifying trips do not roll over from one quarter to another. Rewards are issued automatically to members every three months and include hotel discounts, MCI prepaid phone cards, a coupon for shopping at Bloomingdale's and free weekend train tickets. For example, four trips in a quarter earn participants a Transmedia restaurant card, a Metroliner or Empire Club Class upgrade and a 20 percent discount at Clarion Hotels.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 4 of the Television section today about the Fox series "New York Undercover" misstates Dick Wolf's title. He is the executive producer, not a co-executive producer.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: FRIDAY

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Corrections
description: The Long Island Q&A column on Feb. 4, an interview with the president of Olympus America about the company's decision to stay on Long Island, misstated his given name. He is Sidney Braginsky, not Stanley.

title: For Arts Audiences, the Question Is Relevance;Jazz in a Coffee Shop
description: To the Editor:

title: Beirut Radio-TV Plan Protested
description: A battle of words has broken out in Lebanon over the Government's plans to tighten control of radio and television stations, most of which first went on the air during the country's 15-year civil war.

title: Disenfranchised Fan
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CENTRAL PARK;Makeshift Bird Feeders: Bane or Boon?
description: They are suspended in the snowy landscape, totems of the intersection of wildlife and urban life. About a dozen homemade bird feeders, fashioned from gallon-size spring water containers, Kitty Litter jugs, dog food cans -- one with a chopstick for a perch -- hang from branches near the Central Park tennis courts between West 93d and West 96th Streets. They are the avian buzz of the park, drawing purple finches, cardinals and sparrows delighted by the free lunch. No one seems certain who put them up, but the Parks Department is not pleased. "It compromises the birds' ability to hunt and forage on their own," insisted Marc Matsil, chief of natural resources. But Norman Stotz, an Audubon Society member familiar with other homemade feeders near East 74th Street, called them a much-needed boon to the birds. "When we have storms like the one a few weeks ago," he said, "their food sources are covered up." CONSTANCE L. HAYS

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about tax deductions for losses due to corporate mistakes misspelled the surname of a professor of accounting and taxation at New York University who noted a distinction between actions involving poor judgment and those reflecting criminal intent. He is Joseph W. Rebovich, not Rebravitch.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;Inner Children
description: Jackie Wullschlger's INVENTING WONDERLAND: The Lives and Fantasies of Lewis Carroll, Edward Lear, J. M. Barrie, Kenneth Grahame and A. A. Milne (Free Press, $24) briskly examines the authors of five classics of British children's literature and offers shrewd assessments of those profoundly eccentric men and their great works. Each of the writers, Ms. Wullschlger says, "needed a child as muse to trigger the adult imagination into creating an extraordinary fantasy. Once locked into this magical world, however, each drew on his own peculiarly strong affinity with childhood." The key there is "peculiarly," because, as she discreetly puts it, "all shared a reluctance to engage in conventional behavior and relationships." The creation of those fantasy lands, she argues, was made possible by, and in turn reflected, "the confidence and prosperity of Britain between 1860 and 1914." It was a confidence that "lasted until the First World War, when to die ceased to be the awfully big adventure that Peter Pan had expected." Ms. Wullschlger, a literary critic and feature writer at The Financial Times in London, thinks that A. A. Milne's work from the 1920's belongs with the others because it was "a throwback" and "nostalgically desperate" for what had been lost. While she is insightful and clear about all five writers, she is particularly good on Edward Lear. She does not hesitate to address Lear's homosexuality, but she insightfully notes that his relationships with children "had none of the anguished, knowing intensity of Carroll's or Barrie's." Lear, she says, "made child-friends and then let them go, as easily and carelessly as a child on holiday would." "The Owl and the Pussycat," that most beloved nonsense lyric about "two odd, sexless, cozy lovers," was written shortly after Lear was talked out of making a proposal of marriage to a much younger woman, she observes, and it is a poem of "hopeful escape." Eden Ross Lipson

title: DINING OUT;A 1990's Trattoria With a Hint of the 80's
description: A DECADE or so ago, an Italian dining spot declared its serious allegiance to the form by printing "Ristorante" on its awning. But in these dress-down days, "Trattoria" conjures the right mood, the desianation implying fresh food and informality.

description: The Williams Gallery in Princeton (Art, page 10) is just one of thousands of Internet sites joining the World Wide Web. Here are some other sites of interest to New Jersey residents. Readers may let the New Jersey section know of others by E-mail to JerseyNYT

description: 17th Annual Juried Photography Exhibition Smithtown Township Arts Council, 660 Rte. 25A, St. James. Through Feb. 25. 862-6575.

description: WITH the stock market soaring to yet more record highs, perhaps no one has a tougher time than a money manager who likes to buy shares that are cheap.

description: Merlot Pellegrini Vineyards, Cutchogue, 1993. About $16.

description: Defining Differences In Titles

description: There are laws preventing psychoanalysts and lawyers from revealing a client's "dirty laundry." According to Rafkin, it seems homeowners do not deserve such privacy.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE;Community Groups Protect the Arts From Extinction in Schools
description: When he was in junior high school on the Lower East Side, Jose Garcia's days were studded with classes in voice, band, art and music appreciation, a creative cornucopia that eventually led him to a stage career. Today, at age 32, he spends one morning a week at a Brooklyn elementary school where there are no such classes.

title: The Vaew From: Irvington;New Orleans Gala With Egyptian Theme Helps Black Colleges
description: IT was a glittering evening, and not just figuratively speaking. Many partygoers arrived in gold lame; those not draped in shimmering stuff had touches of gold encircling their throats, nestled in their hair, dangling from their ears. In the ballroom, light from gilded wall sconces shown on walls and ceilings adorned with intricate gold-leaf designs.

title: WEDDINGS;Adele S. Dwek and Daniel Dubin
description: Adele Suzanne Dwek, the daughter of Sally and Dr. Joe Dwek of Jamaica Estates, Queens, is to be married today to Daniel Dubin, a son of Shelly Dubin of Englewood, N.J., and the late David Dubin. Rabbi Rafael Butler is to officiate at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: In Westminster Show Season, Dogs Are Party Animals
description: IN a city where mountain-climbing, flamenco-dancing and dog-sledding socialites mix and mingle, Iris Love may not seem any more obsessed than any of her peers.

title: For the Kitschmeister in Chief Who Has Everything
description: FORGET the 1996 primaries and their ugly humiliations: Presidents still command plenty of respect. Check out all those commemorative appliance sales on Presidents' Day tomorrow. And how about the exhibit now being prepared at the National Archives in Washington? It will display not only the ornate formal gifts to Presidents from foreign heads of state and other noteworthies, but also thoughtful tributes crafted by ordinary Americans. It opens March 22 and runs until next February.

title: BOOKEND;Brave Little Books Conquer Italy
description: A mini-revolution has swept through Italy's book publishing industry in recent years, and it has even produced a small miracle: paperback sales are up and prices of all kinds of books are down, thanks to an explosion of little books costing, in many cases, less than a daily newspaper. Some say it began with Epicurus, the third-century B.C. Greek, a collection of whose aphorisms swept Italy in 1992, selling a million copies at a time when paperbacks on average sold 20,000 copies.

title: Swedes Haunted by Palme's Killing, Unsolved After 10 Years
description: The bloodstain on the sidewalk has been replaced with a brass plaque in memory of Prime Minister Olof Palme, but 10 years and 18,000 leads later there is still no solution to his murder.

title: DINING OUT;The Look Is French, the Accent Italian
description: FOCACCIA GRILL'S name and menu have an Italian flavor, but its look is classic French. The cozy Wantagh storefront fits the bistro mold with its belle epoch posters, pressed-tin ceilings, turn-of-the-century light fixtures, dark wainscotting, half-curtains at the windows and cloth-topped tables crowned with white butcher paper and votive candles.

title: In the Region/New Jersey;New Law Addresses Both Conservation and Growth
description: LEGISLATION signed into law last month by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman provides local officials with another tool to conserve open space and direct growth.

title: Dog-Fight Crackdown Reveals Animal Cruelty
description: Scores of bleeding bite wounds covered the head and hindquarters of the female German shepherd that a passer-by found dying in front of a church down the block from a housing project in this city's gritty Bayview neighborhood. To animal control officers the pitiful sight was sadly familiar: pit bull bait.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: THE INSTINCT FOR BLISS Short Stories. By Melissa Pritchard. Zoland, $20.95.

title: ART VIEW;Black Artists At Home In Postwar Paris
description: PARIS IN THE YEARS AFTER World War II still evoked la vie de boheme for countless Americans. They cheerfully looked beyond the realities of that convalescent city, where, after liberation, Parisians were the hungriest they had been since the Prussian siege. During the late 1940's, 50's and 60's, American art students went there in droves, lured by the residual fame of the great School of Paris.

title: A Test Case for Special Education
description: As he began first grade in 1991, a boy known in legal papers as E.J. was performing schoolwork at or above grade level. His reading ability placed him in the 99th percentile. But the boy's teacher said he was restless and disruptive, repeatedly touched classmates and sometimes fought with them, blurted out noises and soiled his pants.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Michigan Player Injured
description: Five Michigan basketball players and a recruit all escaped serious injury when their vehicle rolled over while returning from a party in Detroit at 4:50 A.M. today. However, Robert Traylor, the 320-pound starting forward, broke his right arm and will miss the rest of the season.

title: New Rochelle Swimmer Steps Up Her Pace for Olympic Trials
description: CRISTINA TEUSCHER of New Rochelle placed fourth in both the 200-meter freestyle and the 400-meter individual medley at the United States national championships last week in Orlando. For the 17-year-old, two-time national champion, this year's race was more of a tune up for next month's Olympic Trials.

title: WEDDINGS;Miss Robinson, Mr. McLymont Jr.
description: Rekasha Arissa Robinson, a senior counsel at the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, was married yesterday to Felix Frederick McLymont Jr., a private investigator. The Rev. George E. Koury performed the ceremony at Central Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: OUTDOORS;Fish-Out-of-Water Stories Troubling for Ecology
description: When Emory Campbell moved a few collapsed cabinets in the flooded garage of his neighbor Josephine Galvani in the aftermath of the great flood of Jan. 19, he noticed an unusual agitation in a pool of standing water. Looking closely, he discovered a small trout. The fish had apparently been swept from the nearby upper Beaverkill River into the garage at the peak of the flood and left stranded when the water finally receded.

title: FOOTBALL;Brown Of Interest To Others
description: Even though it is all but certain that quarterback Dave Brown will return to the Giants, other teams are expressing interest in the unrestricted free agent.

title: THE NIGHT;A Socialite Souffle At the Met
description: AT the opening of the "Fabepge in America" exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Feb. 13, the guest list of socialites was almost, but not quite, as precious as the 400 objects on display.

description: The police misplaced crucial evidence that might have solved the slaying of 6-year-old Adam Walsh, one of the country's most famous unsolved killings, newspapers reported today, based on newly released files.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST VILLAGE;Voice Against Violence Quits
description: Just three weeks after Matt Foreman became the executive director of the Gay and Lesbian Anti-Violence Project, in January 1990, a man named James Zappalorti was stabbed and beaten to death on Staten Island by two men who thought he was gay. Mr. Foreman's group was soon counseling his family, offering a reward to find his killers and rallying to express outrage.

title: Fetus Is Safe if Mother Ate Fish With Some Mercury, Study Says
description: Pregnant women who eat fish containing low levels of mercury every day apparently do not harm their babies, as many had feared, according to a major new study.

title: Rwanda Refugees May Well Fear Return
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION;A Change in the Weather
description: THEY USUALLY SAVE IT for last or just about last, like dessert or the announcement of best picture at the Academy Awards. It lasts anywhere from two to three minutes, depending on where you live and what's going on that night. Over the years, it has been presented by seductive women in gowns, howling clowns, pigs, fish and puppets. It's the part of the local-news broadcast more people watch than any other. And they watch it as if their lives depended on it, which in some cases they do. It's the silliest and longest-running joke on the air. What else could "it" be but our national lullaby, the nightly weather report.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;Flying One Way At a Time
description: JET TRAIN, a brand-new airline serving Orlando and Pittsburgh from Newark, sells only one-way tickets: Travelers need not stay over Saturday night, or even return on the same carrier, to qualify for its cheap fares. When I flew on the line early this month, I met three travelers who chose Jet Train just for this latitude. I myself chose Sun Jet, another airline, for the return trip.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Astoria, Queens;Where the Piano Meets the Bouzouki
description: UMBRELLAS were the only concession to wind and rain on a recent Saturday afternoon along Astoria's Steinway Street, where a seemingly unending expanse of small shops and eating places of every description fairly bristled with shoppers undeterred by the weather.

title: HOWARD STERN AND THE HIGHBROWS
description: I took great offense at Kakutani's labeling most memoirs today "self-dramatizing confessions." When I was a child, I thought I was the only one in the world growing up in a bizarre household. I have drawn great comfort from reading memoirs by people like Michael Ryan that portray families as troubled as my own. I hope other memoir writers will continue to spill their guts.

title: THE TRIUMPH OF LIBERALISM
description: As a New Deal kid, I have been waiting for Rosenblatt's article for a long time, precisely from the moment during the 1988 Presidential debates when Michael Dukakis stood tongue-tied while George Bush accused him of being a "liberal." I expected the clarion response to come from a professor emeritus. Instead, it has been stated most poignantly and powerfully by an essayist who thinks like a poet.

title: Dispute Expands Over Vision Training
description: SUZANNE MASSER might have been playing a game as she aimed colored pegs at holes in a spinning turntable. But Suzanne, a second-grader at Primrose Elementary School in Somers, was not playing. The turntable exercise, part of a controversial therapy known as vision training, was intended to help strengthen her eyes and improve her performance in school.

title: Streetscapes/Riverview Terrace;East of Sutton Place, a Little Known Enclave
description: THE house at No. 1 Riverview Terrace, a blocklong private street unknown to most New Yorkers, is undergoing its third metamorphosis in over a century. The extensive renovation will bring another change to a little clutch of homes overlooking the East River at East 58th Street, a curious mix of Victorian and postmodern on one of the most unusual streets in New York.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times;This Star Would Shine In New York
description: ISN'T it pretty to think so?" as Hemingway's Jake Barnes once said.

description: IN an effort to break down barriers for the uninitiated, Sotheby's and the Bruce Museum in Greenwich have collaborated to present "The Young Collectors Series," three evenings that attempt to make the collecting process less intimidating.

title: Inviting Lodgings, Luxuriant Land
description: I MIGHT not have gone to Costa Rica if my son, Marc, had not been working there. After a residence of almost two years, he felt it was time we saw his new environment.

description: RAILS ON PAPER

title: A Truck Kills an Officer Detouring Traffic
description: A New York City police officer who was helping to detour traffic after an accident in Brooklyn, died yesterday afternoon after being struck by a truck on the Shore Parkway, officials said.
