description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Linda Stukel, Mitchel Lautenberg
description: Linda Stukel, a daughter of Shirley Warecki and a stepdaughter of Michael Warecki of Inver Grove Heights, Minn., is to be married today to Dr. Mitchel Lautenberg, a son of Saundra Lautenberg of West Orange N.J., and Joel Lautenberg of Chester, N.J. Rabbi Shel Rokofsky officiated with the Rev. B. L. Swertfager, a Lutheran minister, at the Terrace Restaurant in New York.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Rose Plays Ball, Then Throws Barb
description: PETE ROSE returned to baseball -- for a day, anyway -- and did not miss a beat.

title: FROM THE DESK OF: LLOYD M. KRIEGER;Hey, Mac, Don't Fail Me Now!
description: MEMBERS of my computer-savvy generation can be divided into two groups: PC people and Macintosh people. The difference goes beyond what sits on our desks or what we carry in our briefcases. It reflects our attitude about our work and ourselves.

title: Scoundrels and HatemongersTo the Editor:    Richard Gid Powers, in "Not Without Honor: The History of American Anticommunism" (reviewed by Sean Wilentz on Jan. 21), admits that some American  anti-Communists were scoundrels and hatemongers, but says that these people were the exceptions, that those in the mainstream of the anti-Communist crusade spoke the truth and fought the good fight.
description: But I remember vividly when in 1949 a mainstream publication, Life magazine, published its rogues' gallery of American fellow travelers (supposed Communist sympathizers). The list included the Nobel laureates Thomas Mann and Albert Einstein. Mann, like Einstein a refugee from Nazi Germany, left the United States to live in Switzerland. According to Ronald W. Clark in "Einstein: The Life and Times," Einstein considered looking for a country with greater freedom of scholarship, but decided to stay.

title: OFF THE RACK: BRETT BRUNE;When a Portrait Doesn't Include the Wrinkles
description: THE net worth of black families is "just 10 percent that of white families," Worth magazine says in its March issue as it proceeds to describe a black man out to fill the financial chasm between the two races. He is Kelvin Boston, who is the host of a PBS program on personal finance and who wrote "Smart Money Moves for African-Americans," published Jan. 3 by G. P. Putnam's Sons.

title: February 11-17;Network, Rate Thyself
description: Sounding the censorship alarm failed, so last week executives from the four broadcast television networks, along with their cable confreres, buckled down to design their own rating system, similar to the Motion Picture Association of America's code for movies. When Congress's telecommunications reform bill required new TV sets to have a V-chip (a microchip consumers can set to block coded TV shows), the networks threatened First Amendment lawsuits. But they were stymied by the bill's wording, which asks them, not the Government, to rate shows. Devising a reverse "Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval" will be difficult, but political grandstanding over family values has persuaded the networks that it must be done -- preferably before they meet with President Clinton on Feb. 29. LAWRIE MIFFLIN

title: World News Briefs;Islamic Party in Turkey Is Closer to Sharing Power
description: Turkey's Islamic party said today that it was close to a power-sharing agreement with a conservative party and that it would work through a Muslim holiday to try to form a Government.

title: CHINA: PROFIT ... OR PRINCIPLE?;The Chinese Are Coming. Wait. They're Already Here.
description: Early in January a group of Hong Kong's wealthiest tycoons boarded an Air China flight to Beijing for three days of meetings to promote the territory's interests with some of China's most senior officials. The visit reached its climax in a meeting with Li Peng, China's Prime Minister, the man widely regarded as having ordered the 1989 massacre of protesters at Tiananmen Square.

title: INSIDE
description: New Sharansky Forum Natan Sharansky, the former Russian dissident, decided to run for Parlaiment in Israel over the issue of whether Russian immigrants are being made to feel at home. Page 14.

title: 10 at Tiffany's
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;New York-Yugoslavia Air Service to Resume
description: Airline flights between the United States and Yugoslavia, which had been suspended in 1992 when sanctions were imposed by Washington because of the fighting in the breakaway states, will be resumed soon, probably with service between New York and Belgrade.

title: New to the U.S., Back in School;Culturally Lost Parents Join Youths at Newcomer High
description: Reuniting with his family was harder than Gregoire Mutombo expected.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Disney Opens A Florida 'Institute'
description: The Disney Institute, a new Walt Disney Company resort, opened this month in Orlando, Fla. The resort is designed primarily for adults and families with children 10 years and older who want to pursue a variety of hands-on activities ranging from bird-watching to cooking. Vacationers can choose from more than 80 programs in nine areas, including Entertainment Arts, Sports and Fitness, Life Styles, Story Arts, Culinary Arts, Design Arts, Environment, Performing Arts and Youth Programs.

title: DIRTY LAUNDRY
description: I strove to read Louise Rafkin's Lives column, "Dirty Laundry" (Jan. 28), in the spirit of the old (and, by me, lamented) Endpaper page, but my efforts failed and Rafkin's evident seriousness prevailed. She has convinced me and a sizable number of my friends that never, never shall we allow a stranger into our homes to do so much as dust a table unless we are present.

title: I Will Not Show R-Rated Films in School, I Will Not . . .
description: WHILE SOME minors have relatively little problem seeing R-rated films in movie theaters, teachers who show R-rated films in class are finding increasing censure. A report by People for the American Way, a national civil liberties organization, says that more than twice as many complaints were lodged about films shown in the classroom last year than in 1994.

title: The Return of the Liberal
description: They Only Look Dead Why Progressives Will Dominate the Next Political Era. By E. J. Dionne Jr. 352 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.

title: The Grand Illusionist
description: ROBERTSON DAVIES Man of Myth. By Judith Skelton Grant. Illustrated. 787 pp. New York: Viking. $35. WHEN the Canadian writer Robertson Davies died at the age of 82 last December, readers around the globe mourned, but for a reason not noted in the obituaries. Davies's last two novels, both set in Toronto and sharing many of the same characters, had made us hope that there would be a third novel to complete what would have been the fourth of his fictional trilogies -- novels that, whether read independently or as a whole, managed to be both lighthearted in tone and magisterial in scope, at once deeply philosophical and unabashedly slapstick.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;In Contracts, Red Sox Choose Not to Follow The Indians' Example
description: If Mo Vaughn and John Valentin played for the Cleveland Indians, their employer would not have approached their salary arbitration hearings with economic trepidation. That's because if Vaughn and Valentin played for the Indians, they would have been signed for 1996 a couple of years ago and the team would not have faced any arbitration hearings.

title: Under the Smoky Skies of Bamako
description: THERE are bats in the trees of Bamako, Mali. If you are not looking for them, you probably will not notice them, at least not from street level. But they're up there all right, in the trees, hanging in clusters, their squirming not easily noticeable against the movement of the leaves.

title: POLITICS: THE ROUNDUP;G.O.P. Rivals Are Knee-Deep in Snow and Accusations
description: Republican Presidential candidates sniped at one another across southern New Hampshire today, each straining for an accusation or a snippet of film that would provide an edge in the primary voting on Tuesday.

title: COVER STORY;On 'New York Undercover,' the Cops Are Equipped With Attitude
description: THE buzz about Fox's buddy-cop series "New York Undercover" keeps getting louder, like the blare of an oncoming boom box. Entertainment Weekly, in its fall preview issue, called it "TV's funkiest copy show." Last month, midway through the show's second season, Rolling Stone magazine declared it "a genuine underground hit."

title: DANCE VIEW;Glimpses of Diaghilev's Glory Days
description: ANYONE WHO CARES FOR the alliance of dance, music and art will be fascinated by "Diaghilev: Creator of the Ballets Russes," the current exhibition at the Barbican Art Gallery here.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY;A WASP's Tale
description: Louis Auchincloss has modeled his latest novel on the 1918 American classic "The Education of Henry Adams," whose author a friend once called "the only man in the world who could sit on a fence and watch himself go by." Writing in 1975 at the age of 80, the narrator of THE EDUCATION OF OSCAR FAIRFAX (Houghton Mifflin, $22.95) describes his own coming of age with the same ironic detachment. With one grandfather the Episcopal Bishop of New York and the other the founder of an eminent Wall Street law firm, Oscar receives an education that is less sentimental than perfectly decorous, its lessons encouraging Social Register virtues: tact, compromise, genteel humility, excellent manners. After Yale and Columbia Law School, he abandons his dreams of a literary career to join the family legal practice, following his father's advice that it provides the best arena for his "constant preoccupation," people watching. ("He said it didn't matter in which I took the greater interest: the clients or the law.") And there are plenty of opportunities for social observation: a Supreme Court Justice whose opinions on torts and contracts "read like short stories by Henry James"; a gossipy Hungarian princess who hobnobbed with Proust; a talented bounder who wins a partnership in the Fairfax law firm, marriage to Oscar's sister and national prominence in World War II. There is even a cameo appearance by Edith Wharton, Mr. Auchincloss's literary progenitor, showing off the roses in her garden in France. More a series of vignettes than a novel, the book has a few weak spots: the dialogue can be too starched and frilly, and a Spanish daughter-in-law seems to exist only so that Oscar can deliver opinions on Franco. Yet Mr. Auchincloss's own voice remains a seductive one -- crisp, stately and wonderfully controlled. Donna Rifkind

title: Coping With the Aftershocks of a Sponsor's Default
description: THAT Friday night five years ago when a van rolled to the curb and half a dozen process servers bearing stacks of 200-page legal papers climbed out still grips the minds of people at the Acropolis, a 16-building co-op near the towers of the Triborough Bridge in Astoria, Queens.

title: All 20 Bodies Recovered From Crushed Road Tunnel in Japan
description: Rescuers have recovered all 20 bodies of victims crushed by a rock fall in a Japanese road tunnel a week ago, the police said today.

title: The Media Missed the Message
description: Iowa is history," the Republican strategist Ed Rollins told Larry King on CNN. It was Feb. 12, the evening of the caucuses, and within hours nearly all of the 3,000 correspondents and TV crew members who had gathered to cover the event had left the state. Many headed for New Hampshire, whose voters' political values and heritage they will find deeply fascinating until the polls close there, Tuesday night.

title: MAKING IT WORK;Class War at the Garden
description: AT the very moment Pat Verbeek of the New York Rangers scored the first goal against the New York Islanders in the opening minutes of a recent game at Madison Square Garden, two men in pin-striped suits with seats near the ice stood up.

title: In the Region/Long Island;New Limit on Assessment Appeals Protested
description: AS demands for property tax-reform grow more heated on Long Island, an amendment to the real-property tax law that took effect Jan. 1 will make it even more difficult for overassessed property owners to get relief.

title: Bruno F. Straub, Hungarian Ex-President, 82
description: Bruno F. Straub, a scientist who was President of Hungary in the waning days of Communism, died on Thursday, the state radio said. He was 82.

title: BASKETBALL;Nets Turn It Around In Just 2 Minutes
description: The final two minutes belonged to Chris Childs. A thrilling victory belonged to the Nets. And a disappointed locker room belonged to the Knicks.

title: A $40 Million Conceit
description: WHEN California's new money collides with old money, the results can be, well, unsettling.

title: Edmund G. Brown Is Dead at 90; He Led California in Boom Years
description: Edmund G. (Pat) Brown, the former Governor of California who fathered the state's modern economic boom with expansive government programs to build freeways, vast water systems and public universities open to all at low cost, died on Friday at his home here. He was 90.

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 28 about a new album by the Irish rock band Therapy? misidentified the writer of the song "Diane," with a final chorus in which the name Diane turns into the word "dying." He is Grant Hart of Husker Du, not Andrew Cairns of Therapy?.

title: IN THE GARDEN;Even House Plants Like to Slow Down a Bit
description: THIS is a story about an ivy-leaved geranium. It has a happy ending, and instead of the usual "Once upon a time," the story begins at a garden center.

title: 200-Year-Old House Reveals Some of Its Past
description: The artist Axel Horn paints on the ground floor in the former summer kitchen of his 200-year-old farmhouse here. He draws and writes in a second floor room and sculptures in a shed on the property.

title: For Arts Audiences, the Question Is Relevance;Fighters vs. Flutes
description: To the Editor:

title: IDEAS & TRENDS;Love It, Hate It, It's Hollywood
description: IN Billy Wilder's 1950 film "Sunset Boulevard," Joe Gillis, a screenwriter, meets the fading movie star, Norma Desmond, for the first time.

title: Pataki Proposes Sale of Stewart Airport
description: In one of the biggest privatization proposals of his administration, Gov. George E. Pataki wants to sell the 9,600-acre Stewart International Airport in New Windsor, 60 miles north of New York City.

title: EVENING HOURS;Eggs Shine, Designers Shiver
description: Previewing the Faberge show at the Metropolitan, seeking a warm spot at the Council of Fashion Designers awards.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORT GREENE;Pratt Mends Fences and Finances Along With Auditorium
description: Pratt Institute is poised to begin a $2 million renovation of Memorial Hall, a neo-Romanesque auditorium that was shut down in 1988 because of numerous city code violations. And to Pratt's president, Thomas F. Schutte, the hall's revival symbolizes the institute's recovery from a steady hemorrhage in enrollment and money just a few years ago.

title: MUSIC;Keyboard Works, Old and Very New
description: THE keyboard, solo and otherwise, highlights several concerts this week, with three piano programs leading the way this afternoon.

title: QUICK BITE;A Spicey, Garlicky Korean Feast
description: There are Korean delis, and then there are Korean delis. Korea Foods, a tiny shop along the strip of Korean businesses on Palisades Park's main drag, is definitely one of the latter.

title: HOWARD STERN AND THE HIGHBROWS
description: Kakutani uses a broad array of adjectives to describe Howard Stern, calling him rude, vulgar, infantile, exhibitionistic, narcissistic, manipulative and gross. Unfortunately, she leaves out the one adjective that millions of Stern's listeners know describes him best: funny.

title: Families Only
description: To the Editor: Is it time to consider family sections on all intermediate and long-term flights on the major airlines? As more and more adults travel with children, it is obvious that their needs are substantially different from those of adults traveling alone or with other adults.

title: Commercial Property/How Safe Is 'Perc'?;Some Residents Edgy About In-House Dry Cleaners
description: IT is a classic clash of commercial and residental real estate interests, writ small. For decades, the local dry cleaner has been a thread in the neighborhood tapestry. Now, because of environmental concerns, the weave may be fraying.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FOREST HILLS;Home Depot Plan Stirs Fears
description: For years, the industrial area along Woodhaven Boulevard south of Metropolitan Avenue was desolate with abandoned warehouses and a vacant lot owned by the city. But a recent effort by the city's Economic Development Corporation and the borough president's office to develop it into a commercial shopping strip has met with opposition from the community.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BELLEROSE;Longer Trek for Mental Help
description: After the death of her mother in 1989, Barbara Cramer suffered a nervous breakdown and has since required psychiatric therapy at the New York State Mental Health Steinway Clinic. Ms. Cramer, 56, said she has grown fond of her caseworker and with the personalized help, she has been able to live independently despite being diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia.

title: February 11-17;Israel's Timing of Closure
description: Last Monday, fearing that Islamic militants would use the end of Ramadan and the end of the 40-day period of mourning for a slain terrorist known as "the engineer" to launch attacks on Israel, the Israelis imposed what they call a "closure" on the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, barring Palestinians from entering Israel proper. For the Israelis, the justification for the harsh measure was self-evident: security.

title: Rail Europe
description: To the Editor: Following the appearance of your Q & A "The Train in Spain" (Oct. 15), I called Rail Europe for train routes and schedules in Spain. Two weeks later I received a generic package on European intercity service.

title: Plan for Luxury Mall In Syosset Advances
description: DESPITE some concerns, plans for a one-million-square-foot shopping mall in Syosset, aimed largely at affluent shoppers, are moving forward.

title: One Swimmer's Quest to Stay on the Team
description: AT every swim meet, David Dennin anchors one of the Trumbull High School's free style relays. He steps up to the blocks, gets ready for the start and takes off. He is invariably the slowest person in the pool but you'd never know it from the applause that thunders across the pool, both teams clapping, waving towels, urging him on.

title: CHINA: PULLING TOGETHER ... OR COMING APART?;Class Climbing
description: Exploding economic growth is introducing new wealth and values in China and even eroding the bedrock of society, the family. Consider the Gao family of Nanjing, a city of 2.2 million residents about 200 miles from the mouth of the Yangtze River. The father, Gao Made, 76, is a professional painter, and the mother, Chen Ruqing, 70, is an art designer. As artists and intellectuals, they have benefited from the economic changes.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: LONG AGO LOVER

title: It's Man Over Machine as Chess Champion Beats Computer He Calls Tough Opponent
description: Just before his 40th move in the sixth and final game of his match against Deep Blue, the world's strongest chess computer, Garry Kasparov, the world's strongest human chess player, picked up his watch from the table and put it back on his wrist.

title: VOWS;Wendyll Brown and John Farber
description: WHEN Wendyll Brown, 37, appeared before the 150 guests at her wedding on Feb. 3, several people said they were surprised to see her in silk high-heel shoes rather than in running sneakers. She was also wearing a wispy gown, a dainty pearl necklace and petite Victorian-style earrings. Her hair was in a tight French twist.

title: EARNING IT;Quiet on the Home Front: Restlessness in the 90's
description: THREE years ago, Sandy Baird left the corporate world and set up a public relations company in her San Diego home. It was a good move. Her business is thriving, and her life has never been better.

title: Is Diamond Toning Down? And What of 'Black Radio'?
description: To the Editor:

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Annals of Declassification;Nuclear Secrets Worth Keeping
description: DIAGRAMS of nuclear weapons are available to anyone with access to the Internet, and earlier this month the United States Government published an accounting of every bit of bomb fuel it ever made, and where it all went, nearly down to the last ounce. The Energy Department even has an Internet web page where people hungry for nuclear secrets can search through abstracts of once-classified documents and learn how to order the full documents for free; if they are brief enough, the Government will fax the documents out.

title: Orphan Park' Is Getting Some Family Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;Some Label All-Night Deli 'Drug' Store
description: The choreography of drug dealing on the northeast corner of 106th Street and Amsterdam Avenue is galling enough to locals and passers-by.

title: Surveillance Cameras Monitor Comings and Goings in Roslyn
description: DRIVE by the ranch-style homes that dot the sleepy streets of the Roslyn Country Club section of Roslyn Heights, and you may get the feeling you're being watched.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: IN BRIEF;Changes Wait in the Wings As a Theater Is Sold
description: Last summer, Robert Andres approached Alberta Handelman about renting space to show art films at the Blooming Grove Theater in Montclair, which she owned. Her response was: "Do you want to buy it?" So he did.

title: WEDDINGS;Laura Landro, Richard Salomon
description: Laura Landro, a senior editor at The Wall Street Journal in New York, was married Friday to Richard E. Salomon, the president of Spears, Benzak, Salomon & Farrell Inc., an investment advisory company in New York. Don Johnson, the senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony at the couple's home in New York.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: FOR A HANDFUL OF FEATHERS By Guy de la Valdne. Atlantic Monthly, $18.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: FLATIRON DISTRICT;Waiting for the Iron Curtain to Rise
description: THE Ubu Repertory Theater has a mission: to acquaint American audiences with contemporary French-language plays by presenting them in translation. The current work, "Always Together," which runs through next Sunday, is a partly autobiographical drama by Anca Visdei, a Romanian-born writer now living in Paris.

title: INVESTING IT;Tenneco's Big Shipyard May Soon Sail Off Solo
description: WHAT'S a good used shipyard worth?

title: That First Job
description: Making deviled egges at the local deli. Getting file-card finger as a summer researcher for your history professor. Unpacking box after box of boots at the local Florsheim's. First jobs may offer little prestige, but they hold vivid memories -- like that first paycheck. If your have a story about your debut in the world of work, sent it to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 227 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 18, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Toyota RAV4;A Cute Brute Rocks to an MTV Beat
description: A FRIEND'S daughter bounded into their kitchen and asked which family vehicle she could have for the day: the luxury sedan, the sport utility vehicle, or, heaven forbid, the mini-van.

title: Madrid Dangers
description: To the Editor: Travelers should be warned about Madrid. As a result of my trip to Spain in October, I enthusiastically recommend Granada, Toledo and Seville. The beauties of Madrid are many, but our visit was marred by a plague of theft.

title: Where Students Teach Students
description: THERE will be a need for about two million qualified teachers in the United States over the next decade, according to the National Commission on Teaching and America's Future, a nonprofit research group based at Teachers College of Columbia University.

title: History Trip
description: To the Editor: John Dornberg's "What's Doing in Munich" (Dec. 3) reminded me of my stay in Munich on a frosty December a few years back. My colleagues spent hours admiring the Christkindl Market, but before joining them I took the fast train and then a bus to visit the Dachau concentration camp. There I encountered a young German, and we walked together over the snow-covered ground of horrors. He was aghast and ashamed. This is to suggest that a visit to the camp, a few miles from the city center, should be added to the list of what to do when in Munich.

title: Phis Carnegie Debut Breaks the Mold
description: Every season a new crop of musicians walk, run or are pushed onto the stage of America's most revered concert hall in a hallowed rite of passage called the Carnegie Hall debut recital. The performers are almost always young and ambitious. For those who have already made their marks elsewhere, the Carnegie debut lends cachet to a burgeoning reputation. Those as yet unknown hope that spending two hours in Carnegie Hall's spotlight will help them achieve what thay want most: a career as a performer.

title: BENEFITS
description: Citizens Committee Honors TUESDAY -- Edgar Bronfman Jr., the president of the Seagram Company, and the columnist Liz Smith will be among those honored at the New Yorker for New York Award dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria. The Boys Choir of Harlem will also receive an award, and it and Bobby Short will perform. The black-tie event will benefit the Citizens Committee f'r New York City, which supports neighborhood organizations. Cocktails at 7 P.M. Tickets, $500, from (212) 685-1095.

title: GOOD EATING;Just a Short Stroll From Madison Sq.
description: AN AMERICAN PLACE *** (212) 684-2122; 2 Park Avenue, (entrance on 32d Street); $$$(c) all major credit cards

title: THE TRIUMPH OF LIBERALISM
description: I could not tell whether Roger Rosenblatt's essay "The Triumph of Liberalism" (Jan. 14) was a satire or not. His thesis reminded me of our Government's resolution to the failure of its Vietnam policy: declare a victory and get out.

title: Four Hands, One Bench, Still Married
description: MARRIED to each other for 47 years, Jean and Kenneth Wentworth have an unusually close relationship -- literally. They have shared the same piano bench since the beginning. As duo pianists, they also share a reverence for a special form of musical literature.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Feb. 4 with a listing of cruises misidentified the port in Bermuda where the Dreamward was shown. It was St. George's, not Hamilton.

title: Always an Adviser, Now a Bride: The 'I Dos' And 'I Don'ts'
description: MARCY BLUM, one of New York's better-known wedding consultants, has an unusual wedding album, especially for someone in the bridal business.

title: Board of Education: A Thing of the Past?
description: The readiness of state and city leaders to dismantle New York City's 26-year-old decentralized system of local school boards is one of those transforming moments in a city's history, but, as with many overhauls, New York City has been over this territory before.

title: New Yorkers & Co.
description: Keeping Your Cigars In a Good Humidor

title: ATLANTIC CITY;Captain of the Showboat
description: IN the last few months, Herbert R. Wolfe, 55, a sad-eyed casino executive who takes his lunch in the company cafeteria and says he buys his suits at Syms, has become a hot property.

title: MUSIC;Trios and Quartets Fill Niche for Concerts
description: TRIOS and quartets play a prominent role in this week's events with the Arden and Venus Trios appearing today and next Sunday, respectively, and the Tokyo and Brentano String Quartets similarly positioned.

title: BASKETBALL;Knicks Are Close to a Trade
description: The Knicks were reportedly close to trading Doug Christie and Herb Williams to the Toronto Raptors, in exchange for Willie Anderson and Victor Alexander.

title: More on Magic
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FILM VIEW;Higher Style From Hong Kong's Masters
description: IT IS CLEAR FROM THE FIRST scene in John Woo's new film, "Broken Arrow," an action epic about an Air Force commander gone AWOL with two nuclear weapons, which character will be the villain and which the hero. Sparring with his fellow pilot Christian Slater in a boxing ring, John Travolta says he is a fan of boxing. "I always liked Bruce Lee movies," Mr. Slater retorts.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Huskies Pick Up Momentum And Game
description: Connecticut may be the third-ranked men's team in the nation behind Massachusetts and Kentucky, but for the first half of the first half today it played ordinary basketball. Notre Dame played well, beat the Huskies' fullcourt trapping defense, hit four 3-point shots and led by 22-17.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT/Page 3/ With Tenneco now busy cleaning house, investors may soon have to decide what a share in the company's shipyard will be worth. By James Sterngold.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;In the Big Picture, Just a Small Victory
description: For about 15 minutes in the second half of the game between St. John's and Seton Hall at Madison Square Garden last night, there was the kind of excitement in the air from the bygone time when these a meeting between these two Big East rivals meant something.

title: THEATER;Backstage at a Hit: Memories Are Made of This
description: WHEN THE REVIVAL OF William Inge's 1955 play "Bus Stop" opens at Circle in the Square on Thursday, the audience and friends won't be the only ones in attendance. Memories will take up quite a few seats. For 478 performances, "Bus Stop" was the buzz of Broadway. The play that followed Inge's Pulitzer Prize-winning "Picnic" by two years, it was considered a surprise departure from his earlier, family-based dramas.

title: Q and A
description: Vacations for the Disabled

title: In the Region/Westchester;A Preview of Coming Attractions for White Plains
description: DECLARING Westchester County to be underscreened, a major movie-theater company has joined forces with a county developer to build a multiplex in the heart of this city's downtown.

title: Winter Break, and the Schedule Is Full
description: THE sound of school doors closing for winter break need not be an ominous one for parents wondering how to fill the many hours of free time their children will be granted this week.

title: HOME CLINIC;Restoring Damaged Plaster Molding
description: STEAM heating is the hydronic heating system that uses steam to carry the heat from the furnace into the rest of the house.

title: TENNIS;Rising Star Tries to Conquer the Late Lapses
description: It's all about patterns for Chanda Rubin, or more accurately, breaking patterns.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE;Guardian Angel Of Ave. D Retires After a Last Clash
description: Dr. Joseph I. Kramer took early retirement. Ninety minutes early.

title: SPENDING IT;Few Financial Walls Against the Floods
description: THE blizzard and heavy rains in the Northeast last month caused more than $1 billion in insured losses, but a lot of other damage went uncovered because most people didn't have flood insurance.

title: FUNDS WATCH;Popularity Isn't Everything
description: When it comes to investing in mutual funds, going against the grain can pay off big, according to the fund analysts at Morningstar Inc. in Chicago.

title: IN PERSON;The Art of a Lifetime
description: ART has to live in our minds first," Joe Overstreet says. "Then we see it."

title: Partygoers To Have Expanded Free Cabs
description: IT was after 3 A.M. on a Sunday last month when Louis Stoltenborg, 21, of Bay Shore, and his next-door neighbor realized that they needed a ride home.

title: Who'll Deliver the Milk In the Vehicle-Free City?
description: To the Editor:

title: Danger Was a Passenger
description: A reconstruction of a New Jersey Transit engineer's last 24 hours offers insights into the crash that killed him and two others. Page 37.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SUNSET PARK;Innovative Ear for Business
description: Concealed in a cream-colored, three-story house along a graffiti-covered slice of Seventh Avenue is a production complex where looks are played down and sound is played up.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-15

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;The Ecstasy Of Rhythm, For New Ears
description: THERE'S NO SUCH THING AS PURE RHYTHM. From a simple handclap to the elaborate human-and-machine beat of a Mariah Carey song, every percussive sound has a pitch, a tone and a contour, not just a time value. Drums can boom or crunch, skitter or hum; impact gives them many different voices.

title: On Language;Please Pass the Plural Pease
description: TODAY IT'S STRICTLY eat-your-peas, with no going off on parenthetical tangents. (Peas, which we now take to be the plural of pea, was originally pease, a dishful of the vegetable; when somebody in the 17th century stuck his fingers in a dish of pease and picked out an individual component, he said, "I'll call this a pea, without the s, because it's only one." That creation of the singular from the plural is a form of "back-formation." Most people think that language is orderly, and that one pea led to a plateful of peas, a good reason not to listen to most people.)

title: Snow Sport Ends in Death
description: A teen-ager being towed in an inner tube behind a car was killed early today after he collided with a parked car, the police said.

title: Sports of The Times;On Maryland Campus, It Doesn't Hit the Spot
description: HERE'S another thing that is ethically wrong with big-time college sports: no good parking spots for student-athletes. Bring a poor kid in to play ball, pull some strings to get him a car, then where the heck is he supposed to put it?

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Barcelona
description: If Atlanta needs any reassurance about its decision to be host to the Olympic Summer Games this year, it should look to the last host city, Barcelona, which is still reaping dividends from the 1992 Summer Games as a makeover of the city continues unabated.

title: February 11-17;It's Not Good but It's Done
description: A Manhattan jury concluded last week that one simple word carried more weight than half-a-million overwrought ones. No matter how terribly written the manuscript by the actress Joan Collins, said the jury, she did partially fulfill her two-book contract with Random House. That is because her publisher neglected to require that her manuscript be, in the industry's boilerplate protection clause, "satisfactory" -- only "complete."

title: Habitats/East Side, West Side?;A Newlywed Solution
description: SOME people are dog people. Some people are cat people. Some people are East Side people. Some are West Side people.

title: No Headline
description: It's one thing to be very conservative, which I am, and another thing to be a little kooky."

title: TENNIS;Sampras Advances to Final
description: Pete Sampras is a victory away from being No. 1 again after enduring what he dreads most -- a tie breaker -- to complete a 7-6 (8-6), 6-3 victory over Jan Kroslak in the Sybase Open semifinals today.

title: China: On the Edge...of What?
description: It all began with Deng Xiaoping's shocking declaration that "to get rich is glorious," the rough equivalent of Ronald Reagan exhorting the workers of the world to unite. By now, bang has accelerated into boom, as if China wants to make up for centuries of underdevelopment in one breathless dash.

title: Serena's Song Wins
description: Serena's Song breezed to a 1 1/4-length victory over Twice the Vice in the $155,800 Santa Maria Handicap today at Santa Anita, setting up a possible confrontation with the 1995 Horse of the Year, Cigar.

title: DIRTY LAUNDRY
description: I enjoyed reading about Rafkin's experiences. I never really thought about how much a housekeeper learns about her clients just by doing her job. I, too, was going to teach American lit, but I went into textbook publishing instead. I think Rafkin's job is much more interesting than mine, though. She's a real spy, in disguise.

title: Frank Vincent's Two-Limo Night
description: BY all accounts Frank Vincent was a good drummer. His long musician period began in the 1960's, a frenzied time when he got married, had two children and drank, flirting and playing his way through most every nightclub and recording studio in New York. During the day he would do studio work with acts like Paul Anka, Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme, Del Shannon, the Duprees and others. At night he would play with some incarnation of his own band, called "Frank Vincent and the Aristocats."

title: ART;Remember That Weird Stuff Students May Have Had in the 70's?
description: IT was a canny decision to mount a show distinguished by ephemerality just now at Real Art Ways in Hartford.

title: ON THE STREET;Let It Glow, Let It Glow, Let It Glow
description: They look like highly polished sterling silver tea cozies, the down-filled silver jackets many New Yorkers are cocooning in this winter.

title: POP VIEW;Second Acts for Aging Rockers
description: DO POP STARS' LIVES HAVE SECOND acts? That's the question raised by two musical revues recently staged in New York City. In "20th Century Man: An Evening With Ray Davies," now at the Westbeth Theater Center, the leader of the British rock group the Kinks intersperses hilarious and poignant re'dings from "X-Ray," his self-described "unauthorized autobiography," with songs from the first third of his three-decade-plus career. And in "20th Century Pop . . . a Musical Celebration," presented last month at Rainbow and Stars, the singers Marianne Faithfull, Darlene Love and Merry Clayton gave a reprise of the high -- and low -- points of their careers in a show that extolled their survival as women in the music industry.

title: Judo Expert, Olympics Bound Once More
description: FOR Darlene (Poochie) Montgomery, sooner would have been better. But later is better than not at all.

title: Yeltsin Ouster Of TV Chief Stirs a Storm
description: Almost immediately after telling voters that he is Russia's best hope for reform, President Boris N. Yeltsin has undercut his re-election campaign message by sparking concerns that he is trying to muzzle the media.

title: WEDDINGS;Laura J. Kostel, Matthew B. Fahey
description: Laura Julia Kostel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Kostel of Williamsburg, Va., was married yesterday to Matthew Brine Fahey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Fahey of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Robert Marston officiated at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Newport News, Va. The Rev. Richard Clifford, a Roman Catholic priest, participated in the ceremony.

title: Correction
description: An article in some copies last Sunday about plans to build the Mohegan Sun Casino and Resort in Montville, Conn., misstated the identity of the executive alleged by Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut to have paid a bribe 10 years ago to open a casino in the South African black homeland of Transkei. The Sun International executive was Sol Kerzner. It is his son Howard Kerzner who is involved in the Connecticut casino.

title: Israel's Second City
description: TOURS of Israel usually give Tel Aviv short shrift. A few days at the beginning or the end and that's that. This was my third tour over a period of 20 years, and it was still Jerusalem the Golden that got most of the attention and almost all the respect. In Jerusalem malls at night, even carousing kids wear yarmulkes, and people on the street stare at you if you're a grown woman walking around in pants. Compared with all this piety, the mood in Tel Aviv is stunningly secular. In this city, which variously calls itself the Big Orange, the City That Never Stops, and the City That Never Takes a Break (who writes their p.r., I wonder?), it's hard to imagine anyone looking at you askance about anything. This is the contemporary version of the vision that Theodor Herzl, the founder of Zionism, had of a cosmopolitan city on the sea: Tel Aviv -- literally a hill (man-made) of spring (new life). Where once there was absolutely nothing, there is now an urban sprawl of about 350,000 people -- nearly two million if you count suburbs -- and a lot of awful architecture that springs up from a flat terrain with nowhere to hide. I suppose that depending on whether you come here first or last on a trip to Israel, you say, "Look what they've accomplished," or "My God,what have they done?"

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Find a Happy Ending for Homestand
description: This weekend, the Islanders can at least go to dinner with their families and not, in the words of Patrick Flatley, "get those slanted looks" from everyone in the restaurant.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: THE WORLD: America's Burden;At Hour of Triumph, Democracy Recedes As the Global Ideal
description: THROUGHOUT the world's longest experiment with democratic government, America has always thought of itself as morally obliged to export its way of life. What the White Man's Burden was to Kipling's generation of Englishmen, the promotion of democracy has been to four generations of Americans -- the foreign policy equivalent of apple pie. Ever since Woodrow Wilson vowed to make the world safe for democracy, most Presidents have rhetorically endorsed this goal.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Eastern Front
description: WHEN TITANS CLASHED How the Red Army Stopped Hitler. By David M. Glantz and Jonathan M. House. Illustrated. 414 pp. Lawrence: University Press of Kansas. $29.95.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOUGLASTON;Last Community Chest Shuts
description: Mention Community Chest to most people and the board game Monopoly comes to mind. But in a bygone era, the Community Chest was an invaluable resource for charities that didn't have the means to raise money on their own.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Helping Homeless In Winter
description: South Windham, Conn., $200 from Roger C. Biron of Leonia, N.J., and $100 from Stanley Rosenfeld of Manhattan in December. All asked that their gifts go to help people without homes.

title: Mountains of the Mind
description: Death in the Andes By Mario Vargas Llosa. Translated by Edith Grossman. 276 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24.

description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST SIDE;Keep Low-Rise Chelsea Tall on Character, Board Says
description: Concerned that unchecked development could spoil the character of Chelsea, Community Board 4 is urging the city to limit the height of new buildings on and around lower Eighth Avenue while allowing larger ones between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue. The condition for larger buildings would be that a percentage of the units go to low- and middle-income tenants.

title: ARTS IN LOS ANGELES;The Mark Taper Is Not Moving
description: To the Editor:

title: February 11-17;Bosnia Arrests Shake Dayton Peace Accords
description: The War Crimes Tribunal at The Hague didn't make the job of NATO commanders in Bosnia any easier last week.

title: Friend or Foe?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jail Letters Of Dissident In China Are Defiant
description: When China's leaders ordered the police to seize the country's leading dissident, Wei Jingsheng, two years ago and confiscate his notes and computer files, they presumably figured that they had silenced him.

title: No Bums' Rush
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: New Debate On Penalties For Juvenile Offenders
description: THIS month's sentencing of Hopeton Minott, a former Mount Vernon High school student convicted of stabbing to death a classmate in 1994, has further intensified the debate over how best to deal with youths who commit serious crimes.

title: WEDDINGS;Susan J. Wyland, Norman N. Lanes
description: Susan Jayne Wyland, the editor of the magazine Martha Stewart Living in New York, and Dr. Norman Neil Lanes, a cardiologist and internist in New York, were married last evening. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel performed the ceremony at the Tillman Chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations in New York.

title: On the Edge
description: ENDANGERED DREAMS The Great Depression in California. By Kevin Starr. Illustrated. 402 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $35.

title: Lives;His Accident
description: Sometimes, when I have been away from my husband for a few days, I have this fantasy. It happens when I am driving a car, pulling up slowly to a red light. I imagine -- to that dazed and terrifying point of near reality that characterizes the deepest dreams -- that I press my foot violently down on the gas pedal. The impact shoots up to my hip as the sudden acceleration rams me firmly into the back of the seat.

title: Gustave Solomon, Mathematician, Is Dead at 65
description: Gustave Solomon, a mathematician whose work was important in the world of digital information, died on Jan. 31 at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 65 and had lived in the Los Angeles area since 1961.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;Survey Finds Travel Tax Rarely Goes to Tourism
description: EVERYONE knows that travel is taxing, but a good indication of how taxing can be gleaned from the recent report, "Travel Taxes in America's Top Destinations," a survey conducted for the Travel and Tourism Government Affairs Council in 50 cities from Anaheim, Calif., to West Palm Beach, Fla. The cities are those with the largest number of hotel rooms.

title: EARNING IT;Retiring? Check Over The Boss's Arithmetic
description: WHEN Bruce A. Durant was pondering early retirement last summer, his employer, United Parcel Service of America, gave him a signed statement showing that his monthly pension would be $2,623.

title: Swoosh and Stripes Has Banner Year
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Cocaine Use Soared Despite Prohibition
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding a Qualified House Inspector
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE;Club Is Still Late, But Now Legal
description: For some nightclub denizens and barflies, 4 A.M., the city's legal cutoff for serving alcohol, is just too early for last call. Dozens of illegal after-hours clubs cater to their early-morning cravings. For more than a decade one of the most famous, Save the Robots, was run behind a nondescript doorway on Avenue B near Second Street. It was a haven for East Villagers, club kids, drag performers, skinheads and sundry insomniacs.

title: IN THE KITCHEN;Pears, Cranberries and Chocolate for Dessert
description: AT this time of year, produce stands are filled with berries, peaches and apricots from other climates, but for desserts these are expensive and not necessarily satisfying choices.

title: The Top Colleges Are Reporting Record Numbers of Applications
description: The nation's prestigious colleges are being flooded with record numbers of applications as high school seniors increasingly worry about getting into the top tier, admissions officers say.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 18, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

title: Bill Linder And His City Of Hope
description: KENDELE BASKERVILLE, 20, in a navy-blue security-guard uniform, is a New Community man. He got his job through the New Community Corporation. He works in a supermarket run as a partnership between Pathmark and New Community in Newark's beleaguered Central Ward. He is getting a high school diploma with the help of New Community staff members. His uniform is made by New Community's fashion institute, its green NCC logo -- on fleets of vans, the front of the monthly newsletter, apartment buildings and restaurant menus -- symbolizing hope and new beginnings.

title: He Spoke Out of Turn; Local Justice Landed Hard
description: To the Editor:

title: Danger Rode on New Jersey Transit Engineer's Coveted Shift
description: It was just past 7 A.M. on Feb. 9, and John J. DeCurtis was planning to knock off work and go home. His night shift as a New Jersey Transit engineer had officially ended when he pulled his train into the Hoboken station, and Mr. DeCurtis, a quiet man who dedicated his free time to cars and boats, wanted to stop in at his son's auto repair shop on Staten Island before heading to his own house nearby.

title: Floridians Sue to Void Assisted-Suicide Ban
description: Three terminally ill people and a group led by the American Civil Liberties Union have filed suit to try to overturn Florida's ban on doctor-assisted suicide.

title: Germs in the Air
description: To the Editor: Another letter about the Practical Traveler, "In an Airplane, Sharing Germs" (Dec. 3). I returned recently from a needed vacation on Aruba. On my flight, there were at least a half dozen people with head colds, all seated close to me. I now have a cold.

title: The Devil's Lexicographer
description: AMBROSE BIERCE Alone in Bad Company. By Roy Morris Jr. 306 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $30. THE journalist and short-story writer Ambrose Bierce was a master of pithy cynicism. His acrid sayings, collected in "The Devil's Dictionary," have a blackly humorous sting that can make even jaded moderns wince. Witness some of his definitions: "BIRTH, n. The first and direst of all disasters"; "RELIGION, n. A daughter of Hope and Fear, explaining to Ignorance the nature of the Unknowable"; "BRIDE, n. A woman with a fine prospect of happiness behind her"; "POSITIVE, adj. Mistaken at the top of one's voice"; "LAWYER, n. One skilled in circumvention of the law"; "SELF-ESTEEM, n. An erroneous appraisement."

title: New Details on Fatal Fire
description: As marshals arrested a second man in the death of Firefighter Louis Valentino, they also released new details about the chain of events that led to the blaze that killed him.

title: AUTO RACING;Dale Jarrett Overpowers Conspirators And Earnhardt
description: Deals, conspiracies, fleeting friendships or whatever else one may call them, not one of them was enough today to overcome the raw horsepower that helped Dale Jarrett win his second Daytona 500.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-7

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;$1 Million to Repair Potholes
description: A winter that has seesawed between freezing temperatures and unseasonable thaws inevitably has wreaked extensive damage on New Jersey roadways. But drivers need not fear the worst. The Department of Transportation plans to spend more than $1 million to have private contractors fix the potholes, the A.P. reported yesterday.

title: Evelyn Laye, Comic Actress, 95
description: Evelyn Laye, a British musical comedy star whose 80-year career included appearances on Broadway, died on Saturday at a nursing home in London. She was 95.

title: Brownie McGhee, 80, Early Piedmont Bluesman
description: Brownie McGhee, the blues guitarist and singer who brought fingerpicking Piedmont blues to an international audience, died on Friday at Summit Hospital in Oakland, Calif., where he lived. He was 80.

title: POLITICS: LOOKING TO ECONOMICS;Dole, Stung in 1988, Charts Cautious Economic Course
description: When he was running for President eight years ago, Bob Dole offered bitter medicine to reduce the deficit: an across-the-board freeze for one year on all Federal spending. And he lost the New Hampshire primary.

title: BASEBALL;Cuban Pitcher Gambles On a Major League Life
description: Osvaldo Fernandez, like thousands of Cuban baseball players, had no real working knowledge of major league baseball.

title: Abraxas Considers a Sale
description: The Abraxas Petroleum Corporation said Friday that it was in talks about the possible sale of some oil-producing properties for more than $12 million. The oil and gas exploration and production company said it would use proceeds from a possible sale to pay off debt and to pursue the acquisition of other oil assets. The company did not disclose the party with which it is in talks.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;From a Diva and Choir, Hope, Sass and Obbligatos
description: It's no wonder that black opera divas from Marian Anderson to Jessye Norman have extended their repertories to include spirituals. The songs have indelible melodies, honed by generations of tradition while they salute an African-American legacy. And spectacular vocal displays are as much a part of gospel music as they are of opera. Grace Bumbry, the internationally known mezzo-soprano, has taken the connection further. She has started the Grace Bumbry Black Musical Heritage Ensemble, a choir that sang spirituals and gospel songs at Carnegie Hall on Friday night.

title: Fire Widows Share A Kinship of Grief;For Survivors, 'There Are No Guidelines'
description: In telephone calls that stretch into hours, in encounters at street namings and wakes, a widening network of New York City "fire widows" sort through the fallout of their firefighter husbands' sudden, violent and public deaths.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Divided on the Deficit
description: When it comes to spending, New Jersey's congressional delegation is split. Last year, slightly more than half of its members voted to reduce the Federal deficit, while the rest sought net spending increases, a conservative watchdog group has reported.

title: Dublin Stops Statoil From Takeover Deal
description: The Irish Government has blocked the takeover by Norway's state-owned Statoil of 257 gas stations owned by Conoco's Jet unit after a review of the proposed deal.

title: Clinton Girls Win in Track
description: DeWitt Clinton of the Bronx won its first girls' Public Schools Athletic League track title, and Brooklyn Tech captured the boys' crown yesterday at the Armory Track and Field Center.

title: POLITICS: THE ROUNDUP;Pledges, Accusations and Appeals As First Primary Vote Draws Near
description: Senator Bob Dole won a high-profile endorsement. Patrick J. Buchanan turned his attacks on the "knights and barons" of the Republican Party. Steve Forbes appealed for votes from anti-abortion forces. And Lamar Alexander reiterated his opposition to the ban on assault weapons.

title: Colombia Chief Denies He Spoke of Quitting
description: The office of President Ernesto Samper denied today that he had said "that he is seeking at this time the capacity to leave in a dignified form from the presidency."

title: Markets Closed
description: All financial and commodity markets and banks in the United States are closed today in observance of Washington's Birthday. Most overseas markets are open.

title: Child Abuse Charges for 2
description: A Bronx woman and her boyfriend were arrested yesterday after the woman's 2-year-old daughter was found with cuts, bruises and possibly a broken arm and hand, the police said.

title: Bomb in London Bus Kills 1 and Injures 7
description: A double-decker bus exploded in the center of London's theater district late Sunday night, sending glass and metal debris flying, killing one person and injuring at least seven others, the authorities said.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Some Big Individual Donors Aid Fund
description: There are many people like Joan L. Downes of Baldwin, L.I., who gave $50, and Doris R. Gordon of Greenwich, Conn., who could afford $100. But there are only a handful of people like Mark Seaman of Staten Island, who was able to send $3,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund this year to help provide housing for the homeless, food for the hungry, and medicine for the sick.

title: Fight for Life of a Helpless, Brain-Damaged Man Goes to the SupremeCourt
description: In January 1987, as Mary and Michael Martin were taking their three children out for dinner in Moline, Mich., a train hit their family car, killing their middle child, Melanie, and leaving Mr. Martin with such catastrophic injuries that he cannot walk, talk, roll over, eat or perform basic bodily functions on his own.

title: Sports of The Times;Childs Thinks He Can . . . and So Do the Nets
description: HE was thinking clearly, thinking relaxed this is the Chris Childs of today, the sober Chris Childs -- thinking he had nothing to lose when he let fly with a 3-pointer, which found its mark and tied the score at 77-77 deep into the fourth quarter.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: SKIING;Street Takes Downhill At World Competition
description: With United States skiers taking three of the top five spots, Picabo Street won the downhill today to become the first American woman to win an event at the world championships.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: LONDON THEATER;A Farcical Freud Meets Disciple Dali
description: The man with the beard is in his 80's, but he thinks fast and is quick on his feet. In an attempt to clothe the naked young woman he's hidden in the closet, he tries to remove the trousers of the fellow who's lying on the floor, accidently rendered unconscious by a blow to the head. Just as he's worked the trousers down to the fellow's knees, his doctor barges in, doing a double take. "You and I," the doctor says gravely, "have to have a serious chat." Explains the elderly man, "He was complaining of abdominal pains."

title: Better Yeltsin in Russia Than Anybody Else
description: To the Editor:

title: G.I.'s Guide to Bosnia
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Plan to Sell Water Company
description: Residents of Flemington may find themselves paying twice as much for water if the borough accepts an offer to sell its water company to the privately owned Elizabethtown Water Company, officials said. In addition to bringing in revenue, selling off the water company would provide Flemington, which now gets most of its water from wells, with a more reliable source in the event of a drought, said Joseph Novick, a Flemington Borough councilman. The sale would also free the borough from future expenses for such things as pipes, he added.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Slow Recovery, or a Shift In the Business Cycle? The greater New York region has recovered only about a third of the 770,000 jobs it lost in the most recent recession, and it shows no sign of quickly regaining the rest. The phenomenon has shaken faith in the long-held belief in the area that the business cycle is eternal and that when an economic downturn is over, old-fashioned growth will resume. [Page A1.]

title: Shareholders Shrugging Off Milwaukee Media Buyout Bid
description: The employee-owners of Journal Communications Inc., which owns The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel and half a dozen subsidiaries, have shown little interest so far in an investment group's offer to pay nearly double the current trading price for their stock.

title: BASEBALL;Advice Is Everywhere for Thompson, the Nowhere Met
description: When Bob Thompson awoke this morning, the first thing he did was get on his knees to say a prayer. In the quiet of his hotel room, he asked God to give him the words that his son Ryan needed to hear as he begins a spring training and a season that could make or break his major league career.

title: Clear Channel To Buy Stations
description: Clear Channel Communications Inc. said Friday that it had reached a definitive agreement to acquire three Grand Rapids, Mich., radio stations from Wood Radio L.P. for $42.3 million in cash.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Monday about reports of forced labor in Bosnia misspelled the surname of an official for the International Committee of the Red Cross who said that most of the forced laborers had been freed. She is Ann-Sophie Bonefeld, not Bonfeld.

title: POLITICS;In Their Own Words
description: LAMAR ALEXANDER

title: BASEBALL;Raines Self-Aware And Raring To Run
description: Tim Raines is honest and affable and freely provides an expansive scouting report on himself. Do not expect him to win a Gold Glove award in left field, rush into a new clubhouse and try replacing Don Mattingly as the unchallenged leader on the Yankees or win another batting title.

title: Apartheid's Fall Opens Door to Scourge of Cocaine
description: On a weekday afternoon recently, the streets of this city's largely black Hillbrow neighborhood were alive with commerce -- vendors selling fruit from plates on the sidewalk, barbers working under makeshift tents, men sitting behind ancient pedal-powered sewing machines, willing to tailor at a moment's notice.

title: Holiday Today
description: Washington's Birthday, which is Feb. 22, is observed today.

title: TECHNOLOGY: CONNECTIONS;In this new game, you'll never play with a full deck.
description: SOMETIME next month a game will be played on the Internet, challenging surfers to leap between sites, solving puzzles and cracking codes that will give them access to secret data hidden behind firewalls and software barriers. The point of the contest will not be to declare a champion hacker (though some prizes will be awarded), but to beat the publicity drums for a new game called Netrunner.

title: Eleanor Clark Is Dead at 82; A Ruminative Travel Essayist
description: Eleanor Clark, an author best known for the evocative range of her accounts of oystering in Brittany and of the streets of Rome, died on Friday at a retirement home in Boston. She was 82.

title: The Losers in Bangladesh
description: Bangladesh's election last Thursday is likely to prolong rather than resolve an unsettled country's political crisis. Because an organized boycott kept opposition voters away in droves, Prime Minister Khaleda Zia's ruling Bangladesh Nationalist Party was able to claim victory. But because the turnout seems to have been 10 percent or less, while election violence took at least a dozen lives, Sheikh Hasani Wazed of the opposition Awami League could claim a moral victory.

title: Latest G.I. Sabers Rattle Persuasively in Bosnia
description: After an American commander threatened Bosnian Serb troops with warplanes and attack helicopters, NATO forces gained entry this weekend to two Bosnian Serb arms depots in eastern Bosnia. NATO had twice been denied access to the depots, in Han Pijesak and Han Kram. And though a Bosnian Serb general, Zdravko Tomimir, had promised entry on Saturday, NATO troops were kept out until an American colonel threatened to use force as A-10 anti-tank planes and Kiowa attack helicopters cruised nearby.

title: Athlete and Legal Issue on Trial
description: When Warren Moon, the star National Football League quarterback, went on trial on assault charges this week, his wife, Felicia, was by his side. They held hands on the way into the courthouse. During breaks, they embraced and bowed their heads in prayer.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Easing Elderly's Tax Burden
description: In Massachusetts, elderly people with financial problems can reduce their property taxes by as much as $500 a year by performing minimum-wage clerical work for their municipality. Impressed by the idea, the Whitman administration is considering whether such a program would work in New Jersey, Bob Friant, a spokesman for the Department of Community Affairs, said yesterday.

title: Japan Merchandise Trade Surplus Cut 83%
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus fell 83 percent last month from a year earlier, its biggest drop in six years, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: World News Briefs;Poles Vote on Privatizing State's Remaining Assets
description: Poles voted today in a five-question referendum on the privatization of state assets.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Chekhov as a Radical Instead of Bittersweet
description: CHEKHOV'S PLAYS An Opening Into Eternity By Richard Gilman 261 pages. Yale University Press. $30.

title: Better Yeltsin in Russia Than Anybody Else;Which Zyuganov?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters;Sorting Out the Hopefuls to Run Against Giuliani
description: THE country may be focused on New Hampshire and Bob, Pat, Steve and Lamar. But in the political world of New York, the talk is of Ruth, Freddy, Alan and Mark. Especially, these days, Mark.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Yo-Yo Ma, Emanuel Ax And a Schubertian Salon
description: Partly to celebrate the 20th anniversary of their recital collaboration and partly for Valentine's Day, the pianist Emanuel Ax and the cellist Yo-Yo Ma invited a handful of colleagues to a public party on the stage of Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening.

title: Toddler Cares for Sister After Mother Dies
description: For a day or two after his mother died in their apartment, 2-year-old Thomas Hubbard fed his baby sister cereal and took care of her, not letting in the new baby sitter because she was a stranger.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Capturing the Complexities Of Shaker and of Modern
description: The New Music Consort presented five gritty, complex contemporary works on Saturday night at the Manhattan School of Music.

title: Better Yeltsin in Russia Than Anybody Else;Electoral Advantage
description: To the Editor:

title: Balkan Leaders Pledge to Carry Out Dayton Accord
description: Officials of the United States and its NATO allies concluded two days of sometimes tense meetings with Balkan leaders here today, producing a series of declarations that recommit the former warring parties to full compliance with the Bosnian peace accords.

title: Canadian Publishers Offer Editions in Chinese
description: After English and French, the largest language group in Canada is Chinese. In this country of nearly 30 million people, more than 500,000 are Chinese -- many from Hong Kong, fearing for the future after the city is returned to China in mid-1997.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Hospital Sued in Boy's Death
description: A 14-year-old who hanged himself at Bergen Pines County Hospital last March should have been more closely watched, the lawyer for the boy's mother says.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;UConn's Allen Is Worldly And Wise
description: When Ray Allen takes his place with the starting lineup of the University of Connecticut Huskies, the introduction over the public-address system -- "From Dalzell, South Carolina . . ." -- is as misleading as it is loud.

title: Editorial Notebook: Shades of 'City Hall';New Film Captures The Fog of Government
description: A few steps from City Hall stands a hulking edifice known as the Municipal Building, where bureaucrats toil in seedy anonymity. A scene in the new movie, "City Hall," captures their imperial isolation as a crusading deputy mayor pursues his murder investigation deep into the building's recesses. There he finds a sallow-faced departmental supervisor looking up at him with curiosity and disdain. "You're the first deputy mayor to set foot on this floor," he says. "We had a commissioner once, but it was the wrong floor."

title: Cocaine Acquittals Shock Prosecutors
description: A Miami jury found two men accused of importing 75 tons of cocaine not guilty late Friday in a verdict that stunned Government lawyers.

title: Ankara Talks May Put Islamic Party in Coalition
description: The leader of Turkey's pro-Islamic Welfare Party is to resume talks on Monday with the head of a conservative party, inching closer to a deal that could ultimately give the Islamic movement its first turn at the head of a modern Turkish government.

title: Hark! A Mainer Stirs Economic Populism!
description: Clanging on a trash-can lid to kick off a Maine corn chowder potluck meeting this month, the featured speaker and organizer plunged into a fast-paced condemnation of corporate downsizing and free trade.

title: World News Briefs;Nearly 50 Believed Dead As Philippine Ferry Sinks
description: Close to 50 people were believed dead after a ferry capsized in the central Philippines, the coast guard said today.

title: Patents;Scientists try to get a microbe that kills garden pests to turn against the common cockroach.
description: BACILLUS THURINGIENSIS is a naturally occurring microbe that gardeners have used to combat all manner of outdoor pests, from gypsy moths and bagworms to nematodes and beetles. So it seemed inevitable that entomologists would try to figure out a way to deploy it against that most persistent of indoor pests, the cockroach.

title: Taking In the Sites;High-Tech Job Hunting, Even for Low-Tech Positions
description: For those who have been victims of downsizing, retrenchment, layoffs or dismissal, hunting for a new job can be a daunting task. And though technology may be one of the villains in the workplace upheavals of the 1990's, technology -- in the guise of the World Wide Web -- may also be a good Samaritan.

title: POLITICS: STEADFAST CANDIDATE;For Alexander, There's a Sense Of Told You So
description: Three weeks ago, Lamar Alexander held a polite and thoroughly unremarkable little gathering at Lamie's Tavern, an old political watering hole near the New Hampshire seacoast. A few dozen voters showed up, plus a dozy cameraman and a couple of bored reporters.

title: As Big Deal Closes, Gangsta Rap Falls Out of Its Critics' Sights
description: By all accounts, this ought to be a busy week for critics of media companies and the supposedly socially corrosive products the companies purvey.

title: Cap Over Wall' Joined Political Lexicon
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: LABOR;With New Militancy, Nation's Unions Hope to Drive Republicans From Congress
description: The nation's labor unions, now under more militant leadership, are gathering here today to open a drive to oust Republicans in Congress, promising their most organized and expensive political campaign ever.

title: HOCKEY;Rolston's Goals Score Points With Lemaire
description: Brian Rolston is one of several Devils who need to raise their performance level in the stretch run for a spot in the playoffs.

title: 2d Man Charged in Blaze That Killed a Firefighter
description: Investigators arrested a second man on murder charges yesterday in the death of a firefighter at a Brooklyn chop shop. They also provided details on the chain of events that led to the blaze, saying it started when sparks from a grinding machine used to erase vehicle identification numbers ignited a pool of gasoline.

title: Magic' Casts a Spell on Players;There's Mayhem and Money in Fantasy Card Game
description: Shuffle and deal, shuffle and deal: Until the round was over and the cards had been put away, Stacy Doust did not really realize what she had done.

title: ECONOMIC PULSE: The New York Region;Region's Economy in Fundamental Shift
description: Through the darkest days of the recession in the late 1980's and early 1990's, there was a certain tenet of faith in the New York region: Like the seasons, the business cycle was eternal, and when the downturn was over old-fashioned growth would return.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week. Some reports were delayed by last month's partial shutdown of the Government.

title: Bridge
description: There are now many programs that allow home computer owners to play bridge against their machine. Jim Loy of Bozeman, Mont., has performed a useful service by buying and testing 25 and reviewing them on the Internet.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Experts guided initiates through the art of cigar smoking Friday night at an all-women cigar smoke at Morton's of Chicago steakhouse in midtown Manhattan.

title: Producing Custom-Made Clothes for the Masses
description: About half of all Americans buy off-the-rack clothing that does not fit well, said researchers at the Technology/Clothing Technology Corporation, an apparel industry group. Half of those pay to have their clothing altered; the rest just wear ill-fitting clothes.

title: ON BASKETBALL;If This Is Oblivion, UMass Wants More
description: Boy, is UMass in trouble now. With every passing game that the Minutemen refuse to lose, 25 and counting, the only major undefeated team in America takes one step closer to oblivion. That is what you hear these days. If the Minutemen should become the third National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament team in 20 seasons to enter without a loss, joining U.N.L.V. in 1991 and Indiana State in 1979, their perfection will lead to their undoing.

title: MEDIA: TELEVISION;Watch this! Cheap tricks abound during ratings sweeps.
description: FEBRUARY is a Nielsen rating sweep month, and television is awash in get-viewers-quick schemes.

title: World News Briefs;Death Toll Rises to 53 After Quake in Indonesia
description: The death toll from a powerful earthquake that triggered sea waves and flattened villages in the remote Irian Jaya Province of Indonesia has risen to 53, a police spokesman said today.

title: Kennedy-Castro Encounter Touched by History
description: At the height of the cold war, Fidel Castro and John F. Kennedy were the bitterest of adversaries. So when the Cuban leader strode into a reception room at the Palace of the Revolution here early today to meet Robert and Michael Kennedy, two nephews of the American President, history hung heavily over the encounter.

title: Marilyn Monroe Cooing in Falsetto
description: It isn't the jet-black hair, the silky pink dress or her endearing effervescence that win her fans, but at 60 years old, Mariko Mukai is still a siren in Japan. For millions of ordinary Japanese, who for two decades watched American movies on Japanese television, she is the sweet and syrupy falsetto of Marilyn Monroe.

title: P.& G. Plans To Cut Costs Of Marketing
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, one of the largest advertisers in the world, said today that it would cut its spending on marketing in the next few years to reduce prices on products.

title: Paternalistic Drug Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay;In a Smoke-Free Room
description: Two weeks ago, newsmagazine covers were touting Steve Forbes; polls were reporting growing Forbes strength in Iowa and pulling away from the field in New Hampshire.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Head Offers A Yonkers Dissident Hope
description: Kweisi Mfume, the newly appointed president of the N.A.A.C.P., said this weekend that there was still a place in the organization for a dissident leader from Yonkers who was removed after questioning the use of busing to combat school segregation.

title: Dow Corning Seeks Medical Panel
description: The Dow Corning Corporation said Friday that it wanted a Federal bankruptcy judge to appoint a panel of medical experts to help put a dollar value on thousands of breast- implant injury claims.

title: POLITICS: LOSING MOMENTUM;The Surge Has Waned, but Forbes Remains Hopeful
description: Barely two weeks ago in Iowa, Steve Forbes was a heavyweight. His Presidential candidacy spooked the front-runner, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas. Now, on the eve of New Hampshire's primary, Mr. Forbes finds himself a bantamweight candidate, hoping to do well enough to get an economy-class ticket to future primaries.

title: INSIDE
description: Shoring Up Bosnia Peace

title: The Face of Computing 50 Years and 18,000 Tubes Ago
description: The electric light bulb, we all know, was invented by Thomas Edison. The telephone was the work of Alexander Graham Bell. And the computer . . . .

title: Getting Ready for the V-Chip
description: Amid growing public and political discontent over the amount of sex and violence on television, the four broadcast networks are now moving to establish their own ratings system, much as the Motion Picture Association of America years ago developed one for movies. This new willingness on the part of the networks to provide more information to help guide parents in choosing shows for their children is welcome. True, the networks are acting only after a troubling degree of coercion and interference by Congress. But if the networks and their governmental overseers proceed carefully, they should be able to devise a system that serves the public interest without violating the free speech safeguards of the Constitution.

title: Toronto Journal;Down These Frigid Streets: Homeless in Canada
description: Warily, he walked into the Moss Park Armory of the Canadian Armed Forces in downtown Toronto, spotted a large cardboard box filled with pile and down jackets and tried one on for size. Other homeless men and women were doing the same.

title: Newspaper Owners Do the Shuffle;Communities Worry as Dailies Pass From Chain to Chain
description: For a generation, family owners of local newspapers in places across the country like this old city on the Connecticut River have been selling off to chains.

title: Stocks Slip in Japan
description: Stocks traded lower here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 81.52 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,721.25. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 83.42 points.

title: Incoming Leader of N.A.A.C.P. Vows That 'Change Is at Hand'
description: Kweisi Mfume, who is to be formally sworn in tomorrow in Washington as the newly chosen chief officer of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, has already put his personal stamp on the troubled organization.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Ibsen and Shaw Have Their Say on Women's Rights
description: Few playwrights championed the cause of women more than Ibsen and Shaw, each creating his own version of the "new woman" for the new century. The main difference was that Ibsen had his slam the door on her family or play with a gun while Shaw gave his elocution lessons or a job.

title: Investigators Citing Design Flaw And Engineer Error in Accident
description: Investigators suggested today that some of the 11 people killed in a head-on train collision on Friday might have lived if emergency exits had operated properly. The investigators also suggested that the accident was the result of operator error and design flaw.

title: A Collision Of Brains And Brawn
description: The opposite poles of chess thinking -- abstract judgment and concrete calculation -- have never been more forcefully illustrated than in the six games between Garry Kasparov, the world champion, and Deep Blue, I.B.M.'s king of computers.

title: Killed Officer Is Identified
description: No charges were filed against the driver of a vehicle that struck and killed a New York City police officer on Saturday, officials said.

title: POLITICS: THE RELIGIOUS RIGHT;At Site of G.O.P. Primary, Fundamentalists Are Few
description: As the race for the Republican Presidential nomination has moved to the Northeast, so has it shifted onto territory where the political muscle of religious conservatives appears much less formidable than in the Midwestern Farm Belt.

title: Woman Dies After Push Under Train by Robber, Police Say
description: A 15-year-old Brooklyn teen-ager pushed a woman to her death from a moving subway train while trying to steal her gold earrings early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Irish Exhibition Critics Don't Want to Whitewash History
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
