description: An article yesterday about fighting poverty in Indonesia misidentified the Indonesian currency. It is the rupiah, not the ringgit.

title: Why Women Decide to Skip Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Inquiry Into a Pupil's Assault
description: School officials are investigating whether a kindergarten teacher in Newark ordered her students to punch a boy who had torn up her lesson plan.

title: Better Yeltsin in Russia Than Anybody Else;Independent Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Cash and Carry On at Trader Knick
description: Economic downsizing continued yesterday at Madison Square Garden. Soon to follow is the head-hunting process, in which someone very good at what he does will be paid gobs of money to guide the company back to prominence.

title: Mexican Party Pulls Out of Talks on Political Reform
description: The main opposition party has embarrassed President Ernesto Zedillo by pulling out of negotiations to make Mexico's political system more democratic, charging that the Government is continuing a decades-old practice of stealing elections.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MILDRED FRIEDMAN celebrated the 15th anniversary of her kidney transplant operation yesterday on a four-hour Hudson River cruise aboard the Riveranda of the World Yacht line. Her husband, Dr. ELI A. FRIEDMAN, a kidney doctor, planned the event as a reprise of a party he had for his wife five years ago.

title: Why Women Decide to Skip Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTO RACING;An Engine of Instruction
description: Runt Pittman is learning that fame can blow pp in your face about as fast as an over-revved racing engine. He built the engines that were largely credited with making Sterling Marlin the two-time defending champion coming into today's Daytona 500.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;UConn Is Tested By a Game Rutgers
description: On Saturday, after his Massachusetts men's basketball team beat dangerous Virginia Tech, Coach John Calipari was talking about the pressure on his team because it is ranked No. 1 in the nation. Everywhere you go, he said, the other team is primed because this is its game of the year.

title: 2 Months After Treaty Is Signed, Sarajevo Blooms
description: A few weeks ago, a shipment of polished Italian marble inlaid with smoky mirrors was delivered to the Mikkele Cafe here. It was installed along with new wall-to-wall carpeting, carved tables and chairs, and brass statuary custom-made by local craftsmen.

title: Amtrak Train Kills Small Boy
description: A 4-year-old boy was killed and a man nearly lost a leg when they were hit by an Amtrak train traveling from San Diego to Los Angeles on Saturday. The man and the boy were walking alongside railroad tracks.

title: Suffering Afghans Reach Breaking Point
description: To the Editor:

title: A Public Station Sheds Some Glitter And Digs for Its IntellectualRoots
description: At the Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Awards presentations for excellence in broadcasting a few weeks ago, public television's "The American Experience" was honored for a trio of documentaries: "The Battle of the Bulge," produced by Tom Lennon; "F.D.R.," produced by David Grubin, and "The Way West," produced by Ric Burns.

title: Woman Dies in House Fire
description: A house fire here claimed the life of an elderly woman early this morning, fire officials said.

title: 1 Dies, 8 Hurt As Blast Rips Bus in Center Of London
description: A double-decker bus exploded in the center of London's theater district late Sunday night, sending glass and metal debris flying, killing one person and injuring at least seven others, the authorities said.

title: HOCKEY;Richter Injured Again Minutes Into His Return
description: Why Pittsburgh?

title: Innovation, Hence Survival, at Apple
description: If Apple Computer's new chairman and chief executive, Gilbert F. Amelio, has a grand vision for remaking the personal computer company as it approaches its third decade, he has not yet disclosed it.

title: China Searches for Respect
description: This is a tough time in relations between the United States and China. Washington is torn over what to do about Beijing's saber rattling in the Taiwan Strait, its covert nuclear aid to Pakistan and Iran, its failure to clamp down on the pirating of intellectual property and its continued flagrant disregard of human rights.

title: From Book Editor to Publisher, Pretty Darn Quick
description: Jerry Seinfeld, Paul Reiser and Ellen DeGeneres have at least three things in common: hit television comedies, best-selling books published by Bantam and a young editor there, Rob Weisbach.

title: Will Dubbing Fly in the U.S.? Read My Lips
description: Even though "The Postman" last week became the first foreign-language film since the 1973 Swedish drama "Cries and Whispers" to win an Oscar nomination for best picture, relatively few American filmgoers are likely to see this bittersweet Italian comedy. Its gross box-office revenues to date are $11 million -- impressive for its genre, but little more than a weekend's work for an above-average Hollywood offering.

title: No Headline
description: As it goes deeper and deeper, it displays elements of strategic understanding. Somewhere out there, mere tactics are translating into strategy. This is the closest thing I've seen to computer intelligence. It's a weird form of intelligence, the beginning of intelligence. But you can feel it. You can smell it." FREDERICK FRIEDEL, Gary Kasparov's computer adviser. [A1:2.]

title: Region's Hospitals Have Seen the Future, and It's an Outpatient Clinic
description: The future of health care in the New York region, industry analysts say, is an airy, gleaming building on Union Square that looks like a medical mall: pediatrics on 2, orthopedics and internal medicine on 3, coffee shop on 1, and glass-walled waiting rooms looking out on an atrium with a waterfall.

title: Tommy Rettig, 54, Actor on 'Lassie'
description: Tommy Rettig, the first boy to play Lassie's master on television, was found dead in his home in Marina del Rey on Thursday. He was 54.

title: Ann Barry, Editor And Writer, 53
description: Ann Barry, who pursued a freelance writing career while working as an editor at The New York Times and at The New Yorker, died of cancer on Saturday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 53 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Abroad at Home;And We Walked Away
description: If we imagined a nightmare world, it might be a place governed by illiterate teen-age boys. They have never been to school, but they know the Absolute Truth -- and enforce it with Kalashnikov rifles.

title: Hopes Cut Short After Brief, Tough Lives
description: They were studying to become nurses aides, carpenters and bricklayers and trying to overcome what they saw as bad decisions that were holding them back. Some had dropped out of school. Some could not find jobs. Some came from troubled families. Some were drug users.

title: In America;An Exercise in Futility
description: None of the campaigns are working. Millions are being spent on inane and annoying ads, and the candidates are dutifully tramping through the snow and the bitter cold, proffering one false promise after another (like compulsive salesmen who couldn't stop peddling their discredited wares, even if they wanted to), all for naught.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;A Patience Tested by Floods
description: During the last 10 weeks, 200 homes along the Pascack Brook have been flooded five times.

title: Council Pushes Own Budget Ideas
description: The New York City Council has long been criticized for failing to take a strong stand in budget talks with the Mayor, but some early signs suggest that in at least one respect, this year may be different.

title: HOCKEY;Flyers Find The Holes In Devils' Defense
description: The Flyers found many gaps in the vaunted defense of the Devils this afternoon, just a day after the fifth shutout of the season for Martin Brodeur, New Jersey's indefatigable young goaltender.

title: POLITICS: THE SCENE;Judgments On Politics, Primaries, Pancakes
description: In the final hours, as the words and antics of the Presidential primary dwindled to a suffocating weariness, it seemed more appropriate than shocking to hear one candidate dare to raise the ultimate issue -- death -- and speak almost longingly of the victory of the grave.

title: Republicans Wind Up Bare-Fisted Donnybrook in New Hampshire
description: WASHINGTON  On the eve of the presidential primary in New Hampshire, a traditional maker and breaker of candidacies, the Republican hopefuls engaged Monday in a last bare-fisted flurry of campaigning, with signs pointing to an extremely close finish.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: A Meditation on Styles And a Bach Piano Score New York City Ballet New York State Theater

title: Morrison Knudsen in Talks About Its Debt
description: The Morrison Knudsen Corporation said today that it had begun preliminary negotiations with its creditors and had proposed exchanging its existing secured debt for equity.

title: Striking Chrysler Workers Ignore Union
description: The United Auto Workers ordered striking workers today to return to their jobs at a Chrysler Corporation truck plant here, but few of them obeyed, keeping the assembly line idle.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Discovering The New In the Old
description: The most provocative moments in Peter Serkin's recital at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon were not in the dense harmonic thickets of Stefan Wolpe's Toccata or the rhythmic maze that Wolpe presented in his "Form IV," but in the comfortably familiar contours of the Beethoven "Appassionata." Perhaps that is as it should be: when works are played in safe, standardized readings, they fade into the woodwork. The trick, for a performer, is to find surprises in these pieces without doing them violence.

title: Markets Closed
description: All financial and commodity markets and banks in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Washington's Birthday. Most overseas markets were open.

title: World News Briefs;Yeltsin and Kohl Discuss Investment and NATO
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin met today with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany for talks on Mr. Yeltsin's efforts to win re-election, the decline of German business interests in Russia and the expansion of NATO.

title: Review/Fashion;Americans Master the Prefall Game
description: An old saying in the rag trade had it that there were five seasons: fall, winter, spring, summer and slack. Today, there are all of the above, plus resort, holiday, prespring and prefall. Why? Because department stores demand a constant influx of new merchandise. Might there come a day when we see a new collection every month?

title: POLITICS;Closing Arguments
description: BOB DOLE

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING Wiberg Wins Combined Event A steep, icy slalom course couldn't keep Pernilla Wiberg of Sweden from winning the combined event yesterday at the Alpine world championships in Sierra Nevada, Spain.

title: INSIDE
description: Marijuana Use Growing

title: Lincoln Kirstein Remembered For His Lifetime in the Arts
description: Friends and colleagues honored Lincoln Kirstein as one of the most astonishing and influential figures in 20th-century American culture at a memorial tribute on Sunday night at the New York State Theater. Many speakers praised him for being a founder of the New York City Ballet and its affiliated School of American Ballet. But Mr. Kirstein, who died on Jan. 5 at the age of 88, was also remembered as a writer, art curator and visionary.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Pentium Machines to Go; Whistles Not Included
description: THE number is clearly meant to catch the eye. It does. $1,999 is the lowest price I have seen for a name-brand Pentium-based notebook computer, a product that barely existed a year ago. The low end of the portable market has suddenly become downright attractive.

title: On Taiwan, Congress Makes No Mere Gestures
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles O. Finley, Baseball Team Owner Who Challenged Traditions, Diesat 77
description: Charles O. Finley, the contentious and colorful former owner of the Oakland A's who challenged baseball tradition by championing changes like bright-colored uniforms and the designated hitter, died yesterday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 77.

title: Mazda Stock Slips After Engine Report
description: Shares of the Mazda Motor Corporation fell as much as 4.5 percent today after a Japanese newspaper said the company would stop making rotary engines, one of its first successful products. Mazda later denied the report.

title: Pioneer Electronic Expects Wider Loss
description: Battered by fierce price competition and sluggish overseas demand for its key products, the Pioneer Electronic Corporation said today that it was likely to post a wider loss than it had expected for the fiscal year that ends in March.

title: Salvador Massacre Recalls U.S. Role
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THE STRATEGY;This Presidential Race Is Its Own Biggest Fan
description: Some campaigns turn on ideology, others turn on character. The 1996 Presidential primary here may be remembered as the first campaign to turn on itself.

title: Honduras Puts Rightist Officer In a U.N. Role
description: Honduras has appointed as a representative to the United Nations a former general who last year defied civilian efforts to arrest military officers on charges of rights abuses and who staged an intimidating show of military force in the capital.

title: A.D.P. Makes Acquistion
description: Automatic Data Processing Inc.'s Dealer Services Group said today that it had acquired Performance Inc. of Chantilly, Va., for an undisclosed amount. Performance, a provider of consulting and professional service programs to the automotive industry, said that it would retain its president, Clay McCuistion. Automatic Data Processing, which is based in Roseland, N.J., provides data processing and other services to automotive dealers and other businesses.

title: Massachusetts Lifts a Ban On Merrill
description: The Massachusetts state Treasurer has lifted a two-year ban against Merrill Lynch & Company that prevented Merrill, the nation's largest securities firm, from managing the refinancing of the state's bonds.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Star Soloist Takes Second Place Tokyo String Quartet Alice Tully Hall

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Rhodes Reaches Arbitration
description: Pitcher ARTHUR RHODES and the Baltimore Orioles argued their salary case yesterday before the arbitrator ROBERT LIGHT.

title: For Olympic Licensees, Race Is On
description: Even though the first Olympic medals won't be awarded until July, the race for gold is already under way among corporate licensees, and some winners and losers are quickly emerging.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Calls for the E.P.A. Copter
description: Two New Jersey Congressmen want the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to resume helicopter monitoring of New Jersey's beaches.

title: Nesting Beyond the Snowbirds;Foreigners Flock to Miami's Luxury Condominiums
description: Ugo Colombo is a smallish man with a big taste for finely tailored Italian suits and tall buildings. Very tall buildings.

title: Norsk Hydro Profits Rise
description: Norsk Hydro A.S., the Norwegian industrial group, reported today that its profits rose 71 percent in 1995, but a disappointing performance from the group's light metals division meant that the results fell short of market expectations.

title: Fears in Dublin
description: In response to the bombings in London, Protestant paramilitary groups indicated that they might end their cease-fire. Page A8.

title: Willie Brown's Performance Is a Hit
description: It is more than a run-of-the-mill political honeymoon that this beauty of a city is having with its flamboyant new Mayor.

title: PERIFERALS;For Portable Storage
description: THE hard disk on the Macintosh was filling up with my projects and my wife's, and I was removing software and documents not because I wanted to, but to make room. Such cramping is not uncommon when two or people share a computer. I had to get a Zip drive.

title: G.M. to Merge GMC Division With Pontiac
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to announce on Tuesday the merger of its Pontiac and GMC divisions, a sign that G.M. management is moving to consolidate the conflicting brands and corporate fiefs that have hampered the auto maker for decades.

title: Pierre Verger, 93, Photographer And a Brazilian Voodoo Priest
description: Pierre Verger, a worldly Parisian-born photographer whose quest for the natural life led him to an unlikely paradise in northeastern Brazil, died on Feb. 11 at his home in Salvador, the capital of the coastal Bahia state, where he was at once a renowned authority on the cultural links with Africa and a revered religious figure. He was 93.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Washington's Black Soldiers
description: The role of black soldiers in the Civil War is well recognized, but an East Brunswick history teacher believes that the African-Americans in George Washington's army have often been overlooked.

title: Play a Hooker and Win an Oscar
description: The first Academy Award for best actress was given in 1928 to Janet Gaynor for her performances in three films, including "Street Angel," in which she played a prostitute. Her rival for the Oscar was Gloria Swanson, who starred in "Sadie Thompson," about a woman who was, well, pretty loose in her morals.

title: Seagate Acquires Arcada Stake
description: Seagate Technology Inc. said today that it had paid $158 million to acquire the remaining 31 percent of Arcada Holdings Inc. that was not owned by Conner Peripherals Inc., which Seagate recently acquired.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A revival of Stephen Sondheim's "Company," a Tony Award-winning musical first seen on Broadway in 1970, won three 1995 Laurence Olivier Awards in London on Sunday night. ADRIAN LESTER won the award for best musical actor, SHEILA GISH won for best supporting performance in a musical and SAM MENDES won for best director.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Where are the merchandising tie-ins for 'Babe'? And when did 'golden retriever'  become a color?
description: IT'S time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media.

title: A Horse of a Different Color;Saratoga Would Keep Casino Taint Off Its Tidy Turf
description: This city is famous for the horses. And not the hayride kind. The kind you bet on.

title: Spain's Democratic Choice
description: Spanish democracy moves into a more mature, if less heroic, phase with next month's elections. Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, long the symbol of democratic resistance to the old Franco dictatorship, now must also bear the burdens of an increasingly difficult incumbency. His Socialist party, in power for the past 13 years, has recently been battered by a series of disillusioning scandals. Polls show the main conservative opposition party, led by the prosaic but persistent Jose Maria Aznar, running ahead by as much as 10 percentage points.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;School Names Headmaster
description: The Lawrenceville School, whose alumni include the poet James Merrill and Michael Eisner, chairman of the Walt Disney Company, named a new headmaster last weekend. He is Michael Carey, chairman of the department of philosophy and religion at Deerfield Academy in Deerfield, Mass.

title: Unions Looking South To Find New Members
description: Trying to halt the four-decade-long slide in the percentage of workers belonging to unions, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. unveiled plans today to intensify efforts to attract American workers to unions, with a focus on the South.

title: Muslims to Take a Sarajevo Suburb Sooner Than Expected
description: United Nations officials announced today that police officers from the Muslim-dominated Government will move into this Serbian suburb of Sarajevo on Friday, weeks earlier than most residents here had expected.

title: Computer City Talks Halted
description: The Tandy Corporation said today that it had conducted talks recently about selling its Computer City division to CompUSA Inc. but that the meetings had been discontinued.

title: Judge Under Challenge Is an Eccentric Idealist
description: Not long after he became a judge, Lorin Duckman began a monthly newsletter for courthouse colleagues. Its name was Ducknews, and it was devoted exclusively to news about himself.

title: What Is a Park if Not a Refuge?
description: To the Editor:

title: Melville the Celebrity
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: ON THE INTERNET;Direct From New Hampshire, Thanks to Web
description: In a wired revival of the cracker-barrel tradition, the world has been able for the first time to eavesdrop as New Hampshire voters have savored their political power.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: PERFORMANCE ART
description: The Courage and Whimsy Behind the Stereotypes 'An Evening of Black Magic: Songlines and Dreamtracks' Phillip Brown Dixon Place

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.F.L.;Moon's Wife Denies Abuse
description: As testimony continued yesterday in the assault trial of WARREN MOON, the 39-year-old quarterback of the Minnesota Vikings, Moon's wife continued to defend her husband at the expense of her own reputation. Under questioning from her husband's lawyer, RUSTY HARDIN, FELICIA MOON portrayed herself as at times an enraged, hysterical and vengeful wife who escalated marital squabbles to violence.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: POP
description: Feeling a Kinship With Anyone Different Catie Curtis Bottom Line

title: Probes Will Carry New Hope For Detecting Life on Mars
description: THEY have no antennas or pointy little heads or the kind of death rays that H. G. Wells pictured in his "War of the Worlds." Even so, Martians may very well be real and living comfortably in secluded parts of the red planet, scientists are beginning to suspect.

title: BASKETBALL;Hoyas End Huskies' 23-Game Streak With Defense
description: The students initiated the idea, just the way any great teacher would prefer. The Georgetown Hoyas, facing a passionate challenge in the middle of an impressive but uneven season, came to their coach with the suggestion. "They said they didn't feel they were playing as intense until we got in trouble," John Thompson remembered. "They wanted to step up the tempo of the defense. I told them: 'Hey, I'm for it. I don't know much about offense anyway.' "

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Sickle-Cell Center to Open
description: Sickle-cell anemia is relatively rare, afflicting only 72,000 Americans. But 1 in 1,000 African-Americans have the disease, which causes chronic episodes of debilitating pain.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Princeton University at 250
description: Princeton University's elaborate 250th anniversary celebration will begin Friday with speeches, music and poetry commissioned for the event.

title: By Design;High-Riding Shoulder Bag
description: Backpacks are practical but can be awkward. Clutches and top-handle bags are fine for evening, but they don't leave the hands free. So the trusty shoulder bag is coming back into favor, with a slight twist: it has a streamlined body and a short strap, and it is tucked under an arm rather than flapping around the hips. It's the perfect complement to spring's sleek clothes.

title: ROCK REVIEW;Moving Up the Ladder, To Cheers and Lingerie
description: In the last year and a half, Everclear has rapidly been climbing the club ladder in Manhattan, moving from a near-empty after-midnight slot at CBGB to a well-attended show for a half-distracted, half-enthusiastic audience at the Westbeth Theater Center to Sunday night's show at the Academy, where a sold-out crowd sang along with almost every song and more than a dozen bras and shirts were thrown on stage. "What are you going to wear home?" the band's bemused singer and guitarist, Art Alexakis, asked as the clothes continued to fly.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;EuroBelgian Air Bid
description: The British entrepreneur Richard Branson announced plans yesterday to take over a European regional airline that is based in Brussels to operate with Virgin Atlantic Airways, the long-haul airline that Mr. Branson owns. Mr. Branson's Virgin Group said it had signed a memorandum of understanding to buy 80 percent of EuroBelgian Airlines S.A. from Brussels-based City Hotels, the majority owner, and a group of private investors. A spokesman for Virgin said that if the deal went ahead the business would be owned by a newly created company, Virgin European Airways, which would operate separately from Virgin Atlantic Airways. The initial value of the deal is likely to be about L43 million ($67 million). (Reuters)

title: Wired on Politics
description: For a brief moment during Thursday's Republican debate, I was convinced that CNN's "thermometer" poll of 36 undecided G.O.P. voters actually measured body heat. Thanks to a breakthrough in computer graphics, the network was able to chart each subtle shift in the sample voters' moods, theoretically showing us what to expect in today's New Hampshire primary.

title: From '80 Crime, White-Sioux Tension Today
description: The main bridge over the Missouri River here stretches nearly a mile before it connects this overwhelmingly white farming town of 4,200 people to the Standing Rock Indian Reservation, where Sitting Bull is buried on a bluff and the vast prairie dips and rolls into the horizon.

title: TRACK AND FIELD NOTEBOOK;Gorgeous Anonymity For Marathon Winner
description: He jogged into Central Park wearing sweats and a ski cap at 6 o'clock Sunday night. He ran for 20 or 25 minutes. Not one head turned.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Taps Off for Tank Repairs
description: From midnight tomorrow until midnight Thursday, about 1,500 residents will be without running water so Rockaway's 150,000-gallon tank can be repaired, Mayor Joseph L. Lebar said yesterday.

title: BASKETBALL;Howard Hopes, Knicks Wish
description: Now that the Knicks have freed up room under the salary cap by executing two trades in 10 days, one player who figures to be high on their wish list is Juwan Howard.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Polaroid Corp., Cambridge, Mass., to Holland Mark Martin, Burlington, Mass., to handle the consolidated advertising and direct marketing account of Polaroid's electronic imaging systems division, previously split between Holland Mark for direct marketing and Duval Woglom Brueckner & Partners, Providence, R.I., for advertising. The billings have not been determined.

title: Train Survivors Couldn't See How to Exit
description: Smoke and flames were filling the front car of the commuter train, drenched with diesel fuel from the Amtrak locomotives it had just hit. Damian Benitez, one of 18 people in the car, ran to the doors and tried to open them.

title: Iberia Reaches Pact With Pilots
description: Iberia, the Spanish state-owned airline, reached a deal with its pilots today, clearing the last obstacle to an injection of new capital to save it from bankruptcy.

title: Resurgent Liberals Put Conservatives on Defense
description: Last year, as Gov. John G. Rowland led a drive to scale back government, reduce welfare benefits and cut taxes, liberal Democrats and their allies were virtually invisible.

title: 500,000 in Madrid Protest Basque Violence
description: More than half a million people marched in silence through the streets of central Madrid tonight to protest a campaign of violence by Basque separatists.

title: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Union Official Takes Job With Democrats
description: Gerry Hudson, a senior official with New York City's largest hospital workers union, has been named political director of the New York State Democratic Party, a position in which he will oversee the party's campaign activities.

title: On My Mind;Lean, Mean and Loopy
description: As the glorious array of Republican candidates moves from primary to primary, dwindling perforce but still dazzling us with profound debate, we must not ignore the generosity of the Republican leadership toward its foe. Unprecedented, one might say. Or, one might say, loopy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Apple Agrees to License Mac System to Motorola Apple Computer, in one of the first announcements under its new chief executive, said it was licensing its Macintosh operating system to Motorola. Analysts said the arrangement pointed to a new strategy by Apple of confronting Microsoft's and Intel's rival PC standard in parts of the world where the personal computer market is not yet well developed. [Page D2.] NatWest Bids $713 Million For a British Asset Manager National Westminster took a step toward becoming a comprehensive financial-services company by offering $713 million for Gartmore, one of the fastest-growing asset management companies in Britain. [D9.]

title: School District's Excesses Mirror the Faults of the System
description: In May 1992, Joseph A. Fernandez, then the Schools Chancellor, took a swipe at the legendary corruption of Community School Board 9 in the Bronx by suspending Carmelo Saez Jr., the board president, who had come to symbolize the entrenched politics of local city school districts. Mr. Saez's offense, according to Board of Education officials, was using school equipment to make a fund-raising videotape for a private drum and bugle corps he ran.

title: No Headline
description: There's always been prejudice and tension between whites and Indians around here. I'd do anything to change it. It's stupid." BECKY RICE, a white woman in Mobridge, S.D. [A1:4.]

title: Market Place;On idle talk, artful deception, greed and other market fixtures.
description: SHARE prices gyrated wildly as bulls and bears spread rumors that may or may not have had any relationship to reality, and as traders furiously speculated in options. Short- sellers were vilified, and everyone suspected that everyone else was trying to manipulate prices.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;NatWest Bids $713 Million for Gartmore
description: National Westminster, the big British banking group, offered L466 million, or $713 million, today for Gartmore, one of the nation's fastest-growing asset-management companies.

title: Microsoft Sets A Revamping To Gain Edge On the Internet
description: The Microsoft Corporation plans to announce a company-wide reorganization today to strengthen its focus in both the interactive computing market and its traditional operating systems business.

title: Learning Disabled Deserve Level Field
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTA 1996;Wrong Turn: Swords Into Plowshares
description: For decades, Hungary was the powerhouse of Olympic fencing, bringing home more gold in that sport than any other. Their male duelers were virtually invincible.

title: JP Foodservice Rejects Deal With Sarah Lee
description: JP Foodservice Inc. said yesterday that it and the Sara Lee Corporation had ended talks on merging JP with Sara Lee's food-distribution business.

title: Rwanda War Crimes Tribunal Indicts 2 Men in Jail in Zambia
description: A United Nations tribunal today indicted two Rwandans in jail in Zambia on charges of genocide, setting the stage for the first trial to stem from the 1994 massacres in Rwanda in which an estimated half million people died.

title: NYC;Their Loss Of Respect Starts at Home
description: WHEN she assigned the topic to her young writers, Wendy Salinger expected to get back some hard looks at life in the city. She wasn't disappointed. The 17 public-school teen-agers in the writing workshop that she presides over each week at the 92d Street Y had been asked to reflect on someone they once respected and no longer do. Most didn't have to think long about it.

title: Why Make Divorce Easy?
description: For all practical purposes, the debate is over. Almost all Americans now agree that divorce is harmful to children. Now the question becomes: What, if anything, can we do about the fact that at least half of our marriages fail?

title: BASKETBALL;Bradley Enters The Big Time, And Nets Roll
description: One night it is Armon Gilliam. The next it is Chris Childs. Or P. J. Brown. Or Jayson Williams.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;'Orientalism' By Way Of Brooklyn
description: Orientalism" was the Brooklyn Philharmonic's topic last weekend, and by Sunday afternoon it had become a term so loaded with esthetic and political baggage that one scarcely knew whether to hiss or cheer it. There was opportunity to do both: an orchestra program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday, repeated Saturday, and a mix of talk and chamber music at the Majestic Theater on Sunday.

title: Federated Appointment
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. said today that it had decided to have one chairman oversee its two data management divisions. Effective on March 1, James Amann will be chairman and chief executive of the Federated Systems Group in Atlanta and the Financial and Credit Services Group in Cincinnati. Lawrence Honig, president and chief executive of Federated Systems since 1994, will leave the company. The company said the move would help it meet its evolving data management needs. The groups will remain separate divisions.

title: Penny Gifts but a Million-Dollar Heart
description: They call him Papa George, as in, "Papa George, I found $10 for your charities!"

title: Rhoda H. Goldman, Civic Benefactor, 71
description: Rhoda Haas Goldman, a San Francisco civic leader and benefactor of a wide variety of causes, died on Saturday while vacationing in Honolulu. She was 71.

title: Chess
description: Future world champions are not easy to pick from their pre-title match performances. At least two challengers had frightful results against the champions they later overcame: Bobby Fischer had lost three tournament games to Boris Spassky before he got the laurel wreath in the 1972 match in Iceland; Alexander Alekhine had lost six tournament games to Jose Raoul Capablanca before his 1927 triumph in Buenos Aires.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Capriati Is Set for Comeback
description: JENNIFER CAPRIATI, who hasn't played a competitive tennis match in 15 months, will start her comeback tomorrow against KRISTIE BOOGERT of the Netherlands in a $450,000 tournament at Essen, Germany. The event starts today, but Capriati's match is scheduled for tomorrow so it could be televised.

title: PPG Buys Eastman Unit
description: PPG Industries said today that it had acquired the Evtech powder coatings business of the Eastman Chemical Company for an undisclosed amount. Eastman said it sold the business to concentrate on selling raw materials to the paints and coatings industry. Unlike paints, powder coatings do not contain solvents or produce hazardous waste. The powder is sprayed onto metal parts and heated to melt the plastic-based resins to form the coating.

title: BASKETBALL;Brandon Leads Cavaliers To Eighth Straight Victory
description: Cavaliers 73, Heat 70

title: Turks Report Progress as Coalition Talks Break
description: Turkish political leaders held a sixth round of negotiations today aimed at forming a coalition government that would allow an Islamic party to share power for the first time in modern Turkish history, then suspended the talks for a day to observe the end of Ramadan, the Muslim holy month.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Stocks Generally Lower On the Overseas Markets
description: Stocks were generally lower on Asian and European markets yesterday.

title: On Taiwan, Congress Makes No Mere Gestures;Recognize Two Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Van Kills A Pedestrian, 87
description: A police van struck and killed an 87-year-old man crossing the street in midtown Manhattan yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Apple Computer Makes Motorola Licensing Deal
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would license its Macintosh operating system to Motorola Inc. and for the first time Apple said that it would allow Motorola to sell its own sublicenses to the popular software program.

title: Official in Bias Case Regains College Job
description: An administrator at the State University College at Oneonta who was demoted for releasing a list of black male students to the police in 1992 has been reinstated to his former position.

title: Engineered Mice Mimic Drug Use And Mental Ills
description: A NEW, superactive strain of mice that dash about their cages as if they are high on cocaine is yielding fresh ideas about ways to treat devastating human disorders, including drug addiction, schizophrenia and Parkinson's disease.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Russian Phone Talks With Stet May Resume
description: Stet S.p.A., Italy's state-owned telecommunications company, and the Russian phone company Svyazinvest are near to renewing negotiations stalled since last December, an Italian official said yesterday.

title: BASEBALL;For Mets, Bases Are Loaded With Talent, and Intrigue
description: Who's on first base? We know that.

title: Quakes Rattle Nerves, And Not Much Else
description: No, Lisa Crilly did not feel the earth shudder this morning. But that did not stop her from trying to find out if her mother in Ringwood did.

title: Jericho Journal;Wake Up, Palestinians! Your Turn at the Airwaves
description: On a recent balmy morning in this sleepy oasis, Daniela Karim Khalaf slipped behind a microphone to kick off her popular call-in show on the Voice of Palestine, the radio station of the Palestinian Authority.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Shipbuilder Needs Immediate Bailout
description: Bremer Vulkan A.G., the largest shipbuilder in Germany, might declare bankruptcy today unless the group's management board, bankers and government officials can put together a rescue plan. Any plan would be subject to the approval of the European Commission in Brussels.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Florida State Coach Suspended
description: Florida State Coach PAT KENNEDY has been suspended for one game after he received two technical fouls and was ejected from this past Saturday's game at Clemson. Kennedy will miss Thursday's home game against Duke, the Seminoles' athletics director, DAVE HART Jr., said yesterday. Kennedy will resume his coaching duties beginning with Saturday's game against North Carolina. Kennedy was ejected midway through the second half of Clemson's 67-59 victory over Florida State. It was the first time in 24 years a coach had been ejected.(AP)

title: World News Briefs;Solidarity Loses Vote On Polish State Assets
description: The Solidarity union conceded today that its latest challenge to the former Communists who have won control of the Government, a referendum on sharing state assets, probably had failed to win enough support.

title: Closing Arguments In Menendez Trial
description: Closing arguments were set to begin Tuesday in the retrial of Erik and Lyle Menendez, the Beverly Hills brothers accused in the shotgun slayings of their wealthy parents.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British and Japanese In Multimedia Venture
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said yesterday that they would develop multimedia products together. British Telecommunications and a unit of Matsushita that sells products under the Panasonic brand name said they would develop television set-top controllers for on-line and broadcast subscription services, video-telephone semiconductor chips and video servers, for use in services like video on demand.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League CLEVELAND INDIANS -- Agreed to terms with Brian Anderson, pitcher, on a two-year contract.

title: Colombia Legislators Talk of Amnesty, for Themselves
description: So many Colombian congressmen are already on trial or are likely to be charged soon with accepting narcotics money that congressional leaders have begun discussing an amnesty proposal that would exempt lawmakers from prosecution if they agree to withdraw from public life.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Consumer Marketers Announce Switches
description: Three consumer marketers have changed agencies on their accounts.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Taking Control as Soubrette and Doll
description: There is excellent dancing, and then there is great dancing, the kind that Nichol Hlinka of the New York City Ballet poured so consistently into the season's first performance of "Coppelia" on Friday night.

title: HOCKEY;Richter's Painful Split Could Cost Rangers
description: Mike Richter, the Rangers' starting goaltender who reinjured his groin Sunday night in Pittsburgh, was examined today at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan, but team officials said further evaluation was necessary and that Richter's status remained unclear.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Ives and Mahler, Through the Same Lens
description: It is one of the great legends of 20th-century musical history: Gustav Mahler sees the manuscript score of Charles Ives's Third Symphony in a New York music shop and recognizes its genius with one swift glance. He takes the score with him on his final trip back to Europe, but dies before he can conduct it. From this story has risen a powerful fantasy: what if Mahler had lived to rescue America's musical visionary from artistic isolation? The problem with the tale is that it comes from Ives himself, a notorious fabulist and purveyor of unverifiable anecdotes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Housing Fraud Trial Nears
description: Between March 1989 and May 1990, prosecutors say, Michael Pazden and his brother, Robert, accepted down payments averaging $25,000 each on 43 condominiums to be carved from industrial buildings near the Passaic River in their hometown of Clifton. But the Pazdens never delivered on their promise, and the money disappeared, said John Snowden, an assistant prosecutor for Passaic County. "Most of these people were not wealthy people," Mr. Snowden said.

title: Editorial Notebook;Struggling in the Snow
description: You have to go all the way back to the days of George Wallace or the original Bob Dole to find a national candidate with as mean a sense of humor as Pat Buchanan's. He doesn't limit himself to ridiculing his opponents, either. His characterization of George Will as a yapping "poodle" who deserved a few swats with a rolled-up newspaper was gleefully cheered by Mr. Buchanan's supporters. It was also widely admired by a press corps that thinks Mr. Will and his employer, ABC News, have been too quiet about the fact that Mr. Will's wife works for the Dole campaign.

title: Two Navy Fliers Die In Latest F-14 Crash
description: An F-14D fighter jet crashed into the Pacific Ocean on Sunday during exercises, killing its two crew members, the Navy reported.

title: Sports of The Times;The Owner Knew More Than Stunts
description: NEVER mind the gaudy uniforms or the Sgt. Pepper mustaches or the made-up nicknames (Catfish, Blue Moon) or the sheep grazing behind the outfield. That was just Charles O. Finley trying to catch everybody's attention.

title: TV SPORTS;Up Next, Swimsuits in the Crossfire
description: CNN and Sports Illustrated are starting a 24-hour sports news network. A CNN for sports information, analysis, perspective, features and interviews.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Don't Hold Your Breath for Later-Model Humans
description: ESCAPE VELOCITY Cyberculture at the End of the Century By Mark Dery 376 pages. Grove Press. $23.

title: Small Travel Agencies Face Hard Times Under Fee Cap
description: Mary Hogan, the owner of a tiny three-person travel agency in Cambridge, Mass., thought she was ready for anything in the notoriously fickle travel business. "I survived the gulf war," she said, "when not a soul was traveling anywhere."

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Never Mind His Politics, Is the Man Telegenic?
description: As New Hampshire enjoys the final day of its quadrennial season in the television sun, voters must be contemplating the prospect of spending four years in the company of any of the Republican hopefuls.

title: Under Attack, Ant Can Turn Out Goliaths With Genetic Trick
description: A NEW study has shown that ants can perform a biological feat long speculated about but never proved: manipulating the expression of genes among developing juveniles so they can increase the ratio within a colony of large, aggressive "soldiers" to more docile workers in order to respond to a threat.

title: Russian Troops Shell Rebels in Chechen Town
description: Russian forces today shelled the outskirts of a village in Chechnya where separatists have set up a headquarters.

title: Bus Blast Claimed by the I.R.A.; Bomber May Be One of Victims
description: The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility today for the bomb that tore through a double-decker bus in central London late Sunday night, and the police said there was a chance the single body they pulled from the wreckage was that of the bomber. Nine others were wounded in the explosion.

title: Card Sharps, Oil Guys
description: To the Editor:

title: Copyright Pirates Prosper In China Despite Promises
description: Inside a military compound, where the veranda alongside his office looks out on a grand, white-columned building used by the Chinese Air Force, Wang Binyan leaned back in his black leather chair and spoke genially about being a copyright pirate.

title: Ebola Killed 13 in Gabon, W.H.O. Says
description: The World Health Organization confirmed today that 13 people had died from the Ebola virus in Gabon, in West Africa, after a dead chimpanzee was eaten at a feast in a remote village.

title: FOOTBALL;O'Donnell to See Jets In Hempstead Today
description: Neil O'Donnell, the Steelers' free-agent quarterback, will visit the Jets today to tour their center in Hempstead, L.I., sit down with the coaches and determine whether he would be happy helping the offense establish a semblance of competitiveness next season.

title: More Productive Police
description: In his battle with New York City's police unions, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has begun to consider ideas that both he and the police once resisted. If the police are awarded costly wage increases by a state-run arbitration board, the Mayor says, he may pay for the raises by demanding improved productivity. That could include the use of one-person patrol cars, which he once opposed as unsafe. He also wants to cut overtime and accelerate the transfer of officers from desk jobs to the streets. Mr. Giuliani must not jeopardize public safety or act out of pique, but he is on the right track.

title: A Newfound Mammal Of Philippine Treetops Gets High-Flown Name
description: A MAMMAL species previously unknown to science, a nocturnal, squirrel-like rodent, has been discovered in the Philippines. The mammal, called the Panay cloudrunner, was found as scientists race the chainsaw to document and preserve hitherto unknown animals in the islands' fast-disappearing forests.

title: Campaign Cash:The Ins and Outs
description: Candice Nelson, a professor of government at American University in Washington, is co-author of"The Money Chase," a book on campaign finance reform, and of"Campaigns and Elections: American Style." She spoke to Brian Knowlton of the International Herald Tribune about the role of money in American political campaigns.

title: Q&A
description: Bumblebees

title: With Federal Help, New York Region's Future Looks Brighter
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Two Banks Making Changes in Agencies
description: One financial institution is changing agencies and a second has placed its account in review.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Indian Telephone Ruling
description: The Supreme Court of India dismissed a challenge yesterday to the Government's decision to license private companies to offer basic telephone service. Justice N. P. Singh said the petitioners, including private citizens and opposition members of Parliament, had failed to prove that the Government had acted in bad faith in issuing the licenses. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;CANDIDATES CLASH OVER TRADE ISSUES HEADING INTO VOTE
description: In the final hours before the nation's first primary, the unusually vituperative competition here for the Republican Presidential nomination swerved today into a confrontation over international trade.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Saturday about a presentation of "Du Barry Was a Lady" by Encores! Great American Musicals in Concert at City Center in Manhattan misidentified a song in the Broadway musical "Company." It is "Getting Married Today," not "I'm Not Getting Married."

title: Gore Is Singing a Popular Refrain to Gathered Union Leaders
description: Signing on squarely with the leading items on organized labor's election-year agenda, Vice President Al Gore told the nation's unions today that President Clinton would veto Republican proposals to shrink the Occupational Safety and Health Administration and curb its powers to police the workplace.

title: Georgia Town Settles Lawsuit Over List of 'Troublemakers'
description: Merchants and elected officials in Union Point, a small town about 80 miles east of Atlanta, have settled a lawsuit brought by more than a dozen local residents whose names were put on a list of people believed to be troublemakers, and who were banned from entering local businesses under threat of arrest for trespassing.

title: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;A Flare-Up of Passions On Trade And Jobs
description: Usually arguments over America's trade policies are considered a snooze on the campaign trail, and for four decades how Washington should deal with its economic rivals has rarely been an issue for Republicans, the party of big business and traditionally an unflinching defender of free trade.

title: On-Line Software Deal
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation has agreed to integrate software from Aurum Software Inc. into its popular Navigator software to help companies track sales leads from their sites on the World Wide Web. The companies said today that they would announce the agreement on Tuesday. Aurum's software enables companies to merge sales leads coming from their Web sites into their current internal sales and marketing systems. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: BASEBALL;The Rockies Stopped Short Of Losing Weiss to Cards
description: Even a club that has drawn four million fans in a season and collected more than three million tickets in a strike-soured year has to make some tough financial decisions.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Dysfunctional Family In Divided South Africa
description: Jon Robin Baitz, the young playwright celebrated for such earlier work as "The Substance of Fire" and "The Film Society," is thinking globally in "A Fair Country," a bitter, ambitious if disappointing new family drama that opened last night at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: Israel to Let Palestinian Parliament Members Into Self-Rule Areas
description: Israel said today that it had approved the return of 154 members of the Palestine National Council, including a hijacker, Leila Khaled, to areas controlled by the Palestinian self-rule government.

title: Patterns
description: After Biba, a Grown-Up Look

title: Investors Contend They Won RJR Nabisco Vote
description: In the latest twist in the battle between the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation and Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn, the two investors plan to announce today that they have won a nonbinding shareholder vote supporting a rapid spinoff of the company's food business from its tobacco operations.

title: Artists and Arts Groups Angered By New Rules for Federal Grants
description: Whether or not the National Endowment for the Arts is on its last legs, as many in Washington believe, it has been kept hopping by an outcry over new rules that make it hard or impossible for most aid applicants to get a share of the endowment's devastated budget.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japan Trade Surplus Plummeted in January
description: Japan almost posted a trade deficit in January, the Finance Ministry reported today.

title: BASEBALL;Last Year's Playoff Loss Is Still Bitter for O'Neill
description: Innocently and unwittingly, Nevalee O'Neill made a critical fashion faux pas before venturing out with her husband, Paul, last week. She wore the black and brown outfit, the one she purchased in Seattle when she was pregnant last October, the one she wore on the depressing plane trip back to New York after the Yankees stumbled against the Mariners in the playoffs.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The actor CHARLIE SHEEN says he is divorcing his wife of nearly six months, the model DONNA PEELE.

title: POLITICS: POLITICAL MEMO;Post-Cold War Candidates Find No Place Like Home
description: Among the far-flung ramifications of the end of the cold war, few have been as little noted or studied as its remarkable and immediate impact on the nature of American Presidential campaigns.

title: U.N. and Iraq Fail to Reach Agreement On Oil Sales
description: Two weeks of talks between the Iraqi Government and the United Nations on a plan to allow Iraq limited oil sales to pay for food and medicine ended today without agreement. Both sides said that what happens now was up to political leaders.

title: BASKETBALL;St. Louis Forces Cincinnati to Work for Its 20th Victory
description: Cincinnati 69, St. Louis 64 Art Long scored all but 2 of his 14 points in the second half and Danny Fortson hit six straight free throws in the last two and a half minutes last night as No. 6 Cincinnati held off host St. Louis, 69-64.

title: Dubliners Fear Protestant Raids From North
description: Protestant paramilitary groups in Northern Ireland indicated today that they were seriously considering ending the cease-fire they called in October 1994 and there were fears that they would carry out attacks here in the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republic.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;Saxophone Not Bound By Limits
description: Wessell Anderson's 'Ways'

title: Solar Storm Forecasts
description: Scientists think they are close to providing 50 to 70 hours of warning before huge solar storms knock out telecommunications and electronics systems here on Earth.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.F.L.;Sanders Chooses Football
description: DEION SANDERS of the Dallas Cowboys is expected to announce today that he is temporarily putting his two-sport career on hold to concentrate on being the only two-way player in the National Football League.

title: Exporting an Arms Race
description: The White House is about to take one of the greatest national security gambles since the end of the cold war. To please the computer industry, the Clinton Administration is preparing to send powerful American supercomputers to Russian nuclear weapons laboratories.

title: Treasury Auctions Planned for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a televised news conference for Gary Kasparov, the chess player, misidentified an I.B.M. official appearing with him. It was C. J. Tan, the project manager of the Deep Blue research team, not Feng-Hsiung Hsu.

title: Marijuana Use by Youths Continues to Rise
description: The use of marijuana by adolescents continues to bound back after years of decline, and parents, many of whom once tried drugs themselves, may not have a clue that their own children are experimenting too, according to a nationwide survey scheduled for release today.

title: BASKETBALL;Team Thinks Chemistry As New Knicks Join Up
description: Willie Anderson attracted a gantlet of cameras and microphones today as he walked toward the water bucket after practice. The scene caused Brad Lohaus, that grizzled Knick veteran of 12 days, to shake his head. "New guy, huh?" he asked incredulously.

title: Troubled Past Plagued Youth Held in Killing
description: A 15-year-old boy charged in the death of a woman in a subway robbery on Sunday had a history of severe psychiatric problems and violence, including slashing a schoolmate, threatening to kill himself, hearing voices and abusing drugs, a doctor familiar with his case said yesterday.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;Combination Strategy Reinvigorates Search for AIDS Vaccine
description: Developing an AIDS vaccine is one of the greatest challenges in science. Since the first injections of an experimental AIDS vaccine were given in the United States in 1987, more than 2,000 uninfected adults have received about 20 experimental vaccines. Only a handful of AIDS vaccines have made it to the second of the three stages of the trials that are needed before any vaccine can be marketed. None has reached the third stage, full-scale testing.

title: POLITICS: THE PLAYERS;For Dole's Goal in New Hampshire, the Governor Holds the Cards
description: It was not one of Bob Dole's finer moments. A reporter asked him the other day whether he would sign a bill that would deny welfare benefits to teen-age mothers. The Senator, looking uncomfortable, mumbled something about leaving the decision to the states.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Stratton Acquisition
description: The Stratton Group, a company started by Michael Dingman, an investor based in the Bahamas, has acquired a Russian paper company near the Finnish border. Stratton's purchase, for an undisclosed sum, of AO Segezhabumprom, the largest maker of paper sacks in Europe, is its first investment in Russia and its third investment in the paper industry in the former Eastern bloc. Stratton said yesterday that through a subsidiary, it bought shares in the Russian company directly from workers. The workers received their shares through the nation's voucher sale of state assets. Other shares were purchased from investors. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Mother and Her Boyfriend Held in Beating of Child
description: The angry cursing happened daily and the wall-rattling banging occurred almost as often, but building residents said the screaming was rarer, piercing the air around 1925 Andrews Avenue in the Bronx only once or twice a week.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;They're Superhuman and Teen-Agers. Uh-Oh.
description: Is television just one great big comic book? You'll get no argument from Fox Broadcasting. Its "Tuesday Night Movie" this week is "Generation X," which comes out of Marvel Comics, which in turn has embarked on a venture called Marvel Films-Entertainment Group. Hey, look at the box-office grosses for the Superman and Batman movies.

title: Gompe Chimps Archived on Video and CD-ROM
description: HOLD on to your mouse: Jane Goodall's Gombe chimps are going on line. No, these wild anthropoids have not yet learned to use the computer, but any human who can, will be able to discover billions of bytes about their behavior without ever having to leave a desktop PC.

title: World News Briefs;French Police Round Up Suspected Arab Militants
description: The French police arrested 25 people and seized a cache of arms in 15 raids today on suspected Muslim militants in the Paris region, officials said. Most of those arrested were Algerians and Tunisians; one Frenchman was arrested, at whose home the weapons were found.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Major League Soccer

title: Changing City, Changing Carnival
description: The parade was staged by one of the lesser of the private, secretive clubs that put on the world-famous party of Mardi Gras. What it lacked in history and old money, it filled in with racket and tableau as it lurched along St. Charles Avenue last week, the drums booming like thunderclaps, the colored beads dropping like Kool-Aid rain.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SWIMMING;Riley Cleared to Swim At Atlanta Olympics
description: The world champion SAMANTHA RILEY was cleared yesterday to swim at the Atlanta Olympics, while her coach was banned for two years.

title: 34 Slightly Hurt as Pilot, Fearing Fire, Orders Exit
description: Shortly after an American Airlines jetliner backed away from the gate at Kennedy International Airport about 7 A.M. yesterday, the pilot thought there was a fire on board. So he issued an order that he knew might cause injuries but which might also save lives.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Neglected One-Act Operas
description: The American Chamber Opera Company deserves credit for presenting small-scale contemporary American works.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League CLEVELAND INDIANS -- Agreed to terms with Brian Anderson, pitcher, on a two-year contract. Football National Football League PHILADELPHIA EAGLES -- Named Dick Daniels director of football operations. Canadian Football League BRITISH COLUMBIA LIONS -- Signed Virgil Robertson, linebacker.

title: New Diet Pills Raise Old Safety Questions
description: A NEW generation of diet pills on their way to the market is reigniting old battles over obesity and the dangers of treating it with drugs.

title: The Problem Is Winter, The Answer Is Soup
description: THROUGH blizzards, gentle storms, slush, midwinter blues, transportation delays, leaking roofs, flooded basements, stalled cars, bouts of flu, gray rain and even faint glimmers of spring, there has been one incontrovertible comfort: soup.

title: Microsoft Shifts Focus Of Software
description: Acknowledging that the Internet and other technology trends are shifting the focus of the software market that the Microsoft Corporation has long dominated, the company announced today a series of organizational changes in an effort to redirect the company's product development efforts.

title: Celebrating Cod and Its Royal Ancestry
description: IN conjunction with its exhibition "When Cod Was King," on the history of codfishing, the South Street Seaport Museum, 207 Front Street, has scheduled a series of lectures and tastings sponsored by Saveur Magazine. The first event, a panel discussion by food experts about the use of cod in different cultures, is set for March 9 at 2 P.M. at the A. A. Low Gallery, 171 John Street (at South Street), and is $8 for museum members, $10 for nonmembers.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;In Pursuit Of Elliott, Jets Take Early Lead
description: Giants offensive lineman Jumbo Elliott is in a prime position. He is one of the few top-notch left tackles remaining on the market. He is a Pro Bowl selection who has anchored the left side of the Giants' line for years. Now, however, he could end up signing with the Jets sometime this week.

title: Sarajevo Reborn
description: In every war, and every peace, there are moments that capture a larger truth. The 1994 mortar attack that killed 69 people in Sarajevo's open-air market distilled the brutal violence of the Balkan war. Now the rebirth of the same city symbolizes the promise of peace.

title: GMC and Pontiac: One Division, 2 Images
description: With the merger of its Pontiac and GMC divisions, the General Motors Corporation has sent a clear signal of a strategy it plans to pursue in the years to come: keep well-known brand names alive, while seeking savings in areas that customers are less likely to notice.

title: POLITICS: CAMPAIGN '92;Author, Subject of Article, Denies He Wrote 'Colors'
description: Shouting over the din of a New Hampshire press room as he covered the Presidential primary voting yesterday, Joe Klein denied repeatedly that he is Anonymous, the author of "Primary Colors," the recent roman a clef about the Presidential race of 1992.

title: BASKETBALL;Seton Hall Hangs On To Shock Syracuse
description: Syracuse is ranked in the top 20 in the nation. It had won its last five games and it has won game after game on the heroics of John Wallace, its 6-foot-8-inch power forward and a potential lottery pick in the National Basketball Association draft. Seton Hall had lost its last six games, and it has struggled all season to put two good games together, let alone win them.

title: Russia Says 170 Chechens Died in Attack on Main Rebel Town
description: In a move that raised new questions about President Boris N. Yeltsin's campaign promise to end the war in Chechnya, the Russian military has attacked the main rebel stronghold in the secessionist republic.

title: Restricting Divorce Hurts Children and Women;Earn Right to Say 'I Do'
description: To the Editor:

title: Restricting Divorce Hurts Children and Women;A Contract to Be Kept
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Vigil for a Slain Youth
description: A candlelight vigil is scheduled for tonight at the site where a black teen-ager, Lawrence Meyers, was fatally shot by a white housing police officer a year ago. The shooting, ruled accidental by the Passaic County Prosecutor's office, prompted demonstrations by some black residents.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: No Headline
description: If it had been in Guam, I would have gone there."

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;With Just a Single Loss, UConn Is Feeling Neurotic
description: As the Connecticut Huskies manufactured their record winning streak, not once trailing in the second half of 23 consecutive victories, they could not help but look at a challenge ahead. "I think I want to gauge our defense against Georgetown," Ray Allen volunteered more than three weeks ago. "That'll be the true test."

title: Agreement Reached in Wellpoint Deal
description: Blue Cross of California reached a definitive agreement today to recapitalize Wellpoint Health Networks Inc. in a deal that will result in a charitable foundation initially holding more than 80 percent of the new Wellpoint.

title: FILM REVIEW;Slackers With Ambition: To Become Desperadoes
description: Wes Anderson's suburban slacker comedy "Bottle Rocket" begins with a not-so-daring escape. Actually, it's no escape at all. When Anthony (Luke Wilson) leaves the mental hospital in which he has spent time, he waves goodbye to patients and doctors and strolls away in open sight. Anyone in his right mind could tell that Anthony was leaving the hospital a free man.

title: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;BUCHANAN A NARROW VICTOR OVER DOLE IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: Patrick J. Buchanan eked out a razor-thin victory in the Republican Presidential primary in New Hampshire on Tuesday, defeating Senator Bob Dole with a fiery anti-Washington message that left Mr. Dole struggling to reignite his campaign.

title: Governors Want New Focus on Education
description: Worried that the momentum for overhauling American education is slipping away, the nation's governors plan to gather next month for a second discussion of the subject, six years after President George Bush called them together to make radical changes in the country's schools.

title: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;BUCHANAN A NARROW VICTOR OVER DOLE IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: With the whole nation listening intently, New Hampshire roared once more tonight and delivered a stentorian message that promises confusion for the Republican Party for months to come.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Computer Maker Bull Returns to the Black
description: Compagnie des Machines Bull, France's biggest computer company, reported yesterday that it had its first profit in seven years in 1995, posting net income of 306 million French francs ($61 million). The company had piled up losses totaling more than 22 billion francs in the preceding six years, including 1.96 billion francs in 1994.

title: U.S. Orders Passenger Trains to Slow Down After Some Stations
description: After 14 deaths in commuter train wrecks in the last 14 days, the Transportation Department today issued emergency procedures intended to reduce the speed of the trains after they leave stations where there are no signals..

title: COMPANY NEWS;PUBLIC OFFERING PLANNED FOR PLANET HOLLYWOOD
description: Planet Hollywood International Inc. registered yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a initial public offering of common shares. The restaurant chain, based in Orlando, Fla., estimated that the offering would raise up to $190.5 million. The company said it planned to use $130.8 million of the net proceeds to pay debt and the rest for general corporate purposes, including new restaurants. Planet Hollywood has 22 company-owned and six franchised restaurants in eight countries. Some of Hollywood's biggest stars, including Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sylvester Stallone, Bruce Willis, Demi Moore and Whoopi Goldberg, are shareholders.

title: Restricting Divorce Hurts Children and Women;Take the Pain Away
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Mediterranean Pulse for Oriental Tales
description: To say that the music of Maurice Ohana is multicultural is to paste a buzzword over a rich and singular life. Though usually bracketed as a French composer, Ohana was born in Casablanca, Morocco, of British and Spanish descent; his father came from Gibraltar. He studied and later settled in Paris. Having assimilated influences from Falla, Debussy and Stravinsky, he rejected the Serialist fashions that swept Europe after World War II and returned to his Mediterranean roots, steeping himself in Andalusian, North African and ancient Byzantine traditions.

title: Anti-Semitic Graffiti Sprayed on Homes in Westchester
description: Twelve-year-old Julia Kleinman, a slight blond girl with braces, stood in the snow and gazed at the slur on the clapboard-sided white house, "Kill Jews" in black capital letters almost half as tall as she is.

title: The Unwilling Witness
description: Warren Moon, the Minnesota Vikings' star quarterback, was arrested and charged with assault last summer after an alleged altercation with his wife, Felicia. Now his home state, Texas, adamantly wants him convicted. His wife, equally adamantly, does not.

title: Food Notes
description: Speaking of Italian Food

title: Clean Food's Flip Side
description: To The Living Section:

title: HOCKEY;Richter to Miss at Least Two Weeks
description: Mike Richter was back at practice today, two days after reinjuring his groin in a loss at Pittsburgh, but it will be several weeks before he is ready to play again.

title: 2 Customs Agents Are Facing Charges In Kidnapping Case
description: Two United States Customs inspectors have been charged with kidnapping and beating a suspected drug dealer last year while trying to rob him of cash and cocaine, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Why the I.R.A. Stopped Talking
description: The Irish peace process is in ruins.

title: Building Cooking Expertise, A Meal (or Two) at a Time
description: MY husband, who periodically vows to help fix dinner, had to make good on his word not long ago when I went out of town. With our 13-year-old daughter, we planned the menus and included four of her favorite dinners.

title: Dr. Francesca M. Thompson, 51, Chronicler of Fight With Cancer
description: Dr. Francesca Morosani Thompson, a prominent orthopedic surgeon at Roosevelt Hospital who chronicled her struggle against cancer of the bone marrow in a book, "Going for the Cure," died on Thursday at New York Hospital. A resident of the Upper East Side of Manhattan, she was 51.

title: BASEBALL;It's Early, But Kent Is Shedding The Blues
description: The face and the uniform belonged to Jeff Kent, but the smile and the personality suggested otherwise. Could this be the same player who wore a scowl for much of last season and kept many of his teammates and reporters at arm's length?

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies on Monday about a study by the National Taxpayers Union on budget votes by the state's Congressional delegation misstated the group's finding about Representative Robert G. Torricelli. The study said Mr. Torricelli, Democrat of Englewood, voted in 1995 to increase Federal spending by a net amount of $38.2 billion, not $25.3 billion.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Mass merchandisers jostle with tobacco companies to cash in on the auto racing craze.
description: IS the Winston Cup about to become the Kleenex Cup?

title: Citing Crackdown on Dissidents, Cuban Group Cancels Conference
description: A coalition of Cuban dissident and human rights groups has canceled plans to hold a conference here this weekend, citing what they called "a wave of repression" by the state security apparatus against the organizers of the event, which would have been the first of its kind.

title: BASEBALL;Atlanta's Real Summer Games
description: For the first time since the night they won the World Series, Bobby Cox gathered all of his players in the Atlanta Braves' clubhouse today. With suntan lotion substituting for Champagne, the manager issued a warning.

title: Personal Health
description: MANY adults in this country are justifiably envious of young people who grew up drinking fluoridated water, using fluoride toothpastes and rinses and having sealants applied to protect the chewing surfaces of their teeth.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the effect of the winter's big snowstorms on ski resorts in the Northeast misspelled the surname of the general manager of the Red Lion Inn in Stockbridge, Mass. He is Brooks Bradbury, not Bradbudy.

title: Market Place;The civil war at RJR Nabisco has seen only its first major battle.
description: BENNETT S. LEBOW and his fellow investor, Carl C. Icahn, have claimed victory in the first major offensive of their five-month battle with the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation. But can they win the war?

title: Agency Asks Park's Friends to Heal Its Weather Wounds
description: Inside Lock 44 of the Chesapeake & Ohio Canal, just south of here along the Potomac River in western Maryland, huge chunks of ice lie strewn about as if flung by a mighty discus thrower. Scaffolding that workers had been using to repair the locks peeks out from its frozen entombment, and even some of the heavy stones, set in 1834 when the lock wall was built, appear badly chipped by the force of ice and other debris.

title: Bosnian Serbs Pressed to Flee Area Near Sarajevo
description: In violation of the spirit if not the letter of the Dayton peace agreement, Bosnian Serb leaders are urgently pressing all Serbs living near Sarajevo to abandon their communities before the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government assumes control in the coming weeks.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DEAN FOODS SAYS EARNINGS COULD FALL 50%
description: The Dean Foods Company said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings could fall as much as 50 percent from the corresponding period last year because of problems in its vegetable business. Analysts had expected the company to report earnings of 42 cents a share in the quarter ending on Sunday, compared with 43 cents a year ago, according to Zacks Investment Research. The company, based in Franklin Park, Ill., may also take a charge against earnings in the fourth quarter if a reorganization program is enacted, Howard M. Dean, the company's chairman, said. "It is possible we might sell off some operations," he said. Shares of Dean Foods fell $1.125 yesterday, to $26.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions on Monday with an article about victims of Friday's collision of an Amtrak train and a commuter train in Silver Spring, Md., reversed the identities of two passengers in some editions. Rodney Crawford (with a mustache), 19, was injured in the crash; the second person pictured, Dante Swain, 18, was killed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Account Review For Playskool Toys
description: Hasbro Inc. in Pawtucket, R.I., has placed in review the broadcast advertising portion of the account of its Playskool line of toys, which has been handled by Griffin Bacal Inc. in New York. Though the billings were not disclosed, Advertising Age estimated them at $30 million.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Miami Overcomes St. John's in Overtime
description: In the end, there was just too much Steve Rich tonight for St. John's.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;U.S. Money for AIDS Centers
description: For the first time since the fiscal year began last October, Newark and Jersey City have received Federal money for clinics and AIDS services groups. But both came up short compared with last year because of the budget battle.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Mettle and Tenderness, Too
description: Three years ago, the young Romanian soprano Angela Gheorghiu made a notable Metropolitan Opera debut as Mimi in "La Boheme." Since then she has been acclaimed in Paris and London, particularly for her Violetta in a Covent Garden "La Traviata" conducted by Sir Georg Solti, a performance now available on a London recording.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HAWKER SIDDELEY TO SPIN OFF 55% STAKE IN CGTX
description: Hawker Siddeley Canada Inc. said yesterday that it would spin off its 55 percent stake in CGTX Inc. in a deal with Procor Ltd. Procor, which is part of Chicago-based Marmon Group Inc., plans to offer $14.85 (Canadian) a share for the CGTX stake, which amounts to about $120 million (Canadian), or $87 million (United States). CGTX is a Chicago-based transportation and distribution concern. Hawker Siddeley's businesses include engine repair and sawmill equipment. In December, Hawker Siddeley turned down an offer by the GATX Corporation, which owns the other 45 percent of CGTX, to buy the 55 percent stake. Hawker Siddeley is based in Mississauga, Ontario.

title: Executive Changes
description: GRAND METROPOLITAN P.L.C., London, said it had appointed John Keenan, who headed the worldwide expansion of Kraft Foods International, as chief executive of its spirits division.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TEXAS INSTRUMENTS PLANS ANOTHER CHIP PLANT IN DALLAS
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said yesterday that it planned to build a $2 billion semiconductor factory in Dallas, only months after completing a similar plant nearby. The new plant will be used to build digital signal processors, high-speed chips that are designed to handle a variety of signals. The chips are used in devices ranging from computer hard drives and modems to cellular telephones and children's toys. Texas Instruments, based in Dallas, is completing the second phase of a $1 billion plant that will begin producing the processors this year.

title: DANCE REVIEW;The Allure of an Orange
description: Neta Pulvermacher offered dance to dazzle the eye in a program of new and recent work presented by the Danspace Project on Friday night at St. Mark's Church. Ms. Pulvermacher's new "To Bite an Orange With Its Peel," danced to Schumann lieder, was performed in front of Jerry Gilmore's projections of giant glistening oranges: whole, sliced and ranging in color from pale yellow to blood red.

title: Toru Takemitsu, 65, Introspective Composer Whose Music Evokes East andWest, Is Dead
description: Toru Takemitsu, a prolific composer known for his intensely introspective and usually gently etched concert works as well as for the dozens of colorful, evocative scores he wrote for Japanese films, died yesterday at Toranomen Hospital in Tokyo.
