He was 65 and had homes in Tokyo and in the mountains near Karuizawa, northwest of Tokyo, where he did much of his composing.

title: POLITICS: THE FUTURE;A Hard Race Is Over, but Things Might Get Harder
description: With the New Hampshire primary and Iowa caucuses behind them, the Republican Presidential candidates confronted a new, exhausting reality tonight: The upcoming two weeks might make these last two grueling months seem almost easy.

title: Wife Recalls Subway Bomber's Obsessions
description: The wife of Edward J. Leary took the witness stand yesterday in her husband's defense, telling jurors how his behavior became increasingly bizarre and obsessive in the months and weeks leading up to two subway firebombings that he carried out 14 months ago.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;The Chemistry Just Isn't Right for the New Knicks
description: The Knicks have started a period of transition. And it may also be a period of regression.

title: Research Links Writing Style to the Risk of Alzheimer's
description: Alzheimer's disease, the dreaded affliction of old age, might show its first subtle effects when its victims are as young as 20.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Fuji Bank to Cut 12% of Work Force
description: Fuji Bank plans to cut its work force by 1,800 jobs, or 12 percent, in the next three years, its president said yesterday. Japanese banks are trying to cut costs because of huge amounts of bad debt left from soured loans made to real estate and stock speculators in the late 1980's.

title: Levi Strauss Stock Buyout Would Benefit Small Group
description: A newly released company document shows that the proposed multibillion-dollar buyout of some shareholders by Levi Strauss Associates Inc. would provide unusual benefits for the company's chairman, Robert D. Haas, and a small number of other people close to him.

title: Jobs and Environment Aren't in Conflict
description: To the Editor

title: Iraqi Defector Goes Home, To Father-in-Law Hussein
description: The Iraqi general and son-in-law to Saddam Hussein whose defection six months ago was seen as a major blow to the Iraqi Government abandoned his exile in Jordan today and returned to Iraq with members of his family.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sunday about New Hampshire's economy and the state's Presidential votes since 1976 misstated results of those elections through 1988. The chart also included an erroneous footnote in some editions about the 1980 election. An independent candidate, John Anderson (not John Glenn), won 12.9 percent of the vote in New Hampshire, not 10 percent.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Beard Has Something To Smile About
description: Butch Beard's players are beginning to notice a not-so-subtle difference in their coach: He's starting to have fun.

title: COMPANY NEWS;McDONALD'S BOUGHT BACK 8 MILLION SHARES IN 1995
description: The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that it bought back about eight million shares for about $300 million last year. The company bought the shares under a three-year, $1 billion repurchase plan that was announced in January 1994. McDonald's said last month that it expected the buyback to be completed early this year, and that it planned to buy back another $2 billion of common stock in the next three years. As of Dec. 31, there were 699.8 million common shares outstanding. Its shares fell 50 cents yesterday, to $49.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. The shares traded at about $28 when the buyback began.

title: Record Labels Sue Amway Over Its Videos
description: Eleven of the largest record companies filed a multimillion-dollar lawsuit yesterday in the United States District Court in Orlando, Fla., accusing the Amway Corporation and 39 of its distributors with copyright infringement and unfair competition.

title: Can SUNY Afford Cornell?;Officials Are Questioning Division of State Support
description: Perched atop a hill at the edge of Cayuga Lake, Cornell University is best known as a private Ivy League institution, one that just raised $1.5 billion. But it is also part of the State University system, receiving about $170 million a year to teach industrial arts and farming.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: West Side Project Has Many Opponents
description: To the Editor:

title: Journal;The New Cynics
description: Since my household is not yet protected by the V-chip, I could not prevent Simon, who is 11, from stealing glimpses of the G.O.P. bloodbath in New Hampshire. But when I caught him red-handed over the weekend watching a Steve Forbes rally on C-Span, he had an airtight excuse: He was reporting a story.

title: House Democrats Assail Welfare Plan Backed by Governors
description: House Democrats today sharply criticized a package of welfare proposals endorsed unanimously this month by members of the National Governors' Association, including 18 Democrats.

title: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
description: Japanese stocks traded lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 283.44 points, or 1.37 percent, at 20,372.23. On Tuesday the index was off 65.58 points.

title: Pataki Plans to Tax Goods Bought on Reservations
description: The Pataki administration adopted regulations today to resolve a problem that has frustrated the state for years: how to collect sales taxes from businesses on Indian reservations without violating Indian sovereignty.

title: Mexico Tortilla Maker Won No Favors
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Assails The Candidacy Of Buchanan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani still may not be ready to say whom he will endorse among the Republican candidates for President, but yesterday he narrowed the field, declaring that he would never support Patrick J. Buchanan for any elected office because of his positions on immigration, race and religion.

title: Thorn EMI Planning to Spin Off Its Rental-Equipment Operations
description: Thorn EMI P.L.C. said today that it would spin off its rentals unit at the end of July and reported a 29 percent jump in nine-month pretax profit.

title: Chiron to Buy Nearly Half Of Hoechst Vaccine Unit
description: The Chiron Corporation, a leading biotechnology company, said today that it had agreed to buy 49 percent of the human-vaccine business of Behringwerke A.G., for $118 million in cash.

title: In the Train Wrecks' Aftermath
description: Two train collisions seven days apart have brought calamity to the ordinarily quiet and safe commuter systems of New York and Washington D.C. Federal and local officials are responding with intense investigations and emergency measures. They have already found some surprising soft spots in the rail network's safety rules and practices.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: The Vision Thing, Again
description: The New Hampshire primary results may teach the Republican Party what the Democrats learned in the era of Walter Mondale -- the Presidency is not a reward for faithful party service. Senator Bob Dole has yet to find a message that means anything to Americans worried about a brand-new set of economic problems. Like Ted Kennedy's disastrous foray in 1980, Mr. Dole's wounded run for President has been defined by his inability even to articulate why he wants the job.

title: Top Court Official Declines to Reassign Judge
description: New York State's top administrative judge yesterday refused to reassign -- even temporarily -- a Criminal Court judge whose removal has been demanded by Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Stockton Breaks Record for Steals
description: John Stockton broke Maurice Cheeks's National Basketball Association record for career steals tonight. The Utah guard reached steal No. 2,311 when he snatched the ball from the hands of Boston's Eric Williams with 8 minutes 21 seconds remaining in a 112-98 victory over the Celtics.

title: Man Held in Abuse At Day-Care Center
description: A man whose wife runs a day-care center has been charged with sexually abusing a 3-year-old girl at the center, the authorities said today.

title: CUC Will Buy 2 Software Companies for $1.8 Billion
description: CUC International Inc., a company best known for its membership shopping clubs, said yesterday that it planned to swap more than $1.8 billion in stock to acquire two leading consumer software companies, Sierra On-Line Inc. and Davidson & Associates.

title: Wine Talk
description: ORLEY ASHENFELTER, the Princeton University economist who regularly upsets the wine establishment with his unorthodox approach to judging vintages, has completed a new classification of California cabernet sauvignons.

title: Cuba's 16th Jazz Festival, Dazzling in Its Obscurity
description: Sometime during the middle of the sprawling, disorganized and endlessly rich Jazz Festival Plaza 96 in Havana last week, a Japanese trumpeter stood up next to a Cuban saxophonist with dreadlocks and played an American blues with musicians from the United States. It wasn't particularly good music, but it did suggest that the world, with all its political, national and cultural stances, was finding a common language, at least for a moment or two.

title: INSIDE
description: Indictments on Clinton Gifts

title: Testimony by Greenspan Rattles Stock and Bond Markets;Blue Chips Fall 44.79; 30-Year Bond Plunges In Fourth Day of Selloff
description: Stock and bond markets declined sharply yesterday, continuing a four-day selloff that is leading some investors to question whether a fundamental shift in sentiment might be under way.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Unilever Net Off 14%; Strong Guilder Cited
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch consumer products maker, said yesterday that its profit fell 14 percent in 1995 because of the guilder's strength, charges for revampings and sluggish consumer spending. The company earned 3.73 billion guilders ($2.29 billion) last year, compared with 4.34 billion guilders in 1994.

title: Real Estate;A securities firm finds some ready-made trading space available for lease in midtown.
description: BREAN MURRAY FOSTER SECURITIES INC. has leased 35,000 square feet at 570 Lexington Avenue, the landmarked Art Deco building that was for many years the headquarters of the General Electric Company.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Valentin Gets Big Raise
description: After arguing their case yesterday before the arbitrator IRA JAFFE, shortstop JOHN VALENTIN and the Boston Red Sox agreed to a one-year contract worth $2.673 million, up from $637,5000 last season.

title: 2 Bankers Who Gave to Clinton Are Indicted for Misusing Funds
description: Two bankers were indicted today on Federal charges that they misused bank money and hid political contributions to several campaigns including that of Bill Clinton when he was re-elected Arkansas Governor in 1990.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TEXTRON TO ACQUIRE A FRENCH MAKER OF FASTENERS
description: Textron Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Valois Industries of France for cash and assumed debt, continuing a plan to build its fastener business through acquisitions. Textron declined to provide terms of the deal, but Les Echos, a French newspaper, reported that Textron would pay about 1.25 billion francs, or $250 million. Valois, a Paris-based maker of engineered fastening systems for automobiles, electronics and household appliances, had sales of $435 million in 1995. The acquisition will raise Textron's fastener-business revenue to $1.5 billion this year, from $1 billion in 1995, the company said.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Moon Takes Stand to Deny That He Attacked His Wife
description: Defending himself against charges of spousal abuse, Warren Moon took the stand tonight and firmly denied assaulting his wife, Felicia, at their home in Missouri City, Tex., last summer. The appearance on the stand by the Minnesota Vikings' quarterback came shortly after prosecutors rested their misdemeanor case against him.

title: Eating Well
description: THIS is not a trick question:

title: G.O.P. Commandment
description: To the Editor:

title: Their Fast Over, Muslims Offer Some Advice for Lent
description: As Ramadan, the Islamic month of fasting, ended yesterday and the Christian penitential season of Lent began today, a group of Muslim university students had some direct advice for Christians who were contemplating fasting:

title: Jail Is Under Investigation After 2 Inmates Are Charged in a Woman'sRape
description: Prosecutors and the county police are investigating operations at the Union County Jail after two inmates were charged last week with raping a woman who had been held in the jail overnight.

title: Hospital Did Not Monitor Outpatient Treatment of Suspect in SubwayMurder
description: Doctors at Kings County Hospital Center never checked on the outpatient treatment of a mentally ill teen-ager accused in the death of a woman in a subway robbery on Sunday, even though state officials say regulations require psychiatric hospitals to monitor such patients to make sure they get the help they need after discharge.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Scarred Cradle of Black America: Mississippi
description: MISSISSIPPI An American Journey By Anthony Walton Illustrated. 279 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.

title: Layoffs at Kimberly-Clark
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation, the maker of Cottonelle bathroom tissue and Scott napkins, said today that it planned to spend $40 million to modernize a tissue mill in Chester, Pa. The move, which calls for rebuilding a tissue machine, will result in the loss of 100 jobs, of which 40 have already been eliminated.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SUNAMERICA TO BUY ANNUITY CONTRACTS FROM BENEFICIAL
description: SunAmerica Inc. said yesterday that its SunAmerica Life Insurance unit had agreed to buy the $950 million annuity portfolio of the Central National Life Insurance Company of Omaha, a unit of the Beneficial Corporation. The purchase price was not disclosed. Central National will transfer about 45,000 single- and flexible-premium fixed annuity contracts, held mainly in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and North Carolina. The purchase, along with other recently announced acquisitions, will add about $4.5 billion in assets to Los Angeles-based SunAmerica, bringing its total assets to nearly $34 billion.

title: Sports of The Times;A Chess King Bails Out the Big Four
description: ONLY seven weeks into 1996, Garry Kasparov is the leader in the clubhouse for Sportsman of the Year. Well, not exactly Sportsman of the Year, since he is a chess player, but certainly Human of the Year or Brain of the Year.

title: Oklahoma Bombing Case To Be Moved to Colorado
description: Citing extensive publicity that had "demonized" the two men charged with bombing the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, a Federal judge has ruled that the accused could not get a fair trial anywhere in the state of Oklahoma and ordered the case moved to Denver.

title: Sheep Inc.: As a Herd Grows, So Do a Restaurant and Inn
description: TOM CLARK, who lives in Rye, N.Y., and has an investment company in Greenwich, Conn., has long been interested in raising sheep. "I grew up near Poughkeepsie, my grandfather had 25 acres, and I took care of three sheep," he said.

title: Bugner Is Rejected In His Bid to Fight
description: The heavyweight boxer Joe Bugner has been turned down for a second time in his bid to fight in Britain.

title: Business Travel;France is going on the Internet to provide information for visitors.
description: WITH cyberized savoir-faire befitting the 1990's, France is going on the Internet next month with a complete catalogue of just about everything you need to know about the country to make your visit as smooth as a glass of Dom Perignon.

title: Mr. Holland' Succeeds, Almost Despite Itself
description: The title is a dud. The film is probably 20 minutes too long. Its star has been stuck in the down cycle of an erratic career. The director is a virtual unknown. And even the movie's producer needs several paragraphs to explain what it's about.

title: Food Allergy Called Unseen Asthma Villain
description: COULD food allergies contribute to asthma attacks? Allergies to inhaled substances like pollen, molds, dust mites and animal dander often touch off asthma attacks in susceptible people. Now, a new study has linked food allergies to the respiratory difficulties that underlie asthma.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;A Hot, Low-Fat Sausage Hash
description: Low-fat sausages are unsung heroes of the reduced-fat movement. So much of their flavor comes from the seasoning, not just the fat, that it is possible to recreate mouth-watering versions with much less fat. Try a spicy sausage -- Southwestern, Thai, hot Italian -- in a favorite American comfort food, hash. Serve it with a spinach and mushroom salad.

title: Seoul and Tokyo Dispute Offshore Islands
description: Japan and South Korea staked competing claims to waters around their shores today, in a dispute over islets that fall within those waters.

title: Unit of Merck Files a Suit
description: Merck-Medco Managed Care Inc., a unit of Merck & Company, said today that it had filed an antitrust suit against four pharmacy retailers in Baltimore.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNOCAL TO SELL OIL AND GAS FIELDS IN CALIFORNIA
description: In a continuing trend by major oil companies to sell off domestic assets to finance exploration overseas, Unocal said yesterday that it was selling its oil and gas fields in California for $500 million to the Nuevo Energy Company of Houston. John J. Myers, an analyst at Morgan Keegan & Company of Austin, Tex., said the acquisition would triple Nuevo's oil and gas reserves and thrust the company, formed in 1990, into the ranks of one of the midsized independents. Such independents often cut staff and salaries, contract out much of the operations and call in their own technical experts. Nuevo's shares rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $23.625, on the Big Board; Unocal shares fell 25 cents, to $30.875. The sale was negotiated by Torch Energy Advisors Inc., which will operate the fields for Nuevo. The fields involved belong to a Unocal subsidiary, the Union Oil Company of California.

title: Brothers Draw Long Sentences in Killing of a Police Officer
description: As a police officer's widow described the anguish of losing her new husband, two teen-age brothers were sentenced yesterday to long prison terms for their roles in a Brooklyn robbery in which their uncle shot and killed the officer.

title: BASEBALL;Fernandez Says Hello, Now Trade Me
description: Tony Fernandez does not want to cause a commotion. He does not want to be a problem in the clubhouse and does not want to create a distraction by complaining about his status. Especially on the first official day of full-squad workouts.

title: Reporter's Notebook;Reservations by Labor About Surf-Side Meetings
description: It is always a matter of considerable chagrin to me," Samuel Gompers, president of the American Federation of Labor, wrote in 1910, "if at any time I cannot bring myself in agreement to a recommendation of my colleagues of the executive council."

title: Anguish of Rwanda Echoed in a Baby's Cry
description: Exhausted from hours of labor in a hospital tent at the center of the sprawling refugee camp, Jacqueline Nyiranza held her first baby, a scrawny and wrinkled infant, close to her breast. The baby, born prematurely, was weak, and she held it as if it were the most fragile thing imaginable, as if it were the only hope she had to rebuild a life shattered by war and flight.

title: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;Down to the Wire, a Clutch Of Candidates and Choices
description: I just now made up my mind right there," said Ruth Nottage, gesturing down at the entry threshold of the Town Hall voting precinct here this morning to underline the impetuosity forced upon her by what she decided was a befuddling slate of Republican Presidential contenders.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Spare The Rod And Spoil Little Heidi
description: Be too permissive with your daughter and she is likely to grow up to be a Hollywood madam. That seems to be the message of the forcefully acted cautionary tale called "The Good Doctor: The Paul Fleiss Story," tonight's television movie on CBS. You may not be too familiar with Dr. Fleiss, but surely you couldn't have missed the lurid headlines about his daughter Heidi. This is her shabby story, artfully fudged in spots, as seen through Daddy's eyes.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Hong Kong and Singapore Vow To Join Japan in Monetary Steps
description: Monetary authorities in Hong Kong and Singapore have agreed to intervene in their currency markets on behalf of Japan, an arrangement that will give Tokyo a new weapon in resisting the rise of the yen, Japanese officials said today.

title: Cox Is Reported About to Buy A Stake in Special-Effects Maker
description: Cox Enterprises, the big media company, is planning on Wednesday to announce here that it is buying a one-third interest in Digital Domain, a leader in computer-generated special effects and images, people with knowledge of the deal said today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Title Fights Are Set
description: Three world title fights have been added to the pay-per-view card of the MIKE TYSON-FRANK BRUNO World Boxing Council heavyweight championship bout on March 16 in Las Vegas, Nev., the promoter DON KING said yesterday.

title: POLITICS;For the Pollsters, Too Close for Comfort
description: For those who make their living predicting elections, it was a nail-biting night.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ARTHUR OCHS SULZBERGER, chairman and chief executive of The New York Times Company, plans to marry ALLISON COWLES on March 9 in a small family ceremony in Spokane, Wash.

title: A Simple Garlic Peeler That Works Almost Too Well
description: AN inexpensive, ridiculously simple gadget -- a small rubber tube shaped like a cannoli mold -- has quietly entered the pantheon of kitchen tools. The E-Z-Rol garlic peeler works and works fast, unlike the multitude of other garlic gadgets on the market, and it actually makes garlic peeling fun.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Judge Rules Against Dallas
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan refused yesterday to grant the Dallas Cowboys' motion to dismiss NFL Properties' $300 million suit against them charging that the team's deals for Nike, Pepsi-Cola and American Express to sponsor Texas Stadium violate the National Football League licensing and sponsorship policies.

title: In Era of Fiscal Damage Control, Cities Fight Idea of 'Tax Exempt'
description: Most everyone here agrees with Mayor Roy A. Bernardi that Syracuse, like many cities across the country, has a problem: declines in Federal, state and local aid have left it so starved for funds that it is nearing a crisis.

title: BASEBALL;Baseball's Owners Plan New Proposal
description: Baseball's club owners plan to give the players' representatives another proposal today in an effort to settle their labor dispute and forge a new collective bargaining agreement before the season starts.

title: Supreme Court Roundup;Justices Reconsider Law Requiring Cable TV to Carry Local Stations' Signals
description: In a case with important First Amendment implications for Government regulation of communications, the Supreme Court agreed today to review a 1992 Federal law that requires cable television systems to retransmit the signals of local broadcast television stations.

title: Poll Indicates Support for Tax to Rebuild Schools
description: Rather than allow a $1.50-a-week tax to expire, an overwhelming majority of New Yorkers would be willing to redirect the money to help rebuild the city's crumbling schools, according to the results of a poll released yesterday by Quinnipiac College.

title: About New York;A Latin Takes Manhattan
description: BALBUENA has finally arrived!

title: French Court Upholds Award in van Gogh Sale
description: France's highest civil court ordered the state today to pay an art collector $29 million to settle a dispute over a van Gogh masterpiece.

title: Foundation Underwrites Intelligence Research
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: TINA BROWN, editor of The New Yorker, is awash in women's issues. A double issue of the magazine, called the Women's Issue, with a pink cover, is on newsstands. Today, Ms. Brown is holding a lunch at the Americas Society in Manhattan for 65 prominent women to talk about women's issues.

title: POLITICS;Dole Still Leads in Money
description: Senator Bob Dole remains the leader in raising money, adding $1.79 million to his coffers in January, which held a total of $4.8 million at the start of February.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Crude Oil Prices Rise Sharply On Lack of Agreement With Iraq
description: Crude oil prices posted their sharpest one-day gain since the Persian Gulf war yesterday, while gold prices tumbled.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: H& R Block to Spin Off Its Compuserve Subsidiary Taxes and cyberspace have apparently not been quite the right mix for H& R Block, which is spinning off Compuserve, its on-line service subsidiary. The company plans to sell a 20 percent stake in Compuserve to the public and distribute the rest to its shareholders.

title: Olestra vs. Bovine Hormone
description: To The Living Section:

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Rate Doubts Still Undercut Bond Prices
description: Investors in Treasury bonds extended their losing streak to four sessions yesterday as disappointment with the Federal Reserve and technical factors led prices down.

title: COMPANY NEWS;4HEALTH AND SURGICAL TECHNOLOGIES PLAN TO MERGE
description: 4Health Inc. said yesterday that it would merge with Surgical Technologies Inc. in a "reverse acquisition" that would allow shares of closely held 4Health to trade publicly. The companies valued the transaction at $36 million. Surgical Technologies will buy 4Health, which will then assume control of the merged company. 4Health, based in Boulder, Colo., makes Nature's Secret and Harmony Formulas nutritional supplements. Surgical Technologies, based in Salt Lake City, will issue nine million shares for 4Health shareholders. Its stock will be split 1 for 2 after the transaction is completed, leaving Surgical Technologies shareholders with 2.25 million 4Health shares, or 20 percent of stock outstanding.

title: London Police Uncover I.R.A. Explosives
description: Anti-terrorist officers investigating the recent spate of bomb attacks in London said today that they had uncovered large caches of Irish Republican Army bomb-making equipment and explosives in a series of raids around the capital overnight and this morning.

title: Sports of The Times;Knicks Have Their Own Fault Line
description: THOSE cute little earthquakes in northern New Jersey have nothing to do with the Ramapo fault line. They are, instead, aftershocks from the jittery Anderson plate and the skittery Coleman plate shifting out of danger.

title: Mental Health Care for Outpatients Is Often Lax
description: Mental-health officials and advocates have grappled repeatedly in recent years with the problem of patients who, after leaving the hospital, fail to take their medication, deteriorating and sometimes posing a danger to themselves or others.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ORACLE AND VERIFONE TO PURSUE ON-LINE PAYMENT SYSTEM
description: The Oracle Corporation, the giant data base software developer, and Verifone Inc., the largest developer of credit-card verification systems, will announce an alliance today to create a secure payment system for consumers and businesses on the Internet. The system will combine Oracle's Webserver software with Verifone's secure payment software to give merchants, banks and other financial providers an on-line payment system. The companies will also incorporate the Verifone Pay Window software into Oracle's Power Browser, its free browser for surfing the Internet's World Wide Web. Verifone's Pay Window software will provide transaction options and make the Power Browser easier to use.

title: Abused Boy Found Dead In the Bronx
description: In unrelated incidents, two Bronx children -- both of whom were taken from city custody and returned to a parent -- became the latest additions to New York City's list of child abuse victims yesterday. One 2-year-old boy was found dead and his father was charged with murder; a 2-year-old girl was raped and her mother and uncle were arrested.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;O'Donnell Is Impressed by Visit With Jets
description: Neil O'Donnell, the free-agent quarterback who helped take the Pittsburgh Steelers to the Super Bowl, got a chance to tour the Jets' complex at Hofstra University this morning, talk with various team administrators and eat lunch with Leon Hess, the team's reclusive multimillionaire owner.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday with an article about the efforts of WNET, the New York public television station, to change its image misstated production credits for two series from WGBH, the Boston public television station. WGBH is the sole producer of "Masterpiece Theater" and "Mystery," although the BBC and other British television production companies are co-producers of some individual programs.

title: TALKING TOYS WITH: Betty James;Persevering for Family and Slinky
description: THE elevator in the Toy Building is packed. The door opens on six and a petite woman dressed in black steps out.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Car Grant From the Pentagon
description: Electric cars not only run cleanly, but they might have military uses. The state's Department of Transportation said yesterday that it had received a $100,000 Pentagon grant to buy two Geo Metro cars refitted for electric power.

title: OLYMPICS;Atlanta's Biggest Concern Is Finances
description: With the Games only 150 days away, Atlanta's Olympic preparations are generally on target, but concerns remain about finances, an International Olympic Committee official said today.

title: Testimony by Greenspan Rattles Stock and Bond Markets;Hopes of Rate Cut Dim As Economy Is Termed 'Basically on Track'
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, described the economy today as soft but dismissed fears of a downturn, giving the impression that he was not eager to bolster growth with another round of cuts right away in short-term interest rates.

title: 2 Views of Kevorkian: Killer or Comforter
description: For the second time since he began his crusade for planned death, Dr. Jack Kevorkian came to trial today, with prosecutors urging jurors not to treat the case "as a debate on the issue or the law that makes assisted suicide a crime" but to consider instead the deaths of two people and the conduct of the defendant.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;49ers Sought Jets Deal For Murrell
description: The 49ers recently offered left tackle Steve Wallace, defensive end Dennis Brown and an undisclosed draft pick to the Jets for running back Adrian Murrell, according to several people close to the situation.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Man Guilty of Artist's Murder
description: The 1992 murder of a 22-year-old artist who was abducted on her way to paint a mural at a private club in Trenton received so much local publicity that a jury was empaneled in Burlington County and bused to the Mercer County courthouse. Yesterday, that jury found Ambrose Harris of Trenton guilty in the murder of the artist, Kristin Huggins, The Associated Press reported.

title: U.S. Mediator on Northern Ireland Will Try Again
description: Former Senator George J. Mitchell, who sought and failed to make peace in Northern Ireland last month, left the United States tonight to try to salvage the bomb-shattered peace effort and ease a political problem for President Clinton.

title: Embryo Research Is 'Pro-Life'
description: When President Clinton put his pen to the latest stopgap spending measure, he also signed into law a temporary ban on Federal financing of human embryo research. The restriction, which lasts until Sept. 30, serves no moral purpose and is a serious setback in the fight against birth defects, hereditary diseases and possibly cancer.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Churchill, More Than His Father Predicted
description: The Churchills" is really about the Churchill, with walk-ons for Clementine, Randolph, Diana, Sarah, Mary and other family members.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TYLAN GENERAL INC., San Diego, a provider of equipment used in semiconductor manufacturing, agreed to buy Span Instruments Inc., a software maker in Plano, Tex., for an undisclosed amount of stock.

title: U.S. Set to Impose Limited Trade Sanctions on China
description: The Clinton Administration intends to punish China for supplying nuclear materials to Pakistan by applying selective sanctions intended to hurt China without disrupting American companies that do business there, senior officials say.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;SmithKline Profit Up 7%
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. reported yesterday that it had a 7 percent rise in profits for 1995, citing new products and stronger profit margins. Excluding exceptional items, profits before tax rose 7 percent, to L1.36 billion ($2.10 billion) in 1995, with operating profits from continuing operations up 19 percent. to L1.47 billion ($2.27 billion). The company said that profit margins at its consumer health care business rose by 2.4 percentage points, to 16.5 percent, and that it had made continued advances in eforts to convert more prescription products to over-the-counter medicines. (Reuters)

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Neon Signs Lead to Fines
description: For a year, Long Hill Township has been trying to enforce a 1990 ban on neon signs, and now the battle is escalating. "We've hired a lawyer and we're planning to fight it in court," said Ted Stampoulos, manager of Calabria II Pizzeria. "We're set 50 feet back from the road, and if I turn off the 'open' sign, my customers don't know I'm here to serve them."

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer entry error, an article yesterday about the final day of campaigning before the New Hampshire primary truncated a quotation from Lamar Alexander and omitted one from Senator Bob Dole in some editions. The conclusion of the article should have read:

title: Correction: New Hampshire
description: A chart Sunday about New Hampshire's economy and its Presidential votes since 1976 misstated results of those elections through 1988. It also included an erroneous footnote in some editions about the 1980 election. A corrected version follows.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;A Hope for Needy Parents To Teach Their Children Well
description: It is cold and the streets are slushy when Merl J. Chavis arrives at Sandra Walker's home in the East New York section of Brooklyn. Ms. Walker is standing at the door and her 4-year-old daughter, Destany, is sitting at the top of the stairs. They have been waiting for Ms. Chavis, waiting all week to find out what new game or book will be coming their way.

title: Pratt & Lambert Job Loss
description: About 200 employees of Pratt & Lambert United Inc. in Buffalo will lose their jobs by the end of May, a spokesman for the Sherwin-Williams Company said on Monday. Sherwin-Williams, which acquired Pratt & Lambert in January for $400 million, said it would close the company's headquarters and a paint plant. Sherwin-Williams, based in Cleveland, makes paints under the Sherwin-Williams and Dutch Boy brand names. The company sells its paints mainly through its paint stores and provides the Sears, Roebuck & Company with private-label paint brands.

title: Malaysian Sports Car Due
description: The first sports car made in Malaysia is to roll out of the factory in April. TVR Sports (Malaysia) Pty. Ltd., which has the license to manufacture the composite-body sports car with TVR Engineering of Britain, began pilot production last month at a plant in Port Klang, near here, The New Straits Times reported today. About 1,000 TVR Chimaera cars a year will be produced, most for export, said the managing director of TVR Sports, Ti Teow Yong. The car, with a V8 engine, is expected to cost about $80,000. Malaysian companies already make or assemble passenger cars.

title: Tecoluca Journal;The Rebel Is Mayor Now and It's Tough Slogging
description: As a guerrilla who spent part of his country's 12-year civil war on the slopes of the towering Chinchontepec volcano just west of here, Nicolas Garcia often looked down on his hometown from his mountain redoubt and dreamed of the day when he and his comrades would seize power and impose their revolutionary program.

title: Squeezing the Textile Workers;Trade and Technology Force a New Wave of Job Cuts
description: Martha Smith cried as she left the Dover Mills plant of Andover Togs Inc. on a Wednesday afternoon late in January. Along with approximately 100 other people, she had lost her job sewing children's clothing.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Shooting Victim Recovers
description: Two weeks after an East Orange minister was shot in a carjacking, doctors termed his recovery miraculous. "Most people with this kind of injury -- four or five gunshot wounds around the head -- would not survive," Dr. Eric Munoz, the medical director of University Hospital, said yesterday. He expects the patient, the Rev. William Barnett, to recover fully.

title: Questions About Care Of Suspect in Killing
description: The teen-ager accused of killing a woman on a Brooklyn subway train had not been monitored after release by doctors at Kings County Hospital's psychiatric unit. State officials say that may have violated guidelines.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;H & R Block to Separate Compuserve From Tax Unit
description: H & R Block Inc. said yesterday that it would spin off Compuserve Inc., its on-line subsidiary, from its tax preparation business, creating two public companies.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;Cox to Leave Dolphins For 4-Year Bears Deal
description: Bryan Cox, a three-time Pro Bowl linebacker known for his emotional outbursts during a five-year career with the Miami Dolphins, has agreed to four-year contract with the Chicago Bears.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Clorox Parting Ways With Foote, Cone
description: The Clorox Company said yesterday that it would end its 71-year relationship with the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding by moving its bleach and home-cleaning business to DDB Needham Worldwide, effective April 15. Trade publications have estimated billings at $70 million to $100 million.

title: Holding Line on Postage
description: Postmaster General Marvin Runyon said today that he wanted to keep the price of mailing a letter unchanged for the rest of this century. That will mean cutting costs and improving efficiency, Mr. Runyon said at a meeting of the nation's postmasters.

title: Foundation Underwrites Intelligence Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Those Florida Summers
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Secret Ballot Is Requested
description: Many people may think that party leaders conduct too much of their business behind closed doors. But one man running for the Congressional seat being vacated by Robert G. Torricelli of Englewood wants the Bergen County Democratic organization to vote in secret when it decides whom to support in the June primary.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Muslim holiday Eid al-Fitr, a feast marking the end of Ramadan, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended today and Thursday in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Restricting Divorce Hurts Children and Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Harry Coyle, 74, TV Director; Pioneered Coverage of Baseball
description: Harry Coyle, a director who pioneered the on-air look of televised baseball games over a 42-year career, died on Monday at Mercy Hospital in Des Moines. He was 74.

title: Composers Separated By Their Similarities
description: They are in some ways very much alike: Aaron Jay Kernis, 36, and Richard Danielpour, 40, both write colorfully orchestrated music that embraces melody and tonality but also draws on the complexities of contemporary musical language. Each has composed works with political, social or spiritual undertones, as well as lighter pieces that borrow freely from the broad lexicon of popular music. They are getting plenty of commissions from orchestras, soloists and chamber groups. Mainstream audiences, though wary of contemporary music, find their works surprisingly accessible.

title: General Who Fled Goes Home to Iraq, Blessed by Hussein
description: The Iraqi general and son-in-law to Saddam Hussein who defected six months ago has returned to Iraq with President Hussein's blessing.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Games that will help to decide the home-ice advantage gain intensity this weekend, with playoffs beginning in two weeks. The outlook for the four Division I leagues follows:

title: The Dutch Have Repaid More Fokker Debt
description: The Dutch Government acknowledged today that it had been required to pay more money to banks demanding repayment of state-backed loans to Fokker, the beleaguered commuter-aircraft manufacturer.

title: Sears Moves To Shed Stake In Prodigy
description: And now it is Prodigy's turn.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;7th Indian Minister Quits in Bribery Scandal
description: Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao's Government was under siege today after a bribery scandal claimed a seventh Cabinet minister.

title: Chechen Town's Fugitives Say Russians Shell Civilians
description: Chechen civilians said today that they had come under fire from Russian forces as they fled the battered town of Novogroznensky and that others had been trapped there, contradicting Russian statements that the assault had been delayed until all civilians had left.

title: POLITICS: THE PRESIDENT;Quiet Glee Over G.O.P. Demolition Derby
description: President Clinton steered determinedly away from an assessment of the Republican Presidential field today, saying, "This country doesn't need another pundit." But his aides and advisers were as jubilant as if Mr. Clinton himself was the only victor in New Hampshire.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;British Balloonists Delay Round-the-World Try
description: A British team of aeronauts who had hoped to make the first nonstop manned balloon flight around the world announced yesterday that unfavorable weather had forced them to postpone the attempt until October. The delay marked the end of a planned three-way race, from which the other two competitors -- a Dutch and an American balloonist -- had already dropped out.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BAY NETWORKS Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., a maker of computer networking equipment, agreed to acquire Performance Technology Inc. of San Antonio, a closely held maker of a hardware and software package that provides Internet access, for about $13 million in cash.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Final Four Scheme Charged
description: Critics of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority accused its officials yesterday of hoarding as many as 1,100 tickets to college basketball's Final Four tournament, to be held in the Meadowlands arena, The Associated Press reported.

title: What if Computer Had Won the Chess Match?
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Dutch Government Selling a DSM Stake
description: The Dutch Government said yesterday that it would sell a 20 percent stake in DSM N.V., thus taking advantage of the chemical company's record share price and limiting its exposure to a likely decline in the industry. The stake is to be sold for 1.12 billion guilders, about $691 million, to Dutch institutional investors. The sale will cut the Government's stake to 10 percent from 30 percent.

title: Drug Policy Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Candidate for Marketing Job Withdraws
description: As its professional sports rivals feverishly market themselves, Major League Baseball is again searching for someone to run a much-needed, newly created marketing division designed by the man who withdrew his candidacy for the job.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Editor of New York Objects to Coverage
description: Kurt Andersen, the editor in chief of New York magazine, objected yesterday to elements of an article in The New York Times yesterday concerning an article the magazine published contending that it had "unmasked" the anonymous author of "Primary Colors."

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Father Not Liable for Tuition
description: A divorced father does not have to contribute to his daughter's college costs because his ex-wife did not consult him on major educational decisions, a state appeals court ruled.

title: Legislator Seeks Kashmir Hostages' Release
description: Bill Richardson, a Congressman from New Mexico who has helped win the release of Americans held in Iraq and North Korea, arrived in Kashmir today to try to free four tourists who have been held hostage for seven months.

title: What if Computer Had Won the Chess Match?
description: A Mean Chess-Playing Computer Tears at the Meaning of Thought"

title: WINTER SPORTS;Thrill of Sliding Goes Straight to the Bone
description: It has the teeth-rattling speed of a bobsled, the vulnerability of a luge, and it attracts the kind of racer whose life-preservation instincts are highly questionable.

title: BASKETBALL;Nets Work Overtime for 5th Straight Victory
description: Believe it. The Nets are on a roll.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;New Works as a Sidelight
description: There are two ways to view the "Music of Our Time" project of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. The official line is that this yearly three-concert series at Merkin Condert Hall is an outgrowth of the society's commitment to contemporary music. Another interpretation is that in lieu of incorporating many new works into its popular programs at Alice Tully Hall, the society has created a sub-series for interested audiences at a smaller venue. This may be savvy marketing, but it does little to bring living composers and audiences closer together.

title: Hampton Plans Visit to 49ers
description: Rodney Hampton, who has rushed for more than 1,000 yards each of the last five seasons with the Giants, has scheduled a visit to San Francisco next Monday.

title: BASEBALL;Williams's Lofty Salary Has Expectations Rising
description: A nurse with a sense of humor applied a green Power Rangers Band-Aid to Bernie Williams's right arm after a blood test before the first day of Yankee workouts on Tuesday. Williams is a young player, but he is not that young.

title: Cypress Closes Funds
description: Cypress Group, a private New York-based investment firm, announced this week that it had closed its $1.05 billion merchant banking funds. The funds make equity investments in privately negotiated transactions. With this closing, Cypress also announced its first portfolio investment, a $139 million investment in Cinemark USA Inc., a movie theater operator. Cypress, formed in 1994, is headed by its four founding executives: James A. Stern, Jeffrey P. Hughes, James L. Singleton and David P. Spalding.

title: Foes of Affirmative Action Claim California Ballot Spot
description: Opponents of affirmative-action programs in California said today that after a faltering start they had gathered petitions with more than a million signatures, more than enough to put preferential treatment based on race and sex to a statewide yes-or-no vote in November.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SWIMMING;Warning Draws Praise From Medical Chief
description: The chief medical official of the Olympics applauded the international swimming federation yesterday for giving only a warning to the world champion SAMANTHA RILEY of Australia over a positive drug test.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CONRAIL PLANS TO CUT 900 NONUNION JOBS
description: Conrail Inc. said yesterday that it planned to cut 900 nonunion jobs, or 3.9 percent of its work force, in the next three years. Separately, Conrail said James A. Hagen would retire as chairman and a member of the company's board after the annual shareholders' meeting on May 15. Hagen, 63, will be replaced by David M. LeVan, Conrail's president and chief executive. The company, which provides rail-freight services in the Midwest and the Northeast, said it was offering early retirement and voluntary separation packages to more than 2,700 of its 3,000 nonunion employees. Conrail has a total of about 23,000 employees. Conrail said it was prepared to dismiss or reassign employees if it could not reach the goal of 900 job cuts.

title: Singapore Answered Charge of Nepotism
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Fall in Japan
description: The Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 31.29 points, or 0.15 percent, at 20,340.94 here today. On Wednesday, the Nikkei fell 283.44 points, or 1.37 percent.

title: Not All Arts Audiences Are Graying
description: To the Editor:

title: One Arrest, Two Versions;Hispanic L.I. Residents Say Beating Illustrates Harassment
description: On the afternoon of Jan. 11, the face of Jose Alberto Solorzano was unblemished. By nightfall, after an encounter with the village police, his cheeks were bruised and the skin around his swollen eyes had turned the color of plums.

title: Prodigy Sale Sought Amid On-Line Boom
description: Despite remarkable growth, the computer on-line service industry has been undergoing great upheaval, with a flurry of new alliances and acquisitions in recent months.

title: Brain Chemical Said to Play Role in Cigarette Addiction
description: Discovery of an important biochemical difference in the brains of smokers suggests a new way, independent of nicotine, in which smoking may become addictive.

title: HORSE RACING;Strong Field Is Entered To Test Unbridled's Song
description: Ten of the best Triple Crown candidates in the East were entered today in the Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park this Saturday, and for nine the immediate mission will be to try to catch Unbridled's Song, the favorite for the Kentucky Derby.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;State Would Cut School's Aid
description: The A. Harry Moore School accepts disabled students from four counties, but it gets 89 percent of its $3.9 million budget from the state. The State Department of Education, saying local districts are not paying their fair share, has proposed cutting aid to the school by $750,000.

title: POLITICS: IN NEW YORK;Giuliani Criticizes Policies Of Buchanan as Dangerous
description: A day after Patrick J. Buchanan won the New Hampshire Republican Presidential primary, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani attacked him once again, denouncing the candidate's positions on trade and immigration as dangerous to America and saying his past remarks and actions suggest that he is anti-Semitic.

title: Staten Island Ferry Smashes into Pilings in Heavy Fog, Injuring 18
description: A ferry docking into St. George's Terminal on Staten Island smashed into pilings in fog-shrouded waters yesterday, sending 18 people to hospitals, officials said.

title: New Site for Bomb Trial Brings Burdens, Experts Say
description: This week's decision by a Federal judge to move the Oklahoma City bombing trial out of state to Denver will involve risks, burdens and costs for all concerned, lawyers, scholars and government officials agree.

title: Students Paid the Price When Private Firm Took Over Schools;Privatizers Made Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: ITT Hartford Contracts
description: ITT Hartford Group Inc. has assumed about $143 million in annuity contracts and life insurance policies held by customers of the Investors Equity Life Insurance Company of Hawaii. The company, based in Hartford, said Investors Equity was placed into rehabilitation by Hawaii on June 24, 1994, after the company lost several million dollars of policyholders' money in investment losses. ITT Hartford said it had assumed about 6,000 annuities and 7,000 policies.

title: Not All Arts Audiences Are Graying
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;Accessible Yet Modern, Janacek Did Everything His Way
description: Two String Quartets by Janacek

title: Oil Tanker Refloated Off Wales
description: An enormous oil tanker that ran aground off the Welsh coast last week was finally set afloat again tonight, but only after it spewed more than 65,000 tons of crude oil into one of Britain's most environmentally sensitive areas.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Ferry Crewmen Honored
description: Two crewmen on a New Jersey commuter ferry will be honored today for pulling five people to safety last July from a capsized cabin cruiser in the East River and for rescuing a man who jumped off the Pulaski Bridge a few days later.

title: Afrikaners Try to Stand in the Schoolhouse Door
description: Surrounded by television cameras and reporters, Meiki Kekana wasn't trying to hide her sense of triumph today as she walked her 7-year-old son through the doors of the all-white public elementary school here and enrolled him for classes.

title: TENNIS;Capriati's Comeback Begins With a Victory
description: Jennifer Capriati was a long way from her sun-drenched beginnings as a professional tennis player.

title: Theater in Review
description: Rearranging Shakespeare So Rustics Follow Rage 'The Winter's Tale' Pearl Theater Company

title: Zoe Caldwell Collapses During 'Master Class'
description: Apparently nauseated by oysters she had after her matinee, the actress Zoe Caldwell collapsed 20 minutes into last night's performance of "Master Class."

title: Economic Scene;A California initiative would put lawyers to the free-market test.
description: SO, who are the good guys in California's battle over limiting legal fees in civil suits? "Consumer attorneys," according to the ads now saturating local television in the Golden State -- the ones "who get unsafe automobiles off the road, protect people's retirement savings from investment frauds and force polluters to pay for cleaning up their poisonous waste."

title: Pataki and Giuliani: Bound by Pragmatism
description: Not long ago, the scene would have seemed implausible. But there they were, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki, sharing a Manhattan dais last week, offering glowing appraisals of each other.

title: POLITICS: VYING FOR LEAD;'The Real Bob Dole' Vows He'll Prevail
description: Bob Dole left New Hampshire in second place today but vowed that "the real Bob Dole" was emerging to help him go the distance and that he would win the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Liberties;All the Bob Doles
description: Maureen Dowd is confused. There are too many Bob Doles lurking around, talking about each other in the third person, getting in each other's way.

title: Don't Allow Megastores Near Neighborhoods
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;NOVELL INC. (NOVL,NNM)
description: Novell Inc. said yesterday that its net income fell 22 percent in its first quarter, though its operating profits exceeded analyst expectations. The software company also forecast a "moderate" loss for its second quarter as it adjusts its inventory.

title: WINTER SPORTS;Birkebeiner Strategy Is Just a Gamble
description: Having spent 10 years on the United States Nordic Ski Team, Ingrid Butts has learned a thing or two about pacing herself. But she has also found that strategies don't always work. At times, in fact, they can turn as slippery as the snow underfoot.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PILOTS' UNION ACCEPTS PAY CUT IN RETURN FOR OPTIONS
description: The union representing pilots at Delta Air Lines Inc. said yesterday that it had tentatively agreed to accept 2 percent pay cuts for its members for the next four years in return for stock options in the airline. The deal also calls for the airline to give the union, the Air Line Pilots Association, a nonvoting board seat and a guarantee that Delta will recall all of the 472 pilots that it has furloughed, a union official said. Delta has also agreed to improve its retirement plan and will begin offering early retirement packages to pilots, the union said. The agreement remains subject to ratification by the union's governing body and by the membership.

title: From the Democrats, Glee but No Gloating
description: President Clinton refrained from public analysis of the Republican results in the New Hampshire primary -- "This country doesn't need another pundit," he said -- but Democrats saw nothing but good fortune in the three-way split there and the emergence of Patrick J. Buchanan.

title: Justices Wrestle With TV Indecency Issue
description: The Clinton Administration's defense of a Federal law intended to curb children's access to sexually explicit programming on cable television got a skeptical hearing from the Supreme Court today in a case that could help shape the legal framework for regulation of indecency on the Internet as well as on television.

title: POLITICS: STILL FIGHTING;Lugar Turns to New England Primary in His Struggling Campaign
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana said today that he would concentrate on New England's regional primary in two weeks, hoping to use it to breathe life into a Presidential campaign that has yet to do better than fifth place.

title: No Headline
description: Learn about this drug, and sit down with your sons and daughters. I learned way too late, and I feel like I failed him. Travis was a really good kid -- not a perfect kid. He made some wrong decisions, and this drug sucked him away."

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Giggles Intact, Political Satire Is Back on TV
description: A lot of Republicans do not see Pat Buchanan as a joke, not any longer," Dan Rather said with high anchorman's seriousness on Tuesday night, not long before CBS projected that Mr. Buchanan would win the Republican primary in New Hampshire. Meanwhile, at the Comedy Central channel, which is covering the Presidential campaign under the banner "Indecision '96," the attitude was pretty much "Speak for yourself, Dan." Everyone from President Clinton to Mr. Buchanan becomes material at Comedy Central, and in an era of numbing press overload its coverage sometimes makes more sense than that of humorless reporters. The channel's standard-bearing talk show, "Politically Incorrect," is almost single-handedly reviving political satire on television.

title: ON LOCATION WITH: John Woo;Ballets With Bullets
description: It was 11 P.M. at the Sutton Place Hotel in the heart of Vancouver, and John Woo sat in a near-empty restaurant, exhausted following a long day of film editing. "So much to learn," the 49-year-old film maker repeated softly. "So many things to improve."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;The cruise industry is moving toward more campaigns in the face of declining business.
description: INDIVIDUAL cruise lines are advertising more than ever. And if the industry as a group can reconcile the conceptual and financial differences, another $10 million in ads will come onto the airwaves in each of the next three years.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STATE FARM PLANS TO CUT ITS EXPOSURE IN FLORIDA
description: The State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company said yesterday that it was taking steps to limit its financial exposure in Florida. The company said two of its subsidiaries, State Farm Fire and Casualty and State Farm General Insurance, would not renew insurance policies for commercial property in Palm Beach and Hillsborough counties, beginning on Aug. 1. Commercial property coverage will also not be renewed in the parts of Dade, Broward and Pinellas counties that are not eligible for insurance through the Florida Windstorm Underwriting Association, State Farm said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Florida Citrus Group Selects Ammirati
description: The Florida Department of Citrus in Lakeland, Fla., said yesterday that it had selected Ammirati & Puris/Lintas in New York to handle its orange juice and grapefruit juice advertising accounts, with billings estimated at $27 million. The Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide unit of Cordiant P.L.C. in New York had handled the accounts for the last 25 years until that agency was elim inated from the review last month.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Falls vs. Yen as Rumors Of Intervention Do Not Pan Out
description: The dollar slumped against the yen yesterday on signs that the Japanese central bank had not forcefully intervened on the American currency's behalf.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Billion Marks Lost, Shipbuilder To Seek Bankruptcy in Germany
description: Bremer Vulkan Verbund A.G., Germany's largest shipbuilder, said today that it had lost one billion marks, or $685 million, in 1995 and would seek court protection from its creditors to avoid bankruptcy.

title: Jurors Acquit Rap Musician In Murder Case
description: A jury that acquitted the rap artist Snoop Doggy Dogg and his former bodyguard of murder charges earlier this week said today that it was deadlocked on lesser charges of voluntary manslaughter, even after the judge ordered jurors to try to break their 9-to-3 split in favor of acquittal.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Sale of D.M.V. List Assailed
description: A plan by state officials to raise $11 million by selling names and addresses culled from Division of Motor Vehicles records to private companies has drawn criticism from civil liberties lawyers and legislators. "There's an expectation of privacy when you're supplying mandatory information to the government," said Penny Venetis of the Constitutional Litigation Clinic at Rutgers Law School.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Some runners can't decide what race to enter -- 200, 400 or 800 meters. NANCY NAVALTA, a sprinter in the Philippines, has a different problem. Should she run as a man -- or a woman? Sometimes, she does both.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Judge Lorin Duckman, who has been criticized because of two recent rulings in domestic-violence cases, misspelled the surname of the president-elect of the Brooklyn Bar Association. He is Mark A. Longo, not Long.

title: Currents;Sundials to Set Your Watch By
description: SUNDIALS have an air of antiquity -- and a reputation for rotten timekeeping. John Pearson Blanks (1912-84), a Pan Am aircraft mechanic, tried to change that in the 1950's with swoopy space-age silhouettes. And more important, he incorporated a mechanism that allowed his sundials to be minutely adjusted to follow the sun's arc in any hemisphere.

title: Chirac to Unveil Plans for an All-Volunteer French Army
description: PARIS  Sweeping defense changes planned by France, including an end to the military draft, are aimed at streamlining its armaments industries and forging a much smaller, all-volunteer army designed to intervene in Bosnian-type crises on Europe's fringes.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $25 million of step-up notes due in 2006 through First Tennessee Bank. The notes are callable in one year, carry an interest rate of 7.3 percent and are priced at par.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BRADLEES TO CLOSE 12 DEPARTMENT STORES
description: Bradlees Inc., a discount retailer operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, said yesterday that it would close 12 stores by May. The company, which is based in Braintree, Mass., operates more than 100 department stores in the Northeast. Bradlees said this month that it would consolidate the management positions at its stores and eliminate 450 jobs in an effort to save $19 million a year. The stores to be closed are in Maine, Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York and New Jersey.

title: Market Place;After a planned split of operations, what would Thorn EMI do for an encore? Maybe sell itself off.
description: SIR COLIN SOUTHGATE is a living embodiment of that old refrain: Watch what I do, not what I say.

title: What Buchanan Owes Clinton
description: Patrick J. Buchanan's stump speeches calling for trade protectionism have taken on a life of their own even though they have been denounced by most mainstream policy wonks and politicians. He has used the issue to win the New Hampshire primary and has found that even Senator Bob Dole has borrowed part of his platform.

title: Harlem Troupe Creates a Children's Program
description: Dance Theater of Harlem announced yesterday the formation of a new program, "Dancing Through Barriers," to take ballet to children in the five boroughs of New York City. The program, which begins on Monday at Public School 33 on Jerome Avenue in the Bronx, is to consist of school assembly discussions of ballet history and of daily life in a dance company, lecture-demonstrations conducted by dancers in both the senior and junior companies of Dance Theater, classroom discussions, and dance classes with children 13 and younger.

title: Berlin Fires Up Its Film Festival With Star Power
description: The main difference between the Berlin International Film Festival and Europe's two other main movie jamborees is hard to miss. Cannes is in the spring, Venice in the summer and Berlin in the bleak midwinter. With rain and snow sharing top billing here, the climate is hardly propitious for starlet-gazing. Put differently, this festival is serious business.

title: BASEBALL;Stealing: A New Art Sought By Green
description: The day before spring camp opened, Manager Dallas Green was asked what he was most eager to see once workouts began. After a moment of thought, Green's face broke into a sly smile. "I want to see Lance Johnson steal a base," he said. "We haven't had too many of those around here."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Volvo Profit Fell 38% in Fourth Quarter
description: Volvo A.B., the Swedish automobile maker, said yesterday that its pretax profit fell 38 percent in the fourth quarter, chiefly because of a loss in its car division. The profit of 2.28 billion kronor, about $337 million, did not meet analyst expectations. It included a charge of 303 million kronor for cuts in staff numbers at the car division. The company's pretax profit for the full year fell to 13.05 billion kronor from 16.38 billion a year earlier.

title: Inquiry Is Said to Focus on 1990 Clinton Meeting With Banker
description: The Whitewater independent counsel is looking into a 1990 meeting at which an Arkansas banker gave Bill Clinton, who was then Governor of Arkansas, $7,000 in political contributions, lawyers familiar with the investigation said today.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasuries Rise in Price, Ending Slide
description: What a difference a day makes.

title: Vintage Bulbs Charm Modern Gardeners
description: PEOPLE all over the United States are finding something new to do with antiques: burying them.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MESA SAYS IT IS TALKING TO 3 COMPANIES ABOUT A DEAL
description: Mesa Inc. said yesterday that it was in discussions with three companies interested in buying assets or in making a deal that would infuse cash into Mesa, the debt-laden oil and natural gas company. After fielding interest from more than 100 companies last year in assets that include natural gas fields in the Hugoton basin in western Kansas, the company and its investment banker are negotiating with a final group of three, Mesa's chairman, T. Boone Pickens, said. He declined to identify the possible buyers. Mesa faces a June 30 deadline for payment on a portion of its $1.1 billion in debt and expects to complete a deal before then, Mr. Pickens said. The transactions being negotiated do not include an outright sale or merger of the entire company, which is based in Irving, Tex., a Mesa spokesman said.

title: Holbrooke Gets His Own Day in the Limelight
description: For Richard C. Holbrooke, a man for whom no amount of adulation can ever be quite enough, today was probably as good as it gets.

title: French Government Will Sell Thomson This Year
description: The French Government announced yesterday that it planned to sell Thomson S.A., the huge defense and consumer-electronics company, to private investors by the end of 1996.

title: A Derailment In Colorado Kills Two
description: A freight train carrying 120,000 gallons of sulfuric acid down a steep Colorado mountainside derailed south of Vail early this morning, killing two crew members and puncturing at least two tanker cars containing 27,000 gallons of its poisonous cargo.

title: In San Diego, An Old Drug Comes Back
description: For years, San Diego County was called the methamphetamine capital of North America, but then the use of the drug declined in the early 1990's, coinciding with a campaign of high-profile drug sweeps.

title: Corrections
description: A dance listing in the Arts and Leisure section on Sunday misidentified the troupe that will perform this weekend at the Cunningham Studio, 55 Bethune Street, in the West Village. Steeledance, not the Hendricks Dance Project, will appear tomorrow night at 9 and on Saturday and Sunday evenings at 8.

title: POLITICS: IN THE PACK;Alexander Fires On Buchanan, To Get Dole
description: As he moved today onto familiar Southern terrain, Lamar Alexander trained intense fire on Patrick J. Buchanan. But his intended target was Senator Bob Dole.

title: HOCKEY;Devils Lose the Game And a Valuable Rookie
description: The Devils suffered their second consecutive loss tonight, a 4-1 decision to the Florida Panthers, and lost Petr Sykora, their terrific rookie center.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Perennially Young Cast, And Getting Younger
description: Unlike Peter Pan, the dancers in Feld Ballets/NY are not just perennially young. The company as a whole is getting younger.

title: Currents;Met Displays Synthetic Built For the Ages
description: ART lovers gazing upon the newly restored stone reliefs from the Telephos frieze -- one of the wonders of the ancient world, on loan to the Metropolitan Museum of Art through April 14 -- might want to consider the modern wonder that came along with them.

title: HOCKEY;Isles Aim at Ranger Streak
description: The intense rivalry between the Rangers and the Islanders should get even hotter tonight at Madison Square Garden, where the Rangers will attempt to break a 25-year-old franchise record for consecutive home games without a loss.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Gehe Raises Its Bid For Lloyds Chemists
description: Gehe A.G. of Germany raised its bid yesterday for the British drug wholesaler and pharmacy Lloyds Chemists P.L.C. to L645 million, about $1 billion, topping Unichem P.L.C.'s bid by more than L16 million. Unichem made what it then called its final bid, for L633.7 million, or about $982 million, on Feb. 7.

title: Time Warner Plans to Sell Medical Self-Help Videos
description: At a time when many patients want to know more than doctors and insurers are telling them, a unit of Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it was shipping one million copies of a new line of medical self-help videotapes to big drugstore and mass-marketing chains across the country.

title: Ratepayers' Counsel Faces Loss of Days
description: State Attorney General Richard Blumenthal has proposed that Connecticut's consumer counsel be docked vacation time for attending golf tournaments while he was supposed to be at work.

title: What if Computer Had Won the Chess Match?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ben Schley, 80; Turned Fly Fishing Into a Career
description: Ben Schley, a fly fisherman whose companions included Presidents and anyone else who shared his reverence for nature, died on Saturday at a hospital in Martinsburg, W.Va. He was 80 and lived in Shepherdstown, W.Va., not far from the upper reaches of the Potomac River, which had captured his imagination as a boy and never let it go.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Moon Delivers Testimony About Restraining Wife
description: Continuing to defend himself against a charge of spousal abuse, Warren Moon testified for the second consecutive day and firmly denied hitting his wife, Felicia, during an altercation last July 18.

title: The G.O.P.'s Extremism Debate
description: The famed Eleventh Commandment popularized by Ronald Reagan ("Thou shalt not speak ill of fellow Republicans") takes a beating in most primary campaigns. But not since the Goldwater-Rockefeller contest of 1964 has it been so quickly broken as in this primary season. Following Pat Buchanan's victory in New Hampshire, Bob Dole, Lamar Alexander and the Congressional leadership immediately resorted to the G.O.P.'s rhetorical equivalent of a tactical nuclear weapon against Mr. Buchanan by labeling him an extremist.

title: Executive Changes
description: DONALDSON, LUFKIN & JENRETTE, New York, a unit of the Equitable Cos., named G. Moffett Cochran, president of its Wood, Struthers & Winthrop Management unit, to the additional responsibility of heading a new money management unit focusing on institutional investors called DLJ Investment Management.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A House Guest Inspires Not So Maternal Feelings
description: It isn't what most people would think of as a sexually tantalizing smell: floral, fruity and unquestionably synthetic, it is as welcome to the nostrils as a vinyl handkerchief. But for the blowzy, middle-aged Kath, played to pulpy perfection by Ellen Parker in the new revival of Joe Orton's "Entertaining Mr. Sloane," this aerosol room freshener is just what's needed for seducing a strapping lad with the smoothest skin she's ever seen.

title: BASEBALL;Counteroffer by Owners Includes a Salary Tax
description: Seeking an avenue to common collective bargaining ground, the owners' labor strategists presented a new proposal to the players today that incorporated the players' idea for a tax on their salaries.

title: Jill Rose, 52, Head Of Photo Museum
description: Jill Rose, the president of the International Center of Photography, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 52 and lived in Manhattan.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japan to Conduct Study of Trade Practices in Film Market
description: Japan's Fair Trade Commission said today that it would conduct a survey of the Japanese photographic film and paper market.

title: As Leaders Urge Them On, Serbs Clog Roads Out of Sarajevo
description: The exodus of fearful Serbs from their homes around Sarajevo continued today, with caravans of trucks and overloaded automobiles clogging the icy roads that lead toward Serbian-controlled regions of Eastern Bosnia.

title: INSIDE
description: Alternate Path to Addiction

title: I.R.A. Says Bomb Victim Was a Guerrilla
description: The Irish Republican Army announced today that a 21-year-old Irishman who was killed by a bomb on a London bus last Sunday was one of its guerrillas.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Astra Pretax Profit Gains
description: Astra A.B., Sweden's largest company by market capitalization, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter pretax profit rose 22 percent, because of increased sales. Pretax profit for the drug maker rose to 2.9 billion kronor, about $429 million, in the fourth quarter. For the year, it rose 25 percent, to 12.06 billion kronor. Sales rose 15 percent in the quarter, to 9.12 billion kronor, and 28 percent in the full year, to 35.8 billion. Astra also said that it would seek a full American depository listing for its shares in New York as early as late spring. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: In About-Face, U.S. Proposes Standby Force for Burundi
description: In an about-face, the Clinton Administration has decided to urge the Security Council to authorize an international standby force to head off widespread violence in Burundi, Madeleine K. Albright, the American delegate to the United Nations, says.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;SOME REPUBLICANS HOPING FOR A WAY TO STOP BUCHANAN
description: Jolted by Patrick J. Buchanan's triumph in the New Hampshire primary, Republicans around the country, including Gen. Colin L. Powell, today plunged into a furious debate over how Mr. Buchanan emerged and how he could be stopped.

title: Fossil Dealer, Target of Federal Prosecutors, Begins Jail Term
description: Peter L. Larsen, a commercial fossil dealer accused of dinosaur hunting without a Federal permit, left his South Dakota home yesterday to surrender to Federal authorities and begin serving a two-year prison term.

title: Farrakhan's Angry World Tour Brings Harsh Criticism at Home
description: Four months after his Million Man March edged him toward the political mainstream, Louis Farrakhan has touched off wide criticism with an extended world tour, which included countries the United States considers pariahs, and his bitterly anti-American remarks along the way.

title: POLITICS: ON THE MOVE;Exultant Buchanan Pushes Economic Insecurity Theme
description: With perhaps more audacity, but inarguably with more delegates than his opponents for the Republican Presidential nomination, Patrick J. Buchanan came here today and took the measure of this mountain for his own face.

title: Court Bars Landlord From Evicting Clinic
description: A state appeals court has barred a landlord from evicting an abortion clinic on Long Island that has been the target of violence during anti-abortion protests.

title: Theater in Review
description: More Than Distance Between Two Sisters 'Always Together' Ubu Repertory Theater

title: Getting What They Deserve?;No Profit Is No Problem for High-Paid Executives
description: Correction Appended

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;King Fahd to Resume Power in Saudi Arabia
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia announced that he had recovered from his illness and that he would resume full power, the Saudi Press Agency reported today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HECHINGER SAYS LOSS WILL BE BIGGER THAN EXPECTED
description: The Hechinger Company said yesterday that its loss in the fourth quarter would be bigger than expected, because of winter storms, strong competition and slow home sales. The company also said it would stop paying dividends on its common stock. Hechinger, a struggling operator of 118 home-improvement stores, said it would report a loss from operations of $30 million to $35 million, or 66 to 73 cents a share, in the fiscal fourth quarter. The projected loss is much higher than analysts' estimates. The company, which is based in Landover, Md., is also taking a pretax charge of $25 million, or 57 cents a share, in the quarter, which ended on Feb. 3, for employee severance packages and expenses related to combining certain management and administrative functions. The charge will lead to a final loss of as much as $1.30 a share, the company said.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Drug Aid Cut Called Unlikely
description: Governor Whitman's plan to exclude about 30,000 elderly people from a state-subsidized prescription program has no chance of legislative approval, the State Senate majority leader, John Bennett, Republican of Eatontown, said yesterday.

title: BEACH VOLLEYBALL;A Journey From Slam Dunk to Spike
description: One drinks coffee in the morning; the other drinks salt pills.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: TMP Interactive, Framingham, Mass., to Harpell/Martins & Co., Concord, Mass., as the first agency to handle advertising for the developer of the Monster Board, which provides career information on the World Wide Web. The billings were estimated at $3 million.
