ERO Industries, a division of ERO Inc., Mount Prospect, Ill., to Anda & Scotti Advertising, New York, as the first agency to handle a national consumer campaign for the Slumber Shoppe line of products like sleeping bags and play tents. The billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

title: Why Whitewater?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: BASKETBALL;The Knicks Show Their Age, but Also Their Poise
description: Grant Hill jackknifed his way through the heart of the Knicks' makeshift front line tonight, running smack into the 7-foot Patrick Ewing. He deftly twisted his 6-foot-8-inch frame around the center and somehow scored off the glass and drew the foul.

title: Bronx Judge Defends Ruling In Abuse Case
description: A Bronx judge said yesterday that he had acted with the strong endorsement of city child welfare officials when he moved an infant from foster care to the custody of his father, who has been charged with murdering the child.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Pepsi Courts Myanmar, Preferring Sales to Politics
description: There are not many countries left where you can't buy a bottle of Pepsi-Cola, so when a suitable business partner turned up in the isolated Southeast Asian nation of Myanmar five years ago, Pepsico was eager to set up a bottling plant.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;The Schubertiade Ends With Song and Piano
description: There was a moment during Sunday afternoon's Schubertiade concert at the 92d Street Y when the intended goal of recreating an informal musicale like those the composer presided over was beautifully realized.

title: EASTERN COLLEGE REPORT
description: Haggerty Award

title: Comptroller Backs Dismantling Lilco
description: The Pataki administration's plan to dismantle the Long Island Lighting Company in the hope of cutting electric rates on Long Island has many potential problems but is worth trying, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall said today.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Viacom Reports a Small Profit As Cash Flow Remains Steady
description: Viacom Inc. reported yesterday that it earned a small profit in the fourth quarter, reversing a loss in the comparable 1994 quarter.

title: Theater in Review
description: Magic Fingers Of a Different Sort 'A Laying of Hands' Onyx Theater Company

title: POLITICS: THE ASSESSMENT;How 'Front Runner' in G.O.P. Race Had a Flat Tire in New Hampshire
description: How did it happen? How did Bob Dole, one of the most effective politicians of the post-war era, elected five times to the Senate, elected Republican leader more often than anyone in history, backed by the potent organization of a Governor who won re-election two years ago with a record 70 percent of the vote, contrive to lose the New Hampshire primary to a television commentator who had never before won an election anywhere?

title: Fund Chairman Gets New Heart
description: The mutual fund pioneer John C. Bogle, the chairman of the Vanguard Group of Investment Companies, underwent heart transplant surgery today at a Philadelphia hospital.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Renault Plans More Job Cuts
description: The French auto maker Renault S.A. is planning to cut 1,640 jobs this year, primarily through state-financed early retirement programs and part-time job conversions.

title: POLITICS: THE UNIONS;Labor Leader Calls Buchanan Workers' Enemy
description: A day after Patrick J. Buchanan won the New Hampshire primary by campaigning as a champion of workers' concerns, the leader of the American labor movement denounced the Republican candidate as racist, anti-Semitic and opposed to the interests of American workers.

title: Norma Kamali Cleans House
description: IF, for some, collecting is one of life's joys, then so is undecorating -- purging yourself of decades of stuff. Preferably at a top-flight auction house, and preferably for high prices.

title: Michael Deutch, 88, Co-Inventor Of Method for Synthetic Rubber
description: Michael J. Deutch, who fled Lenin's Russia and Hitler's Europe for the United States, helped invent the chemical process for making synthetic rubber in World War II and advised American military and foreign policy officials, died on Monday at the Washington Hospice. He was 88.

title: POLITICS;Excerpts From Buchanan Campaign Speech
description: Following are excerpts from a speech by Patrick J. Buchanan at a campaign rally in Nashua, N.H., on Saturday, as transcribed by The New York Times. The speech provides an example of the message Mr. Buchanan delivers in his standard campaign speech.

title: Taking Romanovs On the Road
description: Rollicking cries of "Yee-haw!" and "Whoa!" blasted from a carpenter's radio broadcasting a Texas-style rodeo going on across town.

title: POP REVIEW;Honoring Tibet in Meditative Songs
description: The fourth annual benefit for Tibet House, which took place on Monday night at Carnegie Hall, brought out the somber side of its performers. Tibet House is a nonprofit organization working to preserve Tibetan culture; contemplating Tibetan Buddhism and China's occupation of Tibet, nearly every performer chose songs that mused over mortality, faith and eternity.

title: Changing a Culture of Courage
description: Three times this year, small groups of New York City firefighters have gathered on Randalls Island for a special drill that causes even veteran officers to look on and fall silent.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Jets' Bidding To Sign Elliott Getting Bolder
description: In the sometimes bizarre world of pro football free agency, a player can change teams and not even change his mailing address. That is something that Jumbo Elliott, one of the best left tackles in the game, is coming close to doing.

title: Terrorism and Ireland
description: The renewed bombing campaign of the Irish Republican Army has already caused senseless deaths, injuries and property destruction in London. No matter how frustrated the I.R.A. became with the political process, its return to terrorism is inexcusable and self-defeating. The bombings have swiftly transformed the organization from one of the parties seeking peace in Northern Ireland to the peace spoiler.

title: Short of Money, the French Face Cuts in Their Cherished Military
description: For decades, this town of tank-makers and army bases has thrived on France's determination to be a military giant.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Essay;For Heart and Soul
description: The best news to come out of New Hampshire is the demise of New Hampshire as the bellwether political state.

title: Currents;History to Put on Walls
description: CHRISTOPHER OHRSTROM'S epiphany came as a child in the 1960's. His American mother, married to an English lord, hired the great decorator John Fowler to renovate their house. Hand-mixed paints were ordered, and the youngster was hooked. "That's the genesis of this," Mr. Ohrstrom said of Historic Paints Ltd., his workshop in an upstate New York village. Here he and his partner, Matthew Mosca, manufacture 17 colors common between 1725 and 1850. All contain earth or vegetable pigments, linseed oil, turpentine and natural varnishes. They are color-rich nontoxic paints with subtle striped complexions -- "ropy" in paint parlance. Prices are $12.50 a pint (covers 85 square feet) or $21 a quart (175 square feet). To order: (607) 278-6655.

title: BASEBALL;Don't Look for Ripken to Rest on Laurels
description: Cal Ripken Jr. expressed strong hope today that the utility infielder in the adjoining locker would win a job with the Baltimore Orioles. But, Ripken quickly added, he will not relinquish any of his playing time so that his brother, Billy, can play once in a while.

title: What if Computer Had Won the Chess Match?
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Player Has Transplant
description: MILOS HOLAN of the Anaheim Mighty Ducks, diagnosed last fall with leukemia, received a bone marrow transplant yesterday. Holan, 24, was listed in stable condition at City of Hope National Medical Center in Duarte, Calif. An unidentified donor, who hospital officials said is not related to Holan, was located early in January. (AP)

title: Sports of the Times;The Lessons Of Mixing Work, Play
description: SHE once beat Billie Jean King on Center Court at Wimbledon, and Chris Evert on the red Paris clay. She was ranked second in the world. Andrea Jaeger, who surrendered much of her childhood and a teen-ager's life in order to do so, said yesterday from her home in Aspen: "I can't say 'I don't want those memories.' "

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Real Estate column yesterday about a new Papyrus stationery store at 852-54 Lexington Avenue in Manhattan misidentified the chain's representative in the deal. It was Retail Properties; Faith Hope Consolo of the Garrick-Aug real estate brokerage firm represented the building.

title: Brooklyn Man Held On Charges of Incest
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager who came home on Wednesday morning to find his father having sex with his 14-year-old sister confronted the man, only to have the father threaten him with a gun, the police said. The teen-ager managed to escape and alert the police.

title: Embittered Garuzzo Is Credited With Firm's Return to Profitability : Fiat Fires No. 3 Officer Days Before Agnelli Goes
description: PARIS  In a bitter corporate shakeup at one of Europe's biggest car makers, the Fiat group is ousting a top executive who helped to bring it back to profitability in recent years.

title: If It Smells Like Spring, It's a Flower Show (or Is It Spring?)
description: WHOEVER thought of tricking plants so that they bloom in the middle of a snowstorm was probably one of those SAD (seasonal affected disorder) people. Longing for light. Crying into the wind cutting around a street hard by the river. Begging those first true leaves of the potted basil to come up.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Tuesday, with an article about the difficulties faced by small travel agencies since the airlines put a cap on commissions, misidentified the Massachusetts travel agency once owned by Mary Hogan. She ran Hogan Travel Inc., which has gone out of business; she now works for Uni globe/the Travel Connection.

title: Aide to Crew Held 2d Job In Education
description: In his first month on the job, the chief spokesman for the new Schools Chancellor, Dr. Rudy Crew, continued to work as a consultant for a private educational organization. Yesterday, the Board of Education's president, Carol A. Gresser, asked investigators to examine whether his actions violated city conflict-of-interest rules.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: COMPANY NEWS;FIGGIE MIGHT SELL ALL OR PART OF COMPANY
description: Figgie International Inc., a diversified holding company that has been making structural changes in an effort to rebuild its earnings, said yesterday that it might sell all or part of the company. The company's products include electronics equipment for the defense industry and breathing products for firefighters and for aviation purposes. Figgie, which is based in Willoughby, Ohio, said it had hired the investment banking firms Morgan Stanley and Smith Barney to help it evaluate its options. Figgie had sales of more than $1 billion three years ago, but it has since pared numerous units. Figgie's stock rose $1.875 yesterday, to $12.875, in Nasdaq trading. At that price the company has a market capitalization of more than $236 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Court Bars Clinic Eviction Despite Abortion Protests
description: In a unanimous decision, a state appeals court has ruled that a landlord cannot evict a Garden City abortion clinic that had been the target of anti-abortion violence.

title: New York vs. California In a Closet Space Race
description: MY brother-in-law is obsessed with having more linear feet than anybody.

title: Girl, 10, Records Suspect in Abuse Case
description: Two days after she was sexually molested for a second time, the girl confronted her abuser, who admitted his wrongdoing and apologized profusely, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the film roles of women nominated for Academy Awards misstated the legal record of Sydney Biddle Barrows, who became known as the Mayflower Madam. She pleaded guilty in 1985 to promoting prostitution, a misdemeanor for which she was fined $5,000; she was not charged as a prostitute.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FAIRFAX FINANCIAL TO BUY MOST OF SKANDIA AMERICA
description: Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy most of the Skandia America Reinsurance Corporation for about $230 million. Skandia America, which is based in New York, writes casualty and property reinsurance, which is protection that insurance companies buy to alleviate their own risks. Last year the company, not including its Capital Assurance and Capital Alliance Insurance units, which are not being sold, had gross written premiums of $205 million and total assets of about $1.3 billion. Fairfax is a financial-services company based in Toronto. Skandia America is a subsidiary of the Skandia Insurance Company, which is based in Stockholm.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Helping to Heal the Wounds of Loss
description: John Yglesias was buried without a headstone when he died in January 1994, after a long bout with cancer.

title: Man Is Executed for Killing Brother, 9
description: A man was executed by injection early today for shooting his 9-year-old brother to death after an argument with his family over bad checks.

title: Warriors, Oakland Agree on Arena
description: Ending months of negotiations and the threat of the team's move to another facility in San Jose or San Francisco, operators of the Oakland Coliseum and the Golden State Warriors today reached agreement in principal on a $121 million arena reconstruction.

title: Transplant Surgeon Is Acquitted by Jury In Embezzling Case
description: Dr. John Najarian, a transplant surgeon who achieved some of the most daring breakthroughs in the field, was acquitted today of charges that he embezzled from the University of Minnesota.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Elf Aquitaine Posts Profit for 1995
description: France's biggest oil company, Elf Aquitaine, said yesterday that it had returned to profitability in 1995, but its chairman said he wanted to raise earnings further without many more asset sales. The company posted net income of 5 billion French francs, or $999.6 million, against a loss of 5.4 billion francs a year earlier, when it took heavy charges to write down assets. Sales were steady at 208.3 billion francs, about $41.6 billion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Post Recovery As Rate-Cut Hopes Revive Alan Greenspan's words were familiar, but the markets heard them with new ears. Stocks surged, recovering in large part from a selloff on Tuesday that came after the Federal Reserve chairman appeared to knock down one of the pillars of this year's rally: an expectation of a cut soon in interest rates. Mr. Greenspan offered many of the same opinions in Congressional testimony yesterday as he did Tuesday, but traders now saw in them suggestions that rate cuts were still possible.

title: Stocks Stop Their Slide, as Dow Jumps 57.44
description: Stock prices registered a sharp, broad rebound yesterday, a turnaround sparked in part by a reassessment of comments on the economy by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Muslim holiday Eid al-Fitr, a feast marking the end of Ramadan, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended today in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Morton Gould, Composer And Conductor, Dies at 82
description: Morton Gould, an American composer whose long and fruitful career did much to erase the lines between between concert and popular idioms, died yesterday at a hotel in Orlando, Fla. He was 82.

title: Third Teen-Ager Found Guilty of Slaying Police Officer During Holdup
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager was convicted yesterday of murder and robbery after a jury found that he had willingly participated in the armed holdup of a bicycle shop in which another robber killed a police officer.

title: Managua Journal;Born Out of War, Nicaragua's Police Keep the Peace
description: The latest winner of the Police Friendship Medal, for civilians who give exemplary support to Nicaragua's crime fighters, was Pablo Antonio Vega, the Roman Catholic Bishop of a province that saw some of the meanest battles of the civil war of the 1980's.

title: My Spy Story
description: After several days in a prison near Baghdad in 1991, I was told "they" wanted to see me. Blindfolded, I was led into a room where, judging from the voices, there were at least half a dozen men. For days, I had heard and sometimes watched as guards beat and tortured Iraqi prisoners.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Loan Details Revealed
description: Guard DUANE SIMPKINS of the University of Maryland needed a loan from a former coach to pay off $8,242 worth of campus parking tickets, the National Collegiate Athletic Association said yesterday. Simpkins was given a three-game suspension last week by the N.C.A.A. for accepting a $2,000 loan from DONNIE GROSS, a former Amateur Athletics Union coach. Simpkins and school officials previously declined to reveal how much money he owed in fines. (AP)

title: British Ford Has Egg Whites on Its Face
description: The British subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company came under attack in Parliament today after it was disclosed that the company changed black faces to white ones in an advertising campaign.

title: Israel Sets Election Date and Both Sides Come Out Swinging
description: Israelis were told today that national elections will be held on May 29, and an initial exchange of blows, coupled with the heated bickering over the date itself, left little doubt that the campaign will be ferocious.

title: Families Hope Freeway Killer's Execution Ends Their Years of Pain
description: If Sandra Miller's plans go right, the man who raped, tortured and strangled her 15-year-old son will receive a letter from her on Thursday that reads, in part:

title: Currents;Chiaroscurist at Large
description: WHEN Erik Hanson travels, he doesn't snap aides-memoires. The photographer uses his Grand Tour-style shots as essays on sun and shadow. Particularly fruitful were trips to Egypt (at right) and Spain. The images combine tones of warm sepia with cool platinum. Others are touched with blues and greens. His photos, which have graced Scientific American, cost $200 for an 8 by 10 to $600 for a 20 by 24; (212) 254-1045.

title: The Judge and the Lawyer: Some Not-So-Judicious Letters
description: For seven months in 1994, somebody sent Thomas F. Liotti, a prominent Nassau County criminal defense lawyer, an alarming series of anonymous faxes and letters, festooned with decals of American flags, grinning leprechauns and Tasmanian Devil cartoons.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Judge Pleads Guilty
description: A Morris County Superior Court judge who flunked a sobriety test after his car got stuck in a snowbank pleaded guilty yesterday to drunken driving.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;He's Tall, Dark and Fond of Stalin
description: THE PATRIOT By Piers Paul Read 290 pages. Random House. $23.

title: Currents;Sic Transit Sister
description: STYLE, like time, marches on. Albert Hadley's revamp of Parish-Hadley, the design firm at 305 East 63d Street, made its debut at a party last week for "Nancy Lancaster" by Robert Becker (Knopf, $40), a biography of the Anglo-American tastemaker. Instead of the chintz and frond-pattern wallpaper beloved by Sister Parish, who died in 1994 at 84, Mr. Hadley's chic minimalism reigns. Its heart is a beige gallery spiked with scarlet accents and modern art. An oil of Mrs. Parish hangs in a conference room -- her gaze discreetly blocked by a wall.

title: Greenspan Says Further Cut in Rates Is Possible
description: Helping to calm jittery financial markets, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told the Senate Banking Committee today that further rate cuts are possible as long as inflation stays low.

title: Retailer Plans Sales Growth And Expansion
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's third-largest retailer, said yesterday that it planned to open 285 to 350 stores this year and to remodel 90 to 100 others. The company also said it expected to show sales growth, and that it might pursue acquisitions.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Chargers Sign Salisbury
description: Quarterback SEAN SALISBURY signed a two-year contract worth about $1 million yesterday with the San Diego Chargers, a team he grew up idolizing. The 32-year-old Salisbury, who will back up STAN HUMPHRIES, grew up in nearby Escondido, Calif., then played at the University of Southern California. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: A report on Tuesday about a tribute on Sunday to Lincoln Kirstein, a founder of the New York City Ballet, included remarks by Agnes Gund, president of the Museum of Modern Art, that misidentified the subject of an exhibition at the museum. In the 1930's, Mr. Kirstein organized a show of the work of Walker Evans, not of Edward Weston.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;NBC in Talks to Free Executive To Take a Top Position at ABC
description: Top NBC executives were negotiating last night to release Jamie McDermott, one of television's most highly regarded young programming executives, from her contract.

title: A New Element Is Found: Zinc's Heavy Kin
description: Scientists at a German research institute have added a new element to the periodic table: element 112, a heavier, still unnamed relative of zinc, cadmium and mercury.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Boston Market Talking to Agencies
description: The Boston Market restaurant chain owned by Boston Chicken Inc. has begun talking to several agencies for additional creative resources beyond its agency of record, J. Walter Thompson New York.

title: Good People Go Bad in Iowa, And a Drug Is Being Blamed
description: In this small town surrounded by corn fields, nothing but Sunday morning church bells ever made much noise, and the jail sat three-quarters empty most of the time.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;MCA Agrees to Buy Stake In Interscope Record Label
description: After weeks of negotiations, MCA Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 50 percent of Interscope Records, the Los Angeles label that was at the center of last year's debate over "gangsta" rap.

title: A Tough Year Leaves Charities in Need
description: Time after time, the story repeats itself. A desperate person -- whether an abused woman or an elderly man facing eviction or an addict grasping for self-respect -- decides it is time to find help. The person starts calling social-service agencies, only to be told there is no room, there are long waiting lists, the agency has reached its limits. Finally, one phone number leads to an open door -- and help from a charity supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMPAQ TAKES STEPS TO RAISE EDUCATION MARKET SHARE
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation displayed its first personal computers yesterday that are designed to run on school and college networks, in a bid to raise its share of the education market, a stronghold of Apple Computer Inc. Compaq, the world's largest PC maker, also said it had hired Sue Collins, who until 11 days ago was Apple's manager of strategic initiatives for education markets. Compaq named Ms. Collins director of education marketing, responsible for sales to schools and colleges.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The tenor LUCIANO PAVAROTTI, 60, has said he is in love with his secretary, NICOLETTA MANTOVANI, 26, according to the Italian magazine Chi. The weekly magazine published pictures of the couple kissing recently in Barbados.

title: S.E.C. Seeks to Keep Fraud Figure in Jail
description: A fresh set of legal troubles arose yesterday for the failed financier Steven Hoffenberg, the architect of one of the largest Ponzi schemes in history.

title: Bridge
description: Some bridge players work their brains harder than others at the card table. One of the hardest workers is Bob Levin of Aventura, Fla., a former world champion who held the East cards on the diagramed deal from the 1995 International Team Trials in Las Vegas, Nev. He responded one heart to one diamond, and wound up defending four spades.

title: Most of the Schengen Group ContinuesTo Resist Cooperation on Police Matters : Myriad Disputes Stall Union's Border Treaty
description: BRUSSELS  The goal of passport-free travel between European Union countries remains distant because of a proliferation of disputes over terrorism and drugs, EU officials say.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CYPRESS SEMICONDUCTOR TO BUILD NEW PLANT IN TEXAS
description: The Cypress Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that it would invest $700 million to build a semiconductor plant in Round Rock, Tex., near Austin. Cypress said that the plant would be its fifth semiconductor wafer manufacturing operation and that it would employ 700 people. The company, which is based in San Jose, Calif., already operates a plant in Round Rock that employs about 400 workers. The new plant is to be in operation by mid-1997.

title: Students Paid the Price When Private Firm Took Over Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters;What Victors Did Not Say Tuesday Night
description: IT was too much to expect. That's obvious now. Why would they? They wouldn't -- of course, they wouldn't. So they didn't.

title: BASKETBALL;Recent Trades Prove to Be Distracting
description: On Tuesday night, Derek Harper was asked what he thought of the Knicks' recent trades.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Calendar: Shows And Talks
description: Gardening Symposium New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, the Bronx; (718) 817-8747.

title: Center Created For All Blacks Going to School
description: The United Negro College Fund is creating a research institute devoted solely to the education of black students in America, from nursery to graduate school.

title: GARDEN Q. & A.
description: Hold Your Seeds

title: Theater in Review
description: 'Aladdin,' With Genie, Trampolines and Skates Walt Disney's World on Ice Radio City Music Hall

title: Labor Sees Fiscal Hope in Credit Card Deal
description: To help finance its political activities and its plans to expand, the labor movement is harnessing an unexpected tool: capitalism.

title: ROCK REVIEW;With Age And Time, Bitterness
description: Bob Seger never subscribed to rock's illusion of perpetual youth. Back in the 1970's, he was already nostalgic; on a million-selling album, he fondly looked back on teen-age sexual initiations in "Night Moves" and promised that "Rock-and-Roll Never Forgets," even after "sweet 16's turned 31." His music tossed off Chuck Berry riffs alongside gleaming, stately ballads; his voice had the grain and fervor of 1960's soul. Mr. Seger, now 51, has held on to the heroic tone and roots-rock flourishes that have made him an arena headliner for almost two decades. But in his latest songs, he has moved from nostalgia to bitterness.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: Squirt TV' MTV, tonight at midnight

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Panel Supports Emission Bill
description: A State Senate committee backed a bill yesterday intended to protect New Jersey motorists from tougher motor vehicle emission standards until other states in the Northeast also impose tougher standards. The bill, approved by the Natural Resources and Economic Development Committee, says New Jersey should not put tougher standards into effect until three of the four neighboring states of New York, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and Delaware (or both New York and Pennsylvania) also enact tougher standards to meet the Federal Clean Air Act.

title: Law Knows No City Limits;As New York's Firms Thin Out, Outsiders Rush In
description: Reed Smith Shaw & McClay, a 118-year-old Pittsburgh law firm, had consciously avoided the costs and competition in New York. Last year it hired an international lawyer, Alan A. D'Ambrosio, away from the New York firm of Schnader Harrison Segal & Lewis and put him in charge of a new Reed Smith office in Manhattan. "We realized that we could never get a reputation in the international arena without a New York office," said David W. Christopher, Reed Smith's chief administrative officer.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Bullets Will Be Wizards
description: The Washington Bullets will become the Washington Wizards starting next season, the team's owner, ABE POLLIN, said yesterday.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Living in Oblivion 1994. Columbia Tri-Star. $97.51. Laser disk, $39.95. 92 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: Hussein Kamel Goes Home
description: The sensational defection to Jordan last summer of Saddam Hussein's son-in-law and director of secret weapons projects was a bonanza for United Nations arms inspectors. His contrite return to Baghdad this week is just as surprising, but its significance seems more personal than political.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;When Bland Plus Bland Equals More Than Bland
description: Few kinds of photography have fallen into such disrepute as portraiture. Where once ambitious portrait photographers could hope to capture a true expression of an individual's character, these days even the best photographers, faced with the task of depicting a subject, seem reduced to confessions of impotence.

title: Jobless Claims Rise by 5,000
description: The number of first-time claims for jobless benefits unexpectedly rose by 5,000 last week, which analysts said reflected a soft labor market.

title: Bosnia President Is Hospitalized
description: The President of Bosnia, Alija Izetbegovic, was taken to a hospital today with unspecified heart problems.

title: Two Exchanges Post Rises In Uncovered Short Sales
description: Open positions of short sales increased to record levels on the New York Stock Exchange in the most recent period and also increased sharply on the American Stock Exchange, the exchanges reported yesterday.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;On Deadline, Riley Makes Bold Moves
description: The Miami Heat, making three trades that drastically changed their team, highlighted an eventful day of dealing before the trading deadline yesterday in the National Basketball Association.

title: NYC;Talent Lost to a Failure Called Politics
description: WHAT, other than unrealized Presidential ambitions, could Jesse Jackson and Ross Perot possibly have in common? Sympathetic phone calls to Felix G. Rohatyn, it seems. Independently of each other, those two political mavericks from opposite poles commiserated with Mr. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker and public watchdog, after he was forced to pull out of the running for the No. 2 seat on the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day last Friday with an article about proposals for a flat tax misstated the effect of a 23 percent version on a married couple with two children and a $75,000 income. Such a family would pay $625 more than under the current tax system, not $750.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising -- ADDENDA;WPP Unit Gets More I.B.M. Billing
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, based in Armonk, N.Y., said yesterday that it had consolidated its Personal Systems Group's worldwide promotions account at the Einson Freeman Promotional Campaigns unit of the WPP Group in Paramus, N.J. The account, with billings estimated at $20 million to $30 million, was previously divided among local agencies. Einson Freeman was awarded the account after a three-month review that began with 12 agencies and was narrowed to Einson Freeman and three undisclosed finalists. A sibling WPP Group unit, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, handles the worldwide advertising account of I.B.M., with billings estimated at $400 million to $500 million.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Like Humbert Humbert, Full of Lust and Lies
description: THE END OF ALICE By A. M. Homes 271 pages. Scribner. $22.

title: 20 Years After Howard Hughes Died, His Empire Ends
description: The heirs of Howard R. Hughes Jr. wound up one of the greatest business empires of this century today by announcing that they had agreed to sell the last remnants of the Hughes holdings, vast tracts of land and buildings in Las Vegas, Nev., and in Los Angeles, to the Rouse Company.

title: POLITICS: MOVING WEST;Buchanan Steps Into an Arizona Crossfire
description: In a tangled and contentious debate, Patrick J. Buchanan and Lamar Alexander jostled for position tonight in the Republican Presidential contest here, battling over two issues that are expected to dominate the nomination fight over the next two weeks of primaries: trade and Mr. Buchanan's idea to shut borders to illegal immigrants.

title: Art in Review
description: Bruce Cratsley Yancey Richardson Gallery 560 Broadway, at Prince Street SoHo Through March 23

title: COMPANY NEWS;CROWN CORK AND SEAL DECLARES CASH DIVIDEND
description: The Crown Cork and Seal Company announced yesterday that it was declaring a quarterly cash dividend of 25 cents a share, the company's first dividend since 1956. The packaging products company plans to pay the dividend on March 29 to shareholders of record on March 15 and it plans to continue paying quarterly dividends. Crown Cork had said it would renew its dividends when it acquired Carnaud Metalbox S.A. of France recently. The company said it generally used extra cash to buy back shares. The stock rose $1.625 yesterday, to $49.

title: Traffic Accident in Texas Raises Questions About a New Gun Law
description: Kenny Tavai was driving his delivery van down Mockingbird Lane in Dallas on Wednesday morning, and Gordon Hale 3d was headed the same way in his pickup truck when the vehicles grazed each other, causing minor damage to their side-view mirrors.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;President Leaves Fox TV News
description: The president of Fox Television News, Joe Peyronnin, has resigned, the News Corporation, Fox's parent company, said yesterday.

title: Mayor Says Reduction in Boxes Led to Fewer False Alarms
description: The Giuliani administration said yesterday that an experiment last year in which a quarter of the city's fire alarm boxes were turned off clearly showed that dismantling the whole system would reduce the number of false alarms and eliminate thousands of runs each year to fires that do not exist.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Imperial Chemical Rise
description: Higher selling prices and improved volumes helped raise Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C.'s 1995 pretax profit by 85 percent, the company said yesterday. Pretax profit was L951 million ($1.47 billion), up from L514 million. Sales were L10.27 billion, up from L9.19 billion. (AP)

title: NBC Executive Takes Leave Amid Rumors Of ABC Post
description: Until this week, Jamie McDermott seemed to be on a straight and clear path toward becoming the programming chief of a major television network. And she was moving fast.

title: After New Hampshire, People vs. the Party?;Buchanan Heard
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Clinton Renames Greenspan And Fills 2 Fed Vacancies President Clinton renominated Alan Greenspan to a third term as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and filled two other vacancies with appointees considered unlikely to strongly dispute the chairman's strategy of slow growth to control inflation. One is the budget director, Alice M. Rivlin, nominated to be Fed vice chairman, and the other is Laurence H. Meyer, an economic forecaster.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Death Tearing A Family Apart
description: The riveting scene at the heart of "Before and After" is one showing the parents of a teen-age boy visiting him in jail. The son sits stony and defiant, refusing to say a word. He has been accused of killing his girlfriend, with whom his parents never knew he was involved. To their shock and horror, the parents realize they hardly know this boy at all.

title: Ernest Manning, 87, Ex-Alberta Premier
description: Ernest Manning, a Premier of Alberta for 25 years and father of the right-wing opposition leader Preston Manning, died on Monday at his home in Calgary, his son said. He was 87.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Marist Players Aiming To Forge Own Identity
description: In the short corridor leading to Dave Magarity's office, there is a picture of Rik Smits gliding past Pittsburgh's Charles Smith for a layup. Inside the office, there is a picture of Smits dunking over Pitt's Jerome Lane.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: A Hit Moves to the Big Time

title: COMPANY NEWS;QUALITY DINING TO BUY BRUEGGER'S BAKERIES
description: Quality Dining Inc., a restaurant operator, said yesterday that it would acquire the Bruegger's Bagel Bakeries chain from the Bruegger's Corporation in a stock deal worth more than $143.5 million. Bruegger's, a closely held company based in Burlington, Vt., owns and operates 40 retail bakeries and franchises 235 outlets in 26 states. Quality Dining, based in Mishawaka, Ind., surged $4.50, to $26, in Nasdaq trading. Quality Dining operates 62 Burger King restaurants, 42 Grady's American Grill restaurants, 18 Chili's Grill and Bar restaurants, 18 Bruegger's Bagel Bakeries and 5 Spageddies Italian Kitchen restaurants in 20 states.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CARNIVAL OFFERS STOCK AND CASH FOR AIRTOURS
description: The Carnival Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire a stake in the British tour operator Airtours P.L.C. in a stock-and-cash deal valued at about $310 million. The deal would give Carnival, a leading cruise-ship operator based in Miami, a 29.6 percent stake in Airtours, skirting British requirements that if a company makes an offer for 30 percent or more of a company, it must make a public offer for the entire company. Carnival said it had agreed to buy 20 million new Airtours shares for about $155 million and bid for another 20 million existing shares in return for Carnival shares or for about $155 million more in cash. Airtours is Britain's No. 2 tour operator.

title: Doctor Says Drugs Put Bombing Suspect in Fantasyland
description: Edward J. Leary was consumed by a dangerous mix of mind-altering drugs and was incapable of realizing the damage that could result from the firebomb he carried onto a Manhattan subway train in 1994, a psychiatrist testifying on his behalf said yesterday.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: U.N. Sees Some Gain In Iraqi Oil Talks
description: Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali told the Security Council today that Iraqi and United Nations negotiators had worked out a 12-step plan that would lead to a limited resumption of oil sales to pay for food and medicine.

title: F.A.A. Plans to Hire More Controllers
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it would hire 100 more air traffic controllers this year and "as many as 500" next year, mostly for busy centers in areas with a high cost of living, which have been hard to staff.

title: ART REVIEW;At the Armory, Bits of This and That
description: It may be poor form to look a gift horse in the mouth, especially one as high-powered as the collection of artworks and art dealers that is the eighth annual "Art Show" at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue. There's so much to be seen and learned here, especially where prints, drawings and photographs are concerned, and there's enough painting and sculpture to sate the hunger for weightier fare.

title: Dealer Who Bilked G.M. Takes Stand in Bribery Trial
description: Nearly four years ago, as the sheriff was knocking at the door of his Long Island car dealership, John McNamara was frantically feeding documents into a paper shredder -- hoping, he later admitted, to destroy evidence of how he had swindled the General Motors Corporation out of $6.2 billion in loans for nonexistent vans.

title: Wanted: Jobs of Last Resort
description: Members of the National Governors' Association were on Capitol Hill yesterday, once again pressing their case for welfare reform. The group has captured glowing reviews from both President Clinton and Congressional Republicans for a package of proposals that would favor block grants to the states over a guarantee of Federal aid.

title: POLITICS: THE NEXT STEP;Delaware Vote to Test Forbes's Viability
description: Even his keenest admirers admit it: Steve Forbes must do a lot better soon or his Presidential campaign will slide quickly into terminal irrelevance.

title: Two New Faces Join Greenspan As Fed Choices
description: President Clinton today renominated Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and filled two other vacancies with appointees considered unlikely to strongly dispute the chairman's slow growth strategy to control inflation.

title: An Adviser to Presidents, Regardless of Party Stripe
description: Laurence H. Meyer, a Democrat nominated yesterday to the Federal Reserve board of governors, has been dispensing advice on the economy to Presidents for more than a decade. He gave President Clinton advice on tax proposals during the 1992 campaign, and has worked with the Administration ever since.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Reforms Sought on Job Corps
description: Citing violence and drug abuse among participants, Representative Robert Franks yesterday called for reforms in the Federal Job Corps youth-training program. Mr. Franks, a Republican from New Providence, said at the Job Corps center here that he would introduce legislation next week to require drug and alcohol testing, to adopt a "zero tolerance" policy toward violence and drug and alcohol abuse and to call for a review by the Department of Labor of each center's performance.

title: 16 Child-Abuse Programs Are Facing Shutdowns
description: Sixteen child-abuse-prevention programs in the city's Beacon School network of after-school educational programs could be forced to close next week unless the Giuliani administration spends $1.2 million to keep them open, city officials and social service providers said yesterday. The programs provide counseling, supervision and instruction to more than 2,500 children considered at risk of neglect or abuse.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Another L.S.U. Injury
description: DEUCE FORD, injury-riddled L.S.U.'s top remaining scorer, will miss the rest of the season and the Southeastern Conference tournament, school officials announced yesterday.

title: BASEBALL;Right-hander Is Sold To Yomiuri Giants
description: The Texas Rangers made an international deal today, selling right-handed pitcher Balvino Galvez to the Yomiuri Giants of the Japanese Central League for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: GOLF;Ballesteros Selected
description: SEVE BALLESTEROS, whose inspired play in recent years helped boost Europe to Ryder Cup prominence, was appointed European Ryder Cup captain yesterday, taking over from the Briton BERNARD GALLACHER.

title: Art in Review
description: Diana Thater David Zwirner Gallery 43 Greene Street, SoHo Through March 16

title: FILM REVIEW;Jackie Chan vs. a Gang
description: If "Rumble in the Bronx" scores well enough at the box office to make Hollywood see major dollar signs, it could augur a new style of action-adventure film in which swaggering macho pyrotechnics give way to balletic daredevil comedy. But don't count on it. The movie, which is the newest and most aggressive effort to establish the Asian superstar Jackie Chan as more than a cult figure in the American market, is a giddy triple somersault of a film that makes no sense whatsoever, although in its best moments it is as much fun to watch as a death-defying circus act.

title: Child Abuse Programs At Risk of Closing
description: Sixteen child-abuse-prevention programs could be closed unless the Giuliani administration spends $1.2 million to keep them open, officials said yesterday.

title: HORSE RACING;Genuine Risk Gives Birth
description: Genuine Risk, the filly who won the 1980 Kentucky Derby and then did not produce a foal until 13 years later, produced another one Wednesday night at Three Chimneys Farm in Midway, Ky.

title: The Shuttle Takes Off for a High-Wire Act
description: The space shuttle Columbia roared aloft today on a difficult mission to tow miles of electrical cable through the hostile environment of outer space, its seven astronauts intent on advancing a futuristic way of studying Earth's atmosphere and of powering and propelling spacecraft.

title: Man Arraigned in Bronx Killings As His Confession Is Released
description: In chilling, matter-of-fact statements given to the police after the fatal shootings of five people in a Bronx shoe store in December, the suspect, Michael Vernon, described how he became angry at a clerk before methodically shooting everyone in the store, including a witness who tried to flee.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by Reuters on Feb. 1 about the illustrator Burne Hogarth misstated his role in the history of the "Tarzan of the Apes" comic strip. He drew it from 1937 to 1950; he did not create it.

title: Counties Reaching for Lilco Tax Accord
description: Summoned to Gov. George E. Pataki's office at the World Trade Center in Manhattan, top officials of Nassau and Suffolk counties said yesterday that they were moving toward resolving a tax refund issue that is the major stumbling block in a complex plan to dismantle the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Apache Corp., Houston, is selling $100 million of debentures due in 2026 through Chicago Capital Markets. The debentures are priced at 99.632 to yield 7.731 percent. The issue is rated Baa3 by Moody's Investors Service, BBB by Standard & Poor's and BBB+ by Duff & Phelps.

title: POLITICS: ON THE AIR;Radio Talk Show Host Fears For True Conservatism's Fate
description: Patrick J. Buchanan's candidacy for the Republican nomination has not simply stirred concern at the highest levels of the Republican Party. It has also alarmed Rush Limbaugh, the talk radio host who functioned as a kind of national precinct captain for the Republican electoral revolution of 1994.

title: ART REVIEW;When Poussin Drew for Himself
description: The greatest French artist of the 17th century, Nicolas Poussin had many gifts, but the ability to draw with ease was not among them. Genius can be hard won, as you see in the exhibition of 65 Poussin drawings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Elliott Close to Decision; But First, One Last Trip
description: The agent for Jumbo Elliott said his client should decide by tomorrow where he is going to play next season.

title: Kaiser Makes Surprise Bid For Alumax
description: The Kaiser Aluminum Corporation made a surprise hostile offer yesterday for rival Alumax Inc., setting the stage for what could be a nasty takeover battle.

title: I.R.A.'s Ultimate Goal
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside Art
description: Lending Out Matisse and Picasso

title: Mexico Is Committed to Battling Drugs;Bank Acquisition
description: To the Editor:

title: Stalkers May Face No Small Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Teen-Agers Charged in Fatal Yonkers Fire
description: Two teen-agers have been charged with second-degree murder and second-degree arson in connection with a house fire last week that killed two toddlers, the authorities said today.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Pocahontas 1995. Disney. $26.99. 87 minutes. Closed captioned. Release date: Wednesday. G.

title: POLITICS: VYING FOR THE LEAD;Dole Adopts a New Persona: Savior of the Grand Old Party
description: Thanks to Patrick J. Buchanan, Bob Dole is starting to find his voice.

title: Art in Review;Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: Sports of The Times;Islanders Sail Through Storm Watch
description: THIS time Mike Milbury was spitting mad, not spitting.

title: Art in Review
description: Richmond Burton Matthew Marks Gallery 1018 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street Through March 2

title: 2 Tribunals On Atrocities Will Be Led By Canadian
description: Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali today appointed a Canadian judge with a background in civil rights and criminal law to replace Richard Goldstone of South Africa as head of the international criminal tribunals on the former Yugoslavia and Rwanda.

title: Mae La Journal;Exiles Adrift: Nowhere to Run, Nowhere to Hide
description: At the end of the school day, the refugee children in a dirt-floor schoolroom here sing the anthem of a nation they call Kawthoolei: "I love you. I will serve you. I will be true to you. I will even die for you."

title: Pepsico's Top Executive Is Set to Resign
description: Pepsico Inc. said today that Wayne Calloway, its chairman and chief executive, would resign and turn over the reins to Roger Enrico, the company's No. 2 executive.

title: Home Video
description: Horror and Camp

title: After New Hampshire, People vs. the Party?;Liberalism's Demise
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Dodgers Sign Nomo To Three-Year Deal
description: HIDEO NOMO became the first Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher ever to sign a multiyear deal after his rookie season when he agreed to terms of a three-year contract yesterday. Terms of the deal were not released, but the package is believed to be worth about $4.3 million.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Jury Rapidly Acquits Moon of Spousal Abuse Charges
description: It took less than a half hour for jurors to deliver a verdict of not guilty today in the spousal abuse trial of Warren Moon. Upon hearing the decision, Moon, the Minnesota Vikings' quarterback, hugged his wife and later bowed his head in prayer with a circle of family and friends.

title: RUSSIA AND I.M.F. AGREE ON A LOAN FOR $10.2 BILLION
description: In a major election-year boost for President Boris N. Yeltsin, the International Monetary Fund and Russia agreed today on a $10.2 billion loan to carry forward the country's free-market reforms.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STROH SEEN IN OFFER FOR HEILEMAN BREWING
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company, teetering again on the brink of bankruptcy, has received a $275 million buyout offer from the Stroh Brewery Company, Benj Steinman of Beer Marketer's Insights said yesterday. Heileman, the nation's No. 5 brewer, announced in September that it was changing the structure of its finances. It received the lowest debt rating from Standard & Poor's after failing to make an interest payment on Jan. 31. Heileman had emerged from bankruptcy protection in 1991 and was bought two years later for $428 million by Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., a Dallas Investment firm. A Heileman lawyer, Randy Smith, declined to comment. Lacey Logan, a spokeswoman at Stroh, which is based in Detroit, said the company did not "comment on speculation and rumor."

title: COMPANY NEWS;BAXTER WITHDRAWS BID FOR NATIONAL MEDICAL
description: Baxter International Inc. said yesterday that it was withdrawing its $3.8 billion offer to acquire the National Medical Care unit of W. R. Grace & Company. Grace had recently agreed to merge National Medical Care, a kidney dialysis services business, with Fresenius A.G. of Germany. Baxter disclosed that it was giving up its bid in a letter to Grace's chief executive, Albert J. Costello. In the letter, Baxter's chief executive, Vernon R. Loucks Jr., said, "We firmly believe that our proposal is clearly more favorable." The bid was withdrawn after Grace's stock rose $1.25, to $68.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. A Grace spokesman was not immediately available for comment.

title: Chancellor's Aide Returns Fee
description: The chief spokesman for Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has returned a $1,500 consulting fee that he collected from a private educational organization during his first month at the Board of Education last fall.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MASTERCARD AND NATIONAL DATA JOINT VENTURE
description: Mastercard International and the National Data Corporation said yesterday that they would create one of the world's largest payment-processing companies to tap the growing international market. The company, to be called Global Payment Systems, is expected to process 2.25 billion transactions a year, produce revenues of about $175 million in its first year and employ 1,100 people worldwide. It would operate as an independent third-party processor with its own board and management team headed by National Data's chairman, Robert A. Yellowlees. National Data's stock rose $4.375, to $29.75.

title: POLITICS;Russian Backer For Buchanan
description: Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, the ultranationalist candidate for the Russian presidency, has hailed the victory by Patrick J. Buchanan in the New Hampshire primary and told him that they could cooperate to deport American and Russian Jews, the Interfax news agency said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Music Piracy Complaint Faced Again by Japan
description: Following the lead of the United States, the European Commission, the executive body of the European Union, lodged a complaint yesterday with the World Trade Organization against Japan over music piracy. "The E.U. and the U.S. have decided to take a joint action in the W.T.O. against Japan's failure to give sufficient intellectual property protection to recording sounds on the Japanese market," a spokesman said.

title: Sperm Decline Reported
description: Sperm counts have fallen by about 25 percent among British men over a generation, doctors reported today, adding to evidence that men in many countries are becoming less fertile.

title: Mexico Is Committed to Battling Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Men's Accuser Recants Story Of Jail Rape
description: Prosecutors dropped rape charges today against two inmates in the Union County Jail after their accuser admitted that she had consented to have sex.

title: Blunt Talker On Budgets And Deficits
description: Perhaps no one in the Clinton Administration gets as fired up as Alice M. Rivlin about eliminating the Federal budget deficit. As director of the Office of Management and Budget since October 1994 and deputy director for 20 months before, she has been a powerful voice for balancing the budget -- and in this her views are strongly akin to those of Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman.

title: Rich Nations Urge Action to Cut Dangers of Lead
description: Industrialized nations have reached the first international agreement on measures to reduce the dangers posed by lead in the environment.

title: Queens School Is Succeeding on a Shoestring
description: In what was once the boys' shower room off the gymnasium at Public School 175 in Queens, 21 kindergarten students sat on the floor or a few chairs and listened attentively as Christine Bregman, a science teacher, explained how a magnet could pull certain objects through sand.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Shades of Brahms and Jerry Lee Lewis
description: Two interesting composers from America's 30-something generation shared a program at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday night.

title: New York's Phantom Primary
description: As things look now, New York State's March 7 Republican primary will take place in the thick of a suspenseful brawl for the party's Presidential nomination. By virtue of the primary's timing -- relatively early in the selection process, for a change -- and the large number of delegates up for grabs, New York should be the stage for a spirited contest among the three leading G.O.P. contenders, Bob Dole, Pat Buchanan and Lamar Alexander.

title: On My Mind;What Dole Owes Us
description: We didn't plan it this way. I didn't realize that jobs and trade and what makes America work would become a big issue in the last few days of this campaign."

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Despite Rise, Dell Profit Is Below Expectations
description: The Dell Computer Corporation reported today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 17 percent, but those results just missed matching analyst expectations.

title: Samuel Wishik, 89, Authority on Public Health
description: Samuel M. Wishik, a professor emeritus of public health at Columbia University who helped devise family planning and health programs throughout the world, died on Monday at Thornton Hospital in San Diego. He was 89 and lived in the La Jolla section of San Diego since retiring from Columbia 18 years ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Feb. 13 about the Vinland Map misattributed research on the map's inscriptions that helped support its authenticity. It was James Enterline, not Ardell Abrahamson, who detected what might be acrostics in the legends.

title: TV SPORTS;Master Storyteller of the Airwaves
description: If you wonder whether a director matters on a baseball telecast, think of "Goodfellas" without Martin Scorsese or "Citizen Kane" without Orson Welles. They would be different films in the hands of lesser craftsmen.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Stock prices were lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 40.56 points, or 0.20 percent, at 20,300.38. On Thursday, the Nikkei was down 31.29 points.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Jan. 25 about Mattel Inc.'s offer to buy Hasbro Inc. misidentified Hasbro's chairman. He is Alan G. Hassenfeld; John W. Amerman is Mattel's chairman.

title: GOVERNMENT CUTS MAY CAUSE LOSSES IN LOAN PROGRAMS
description: When President Clinton delivered his State of the Union Message last month, no part was more warmly applauded than his declaration that the "era of big government is over."

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Worker Shot at Gas Station
description: An attendant at a Shell station on Route 4 was shot three times in a robbery attempt yesterday but managed to telephone for help. The attendant, Mourad Girgis, 50, of Midland Park, was shot in the neck, chest and groin by a gunman, who then drove away, said Charles Buckley, Acting Prosecutor for Bergen County. Mr. Girgis was in critical condition in Hackensack University Hospital Medical Center.

title: FILM REVIEW;A New Linda Fiorentino In Specs and Dull Shoes
description: Unforgettable is a fine word for "The Last Seduction," in which the director John Dahl showed such electrifying film noir finesse and Linda Fiorentino's scorching dragon-lady turn made her a star. So it's strange that "Unforgettable," the new film directed by Mr. Dahl and starring Ms. Fiorentino, is being advertised without mention of their previous triumph.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Inge's Bus Passengers, Stranded Overnight
description: DURING the height of his career in the 1950's, the playwright William Inge was sometimes placed in the pantheon of post-World War II giants with Tennessee Williams and Arthur Miller. They were of the same generation, but Inge was not of the stature of the other two, being neither a great poet of the theater nor a grandly dramatic moralist. He was a deceptively prosy sort of writer.

title: Rape Case Dropped For Lack of Evidence
description: The Bronx District Attorney's office has dropped charges against a Bronx man accused of raping his 2-year-old niece because there is no medical evidence that the girl was raped, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;A Second Ex-Cowboy Is Lured by the Raiders
description: The Oakland Raiders reaped yet another reward of salary cap limitations by luring defensive tackle Russell Maryland from the Super Bowl champion Dallas Cowboys today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TENNECO PLANS TO SELL REMAINING STAKE IN CASE
description: Tenneco Inc. is planning to sell its remaining 21 percent stake in the Case Corporation to the public, according to regulatory documents. Case, a maker of agricultural and construction equipment based in Racine, Wis., said Tenneco would sell its remaining 15.2 million Case shares. Case plans to offer an additional 1.5 million shares, for a total offering of 16.7 million shares. Case currently has 71 million common shares outstanding. Tenneco, a Houston-based automotive, energy, packaging and shipbuilding company, has been steadily cutting its stake in Case over the last two years. Case's stock fell $1.375 yesterday, to $50.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Government Reports a Surplus in January
description: Lower spending and stronger corporate profits helped the Government post a strong $19.27 billion surplus in January, the Treasury Department reported today.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Funds Restored for Helicopter
description: Since the Federal fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, a helicopter used by the Environmental Protection Agency's office in Edison to monitor the cleanliness of ocean water off the Jersey shore has been grounded as one of the lesser-known casualties of the dispute over the Federal budget. Now, it is airborne again. The E.P.A. announced Wednesday it would make $240,000 available so the helicopter can fly part of the time for the next few months.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief theater review yesterday misidentified the theater where "A Laying of Hands" is playing. It is the Judith Anderson, at 422 West 42d Street in Manhattan

title: Scourge of Armies For A Few Hours;Saxons and Scots Confront Rat Race in Brooklyn
description: Cigar smoke billowing behind him, James Grotto strode grandly across the room as he summoned his troops to storm a heavily fortified Confederate ridge in the Battle of Gettysburg.

title: Market Place;A class action is seen as a dress rehearsal for new securities laws.
description: ANYONE curious about how securities class-action lawsuits may change under the rules enacted by Congress last year should keep an eye on a suit now confronting California Micro Devices, a maker of electronics components in Milpitas, Calif.

title: To Rescue a Precious Swamp
description: Over time, America's exploding population and commercial progress have taken a huge toll on the nation's natural resources. But few have been as grievously wounded as Florida's Everglades, an area of more than 2,000 square miles rich in plants and wildlife that has shrunk to half its original size. The Clinton Administration has a new plan to save what is left. It would serve residents of Florida's gilt-edged east coast as well as that magnificent, beleaguered swamp.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Infinity Broadcasting to Buy Specialist in Outdoor Ads
description: In its first deal outside the radio industry, the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy TDI Worldwide Inc., a privately held company that dominates big-city transit advertising in the United States and Britain, for $300 million in cash and stock.

title: After New Hampshire, People vs. the Party?;No More Third Person
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad at Home;Pat Calls the Tune
description: Give him credit. Pat Buchanan has forced attention to the most important political fact in the country today: the belief of ordinary people that they are losing out in economic status and security.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Anderson Fitting In Just Fine As a Knick
description: Charles Oakley will remain out for the next five weeks with a broken right thumb and Patrick Ewing is listed as day to day with a sprained right ankle. Before their summer shopping spree ever comes to fruition, the Knicks are perilously close to putting out an S.O.S. -- Save Our Season -- to any healthy body who will listen.

title: A Scuffle Reopens Canadian Wounds
description: In English-speaking Canada, he is a hero who gave a demonstrator a lesson he will never forget. "True Grit: Big Jean Throttles Quebec Protester," blared the headline in The Edmonton Sun. The Ottawa Sun weighed in with "Hull Hogan."

title: ART REVIEW;History of the Synagogue, Archeology Included
description: Sacred Realm: The Emergence of the Synagogue in the Ancient World," at the Yeshiva University Museum in Manhattan, has built-in appeal: it's a meticulously documented look at the roots of one of the world's oldest surviving religious institutions. But it's also -- be warned -- a dyed-in-the-wool archeological show, with the visual astringency that that implies.

title: POLITICS: THE FINANCES;Perot Hints at a Possible Run This Year
description: Four years ago this month, Ross Perot floated a trial balloon that he has yet to fully puncture: he would run for President, he told Larry King, if enough people wanted him to.

title: South African School Battle Now a War of Nerves
description: Outside the elementary school here today, the police were ready for a confrontation. Traffic was being diverted. Armored vehicles stood ready and dozens of officers patrolled the area -- all to make sure that 15 black students would be able to start their first day of classes in this formerly all-white school.

title: Gould Memorial
description: A memorial tribute to the composer Morton Gould is to be held on Sunday at noon at the Tilles Center for the Performing Arts, C. W. Post Campus, Long Island University, Brookville, L.I. It is open to the public and will feature the pianist Ted Joselson. There will be choral and instrumental works by Mr. Gould, who died on Wednesday at the age of 82.

title: Company Briefs
description: HEWLETT-PACKARD CO., Palo Alto, Calif., agreed to buy the Internet security business of the privately held Secureware Inc., Atlanta, for undisclosed terms.

title: SKI;Compagnoni Has First Title
description: The two-time Olympic champion Deborah Compagnoni of Italy, often a victim of bad luck and illness, was struck with good fortune today and won the women's giant slalom at the world Alpine skiing championships for her first world title.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10

title: Dubbing of Foreign Films: Don't
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki Proposes Law to Let Prosecutors Appeal Sentences
description: Seeking a far-reaching change in the state's criminal justice system, Gov. George E. Pataki announced today that he would propose legislation that would allow prosecutors to appeal sentences and bail amounts after judges set them.

title: Unemployment-Fund Battle Begins
description: Business and labor leaders in New Jersey began a joint lobbying effort today against a legislative proposal that would use $1.1 billion from the state's unemployment insurance fund over the next four years to help pay for hospital care for the poor.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;No Deals for Streaking Nets
description: While the Nets spent much of their well-deserved day off yesterday waiting for the fog to clear so that they could fly back to New Jersey from Milwaukee, Willis Reed was in a self-described "listening mode" up to and, technically, after the trading deadline.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Charities Worry as Donations Fade at the Finish
description: A week before The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund officially ends its 1995-96 campaign, the fund is in danger of finishing behind last year. At $4,374,653, it is $152,266 away from reaching last year's total of $4,526,919.

title: Cold War Over, France Plans a Slim, Volunteer Military
description: Announcing the most sweeping military changes since development of a nuclear deterrent almost 40 years ago, President Jacques Chirac said tonight that France's armed forces would shrink by about a third and become an all-volunteer force within six years.

title: Senate in Tennessee Backs 10 Commandments' Posting
description: The Tennessee Senate has approved by a vote of 27 to 1 a resolution urging homes, businesses, schools and places of worship to post and observe the Ten Commandments, despite an opinion of the State Attorney General that the measure is unconstitutional.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Card Counter Loses on Ban
description: A professional card counter who has been barred from the casinos has lost his attempt to get the ban lifted. The Casino Control Commission, which banned David Morse of Cranston, R.I., last June, voted on Wednesday to continue keeping him out. Mr. Morse, 43, has sued four Atlantic City gambling establishments. He and a few other players have been successful at blackjack over the years because they can quickly deduce the chances of certain cards being dealt based on those that have already been dealt.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Indicted in Minister's Shooting
description: A grand jury indicted Robert Reeves, 30, of Newark yesterday on attempted murder and other charges that could put him in prison for 86 years. Mr. Reeves is accused in the carjacking attack on an East Orange minister who two days ago said he felt no hatred for the man who shot him five times and left him on an East Orange street on Feb. 6. The minister, the Rev. William Barnett, 56, of the Citadel of Hope Mission, still has three bullets lodged in his head but is expected to recover.

title: BASEBALL;Steinbrenner Predicts Big Years From Gooden, Key . . . and Rangers
description: George Steinbrenner orchestrated his own version of a "Seinfeld" episode at Legends Field today as he made sweeping statements about the state of the Yankees and bold predictions ranging from the comebacks of Dwight Gooden and Jimmy Key to the hockey teams that will play for the Stanley Cup.

title: Tribute to Ives After 30-Year Effort
description: WITH money earned in the life-insurance trade, Charles Ives published his Second Piano Sonata, "Concord, Mass., 1840-1860," in a private edition in 1920. Nearly two decades later, his Transcendentalist masterpiece finally received its first complete performance. And while it waited to be heard, American music passed through its glorious pioneer years. Edgard Varese unleashed "organized sound"; Carl Ruggles carved his granite chords; Roger Sessions gave new bite to established Germanic forms; Aaron Copland perfected his astringent early style; Henry Cowell toyed with clusters and polyrhythms. Conductors like Stokowski and Koussevitzky vied for premieres. American music arrived as a world power.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 15 about a proposal in Connecticut to reduce welfare benefits for families whose children have too many unexcused absences from school referred incorrectly to the status of similar programs elsewhere. Federal approval has been granted for such programs in only 22 states; 12 more have applications pending.

title: Little Evidence on Effects Of Combinations of Drugs
description: Doctors and lawyers have argued for half a decade about whether the popular antidepressant Prozac can unleash violent or suicidal behavior. But the defense for Edward J. Leary, the man accused of firebombing two subway trains in 1994, is making a more complicated claim: that because of careless prescribing, Mr. Leary's brain was saturated with dangerously high levels of this and other drugs, producing bizarre behavior that culminated in the bombings.

title: COMPANY NEWS;$1 BILLION LAS VEGAS CASINO COMPLEX SET
description: International Thoroughbred Breeders Inc. is planning to develop a $1 billion casino, hotel, retail and entertainment complex in Las Vegas, Nev., where seven gaming companies are expected to operate under the same roof. Each will have its own theme and management. The 5.4-million-square-foot Starship Orion project will be on the Las Vegas Strip, opposite Circus Circus. The project will also contain 300,000 square feet of retail space, 2,400 hotel rooms, theaters and other entertainment sites. Separately, International Thoroughbred said its former chairman, Robert E. Brennan, had said he would sell his 2.9 million shares to Cambridge Partners, a privately held investment partnership that already holds more than 5 percent of the company.

title: S.I. Lawyer Held in Murder Plot
description: Apparently trying to feed a cocaine habit, a lawyer from Staten Island plotted to rob and kill a man in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, but was arrested there yesterday after revealing his plan to a police informer, the police said.

title: N.J. Transit Is Reassessing Braking Plan
description: New Jersey Transit planned to install an emergency braking system on its Hoboken commuter lines for 13 years, but other pressing needs and a lack of money kept it from completing the job, high-ranking agency officials said this week.

title: Cosmic Blasts May Be Star's Last Gasps
description: A cosmic mystery has literally burst on the astronomical scene. A phenomenon near the center of the Milky Way galaxy, is emitting rapid but erratic blasts of high-energy radiation unlike anything observed before by astronomers.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Blast at Farrakhan
description: The Basketball Hall of Famer KAREEM ABDUL-JABBAR, a student of history, is no fan of LOUIS FARRAKHAN, the controversial leader of the Nation of Islam. "I am an Orthodox Muslim," Abdul-Jabbar said. "I am not a part of Minister Farrakhan's little group.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DIME BANCORP PLANS TO END FEDERAL SUPERVISION
description: Dime Bancorp Inc. plans to sell $93 million in stock to buy from Federal regulators a block of securities tied to the bailout of Anchor Bancorp Inc. Dime, the nation's fourth-largest savings institution, plans to sell 8.4 million shares of stock underlying warrants Anchor issued to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in 1993 to raise capital. Dime assumed responsibility for the warrants when it merged with Anchor in late 1994. With the stock sale, Dime will eliminate the last vestige of years of Government supervision of both Dime and Anchor. Dime shares were unchanged at $11.375.

title: Serbs on Trek: Weighted Down and Terrified
description: In yet another of the heart-rending refugee flights that punctuated the Bosnian war and that now mar the peace, thousands of terrified Serbs trekked over snowy mountains today, away from their homes near Sarajevo.

title: FILM REVIEW;Of the Jekyll-Hyde Duo And Their (His?) Maid
description: Mary Reilly" proves Julia Roberts has the clout to play an unbecoming role in a gloomy film with a story whose outcome, even in the age of the happily-ever-after "Scarlet Letter" remake, is an especially foregone conclusion. Hubris like this is not unknown in Hollywood, but we haven't lately seen it demonstrated so forcefully on dry land.

title: Airline Says Jet Parts Taken From Wreckage in Colombia
description: Scavengers have descended on the wreckage of the American Airlines jetliner that crashed in Colombia last December, making off with more than 500 parts, including the jet engines, the landing gear and electronic components for possible sale to other carriers, the airline said.

title: Frank Newman, 78, a Justice On California's Supreme Court
description: Frank C. Newman, a former judge of the California Supreme Court and an authority on constitutional rights, died on Sunday in an Oakland hospital. He was 78 and lived in Orinda, Calif.

title: About Real Estate;Rental Plans Gain Backers In New Jersey
description: A Manhattan real estate company that owns or manages 9,000 rental apartments in New York City is trying its hand redeveloping three mostly vacant apartment complexes in Essex County, N.J.

title: G.I.'s on Alert After Report Of Threat by Bosnia Serb Chief
description: United States troops in Bosnia have been placed on alert after reliable reports that Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb leader, had ordered his forces to kidnap American soldiers and other NATO troops, Defense Department officials said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising -- ADDENDA;Bombardier Unit Selects Harris Drury
description: The Bombardier Motor Corporation of America, a unit of Bombardier Inc., has retained Harris Drury Cohen in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to handle its Sea-Doo personal watercraft account. In addition, the company has expanded its relationship with Harris Drury Cohen by naming that agency to handle its Sea-Doo jet boat and Celebrity boat accounts. The combined billings were estimated at more than $15 million.

title: CHRONICLE
description: On Wednesday, JOSEPH A. CALIFANO JR., the president of the Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University, will announce the results of two years of research his group has done on the causes of drug, alcohol and tobacco abuse in urban America, using New York City as a laboratory. His staff analyzed different health records, including those from hospitals and the police. He will present the 225-page report at a press conference at the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan.

title: I.B.M. to Buy Canada Partner
description: Moving to strengthen its position in the market for the tools that computer programmers use to write software, I.B.M. announced yesterday that it was acquiring Object Technology International Inc., a small, privately held Canadian software company.

title: In America;Red, Plaid and Nutty
description: With Pat Buchanan commanding the spotlight, very little attention is being paid to the bizarre proposals of the other extremist among the leading Republican Presidential hopefuls.

title: Clinton Aide Quizzed Anew on Whitewater
description: Harold M. Ickes, the hard-driving senior White House aide who headed a team of Clinton Administration advisers handling Whitewater issues when they burst into public view two years ago, faced a hostile Senate panel today in which Republicans accused him of misleading them and Federal investigators.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League TEXAS RANGERS -- Sold the contract of Balvino Galvez, pitcher, to the Yomiyuri Giants of the Japan League for cash.

title: Sprint Names a President And Its Wireless Venture
description: The Sprint Corporation announced today that Ronald T. LeMay had been named president and chief operating officer.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;As Goodby, Silverstein raises its profile, it's still different out there
description: THE agency that Madison Avenue considers perhaps the strongest creative force in American advertising today is raising its profile to a level more commensurate with its abilities and accomplishments.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Short Life Recalled In a New Documentary
description: It is said that one picture is worth a thousand words. The documentary film "Anne Frank Remembered," however, proves again and again that in remembering a historical event as horrific as the Holocaust, nothing brings home its reality with more shattering force than the verbal accounts of those who lived through it.

title: Dow Jumps 92.49 as Stocks Keep Surging
description: Stock prices surged to new levels yesterday, propelled by what analysts said was strong demand from big institutional investors, many of whom have missed out on much of the rally so far this year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising -- ADDENDA;Seagram Grows At FCB/Leber Katz
