description: The Seagram Beverage Group said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with FCB/Leber Katz Partners in New York by naming that agency to handle its North American Dole juices account, which had been at Lord, Dentsu & Partners in Los Angeles, a joint venture of Dentsu Inc. and Young & Rubicam Inc., for the last five years. The billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: Art in Review
description: Julian Schnabel 'The Conversion of St. Paolo Malfi' PaceWildenstein 142 Greene Street SoHo Through March 23

title: COMPANY NEWS;BUICK NAMES BRAND MANAGER FROM KEEBLER
description: The General Motors Corporation's Buick division said yesterday that it had appointed Roger Adams, an executive at the Keebler Company, to be brand manager for the Buick Regal. G.M., which is seeking to sharpen the image of individual vehicles, has hired 34 brand managers since the fall, including five consumer marketers from outside the company. Analysts have criticized G.M.'s marketing as being unfocused, causing its car and truck divisions to compete for the same customers. The brand managers oversee vehicle marketing strategy, including advertising and pricing. Mr. Adams, 39, most recently was Keebler's vice president for marketing and research and development, responsible for the cookie and cracker divisions. United Biscuits P.L.C. sold Keebler's cookie unit last month to Inflo Holdings for $487.5 million. The Regal was Buick's second-best selling model last year, behind the Le Sabre.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Quarterly Profits Up For Honda Motor
description: Riding a strong rebound in domestic sales, the Honda Motor Company, the Japanese auto maker, said yesterday that its profit jumped 41 percent in its third quarter. Honda earned 18.4 billion yen, or $175 million, in the three months that ended on Dec. 31, up from 13 billion yen for the corresponding period in 1994. Sales jumped 13 percent, to 1.02 trillion yen, or $9.7 billion, from 905 billion yen a year earlier.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;U.S. Bonds Gain on Hope Of Rate Cut
description: Treasury prices ended moderately higher yesterday, buoyed by a resilient optimism that the Federal Reserve would soon cut interest rates again.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Why Has Bodhidharma Left for the East? 1993. Milestone. $79.95. 135 minutes. Korean, with English subtitles. No rating.

title: TENNIS;Buoyed by the Crowd, Capriati Battles Back From First-Set Jitters
description: It was 4-0 in favor of the lesser known 19-year-old when the clapping began.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MOLLY IVINS, the syndicated columnist for The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, won't be saying much these days in The Dallas Observer, a free weekly.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about the composer Morton Gould misstated the given name of a daughter. She is Abby Burton, not Amy.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : George Washington Slept Here, Here, Here and Here
description: "George Washington Slept Here" signs planted outside Colonial-era buildings are so common in the eastern United Statesthat it was the title of a Broadway play way back whenand has become a common punch line for dubious historical claims. Seemingly, never has one man gained so much recognition for laying his head on a pillow.

title: Art in Review
description: 'One and Others' Lelong Galerie 20 West 57th Street Through March 9

title: After New Hampshire, People vs. the Party?
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Taking a Walk Down Cinema's Mean Streets
description: IN its own way, 'Cat People' was as important as 'Citizen Kane' in the development of a more mature American cinema," Martin Scorsese tells us, quite convincingly, in "A Personal Journey With Martin Scorsese Through American Movies." Though this vastly entertaining, strong-willed new documentary runs nearly four hours, it has no room for pompous artistes or stuffy academics. It does have plenty of space for the B movies that Hollywood raised to the level of art. Jacques Tourneur's 1942 film, "Cat People," had monsters that were no more than shadows (the budget was that low), a beautiful heroine with unspoken psychosexual fears (movies were that circumspect) and an enduring impact on American horror films, which are often deeper than they seem.

title: POLITICS;In Their Own Words
description: LAMAR ALEXANDER

title: C.I.A. Chief Defends Secrecy, in Spending and Spying, to Senate
description: The Director of Central Intelligence said today that the secret budget for spying might be made public, and he defended a longstanding policy allowing clandestine officers, under extraordinary circumstances, to pose as reporters or to use journalists as informers.

title: Texas Heat Contributes to Fires That Destroy 65 Homes
description: At the beginning of February, less than three weeks ago, they were shivering through ice, snow and the coldest weather to hit these parts in seven years, down in the single digits.

title: POLITICS: ON THE MOVE;Buchanan Drawing Extremist Support, And Problems, Too
description: It was an awkward moment for Patrick J. Buchanan as his campaign car pulled up outside a suburban New Orleans hotel last month. Inside was a room jammed with about 200 of his supporters. Among them was David Duke, the Louisiana politician best known as a former leader of the Ku Klux Klan and a neo-Nazi sympathizer.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Penney's Net Down 23.4% In 4th Quarter
description: The J. C. Penney Company said today that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 23.4 percent from the corresponding period a year ago, amid stiff competition and winter storms that hurt sales in January. The decline marked the fifth consecutive quarter that the company's profit fell from periods a year earlier.

title: Sophie Reuther, a Social and Labor Activist, Is Dead at 82
description: Sophie Reuther, a social activist who captured the heart of the United Auto Workers' co-founder, Victor Reuther, and then proved her mettle as a union organizer during the violent labor wars of the 1930's, died on Tuesday at a hospice near her winter home in Ft. Myers, Fla. She was 82 and had been Mr. Reuther's full partner in labor and in life for 59 years.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;BET Rejects Offer For Units by Rentokil
description: A takeover bid for the British business services company BET P.L.C. took an unusual twist yesterday when the company said Rentokil P.L.C. wanted to make a partial offer for its textile and distribution divisions and most of its business services, including electronic security units.

title: BASEBALL;Young Met Pitchers Turn On The Heat
description: Jason Isringhausen left Carl Everett feeling as if he had never swung a bat. Paul Wilson had Jeff Kent hoping to escape without breaking his wrists. Bill Pulsipher reduced Butch Huskey from a power hitter to a pop-up batter, and Juan Acevedo threw enough smoke to summon the fire department.

title: TV WEEKEND;'Black Is . . . Black Ain't'
description: PBS, Sunday (Channel 13, New York, 10 P.M.)

title: After New Hampshire, People vs. the Party?;Jobs, Jobs and Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM REVIEW;True Tale Of Prodigy Of Poison In Britain
description: With supreme confidence and not a whiff of apology, Benjamin Ross's "Young Poisoner's Handbook" presents a perfectly monstrous hero. He is Graham Young, the scientific prodigy whose favorite lethal weapon was the teacup, and whose antisocial exploits were the stuff of British tabloid headlines during the 1970's.

title: Restaurants
description: What do New Yorkers want in their restaurants? The proprietors of Gotham Bar and Grill have spent 11 years studying the question and they seem to have the answer down pat.

title: N.A.S.D. Fines Hibbard Brown $10 Million
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said today that it had fined Hibbard Brown & Company $10 million and expelled the firm from membership for defrauding hundreds of investors to whom it sold shares of three companies.

title: HOCKEY;Leave It to the Islanders to End the Rangers' Streak
description: In a season filled with devastating injuries, front-office turnover, roster changes and more defeats than most teams, the Islanders have had few moments to rejoice.

title: Donations Drop at Year's End For Clintons' Legal Defense
description: President Clinton's private legal defense fund raised just $105,000 in the last half of 1995 -- well below its previous pace -- even as Mr. Clinton's legal bills arising from the Whitewater investigation continue to run more than $1 million a year, the fund's trustees reported today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FIGURE SKATING;Kwan Received Threat
description: Security was tightened around the American team following a death threat against the United States figure skating champion, MICHELLE KWAN, French media reported yesterday. A suspect has been identified in the incident. Kwan is in Paris to compete at the Champions Series Grand Prix Final this weekend.

title: Keep Free Expression in Public Parks Free
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Former South Korean Generals Arrested for 1980 Massacre
description: Three more former generals were arrested today for their role in the massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators by the army in an uprising 16 years ago.

title: No Headline
description: I think it's time to get back to the basis of morality in this country, which has traditionally been based in Judeo-Christian beliefs."

title: BASKETBALL;Kittles Banned For 3 Games
description: Kerry Kittles, the top scorer for fourth-ranked Villanova, has been suspended for the team's final three regular-season games because of the unauthorized use of a university telephone credit card number.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Ex-Officer Indicted in Death
description: A former Rahway police officer has been indicted on charges of reckless manslaughter in the death of a friend. The indictment, returned Wednesday by a Union County grand jury, accused Richard Pelesko, 23, of being drunk last April 16 when he lost control of his car and struck a utility pole, sending the car airborne for 60 feet and killing John Czaya, also 23. Mr. Pelesko, a rookie police officer, was dismissed shortly afterward. Kenneth Oleckna, a lawyer for Mr. Czaya's family, has notified the Clark Police Department that the family intends to sue on the ground that a Clark police officer had stopped the car earlier that evening and determined that both men were drunk, but let them drive on with Mr. Pelesko at the wheel. DAVID STOUT

title: BASEBALL;Bonds Hopes the Best Is Yet to Come
description: When Jerry Rice told his friend Barry Bonds that all great athletes prepare the way they do because of a fear of failure, Bonds couldn't disagree.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Welcome to the All-Star Cafe," says the man who leads me to a table. He reaches across and shakes my hand. "My name is Carlos and these are our owners." He points to the pictures on the menu and, tapping each with a finger, adds: "Joe Montana, Ken Griffey Jr., Wayne Gretzky, Andre Agassi and Shaquille O'Neal."

title: 25 and Under
description: Opening a restaurant is always risky, simply because restaurants are a difficult business. Opening too far from a large enough corps of restaurantgoers worsens the odds, no matter how good the restaurant.

title: TV WEEKEND;Third-Party Candidates Through the Decades
description: With the Presidential campaign season going into high, tonight's review of America's third-party movements from the Anti-Masons of the 19th century to the Perotians of just yesterday or tomorrow is timely, if not stimulating. "A Third Choice" is a classroom sort of exercise in which Ben Wattenberg takes note of the forces that brought such politicians as Abraham Lincoln, Theodore Roosevelt and those two Wallaces, George and Henry, to the fore.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about France's proposal to reduce its armaments industry, and the plan's effect on the town of Bourges, referred incorrectly to American cities in comparable situations. Long Beach, Calif., is a manufacturing center for McDonnell Douglas, not Lockheed; Groton, Conn., has a plant owned by General Dynamics but is not the company's headquarters.

title: For Children
description: 'Bride of Beowulf' Here 145 Avenue of the Americas, near Spring Street, SoHo Ages 7 and up Tomorrow

title: No Headline
description: Dow Jumps 92.49 Points

title: Art in Review
description: Dan Graham 'Models to Projects, 1978-1995' Marian Goodman Gallery 24 West 57th Street Through March 2

title: Corning Unit Agrees to Fraud Settlement
description: A medical laboratory has agreed to pay $6.68 million to settle charges it defrauded Medicare, Medicaid and other Government programs by performing and billing for unnecessary blood tests, United States Attorney Donald K. Stern said on Wednesday.

title: F-14's Grounded After Persian Gulf Crash
description: The Navy ordered all of its F-14 jet fighters out of the skies for at least three days after one of them crashed today into the Persian Gulf, the third crash of an F-14 in the last month.

title: HORSE RACING;Foot May Keep Cigar Out of Santa Anita
description: Cigar, the great thoroughbred who has won 13 races in a row, was disclosed today to have suffered a stone bruise on his right foreleg and will most likely forgo his trip to California for the $1 million Santa Anita Handicap next week and possibly his trip to the Persian Gulf next month for the $4 million Dubai Invitational.

title: If Marriage Is a Contract, It Can Be Broken
description: To the Editor:

title: New Fiscal Watchdog May Be a Lame Duck
description: The Independent Budget Office, intended to serve as an objective, nonpartisan monitor of New York City's dauntingly complex, often deliberately obscured budget, has opened with little more than a telephone and a desk in a dingy, borrowed office -- and with three of the city's top elected officials, including Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, pledging to abolish it.

title: Karadzic Dreams of a New Capital for Bosnian Serbs
description: After his forces spent most of the last four years destroying ancient mosques and shelling the Austro-Hungarian landmarks that once dotted Sarajevo's horizon, the Bosnian Serb political leader, Radovan Karadzic, is now talking about building, not destroying.

title: Close Eyes. Relax. 10, 9 ...
description: Before you can be hypnotized, you must first see whether you are hypnotizable. I was hopeful.

title: Journal;Contract, The Sequel
description: The Republican Party, it would seem, is in chaotic retreat, its dying sound a buzzing of phones and fax machines. Even Newt Gingrich is so little heard or seen in public these days he could pass for one of the country's best-behaved children. Colin Powell, only yesterday the Republican favorite son, has disowned its new Presidential front-runner -- and has been usurped in the party hierarchy by the Russian ultranationalist Vladimir Zhirinovsky, who on Thursday endorsed Pat Buchanan as a "brother in arms."

title: BASEBALL;Outfielder Catches Mets' Attention in Unintended Way
description: Kevin Roberson wanted to make an impression with the Mets' coaching staff, but not this way. Roberson, an outfielder who is trying to find a home with the Mets after three years in the Chicago Cubs' organization, drew the concern of teammates and coaches when he nearly fainted while taking a blood test today.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the testimony of Harold M. Ickes, a senior White House aide, before the Senate Whitewater committee referred incorrectly in some editions to the position held by his father during the New Deal. It was that of Interior Secretary, not Agriculture Secretary.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Changes at Whitbread
description: U.K. Whitbread P.L.C. announced yesterday that Bill Shannon would become managing director of the Whitbread Inns division and that Stewart Miller had been appointed managing director of Whitbread Pub Partnerships division. Mr. Shannon had been running Whitbread Pub Partnerships on a temporary basis since December, when Wess van Riemsdijk took a leave of absence. "Mr. Riemsdijk's leave of absence is likely to be longer than first thought," Peter Jarvis, chief executive, said. (Dow Jones)

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Behind the Cameras, a Battleground
description: Like television itself, "The Late Shift" is entertaining and appalling.

title: If Marriage Is a Contract, It Can Be Broken
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: BOB DOLE;Dole Says Buchanan Is Extreme In Outlook
description: Bob Dole asserted his independence from religious right leaders today as he continued to criticize Patrick J. Buchanan's views.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MOBILE TELECOMMUNICATION SHARES SLIDE BY 20%
description: The shares of the Mobile Telecommunication Technologies Corporation fell 20 percent after the paging company posted a wider-than-expected fourth-quarter loss late on Thursday and said its chief financial officer had resigned. Mtel also said it was in default of certain loan covenants and was seeking waivers from its banks. It plans to cut $20 million in expenses this year, including jobs. Those cuts amount to about 7 percent of Mtel's 1995 expenses. The results and Robert Fugate's resignation as chief financial officer surprised Wall Street analysts. They said it appeared that Mtel had not effectively managed the introduction of the nation's first two-way paging service. Mtel's shares were down $3.75, at $14.125, in Nasdaq trading of almost 9.1 million shares.

title: U.S. Board Reinstates Foschi
description: Jessica Foschi just might get a chance to qualify for the Olympic team after all.

title: Emotion May Have a Role in Alzheimer's
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: WELFARE;Some Charities Criticize Alexander's Welfare Plan
description: For the last two years, Congressional Republicans have been seeking radical changes in the nation's welfare programs. But Lamar Alexander says they are not radical enough.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;A Divorce for Justice
description: The Atlanta Braves slugger DAVID JUSTICE said yesterday that his divorce from the actress HALLE BERRY has nothing to do with him being stopped by the police in an area frequented by prostitutes and drug dealers.

title: Dorothy Maynor, 85, Soprano and Arts School Founder, Dies
description: Dorothy Maynor, a highly regarded soprano recitalist who founded the Harlem School of the Arts, died on Monday at the Chester County Hospital in West Chester, Pa. She was 85 and lived in Kennett Square, Pa.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday with an article about the New York region's slow recovery from the most recent recession misstated the years for a comparison of business starts and failures. The years being compared were 1994 and 1995, not 1984 and 1985.

title: New Weakness Seen In New Jersey Jobs
description: New Jersey lost a significant number of jobs last month as the state's unemployment rate remained above the national average, suggesting continued sluggishness in the economy, according to new data.

title: Dispute on Gulf War Missile Continues to Fester at M.I.T.
description: A faculty committee at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has reached a not-guilty verdict in a dispute between two of its professors that stemmed from a debate over the effectiveness of the Patriot missile during the Persian Gulf war.

title: Rochester Radio Stations in Deal
description: The American Radio Systems Corporation said today that it had reached an agreement to buy four radio stations in Rochester for $30.5 million from Lincoln Group L.P.

title: Second Foreign Tourist Slain in Florida in '96
description: A Dutch woman was shot to death in Miami today, and her killing, the second of a foreign tourist in the state this year, evoked memories of the string of tourist killings in 1993 that marred Florida's tourism industry.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Money Supply Increases by 8.4%
description: German M-3 money supply growth, a primary policy indicator, grew at an annualized rate of 8.4 percent in January, above target growth rates but well beneath the markets' worst fears, the Bundesbank said yesterday. The central bank said that money supply grew very rapidly in January, largely because of almost stagnant long-term investment and buoyant lending to the Government. Some financial market dealers had speculated that the growth rate might be 15 to 20 percent.

title: Leg at Bomb Site Is Identified, And a Body Will Be Exhumed
description: A leg found last year in the rubble of the Oklahoma City bombing belonged to a woman already identified and buried, raising the possibility that she was buried with someone else's leg, the state medical examiner said today.

title: A Victory for Choice
description: In a case with important national implications for a woman's constitutional right to choose an abortion, a unanimous New York State appeals court has rebuffed a landlord's effort to evict an abortion clinic in Garden City, L.I. During 1994 the clinic was the target of violence, threats and harassment by abortion opponents. The December 1994 shooting spree that killed two people and wounded five others at two abortion clinics in Massachusetts simply made matters worse. Violence at the Garden City clinic escalated, as it did at abortion clinics all over the country.

title: New Bosnia Police Force Takes Over From Serbs in Sarajevo Suburb
description: In an early-morning transfer of power, officials from Bosnia's Muslim-dominated Government today began the reunification of Sarajevo by taking control of the police station in this suburb, where Serbs held power until Thursday night.

title: Alumax Moves To Thwart Hostile Bid By Kaiser
description: Even as speculators bid up its stock, Alumax Inc. took steps yesterday to thwart an unwanted takeover by the Kaiser Aluminum Corporation.

title: POLITICS: STEVE FORBES;Forbes Appears to Pull Back on Spending for Campaign Ads
description: While Steve Forbes has vowed to stay the course despite dismal showings in the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary, his plans for buying television advertisements in states that will soon be holding contests tell a different story.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Sports People column yesterday about the appointment of Seve Ballesteros as the next captain of the European Ryder Cup golf team carried an erroneous credit. It was by Reuters, not The Associated Press.

title: G.O.P. Had Victories In New York State, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;FEDERATED STORES SAYS IT WILL RETAIN 2 UNITS
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. said yesterday that it would retain its Aeropostale and Charter Club specialty chains after saying last year that it might sell the operations. Last June, Federated said it would entertain offers for the $128 million specialty-store operations to focus on its traditional department stores. The company acquired the chains as part of its takeover of R. H. Macy & Company in December 1994. Federated also named Julian R. Geiger president of the specialty stores division. Mr. Geiger, 50, has been president of the Eagle's Eye Kids, River Art and Robin Sinkler wholesale divisions of Asian American Partners.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Guerrillas in Lebanon May Have Israelis' Bodies
description: Party of God guerrillas said today that they have the bodies of two Israeli soldiers missing for the past decade, and offered to swap them for comrades in detention.

title: HOCKEY;Six Goals, But Narrow Victory
description: The Devils scored six goals in an unusually productive game, but Coach Jacques Lemaire was rather unhappy because his team allowed five goals and barely managed a 6-5 triumph over the Montreal Canadiens tonight before a sellout crowd of 19,040 at the Continental Airlines Arena.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Neediest Cases;A Deadened Spirit That Loving Care Revived
description: Two years ago, a violent robbery left Gina F. homebound and disoriented. Her nerves frayed and tangled, she neglected her own daily care, the tasks of lifelong habit.

title: 64 Are Indicted as Gangsters In Chinatown
description: Taking aim at the network of alien smugglers who have brought hundreds of illegal Chinese immigrants to New York in recent years -- and who often use kidnapping, torture and extortion to bolster profits -- Federal prosecutors said yesterday that they had smashed a violent organized-crime gang that had terrorized Chinatown for years.

title: Tories' Rule Is Shaken By Defection
description: Prime Minister John Major's Government has taken yet another blow as one of its members of Parliament defected today from the Conservative Party, paring its hold on power to a margin of a mere two seats.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Wizards in Waiting
description: The Bullets will not become Wizards overnight.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Study Faults College Tuition
description: Comparatively high tuition rates at New Jersey's public colleges and universities are keeping the percentage of college-age state residents enrolled in higher education below the national average, a report released yesterday said. According to the study by the Commission on Higher Education, 33.7 percent of college-age New Jersey residents are enrolled in higher education. Nationally, the average is 34.4 percent. New Jersey also lags behind New York and Pennsylvania, The Associated Press reported.

title: Man Known as the Freeway Killer Is Executed
description: William George Bonin, whom the media had labeled the Freeway Killer, was executed today, becoming the first California convict to be executed by injection.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;A Plea for Peace in Ulster
description: President Clinton spoke by telephone today with the British and Irish Prime Ministers and urged them to keep seeking peace in Northern Ireland.

title: Evicted Ex-Tenant Is Charged In Fire That Killed 2 Children
description: A 36-year-old woman who neighbors said had been evicted last month was charged today in an arson at her former apartment building that killed two toddlers.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;South Africa Remains Resilient Despite Selloff in Currency
description: The South African rand took a pounding in the last week, skidding nearly 10 percent in a selloff set off by a rumor that President Nelson Mandela had suffered a heart attack. Analysts said the currency's drop showed how little confidence the outside world has in this country's political stability.

title: Beliefs
description: A certain kind of madness," Thomas Cahill said when asked what moved him to give "a series of explorations" under the title of "Encountering God."

title: Sports of the Times;Primaries Heating Up For Knicks
description: BATTLE lines for the hearts and souls of premier free agents have been drawn. Pat Riley has his Miami Heat to rebuild, and Ernie Grunfeld has the Knicks. Next summer will be Eastern Conference primary season, the race to determine which of these presidential novices can mount a serious challenge to the Orlando Magic and the Chicago Bulls.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mercedes Layoffs in Brazil
description: Mercedes-Benz laid off 1,200 workers this week at a plant in Campinas and will stop making bus bodies in Brazil. The move "is part of our restructuring process aimed at achieving greater competitiveness on the international market," said Euclides Fontana, a spokesman for Mercedes-Benz's Brazilian subsidiary. The dismissals represent almost 38 percent of the 3,200 workers employed at the plant in Campinas, which is 58 miles north of Sao Paulo. Mercedes is a unit of Daimler-Benz.

title: Annoyance at L.I.R.R. Plan to Shut Stations
description: Riders of the Long Island Rail Road had mixed reactions today to a proposal to close 13 of the railroad's least used stations to cut costs and toprepare for the arrival of 114 double-decker diesel cars next year.

title: A Company Stops Making A Child Drug
description: Doctors say they can no longer get supplies of a drug that is the primary treatment for a severe seizure condition in infants because the manufacturer unexpectedly stopped making it.

title: Brooklyn Judge Taking Time Off Amid Escalating Criticism
description: Lorin Duckman, the Brooklyn Criminal Court judge who has been under harsh attack recently for his handling of two domestic violence cases, will take an unspecified amount of time off from his duties on the bench, a spokeswoman for the state court system said yesterday.

title: Rite Aid Hits Snag In Its Bid for Revco
description: The Rite Aid Corporation is having problems obtaining approval from the Federal Trade Commission for its $1.8 billion bid to buy Revco D.S. Inc.

title: Louise Rorimer-Dushkin, Civic Benefactor, 85
description: Louise Rorimer-Dushkin, a prominent supporter of Manhattan's settlement houses, died on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Santa Fe, N.M. She was 85 and had moved to Santa Fe from the Upper East Side three years ago.

title: Killings in Croatia
description: The Security Council expressed concern today at reports of isolated killings and human rights abuses in areas of Croatia recaptured last year from Serb control.

title: Unilever Cut Original Helene Curtis Bid
description: Unilever N.V. cut its final bid for Helene Curtis Industries by 10 percent earlier this month after reviewing the Chicago-based company's internal financial records.

title: REACTOR ACCIDENT IN JAPAN IMPERILS ENERGY PROGRAM
description: Two months after an accident at its prototype reactor, Japan's program to use plutonium to provide a virtually inexhaustible supply of energy is at a crossroads, and could be in danger of collapse.

title: BASEBALL;Strike Zone a Knee Deeper
description: Baseball has lengthened the strike zone in order to shorten games.

title: Officer Is One Of 6 Indicted In Drug Case
description: It was one of those modest but bustling family businesses, investigators said, in which the owner's mother minded the shop and a brother-in-law, a New York City police officer, made deliveries on his days off. An acquaintance pitched in, they said, dressed in his Army National Guard uniform.

title: Tomba Gets the Gold
description: Alberto Tomba ended a decade of frustration today with a victory in the giant slalom at the world Alpine skiing championships. It was his first medal at the worlds, where he was competing for the fifth time.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Enron Hopes to Restart Work on Plant in India
description: The Enron Development Corporation hopes to restart construction on its power plant in India by May 1 after agreeing on a new price for the plant's electrical output, a company spokeswoman, Diane Bazelides, said yesterday. The company reached the revised power purchase agreement on Thursday with the Maharashtra State Electricity Board. The agreement still needs final approval, however, from the Maharashtra Cabinet, the central Government of India and project lenders.

title: BASKETBALL;Nets Gunning For 6th Straight
description: The post Kenny-and-Derrick era is going exceedingly well. As the Nets prepared to meet the Cavaliers tonight at Gund Arena in Cleveland, they were headed for uncharted territory under Coach Butch Beard.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economic Growth Slowed To Just 0.9% in 4th Quarter The economy grew at a meager nine-tenths of 1 percent annual pace in the final three months of 1995, as consumers kept a tight grip on their wallets, Government spending fell and investment by business slackened, the Commerce Department said. For all of 1995, growth was 2.1 percent, the least since 1991.

title: Jobless Rate Still Exceeds U.S. Average
description: New Jersey lost thousands of jobs last month as the state's unemployment rate remained above the national average, suggesting continued sluggishness in the local economy, according to data released by state and Federal officials today.

title: Grant Sawyer, 77, Governor Of Nevada Who Fought Crime
description: Grant Sawyer, a two-erm Governor of Nevada who sought to rid the gaming industry of the influence of organized crime, died here on Monday night. He was 77.

title: Kmart to Shut 15 Stores, Cutting 1,300 Jobs
description: The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that it would shut 15 stores by the end of May and dismiss 1,300 workers, the opening move in its program to close 60 stores this year.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about the Child Welfare Administration's training academy in Queens misstated the relationship between Joel Steinberg and Lisa Steinberg, the child he was convicted of beating to death. Mr. Steinberg had illegally adopted the child; he was not her legal father.

title: POP REVIEW;Mainstream or Vanguard, and Often Loud
description: Pheeroan Aklaff, one of jazz's more imposing drummers, who moves easily between swing and free playing, is spending a rare week leading a band in a major club, Sweet Basil, through tomorrow.

title: Rudy Crew's Challenge
description: Rudy Crew began his term as New York City's Schools Chancellor with the threat that failing schools would either shape up or face serious housecleaning. Dr. Crew has started to act on that promise by taking control of two Bronx school districts that include the most corrupt and academically disastrous schools in the system. Dozens of other investigations are under way, and a third of the city's 32 local school boards could eventually be suspended for academic malfeasance or influence-peddling. The first two suspensions in the Bronx are particularly tough cases that could make or break the reform effort.

title: U.S.-Chrysler Effort On Car of the Future
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the Department of Energy announced an $84 million research program today to develop high-tech "hybrid" propulsion systems for cars of the future.

title: A Breakthrough on New York Schools?
description: After 26 years of dysfunctional school governance in New York City, the State Legislature has begun to address top-to-bottom reform seriously. A proposal put forward last week by Assembly Democrats would abolish the 32 community school boards and create a new, larger central board.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;President of Colombia Criticized in Drug Case
description: The prosecutor bringing charges against President Ernesto Samper has given a Colombian congressional committee evidence that the President resisted taking action against the leaders of the Cali drug cartel.

title: U.S. Chicken in Every Pot? In Russia, Apparently Not
description: A nasty little skirmish between Russia and the United States is brewing here over a threatened trade barrier.

title: Harry Swartz, 84, an Authority On Allergies and Their Remedies
description: Dr. Harry Felix Swartz, one of the nation's foremost authorities on allergies and their remedies, died on Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 84 and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Roger-A. d'Hulst, Rubens Expert, 77
description: Roger-A. d'Hulst, an authority on the art of Peter Paul Rubens and Jacob Jordaens, died in Brussels on Feb. 15. He was 77.

title: Service for 8 In Job Corps Fills Some With Anger
description: Families of four of the eight Job Corps trainees killed last week in a Maryland train crash joined the victims' classmates here today for a memorial service that paid as much tribute to the Job Corps program as to the dead.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Samsung Helicopter Pact
description: The Samsung Aerospace Company, a unit of the Samsung Group of South Korea, said yesterday that it had agreed with Textron Inc.'s Bell Helicopter division to jointly develop an eight-seat light helicopter by September 1997. Bell will invest $240 million in the project, which was approved by the South Korean Trade Ministry on Thursday. Samsung will contribute $60 million, a Samsung spokesman said. The two companies will produce about 1,020 helicopters between 1998 and 2012, about 460 of them in South Korea. (Reuters)

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Getting Your Students To Kill Your Husband
description: The sex kitten has turned murderous. Ann-Margret's roller-coaster career has included starring opposite Elvis Presley in the movies, singing and dancing in Las Vegas and playing Blanche DuBois in "A Streetcar Named Desire." Now, in her mid-50's, she's going the your-worst-nightmare route in the title role of "Seduced by Madness: The Diane Borchardt Story," a two-part movie on NBC tomorrow and Monday. Here is a demon portrayed with chilling gusto.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Finding Serenity in the Logic Of Contrapuntal Movement
description: Eliot Feld has choreographed an ode to counterpoint. "Paean," which received its premiere on Thursday night at the Joyce Theater, is a formally ingenious work. Yet as danced by Feld Ballets/NY, it also proved a quietly joyous one. Mr. Feld has made compositional logic a sign of spiritual serenity.

title: Emotion May Have a Role in Alzheimer's
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Feb. 14 about the actor Martin Balsam misidentified his role in the film "Seven Days in May." He played a Presidential press secretary, not a military man.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Brian Daley, 48, an Author Of Fantasy and Science Fiction
description: Brian Daley, the author of "The Doomfarers of Coramonde" and other works of fantasy and science fiction, including three "Star Wars" novels, died on Sunday at his home in Arnold, Md., near Annapolis. He was 48.

title: POLITICS: TRADE;President Shows Political Muscle on Visit to California
description: In a state crucial to his re-election prospects, President Clinton today displayed the political power of incumbency.

title: Not a Drop of Savings
description: To the Editor:

title: 9 Soldiers Disciplined After Racism Inquiry
description: The Army said today that nine 82nd Airborne Division soldiers face disciplinary proceedings and could be kicked out on charges of engaging in racist activities.

title: Film Redux In Europe: Action!;New Signs of Life After a Long Decline
description: At the big Shepperton Studios west of London, work progresses on "101 Dalmatians," a version with live actors of Walt Disney's animated classic. At nearby Pinewood Studios, cutting was just finished of "The Michael Collins Story," a tale of Irish independence by Ireland's brightest young director, Neil Jordan. In Berlin, a $230 million investment is well under way to revive the old Babelsberg Studios that produced classics like Fritz Lang's "Metropolis" and "The Blue Angel," with Marlene Dietrich.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Suspended Kittles Offers an Apology
description: With only 14 points against No. 3-ranked Connecticut on Sunday, KERRY KITTLES would have become Villanova's career scoring leader in his final collegiate game at the Spectrum in Philadelphia. But because of some improper telephone calls, the senior swingman will not get that curtain call.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Chapman, Heat Surprise Bulls
description: Pat Riley won't trade this.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNITEL VIDEO CLOSES EDITEL UNIT IN CHICAGO
description: Unitel Video said yesterday that it planned to get out of its money-losing television special-effects and graphics business by selling its Editel unit and that it would shrink the unit, dismissing 75 people, while looking for a buyer. The company closed its Editel Chicago division, dismissing 40 workers, and will trim the staff of its New York division by half. The job cuts amount to about 16 percent of Unitel Video's work force. The Editel divisions generated about one-third of Unitel's annual revenue of $83 million last year. Editel provides special effects, graphics, film coloring and editing primarily for television commercials.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Bears Re-sign Spellman
description: The Chicago Bears re-signed defensive end ALONZO SPELLMAN yesterday, matching an offer sheet he had received from the Jacksonville Jaguars for $12 million over four years.

title: If Marriage Is a Contract, It Can Be Broken
description: To the Editor:

title: Havana Journal;Needing Cash for Bread, Cuba Tries a Circus
description: Down the Paseo del Prado they marched, wave after wave of dancers and drummers decked out in extravagant, blindingly flashy outfits. "I've never seen anything like this before," Oscar Raul Marrero, 11 years old, exulted as he whirled on the sidewalk and watched -- wide-eyed, loose-limbed and nimble-footed -- the spectacle flowing past him.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SCOTTS RESTATES NET AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE QUITS
description: The Scotts Company, the lawn products maker, said yesterday that its chief executive had resigned and that the company would lower its previously reported earnings. Theodore J. Host resigned as president and chief executive immediately. Tadd C. Seitz, the chairman, who turned over day-to-day responsibility to Mr. Host last year, will serve as chief executive and president while the company looks for a successor. Scotts lowered its reported profit figure for the 1995 fiscal year, which ended on Sept. 30, by $2.7 million, or 12 cents a share, to $22.4 million, or 99 cents a share. The company said its 1995 advertising and promotional allowances were understated. Scotts also delayed its annual shareholders meeting, scheduled for March 12, by two weeks.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Elliott Switches Locker Rooms at the Meadowlands
description: Offensive lineman Jumbo Elliott never thought it would come to this -- an all-out bidding war for his services. But it has, and the Jets, the Giants and the Arizona Cardinals now have some competition as the Indianapolis Colts have made Elliott a multiyear offer.

title: Pollution Alert
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;AM INTERNATIONAL SEES BIG LOSS AND CUTS 200 EMPLOYEES
description: AM International Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter loss would be "substantially greater" than the first quarter's and dismissed 200 workers because of worsening results. The company, a business and graphics-equipment maker, also said that it would temporarily shut one of its plants and that it had sold its AM Multigraphics subsidiaries in the Netherlands, France and Belgium. Terms were not disclosed, and company officials declined to elaborate. Shares in AM, based in Rosemont, Ill., closed down 62.5 cents at $3.125.

title: Jury at Impasse in Litton-Honeywell Suit
description: Jurors in Los Angeles hearing a lawsuit by Litton Industries against Honeywell Inc. sent a note to the judge yesterday saying they were at an impasse on the amount of damages.

title: POLITICS: A RADIO RUCKUS;Rough Ride for Buchanan On His Very Own Turf
description: If ever there was a candidate who seemed tailor made for talk radio, it is Patrick J. Buchanan.

title: No Headline
description: I've danced, I've eaten, I've had fun. I'm so glad to see that Carnival has come back. To me, it means our crisis is nearly over and that things can only get better."

title: Economy Slowed in Late 1995 As Growth Rate Dipped to 0.9%
description: The economy grew at a meager annual pace of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the final three months of 1995 as consumers kept a tight grip on their wallets, Government spending fell and investment by business slackened, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: The Overselling of Carlos Salinas
description: It was 1988 and everyone believed that it was morning again in Mexico. Carlos Salinas, a young, articulate, American-trained economist, had just been elected President of Mexico. He promised a brave new era of privatization, free trade and cordial relations with Washington. The old days of debt crises, money-losing state enterprises and anti-yanqui nationalism would be banished. Surrounded by like-minded technocrats with Ivy League connections, President Salinas would yank Mexico out of Latin America and drag it into the first world.

title: Bridge
description: Computer programs that bid and play bridge are improving, though still far behind their chess counterparts. Dealing with hidden data is a problem for the programmers, as is the psychological element.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Discrimination Pact Approved
description: Approving an agreement for the state to pay $3.7 million to settle discrimination claims by black and female prison guards, United States Magistrate Joel A. Pisano said yesterday the pact would help end "pervasive" discrimination in the state prison system. He scheduled a hearing for May 10 to consider any objections before ruling on final approval. State officials have not admitted wrongdoing in the settlement, but they have agreed to create procedures to handle complaints of racial and sexual discrimination and harassment, the A.P. reported.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Under the Philadelphia's Spell, Beethoven Is Brand New
description: A program by the Philadelphia Orchestra on Thursday night luxuriated in the familiar. Beethoven's Fifth Symphony, the latest installment in the Philadelphia's current Beethoven survey, is music more familiar than any other. George Rochberg's Clarinet Concerto, like so much new music these days, alluded heavily to familiar masterpieces: Mozart's Clarinet Concerto, the "Symphonie Fantastique," Sibelius's Fourth Symphony, "Das Lied von der Erde."

title: Ex-G.I. Arrested on Charges Of Spying for Soviet Union
description: A former Army employee at the National Security Agency, which eavesdrops on communications overseas, was arrested today in Pennsylvania on charges that he spied for the Soviet Union in the mid-1960's.

title: Classic Dance and Race: A Story Still Unfolding
description: The dancers are ranged along ballet barres set up on a ship's promenade. Dressed in practice clothes, their bodies are elegantly erect, feet pointed in the classic ballet curve and eyes staring solemnly into the camera. They might be any American troupe embarking on some slightly exotic tour except that, unlike the stereotype, these dancers are black.

title: If Marriage Is a Contract, It Can Be Broken
description: To the Editor:

title: San Francisco Journal;Night Skaters Claim Streets as Their Own
description: The big old clock in the Ferry Building boomed eight deep chimes.

title: Senator and Gossip Maven Part Friends a Year Later
description: As a power couple, however unlikely, few could match the wattage of Alfonse M. D'Amato, the kingmaking United States Senator, and Claudia Cohen, the millionaire gossip reporter, who announced in a nuzzling news conference a year ago this week that they were in love.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Panel Sought in Rape Claims
description: Exasperated prosecutors said yesterday that they would ask a grand jury to decide whether to bring criminal charges against a woman who recanted an allegation that she had been raped by two inmates at the Union County Jail, then changed her story again and said she had been raped.

title: COMPANY NEWS;3 KLM EXECUTIVES RESIGNING FROM NORTHWEST AIR BOARD
description: Three executives of KLM Royal Dutch Airlines are resigning from the board of the Northwest Airlines Corporation and will be replaced by three independent directors, Northwest said yesterday. Northwest said KLM would designate three people not affiliated with KLM or any other current Northwest stockholder. Northwest said KLM was making this change primarily as a step in "enhancing the independence of Northwest's board." The departing directors are KLM's president, Pieter Bouw; the managing director, Leo van Wijk, and the chief financial officer, Rob Abrahamsen. The two airlines are partners in a marketing alliance and KLM owns 18.8 percent of Northwest.

title: Trek Ended, A Manatee Comes Home
description: Like Neil Armstrong and Edmund Hillary, he journeyed to the outer limits of adventure. Then, he dropped from sight for many weeks, caring not a whit that people were worried about him, and reappeared in Florida to spend the winter pursuing females.

title: Girl Reports Abuse, and Questions Arise
description: A 13-year-old runaway was hospitalized yesterday after she escaped from a Brooklyn apartment where she said she had been imprisoned in a closet for three days, tortured and scalded with boiling water, the police said.

title: The Department of Potholes
description: Like every other New Yorker, I spend a good part of my time getting where I am going. So my ears perked up earlier this month when Mayor Rudolph Giuliani proposed eliminating the Department of Transportation. This was just before the Regional Plan Association, an urban planning group, produced a major report urging the city to modernize its outdated transport system in order to keep the city competitive in the next century.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COX ENTERPRISES IN DEAL WITH DONNELLY MARKETING
description: Cox Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy two direct-mail companies from Donnelly Marketing Inc. for an undisclosed amount. The companies to be acquired are Carol Wright Sales Inc. and Carol Wright Consumer Promotions Inc., which include Val-Pak Direct Marketing Systems Inc. The Carol Wright companies, based in Stamford, Conn., have more than 1,500 employees. Cox, based in Atlanta, is a big media company with interests in newspapers and cable television.

title: Foster Care Is No Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN;Buchanan Vows, if Elected, To Put an End to Abortions
description: Patrick J. Buchanan compared pro-abortion forces to the "evil empire" of Communism today, pledging to devote his Presidency to ending abortions in the country and to be remembered as the "most pro-life President in history."

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Star In Milan Takes On New York
description: Daniele Gatti, the acclaimed Milanese conductor, is an intensely serious musician. When he walked out to conduct Mahler's sprawling Sixth Symphony with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night, he looked somber and bowed stiffly. Only once during the final ovations for this remarkable performance, Mr. Gatti's debut with the orchestra, did he break into a disarming smile: when the players, as a token of respect, remained seated and applauded him along with the audience.

title: The N.E.A. Plays to an Empty House
description: Once again, the National Endowment for the Arts teeters on the tightrope between Congressional opponents and infuriated clients. Its staff and budget trimmed by almost 40 percent, the agency has overhauled its grant-giving process. But the reorganization merely polishes the nozzle of the same frayed fire hose that the agency has aimed at the arts for most of its 31 years.

title: Chirac Reaps Glory, and Grumbling, on French Military Cutbacks
description: President Jacques Chirac, denounced around the world only a month ago for conducting underground nuclear weapons tests in the Pacific, reaped praise today for his decision to phase out the land-based third of the French nuclear deterrent and to stop all further production of weapons-grade fissionable material.

title: POLITICS: NEW YORK;Buchanan Presses Ahead for Full Entry in New York Primary
description: With his campaign gaining steam, Patrick J. Buchanan today pressed ahead to overcome one of the toughest challenges in electoral politics: getting on the ballot in the Republican primary throughout New York State.

title: Albany to Help Upgrade School Furnaces
description: The New York Power Authority has agreed to spend $11 million over the next two years to escort 11 New York City schools into the modern age of heating, replacing their nearly century-old, hand-stoked coal furnaces with natural gas and oil burners, authority officials said yesterday.

title: Samuel Hirsch, Former Drama Editor, 79
description: Samuel Hirsch, a former drama editor of The Boston Herald, died on Feb. 15 at his home in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 79.

title: Iraqi Defectors Killed 3 Days After Returning
description: Two sons-in-law of Saddam Hussein who returned to Iraq this week after defecting to Jordan six months ago have been killed by their relatives, the Iraqi Government said tonight.

title: If Marriage Is a Contract, It Can Be Broken
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.S. to Pay 248 Iranians Who Lost Kin to Missile
description: The United States will pay families of Iranians aboard an Iran Air airliner that was shot down by a United States warship in 1988 but will pay no money to the Iranian Government, the State Department announced on Thursday.

title: If Marriage Is a Contract, It Can Be Broken
description: To the Editor:

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Follow Celebration With Defeat
description: The Islanders, who stopped the Rangers' 24-game home undefeated streak on Thursday night, were stopped by Tampa Bay tonight, losing to the Lightning by 3-2 in overtime.

title: Grim Yeltsin Blames His Government for Russia's Ills
description: Sounding eerily like the Communists he is battling for control of Russia, President Boris N. Yeltsin delivered a somber annual address today that was devoted almost completely to blaming his own Government for the tide of problems that have afflicted the nation since he became its leader.

title: Company Briefs
description: CONMED CORP., Utica, N.Y., a maker and distributor of electrosurgery, heart monitoring and other medical products, purchased most of the assets of New Dimensions in Medicine Inc. for about $32 million.

title: Herve Bazin, 84, Novelist and Critic
description: Herve Bazin, a highly regarded French novelist and for the last two decades the president of the Goncourt Academy, which awards France's most prestigious literary prize, died last Saturday at his home near Angers, the Loire Valley city in which he was born. He was 84.

title: HOCKEY;Samuelsson Facing Suspension by N.H.L.
description: Ulf Samuelsson traveled to Miami with the Rangers yesterday with the intention of playing tonight against the Florida Panthers. It is an important game, for first place in both the Atlantic Division and the Eastern Conference. His availability is up to the National Hockey League, and a decision on a question of suspension is expected before the game.

title: Hypnosis Gains Credence As Influence on the Body;It Helps Control Pain, Fear and Habits
description: When Michael Tracy learned at the age of 15 that he had a form of cancer known as lymphoma, his world seemed to cave in on all sides. His father had just died of brain cancer, so as he dealt with the grief and fears for his own future, he faced a series of dreaded spinal taps, bone-marrow aspirations and chemotherapy treatments that would fill his weeks for the next two years.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Wednesday about "Three Stories of the Honorable Flower" at La Mama in the East Village misstated a credit. The staging was by Alex Alatsis alone; Ute Albrecht designed the sets and costumes.

title: BASKETBALL;Ewing Sits, And Hawks Run Over The Knicks
description: Derek Harper was asked last night what the Knicks need to do in order to close their recent rebounding deficit. He let out a curt laugh. "I have to get 10 rebounds, I guess," the veteran point guard said.

title: Buying of Mutual Funds Slowed in Week
description: The pace of new buying of stock mutual funds slowed in the most recent week, according to AMG Data Services, a research group in Arcata, Calif.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Germans Are Gripped by the Return of Fugitives
description: Germany's most famous fugitive came home today from a Miami jail, looking more like a scared tourist than the wheeler-dealer who fled the country 22 months ago, leaving behind the ruins of a real estate empire and $3.5 billion in bad debt.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Plans to Clarify Ownership of S.A.S.
description: The holding companies for Scandinavian Airlines System are preparing measures to clarify the ownership structure to strengthen S.A.S.'s position in capital markets, the companies said yesterday. The move is a response to criticism that S.A.S.'s ownership is difficult to grasp. It is owned by Denmark's DDL, Norway's DNL and Sweden's ABA, which in turned is owned by SILA. These holding companies are listed on their respective domestic exchanges, but each is 50 percent Government owned.

title: POP REVIEW;Pianist Caresses Melody As a Pop Singer Would
description: The young pianist Jacky Terrasson, who is playing at the Village Vanguard through tomorrow, likes change and hates stasis. He and his trio spend sets juxtaposing all the obvious extremes, loud against soft, fast against slow, all abruptly.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Compaq and Packard Bell Settle 10-Month Legal Feud
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation and Packard Bell Electronics Inc. settled a 10-month legal feud and agreed to drop lawsuits against each other, the judge said today.

title: TRACK AND FIELD;Speed Doesn't Always Pay
description: In this era of $8 million-a-year baseball players and $6 million-a-year football players, there are even million-dollar track and field athletes like Sergei Bubka, Noureddine Morceli, Michael Johnson, Carl Lewis and Jackie Joyner-Kersee. And there are also athletes like Alisa Harvey Hill who struggle to get any kind of financial support.

title: Family Violence Has No Religious Exemptions
description: To the Editor:

title: ALBANY'S TAX CUT FACING CHALLENGE
description: With the state facing its potentially worst fiscal crisis in years, a growing number of labor leaders, municipal officials and Democratic legislators are openly advocating what was once considered politically unthinkable: delaying or scaling back an income-tax cut scheduled to take effect in just five weeks.

title: POLITICS;In Their Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Sex Offenders Law Prompts Privacy Debate in New York
description: On Jan. 29, with his wife of 20 years by his side, Joseph Rossillo walked into the Westchester County Court House, prepared to be sentenced for the statutory rape of a 16-year-old relative in 1991.

title: Horse Racing;Cigar's Foot Is on the Mend
description: Cigar began the road to an uncertain recovery today, the abscess in his right front foot healing but the impact on his racing schedule still unknown. But he was surrounded at Gulfstream Park by the bustle of 3-year-old horses on the road to the Kentucky Derby, with Unbridled's Song ranked as the 8-5 choice to outrun nine other colts in the 50th running of the Fountain of Youth Stakes on Saturday.

title: BASKETBALL;Manhattan Stays Alive By Defeating Niagara
description: The season has been a learning process for Manhattan.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Jobless Rate Exceeds Average
description: New Jersey lost thousands of jobs last month as the state's unemployment rate remained above the national average, suggesting continued sluggishness in the economy, according to data released yesterday. Using a new method to estimate unemployment figures, New Jersey's joblessness rate was 6.5 percent in January. Officials also revised the December rate to 6.6 percent, from 7.3 percent, easing concerns that a spike in unemployment had signaled a sudden downturn. [Page 1.]

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Nuclear Reactor Stays Closed
description: The 1,100-megawatt Salem I nuclear reactor in southern New Jersey will remain shut indefinitely because of microscopic cracks in steam generators at the plant, which has been out of service since May, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company said yesterday.

title: Rate Jitters Drive Down Bond Prices
description: Bond investors seemed to catch another case of interest rate jitters yesterday, sparking a selloff that sent prices lower and yields sharply higher.

title: BASEBALL;Rogers Happy to Stay Far From the Spotlight
description: For a pitcher who signed a $20 million free-agent contract and is expected to produce major dividends in a stressful New York scene that is foreign to him, Kenny Rogers has blended in rather anonymously so far. With Dwight Gooden and David Cone in the Yankee lockers to his right and John Wetteland and Andy Pettitte to his left, Rogers has not been the focus that he eventually could be.

title: Roger Bowen, 63, Actor and Novelist
description: Roger Bowen, a writer and actor who played the high-living, foggy-minded Col. Henry Blake in the movie "M*A*S*H" and who was a founder of the Second City Theater in Chicago, died on Feb. 16 while vacationing in Marathon, Fla. He was 63 and lived in Manhattan.

title: POLITICS;David Duke Trying for Senate as Republican
description: David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader who made national headlines in 1991 with his campaign for governor of Louisiana, will run this year for the United States Senate as a Republican.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Oil Prices Drop on Suggestion Iraq May Accept Export Terms
description: Crude oil prices tumbled on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, suggested that Iraq had implicitly accepted the terms of a proposal that would allow it to export oil for the first time in nearly six years.

title: INSIDE
description: Cold War Spy Case

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Arakis Stymied In Sudan Plans
description: The Arakis Energy Corporation said today that it had terminated its arrangement with the Los Angeles businessman Walid al-Omar and his company, Rosscape A.I.D., for financing a proposed Sudan oil pipeline project.

title: William Hogan, 82, A Literary Editor
description: William Hogan, literary editor of The San Francisco Chronicle for 27 years, died on Wednesday at Kaiser Hospital in San Rafael, Calif. He was 82.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF APPAREL DESIGNER, MOSSIMO, CLIMB SHARPLY
description: The stock of the apparel designer Mossimo Inc. closed sharply above its offering price yesterday in its first day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The company, a designer of jeans, shorts and other beach wear, based in Irvine, Calif., has long been hot among teen-age boys and the company will introduce a line of girls' clothes this fall.The three-million-share offering was priced at $18, well above the expected range of $14 to $16 a share. The stock closed at $25 after almost 3.7 million shares were traded, some of them more than once.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Russia and De Beers Sign Diamond Deal
description: Russia signed a diamond marketing agreement yesterday with De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. of South Africa that paves the way for a three-year sales deal, the two sides said. The agreement gives Russia a significantly larger quota for direct exports of uncut stones, according to a senior official at Russia's diamond exporting company.

title: HIGH SCHOOL REPORT
description: A Grand Time in Norwich

title: 2 More Officers Dismissed For Washington Partying
description: The New York City police officer whose drunken exhibitionism in Washington became a national symbol of misconduct within the Police Department has been dismissed from the force, police officials said yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EDMARK STOCK IS HURT BY OUTLOOK ON EARNINGS
description: The stock of the Edmark Corporation, a software maker, fell 15 percent yesterday after the company said it expected second-half results to come in below analysts' expectations. The stock lost $6.25, to $33, in Nasdaq trading. The company, based in Redmond, Wash., said on Thursday that its earnings would be hurt by a slowdown in retailer reorders for its multimedia software products. Edmark said it expected to incur an unspecified operating loss in the third quarter ending March 31 on revenues of $5.5 million to $6 million. A survey by I/B/E/S, which tracks Wall Street analysts, said it expected the company to report a profit of 4 cents a share for the quarter.

title: Latin Nations At U.N. Insist China Change Stand on Haiti
description: Angered by Chinese efforts to cut back or stall the extension of a United Nations peacekeeping mission in Haiti because of its relations with Taiwan, Latin American and Caribbean nations today demanded immediate Security Council action and a rejection of China's demands.

title: Judge Orders Curfew For Stabbing Suspect
description: A Federal judge ordered a curfew yesterday for Lemrick Nelson Jr., who is awaiting trial on charges of violating the civil rights of a Hasidic scholar who was stabbed to death during racial violence in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, in 1991.

title: Silicon Graphics May Buy Cray Research
description: Silicon Graphics Inc. said late today that it planned to meet with analysts and hold a news conference Monday morning in New York to make a "major strategic announcement."

title: Agency Is Both Fiscal Watchdog and Lame Duck
description: Douglas A. Criscitello sits in a dingy, barren, borrowed office in the New York City Municipal Building. He has, for the moment, little more than a telephone, a desk and a stack of resumes, but he is presiding over the birth of a municipal agency that two mayors and most of the city's other elected officials have been trying for six years to kill.

title: About New York;Trading Badge To Seek Justice Before the Bar
description: ROBERT KNIGHTLY used to be a cop. Now he's a Legal Aid lawyer.

title: Alexander on the Poor
description: Lamar Alexander says he wants to rely on private charities, not government, to help the poor, but many of those charities are alarmed.

title: TENNIS;Capriati Looking to the Future After Her Loss in the Quarterfinals
description: The first stage of Jennifer Capriati's second comeback ended today in the quarterfinals of the Faber Grand Prix in three very competitive sets against Jana Novotna. To hear Capriati tell it, there will definitely be more tennis to come.

title: Computers or No, Reduce Nuclear Arsenals
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;GREAT WESTERN CAPITAL SELLS RETAIL SITES PORTFOLIO
description: The Great Western Capital Corporation sold a retail portfolio of 54 sites to the Franchise Finance Corporation of America for $37 million, according to Jones Lang Wootton U.S.A., a real estate advisory firm that managed the sale. The portfolio includes 53 fast-food restaurants, including Wendy's, Kentucky Fried Chicken and Taco Bell outlets. The properties were built about 12 years ago. Great Western Capital is a unit of the Great Western Financial Corporation, a savings and loan holding company based in Chatsworth, Calif. Franchise Finance is a real estate investment trust based in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Wilander Speaks Out
description: MATS WILANDER of Sweden, in his first interview since allegations surfaced that he used cocaine during last year's French Open, insisted yesterday that he has "never used illegal drugs."

title: The Social Fabric
description: For daytime drama and evening shade: dresses in silk, in a variety of weaves, always correct.

title: Another Navy Jet Crashes
description: A Navy jet crashed into the oceaqn during a carrier exercise today, killing one crew member and injuring two others, the Navy said. A fourth crew member was missing.

title: Changing Partners
description: Labor relations have gone topsy-turvy for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. He finds himself clashing with two powerful unions -- for the police and teachers -- that were expected to be friendly to him, while becoming surprisingly amicable with the largest municipal workers' union, which was expected to be a fierce adversary.

title: Portrait Of a Gifted Child
description: IT is a biting-cold Friday morning in a small, overheated apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. Eight-year-old Sheria Mattis pulls on a pair of blue jeans that she decorated the night before with multicolored Magic Markers and neon Band-Aids. On Fridays, her mother lets her wear whatever she wants to school.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A

title: Today It's Irrelevant That Ike Was Liked
description: To the Editor:

title: 60 Miles to Baton Rouge: A Tiny Band of Marchers
description: Nathan Parker is a walking man. The other day he quick-stepped ahead of a tiny band of marchers, leading them around a long, green curve on the River Road in this little town northwest of New Orleans. The breeze from the Mississippi kissed his face as the words of the marchers' old civil rights spirituals drifted up against his back, pushing him toward Baton Rouge.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MY MAP BOOK Written and illustrated by Sara Fanelli. Unpaged. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $14.95. (Ages 5 to 8) MAPS in their most common form, as representations of actual physical distances and dimensions, orient us by manageably defining spatial relationships. Another kind of map, often a pedagogical tool, uses space as a metaphor within which to describe things that are less tangible. Through "mapping" family relationships, favorite activities or emotions, children can articulate aspects of themselves that are central to their identity, but are by nature elusive. Both kinds interest Sara Fanelli, who has created a bright, attractive picture book of maps representing important things in the life of one fictional child.

title: WEDDINGS;Rachel Greenman, Michael Weiss
description: Rachel Miriam Greenman, a daughter of Carol and Robert Greenman of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Michael Jordan Weiss, the son of Rochelle Weiss of St. Louis and the late Richard S. Weiss. Rabbi William Dreskin performed the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: REPRODUCTION CARPETS

title: Experts Fault U.S. on Safety Rules for Railroads
description: Federal and independent safety experts say four serious train wrecks this month, including collisions in Silver Spring, Md., and Jersey City that killed a total of 14 people, could have been prevented if rules and standards they have advocated for years had been adopted by the Government.

title: JAMES IS A GIRL
description: The assertion on your cover that James King lost her youth is beguiling. American adults, despite the fact that few would choose to repeat adolescence, still seem captivated by the myth of teen-age life as a carefree time.

title: BOOKEND;His Own Best Construction
description: During the nearly two decades I knew Harold Brodkey, he bore a semiremarkable resemblance to Sean Connery in "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade." Harold certainly remarked it: he told me on more than one occasion that Connery had "stolen" his appearance and his very character in playing that role. "Oh, Harold," I said when I first heard this complaint. I believe that Harold himself often didn't know whether he was being serious or figurative when he said such things. In any case, he was so handsome and distinctive looking that I sometimes found myself searching my mind for who it was he really resembled -- what star or genius -- only to recognize that the personage I was trying to remember wasn't anyone like Sean Connery or Jimmy Stewart but was Harold Brodkey, a one and only if ever there was one.

title: Q & A
description: Condo Fee For 'Doing Nothing'

title: College Students Protest Latest Switch for a Polling Place
description: STUDENTS who attend Purchase College have had a long and turbulent history when it comes to voting on campus. Students, who in the 1980's brought a successful lawsuit against the County Board of Elections to gain the right to use their college address to vote, have seen their polling place moved on and off campus twice over the last decade.

title: Hispanic Population Making Inroads on the South Fork
description: FIVE years ago a young man from Mexico City who identified himself as Juan left his family and illegally crossed the border to the United States. With no prospects of earning a living and with a wife and two children to feed, he hoped to find a better life here.

title: JAMES IS A GIRL
description: It jars me to see a 16-year-old girl smoking. To have her on the cover of The New York Times Magazine is disgraceful. Girls that age want role models, and to show one who has dropped out of school, drinks beer and coughs violently, no doubt as a result of cigarettes, seems to be the wrong way to go.

title: BASEBALL;Martinez Is Well Aware of Shoes He Fills
description: Tino Martinez has not spoken to Don Mattingly since the Yankees made him their next first baseman. But Jim Krivacs, the agent for both players, told Martinez that Mattingly, who elected not to play this season, applauded seeing him as the new first baseman. Martinez hopes to finally chat with Mattingly this week when the team owner, George Steinbrenner, plays host to a golf tournament near the team's spring camp.

title: The Theft of Identities: A Long and Winding Road
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: ARIZONA;Rare Chance In a Contest Too Close To Predict
description: Some of the confusion left by the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary might be cleared up on Tuesday here when Arizona Republicans, seldom important players in the nominating game in the past, get a chance to render judgment on the candidates.

title: AND THEN THERE WAS FRANK
description: Representative Barney Frank criticizes the Human Rights Campaign's contribution to the National Republican Campaign Committee, calling it "stupid" and suggesting that this money will go to Dick Armey and Newt Gingrich and their anti-gay agenda ("And Then There Was Frank," by Claudia Dreifus, Feb. 4).

title: February 18-24;An Oil Spill Evokes An Earlier Disaster
description: The words Exxon Valdez have become a synonym for environmental disaster. Just say the name of the huge tanker and appalling images of oil-soaked birds rush to mind.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 5 about restaurants in and around Cape Town misstated the address of Cape Manna. A reader's letter dated Feb. 7 points out that it is 34 Napier Street, not 35.

title: Basketball Star Who Scores on Court and Tests
description: Elton Brand, the 6-foot-8, 245-pound junior center for the Peekskill High School basketball team, is one of those rare double threats. On the court, when he catches the ball near the basket, he is virtually unstoppable. And in the classroom, where so many of his basketball peers come up short, Elton maintains an 89 average in Regents-level and honors courses.

title: The Mayor and the Unions: One Ex-Foe Friendly; Two Ex-Friends Hostile
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has suddenly found his world of labor relations turned upside down as he clashes with two powerful unions -- police and teachers -- that were expected to be friendly to him, while becoming surprisingly friendly with the largest municipal workers' union, which was expected to be a fierce adversary.

title: POLITICS: SOUTH CAROLINA;Dole Soldiers Are Set For Buchanan Brigade
description: The South Carolina Presidential primary looms a week away as a particularly redoubtable castle for Patrick J. Buchanan's self-proclaimed peasants to storm. The well-financed legions of the Republican state machine, loyal to Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, are defending the primary as the critical gateway to a string of primaries that quickly follow across the South.

title: ON THE STREET;Staying Dry With Art's Help
description: The ubiquitous art umbrella is a welcome relief these rainy, late winter days. There's nothing like a pretty Renoir picture (left) or the charm of Degas's dancers (right) or the wistful Monet waterlilies (bottom left), with their luscious Impressionist colorings and nostalgic French imagery. The umbrella is a colorful antidote to the deluge of black minimalist clothes devoid of bright accessories that are the fashion of today.

title: Anne Frank: The Girl and the Icon
description: A COUPLE IN FORMAL WEDDING CLOTHES are sweeping joyfully out of a door in Amsterdam, in 1941, heading toward a waiting car. The camera then pans upward to show that many residents of the housing project are also taking pleasure in the sight of young love. For a fleeting instant, the film catches a glimpse of a 12-year-old girl leaning, almost dangerously, out a third-floor window, smiling down at the couple. It is a face now familiar from a dozen photographs -- the dark, wide eyes, the flip of dark hair, the barely contained enthusiasm. Then we see her suddenly turn inside to say something, perhaps responding to the stern call of a mother who doesn't want her to fall, or else to summon her more serious sister to share a glimpse of hope and love as Holland stands on the brink of hardship and horror. It is the only actual movie image we have of Anne Frank.

title: Westchester Q&A: Judith Rovenger;Introducing Children to the Joy of Books
description: WHEN it comes to children's books, there is much more beyond the popular, prodigious "Goosebumps" series by R. L. Stein, but getting some children to explore other options can sometimes be a challenge for parents and librarians.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: SCHOOL'S OUT The Impact of Gay and Lesbian Issues on America's Schools. By Dan Woog. Alyson Publications, paper, $11.95.

title: Our Towns;City's Shelter, Her Backyard
description: SUSAN McCABE sits in the kitchen of her immaculate split-level with her heavy weapons, two shoebox-size file boxes.

title: Amateur Glory
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: YOUR TAXES;Tax Preparers Aren't Ruffled by Proposals for an Overhaul
description: THE reports of our death are greatly exaggerated," said Ozzie Wenich, a spokesman for H & R Block, the nation's largest tax preparation service, responding to calls along the campaign trail to simplify the nation's income tax system, even allowing taxpayers to file postcard-size returns.

title: County's Philharmonic Adds Education Ideas
description: EACH winter and spring for the last 12 years, thousands of third, fourth and fifth graders have learned from the Westchester Philharmonic how music reflects the life and times of composers, from Bach's day to our own. Now the orchestra is expanding its three-month-long education program from Westchester County to Long Island, and taking along its successful mix of musicians' visits to classrooms, a curriculum guide for teachers and a live concert.

title: School Board vs. Bond Opponents
description: IN September 1992 the Commack School District sent fliers asking residents to vote on an $11.7 million bond issue to repair and renovate schools. Almost immediately, a taxpayers' group, contending that the mailing was biased in favor of the bond issue, went to court to try to stop the vote.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: QUEENS UPDATE
description: Two months after the city failed to come up with an alternate site for the Elmhurst Jackson Heights Senior Center, at 87-11 Whitney Avenue, the center's landlord has filed a lawsuit seeking its eviction.

title: YOUR TAXES;In Confusion Over Tax Law, Don't Overlook Some Changes
description: WITH the nation's tax rules in seemingly constant flux, even tax professionals are occasionally tripped up. Ask Nadine Gordon Lee, a partner with Ernst & Young, the Big Six accounting firm in New York.

title: Q and A
description: Touring German Cathedrals

title: An American Tragedy
description: THE TRIALS OF MARIA BARBELLA The True Story of a 19th Century Crime of Passion. By Idanna Pucci. Translated by Stefania Fumo. Illustrated. 324 pp. New York: Four Walls Eight Windows. $22.
