title: Glenn Parker, 40, Accompanist for Singers
description: Glenn Parker, a pianist who accompanied singers and directed the accompanying and coaching program at Westminster Choir College in Princeton, N.J., died on Feb. 15 at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 40 and lived in Manhattan.

title: When British Ministers Mislead
description: An official inquiry into British arms sales to Iraq in the 1980's has concluded that two members of John Major's Cabinet -- William Waldegrave, the chief secretary to the Treasury, and Sir Nicholas Lyell, the Attorney General -- misled Parliament, the public and the courts while serving the Government of Margaret Thatcher. Tomorrow, Parliament opens debate on what should be done. For the health of British democracy, both men should step down.

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;Posters That Once Stirred a Nation
description: Long before Glasnost, Merrill C. Berman, a New York investor, had pioneered in the collecting of Soviet propaganda posters. In 1975, when such posters were still considered anathema in the West, he ignored the advice of a museum curator who, he says, told him to "focus on Russian film posters and forget the political ones."

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: MIDWOOD;Prokofiev and Vivaldi, for Children
description: YOU probably know the music and maybe you remember the story: about Peter (portrayed by all the strings in the orchestra) who lassoes the nasty wolf (whose motif is three French horns) who swallowed the duck (oboe) while the cat (clarinet) and bird (flute) took shelter in a tree.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: PARK SLOPE Battles, Mansions And Preservation

title: Murderers' Row
description: Intensity By Dean Koontz. 308 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday with an article about automatic teller machines misstated a Citibank provision for the use of its machines. Customers with Citibank accounts pay no fee.

title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 11, about the effect of spurned takeover bids on the stock price of the target companies, referred incorrectly to a stock split by Time Warner Inc. in 1992. The stock had a 4-for-1 split, in which four shares replaced each existing share. It was not a 1-for-4 reverse split.

title: Sunday February 25, 1996;QUESTIONS FOR: John Cusack
description: The 29-year-old actor, writer and producer (film and stage) is starring in "City Hall," a new movie about New York politics.

title: New Releases
description: WALLACE RONEY: 'THE WALLACE RONEY QUINTET' Warner Brothers

title: Swing Shift
description: Spring's jazzy new prints, when properly mismatched, can lighten any woman's load.

title: SPENDING IT;Lordship Has Its Price: Blue-Chip Bids for Blueblood Titles
description: WHEN Victor Podd decided to rustle up some new business three years ago for Powertex Inc., his packaging company, he didn't join an association or double his advertising. Instead, he wrote a $30,000 check to the Manorial Society of Great Britain and became the Baron of Newcastle, buying a 900-year-old title put on the block by an aristocrat in need of quick cash.

title: SPITFIRE GRILL';Audiences Are Not Stupid
description: To the Editor:

title: Designing Creature
description: NANCY LANCASTER Her Life, Her World, Her Art. By Robert Becker. Illustrated. 425 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $40.

title: Cholesterol Filter Backed
description: Patients with severely high cholesterol who cannot be helped by low-fat diets or drugs now have a new option: getting the fat literally filtered out of their blood. The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the Liposorber, which cleanses the blood of cholesterol, much like kidney dialysis. But the machine is made by Kaneka America Corporation of New York.

title: PERSPECTIVES;The Spot Builder Makes a Comeback in Queens
description: EVERYTHING has come down -- prices, profit margins, everything," said Leo D. Fakler, an architect in Fresh Meadows, Queens, who for years has been designing houses for Queens builders.

title: THE NIGHT;New Year's Serenity And Chaos
description: WHILE Chinese New Year celebrations were turning the streets of Chinatown into a sonic war zone on Feb. 19, Tibet House, a New York organization that supports the preservation of Tibet's religious and cultural heritage, was celebrating the Tibetan New Year with a benefit concert at Carnegie Hall.

title: Huge Chemical Arms Plant Near Completion in Libya, U.S. Says
description: Libya is close to completing the world's largest underground chemical weapons plant in a hollowed-out mountain 40 miles southeast of Tripoli, United States intelligence services say.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;Finding a Doctor While Away
description: SAFEGUARDING one's health away from home -- or just surviving emergencies -- has created a "growth area" in medicine. Two organizations have recently begun medical networks in the United States that will send a local doctor to your hotel if you become ill while traveling. Others have set up ways to provide your medical records to a physician caring for you while you are away. These supplement the efforts of two older groups, Medic Alert and the International Association for Medical Assistance to Travelers, a nonprofit group that pioneered the field of travel health.

title: February 18-24;Welcome Home, Son-in-Law
description: Six months after fleeing Iraq in a defection celebrated by the West, the son-in-law of Saddam Hussein turned around last week and went home, accompanied by his brother and their wives, both daughters of the Iraqi leader.

title: Horse Racing;Unbridled's Song Upset By a 143-1 Long Shot
description: Melodrama, confusion and sensationally long odds were thrown into the Kentucky Derby picture today when a 143-1 moon shot named Built for Pleasure won the Fountain of Youth Stakes by a neck over Unbridled's Song, widely ranked as the best 3-year-old in the country.

title: World News Briefs;Oil Pumping Begins On Tanker Off Wales
description: An operation to pump out oil from a tanker that ran aground off the coast of Wales finally began today, but wildlife groups said the 65,000 tons of oil spilled from the vessel was causing environmental disaster.

title: BACKTALK;Knee Lifts, Laughter and a Better Life
description: On Jan. 15, Fay Gallant, one of my trainee-athletes, had her 92d birthday, all of which had been celebrated in the United States except her first, which had been in Czarist Russia.

title: La Forza del Destino': Verdi at His Gloomiest And, So, Most Verdian
description: If there is such a thing as the "most Verdian" of Verdi's operas -- Verdi being, perhaps, the gloomiest of great opera composers -- a good case can be made for "La Forza del Destino." This dark, sweeping epic, which once held a place of honor in the Metropolitan Opera repertory, returns for the first time since 1984 on Thursday, in a new production directed by Giancarlo del Monaco and featuring Sharon Sweet, Placido Domingo and Vladimir Chernov.

title: Sunday February 25, 1996: HOT PROPERTY;The Taos Land Grab
description: Every town worth its picture postcard seems to be promoting a film festival, but the Taos Talking Picture Festival in April has come up with a lure that separates it from the scenic crowd: first prize is five acres of New Mexico real estate.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 12 about Canton, Ohio, misstated President William McKinley's connection with the city. Mr. McKinley was accepted to the Ohio bar in 1867 and began his law practice and political career in Canton. His birthplace, however, was Niles, Ohio.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: HOPE By Len Deighton. HarperCollins, $24.

title: Jackie Was Here
description: DURING HER FAMOUS TELEVISED WHITE House tour in 1962, Jacqueline Kennedy breathlessly recounted that Abraham Lincoln once grew upset with his wife over how much she paid for a rug. Jackie herself was clearly entranced with extravagant purchases, and with the telling anecdote behind the ordinary object. She devoted her own time as First Lady to amassing a huge collection of such artifacts -- each, presumably, with its own anecdotal richness.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Phillips Leaves White Sox Camp
description: Chicago White Sox left fielder TONY PHILLIPS left training camp yesterday in Sarasota, Fla., and returned to his home in Scottsdale, Ariz., to attend to undisclosed family matters. Phillips, who signed to a two-year, $3.6 million free-agent contract after playing for the California Angels last season, was expected to return tomorrow or Tuesday.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;Down to the Sea with Smollet and Miss Piggy
description: Beautiful Girls Timothy Hutton, Matt Dillon, Rosie O'Donnell, Uma Thurman, Natalie Portman Directed by Ted Demme R 117 minutes

title: YOUR TAXES;Outlook Clouded on a Capital Gains Rate Cut
description: AS taxpayers prepare their 1995 returns and do tax planning for 1996, no area is more clouded than capital gains. The rate may or may not drop, and if it does, the drop could be effective in 1995, or maybe in 1996.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;Down to the Sea with Smollet and Miss Piggy
description: Muppet Treasure Island Tim Curry, Kevin Bishop, Kermit the Frog, Miss Piggy Directed by Brian Henson G 99 minutes

title: Marathon Man of the Atlanta Games
description: FORGET about the Renaissance. Never mind the Industrial Revolution or the founding of the world's great religions. "The Atlanta Olympic Games," Billy Payne booms out to his Chamber of Commerce dinner audience in Charlotte, N.C., "will be the greatest peacetime event in history."

title: The Method of a Neo-Nazi Mogul
description: Most white supremacists are, by nature, nostalgic and would rather be living deep in the Aryan past. Not George Burdi. He is a racist from the future, and he is impatient for it to arrive.

title: The View From: Irvington;A New Form of Gambling From the Lottery Comes to Town
description: IT was a chilly Saturday night, and Jim Brennan was at his favorite neighborhood bar and grill enjoying a glass of beer, an order of french fries. And a bit of gambling. Mr. Brennan, a social studies teacher, lives next door to the Broadway Grill here, one of those friendly taverns that draw people who have known each other since high school. A few months ago they added a new element to the mix of spirits, inexpensive food and genial customers: Quick Draw.

title: Indonesia Quake Toll Rises
description: The death toll in the earthquake that devastated remote islands off New Guinea a week ago rose to 105 today as three more bodies were found.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: A YEAR IN NEW YORK By Elisha Cooper. City & Company, 22 West 23d Street, New York, N.Y. 10010, $20.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND;Meet the Host
description: THE only thing missing was a marching band. Wedged instrument to instrument outside a cramped 14-by-18-foot television studio were a rock-and-roll band, a classical ensemble, a folk singer and one guitar-strumming aria-to-Allman-Brothers television host.

title: The Decay of Cinema
description: CINEMA'S 100 YEARS SEEM TO HAVE THE SHAPE OF A LIFE cycle: an inevitable birth, the steady accumulation of glories and the onset in the last decade of an ignominious, irreversible decline. It's not that you can't look forward anymore to new films that you can admire. But such films not only have to be exceptions -- that's true of great achievements in any art. They have to be actual violations of the norms and practices that now govern movie making everywhere in the capitalist and would-be capitalist world -- which is to say, everywhere. And ordinary films, films made purely for entertainment (that is, commercial) purposes, are astonishingly witless; the vast majority fail resoundingly to appeal to their cynically targeted audiences. While the point of a great film is now, more than ever, to be a one-of-a-kind achievement, the commercial cinema has settled for a policy of bloated, derivative film-making, a brazen combinatory or recombinatory art, in the hope of reproducing past successes. Cinema, once heralded as the art of the 20th century, seems now, as the century closes numerically, to be a decadent art.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE LEGEND OF THE BAREFOOT MAILMAN By John Henry Fleming. Faber & Faber, $21.95.

title: Details;A Twist of Lime
description: What goes best with turquoise dress? Shoes in this season's new neutral.

title: Now, the Color Purple Has Wheels
description: BLAME it on Barney, the ubiquitous purple dinosaur, or blame it on nostalgia for the psychedelic '70's. But these days, more and more new cars are painted purple.

title: Stamford's W.W.II Veterans Remembered
description: THOUGH World War II had been over for almost two decades, Tony Pavia became fascinated with it and its effect on his hometown while growing up in Stamford in the 1960's. His father had served in the Pacific as a Chief Petty Officer in the Navy, and, although the elder Mr. Pavia seldom talked about it, most of his friends were also World War II veterans. Young Tony would occasionally hear them discuss the war among themselves.

title: Frederick Strong, Retired Judge, 93
description: Frederick Longfellow Strong, a former New York City judge who retired in 1972 after 30 years on the bench, died on Feb. 17 in Bangor, Me. Mr. Strong, a resident of the Upper East Side of Manhattan until three years ago, was 93 and lived in Bangor and Roque Bluffs, Me., the family's summer home.

title: Local Color
description: On billboards and posters Caludia Schiffer, Christy Turlington and other celebrity models preside over Times Square like pagan goodesses or local saints whose images in ancient times served as protection from all manner of afflictions and calamities. Their beauty is general, if not universal: we recognize in their features the regularity, the symmetry and proportions that describe some age-old ideal. Meanwhile, under their impressive gaze, on the sidewalks below, women come and go - real women whose beauty is particular and, in some respects, even more arresting because it violates the very rules that the model's perfection upholds.

title: INVESTING IT;Investors in '900' Lines Feeling Disconnected
description: WHEN she got the phone call a year ago, Phyllis Riggle of Ojai, Calif., was thoroughly fed up with scant returns on investments like money market funds. Yet Ms. Riggle, who sells real estate, wanted a relatively hassle-free place to park her money.

title: Limiting Teen-Age Access to Cigarettes
description: EVAN KENNEDY started smoking when he was 12 years old. All his friends smoked; it seemed like the cool thing to do.

title: ART VIEW;A Window on the World of Mansions and Mastiffs
description: There is in Britain a very large collection of paintings that are held, as are the paintings in the National Gallery in London, in trust for the nation. The paintings in question can in fact be thought of as an annex, and quite often as an alternative, to the National Gallery.

title: Negative Campaign Goes to Trial in Maryland
description: Political candidates have seldom sought vengeance in court for their campaign wounds, but that may be changing. A trial under way here might demonstrate how complaints about negative political campaigning will be resolved in the future.

title: The Nile in High Style
description: AT some point 18 months ago, while I was recovering from cancer surgery, I told my wife, Margaret, that if I survived we ought to spend the rest of our lives doing just what we wanted to. I would give up working and commuting, we would spend more time together, I would go to cooking school and learn how to make Chinese food, Vietnamese, Thai. I sought further for the most exotic of dreams: We would go down the Nile together!

Sunday February 25, 1996: TOBACCO ROAD;Turning Over A New Leaf

But with American smokers increasingly kicking their habit and competition from third-world growers chipping away at foreign markets, farmers have long wished there was something to do with tobacco other than chew, smoke or snort it.

Thanks in part to the advice and encouragement she found at a shelter for mentally ill homeless women run by the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, Ms. Bowman managed to get permanent housing, reunite with her 8-year-old daughter and enroll in a photography course at Parsons School of Design.

Another physician's diagnosis had been inconclusive: an abscess or tumor on the brain; perhaps an acute infection. And though that doctor had not said so, she had been sent home to die.

title: JAMES IS A GIRL
description: The more important 90's story here is about parent abdication, not about image and beauty. I don't know where her father is, but James's mother seems not to question her daughter's right and ability to make important life decisions for herself.

title: WEDDINGS;Julie M. Dowden, L.B. Salander
description: Julie Michele Dowden, the director of the New York office of CARE, the international relief and development organization, was married yesterday to Lawrence Bruce Salander, the president of Salander-O'Reilly Galleries in New York. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, the dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Harvard Club in New York.

title: Variable Rate
description: To the Editor: I read with interest a letter to the editor Jan. 14 from Victor Lopez of Hyatt Hotels. He said: "Hyatt Hotels Corporation policy is always to quote the same rates in inquiries made to either the hotel or our central reservation office. Room rates are set at the local hotel and then entered into hotel and central reservation computers simultaneously." This strikes me as ludicrous.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;Focus on Weston
description: Fascination with Edward Weston's tangled personal life, and especially his affair with Tina Modotti, the Italian revolutionary whose own photos now fetch record prices, has threatened to obscure his achievements as a photographer. But the beautiful and thoughtful EDWARD WESTON: Forms of Passion (Abrams, $65) brings the emphasis back where it belongs, to his carefully wrought, searingly direct images. Drawn from two major archives of Weston material -- those of the Center for Creative Photography in Tucson, Ariz., and the Lane Collection at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts -- this lavishly produced book offers a diverse selection of images. These range from the soft-focus pictorialist images of the 1910's that first made Weston's reputation to the pristine close-ups of natural objects of the 1920's and 30's in which he sought to bring out the abstract forms underlying reality. The book closes with the Surrealist-inspired landscapes and somber, death-tinged photographs he made at the end of his career. Essays by leading photographic historians (including Terence Pitts and Trudy Wilner Stack of the Center for Creative Photography and Gilles Mora, a French historian of photography, who edited the book) pay special attention to the interaction between his life and his art, particularly his early work as a portraitist, his trip to Mexico with Modotti and the painful last years before his death at the age of 71 in 1958. The real strength of the book, though, lies in the wealth of little-known images it presents alongside such iconic works as Weston's close-ups of peppers, seashells and cypress roots. Charles Hagen

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: JUDAICA;An Ethnic Grand Tour
description: The second edition of "A Travel Guide to Jewish Europe" (Pelican Publishing, $18.95), with new chapters on the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary and Slovakia, was recently published. The author, Ben G. Frank, guides readers to the historic sites that survived the Nazis and World War II, as well as listing kosher restaurants and Jewish neighborhoods.

title: Correction
description: A report in the "Sunday" pages on Feb. 4 included erroneous data from the Farmer's Almanac about occurrences of full moons. The last month with no full moon was February 1980, not February 1866. The next month without a full moon will be February 1999, not some month 2.5 million years from now. The report also misstated the times of sunset and moonrise in New York on Feb. 4. They were 5:16 and 5:38 respectively; 5:01 and 5:24 were the correct times in Boston.

title: THE WORLD;Neighbors Knock. Germany Makes Them Wait.
description: FOR centuries, Central Europe was caught between, and fought over by, outsiders like Russians and Germans. The Poles, the Czechs, the Balkan Slavs, all lived in a vacuum that one or another great power seemed always destined to fill.

title: POLITICS: REGISTRATION;Florida May Take Motor Voter Step Further
description: A proposal under consideration by state lawmakers would allow Florida's two million college students to register to vote when they register for classes. The idea is to spur political interest and participation by one of the most electorally apathetic groups of voting-age Americans.

title: YOUR TAXES;Behind the Gains, Unhappy People
description: TO understand the effect the budget impasse in Washington is having on taxpayers, one need look no further than Washington, Mo., where, the Washington Savings Bank, 99 percent locally owned, mostly by farmers and retirees, sold out to a large St. Louis-based bank last November. Believing that Republican members of Congress would slash capital gains tax rates for 1995, the bank's directors took cash for their assets.

title: In the Region: Long Island;Planners Ponder 2,900-Acre Northrop Grumman Site
description: NORTHROP GRUMMAN'S departure on Feb. 14 from its 2,900-acre airport-industrial complex in Calverton left vacant a high-potential development tract.

description: ART OBJECTS Essays on Ecstasy and Effrontery. By Jeanette Winterson. Knopf, $21.

The Minutemen became the last major college basketball team to lose today when George Washington controlled every aspect of the game and held off a loud but ineffective UMass rally in an 86-76 victory.

Some of her friends had babies, too, and it was easy to shove bottles in their mouths to keep them quiet rather than to pay them much attention. What worked best, her friends told her, was to mix cereal into the formula and poke a bigger hole in the rubber nipple to help it flow.

title: Defining Evil
description: A HISTORY OF FASCISM, 1914-1945 By Stanley G. Payne. Illustrated. 613 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. $39.95. IS fascism a thing of the past? The question has both a theoretical and a practical interest. On the theoretical side we are curious whether fascist movements and regimes are so linked to the conditions of Europe between the world wars that nothing having their peculiar combination of features can be found in other historical contexts -- such as our own. Practically, we are anxious about the future of liberal democracy. We wonder if the increase in economic insecurity that affects almost all of us -- but particularly the middle classes, for whom it remains in some ways a novel experience -- may not provoke a revival of movements of the kind that swept away fragile democracies in the 1930's. Looking at the world around us, it seems that powerful fascist movements do belong to the interwar period and pose no major danger to us now. Except perhaps for Russia, where Vladimir Zhirinovsky's bizarrely misnamed Liberal Democratic Party has evoked comparisons with Hitler's National Socialists in Weimar Germany, no democratic state faces anything that could reasonably be described as a fascist threat. Most democracies contain small groups that are estranged from democratic institutions, some of them -- like those who inspired the Oklahoma bombing or those who daubed European synagogues with anti-Semitic slogans -- willing to resort to terrorist violence. Yet none of these groups are in a position to mount a challenge to a democratic state. Can we then safely write off fascism as largely banished from the world?

title: POLITICS: THE BALANCE SHEETS;Buchanan Cast as Tortoise; Dole, the Hare

description: MILLIONS of frequent fliers who are also fervent borrowers may have thought they had found their quick ticket to paradise when they received applications for the Skymiles credit card.

description: Perhaps it was a reversion to form.

title: Playing Tourist At Home
description: PEOPLE do some pretty odd things when they're tourists. Things they'd probably never do back home. Being a tourist allows a person to get lost, happily stand in line, throw pennies in fountains, buy postcards of sunsets, walk down a street looking up instead of down. It's harder to do these things in the place where you live. You'd feel a little foolish. I lived in London for eight years and never once visited Westminster Abbey or St. Paul's Cathedral or the Tower of London. I went to the movies and the supermarket and jogged in the park around the corner, because that's what people do in the places they live.

title: THEATER;How a Media Circus In 1925 Wound Up As a Musical Today
description: Despite both an embryonic Presidential campaign and the stock market crash in October 1987, nearly 7 out of 10 Americans were absorbed by something else that month: the three-day ordeal of "Baby Jessica" McClure, who had tumbled into an abandoned water well in a West Texas oil town. The three major television networks interrupted regular programming to report the rescue. A photograph of Jessica emerging won a Pulitzer Prize. She got to visit the White House. She threw out the first ball on opening day of the Texas Rangers' 1988 season.

description: The State Supreme Court will hear arguments on Tuesday on whether families of murder victims should be allowed to tell juries at sentencing how their lives have been affected by their loss.

description: In their perennial struggle to deter would-be jumpers, Golden Gate Bridge officials have decided to rely on the human touch rather than build new physical barriers.

title: Details;Letter Perfect
description: The best of the perennial basic: truly capital T's.

title: WORD & IMAGE;Digital Castles in the Sky
description: CONGRESS HAS PASSED A LAW TO deregulate and scramble all your telephone and cable services, but if you enjoy worrying about communications, that's only half of this year's convulsion. The Federal Government has yet to redistribute the broadcast spectrum, or at least to fill the newly created television vacancies in that spectrum. Done right, its decisions will greatly upgrade the quality and quantity of broadcast images and enable broadcasters to compete with satellites, phones, cables and computer modems in conveying words and pictures to your home. Done wrong, the decisions will enrich a few and squander a great public resource.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS;Yes, There Is Such a Thing As Mind Over Matter
description: EVEN Hippocrates knew that a blow to the head can leave bruises on the mind. By studying the effects of brain injuries, he demonstrated that the mind is centered not in the heart, as some romantics believed, but right behind the eyes.

title: CULTURE ZONE;The Hero's Last Sigh
description: IF YOU'D MET SALMAN Rushdie 13 years ago, you would never have pegged him as a man who would put his life on the line for literature. At 35, the author of "Midnight's Children" was already a brilliant novelist, but in person he seemed like any other habitue of the London literary scene: gregarious, funny, ambitious, a little self-important, someone at ease at a cocktail party in Chelsea. Back then, the notion of the Ayatollah Khomeini putting out a murder contract on a British novelist would have seemed like a surreal fantasy out of a Rushdie book. Back then, the prospect of Salman Rushdie joining the company of the Brodskys and Koestlers of the world would have seemed remote.

title: MUSIC;A Week of Recitals by Keyboardists
description: THE keyboard -- solo and in instrumental combinations -- appears frequently this week. The New Rochelle pianist Adam Kent, for example, gives a free recital today at 2:30 P.M., at the White Plains Public Library, juxtaposing works by Schubert and Brahms with operatic transcriptions by Busoni and Moritz Moszkowski.

title: WEDDINGS;Marla S. Glick, William Sherman

description: No doubt you will receive many letters deploring the unusual life led by a teen-age model, James King ("James Is a Girl," by Jennifer Egan, Feb. 4). I believe she deserves a note of encouragement.

description: To the final chords of Manolo Sanlucar's score for the ballet "Medea," the guest prima ballerina Lola Greco writhed in grief, her arms raised high as she pleaded to the gods for forgiveness for the murder of her children. A hush fell over the barnlike rehearsal space of the National Ballet of Spain. Though the dancers gathered on the sidelines were deeply familiar with Jose Granero's choreographic interpretation of the Greek tragedy, Ms. Greco had still brought them to tears.

description: A traffic horror show may be in its last act for people living and working near 180th Street and Liberty Avenue.

title: Corrections

Washington has argued that such a force should be on standby on the home soil of countries contributing to it, rather than deployed to Zaire as proposed by Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali. In accepting the American plan it was the United Nations Secretariat, not the Clinton Administration, that shifted policy.

title: Platforms Are the Priority For 72d Street Station
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNDAY VIEW;'Rent' Is Brilliant and Messy All at Once
description: It's odd to have joined the generations that talk about what "the young" are doing, saying and going through these days, and how that is reflected in art and entertainment. When "Hair," the counterculture antiwar musical, opened in the late 60's, I was pleased but a little patronizing as well: you always are when you're part of a subculture that suddenly goes mass culture. So I wonder what today's counterculture young think when they see themselves or a facsimile of themselves on stage in "Rent," the rock opera of the 90's now playing at New York Theater Workshop.

title: Corporations Under Fire
description: It cannot be an easy time in company boardrooms as the Republican campaign echoes with fiery denunciations of corporate avarice and mistreatment of workers. Patrick Buchanan's success in tapping the resentment and insecurity of voters is one thing. Bob Dole's declaration from the Republican mainstream that "corporate profits are setting records and so are corporate layoffs" may hurt even more. But give Mr. Buchanan credit for transforming the terms of the American debate. His solutions may be toxic, but the economic debate he has publicized is an important one.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: SATAN'S SILENCE Ritual Abuse and the Making of a Modern American Witch Hunt. By Debbie Nathan and Michael Snedeker. Basic Books, $25.

title: IN PERSON;On the March
description: THE voice of the Rev. Reginald T. Jackson still rises when he talks of how he lost his one, his only, political race. It was 1971 and he was a senior at Dover High School in Delaware. He was running for student council president in the 2,000-student school, the only one of 400 blacks trying for that office.

title: ON LANGUAGE;Half in Love With 'Full Frontal'
description: THE STATE OF MARYland seems to be in the pornography business. Here it is on the Motor Vehicle Administration's instructions for renewal of my driver's license: "You must be 21 or older to get a full frontal photo license."

description: The weather system that brought sunny skies and springlike temperatures to the New York region yesterday also delivered winds of over 50 miles per hour, knocking out power to more than a thousand homes on Long Island and in New Jersey and collapsing an abandoned building in Newark, officials said.

title: FOOD;Shad and Roe Are Making Their Yearly Cameo Appearance
description: IT is not quite spring yet, but shad and shad roe are already in the market. Shad is the most refined member of the herring family, with a closely textured white flesh and a spectacular pinkish red roe, which is a great delicacy.

title: Clinton Will Advise Schools on Uniforms
description: In the name of putting "discipline and learning back in our schools" President Clinton instructed the Federal Education Department today to distribute manuals to the nation's 16,000 school districts advising them how they can legally enforce a school uniform policy.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLATIRON / CHELSEA;Flatiron Unites to Fight Clubs
description: Ten years ago the neighborhood did not even have an established name. The Flatiron District has come a long way since then, attracting loft dwellers, design firms, shops, clubs and restaurants. Now the area is beginning to come of age politically as new civic groups strive to deal with the growing pains that have accompanied the growth.

title: Business College Offers Awards
description: WHEN it came time to recognize Black History Month in February, Monroe College turned away from traditional programs that dwell on culture, sports and entertainment and turned to its own roots.

title: THE WORLD: Before Rwanda, Before Bosnia;Waiting for Justice in Cambodia
description: AFTER the Nazis, there were the Nuremberg trials. More recently, ethnic cleansing in Bosnia and genocide in Rwanda have led to the establishment of international criminal tribunals. But out there in the middle distance lurks a monstrous catalogue of atrocities against a nation and its people that no judicial process has yet dared to touch: the Khmer Rouge era in Cambodia.

title: Gifted Programs: Necessary Elitism?
description: SOME educators look at a gifted and talented school like P.S. 308 in Bedford-Stuyvesant and see a life raft, a place where students are given the kind of academic push and moral affirmation that can otherwise be hard to come by in the inner city.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;Lights, Camera, Action, Steinberg!
description: As if having some of the most sought-after clients during the height of National Football League free agency has not already turned his life into an epic adventure, Leigh Steinberg has taken on the role of technical adviser in a movie starring Tom Cruise.

title: ART;A Glimpse of Contemporary Taste
description: EXHIBITIONS like "Note Well" at Artspace in New Haven -- which is presented with the explanatory phrase "Five Artists Selected by Five Connecticut Curators" -- are noteworthy because they're a sort of summit conference. As one of the curators, Richard Klein, assistant director of the Aldrich Museum, writes, "Connecticut defined in terms of an art community is not so much a place as a series of locations, institutions and individuals that one has a difficult time adding up to form a whole."

title: BASEBALL;Big Baseball Names For 2 Little Brothers
description: Balladeers may poignantly tell you "he ain't heavy, he's my brother." Can the same be said of a famous brother's baseball legend?

title: JAMES IS A GIRL
description: Images do speak louder than words. Nan Goldin's haunting photos make James King appear as an angel of death.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;Polke Turns Old Magic to a New Medium
description: Sigmar Polke, one of the most influential painters of the postwar era, has serious competition. It's Sigmar Polke the photographer, who is making his presence felt in an impressive survey at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles. "Sigmar Polke Photoworks: When Pictures Vanish" consists of 120 photographs, a great number of which have never been exhibited. Organized by MOCA's chief curator Paul Schimmel, it is the largest exhibition of Polke's camera work yet assembled as well as the first to be seen in this country.

title: SPENDING IT;Banking at Home: Once More, With Feeling
description: RANDY RYAN flies DC-10's for United Airlines, but his wife, Pam, has put their money on autopilot. When they take a six-week vacation in Australia this spring, a computer banking service will make sure their bill payments depart and arrive on time.

title: YOUR TAXES;Filing Electronically Remains for the Few
description: ONE day in the not-so-distant future the traditional midnight run to the downtown post office on April 15 will be replaced by a surge in cyberspace as computers transmit tax returns electronically.

title: TELEVISION VIEW;Unremote Control: An Alphabet Of Chips
description: THE V-CHIP, THAT TECHNOLOGICAL MARVEL that promises to relieve worried parents of tough decisions about what their children watch on television, will now be required in all new television sets. Behind the seeming mechanical impassivity of the chip, choices are to be made by a faceless army of raters and computer experts, who will add shut-off codes to be beamed along with the shows.

title: POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT;Huge and Unwieldy, a County Hospital Talks of Privatizing
description: Bergen Pines County Hospital started 80 years ago as a sanitarium in the truck-farm country of Paramus for people with contagious diseases. Over the years, it grew into a giant health center for the poor, the elderly and those with acute psychiatric problems. Today it is the state's largest hospital, and the seventh-largest public hospital in the nation.

title: Rescuing the Greeks
description: NOT OUT OF AFRICA How Afrocentrism Became an Excuse to Teach Myth as History. By Mary Lefkowitz. 222 pp. New York: A New Republic Book/Basic Books. $24.

title: LIVES;Formerly Anonymous
description: For months now, I have been researching a new book (not a political novel) at a small library on the East Side, where, weekly, I've exchanged pleasantries with the librarians at the front desk. The library actually owns books I've written. I've never been greeted by name. Last week I was greeted by name.

title: INVESTING IT;I.P.O.'s: When Employee-Friendly = Investor-Friendly
description: LOOKING to invest in a company new to the market? Check out its personnel policy.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Strickland Is No-Show at Practice
description: ROD STRICKLAND, digging deeper into a feud with Coach P. J. CARLESIMO, skipped the Portland Trail Blazers' practice yesterday, leading a team executive to say his suspension would be extended indefinitely. The Trail Blazers on Thursday suspended Strickland, who is third in the National Basketball Association in assists with 9.5 a game, after he walked out of a shoot-around before that night's home victory over Denver.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORT GREENE;Of Latte and the Literati: A Renaissance of Readings
description: Friday nights at the Brooklyn Moon Cafe are vaguely reminiscent of an earlier era: Fingers snap, fists are raised in tribute to the spoken word, a few in the crowd sport sunglasses. But the owner, Michael Thompson, said he began the now-trendy Friday-night open-mike sessions not as a haven for revolutionary pauper-poets but as a moneymaker.

title: Bank's Sign Mars a Garden And Fails in an Obligation
description: To the Editor:

title: Historic Sites Arts Series
description: AS winter recedes, the Hudson Valley, like Rip Van Winkle, is waking up.

title: Sun Valley
description: To the Editor: Sun Valley, Idaho -- voted the best ski resort in the nation by the readers of Ski magazine -- was omitted from the midseason ski report in the Travel Advisory (Feb. 11). The resort has fabulous skiing on 63 inches of packed power, with 170 inches for the season to date (as of Feb. 12). There's 107 percent coverage on all 78 runs, on all 2,054 acres.

title: SIGNOFF;On 'Law and Order,' a Real Idealist
description: At the end of a recent episode of "Law and Order" (NBC, Wednesdays at 10 P.M.), the battle-seasoned District Attorney Adam Schiff, played by Steven Hill, rallies his younger fellow prosecutors (Jill Hennessy and Sam Waterston) after a galling setback in court. Apparently guilty of killing a teacher, an anti-'Semitic teen-ager has received a reprieve in the form of an intractably hung jury that the prosecutors learn voted 11 to 1 to convict.

title: Rowland Seeks Private Partner For the Lottery
description: With a $200 million tax cut scheduled to take effect next year, Gov. John G. Rowland hopes to balance his budget, in part, by taking a step no other governor has tried: selling a stake in the state lottery to private investors.

title: February 18-24;A New War-Crimes Prosecutor
description: The international tribunals investigating war crimes in the former Yugoslavia and genocide in Rwanda -- tribunals that are at critical moments in their assignments -- are going to get a new chief prosecutor on Oct. 1. Last week, the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, said that Richard Goldstone, a South African high court judge, will be replaced by Louise Arbour, a Canadian judge with a background in criminal law and civil liberties.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Have Trouble Filling a Tall Order
description: At first, he had only to worry about the allocation of minutes and keeping his All-Star center happy with a steady diet of shots in the low post. But with two-thirds of his front line out with injuries, half his bench trying to learn the plays, and all of New York impatiently waiting for the Knicks to round into pre-playoff form, Don Nelson is no longer merely the caretaker.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Connecticut Welcomes A Rare Tight Struggle
description: The Notre Dame team gave Connecticut a battle today in their Big East women's match, and that was fine with Jennifer Rizzotti, the Huskies' floor leader and torchbearer.

title: Foreign Affairs;Japan Inc. Revisited
description: I found the source of our trade problems with Japan.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;Down to the Sea with Smollet and Miss Piggy
description: Rumble in the Bronx Jackie Chan, Anita Mui, Francoise Yip, Marc Akerstream Directed by Stanley Tong R 87 minutes

title: G.O.P. IN CONGRESS DEBATING TACTICS TO REGAIN AN EDGE
description: With Republican Presidential candidates ignoring the Contract With America, the party's Congressional leadership is debating how to recover the initiative and pass some of their legislative agenda without helping President Clinton's re-election chances.

title: Task Force Recommends Limits On Camera Coverage of Courts
description: California courts should continue to allow cameras at trials but should ban them from pretrial proceedings and most hearings held without the jury present, a task force has recommended.

title: Sunday February 25, 1996: CYBERTHINK;Medium and Message
description: To simulate or to deconstruct, that is the question . . . in cyberspace, anyway. Since the Internet still promises more than it delivers, it's too bad Marshall McLuhan isn't around to decipher the post-modern message of this virtual medium. Instead, a new on-line journal, Talkback! A Forum for Critical Discourse (http://math240.lehman.cuny. edu/talkback), may be just the electronic ticket for those interested in pondering the deeper meaning of the Internet.

title: Sports Of The Times;Jumbo Jet Might Steal A Steeler
description: NOW that the Jets have Jumbo Elliott, the Giants don't.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COLLEGE POINT / FLUSHING;Anatomy of a Deal For Vacant Land
description: Proposals by a Pepsi-Cola bottler to find a developer for a vacant 26-acre tract it owns north of the old Flushing Airport -- possibly for megastores like Kmart and Price Club -- have left area residents and businesses bitter and angry.

title: Swerve, Jab, Weave, Crash: Just Another Traffic Circle
description: To the Editor:

title: Marijuana Club Helps Those in Pain
description: From among the marijuana banana bread and magic brownies, the cannabis "merry pills" and the eight grades of loose marijuana listed on the cheery wall menu like ice cream flavors, Gypsy Calabrese chose a bag of the top-grade Asian "Quad-A."

title: Milan Caution
description: To the Editor: Travelers evidently have to be careful in and around the Milan train station (Letters on Travel, Jan. 7).

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;The Jets and Sharks in Fresh Garb
description: One of the livelier moments in "The Songs of 'West Side Story,' " an all-star album tribute to the 1957 musical, is a partially rapped version of "Gee, Officer Krupke," featuring Lisa Lopes of T.L.C., Salt-n-Pepa and Def Jef.

title: Bank's Sign Mars a Garden And Fails in an Obligation
description: To the Editor:

title: Children's Books;Bookshelf
description: CLEOPATRA: Goddess of Egypt, Enemy of Rome. By Polly Schoyer Brooks. HarperCollins. $15.95. (Ages 11 and up) The life of the most famous queen of the ancient world is the stuff of fiction and plays, but this book is strictly factual: a cool biography with good notes, bibliography and illustrations.

title: YOUR TAXES;On Its Web Site, The I.R.S. Shows It Has a Softer Side
description: THIS is the Internal Revenue Service?

title: City's Deer Problem: Another View
description: I was disappointed by the comments in the article ("A City's Deer Called Too Costly," Feb. 4) by the City Manager of Norwich, William Tallman. He set up a false antagonism between the deer and "starving children in Connecticut."

title: DRIVING;Trouble Spots To Avoid
description: A look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency.

title: It's Greek to us
description: A very well-dressed woman of my acquaintance recently conducted a census of her closet. Much of the data is still confidential, but I did manage to coax from her the exact number of pairs of shoes she owns. A hundred and two, not counting sneakers. That Imelda Marcos-like figure is so otherwise incomprehensible that men may find it helpful, as I do, to picture all this footwear neatly lined up, side by side, on a regulation-size hockey rink. Manolo Blahnik slingbacks, Prada patent leather loafers, ballet slippers from Capezio, flats, heels, boots, platform shoes, spectator pumps, feather-trimmed mules, oxfords, bluchers, saddle shoes, jellies, sandals, moccasins, bucks, combat boots -- they stretch, by my reckoning, all the way from the blueline to the goal mouth. Or, to put it another way, they represent the gap that distances the fashionable from the unfashionable, and -- it amounts to almost the same thing -- women from men.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Feb. 24;Commerce Chief Scouts New U.S. Market: Africa
description: When President Jacques Chirac of France exhorted the United States not to leave Africa "in the vicious circle of exclusion" in his recent speech on Capitol Hill, it is safe to assume that what Mr. Chirac had in mind was not more visits to the continent by Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: JUAMAICA;If There's a Fight, They'll Get in the Middle
description: Although they have been neighbors for 20 years, Tom, 29, and Peter, 38, never said hello to each other. Tom, the superintendent whose family owns the six-unit building in Glendale that both live in, said he was too shy. Peter, an aspiring musician who lives in a two-bedroom rent-controlled apartment with his mother, was not interested in talking.

title: Harpist to Perform at Benefit
description: HARPS are associated with angels, and the international concert harpist Nancy Allen took her harp closer to heaven when she played a Beethoven song on top of Aspen Mountain in Colorado. "We couldn't fit my harp into the ski lift," she said. "A Snowcat brought it up."

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Sloan-Kettering to Honor Nelson
description: DON NELSON, the coach of the Knicks, will be honored by the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center with a benefit dinner on March 11 at Mickey Mantle's restaurant in Manhattan. Nelson will receive the hospital's "Award of Courage" for his visits to the pediatric ward and the encouragement he gives to patients.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Kia Sportage and Kia Sephia;2 Tigers, at Least on Paper
description: IN America, where the phrase "Korean car" inspires the same sort of consumer confidence as the words "Albanian software" or "Canadian football," Kia's entry into the market has been inauspicious.

title: Commercial Property: Brokerage Employment;In Recruiting, Seasoning Now Comes Before Youth
description: IN the early 1980's, when Sholom & Zuckerbrot was opening real estate offices all over New York, it hired scads of youngsters fresh from college. The idea was that they would cut their teeth on cold calls and other necessary but not particularly remunerative work and in the process learn to be brokers.

title: YOUR TAXES;For the Unwary and Gullible, Paying for the Sins of a Spouse
description: WHENEVER you want to marry someone, go have lunch with his ex-wife," the actress Shelley Winters once said. She might have added that the first question to ask is whether he has paid his taxes.

title: More Fathers Are Choosing To Become At-Home Dads
description: JOHN CLEMENTS, 28, of Bellmore cooks, cleans and spends weekdays caring for his infant daughter while his wife works 11-hour days as an accountant. But he would prefer if you didn't call him "Mr. Mom."

title: Clinton Meets Japan Premier as Trade Fires Up Campaign
description: With the trade debate in the Republican Presidential campaign looming over them, President Clinton and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan met Friday night to lay the groundwork for Mr. Clinton's state visit to Tokyo later this year.

title: Cuba's Nuclear Plant Project Worries Washington
description: From the day the Cuban Government began building an atomic reactor here in the early 1980's, American officials were alarmed at the prospect that a nuclear power plant of Soviet design and questionable safety would be going into operation less than 200 miles from American shores, but powerless to do anything about it.

title: Have Show, Will Travel (Within Limits)
description: Monet in Chicago. Vermeer in Washington. Brancusi in Philadelphia. The Barnes Collection in Toronto or Philadelphia. Conceptualism in Los Angeles. New Yorkers had to keep their bags packed (and their wallets open) to be ardent art lovers during the last few months, so many big shows bypassed the city's museums.

title: BOOKSHELF;Whodunnit? 3 Windows On Criminals
description: THE crime rate may be going down, but fascination with the subject remains high. While accounts of crime often sensationalize or simplify, three new books tell the stories behind the stories. Each illuminates its own corner of the justice system.

title: SPENDING IT;Finding Your Glitch in Banking on Your PC
description: IT is a modern corollary to Murphy's Law that any time you find a way to do something more efficiently with a computer, enough bugs crop up so you wind up with no more free time than before.

title: INVESTING WITH: Mary Lisanti;BT Investment Small Cap Fund
description: WITNESSING the stock market's gyrations over the last week, investors with weak stomachs may have wanted to run and hide. Not Mary Lisanti, who runs two mutual funds for Bankers Trust.

title: Therapeutic Value of Talking to Animals
description: TALKING to animals helps people get better. At least that is the philosophy at Green Chimneys, where barnyard creatures and injured wildlife restore confidence to disturbed and disabled youths.

title: OUT OF ORDER;The Conflict Between A.M. and P.M. People
description: THE world is full of irresolvable conflicts, and I almost hesitate to recommend another one. But it's time that more attention was paid to the deep divide in our society between Morning People and Night People.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Feb. 4 with an article about the survival of Latin in New York City misspelled part of the inscription over the main entrance of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The inscription reads "Spiritus Sanctus Quem Mittet Pater in Nomine Meo. Ille Vos Docebit Omnia." It means "The Holy Spirit Whom the Father Will Send in My Name. He Will Teach You All Things."

title: LONG ISLANG GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: The Theft of Identities: A Long and Winding Road
description: To the Editor:

title: Today's Specials
description: One day back in 1896, I was crossing over the Jersey on the ferry, and as we pulled out there was another ferry pulling in. And on it there was a girl. ...A white dress she had on. She was carrying a white parasol. I only saw her for one second. She didn't see me at all. But I'll be a month hasn't gone by since that I haven't thought of that girl."

title: SOAPBOX;Starlight Over 10th Avenue
description: I'M one of Manhattan's lucky ones. I have a view. From my fifth-floor walk-up on 36th Street I can look down along 10th Avenue, and up toward the southern sky.

title: IN BRIEF;New License Plate to Promote Technology in the Classroom
description: Governor Whitman has supported classroom technology by including $10 million for computers in next year's education budget. Now the State Assembly is hoping to create a second technology fund from license plate sales.

title: Love and Other Choices
description: DANCING AFTER HOURS Stories. By Andre Dubus. 234 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $23.

title: JAMES IS A GIRL
description: I was struck by the vapid vampirism of the "support system" James King has around her. With her mother clucking her approval, James smokes, drinks and hangs at the Bowery Bar; the picture of James shooting pool with her "boyfriend" tells the true tale -- a 16-year-old ghost going on 60.

title: Shifting Sands at the Advertising Club
description: WHEN the going gets tough, the tough hang out together. Or, why, despite the economy, two professional organizations are certain of attracting new members.

title: Shuttle's Crew Forced to Delay Satellite Test
description: Because of computer problems, astronauts aboard the space shuttle Columbia will have to wait a day to release a satellite on a 12.8-mile-long tether, a device that will test the prospects of generating electricity in space.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, a picture credit last Sunday with an article about the Champion Greenhouse in Stamford was illegible. The pictures were by Carl David LaBianca for The New York Times.

title: Solar Satellite Lofted to Study Space Weather
description: The space agency launched a solar research satellite early today that scientists hope will provide insights on weather in space and its effects on satellite communications.

title: World News Briefs;Coalition Talks Fail Again in Turkey
description: Talks between the Islamic party that won the most seats in parliamentary elections and a conservative party have failed to form a governing coalition, the leader of the conservative party said today.

title: Mexican Roots
description: WILD STEPS OF HEAVEN By Victor Villasenor. 296 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $19.95.

title: Brookhaven Work Entails Risks
description: As noted recently in your pages ("Angry Neighbors Fight Brookhaven on Water," Jan. 28), over the past weeks some of our neighbors have expressed concerns about radioactive emissions that occur as the result of the operation of two research reactors at Brookhaven National Laboratory.

title: SPITFIRE GRILL';'We Have Become Too Extreme'
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A chart last Sunday listing campaign contributions to first-term members of Congress referred incorrectly to funds received by Representative Zach Wamp, Republican of Tennessee. Mr. Wamp received $1,600 from committees supporting other candidates, not from political action committees.

title: Indian Premier Shrugs Off Scandal
description: After four resignations this week brought to seven the number of Indian Government ministers who have quit since the start of the year in a corruption scandal, Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao told a rally of his governing Congress Party not to worry about the general election expected in April or May.

title: Also Inside
description: MAKING IT WORK 3

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Feb. 11 about "Back of the Big House: The Cultural Landscape of the Plantation," a photographic exhibition on American slavery that aroused objections and was promptly dismantled, misidentified its initial site in Washington. It was the Library of Congress, not the Smithsonian Institution. (The exhibition appeared later under the name "The Cultural Landscape of the Plantation" at the Martin Luther King Jr. Library in Washington.)

title: Liaisons Dangereuses
description: THE LOVE AFFAIR AS A WORK OF ART By Dan Hofstadter. 314 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24. WILL the suggestive title of this witty and wise book be understood? In our age of sexual promiscuity and quantified orgasms, readers may expect an essay on skillful preludes and artful caresses. First the telephone, then the fax and now E-mail have made the handwritten love letter, with its sensuous and emotional associations, an archaic experience. In "The Love Affair as a Work of Art," Dan Hofstadter evokes a 19th-century world in which love letters were an art form with a narrative potential. His book, more than merely nostalgic, raises questions about issues ranging from the sincerity of feelings to the vexing relation between art and life.

title: Loaded Language
description: To the Editor: Having lived in Malawi (and in several other African countries), I greeted Marcia Burick's "Glittering Lake Malawi" (Dec. 31) with delight. Little is written about this small, beautiful country, which is now undergoing the traumas and challenges of recovering from decades of dictatorship.

title: Tom Costello, 58, Avant-Garde Actor
description: Tom Costello, an actor who was a founding member of Andre Gregory's Manhattan Project and a frequent performer in the puppet plays of Theodora Skipitares, died on Feb. 18 at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 58.

title: Kevorkian Jury Watches Tape of Patient Who Chose Suicide
description: Barely six hours before he died in Dr. Jack Kevorkian's apartment, a doctor with bone cancer said in a videotaped statement, "I want to live quite bad, but my suffering is awful, and there's no answer to the pain."

title: Details;Ring Leaders
description: All the signs point to fashion's new direction. Just follow the finger wearing two rings as big as the Ritz.

title: Icebreaker
description: To the Editor: Thanks to John Freeman Gill for helping to bring this winter's weather worries back down to size. I've seldom felt as snug and cozy reading a travel article.

title: ON HOCKEY;For Playoff Run, Rangers Need a Slight Tuneup
description: Entertaining, expensive and experienced, the 1995-96 Rangers seem a good but not great team as they begin the final quarter of the regular season. The next seven weeks include the March 20 trade deadline and the scramble for positioning in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;With Elliott Signed, the Jets Shift Their Focus to O'Donnell
description: The Jets acquired still another trophy yesterday in their audacious quest to lure quarterback Neil O'Donnell from the Super Bowl Steelers: Jumbo Elliott, who earned a ring of his own with the Giants.

title: Record for Vaccinations
description: A record 75 percent of preschoolers are getting recommended vaccinations, leaving one million who still need one or more doses, Federal health researchers say.

title: WEDDINGS;Susan Wyland and Norman Lanes
description: SUSAN WYLAND, the editor of Martha Stewart Living magazine, and Dr. Norman Lanes, an internist in New York, are not at all alike.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: THERE's something a little different in four films on television this week. Edward Dmytryk's CROSSFIRE (1947) WS AN EARLY, ACCLAIMED DRAMA ABOUT ANTI-Semitism. Later that year, the classier-looking "Gentleman's Agreement" copped several Oscars. But the modest, shadowy "Crossfire" lingers. After a gentle bar patron (Sam Levene) is found beatent to death, this compactly shaped whodunit opens up a story of festering bigotry and evil. The small, able cast includes three Roberts - Ryan, Young (in photograph) and Mitchum - Paul Kelly and Gloria Grahame. It's on Tuesday/Early Wednesday at 1:15 A.M. on American Movie Classics.

title: Three F-14 Fighter Jet Crashes Lead to Limits on Navy Pilots
description: The Navy imposed new restrictions today on pilots who fly the F-14 jet fighter, after three of the trouble-plagued jets crashed in the last month, killing four Navy airmen and three civilians.

title: COPING;Parents, Pain, Pride and the Gay Son
description: THE cabdriver spoke fluent English, so Marlene Fanta Shyer engaged him in conversation. She is, after all, a novelist and magazine writer, always fishing for stories. They began talking about their children. "I have three," she chirped, "one of each sex. Boy, girl and gay."

title: Challenge to Kosher Laws Raises Some Deeper Issues
description: THE challenge to the constitutionality of New York State's century-old kosher protection laws, a case rooted on Long Island, is bringing to the forefront important issues involving kosher food affecting Jews and non-Jews.

title: FORBES BEATS DOLE IN DELAWARE VOTE
description: Steve Forbes, the millionaire magazine publisher, today won Delaware's Republican Presidential primary, the second of the year, defeating Senator Bob Dole, who lost for the second time in a week.

title: RESTAURANTS;Doctors of Lox
description: A FEW weeks ago, I visited Cafe Matisse in Rutherford with a friend who is editing the Museum of Modern Art's catalogue on the artist; today, I am visiting Tabatchnick's Backroom restaurant with a woman (my mother) whose grandmother (my great-grandmother Yetta) pickled her own herring in a jar outside her window.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;A Smug Press Battles an Old Voice
description: The news that The Village Voice will soon be distributed free has been met with some smirking at New York Press, the renegade weekly that bills itself as the freethinking alternative to an aging and atherosclerotic Voice.

title: Deputy Police Commissioner Goes Into a Fray
description: The deputy police commissioner Jack Maple is often referred to as the strategic brains behind the Commissioner's aggressive anti-crime programs.

title: Pieces of a Life
description: IN THE LANGUAGE OF LOVE A Novel in 100 Chapters. By Diane Schoemperlen. 358 pp. New York: Viking. $23.95.

title: Critics Aside, Cape May Needs a Revived Railroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties;George, Begone!
description: I needed a break from politics.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLATIRON / CHELSEA;A Pool Remains a Pipe Dream
description: Chelsea is still waiting for its public swimming pool. Twenty-two years ago the city built a six-story red brick building, cut a hole inside for a pool that slopes gently from the shallow end to the deep end and built bleachers. Then came the fiscal crisis of the mid-70's, and the work stopped.

title: ART;Cross-Cultural Forces Show Boldness and Thematic Freedom
description: Eastern Fusion: Contemporary Asian American Art

title: City Dumps To Ask Fees Of 2 Agencies
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's running feuds with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey have reached a new level: he plans to start charging the two agencies to dispose of their garbage in the city's dumps.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: HOW LATE IT WAS, HOW LATE By James Kelman. Delta, $11.95.

title: Morrison's Courage
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Black History Traced in Mount Show in Setauket
description: When you belong to a lot of organizations, you need a lot of briefcases," said Ted Green, as he leafed through papers on his roots from his home In Setauket.

title: Fresh Paint
description: As an older woman fascinated by makeup but also a little afraid. Every time I reach for something to brighten my pallor I see the face of Miss Canfield, a retired junior high teach who was a substitute - the bright circles of rouge, the cockeyed smears of blue shadow, the bleeding vermilion lipstick - and my hand is stayed in midair.

title: No End Seen to I.R.A. Power To Wage a Campaign of Fear
description: The Irish Republican Army has the weaponry and determination to prolong into the next century its campaign of violence to force Britain to give up power in Northern Ireland, according to senior British officials, politicians and academic experts.

title: THE WORLD;Chinese Cold War Forecast: Costly, Dangerous
description: IF the Chinese leadership has the night sweats about a democratically elected Taiwanese President asserting independence to the cheers of the American Congress, the Clinton Administration has a nightmare, too: being forced to abandon its quiet, difficult diplomacy with China and adopt a much tougher approach, like the effort to "contain" the Soviet Union after World War II.

title: Announcing New Party in Italy, Dini Jumps Into Election Fray
description: After a year as the popular head of a non-elected Government, the outgoing Prime Minister, Lamberto Dini, has jumped squarely into Italy's pre-election politics, announcing he will lead a new party with center-left ties.

title: A New Right Man for Seven Roles'
description: JOHN LEGUIZAMO could make anyone believe that people who laugh at themselves are the healthiest people in the world.

title: NEW YORK RADIO;Another Option

title: GOOD EATING;In the West 50's, Before the Show
description: CARNEGIE DELICATESSEN AND RESTAURANT + (212) 757-2245; 845 Seventh Avenue (55th Street); $(c) no credit cards

title: Now, Forager
description: I never buy anything new if I can help it. My wardrobe and my house have been furnished almost exclusively from thrift, junk and consignment shops. I've been thrifting for decades, so I no longer need much and I mostly just upgrade and deaccession. To keep my reflexes in shape, I will often go thrifting theoretically -- moneyless, with an imaginary character to style -- which is like practicing on a silent keyboard. In my spare time, I also volunteer as a guide for the style-impaired. Recently, at the Council Thrift Shop, I put together a new wardrobe for a total stranger. She was very surprised to discover I didn't work there.

title: YOUR TAXES;The Forms Look About the Same, but Beware of the Tinkering
description: RADICAL overhaul of the tax system may dominate political debate these days, but there is remarkably little change in the rules for filing your return for 1995.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;Troubled Residents No Trouble So Far, Opponents Say
description: At dusk, Lou Polotoff, dressed in a black bathrobe with white Chinese characters over sweat pants and sneakers, wearing earphones and a baseball cap, is handing out copies of his Presidential platform in front of Euclid Hall and in the Ray's Pizza next door. Among the planks: "Put all hatemongers in straitjackets for three months."

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE;Mitzvah vs. Chutzpah: Guerrilla Mr. Fix-it Occupies Temple
description: Occupied," reads the sheet draped over the roof of the abandoned synagogue on East Eighth Street. The occupier, a retired firefighter named Ralph Feldman who usually lives next door, says he spent $100,000 of his own money fixing up the dilapidated temple as a mitzvah, or good deed. He says he wants it to remain a synagogue.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;No Park Is an Island, As Yellowstone Proves
description: IT isn't possible to wrap a national park as if it were a compact disk. Developments outside a park's boundaries can seep in, and what happens inside can be felt beyond the broadest borders.

title: Drugs Kill Good People. What's New?
description: To the Editor:

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;What Goes Up, Might Go Up More
description: MANY investors worry that stocks are like balloons pumped up to the bursting point. But one investor who is largely unfazed by the possibility of a big "pop!" is Richard Driehaus.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CD-ROM;C.I.A. Data on a Disk
description: The C.I.A. is making available some of its expertise about the world. Now computer owners can make use of the C.I.A. World Factbook on CD-ROM. The factbook, with 269 entries of data on politics, geography and economics, including maps, is available through the National Technical Information Service, (800) 553-6847, for $30.

title: In the Region: New Jersey;Supermarket Expansions Attracting Bank Services
description: SOMETHING different is being marketed these days at the ShopRite supermarket that opened last year on a stretch of the Hudson River waterfront in Jersey City. Along with fresh produce and meats, consumers can shop for mortgage loans and savings accounts.

title: Out From Under
description: THE ROAD FROM SERFDOM The Economic and Political Consequences of the End of Communism. By Robert Skidelsky. 214 pp. New York: Allen Lane/The Penguin Press. $26.95.

title: Once and Future Tax?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rabbi Marvin Fox; Professor, 73, Led School at Brandeis
description: Rabbi Marvin Fox, a scholar of Jewish thought and former director of the Department of Near Eastern and Judaic Studies at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., died on Feb. 8 at his home in Newton, Mass. He was 73.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: FUNDS WATCH;Think Small To Win Big
description: Many mutual fund investors and advisers have been beating the index fund drum lately. The argument goes that because more than 80 percent of diversified equity funds trailed the Standard & Poor's 500 last year, why not simply buy the index?

title: For Small Patients, Introduction to Surgery
description: NICHOLAS LEBLANC held his mother's hand as he walked down the brightly lighted hall at Norwalk Hospital. Nicholas, who will celebrate his 3d birthday on March 12, was searching for pink signs with arrows pointing the way to the pediatric unit. "Where's my room?" he kept asking, eventually letting go of his mother's hand to run enthusiastically forward in his search.

title: Right Hook;G.O.P.'s Libertarian Streak Becomes a Blur
description: SOMETIMES what is important about a primary season is what doesn't happen. Exhibit A: The absence of a major Presidential candidate to speak, whole-heartedly and full-throatedly, for Republicans who support abortion rights or are otherwise uncomfortable with the conservative social agenda.

title: BENEFITS
description: Curtain Calls on the Park

title: High Heels and Hangovers
description: At the Still Point A Memoir. By Carol Buckley. Illustrated. 255 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $23.

title: JERSEY;For Losing Bettors, Chump Change for Help
description: IN the gaming industry, which is the term preferred by the gambling business and the growing number of states falling over one another to promote it, the numbers always tell a story.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 32 of the Arts and Leisure section today about documentary films on the Hollywood blacklist misstates the day this week for the first broadcast of "Blacklist: Hollywood on Trial," on American Movie Classics. It is Tuesday, not Wednesday.

title: WEDDINGS;Anne Lounsbury, Nicolas Ekstrom
description: Anne Cornell Lounsbury, the daughter of Mrs. Emmett Stewart Epley of Lexington, Va., and the late Robert Hastings Lounsbury, was married yesterday to Nicolas Horlin Ekstrom, the son of Arne Horlin Ekstrom of New York and the late Parmenia Migel Ekstrom. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: Cuttings;Now You Don't See It, Now You Do: Asparagus
description: There is something almost mystical about asparagus. One warm spring day you tramp through the garden, checking out the little lettuce seedlings and other early crops, and the asparagus bed is just a patch of barren earth. The next day you wander through again and there's the asparagus, six to eight inches tall, fat, succulent and ready to eat.

title: INVESTING IT;Bondholders Forgotten In the Fight Over RJR
description: BONDHOLDERS are used to being treated as second-class citizens. But they almost verge on the invisible in the battle by two corporate raiders for control of RJR Nabisco.

title: JERSEYANA;Whitman Budget Leaves Historians Fearing for a Commission's Future
description: As state agencies go, the New Jersey Historical Commission falls into the "obscure" category. But for people obsessed with the past, it has been a perpetual source of information, research tools and grants. So it comes as no surprise that historians in New Jersey and beyond are huffing about Governor Whitman's plan to cut the commission out of the state budget.

title: The Father Coughlin of 1996
description: At 3 o'clock every Sunday afternoon in the early 1930's, an unemployed teamster named Edward Garrett quieted his family in their Manhattan tenement. He settled into his recliner, lit a Camel and tuned his Philco radio to WCBS. Dinner would wait until after the weekly sermon by Father Charles Coughlin, the "radio priest" who gave voice to all the unspoken rage and anxiety in Edward.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Suns Are a .500 Team Standing at a Crossroads
description: Asked to evaluate the recent trades made by the Knicks, Charles Barkley had an opinion, as usual.

title: Street Smart
description: We asked three top fashion designers to turn their hands to some ordinary feature of the urban landscape. Here are their solutions for putting style on every corner.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE;Tower Is Sold For Elder Care
description: The Madonna Residence, a nine-story tower that for decades has marked the start of Park Slope's "Gold Coast" and most recently housed a nursing home, has been sold and will continue to serve the elderly under its new owners.

title: Preservationist Tax Exemptions
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;An Unpredictable Maestro Jars a Staid Repertory
description: What goes through a conductor's mind during the final tumultuous minutes of Mahler's Eighth Symphony? With a peroration out of Goethe's "Faust, Part Two," choral masses roaring the indescribable and the eternal feminine, towering triads of E flat major and bellowing strokes of the gong, this music aims to depict nothing less than "the whole universe beginning to ring and resound." It might draw any conductor into a state of euphoria, even megalomania.

title: Against Edward Said
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTING IT;With Fewer Stocks to Buy, The Bulls May Stay Hungry
description: IT'S not quite the incredible shrinking stock market, but there are fewer stocks around today than there were at the start of last year. And the shrinkage may be both a force that has pushed the Dow upward and a solid clue about where it may be headed.

title: What Happened to Fred Cuny?
description: ASA BASAYEV BELIEVES she saw him. "I remember him because he was very big and a little bit heavy," she said. We were standing on the front steps of the burned-out municipal building in Samashki, a small agricultural town in war-battered western Chechnya, and Basayev, an elderly woman with piercing gray eyes, was pointing toward the debris-strewn main street. "I saw him passing right by here," she said. I had come to Samashki, or what was left of it, with a small entourage -- a driver, a photographer and a translator -- and a question: What happened to Fred Cuny?

title: DINING OUT;Chicken Stands Out at New Steakhouse
description: TWO years ago a steakhouse replacing an Italian restaurant was news. Now it is not. It recently happened again in Woodmere when G. Roberts Steakhouse opened in the double storefront quarters on Broadway that once housed a succession of casual Italian cafes.

title: SPENDING IT;A Hybrid Pension Plan Gains Ground
description: IT has taken a decade, but the Internal Revenue Service has finally proposed rules on the tax status of a new type of pension plan. Benefit consultants say the proposal is favorable enough to employers that the plans, now offered by about 200 large companies, may become much more popular.

title: POLITICS: LAMAR ALEXANDER;A Contender Struggles To Project His Image
description: Marie Blumberg, a 34-year-old insurance underwriter looked on in astonishment as she stumbled across a political rally at the Sheraton Grand Hotel in Tampa, where nearly a dozen Lamar Alexander supporters had gathered recently wearing their candidate's trademark plaid-flannel shirts despite expected 80-degree temperatures. "I've never heard his name before," Ms. Blumberg said.

title: STYLE;Chewing the Fat
description: For a person who has flirted with anorexia, it is a pleasure to see men of a certain age worrying about their weight. Listening to them is not such a pleasure. Because the men are new at the game, they don't hesitate to discuss the fat problem. Incessantly. Women of the same age do not discuss the fat problem, especially not in mixed company. They prefer to face the problem with quiet dignity. Discussing the problem might only draw attention to some stray body part that may be successfully tucked away under an article of clothing.

title: POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT;For the G.O.P., the New Jersey Primary Mights as Well Be in 2000
description: For the leading Republican Presidential contenders coming out of Iowa and New Hampshire -- Patrick J. Buchanan, Bob Dole, Lamar Alexander and Steve Forbes -- New Jersey seems a long way off.

title: Habitats/ New Canaan, Conn.;Living Up to the Neighbors on Ponus Ridge Road
description: ONLY one year ago, the farmhouse on Ponus Ridge Road in New Canaan, Conn., was, for lack of a better word, an eyesore. Well, maybe it wouldn't have been an eyesore on a normal, unassuming back road, but Ponus Ridge is not a normal, unassuming road.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;Town Hall Would Like Its Piece of the Times Square Pie
description: With the refurbished New Victory Theater now open and the Times Square redevelopment project getting underway, Town Hall, a block away on West 43d Street, has more to celebrate than just its 75th anniversary this year: ticket-buying crowds are returning to the neighborhood.

title: TELEVISION VIEW;How to Learn From the Blacklist
description: FOR HOLLYWOOD, IT WAS the worst of times: publicity-driven Congressmen making headlines by hounding screenwriters, directors and actors; studio bosses sacrificing their employees to political pressure; scores of careers put on hold for years or ruined forever.

title: Photographs, Sculptures, Paper Works
description: ON the map, this hamlet is a dot between the Hudson River and the train tracks. In reality, it consists of a landing guarded by ducks and a few small houses dominated by two sizable structures, one stone, the other wood.

description: MARC RIBOT: 'DON'T BLAME ME' DIW
