description: Between Belarus and Oz

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;New British Star: A Century of Cinema
description: The centenary of the first film shown in Britain is being celebrated this year with a number of exhibitions and events.

title: The View From: West Hartford;Peering Into Space With a Little Help From NASA
description: THE Science Center of Connecticut, once known as the Children's Museum in West Hartford, is trying to re-establish itself as a fun-loving educational place for children and adults alike, but its long-term future remains uncertain.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Monday

title: NATO to Let Bosnia Serb Army Aid Exodus
description: Convinced that Serbs who remain in Sarajevo's suburbs are determined to flee rather than submit to the Muslim-dominated Government, NATO today agreed to allow the Bosnian Serb army to send trucks here to transport them out.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;A Mountain That Can Move Sees Olympic Heights Beyond Gridiron
description: He glanced out the apartment window, saw the steady downpour and decided it was Jonathan Ogden weather.

title: New Rules For Electing Pope Stress Secrecy
description: Pope John Paul II issued a new rule book on Friday for how future popes will be elected, largely reaffirming existing guidelines but reinforcing the secrecy of the process and improving accommodations for the 100 or so cardinals who will come to Rome to choose his successors.

title: IN PERSON;Reasons to March: Bill Bradley on the Costs of Poverty and Racism
description: Following is an excerpt from "Time Present, Time Past" (Alfred A. Knopf, 1996), a political memoir by Senator Bill Bradley.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE;Custom Leather: Haute and Hot, At High Prices
description: Agatha Blois, at 19, was a struggling go-go dancer who sewed her own costumes. Growing weary of the scene, she quit -- the dancing, not the sewing. As it turned out, she found she could make a living with the needle. With experience, the self-taught haberdasher began selling clothes from her house.

title: Ready to Rally: Trenton, Here We Come!
description: DAYS after returning from Washington, exhilarated by the Million Man March, 1,500 New Jersey men gathered last October at St. James A.M.E. Church in Newark. "O.K., we went to Washington, now what?" said Lawrence Hamm, state co-chairman of the Million Man March Coalition, describing the feeling.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: VICTORIAN ART

title: Drugs Kill Good People. What's New?
description: To the Editor:

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Casting 'Primary Colors';Let Emma Thompson Play Everyone
description: FORGET the book "You'll Never Make Love in This Town Again," the recent No. 1 best-seller in Hollywood about the real-life sexual adventures of some call girls and their famous show-biz clients. The town has now shifted its attention to another book, "Primary Colors," by an anonymous but obviously informed novelist, a roman a clef about a libidinous Southern governor's quest for the Presidency, his smart, strong-willed and fiercely ambitious wife and an assortment of associates and competitors who seem very much like the cast of characters in Bill Clinton's 1992 campaign for the Presidency.

title: HOCKEY;Devils Win a Tight One And Inch Closer to Caps
description: The Devils culminated the busiest week of their schedule, five games in seven days, with a 2-1 triumph over the Washington Capitals here tonight in a tightly contested defensive battle that came just a night after their six-goal explosion in a victory over Montreal.

title: Icebreaker
description: To the Editor: "An Icebreaker Through the Antarctic" by John Freeman Gill (Jan. 7) was one of the most memorable Travel section articles published in the past several years. The author did a masterful job of conveying to your readers the experience of an arduous but rewarding journey to Antarctica. Reading the story in the comfort of my living room, I actually felt that I was aboard an icebreaker slowly making its way to the frozen continent. The descriptions of the environment, events and sites were incredibly realistic.

title: POP MUSIC;Grammys Look for Hipness in New Rules
description: Christopher Cross and Toto were bad enough, but Tony Bennett was the last straw.

title: MUSIC;At Wesleyan, a Trio Of Collegiate Groups
description: A GATHERING of vocal ensembles from Amherst, Williams and Wesleyan may be initiating an annual event with "Little Three Choral Festival.

title: Cornell University Hasn't Been Spared the SUNY Budget Knife
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: More Elbow Room for Bronx Zoo Primates;Where Gorillas Can Act Like Gorillas
description: Gorillas can expect more elbow room and a better look at visitors -- over two million drop by a year -- when the $30 million Congo Gorilla Forest is completed at the southwest edge of the Bronx Zoo/Wildlife Conservation Park in 1999.

title: China, in Flux, Must Integrate Values
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC;Chaplin in an Unexpected Role: Composer
description: PERHAPS more people would listen to symphony concerts if they offered something to see as well as hear. Taking a cue from the look-listen attraction of opera and ballet, orchestras program films like "Ivan the Terrible" and "Alexander Nevsky" as an excuse to play Prokofiev's scores. Erich Korngold, Miklos Rosza and Bernard Hermann, mainly known (and unknown) as film composers, are also gaining overdue appreciation from this format.

title: February 18-24;Meeting Across an Old Breach
description: It was their desire, as environmentalists, to promote alternatives to Cuba's nuclear reactor program that led two sons of Robert F. Kennedy to Havana last week. But when they and their old family nemesis Fidel Castro finally sat down to talk about energy and natural resources, a flood of historical memories was also unleashed.

title: The Nation;Abortion: the Rate Vs. the Debate
description: REPUBLICAN voters leaving polling places in New Hampshire on Tuesday were asked which one of seven campaign issues mattered themost to them. Two-thirds of the voters responded with the economy, taxes or the deficit. But the top social issue was abortion, cited more frequently than education, trade or the environment. And of the 9 percent of New Hampshire Republicans who said that abortion was the issue that mattered the most, 60 percent voted for Patrick J. Buchanan.

title: Working Hard, Out of Doors, For That Second Chance
description: ON a gray January day, when icy roads snarled morning traffic yet again, two vans full of young people left halfway houses in Hartford and New Haven headed for work at Sherwood Island State Park in Westport. No ordinary commuters, the young men and women were drug and alcohol offenders participating in a new, four-month residential treatment program built on the concept of giving something back to the community.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: DEMOCRACY AND TECHNOLOGY By Richard E. Sclove. Guilford, cloth, $42; paper, $18.95.

title: MARKET WATCH;Digital Reality Strikes Movieland
description: In the movie business, it still helps more than people here care to admit -- to be seen driving up to the right restaurant in the right car and greeting a powerful agent. But more and more, it helps to know your way around the new movie back lot -- a computer work station.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction;Angels of the Mourning
description: They wilt, they swoon, they languish. What's more, they're naked, or mostly naked, or at least some of them are. In his afterword to SAVING GRACES: Images of Women in European Cemeteries (Norton, cloth, $25; paper, $14.95), a collection of more than 100 of his black-and-white photographs of marble, stone and bronze maidens in various degrees of distress, David Robinson notes that these statues, most of them made in the mid- to late 19th century, serve as surrogate mourners and embody the Romantic notion of the link between love and death. And who can say him nay, especially after seeing the uninhibited figure from Genoa's Staglieno cemetery, passed out backward in apparent ecstasy, barely draped and with a posy of roses tucked in her armpit? Ecstatic, too, is the fully draped maiden in Pre Lachaise in Paris, about to be raised to heaven by a well-muscled angel who is hovering above her with a display of more than brotherly (or perhaps sisterly -- it's hard to tell) interest. But the high-relief carving of a kneeling nude in the Staglieno, roses held strategically in her lap, is as unemotional and non-erotic as could be. And how about the figure of the draped young girl in Paris's Passy cemetery who looks not only demure but totally unconcerned about such matters as love and death? No roses, but her attributes include a Greco-Etruscan helmet and a carved replica of a Bernard Palissy ceramic platter, which leads one to wonder whose monument this is, and why these particular artifacts are to the point. But why quibble? The photographs are beautiful, and beautifully reproduced. Sarah Ferrell

title: POSTINGS: Compromise on a Spiritual Center's Sale;Wainwright House Wins Reprieve in Rye
description: The waterfront complex of Wainwright House, an ethical and spiritual education center in Rye, N.Y., was about to be placed on the market earlier this month when an outcry from its advisers and honorary trustees managed to gain a compromise.

title: ON THE MAP;Trying to Save a Piece of Black History in Lawnside
description: As early as 1792, just two years after slavery was outlawed in New Jersey, an African-American community had coalesced at a place called Snow Hill. The town, one of the first in the United States to be organized and governed by free blacks, is now known as the borough of Lawnside.

title: Promise and Peril as Scouts Turn to Internet in Cookie Sale
description: That person in a brown uniform delivering Girl Scout cookies this year just might be a United Parcel Service worker, not a Brownie Scout.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 14 about Siberia located the city of Krasnoyarsk incorrectly. A reader's letter dated Jan. 31, initially misdirected at The Times, points out that it is east of the Urals, not west.

title: Gender Benders
description: GENDER, SEX AND SUBORDINATION IN ENGLAND 1500-1800 By Anthony Fletcher. Illustrated. 442 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $40.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COLLEGE POINT / FLUSHING;Social Worker's Arrest Is Criticized
description: When Chi Loek, a respected social worker, was charged this month with robbery and menacing with a weapon, his colleagues at the Chinese-American Planning Council quickly rallied to his support.

title: OUTDOORS;Unveiling a Whitetail Buck, in the Spirit of Boone and Crockett
description: For some, the star of the 19th annual fishing and outdoor exposition at Rockland Community College Field House in Suffern, N.Y., will be a magnificent whitetail buck shot in Saskatchewan, Nov. 23, 1993.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;In Cyberspace, Seeing the Forest for the Trees
description: PEOPLE ARE RIGHT TO FEAR the negative impact of cyberspace. When we can sit at our home PC's and call up a virtual town square, why should anyone bother to venture into the real-life -- or in cyberspeak, the RL -- public square? Why should dwindling public resources be used to keep RL streets clean, safe and attractive? Aren't we already close to auctioning off our public squares to private developers with the entertainment know-how to turn them into sanitized Public Square theme parks? Isn't this the tragic destiny post-modern architects are fated to embrace?

title: A Celebration of Green Things, in Art and From Real Life
description: WITH the arrival of the exhibition "Art in Bloom," a spring-like glow has descended on the Hurlbutt Gallery at the Greenwich Library.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Upholds Suspension of Jenkins
description: THE executive branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People last week upheld the suspension of Kenneth W. Jenkins, the former Yonkers branch president.

title: Legislators Seek Pay for Committee Work
description: MEMBERS of the Suffolk Legislature are wrestling with a bill to pay themselves for their committee work. And the Presiding Officer, Donald R. Blydenburgh, is puzzled by the opposition.

title: Sunday February 25, 1996: GAMESMANSHIP;I Spy, You Spy, We All Spy
description: The CD-ROM gamesters keep coming up with more multimedia bells and whistles while we await the virtual-reality body suits. In Activision's innovative Spycraft: The Great Game, Tom Clancy meets Myst. This post-cold-war technothriller uses everything from film clips to Web sites in creating a first-person experience as an American intelligence agent coping with the New World Order.

title: France to Form New Body To Further Protect Culture
description: The French Government, on a crusade to safeguard the country's culture from marauding forces of commercialism, has risen yet again to defend the national patrimony, setting up a foundation to involve the citizens directly in trying to protect some of the things that make France French.

title: NEW YORK RADIO;Happiness Is Hard to Find
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Henson Retiring After the Season
description: Confirming longstanding rumors about his retirement, Illinois Coach LOU HENSON announced yesterday that this season would be his last. Members of the Assembly Hall crowd in Champaign, Ill., gasped as Henson, 63, made the announcement just after his team's 91-86 victory over No. 18 Iowa.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD MUSCLE -- A special report.;In Era of Shrinking Budgets, Community Groups Blossom
description: In Fort Greene, Brooklyn, the residents of a housing project had had enough of the pockmarked patchwork of drug corners and shuttered stores, so they formed a neighborhood group, worked with housing police and got Government money to start a nightly patrol.

title: JAMES IS A GIRL
description: At 16, James has traveled and experienced more than most have in a lifetime. It is easy to blame her profession as a corrupting influence.

title: SOAPBOX;All for One, One for All
description: AT first it doesn't sound very cooperative, I admit. The day after the Regional Plan Association released its third long-range plan, warning of dire consequences if the people and governments of the tristate metropolitan region didn't work together to solve common problems, my office released a report that was sharply critical of the most important interstate agency we have: the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Phony Student Arrested Again at Princeton
description: Five years after Princeton University officials discovered that one of their students was using a phony identity, the man has resurfaced on campus, once again masquerading as someone else, the police said.

title: For Immigrant Maids, Not a Job but Servitude
description: The story of Etelbina Flores is the stuff of a television novela, a Spanish soap opera of a timid immigrant maid who toils in a wealthy suburban house for hourly wages too meager to buy a feather duster.

title: Diamond Speaks His Mind And Speaks Up for America
description: To the Editor:

title: Student Engineer at Helm
description: A student engineer was at the controls of the Southern Pacific freight train that derailed 15 miles south of Vail on Wednesday, killing him and the engineer, the lone surviving crew member has told investigators.

title: SCHOOLS;A Monitor on Gambling Becomes a Mentor for Newark's Schoolchildren
description: Jeannine LaRue has been a teacher, a lobbyist, an elected official and, most recently, a member of New Jersey's Casino Control Commission. But if she reinvented herself for each job, she has held fast to one personality trait: a penchant for challenging the system. As a lobbyist for the New Jersey Education Association, she fought for teachers' rights. As a casino commissioner, she exhorted casino executives to do more business with minority-owned firms. And now Ms. LaRue is preparing for what may be her most ambitious project yet.

title: Why the Party Can't Stop Buchanan
description: WHEN Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, was asked the day after the New Hampshire primary whether he could support Patrick J. Buchanan for President if Pitchfork Pat should win the party's nomination, he squirmed. Instead of answering directly, he said he had confidence in Republican voters' judgment.

title: Message Under the Message?
description: Some critics say Patrick J. Bu chanan's oratory is more than in tense; they say it is laced with code words to appeal to anti-Semitism and other forms of bigotry. Page 22.

title: WEDDINGS;Barbara A. Newcomb, Terry Coates
description: Barbara Ann Newcomb, a tax lawyer at the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company in Boston, was married yesterday to Charles Elting Coates 3d, a partner in the Greenwich, Conn., office of Whitman Breed Abbott & Morgan, a law firm. The Rev. Bryan Hehir, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Gail Faithfull, a Presbyterian minister, took part in the service.

title: Platforms Are the Priority For 72d Street Station
description: To the Editor:

title: QUICK BITE;The Power of a Steamy, Spicy Broth
description: Tom Shiao knows the body language by now at his Hunan House restaurant. On wintry nights, when a customer comes in with a red nose and watery eyes, stomping her feet and rubbing her hands, it's time for ginger soup.

title: Streetscapes: The Gotlieb Building at 32 East 58th Street;A Florist's Fantasy Is Blossoming Once Again
description: LAST month Louis Vuitton began to demolish the tiny, Victorian house at 17 East 57th Street to build another new tower. Thus midtown's collection of curiosities dwindles even further.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ELLEN'S CASE By Lois Metzger. 189 pp. New York: A Jean Karl Book/Atheneum Books for Young Readers. $16. (Ages 10 and up)

title: JAMES IS A GIRL
description: I hope the money holds out so if James has to go into rehab, she can at least get to the Betty Ford Center. She might find kindred spirits there, burnt-out former celebrities, sorting through the ashes of their 15 minutes of fame.

title: New Releases
description: 'PASSION FLOWER: FRED HERSCH PLAYS THE MUSIC OF BILLY STRAYHORN' Nonesuch

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;A Step Forward Into the Past in Paris
description: Opera lovers mourning the loss of Venice's Fenice, which burned down in January, can assuage their grief in Paris. On March 1 the Opera Garnier will reopen after more than a year of lavish renovations. And after nearly seven years of being dedicated solely to dance performances, since the opening of the Bastille Opera, the Garnier will once again stage operas. All but the main entrance of the Palais Garnier -- designed by the architect Charles Garnier, commissioned by Napoleon III and opened in 1875 -- has been closed for 16 months.

title: Exiles Say Cuba Downed 2 Planes And Clinton Expresses Outrage
description: Two small aircraft belonging to a Cuban refugee and exile assistance group based here were shot down by Cuban Air Force MIG jet fighters off the northern coast of Cuba on Saturday afternoon, American Government officials and survivors of the incident said tonight.

title: Barbara Howes, Poet and Editor, Dies at 81
description: Barbara Howes, a poet who was one of five finalists for the National Book Award in poetry last year for her book "Collected Poems 1945-1990," died in her sleep early yesterday at the Southwestern Vermont Medical Center in Bennington, Vt. She was 81 and lived on a farm in Pownal, Vt.

title: FILM VIEW;Pols as Rats, But With Feelings
description: I grew up thinking of American presidents as godlike. Or at least saintlike. And this is no exaggeration. A lot of us early boomers did, partly because of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, the hero of our parents generation who had not yet been demystified.

title: SPITFIRE GRILL';What's Wrong With Values?
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Midshipman Pleads Guilty to Drug Charges
description: A Naval Academy senior pleaded guilty on Friday to using the drug LSD and was sentenced to jail, forfeiture of all pay and dismissal from the service.

title: YOUR TAXES;Some New Tricks To Help Filers Avoid An Old Audit Trap
description: SHOW Amir Aczel your tax return and not only will he tell you if it was audited, but nine times out of 10, he says, he can tell you why.

title: NANA AND THE ANCHORMEN
description: I'd like to second Yoffe's call for a C-chip to block out CNN and C-Span from information overloaders like her grandmother. But why stop there?

title: Airline 'Bistro'
description: To the Editor: "Airline Food Keeps Shrinking" (Practical Traveler, Jan. 14) hit me right in the stomach. I travel regularly to and from San Diego, always via American Airlines. Recently, connecting in Chicago on my return trip, passengers were advised to pick up a "bistro lunch bag" as they boarded. The contents were one inedible roll filled with barely identifiable chicken strips, one chocolate cookie, one bag of chips and one small plastic container of . . . water.

title: Negro Leaguers
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Don't Neglect Refugees' Reproductive Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Wounded Child Leads Police To 4 Others in Abuse Case
description: A 13-year-old orphan girl who fled after three days of torture, beatings and repeated sexual abuse in the closet of a Brooklyn apartment led the police to four young children who were also being abused, investigators said yesterday.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: ABRAHAM'S PROMISE By Philip Jeyaretnam. University of Hawaii, paper, $10.95.

title: ON POLITICS;One Man's Battle To Stamp Out Nastiness
description: State Senator James E. McGreevey learned the painful way what can happen when tricks and attacks get out of hand during political contests.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD;ALSO AROUND TOWN
description: WORDS FOR THE ARTS New and used books on classical and contemporary art and architecture will be sold at the American Friends of the Courtauld Book Fair, to benefit the Witt Library of the Courtauld Institute of Art in London; Christie's East, 219 East 67th Street between Second and Third Avenues; Saturday, 10 A.M. to 3 P.M.; free; (212) 546-1026.

title: CHOICE TABLES;When in Tokyo ... Eat at a Department Store
description: ALTHOUGH retailers in Japan are struggling with a sluggish economy, department stores, called hyakkaten (shops of a hundred treasures), are still important community institutions. In addition to providing extraordinary service in the department store line, they display collections from major American and European museums, offer beauty salons staffed with experts in traditional dress, rent formal clothes, maintain photographic studios where tuxedo- or kimono-clad customers can have their portraits taken, and manage restaurants, lots of restaurants -- indeed, a dozen or more within a single store is not unusual. The menus are eclectic, though most serve some kind of yoshoku, or Western-style, cuisine. From the turn of this century on, the Japanese have been smitten with Western cooking, although many of the dishes that have evolved from this love affair, such as korokke (croquettes) or omuraisu (soft omelets filled with ketchup-flavored pilaf), may not slide easily down an American throat. The Japanese also enjoy chuka ryori (Chinese style) adaptations and their own native washoku cooking.

title: In the Region: Connecticut;Coping With the Big Headaches 'Big Boxes' Bring
description: DIFFERENT as they are from each other, urban Stamford and semirural Wallingford face the same issue -- what to do about an influx of "big-box" stores that they perceive as threatening their prized community characteristics.

title: TRACK AND FIELD;George Mason Sophomore Steals Show
description: But the athlete who sent the spectators into a frenzy was one of their own: a 20-year-old George Mason sophomore from Uganda named Julius Achon. The men's mile featured Niall Bruton, Marcus O'Sullivan, Terrance Herrington, Erik Nedeau and Jason Pyrah, but Achon, in only the second indoor race of his life, beat them all with a stunning last-lap kick.

title: The Koreans Are Coming! (But Where Are They Going?)
description: THE South Korean auto maker Kia -- rhymes with Pia, as in Zadora -- opened 35 dealerships this month in Florida, a state already sagging into the Caribbean from the weight of new-car lots.

title: Megan, Her Law And What It Spawned
description: GUESTS at the Megan Nicole Kanka Foundation Valentine Dance enter the Colonial Firehouse in Hamilton Township under a towering arch of red and white and pink balloons. The pink ones, which also adorn every table, are stamped with the words "Megan's Law." As diners prepare to tuck into their roast beef, Maureen Kanka, whose 7-year-old daughter's rape and murder inspired the law, steps up to the D.J.'s microphone.

title: DINING OUT;Casual in Greenwich: Pizza, Pizza, Pizza
description: THE name, Rosey Tomatoes Trattoria, conveys the spirit of this casual new restaurant in Greenwich: bright, cheerful, wholesome and, yes, rosie.

title: To Some, Messiah Is the Message;Media Campaign for Late Rabbi Divides Lubavitch Movement
description: It might have been the unveiling of a shiny new product, or the news conference of a smooth politician out to curry favor. At the back of a conference room in the Hilton Hotel in Manhattan were Perrier bottles and trays of pastries. At the front sat a television for the showing of a six-minute promotional bit that resembled a music video.

title: DINING OUT;Fresh Fish and Fresh Pasta in Harrison
description: THE food at Emilio can be so good that we almost forgive the practice that packs nonsmokers into dreary back rooms paneled with dark pine boards while smokers, a minority, enjoy the bright, airy space and considerable charm of the larger front room. (Avoid Emilio's Siberia -- a grim, gloomy alcove with a handful of tables under a large antlered deer's head.)

title: Prizing Ski Runs in the Northwest
description: I FIRST learned about Northwest skiing several years ago, when I moved from Chicago to Washington State. While hauling my life across the country, I began to pick out scores of little red skiers -- the symbol for ski resorts -- on the Rand McNally road atlas.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Melbourne
description: Because it does not have Sydney's beguiling harbor setting, Melbourne, it is said, has to work harder to win people over. Polished and cultured, it boasts numerous parks and roomy boulevards and an international mix of ethnic neighborhoods and restaurants. It's a city, too, where the ornate facades in an array of older architectural styles contrast sharply with a growing number of modern buildings.

title: COVER STORY;Just Trying to Be the Girl Next Door
description: SHE is the girl next door in television's most exclusive neighborhood, but lately Lea Thompson has been looking around for new digs. It's not the time slot. "God forbid," Ms. Thompson says.

title: CHATTER;Presidents, Best and Worst
description: Recently, we asked: Which President do you admire, most, or least, and why? Students at Midland Park High School had this to say:

title: Labor Uses An Old Idea To Recruit The Young
description: In a new program intended to change labor's image, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. plans to hire 1,000 college students and other young people as interns this summer to show them that the labor movement -- long identified with overpaid leaders and tired ideas -- can be filled with excitement and idealism.

title: WEDDINGS;Wilder O. Bishop, Jason R. Regalbuto
description: Wilder Osborn Bishop, the daughter of Mrs. Wynant D. Vanderpoel 3d of New York and Warner B. Bishop of Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Jason Robert Regalbuto, a son of Mrs. Robert R. Regalbuto of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., and the late Mr. Regalbuto. The Rev. Frank Lecheria performed the ceremony at St. Edward's Roman Catholic Church in Palm Beach.

title: Alsops' Fables
description: TAKING ON THE WORLD Joseph and Stewart Alsop -- Guardians of the American Century. By Robert W. Merry. Illustrated. 644 pp. New York: Viking. $34.95.

title: Forget Hype
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Tomb Fit for A Queen
description: EVERY traveler carries a mental list of the sites that have left their mark on the eye or the heart. Ancient Egypt, with its great reach for immortality, has always yielded many such places. Now Egypt has unveiled yet another treasure, a tomb in Luxor graced with paintings that in beauty and elegance surpass many other pharaonic works of art.

title: Adversaries On Logging Inch Closer In Conference
description: Delegates to a national conference on forest policies ended their deliberations today without resolving the most bitter disputes between environmentalists and the logging industry.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Listless St. John's Goes Down Easily In West Virginia
description: In what had to be its most dismal performance of the season, St. John's played with no enthusiasm and no determination. And yes, the Storm had no chance of beating the Mountaineers at the West Virginia University Coliseum here tonight.

title: THEATER;Being Offensive, With Elegance
description: WEIRD," exclaimed an audience member upon exiting from a recent performance of "Loot," by Joe Orton, at Hartford Stage. At least the weird-susceptible patron remained for the curtain calls; time was when a huffy departure during a Joe Orton play was the polite recourse of the offended.

title: THEATER;'The Last Man in Europe' at the Schoolhouse
description: IT is too easy to assume that 1984 the real year as well as the fictional doomsday -- has come and gone. Look again.

title: GARDENING;Some Tips for Maintaining Trees -- Indoors
description: TREES can and do grow indoors just about everywhere, from office building lobbies to homes. The choice of tree can be left to what a particular variety might offer in the way of decor.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Geena Clonan;Now There Is a Hall of Fame for Women
description: GEENA CLONAN is the founder and curator of the Connecticut Women's Hall of Fame, which will celebrate its second anniversary in May.

title: Dress Rehearsal
description: Appearing as themselves, four actresses of the New York stage sit for their portraits.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;In This Turnabout, Old Questions About Fair Play
description: Judy Akers was watching local TV two weeks ago in the living room of her bed-and-breakfast in Brookville, Kan., when the sportscaster crowed, "Jack's back," and faded to commercial. During that minute, Akers remembered that Coach Jack Hartman retired from Kansas State 10 years ago, full of glory. She also had a painful flashback: She saw herself skulking along a public hallway that ran above the gym, flattening herself against a bathroom door and peering down through an iron fence at Hartman's closed Wildcat practices. He was a great coach, and she had wanted to learn his techniques for penetrating zone defenses so she could teach them to her Wildkittens.

title: New Releases
description: AISHA KANDISHA'S JARRING EFFECTS: 'SHABEESATION' Rykodisc

title: BEST SELLERS: February 25, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

title: NANA AND THE ANCHORMEN
description: Thank you for Emily Yoffe's "Nana and the Anchormen" (Lives, Feb. 4). Yoffe made her point with wit and truth.

title: Eros Sleeps, but Never for Long
description: MAVERICK'S PROGRESS An Autobiography. By James Thomas Flexner. Illustrated. 510 pp. New York. Fordham University Press. $29.95.

title: POLITICS: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN;Candidate's Speech Is Called Code for Controversy
description: In his run for the Republican Presidential nomination, Patrick J. Buchanan has applied several labels to himself: conservative, populist, traditionalist. In a recent radio interview, he coined one that nobody would dispute.

title: DIARY
description: THE ECONOMY Cooling It at the Fed For the most part, this nation's scattered economy has a mind of its own. But if anyone can nudge it this way or that, it's the folks at the Federal Reserve. At the simplest level, the Fed's choice comes down to this: create jobs and risk inflation, or keep things cool and make the financial markets happy. President Clinton at first wanted a Fed vice chairman, Felix Rohatyn, who would come down on the side of jobs. But Republicans balked, so last week the ever-flexible Mr. Clinton reverted to the slow-and-steady approach. He gave Alan Greenspan a third term as chairman; picked Alice Rivlin, his budget director, as vice chairman, and named Laurence Meyer, an economic consultant, to fill a vacant slot. Those choices, Republicans quickly said, were more like it.

title: TELEVISION VIEW;The Verdict's Not In Quite Yet
description: Who killed, or at least seriously maimed, "Murder One"? Early last fall, the ABC series was basking in widespread acclaim. Before it even went on the air, TV Guide was hailing it as the best new show of the season. In no time at all, however, "Murder One" was floundering embarrassingly in the ratings. And it still is. Who's responsible? The prime-suspect list includes: the scheduling honchos at ABC; Steven Bochco, co-creator and executive producer; NBC's "E.R."; Daniel Benzali, star of "Murder One," and the O. J. Simpson trial. The answer could well be "all of the above."

title: February 18-24;A Concealed Gun Claims a Victim
description: When the Texas legislature decided last year to allow average citizens to carry concealed weapons for the first time in a century, proponents scoffed at the law's critics, who painted a horror scenario of minor fender-benders turning into deadly arguments.

title: What Some People Will Do To Block Local Opposition
description: To the Editor:

title: Trouble in Mexico
description: To the Editor: Your Jan. 21 Correspondent's Report, "How Risky Is Mexico?" discusses corruption and lack of adherence to seismic codes, but fails to mention the inability of Mexican authorities to respond quickly to emergencies. This is the most common complaint I have heard from friends who lived through the 1985 Mexico City quake.

title: SCHOOLS;One School's Expansion Mirrors a Growing Interest in Jewish Education
description: For years, pupils at the Joseph Kushner Hebrew Academy have yearned for more space. Their gymnasium also serves as a cafeteria and auditorium, and their synagogue has been the setting for banquets and plays. But this fall, the 400 children in pre-kindergarten through eighth grade will abandon the squat metal building for an enormous new school in nearby Livingston with a pillared facade, courtyards, playing fields, a swimming pool and a synagogue.

title: F.Y.I.
description: The Amiable Child

title: HOME CLINIC;Repairing Those Plaster Moldings
description: SOME older houses have plaster moldings and ornaments (also called enrichments) on the walls and ceilings. Homeowners who live in these homes are sometimes faced with the problem of repairing or restoring these beautiful decorations when they crack or break.

title: Keep Drug Users at Work, But Require Rehabilitation
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WILLIAMSBURG;Sandblasting Safety Tent Draws Critics
description: In the summer of 1992, when a city contractor began sandblasting on the Williamsburg Bridge, Susan Pellegrino watched in horror as dust with dangerous levels of lead doused her neighborhood. After she and her neighbors complained, the state ordered the work suspended.

title: Teaching Musicians How to Keep Their Bodies in Tune
description: LEARNING to play an instrument can be a struggle not only with notes and rhythms but also with aching arms, necks and backs. The pain may be caused by poor posture or unconscious tension. Some musicians have found relief -- and a path to better playing -- with the Alexander Technique, which stresses awareness of the body as a key to well being.

title: Fledgling Democracies Need U.S. Helping Hand
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MURRAY HILL;Barrooms Brawl Over Right to Be 'The Ginger Man'
description: When J. P. Donleavy wrote "The Ginger Man" in 1955, about a roguish but charming barfly, Sebastian Dangerfield, a friend of his told him the tale would go around the world like the Bible.

title: POLITICS: TRADE;Buchanan Threatens Longtime Bipartisan Policy, Official Warns
description: An American on the World Trade Organization's highest tribunal has warned that Patrick J. Buchanan's protectionist policies could undermine a half-century of bipartisan support for opening and regulating international trade.

title: Editorial Notebook: The Fallows Fallacy;A Plan for Turning Reporters Into Lackeys
description: It is always interesting to observe what journalists are reading on the campaign trail. "Primary Colors" is the required light reading, and this year's entry in the self-flagellation category is "Breaking the News: How the Media Undermine American Democracy," by James Fallows. Not since the publication of "Feeding Frenzy" by Larry Sabato in 1991 has there been a book more packed with bad advice for the serious journalist.

title: L.I. VINES
description: Gewurztraminer Palmer Vineyards, Aquebogue, 1994. Select Harvest. About $15 (half bottle).

title: FILM;Seberg, Through a Cracked Lens
description: The 1984 movie "This is Spinal Tap," a satirical look at a fictional rock-and-roll band, was called, for lack of a better term, a mockumentary. But what do you call a biographical film about a dead movie star that contains film clips of the star, is narrated by an actor playing her and contains words the star never uttered?

title: February 18-24;A Blast Stirs New Fears And Efforts for Irish Peace
description: For 17 months, a cease-fire held out hope for a peaceful solution to Northern Ireland's troubles. Last weekend, nine days after the Irish Republican Army announced an end to the cease-fire, any remaining hope was severely shaken by a blast on a double-decker bus in London's theater district.

title: February 18-24;Adieu to the Draft
description: To arms, citizens," calls the Marseillaise, but soon the French won't have to go.

title: New York Disclosure Law Snares a Schools Chief
description: Everyone agrees that Charles P. Skiptunas did the right thing when he forced a teacher he suspected of fondling a student to resign.

title: YOUR TAXES;A Step-by-Step Guide to Mastering the Form 1040
description: No matter how daunting a tax return may look, it is essentially based on two sets of numbers: income and deductions. Overlook any income -- say reinvested mutual fund dividends -- and the I.R.S. is likely to demand its due. Overlook any deductions, and you won't hear a peep, but you'll overpay your taxes. A tax professional or a good computer program can put the numbers in the right places on the forms, but it is up to the taxpayer to provide all the numbers.

title: FOOD;Loco for Cocoa
description: Hot chocolate, it seems to me, is the only reasonable response to the implacable winter of 1996. It speaks to the heart and the senses, and in that way is very infantile. To heed its call is to satisfy a simple, uncomplicated hunger.

title: February 18-24;A Bad Month on the Rails
description: On the nation's railroads, bad news has come in sixes this month.

title: In Auctions Of Airwaves, The Sky Seems To Be the Limit
description: As Assistant Secretary of Commerce under President George Bush, Janice Obuchowski was a passionate evangelist for what was then a radical idea: selling licenses to the nation's airwaves through auctions, rather than giving them away free.

title: Times Co. Appointments
description: its president, James W. FitzGerald, announced. Robert Carney was promoted to vice president for special services, which includes foreign licensing and electronic media, from director of those operations. Theresa McCann, formerly national travel and resort manager for Golf Digest, was named vice president and director of sales for Golf Digest Information Systems. Donna Doherty, editor of Tennis magazine, and Robert Sauerberg Jr., controller of the group, added the title of vice president.

title: In Immigration Bill Debate, Divisions and Odd Alliances
description: Congress will begin final debate this week on the most restrictive immigration laws in 30 years and the first cuts in the number of foreigners entering the country legally since the 1920's.

title: Trade Protectionist Rhetoric Didn't Start With Bill Clinton;Campaign Report
description: To the Editor:

title: Commitments, and Questions, on Electronic Newspapers
description: Newspapers might be cutting costs and trimming staffs, but the prospect of selling their news and advertising over the Internet has opened their purses, even though no one yet knows how, or even whether, today's plans to publish on the World Wide Web will ever make money.

title: HOCKEY;Palffy's Points and Penalty Killing Liven Up Isles
description: Zigmund Palffy of the Islanders scored one power-play goal and assisted on another this afternoon, but his other skills also helped fashion a 2-0 victory over Edmonton at Nassau Coliseum.

title: CLINTON CONSIDERS PUNISHING CUBANS FOR PLANE ATTACK
description: The United States called an emergency meeting of the United Nations Security Council today as President Clinton weighed retaliating against Cuba for downing two civilian aircraft carrying anti-Castro Cuban-Americans.

title: Cases of Rare Nerve Illness in Bergen County Puzzle Experts
description: Six-year-old Valerie Pickett went sledding with friends in the foot of new snow last Saturday. That night, she told her mother, Julie, that her fingers felt "tight and dry."

title: Better Tools Needed on China
description: China's brazen export to Pakistan of magnets used in nuclear bomb production is creating more problems for the Clinton Administration than it has for Beijing. That is because Washington now finds itself with no credible way to respond that does not also inflict serious harm on United States business interests.

title: World News Briefs;Turkish Rightists Reopen Talks to Form Cabinet
description: Turkey's two major conservative parties met today to revive efforts to form a coalition after talks between an Islamic party and one of the conservative parties collapsed.

title: How Other Cities Succeed: Five Ideas to Revitalize New York's Region: Business Districts; Suburban Tokyo Focuses Inward
description: New York has assimilated millions of people and dozens of dizzyingly diverse cultures from around the world over the years, but it has never made much effort to borrow or imitate how other places solve their problems. The experience of the city and the surrounding region was always considered singular -- the problems were bigger, the political dynamic was different. Or perhaps the region was just too proud. New York was No. 1, and who could have anything to teach it?

title: Give Them the Maximum;Small Towns Clamor for the Boon a Big Prison Could Bring
description: Richard Smullen, Supervisor of this upstate mill town, got all worked up the other day when he heard that the state might build a maximum-security prison here to house murderers, rapists and the like.

title: U.S. Tool Orders Up 23% in January
description: Orders for American-made industrial tools surged during January from the previous month, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said, suggesting that capital investment by businesses continues to boom.

title: BASKETBALL;Kukoc Is Big Gun As Bulls Beat Magic
description: Bulls 111, Magic 91

title: How Other Cities Succeed: Five Ideas to Revitalize New York's Region: Greenbelt; Necklace of Space Rings Golden Gate
description: New York has assimilated millions of people and dozens of dizzyingly diverse cultures from around the world over the years, but it has never made much effort to borrow or imitate how other places solve their problems. The experience of the city and the surrounding region was always considered singular -- the problems were bigger, the political dynamic was different. Or perhaps the region was just too proud. New York was No. 1, and who could have anything to teach it?

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Grandma Just Won't Take It Anymore
description: Mom is getting mauled on television these days. The old apple-pie images are are at a premium in prime time. Coming to a conclusion tonight on NBC is "Seduced by Madness," starring Ann-Margret as a Wisconsin teacher who gets three students to kill her wimpy husband. And ABC's "Kidnapping in the Family" offers Kate Jackson, once a glamourpuss on "Charlie's Angels," as a shrewish control-freak mom who kidnaps her own daughter's son. She also lives in Wisconsin. Make of that what you will

title: Cozumel Journal;Where Cruise Liners Intrude, Nafta Tests Waters
description: The reef is named Paradise, and it is an underwater heaven to a host of colorful sea creatures and the scuba divers who love to see them up close.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Astronauts have been known to take objects with personal meaning with them on missions into space, but it is unlikely that anyone has ever taken a Tarnhelm, the magical hood worn in Wagner's "Ring of the Nibelung" before.

title: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
description: Guillain-Barre syndrome is the most common sudden cause of serious and potentially fatal nerve damage in the United States. It strikes about 4,000 Americans a year, and has an incidence rate of 1 to 2 per 100,000 people in the United States.

title: Taking In the Sites;That Other Mouse, Now on the Web
description: Media conglomerates sometimes move at the speed of glaciers, so it is no surprise that some major media companies are only now putting up Web sites. But in at least a few cases, it appears the delay has enabled the latecomers to learn lessons from earlier media sites and allowed them to take advantage of the latest eye-catching (and ear-grabbing) Web technology.

title: No Headline
description: We're the new liberals of the Republican Party. Can you imagine that?"

title: Getting Rid Of Badges That Seem Like Targets
description: Every day before he leaves his home, Richard Heidemann performs a ritual of survival: he applies a Band-Aid next to his left eye and pulls on a long-sleeve shirt, even on the hottest days.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;State May Owe You Money
description: Every year, banks and other institutions turn over about $50 million in uncashed money orders, payroll checks and traveler's checks to the Treasury Department's division of taxation, where the money is placed in interest-bearing accounts.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Lorin Duckman, the Brooklyn Criminal Court Judge who has been under harsh attack for his handling of two domestic violence cases, misstated the position taken by Borough President Ruth Messinger of Manhattan. Ms. Messinger called for the judge's suspension pending the outcome of an inquiry into allegations that he had beaten his wife; she did not call for the judge's removal.

title: Essay;The New Socialism
description: A specter is haunting free enter prisethe specter of the New Socialism.

title: In America;Double Exploitation
description: With the show's rat-a-tat theme music blaring in the background, the television announcer, already planning future shows, says to the national viewing audience: "Is your teen daughter obsessed with sex? If so, call us at 800-93-SALLY and tell us about her."

title: HORSE RACING NOTEBOOK;Built for Pleasure Lazes (and Dazes)
description: Built for Pleasure, the 143-1 shot who scrambled the traffic on the road to the Kentucky Derby when he won the Fountain of Youth Stakes, lay down in his stall at Gulfstream Park today and took a nap while everybody else tried to figure out what his dazzling upset meant in the Triple Crown sweepstakes.

title: Simpson Reaches Accord With Citrus Board
description: O. J. Simpson and the Florida Department of Citrus reached an agreement last week to share marketing rights to the initials O. J.

title: At 89, Willing and Able
description: With a Ph.D. from Yale University, Dr. James I. McKinney, 89, has lived a life of the mind, teaching philosophy at universities and writing books.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Jury Selection in Guards' Case
description: Jury selection is scheduled to begin today in the trial of three Hudson County jail guards accused of robbing a safe containing $1,000 worth of crack cocaine and $125 in cash. Prosecutors said the November 1993 armed robbery took place at the Jersey City home of two drug dealers. The jail has been under state control since a raid last month by a state task force turned up drugs and other contraband in the jail.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Rock Star At the End Of the Road
description: Among role models in the art of self-destruction, Janis Joplin now ranks right up there with Elvis, Marilyn and the Jameses, Morrison and Dean. At Performance Space 122, the Southern Comfort-voiced singer shows up as the ghostly (but definitely carnal) muse of a rock star manque in "Distortion Taco: Analog Hunger in a Digital World," Stephen Brantley's ode to the joys of being young and suicidal.

title: Silicon Graphics Reported Ready to Rescue Cray
description: Silicon Graphics Inc., a leader in 3-D computer work stations, will announce today that it plans to acquire control of the struggling supercomputer maker Cray Research Inc., according to people familiar with the deal.

title: Dr. Rolla Bennett Hill, Pathologist, 66
description: Dr. Rolla Bennett Hill, a former chairman of the pathology department at the Upstate Medical Center of the State University of New York at Syracuse, died on Feb. 12 at a retirement home in Philo, Calif. He was 66.

title: Japan Hints at Shift In Copyright Dispute
description: Japan's Prime Minister, moving to avoid an embarrassing international battle, has signaled that his Government may soon extend copyright protection to music recordings made between 1946 and 1971.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-7

title: Looking Elsewhere For Ways to Improve
description: Many New Yorkers may believe they live in the world's premier metropolis, but the Regional Plan Association says the city can learn from the achievements of others, like London, which is known for its efficient mass transit. A look at five cities and their successes.

title: BASKETBALL;Fill-In Knicks Flop on Center Stage
description: With J. R. Reid starting at center and misplacing his aggression, and Coach Don Nelson's collection of temp workers playing full-time minutes, Charles Barkley surveyed the situation today and declared the Knicks will get to the second round of the playoffs if they possess one necessary component:

title: George Russell, 90, Ex-Official of G.M.
description: George Russell, a former vice chairman of General Motors Corporation, died on Wednesday at the Palm Beach Gardens Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 90.

title: Farrakhan Attacks Critics of His Trip
description: Louis Farrakhan, unrepentant today after his 18-nation trip that included stops in Iraq and Libya, called his critics liars today and said his trip was about peace and responsibility.

title: Dissent Doesn't Stop Guests at Confederate Ball From Whirling theNight Away
description: Rebel yells echoed through a restored Civil War cannon foundry this weekend as revelers rattled their sabers and tossed gray cavalry caps high with Southern pride during a Confederate ball that black leaders called a symbol of white defiance.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Student Killed in Blast in Israel
description: A 23-year-old student from Teaneck and her 25-year-old boyfriend were among 25 people killed yesterday when a bomb ripped through a packed city bus.

title: Satellite and Plans Are Adrift As a Stringlike Tether Snaps
description: Speeding around Earth at nearly five miles a second and working by remote control late yesterday, seven astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia were slowly unreeling from the shuttle's payload bay a long cable topped by a half-ton satellite when the tether, about 12 miles out and nearing its maximum extension of nearly 13 miles, suddenly and mysteriously broke in two.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Colleges Sign Tentative Pact
description: Negotiators for faculty members at eight New Jersey state colleges and Montclair State University said they had reached a tentative contract agreement and had canceled a strike deadline scheduled for Thursday.

title: Man Who Posed as Lawyer To Get Five Years' Probation
description: A man who posed as a lawyer and deceived authorities and clients while working as a public defender for two years will receive five years' probation under the terms of a plea agreement.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Not Flying High Enough on May Day
description: Remember Francis Gary Powers? He became an incident in the cold war on May 1, 1960, when his plane, the supersecret U-2, was shot down over the Soviet Union. "Spy in the Sky" finds unexpected ironies in the story of what he was doing up there.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Arson Is Suspected in Blaze
description: Some offices in a Somerset County complex, including an abortion clinic, were damaged in a fire Saturday, and authorities said they believed the blaze was deliberately set, the A.P. reported yesterday. Investigators are trying to determine if the clinic, Gyn Choices of Central Jersey, was the intended target of the fire, said Melaine Campbell, the Acting County Prosecutor. The clinic has been picketed in the past, the police said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;The Mysteries of Tigers, Rivaled by Those of Men
description: OF TIGERS AND MEN Entering the Age of Extinction By Richard Ives 304 pages. Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $24.95.

title: How Other Cities Succeed: Five Ideas to Revitalize New York's Region: Regional Plans; One Government For 3 Counties
description: New York has assimilated millions of people and dozens of dizzyingly diverse cultures from around the world over the years, but it has never made much effort to borrow or imitate how other places solve their problems. The experience of the city and the surrounding region was always considered singular -- the problems were bigger, the political dynamic was different. Or perhaps the region was just too proud. New York was No. 1, and who could have anything to teach it?

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Aid for Addiction Program
description: The Casino Association of New Jersey, a trade group representing 11 of the 12 Atlantic City casinos, is seeking a new way to subsidize an organization that provides referral, educational and addiction treatment services for problem gamblers. The group, the Council on Compulsive Gambling, had its 1996 budget reduced to $75,000 from an average of $500,000 over the last three years.

title: Bridge
description: One of the most respected figures in the world of bridge was successful Saturday in a highly sociable event that is believed to be unique in North America: the Betty Kaplan Teams, in which a four-person team is required to rotate partnerships. Edgar Kaplan of Manhattan, editor of The Bridge World, a winner of many national titles, and the acknowledged authority on the laws of bridge, won the event, named for his late wife, for the third time.

title: POLITICS;In Their Own Words
description: LAMAR ALEXANDER

title: Ford Move on Natural Gas
description: The Ford Motor Company is adding vehicles powered by natural gas to the fleet of cars and trucks driven by its employees while on the job. Helen Petrauskas, Ford's vice president for environmental and safety engineering, said 10 percent of the vehicles ordered for the company fleet this year would run on natural gas. The goal is to have 30 percent of the 4,000-vehicle fleet using natural gas by 1998. The program involves Ford Tauruses, Crown Victorias, F-Series pickups and Econoline vans. They will be used first in southeastern Michigan and Southern California.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Bill to Bar Accused Judges
description: Eyebrows were raised recently when a judge accused of stealing $173,000 tried to take advantage of a pretrial intervention program for first-time offenders. Under the program, a defendant may be allowed to avoid a criminal record by agreeing before the trial to be supervised by the court for a specified period of time. If all goes well, the charges are erased. Today, the State Senate will consider a bill to bar judges, prosecutors and -- yes -- legislators from the record-expunging program.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Seiniger Unit Gets Hitachi PC Account
description: The Hitachi PC Corporation in San Jose, Calif., a unit of Hitachi Ltd., named the Seiniger Technology division of the Seiniger Advertising Group in Beverly Hills, Calif., to introduce a notebook computer focused on the communications environment. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: BASEBALL;$20 Million Man Takes a Shot on the Shoulder
description: Kenny Rogers saw the blurry white baseball buzzing toward him and knew he had to react to keep from getting hurt.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: WEEKEND

title: World News Briefs;Russian Forces to Leave Republic of Ingushetia
description: Russian officials promised today to withdraw their troops from Ingushetia, a tiny republic that borders the separatist region of Chechnya, Ingush officials said.

title: World News Briefs;Bangladesh Strikes Back At Protest Strikers
description: At least 200 people were injured in fighting today as the Government cracked down on the leaders of a protest campaign.

title: Britain Doesn't Insist On Irish Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: Family Planning Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: A Supercomputer's Suitor Silicon Graphics, a leader in 3-D computer work stations, plans to acquire control of Cray Research, the embattled maker of supercomputers. Page D1.

title: BOMBINGS IN ISRAEL: THE OVERVIEW;2 Suicide Bombings in Israel Kill 25 and Hurt 77, Highest Such Toll
description: A six-month lull in terror attacks in Israel was shattered in the early morning today when militant Muslim suicide bombers detonated pipe bombs in Jerusalem and Ashkelon, killing 25 people and wounding 77, some critically. Among the dead were two Americans.

title: Drug Incident Shakes a School Campus
description: Nestled since 1909 in the sheltering hills of western Massachusetts, the Berkshire School has earned a reputation as one of the more nurturing private secondary schools in New England.

title: Kabul Offers Power-Share
description: The Afghan Government, under siege by a militant Islamic faction, has offered to share power with another opposition faction, both sides said today.

title: BASEBALL;Thompson Hurts Hamstring Right Off the Bat in Camp
description: When outfielder Ryan Thompson arrived at the Mets' spring camp last week, he said his often troubled hamstrings were in the best condition of his career. A rigorous off-season workout program had supposedly made them stronger and more resilient.

title: BASKETBALL;Nets Survive the Celtics' Charge and Get Back on Track
description: The Nets responded, just as their coach, Butch Beard, thought they would. Then, they nearly gave it all away.

title: POLITICS;Washington Governor Will Not Run Again
description: Gov. Mike Lowry, after settling a sexual harassment case and now facing poor standings in the polls, said on Thursday that he would not run for re-election this fall.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL;An N.C.A.A. First For All-Round Player
description: ANITA MAXWELL says she hasn't fully grasped the meaning of her milestone. The New Mexico State athlete has become the first player in National Collegiate Athletic Association history -- men's or women's -- to score 2,500 points, grab 1,000 rebounds and make 300 steals in a collegiate career.

title: Trade Protectionist Rhetoric Didn't Start With Bill Clinton;No 'Informal Adviser'
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE REVIEW;Today's Lost and Evil Child Anxiously Foresees a Future
description: Following Lynn Shapiro into the heart of her dances is a little like the trip through the overgrown forest to find the Sleeping Beauty. One pushes through to the clearing to find strange dreams and memories. That was the case with "Jynxed," a program presented by Ms. Shapiro and her impressive performers on Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Cray Research Inc., Eagan, Minn., to Marsteller Advertising, New York, a division of the Burson-Marsteller unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., to handle the computer company's advertising and public relations accounts, which were previously inactive. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million. Mattel Inc., El Segundo, Calif., to Foote, Cone & Belding, Los Angeles, a unit of True North Communications, to introduce the Mighty Ducks action figures based on characters from the Walt Disney Co. Foote, Cone already handles several Mattel brands, including Hot Wheels. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: Oracle Will Ship New Data Base Software
description: The Oracle Corporation, continuing its emphasis on making information storehouses more accessible over computer networks, plans on Monday to begin shipping a new version of its industry-leading Oracle 7 data base software program.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 13 about the New York State Legislature's override of Gov. George E. Pataki's veto of a police-arbitration bill, and a related article about the history of such votes, misstated the record of past overrides in this century. There have been three -- not one -- all during the administration of Gov. Hugh L. Carey.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Serge Sabarsky, 83, Art Dealer And Expert on Expressionism
description: Serge Sabarsky, an internationally known art dealer and leading authority on German and Austrian Expressionist art, died on Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 83 and lived in Manhattan.

title: POLITICS: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN;Appealing to Gun Owners and Perot Camp
description: In full cry, Patrick J. Buchanan called on two of his important constituencies today, gun owners and supporters of Ross Perot, warning each group that what they valued most was in danger of being stripped away.

title: BOMBINGS IN ISRAEL: VICTIMS;2 Students Found Faith, Love and Death
description: They were in love with their faith and with each other, and they died together as the victims of hate.

title: 8 Christians Killed in Egypt; Militants Suspected
description: In a new surge of violence, masked gunmen thought to be Muslim militants have shot dead 8 Coptic Christians in an ambush in southern Egypt, bringing to 26 the number of people killed in less than two weeks.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Heineken Account Now Under Review
description: Heineken USA and Ross Roy Communications in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., a unit of the Omnicom Group, have agreed to end their nine-month relationship on the Murphy's Irish Stout and Buckler non-alcoholic brands, effective immediately. Billings were not disclosed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;J. Walter Thompson Quits Boston Market
description: Just days after the Boston Market restaurant chain acknowledged discussions with several agencies for additional creative resources, its agency of record, J. Walter Thompson New York, said on Friday that it had resigned the estimated $30 million account, after only 10 months.

title: BASKETBALL;Huskies Set Sights Beyond Big East
description: Their work completed with a far greater degree of resolve than artistry, the Connecticut Huskies left the court at the Spectrum today without the emotional embraces that once accompanied the best record in the Big East. Connecticut's resourceful 70-59 victory over Villanova secured an unprecedented, if unofficial, third consecutive regular-season championship. The Huskies took an essential step toward a potential No. 1 seeding in the national collegiate tournament and restored a sense of assertiveness that had vanished in their loss at Georgetown last Monday.

title: SKIING;Tomba Conquers the Worlds
description: Alberto Tomba called winning at the world Alpine skiing championships tougher than winning an Olympic gold medal. At least for him, it took longer.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FIGURE SKATING;Appearance Limits?
description: The president of the International Skating Union says his organization may consider limiting the number of appearances by its competitors in order to conserve the quality and integrity of the sport.

title: Philippine Leaders Celebrate Freedom to Squabble
description: Almost everyone, it seems, has a bad word to say about someone as the Philippines celebrates the 10th anniversary of one of the glowing moments in its history, the popular uprising that came to be known as People Power.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Health Advertising Is Focus of Moves
description: Two agencies have announced initiatives in health care advertising.

title: C.I.A. Should Use Whatever Cover It Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;A Toast to the Tap
description: It may be of little consequence to gamblers, but Atlantic City made news of another sort last weekend when it beat out 33 other municipalities to win the top prize for the best-tasting tap water. It was the third time in six years that Atlantic City has won the contest, which is sponsored by the tourist office in Berkeley Springs, W.Va. Judges who gathered in West Virginia's eastern panhandle for the competition evaluated the water for appearance, scent and flavor, the A.P. reported. The second prize went to Huntington Station, L.I. TERRY PRISTIN

title: A New New York Partnership
description: News that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Gov. George Pataki have developed an amicable working relationship should come as a relief to New York City residents. During the last gubernatorial election, Mr. Giuliani astonished New Yorkers with his gutsy endorsement of Mario Cuomo. But when Mr. Pataki won anyway, the Mayor's constituents felt like losers in a particularly nasty civil war, waiting for the army of occupation to arrive.

title: I.R.A. Violence Protested In Rallies North and South
description: Tens of thousands of men, women and children here in the Irish Republic and in the British province of Northern Ireland marched, chanted, sang and shouted a message to the Irish Republican Army today: You do not represent us, and you must immediately stop your campaign of violence.

title: POLITICS: STEVE FORBES;Delaware Backs Him Because He Was There
description: Absentee candidates proved no more popular with Delaware voters than absentee landlords, and that was the most important factor in Steve Forbes's victory in this state's second-in-the-nation Presidential primary on Saturday, according to a survey of voters leaving the polls.

title: BASKETBALL;Jaspers Find Their Form At Right Time of Year
description: When its two starting guards were exiled in mid-December, the Manhattan men's basketball team could have thrown in the towel. Instead, the Jaspers learned to win in a new way, and now they are headed into next weekend's Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament with a seven-game winning streak.

title: HOCKEY;For Leetch to Be the Best, Add One Missing Ingredient
description: Coach Colin Campbell of the Rangers does not use the word superstar frivolously. That is why he calls defenseman Brian Leetch a near superstar. But Campbell is clearly convinced that Leetch can supplant Boston's Ray Bourque as the National Hockey League's next great defenseman.

title: Minds of the Elderly May Be More Agile Than Was Thought
description: The conventional image of the aging brain is that people lose neurons the way balding men lose hair. Brain cells are supposed to start falling away around the age of 20, with everything downhill from there. Some people go bald, or senile, early. Some lucky and unusual ones keep their hair, or their wits, about them into their 90's and beyond.

title: Metro Matters;Judge Seen As a Symptom Of a Failed Law
description: MAYBE they should call it Galina's Law. Perhaps that's the only way a proposal to toughen New York's domestic violence laws will ever get anywhere.

title: BASKETBALL;Victory for Lady Jaspers
description: Gina Somma had 38 points, 11 rebounds, 5 steals and 4 assists yesterday as host Manhattan beat Fairfield, 105-91. The Lady Jaspers completed their regular season at 16-10 over all and 11-3 in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference. Manhattan will enter next weekend's conference tournament seeded No. 2.

title: On-Line Services Join Indecency-Law Suit
description: Asserting that the boundaries of free speech in the 21st century are at stake, more than 20 corporate and trade organizations have initiated a major legal challenge to the new Communications Decency Act.

title: POLITICS: FACES IN THE CROWD;At Rallies for Buchanan, Fervent Supporters Are Part of the Show, Too
description: Rob Manes showed up 30 minutes early for the first political rally of his life the other night at the Woodard Junior High School here. Even then, there was not a seat left in the house, so Mr. Manes folded his 72-year-old frame onto a baby-blue blanket he had carefully placed on the linoleum floor, and leaned forward, a toothpick sticking out of his mouth and a railroad cap perched atop his head.

title: Orioles Suit Up for Success
description: As a member of the 1971 Baltimore Orioles, Pat Dobson holds a special place in franchise history. That season Dave McNally, Mike Cuellar, Jim Palmer and Dobson gave the Orioles four 20-game winners, a feat achieved only one other time in baseball history. Twenty-five years later, Dobson has returned to the team as its pitching coach.

title: Anna Larina, 82, the Widow Of Bukharin, Dies in Moscow
description: Anna Mikhailovna Larina, the widow of Nikolai I. Bukharin, a father of the Bolshevik Revolution who was executed under Stalin, and herself a survivor of the Soviet gulag, died of lung cancer here on Saturday, her daughter, Nadezhda Fadeyeva, said. She was 82.

title: Patents;In a throwaway culture, consider the reusable coffin. (Calm your sensibilities;  it's less expensive.)
description: COFFINS can be the costliest part of a funeral, yet few people are willing to settle their loved ones in a plain pine box. Instead, most honor their dead in coffins made with fine wood, ornate carving or moldings, and expensive hardware. That can bring the cost to thousands of dollars.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: POP
description: A Step Into the Past, Presented in Darkness Diamanda Galas Knitting Factory

title: POLITICS: THE PRIMARY SPRINT;COMING PRIMARIES ARE UP FOR GRABS AFTER MIXED VOTE
description: As the Republican Presidential race enters its most consequential and chaotic phase, the combination of an unexpectedly competitive field and the most accelerated schedule of contests ever in American politics has thrown the competition in several pivotal states into a virtual free-for-all.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The theme of a benefit performance tonight for the Authors Guild Foundation is "Minor Characters Step Into the Spotlight," a topic on which SCOTT TUROW is particularly well qualified.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;Johnson's Powerful Message Is Delivered Off the Court
description: A COUNSELOR for a Boston neighborhood health center recently told The Boston Herald that Magic Johnson's return to basketball is sending a dangerous message to children about AIDS, abstinence and safe sex. "The kids see a guy running up and down the court and think if they get H.I.V., they can still play basketball and chase girls," said the counselor, Robert Johnson.

title: Jordan Condemns Killing of Iraqi Defectors
description: King Hussein of Jordan today condemned the killing of two Iraqi defectors he had sheltered, and predicted that his former ally, Saddam Hussein, would not remain in power.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;TV Nourishes the Appetite Of Conspiracy Enthusiasts
description: To enjoy some of the quirkiest television shows of the season, it helps to believe that the Government is out to get you. Or maybe it's not the Government, just some shadowy organization so powerful it makes the United States Government seem like Little Bo Peep. Either way, the most provocative trend is the conspiracy series, in which spunky heroes fight a mysterious Big Brother.

title: Abroad at Home;Voice of America?
description: On its cover this week The Economist, Britain's leading weekly, has a picture of Pat Buchanan. Next to it a headline asks, "Voice of America?" It is a good question, and a serious one.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;No Room for Thuggery In This Physical Game
description: A. C. Green was already on his way for medical treatment by the time yesterday's Knicks-Suns game ended. Instead of being remembered for basketball, this game will be remembered for the vicious forearm that J. R. Reid delivered to Green's mouth, the forearm that knocked two of Green's teeth to the floor.

title: POLITICS: LAMAR ALEXANDER;Behind the Flannel Shirt, Deep Washington Roots
description: Lamar Alexander learned early on that an association with Washington could be a political liability.

title: In Giving, Better Late Than Never
description: Early this month, Nina and Joel Ackerman sent $500 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, along with a confessional note.

title: 60-M.P.H. Winds Kill Three and Cause Severe Damage
description: Fierce winds that whipped to more than 60 miles per hour caused at least three deaths in the metropolitan region yesterday along with severe damage to some homes and businesses, as gusts uprooted trees, peeled roofs away and contributed to the collapse of at least two buildings in Brooklyn.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Debut at Carnegie Hall At the Unlikely Age of 72 Menahem Pressler, pianist

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the plans of H.& R. Block Inc. to spin off its Compuserve unit misspelled the name of another business-oriented on-line service. It is Lexis/Nexis.

title: Computer That Thinks
description: To the Editor:

title: Promoting Basketball In the Home of Cricket
description: If basketball reflects the American dedication to the pursuit of happiness, then traditional English sports demonstrate the British devotion to the pursuit of self-denial.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: POP
description: A Scotswoman Frightens And Then Wonders Why

title: THEATER REVIEW;Two Characters in Search of Meanings
description: Two men, strangers to each other, identified only as the Dealer and the Client, meet under the cover of urban night. The Dealer (Patrice Chereau) is a stocky fellow in an overcoat that looks to be one size too big. He moves quickly and talks fast, as if he had said everything countless times before. His is a spiel of Jesuitical intensity. He's a hustler who seems ever on the edge of attack, but at the beginning he's satisfied to read the other man's thoughts.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Cowles Media Makes Acquisition
description: Cowles Business Media, a unit of the Cowles Media Company in Stamford, Conn., that publishes trade magazines like Inside Media, has agreed to acquire Promo Magazine and related assets of Smith Communications Inc. in Norwalk, Conn. Terms were not disclosed. Kerry E. Smith, 57, the editor and publisher of Promo, and his son, Kerry J. Smith, 32, the managing editor, are to continue to oversee editorial content and develop related properties.

title: POLITICS: BOB DOLE;In Visit to Arizona, Senator Emphasizes Goldwater Roots
description: In an effort to shore up his support among Arizona's fiercely conservative voters, Bob Dole traveled today to the shadow of the craggy peaks of the McDowell Mountains to receive the blessing of the Republican Party's longtime Mr. Conservative, former Senator Barry Goldwater.

title: Failure to Make Trains Safer Is a Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: That Elusive Butterfly, Gender Equality
description: To the Editor:

title: How Other Cities Succeed: Five Ideas to Revitalize New York's Region: Transportation; A Pass for Riders All Over London
description: New York has assimilated millions of people and dozens of dizzyingly diverse cultures from around the world over the years, but it has never made much effort to borrow or imitate how other places solve their problems. The experience of the city and the surrounding region was always considered singular -- the problems were bigger, the political dynamic was different. Or perhaps the region was just too proud. New York was No. 1, and who could have anything to teach it?

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SOCCER;Lalas Is Leaving Italy
description: ALEXI LALAS closed his stint as the first American-born player in the prestigious Italian League yesterday in Padua, but didn't get into his club's game.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: On-Line Companies Join To Oppose Decency Law Asserting that the boundaries of free speech are at stake, more than 20 corporate and trade organizations have initiated a major legal challenge to the new Communications Decency Act. The lawsuit is expected to be filed today in United States District Court in Philadelphia, and consolidated with an earlier lawsuit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union and a dozen other free-speech groups.

title: U.S. Treasury Schedules Weekly Sales of Bills
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, as well as two- and five-year notes and a 52-week bill being auctioned tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday, respectively.

title: No Consensus On TV's Efforts To Rate Content
description: As television industry leaders prepare to meet President Clinton on Thursday to discuss ways to make broadcasting more "family friendly," politics has scrambled the signals.

title: Bitter Feuds Split G.O.P. In Queens and Brooklyn
description: As they looked out at a panoramic view of the city, Queens Republicans had a lot to celebrate at their annual dinner: a Republican Governor, a Republican in Gracie Mansion, several strongholds around the city and fertile ground for future success. But that Republican Mayor was among the many boycotting the affair, and some of those who did attend were angry.

title: An Aerial Assault On the Wired Nation
description: Jim Robbins is a cable television executive, but these days he sounds more like the cellular telephone billionaire Craig O. McCaw.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Of African Descent, Purely Brazilian
description: Anyone who still thinks the dulcet tones of girls from Ipanema represent all of Brazil would have a change of heart, or pulse rate, after the New York debut of the Bale Folc lorico da Bahia at City Center on Friday night.

title: Failure to Make Trains Safer Is a Crime;Plan for Human Error
description: To the Editor:

title: Norman Harvey, 77, Judge in New York
