description: Norman L. Harvey, a former New York State Supreme Court justice in Plattsburgh, died on Feb. 18 at Florida Hospital in Haines City, Fla. He was 77 and had lived in Haines City since moving from his native Canisteo, N.Y., a year ago.

title: BASKETBALL;Cincinnati Hits Its Shot, So Down Goes Tulane
description: Cincinnati 65, Tulane 63 Darnell Burton sank a 3-point basket from deep in the corner with two seconds left yesterday, leading sixth-ranked Cincinnati past Tulane by 65-63 in New Orleans.

title: Couple Arrested In Beating of Child
description: A man and a woman were arrested in the Bronx last night for chaining their 14-year-old daughter to a banister and beating her, the police said.

title: A Hospital Goes to Court Over a Baby
description: In a dispute that legal and medical experts say is both highly unusual and indicative of gray areas in New York State law, administrators at a Queens hospital have said they will go to court today for permission to remove a 5-month-old girl from a ventilator against her parents' wishes.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Tuesday about the Hungarian fencing team misspelled the surname and native country of an artist cited by one fencer stating her preference for the design of their uniforms. He is Victor Vasarely, not Vaserily; he is from Hungary, not Italy.

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 179.89 points, or about nine-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,480.27. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 40.56 points.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD Mutola Sets Mark

title: How Other Cities Succeed: Five Ideas to Revitalize New York's Region: Work Force; Better Training In Pittsburgh
description: New York has assimilated millions of people and dozens of dizzyingly diverse cultures from around the world over the years, but it has never made much effort to borrow or imitate how other places solve their problems. The experience of the city and the surrounding region was always considered singular -- the problems were bigger, the political dynamic was different. Or perhaps the region was just too proud. New York was No. 1, and who could have anything to teach it?

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week. Some reports were delayed by last month's partial shutdown of the Government.

title: Inquiry on Cabby Killings
description: The police have formed a homicide task force to determine whether a single person carried out the killings of four livery-cab drivers over the last 13 months.

title: Refusing to Panic, Some Serbs Accept Bosnian Rule
description: For nearly half a century, Vlado Koprivica has been a friendly and hard-working but thoroughly unremarkable resident of this Sarajevo suburb. Now he is suddenly someone very rare: a Serb who is staying.

title: MEDIA: PRESS;An Internet service is denied access to the Capitol.
description: A Washington reporter is as easily identifiable these days as the Washington Monument: look for the yellow tag on a neck chain, symbol of membership in the House and Senate press galleries. More than a ticket to working space in the Capitol, it is a badge of reportorial respectability, an entree to a business club -- albeit one with heaps of rancid overcoats and Government-issue sofas -- run by working journalists, for working journalists.

title: Positively Negative
description: Every election year sees an increase in negative political advertising, and every year the pundits and commentators tell us that the voters are fed up with it and want more positive discussion of the issues. The talking heads are wrong. Negative ads not only work, they give voters better information than positive ads.

title: HOCKEY;Win 3 Games, Rest 3 Days
description: Coach Jacques Lemaire rewarded the Devils with three days of no activity on the ice after the Devils finished the busiest week of their schedule the way it started -- with a 2-1 victory over Washington on Saturday.

title: Looking on Broadway For Ramshackle Home
description: On the opening night of "Rent" two weeks ago, the phones in the offices of the New York Theater Workshop began ringing off the hook. They haven't stopped since.

title: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;Wanted: Web site reviewers. Little or no experience necessary. Pay to match.
description: VENTURE capitalists these days are bragging about all the new jobs and wealth they're creating with the success of Internet-based companies like Netscape Communications and Cybercash.

title: Farrakhan's Right
description: To the Editor:

title: IN PERFORMANCE: JAZZ
description: Sticking to the 50's, With Players From That Era 'A Jazz Retrospective' Town Hall

title: Art, Anger and Anxiety
description: Those whom God wishes to destroy, he first makes mad" is an axiom applicable to anyone wrestling with a tax return, a hospital bill or, it would seem, an application for a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. At first glance, the N.E.A.'s revised and recently announced application process seems hopelessly convoluted, requiring an army of interpreters and accountants. On closer inspection, it marks a sensible attempt to deal with the vicious cuts in both the N.E.A.'s budget (now $99.5 million) and staff.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Marsalis and His Band Rework Monk and Others
description: Wynton Marsalis reconvened his septet, added the clarinetist Michael White and performed the music of Jelly Roll Morton and Thelonious Monk and his own music for a show at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night. It was hard not to get the idea that there wasn't much ambition in the program, which is part of the Jazz at Lincoln Center series; Mr. Marsalis is soon to release his reworkings of Monk's music.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;With a new push onto the World Wide Web, J. Walter Thompson checks out its sea legs.
description: THE advertising executive who so loved the sea that he became the commodore of the New York Yacht Club is now sailing into cyberspace.

title: Pilots' Group, Firm Foe Of Castro, Ignored Risks
description: Before an air mission over Havana last summer, Billy Schuss, a pilot and co-founder of Brothers to the Rescue, sat down with Mario de la Pena to make sure some things were clear. They would not land if the Cubans tried to force their plane down, he told Mr. de la Pena, 24, who was about to make his first flight in Cuban airspace. If they died, he said, that was their choice.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Wednesday with an article about a dispute over the amount of state money given to Cornell University misstated the background of one Cornell trustee, Richard J. Schwartz. He owns an investment company and is chairman of the New York Council on the Arts. He is not the Richard J. Schwartz who is a senior adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: At 84, Not Missing a Beat
description: Mischa Frankel celebrated his 84th birthday on Feb. 1 in the Virgin Islands, attending a seminar at the Omega Institute, dancing to African drumming and leading a group in an old folk song with the refrain, "Love is something that if you give it away, you end up having more."

title: Equity Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Intel Is Criticized Over a Newer Chip
description: Some users of computers with the Intel Corporation's speedy new Pentium Pro microprocessor are complaining about sluggish performance.

title: New Era of Robust Elderly Belies Fears of Scientists
description: They called it the failure of success. As medical scientists got better and better at treating people with fatal diseases -- but not curing them -- the nation would be burdened with an accumulation of elderly people who were living longer and longer but were crippled with pain and riddled with disabilities.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAXXIM MEDICAL MAKES BID FOR STERILE CONCEPTS
description: Maxxim Medical Inc. said yesterday that it had offered to acquire Sterile Concepts Holdings Inc. for about $118 million, which includes the assumption of about $29 million in debt. Maxxim offered $16 in cash or newly issued shares, or a combination of the two, for each Sterile Concepts common share. Maxxim said it made the offer in mid-February, but has not received a reply from Sterile Concepts. Shares of Sterile Concepts rose $3.75, or 29 percent, to $16.75, on the New York Stock Exchange; Maxxim Medical shares fell 37.5 cents, to $18.875. Both companies make medical products. The combined company would have annual sales of more than $500 million. Sterile Concepts is based in Richmond; Maxxim is based in Sugar Land, Tex.

title: International Paper Names Chief Executive
description: The International Paper Company said today that John A. Georges would retire on March 31 as chairman and chief executive and that John T. Dillon, president and chief operating officer, would succeed Mr. Georges.

title: Dan Kiley, 54, Dies; Wrote 'Peter Pan Syndrome'
description: Dan Kiley, the psychologist whose 1983 book, "The Peter Pan Syndrome," became an international best seller and led to a wave of copycat pop-psychology books, died on Saturday in Tucson, Ariz. He was 54.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Times Co. Appointment
description: president and group publisher for its Magazine Group, the company's chairman and chief executive, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, announced yesterday. Mr. Medenica will assume his new position on Friday. He will become publisher of Tennis magazine and will also oversee the group's special services, which include foreign licensing, electronic media, custom publishing and related products. In addition, he will manage human resources for the Magazine Group. Mr. Medenica, who joined the Times Company in 1982, has been vice president for operations and planning since 1993.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;The Battle Over Breast Implants
description: There was a time, not so long ago, when women were lining up for silicone breast implants, some in the aftermath of a mastectomy, others to supply what nature had neglected. Now tens of thousands of women are suing the manufacturers, and the implants are no longer being made in this country for rehabilitation or for decoration. Dow Corning, a joint venture of the Dow Chemical Company and Corning Inc. and once the biggest maker, has declared bankruptcy. (Earlier this month Dow Corning won its own lawsuit against insurance companies that resisted covering the huge costs of the litigation.)

title: Calling Downings 'Appalling, ' He Backs Tightened Sanctions : Clinton Orders Steps To Punish Havana
description: WASHINGTON  President Bill Clinton announced an array of economic, political and diplomatic measures on Monday aimed at punishing Cuba for what he called its "appalling" downing of two small civilian planes flying off of its coast.

title: No Headline
description: We will not rest until all of the lunatics and violent persons are properly punished. Murder will not kill the peace process. But there will be no forgiveness for murderers because of the peace process."

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Drexler Will Miss Five to Six Weeks
description: CLYDE DREXLER, the second-leading scorer for the two-time defending champion Houston Rockets, will be sidelined five to six weeks after arthroscopic surgery yesterday to repair cartilage damage in his right knee.

title: Laughs: Rhythmic Bursts of Social Glue
description: HERE is a sampling of knee slappers to jump-start your day:

title: COMPANY NEWS;NORANDA TO BID FOR REST OF KERR ADDISON STOCK
description: Noranda Inc. said yesterday that it planned to offer $230 million (Canadian), or $167.1 million (United States), to acquire the remaining shares of Kerr Addison Mines Ltd. Noranda, based in Toronto, now owns about 9.2 million shares, or 52.1 percent of Kerr Addison, also of Toronto. The two companies are mining concerns. Noranda said it expected that materials relating to the offer would be mailed to Kerr Addison shareholders within the next two weeks.

title: Super-Counterfeit $100's Baffle U.S.
description: During the last six years, counterfeiters in the Middle East have turned out millions of dollars in exceptionally high-quality $100 bills, defying intense American efforts to find and halt their operation, senior American officials say.

title: POLITICS;In Their Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Micron Delays Chip Factory
description: Micron Technology Inc. said late today that it would delay completion of a $2.5 billion computer chip factory in Lehi, Utah, until market conditions improve.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Prep Star Hurt in Car Crash
description: Ronnie Fields, ranked among the nation's finest high school basketball players, broke a bone in his neck in a car accident early today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Cyberwar's Literary Fallout Rivals the Cyberwar
description: TAKEDOWN The Pursuit and Capture of Kevin Mitnick, America's Most Wanted Computer Outlaw -- by the Man Who Did It By Tsutomu Shimomura with John Markoff 324 pages. Hyperion. $24.95.

title: PERES PROMISES A WAR ON HAMAS
description: Responding to Israeli rage and grief over the deadliest day of suicide bombing the country has known, Prime Minister Shimon Peres vowed today to wage a "methodical and incessant" war against the militant Islamic movement Hamas.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BAY NETWORKS AGREES TO ACQUIRE ARMON NETWORKING
description: Bay Networks Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase Armon Networking Ltd., a maker of computer-networking products, for about $33 million. Armon is a private company in Tel Aviv. Bay Networks, which also supplies computer-networking equipment, plans to integrate Armon into its network management group under the name Bay Networks Israel Ltd. The acquisition would be subject to Israeli Government approval. Bay Networks, based in Billerica, Mass., expects to record a third-quarter charge for the purchase, equal to a "very significant" part of the total purchase price.

title: The Cuban Shootdown
description: The Cuban Government made prophets of its most caustic critics Saturday by shooting two American civil aircraft out of the sky. There can be no justification for deliberately killing four civilians who posed no military threat to Cuba.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;So Who's Afraid of Good Times?
description: THE Good Times virus is a hoax.

title: Philips Unit to Pay U.S. $65 Million to Settle Claim on Fraud
description: The North American subsidiary of Philips Electronics N.V. agreed today to pay the United States Government $65.3 million to settle civil claims that it falsified testing data and failed to test equipment it made for the Department of Defense and NASA.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;TBWA Chiat/Day Shifts Top Managers
description: The TBWA Chiat/Day unit of TBWA International, formed last year by the merger of Chiat/Day and TBWA Advertising, is shifting top managers as another step in efforts to integrate the two agencies.

title: Toward Irish Peace, An All-Ulster Assembly?
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Chain to Offer New Class of Shares
description: Thrifty Payless Holdings Inc., the second-largest drugstore chain in the West, said today that it was planning a global initial stock offering of up to $374 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Teledyne Raises Bid for WHX and Hints at New Proxy Battle
description: The WHX Corporation has increased its pressure for a merger with Teledyne Inc., raising its offer to $32 a share, or a total of $1.78 billion, from $30 a share, or $1.67 billion.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: From Asian Lips
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Saturday showing a recent decline in the South African currency, the rand, on foreign-exchange markets included an outdated image of the South African flag. The current flag, adopted in 1994 and colored red, white, green, blue, black and gold, looks like this:

title: A Tribute to Louis Malle
description: A tribute to the film director Louis Malle is planned on Thursday at 4:30 P.M. at the New Victory Theater, 209 West 42d Street, Manhattan. Mr. Malle died last November at the age of 63.

title: BASEBALL;Montreal Tries to Win The Low-Budget Way
description: The question was simple: Do you have any idea what the Expos' plans are for you? The answer was unequivocal.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Ex-Officer Sentenced in Theft
description: A former Newark police officer who stole $180 from the purse of a 17-year-old after she was stopped for driving with a broken headlight was sentenced yesterday to two years' probation.

title: Wanted: Parents To Pay Child Support
description: New York State will start distributing a list of the 10 parents who owe the most money in child-support payments in hopes of putting more pressure on delinquent parents, Gov. George E. Pataki said.

title: POLITICS: ON THE AIR;Fox to Give Free TV Time To Candidates For President
description: Declaring that the millions of dollars candidates must raise to buy televised political advertisements has become "a cancer in our political system," Rupert Murdoch, chairman of the News Corporation, announced that his Fox television network would give a series of free prime-time speaking opportunities to the leading Presidential candidates in the fall.

title: Parents Are Called Dedicated, Despite Their Arrest in Abuse
description: When the police arrived at the tidy, freshly painted house on Gunther Avenue in the Baychester section of the Bronx on Sunday afternoon, the situation looked bad.

title: Man Pleads Guilty in Brooklyn Hotel Fire
description: A Brooklyn man pleaded guilty yesterday to burglary and other charges after admitting that he touched off a spectacular fire that gutted a vacant part of the landmark St. George Hotel in Brooklyn Heights and sent hundreds of people fleeing in panic from neighboring buildings.

title: Stanley Shapoff, 78; Trained Star Horses
description: Stanley (Skippy) Shapoff, a longtime horse trainer who ran second with his colt Hudson County in the 1974 Kentucky Derby, died Sunday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, N.Y. He was 78 years old and had suffered in recent years from a heart condition.

title: Where the Loss of Jobs Means Growing Anger
description: In August 1994, Lucy Smith, a secretary for Citizens Savings Bank, a very profitable locally owned bank, attended a company meeting to learn what would happen to her job now that Citizens was being sold to a larger national bank.

title: Sports of The Times;Why Doesn't Hockey Have Shot Tutors?
description: BASEBALL teams have hitting coaches and pitching coaches. Football teams have quarterback coaches and kicking coaches. Basketball teams have rebounding coaches and free-throw coaches. Golfers have swing coaches. Tennis players have stroke coaches. Some athletes even have nutritional coaches.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Perry to Join World League
description: The former Chicago Bears star WILLIAM (REFRIGERATOR) PERRY will play for the London Monarchs in the World League in the season starting next month, the club said yesterday.

title: BASEBALL;Their Arms in Order, Mets Work on Gloves
description: Ask Dallas Green what excites him about his Mets and the response, surprisingly, might not be pitching. Look past the young arms and it is the potential of fielding one of the best defensive units in the National League that has the Mets' manager bubbling.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Building Supplies Maker Sets 500 More Job Cuts
description: Blue Circle Industries P.L.C., a British building materials and heating supplies company, said yesterday that it would cut up to 500 more jobs this year as part of its plans to reorganize its heating business in Britain and continental Europe. The staff reductions come in addition to December's announcement of more than 600 job cuts in Britain, France and Germany, bringing the total to around 1,150. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Russia's Prime Minister Says He'll Soften the Economic Steps
description: Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia said today that he would soften the process of economic reform as demanded by President Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: Stocks Plunge In Japan
description: Stocks fell sharply here today, amid concern, traders said, that a declining dollar would hurt profits of electronics exporters and fears that higher interest rates could strangle a budding recovery.

title: I.B.M. Plans To Increase Workers' Pay And Bonuses
description: Having restored itself to profitability by cutting 135,000 jobs in the United States over the last decade, I.B.M. has decided to improve the lot of its 110,000 remaining employees by increasing their bonuses and merit pay by an average of 8 percent this year.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of a front-page article yesterday about the snapping of a tether from a satellite to the space shuttle Columbia was omitted from some copies. Readers wishing corrected copies of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992.

title: Who Says Republicans Are Free Traders?
description: In the New Hampshire primary, Patrick Buchanan pressed the hot button that energized many 19th-century Presidential campaigns. Blasting one-sided trade deals that he says cost American workers jobs, he reinvigorated the economic nationalist tradition in the Republican Party.

title: Tax Cut for Bosnia G.I.'s
description: President Clinton asked Congress today to grant $40 million in tax relief to 20,000 American troops serving with the NATO-led peacekeeping force in the Balkans.

title: Hospital Asks Court to Decide Fate of Baby on Life Support
description: Lawyers for a Queens hospital asked a judge yesterday to decide whether a 5-month-old girl should be removed from a respirator against her parents' wishes, while the Queens District Attorney's office confirmed that it was investigating whether the baby's brain injuries resulted from parental abuse.

title: Cuba Blames U.S. in Downing of Planes
description: By turns scornful, angry and defiant, the Cuban Government blamed the United States today for fomenting the incident in which two light planes were shot down over the Straits of Florida on Saturday and accused the Clinton Administration of lying about the attack for political ends.

title: Vehbi Koc, 94, Turk Who Built His Nation's Biggest Business
description: Vehbi Koc, who left school as a teen-ager to open a small grocery store and in eight decades amassed Turkey's most formidable financial empire, died on Sunday. He was 94.

title: INSIDE
description: 'Killing Fields' Actor Slain

title: COMPANY NEWS;HS RESOURCES TO BUY BASIN ASSETS AND TIDE WEST
description: HS Resources Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Tide West Oil Company and some oil and gas properties from Basin Exploration Inc. for a total of $323.3 million. HS Resources, an oil and gas company in San Francisco, plans to acquire Tide West for $197.8 million in cash, stock and debt. The figure includes $8.75 in cash plus 0.6295 of an HS Resources common share, or about $15.60 a share, for each Tide West share. HS Resources also plans to assume $38.7 million in liabilities. Tide West's stock rose $1, to $14, yesterday in Nasdaq trading. HS Resources fell 50 cents, to $10.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Separately, HS Resources said it would pay Denver-based Basin Exploration $38 million for oil and gas properties in the Wattenberg field and $87.5 million for Basin's holdings in the Denver-Julesberg Basin in Colorado.

title: The Surplus That Wouldn't Die;Matsushita Tries and Fails to Balance Its Trade Books
description: Shoppers flock to the four L.L. Bean stores in Japan for the latest in rugged American fashions. And with each sale of a parka or pair of boots, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company chalks up another import.

title: Wall Street Wary of Silicon Graphics Deal
description: Edward R. McCracken, the chairman of Silicon Graphics Inc., said yesterday that his company's planned acquisition of Cray Research, the supercomputer maker, would create "the No. 1 high-performance computer company in the world and a real national asset for America."

title: Push by I.M.F. Won't Serve Russia Well
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance in Review
description: Sunshine and Sassiness In a Dual Role 'Coppelia' New York City Ballet New York State Theater

title: CLINTON SEEKING WIDER SANCTIONS AGAINST CUBANS
description: Denouncing the downing of two private American planes by Cuba as "a flagrant violation of international law," President Clinton today suspended all air charter travel between the United States and the island and pledged to reach agreement with Congress on a pending bill to tighten economic sanctions.

title: Surrender Watched by Paramilitary Groups
description: A doctor wanted on charges of not paying child support surrendered today after a six-day standoff in which he rallied members of right-wing paramilitary groups to his home, saying he feared that F.B.I. agents would kill him.

title: Supreme Court Roundup;Justices Hear Arguments on Disparity in Cocaine Sentences
description: There was no dispute in the Supreme Court today that the Federal Government prosecutes many more blacks than whites for crimes involving crack cocaine, which carry stiff minimum sentences much higher than those for other forms of cocaine under Federal law or for state crimes involving crack.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Home Movie: Hooray for Hollywood!
description: FLASH back to 1958: "That is always the central fact about the film maker as opposed to any other artist," Orson Welles writes in frustration. "He can never afford to own his own tools."

title: POLITICS: STEVE FORBES;The Flat-Tax Candidate Subordinates Himself to His Economic Message
description: At the end of his standard flat-tax stump speech to an attentive crowd of elderly residents here today, Steve Forbes touched lightly on what is becoming a common refrain: that his optimistic, Reaganesque message is far more important than the electoral fate of the messenger.

title: A Decade of Work Lost With Tether
description: Like a child watching a helium balloon slip from an outstretched hand, scientists looked on in distress as a half-ton satellite being towed by the space shuttle Columbia broke loose and floated into the black void, dangling 12 miles of frayed, curled cord.

title: Ex-Strongman At Seoul Trial Is Denying Taking Bribes
description: Pale and weak but defiant, former President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea today denied taking bribes at the start of his trial in Seoul on charges of amassing a huge political slush fund.

title: Salvation at Hand for a California Landscape
description: HERE in the sharply defined hills and steep canyons of Southern California, the nation's biggest and boldest attempt to reconcile urban development with the natural landscape is approaching a make-or-break point.

title: Berlusconi Looks Like the Loser in Dini's Jump Into Politics
description: PARIS  The transformation of Prime Minister Lamberto Dini from caretaker technocrat to leader of a new centrist political party has triggered a scramble in Italian politics that could spell more trouble for Silvio Berlusconi, the beleaguered media tycoon-turned-politician.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;HSBC Earnings Rise
description: The British banking company HSBC Holdings P.L.C. said yesterday that its profit rose 20 percent in 1995, led by strong gains in Hong Kong and the United States. HSBC said its profit was L2.46 billion ($3.79 billion), up from L2.05 billion in 1994. HSBC Americas Inc., formerly Marine Midland Banks Inc., reported a profit of $292 million, up 28 percent. The Hong Kong division's profit rose 16 percent and the British unit, Midland Bank, reported 3 percent higher profits. But the investment banking unit had a 19 percent decline in profits. (AP)

title: POLITICS: LAMAR ALEXANDER;Southerner Places His Hopes Down Home
description: Anticipating a disappointing finish in Tuesday's primaries in Arizona and the Dakotas, Lamar Alexander focused instead on the South today, pounding out ragtime tunes on the piano for cheering supporters here and touting his credentials as a "Republican governor from the New South with a conservative vision of the future."

title: BASKETBALL;Losing Streak Bottoms Out
description: The losingest team in college basketball history is no more. Rutgers-Camden's provost eliminated the men's team today after 108 consecutive defeats.

title: HORSE RACING;Louis Quatorze Gives Zito Hope for the Derby
description: Louis Quatorze, who withdrew from the Fountain of Youth Stakes to find a gentler approach to the Kentucky Derby, found one today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VESTAR EQUITY TO BUY SPRINGS INDUSTRIES UNIT
description: Springs Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its fiberglass-making subsidiary to the buyout firm Vestar Equity Partners L.P. and the unit's management for $185 million in cash and preferred stock. The Springs subsidiary, Clark-Schwebel Inc., is one of the world's largest makers of fiberglass and industrial fabrics and employs more than 1,500 people in plants in North Carolina, South Carolina and Georgia. Under the agreement, Vestar would pay $155 million in cash and Clark-Schwebel securities consisting of preferred stock with a liquidation value of $30 million. Clark-Schwebel contributed about 10 percent of the Springs 1995 revenue of $2.23 billion. Springs is a maker of home furnishings based in Fort Mill, S.C.

title: Hearing Set to Consider Cameras in U.S. Court
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan has agreed to hear Court TV's challenge to a national judicial policy barring cameras from Federal courtrooms.

title: White House Criticizes Plan For Welfare
description: The Clinton Administration will soon raise major objections to changes in welfare and Medicaid that were recommended unanimously by the nation's governors, Administration officials said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KAREN ZIEMBA is working hard to learn to play the violin -- badly.

title: Texas Balancing Act Is Succeeding
description: AS Southern California's experiment in balancing development with wildlife preservation approaches a critical juncture, another ambitious program may have turned the corner to success -- contrary to some recent expectations.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VALSPAR CORP., Minneapolis, a maker of paints and coatings, agreed to purchase Coates Canning, a can-coating business, from Total S.A. of Paris, for an undisclosed amount.

title: POLITICS: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN;Big Tent Is Shrinking For Grand Old Populist
description: Patrick J. Buchanan has progressed in the last three weeks from a long-shot candidate for the Republican nomination to the instrument of a conservative cause, then to the champion of a new political movement named for himself.

title: Comptroller Lists Doubts On Plan to Move Workers
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall charged today that Gov. George E. Pataki had exaggerated the benefits of his plan to move nearly 5,000 state-financed jobs out of the Democratic strongholds of New York City and Albany, signaling that he was leaning against approving it.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about two American victims of a terrorist bombing in Jerusalem misspelled the surname of the dean of Barnard College, a former faculty adviser to one victim. The dean is Dorothy Denburg, not Denberg.

title: The Episcopal Inquisition
description: It is a sad paradox that Christianity, which began as a heretical Jewish sect and suffered centuries of persecution, quickly became so strikingly repressive of deviants. As soon as their faith was legalized in the fourth century, Christians began imposing uniformity of belief. Heretics were subject to exile, confiscations of property, branding and death. The very words "heresy trial" evoke the Spanish Inquisition and other shameful episodes of Christian history.

title: A Casual Revolution Is Heating Up
description: If the television show "Dynasty" was the paradigm of 1980's fashion, the current hit "Friends" tells quite a different story. Rachel's cardigans, nondescript short skirts and body-by-Rachel T-shirts bespeak a life of languid, low-key effort. Alexis of "Dynasty," on the other hand, with celebrity-size shoulders, pinched waist and towering heels -- cobalt blue and sequins were a favorite combination -- was poised for saber-toothed war.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Righting A Wrong In a World Out of Joint
description: The questions are relentless, designed, it would seem, to make even the most confident doubt their memories, their beliefs, their very selves. It feels appallingly right that the men under interrogation appear to be dissolving into the shadows and that their questioner is faceless. This is indeed the stuff of nightmares from which a person can never wake completely.

title: A Universal Language
description: LAUGH, and the world laughs with you -- whatever the country, whatever the tribe. Anthropologists have never encountered a culture where people do not laugh to express merriment and sociability; even deaf people sometimes laugh out loud. Babies begin laughing at the age of 2 or 3 months, said Dr. William F. Fry of the Stanford University School of Medicine, just when the parents are getting fed up with all the fussing.

title: Another Livery-Cab Driver Is Fatally Shot in Brooklyn
description: A livery-cab driver was found shot to death in the front seat of his car on a Brooklyn street early yesterday, the police said.

title: No-Fee Fund Program at Donaldson, Lufkin
description: The Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation is jumping into a new business, competing for mutual fund customers against companies like the Charles Schwab Corporation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-15

title: COMPANY NEWS;NORTHWEST AIRLINES AGREES TO AIRBUS ORDER
description: In its first major aircraft purchase since it went public two years ago, Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it had a memorandum of understanding with Airbus Industrie for a new order of 20 Airbus A320 planes. Northwest, based in St. Paul, did not disclose the value of the purchase, but it is expected to be $500 million or more. Northwest also said it had delayed delivery on 16 long-range Airbus A330 planes. Under the Airbus agreement, Northwest would take delivery of 10 A320's in 1998 and 10 more in 1999. It now operates a fleet of 50 A320's.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;New Head for Kean College
description: The long, rancorous search for a new president for Kean College ended yesterday when the board of trustees chose Ronald L. Applbaum for the post. Dr. Applbaum is currently president of Westfield State College in Massachusetts.

title: Corning Introduces System to Cut Emissions as Vehicle Is Started
description: Corning Inc. introduced an automobile pollution-control system today that it said would cut emissions far in excess of the strict limits to be in place by the year 2000.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Friday about the documentary "A Third Choice" misidentified the leader of the 1948 Dixiecrat movement. It was led by Strom Thurmond, not George Wallace.

title: Jury Absolves Bellevue of Negligence in a 1989 Murder
description: A Manhattan jury found yesterday that the city-run Bellevue Hospital Center was not responsible for the death of a pregnant 33-year-old doctor who was raped and strangled in her office seven years ago by a former mental patient at the hospital.

title: Britain Faulted on Oil-Spill Damage Estimates
description: Wildlife experts accused British officials today of either misleading the public or of being naive about the extent of damage 70,000 tons oil from a grounded and leaking oil tanker caused to the coast of Wales.

title: Woman Is Charged In Tale of Robbery
description: A Long Island woman who told the police she had been locked in the trunk of a car for three days after a robbery was charged this morning with filing a false report.

title: Killing Accomplishes Nothing but Killing
description: To the Editor;

title: POLITICS: NORTH DAKOTA;In Farm State, Buchanan Finds No Help in History
description: Landlocked in the nation's prairie heartland, North Dakota would seem to be Pat Buchanan country.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Universal Studios' Account Review
description: The unit of MCA Inc. that manages the Universal Studios theme parks said yesterday that it had begun a review on its account, which for the last three years has been divided between Seiniger Kaufman Advertising in Beverly Hills, Calif., and DDB Needham Los Angeles. Though the billings were not disclosed, trade publications estimated them at $20 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;A Consolidation For Dayton Hudson
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation in Minneapolis, which owns and operates chains of department stores like Dayton's and Hudson's as well as the Target and Mervyn's chains of discount stores, said yesterday that it had consolidated its broadcast media buying account at the Haworth Group in Minneapolis. The account, with billings estimated at $100 million, was previously divided between Haworth and Focus Media in Los Angeles.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: First Midwest Bank N.A., Itasca, Ill., to Grant/Jacoby Inc., Chicago, to handle its account, previously at Salzinski & Buda Inc., Chicago. The billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Fish and Co. (Psst, That's the Knicks) Fall to L.A.
description: Vlade Divac was asked before tonight's game about his counterpart in the pivot, Matt Fish. He laughed.

title: A Broadened Attack
description: Patrick J. Buchanan has widened his attacks to tap into resentment not only of the Government, but also corporations, unions and the party he wants to represent. Page A18.

title: Where Are New York's Ski Manners?
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;Hampton Takes a Tour With 49ers
description: He is not jumping ship yet, but Rodney Hampton, the Giants' career rushing leader, was in San Francisco yesterday visiting the 49ers. His agent, Ralph Cindrich, said the visit went well. He also said the 49ers are going to try to structure a package in the next few days to lure Hampton.

title: When Violinists Play, Their Violins Improve
description: MANY a parent has suffered with the hope that more practice would improve the sounds produced by his or her child's merciless sawing of the youngster's first violin. Now researchers have found that regular practice not only improves the skills of violinists, but also the tone of the instrument.

title: Niall MacDermot, 79; Led World Jurist Unit
description: Niall MacDermot, who was Secretary General of the International Committee of Jurists for 20 years and a former British Labor Government minister, has died at the age of 79, the committee announced today.

title: After Four Years, Muslims Return to Sarajevo Suburb
description: When the bus from Sarajevo pulled up here today for the first time in four years, the first person to jump out was 18-year-old Edin Spanic, who was chased out of town in 1992 together with his family and all other local Muslims.

title: J.R. Reid Fined And Suspended
description: J. R. Reid was suspended for two games and fined $10,000 today for knocking out two of A. C. Green's teeth with a vicious elbow during the fourth quarter of the Phoenix Suns' 113-105 victory over the Knicks on Sunday.

title: BASKETBALL;A Tearful Final Night At UConn
description: On the night that Jennifer Rizzotti, Jamelle Elliott and Kim Better played their last regular-season home game at the University of Connecticut, the Huskies attempted to establish a new team regulation.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHELSEA CLINTON turns 16 today, which means that the first daughter is eligible to drive. So like doting dads everywhere, President Clinton has been taking her out for lessons -- not on the busy streets of Washington, but at Camp David, said NEEL LATTIMORE, deputy press secretary to Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Q & A
description: Disappearing Tails

title: TV SPORTS;Superstations Are Told: Go Home!
description: The anti-superstation forces in baseball have laid low for a while, leaving Atlanta Braves games on TBS, Chicago Cubs games on WGN and Mets games on WWOR to proceed without the fulminations of past superstation foes like Fay Vincent, the former commissioner, and John McMullen, the former Houston Astros' owner.

title: Threat to Driver's Licenses Leads to More Child Support
description: New York State will start distributing a list of the 10 parents who owe the most money in child support payments in hopes of putting more pressure on delinquent parents, Gov. George E. Pataki said today.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Little Joy for Mahoney As St. John's Is Defeated
description: It wasn't much of a game, but then St. John's wasn't much of a team. In its 92-79 loss to Syracuse last night in Madison Square Garden, the Red Storm took poor care of the basketball, allowed the Orangemen too many transition baskets (one came on a four-on-none breakaway) and emerged with a final score much more respectable than its performance.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;South African School Ends Segregation Battle
description: A former whites-only school that was forced to admit blacks has halted plans to fight the decision.

title: Boeing Names Chief From Commercial Side of the Company
description: The Boeing Company named Philip M. Condit chief executive yesterday, succeeding Frank Shrontz, who is stepping down somewhat sooner than expected.

title: By Design;When the Walking Is Easy
description: One more proof that women no longer let designers dictate: Remember those pointy toes and stiletto heels of last year? And how they were rejected by the public? Well, women should be happier with this year's abundance of comfortable-looking shoes with squared-off toes and chunky block heels. Like many of this spring's clothes, these shoes have a decidedly 1970's look..

title: NYC;Under Fire, Judge Decides To Fire Back
description: HANDS cuffed behind his back, the robbery suspect asked the judge to lower the $20,000 bail that has kept him in jail for months. "You say that's reasonable?" he asked Acting Justice David Friedman of State Supreme Court. "That's a ransom. I don't got that money."

title: British Premier Stays Afloat: A Single Vote Is a Life Belt
description: By a single vote, the Government of Prime Minister John Major won a critical vote today on a debate over an independent investigation into Britain's sales of military equipment to Iraq in the 1980's.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Citibank tries to raise its visibility in California with a campaign stressing dreams and opportunities.
description: IN its largest advertising effort since entering the California market in 1982, Citibank is trying to raise its visibility with a campaign that suggests customers are still entitled to the unlimited opportunities once associated with that state.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in "This Week" in the Connecticut Weekly on Sunday about a nonviolent Punch and Judy puppet show at the Whitney Museum of American Art in Stamford misstated the date. It will be this Saturday at 2 P.M.; it was not last Sunday.

title: Indian Parties Make Hay of a Scandal
description: Indian opposition parties forced the adjournment of both houses of Parliament today, serving notice they intend to use the last session before general elections to focus on a political corruption scandal.

title: Schools Are Likely to Stop Automatic English Testing
description: The Board of Education is expected this week to end the automatic testing of all children with Spanish surnames for proficiency in English, a practice that parents, teachers and some administrators have called discriminatory.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Haitians Stage Protests As U.N. Troops Pack
description: As the mandate for the United Nations peacekeeping force draws to an end, demonstrators disrupted Haiti's capital today in two separate protests.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;An Enduring Union of Opposites
description: Orchestras and their music directors constitute a marriage of sorts; and in whatever configuration, matrimonial success is best measured by endurance. Perhaps the oddest orchestral couple of recent years is Riccardo Chailly and the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam, and yet here they were last weekend after seven seasons together, playing three fascinating programs at Carnegie Hall.

title: 2 Deaths in Israel, and the Stark Echoes at Home
description: This morning's prayer service at The Frisch School ended the way another service did 10 months ago, with a remembrance of a vibrant young graduate killed in a suicide bomber's attack on an Israeli bus.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FLORIDA EAST COAST GETS OFFER FOR SUBSIDIARY
description: Florida East Coast Industries said yesterday that the St. Joe Paper Company had offered to buy its Gran Central Corporation subsidiary in a tax-free stock swap. St. Joe Paper owns a 54 percent stake, worth about $370 million, in Florida East Coast Industries. St. Joe Paper said it was interested in acquiring Gran Central in exchange for the Florida East Coast Industries stock it holds. Gran Central develops Florida office, commercial and industrial properties. Florida East Coast is based in St. Augustine, Fla.; St. Joe Paper is in Jacksonville, Fla. Trading in the shares of both companies was halted on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: No to Embryo Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Possible Fokker Deal
description: The Dutch industrial machinery company Stork N.V. confirmed today that it was interested in buying parts of the financially ailing aircraft maker Fokker N.V. A spokesman for Stork said the company had not begun talks with Fokker to acquire the businesses because the aircraft maker was still looking for someone to buy the entire company. Last month, Fokker's majority shareholder, Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany, halted its support of the company, which has been searching for a new foreign investor.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Working Days and Lightening Up at the Bus Depot
description: There seems to be something of a neglected-child syndrome in NBC's treatment of "The John Larroquette Show." As the network's programming juggernaut scoops up powerful ratings, much is ballyhooed, justifiably, about "Seinfeld," "Friends," "E.R" and "Frasier." The Larroquette series tends to get reduced to a minor player. That's not so, in terms of either ratings or quality.

title: German Fraud Charges Against Shipbuilder
description: Deepening a crisis at Germany's largest shipbuilder, a Government agency has filed suit against the former management, charging that it fraudulently misdirected aid money designated for eastern German yards.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Abductions by Aliens: What People Recall
description: Sightings of unidentified flying objects come and go with the appearance of books, movies and television programs about extraterrestrial exploits. In recent years, there's been a flurry of tales of abduction by creatures from out there, some spiced with sexual encounters of an odd kind. You can hear tonight from a few self-described abductees telling with considerable emotion of the dazzling lights, the strange craft and the little folk with big eyes who have worked their wills upon them. One woman remembers giving birth to an alien baby.

title: Using Greenery to Breed More Bucks
description: It's been a long time since New York City's parks could afford to just sit there and look beautiful. Many of the smaller ones are, in fact, decidedly unbeautiful, and it is only the presence of an army of welfare recipients armed with rakes that has kept some of the larger ones reasonably clean and trimmed. That is why Parks Commissioner Henry Stern and his colleagues are eager to make these oases into financial assets as well as esthetic ones. Any money they can generate will help restore vitality to a system being starved of funds. "If it doesn't inconvenience anyone, do the park any significant harm or get in the way of public use," he quite reasonably asks, "why not?"

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: United States

title: Bomb Kills 5 in Albania; 2 Ex-Officers Arrested
description: A car bomb exploded outside a supermarket today, killing 5 people and wounding 30. Two members of the disbanded Communist secret police were charged with the crime.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Salvaging a Season With What's Left of Knicks
description: During the break for the All-Star Game two weeks ago, Patrick Ewing visited Magic Johnson in his San Antonio hotel room. They laughed and talked about the remote possibility of Johnson joining the Knicks next season.

title: Editorial Notebook;America's Big Idea Museum
description: It is assuredly not what he wanted, but whatever Steve Forbes's fate in the campaign, he can now claim the rare distinction of adding a new exhibit to the American Museum of Big Ideas. His flat tax joins a procession of cure-everything formulas that, in their season, became the talk of the country and, in some cases, led to changes. This was partly because each plainly touched a tender nerve.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Know Every Game Counts and Aim to Handle the Heat
description: The Nets have heard their coach say it several times during the season. And in all likelihood, they will hear it again twice this week and at least a dozen more times in the next two months.

title: Thomson to Buy Legal Publisher In a $3.43 Billion Cash Accord
description: The Thomson Corporation continued its strategic move into electronic publishing and on-line information services yesterday with the announcement that it would buy West Publishing Company, a leading provider of legal research materials, for $3.43 billion in cash, most of it borrowed.

title: Market Place;1996's gold-price rise sets bulls, bears and bankers to predicting.
description: THIS year's mini-gold rush has opened a split of Klondike proportions between the precious metal's bulls and bears.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Engine Fire Halts Cruise Ship in Pacific
description: An engine fire immobilized the cruise ship Sagafjord in the South China Sea, stranding more than 800 people, the ship's owner said today.

title: Cambodian Physician Who Won an Oscar for 'Killing Fields' Is Slain
description: Dr. Haing S. Ngor, a Cambodian physician who later won an Academy Award for his debut acting performance in the 1984 film "The Killing Fields," was shot to death on Sunday night outside his home here.

title: N.J. Transit Wants Emergency Rail-Safety Rules Eased
description: New Jersey Transit and other commuter railroads asked today that the Department of Transportation relax emergency safety rules issued after collisions this month in Jersey City and Silver Spring, Md., that killed 14 people.

title: AT&T Makes Belated Move On Internet
description: The AT&T Corporation, which was late to recognize the importance of the Internet, is to introduce a service Tuesday that it hopes to use to link millions of its long-distance telephone customers to the global computer network.

title: Rikers Inmates Get One-Week Smoking Reprieve
description: A plan by New York City's Department of Corrections to begin weaning inmates at Rikers Island from cigarettes has been postponed for a week, a department spokesman said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Average Falls 65.39 On Fears of Rising Rates Blue-chip stocks tumbled, ending their three-day advance, dragged down in part by slumping bond prices. Investors feared rising bond rates would hurt corporate profits.

title: Fasting in Protestantism Isn't to Gain Favor
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: BASKETBALL;A High School Star Ponders His Future
description: The sign in front of the high school in this small town some 30 miles north of Philadelphia stated that the game was sold out and that no tickets were available. People outside the double doors and in the packed parking lot on this crisp Friday night last week were asking whether anyone had tickets to sell. And no one did, clutching them like passes for entry through the Pearly Gates.

title: HOCKEY;Devils Make Deal for Housley
description: The Devils, addressing their seasonlong need for a scorer, acquired defenseman Phil Housley and a minor leaguer from the Calgary Flames last night for defensemen Tom Albelin and Cale Hulse and forward Jocelyn Lemieux.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Once-Mighty Saatchi Takes It From the Top
description: Maurice Saatchi's wife, the novelist Josephine Hart, once wrote: "Damaged people are dangerous. They know they can survive."

title: POLITICS: BOB DOLE;With Dole Campaign Off Track, He Puts 2 Advisers Off the Team
description: In a stark acknowledgment that his campaign has gone awry and that he has offered an inconsistent message, Senator Bob Dole said today that he had dismissed his campaign pollster and demoted his deputy chairman, just as the campaign is heading into a make-or-break period.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;It's a Jump Ball Between Jets and Steelers for O'Donnell
description: Despite their sorry record last season and the decades-long malaise, the Jets found themselves today in the extraordinary position of being the only team negotiating with quarterback Neil O'Donnell except for the Steelers, the team he helped bring to the Super Bowl.

title: Patterns
description: Designers Fancy Furs

title: On My Mind;Shall We Wait and See?
description: Menachem Begin faced the question in 1981 and Bill Clinton faces it now, one of the most difficult questions of national leadership.

title: Farrakhan Defends Ties to Libyan Leader
description: Louis Farrakhan, the Nation of Islam leader who just returned from an 18-nation tour of Africa and the Middle East, boasted of accepting a $1 billion pledge from Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, but he said he was preaching peace in Libya and Iraq -- not, as government critics said, cavorting with dictators.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CONSORTIUM ACQUIRES 3 RAIL FREIGHT COMPANIES
description: A consortium of United States and New Zealand interests said yesterday that it had acquired three British rail freight companies for $343 million. The Wisconsin Central Transportation Corporation of Rosemont, Ill.; Berkshire Partners, a privately held investment firm in Boston, and the New Zealand investment bank Fay Richwhite & Company each acquired a third of the companies. The consortium purchased Loadhaul, Mainline Freight and Transrail Freight, which have combined annual revenue of $870 million. They have a total of 7,500 employees and carry commodities such as coal and ore.

title: Some Hedge Funds Are Hurt By a Rise in Interest Rates
description: Several big hedge funds, which invest billions of dollars for the wealthy, have lost money in recent days as long-term interest rates have risen unexpectedly. As a result, some of these swashbuckling investment firms have given up the sizable profits they made in January, and in some cases have even registered losses, traders and analysts said.

title: POLITICS: NEW YORK;Mayor and Local G.O.P. Seek to Stop Buchanan
description: Hoping to use next week's New York primary to slow the momentum of Patrick J. Buchanan, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would soon name a candidate he believed New Yorkers should vote for -- aides said it would probably be Senator Bob Dole -- to send a message that Mr. Buchanan's brand of conservatism was unacceptable.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Bailey's World Record Checks Out
description: DONOVAN BAILEY of Canada apparently will get a world indoor record for the 50-meter dash after all.

title: Arrests in Tourist's Killing
description: Three people were arrested on Saturday after police officers acted on a tip in the fatal shooting of a Dutch tourist at a gas station. The suspects -- two teen-agers and a young man -- were charged with first-degree murder and robbery. They were identified as Max Brazley, 16; Barry Chandler, 20, and Xaviein Bendross, 16. Mr. Chandler is also charged with possession of firearms by a convicted felon.

title: When Executive Pay Is Tied to Performance
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bill Bars Benefits to Aliens
description: Only three days after a state appeals court held that undocumented immigrants are entitled to worker's compensation, the Senate approved a bill yesterday that would deny them those benefits.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Winner Seems to Be Whitman
description: Details released yesterday of the tentative agreement reached by negotiators for faculty members at eight state colleges and Montclair State University last weekend suggest that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has scored another victory in her battle to hold down wages of state workers.

title: Act Now to Prevent More Oil Spills at Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Inquiry Looks At Insurer of Crops
description: Shares of the Crop Growers Corporation, a crop insurance provider, fell 32 percent today after the company said that Federal officials were investigating charges of illegal campaign contributions.

title: For Lakes, Ultraviolet Danger Doesn't Come Just From Sky
description: A NEW study suggests that a double whammy of acid rain and global warming might aggravate the harmful effects of ultraviolet rays on some kinds of lake ecosystems.

title: Motorola Venture With Sun Microsystems
description: Motorola Inc. and Sun Microsystems Inc. said yesterday that they planned to collaborate to build high-speed Internet access systems for home use.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Akzo Nobel Profit Down By 30% in Quarter
description: Akzo Nobel N.V., the largest Dutch chemical and drug company, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 30 percent. Alexander Vermeeren, a member of Akzo Nobel's management board, said sales of the oral contraceptive Marvelon -- marketed as Desogen in the United States -- "dropped dramatically" in Germany and Britain because of a warning that there might be an increased risk of blood clots.

title: Picket Line at Barnard Is Test in Class Struggle 101
description: Judging from the raucous scene at its front gate, Barnard College resembled an auto plant far more than an ivory tower yesterday as dozens of striking workers carried picket signs, blew whistles and implored students and professors to honor their picket line.

title: Ending Lively Era, A Dean Is Leaving St. John the Divine;The Innovator's Work Is Done, Even if the Cathedral Is Not
description: If anything, the Very Rev. James Parks Morton is a showman. He once exhibited a sculpture of a female Jesus, complete with bare breasts, as a statement against sexism. A Hudson River blue crab lives in a murky tank in a side chapel as a statement on the environment.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Feb. 1 with an article about family members who sit on corporate boards misstated the relationship of Richard J. Raskin, a director of the Stone Container Corporation, to the Stone family. Richard J. Raskin is the son-in-law of Jerome H. Stone, the company's chairman emeritus, not of Roger W. Stone, the current chairman.

title: Spy Satellite Agency Heads Are Ousted For Lost Money
description: The top two managers of the National Reconnaissance Office, the secret agency that builds spy satellites, were dismissed today after losing track of more than $2 billion in classified money.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Senate Approves Ethics Bill
description: The State Senate unanimously approved legislation yesterday aimed at stopping lawmakers from pressuring state agencies on behalf of their constituents. The sponsor of bill, Senator William E. Schluter, Republican of Flemington, said the bill was inspired by the controversy that arose two years ago when six legislators pressed the State Lottery Commission to award a contract to a Bergen County company.

title: Ralph Quattrociocchi, Ex-State Senator, 66
description: Ralph Quattrociocchi, a four-term Democratic state senator who lost a bitter comeback race after joining the Republican Party, died on Saturday at his home in the suburb of Greece. He was 66.

title: Warsaw Journal;Poland's Free Press Hero? Or Editor in Mischief?
description: Seen with his magnum of champagne celebrating the comeback of the former Communists, at the wheel of his Jaguar or at the helm of his wildly successful, lewd and ruthless newspaper, Jerzy Urban represents all that Poland's anti-Communists love to hate.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Braves Visit the White House
description: The Atlanta Braves toured the White House yesterday, chatting briefly with PRESIDENT CLINTON, who offered belated congratulations to the team. The Braves' first invitation to the White House last year was canceled because of the crisis in Bosnia. The Braves broke with their spring training schedule, traveling from West Palm Beach, Fla., to Washington for the two-hour tour, reception and ceremony. (AP)

title: School of Americas
description: To the Editor:

title: China Slows Action by U.N. Against Cuba
description: A last-minute ploy by China tonight held up a Security Council statement condemning Cuba for its attack on civilian aircraft. The delay is an unexpected embarrassment for the Clinton Administration, which has been demanding Council reaction since Sunday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Botha Told to Fight Moorer
description: The International Boxing Federation reversed course yesterday to comply with a settlement ordered by a Federal court and said FRANCOIS BOTHA, its heavyweight champion, will fight MICHAEL MOORER.

title: POLITICS: THE POLL;SOCIAL ISSUES GIVE BUCHANAN BOOST, A NEW POLL FINDS
description: Patrick J. Buchanan's views on social issues like abortion and immigration are attracting voters to his campaign more than his economic populism, a new New York Times/CBS News poll shows.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Drop As Traders Wait for Data
description: Prices of Treasury securities dropped yesterday, with buyers reluctant to take positions ahead of the release of numerous economic reports scheduled for this week.

title: When Young Universe Gave Birth to Galaxies
description: WITH new telescopes, new techniques and some plain luck, astronomers are beginning to catch revealing glimpses of the universe in its formative youth, when its originally smooth and featureless expanses were being transformed into collections of stars in the earliest galaxies.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KERKORIAN MIGHT INCREASE GAMING INVESTMENT
description: Kirk Kerkorian is considering raising his investment in the gaming industry, the chairman of his investment company, the Tracinda Corporation, said yesterday. "Our investment in the gaming industry is one that we will continue to find ways to expand over the next several years," the chairman, Jerome B. York, said yesterday. Mr. Kerkorian already owns 47.9 million shares, or 74 percent, of the stock in MGM Grand Inc., which operates the MGM Grand hotel in Las Vegas, Nev. Mr. Kerkorian, Chrysler's largest shareholder, ended a 10-month battle with the auto maker earlier this month. Chrysler pledged to repurchase $2 billion of its stock this year and $1 billion next year, and Mr. Kerkorian stands to receive about 14 percent of that, or about $420 million.

title: Hamas Blames Killings by Israel for New Bombings
description: A top leader of the Islamic group Hamas said today that the resumption of suicide attacks in Israel after a six-month lull had been prompted by Israeli assassinations of Muslim militants that climaxed with the killing of the fugitive bomb-maker Yahya Ayyash in Gaza last month.

title: Pirate Radio in Touch With the Village, Not the F.C.C.
description: As dusk fell over the East Village on a recent Friday, two figures stood on a rooftop, the wind and snow beating at their faces until they turned bright red. Teetering in their hands was a 22-foot rod made of plumbing pipes with a thin metal crossbar near the top.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;Granting Second Life To Songs
description: Even the best pop songs begin to wear thin if they're overexposed. But some CD singles are remedying this problem by offering not just remixes but new recordings of a song, often with guest appearances by other pop stars. Occasionally, a new hit is created or enough versions of a song are made to saturate different radio formats. The group Everything but the Girl's 1994 album, "Amplified Heart," was languishing until last year, when it commissioned Todd Terry to remix the song "Missing" as a single. For the last two weeks, his version of "Missing" has been the second-most-played song on radio (after Mariah Carey's "One Sweet Day").

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;20-Year Tax Fraud Sentence
description: A Florida man was sentenced yesterday to 20 years in prison for his role in defrauding New Jersey and the Federal Government of $100 million in gasoline taxes. The sentence for the man, Anthony Morelli, is believed to be the harshest ever meted out in a tax evasion case of this type, said Robert G. Stahl, an assistant United States attorney.

title: No Conspiracy Found in Fire That Killed 8
description: As the police wind down their investigation into the arson in December at a Harlem clothing store that killed eight people, they say they have been unable to determine whether anyone aided or directed the man who set the fire, making it unlikely prosecutors will charge there was a conspiracy to attack the store on 125th Street.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daewoo Plans for India
description: The Daewoo Group of South Korea is planning to invest $5 billion in India in the next five years, Lee Chul Soo, chairman of DCM Daewoo Ltd., told a meeting of Indian and Korean business executives in New Delhi yesterday. The spending will make Daewoo the largest foreign investor in India. Daewoo's main project is a car manufacturing venture with the DCM Group. Daewoo holds a 51 percent stake in the venture. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Armed Forces Still Question Homosexuals
description: Two years after the Clinton Adminstration enacted a policy of "don't ask, don't tell" for homosexuals in the military, Pentagon documents and interviews with service members show that the military is not only continuing to ask some of them about their sexual orientation, but is also asking their parents, their friends and their therapists.

title: BASEBALL;Taylor Struggles To Recover Control
description: Brien Taylor had hoped to use two innings of intrasquad pitching tonight at Legends Field to show that he has a future with the Yankees, after all. Instead, the 24-year-old left-hander demonstrated that he still doesn't belong in a major league uniform.

title: Executive Changes
description: AMERICAN COMMUNICATIONS SERVICES INC., Annapolis Junction, Md., appointed Harry D'Andrea chief financial officer, succeeding Ronald Kaiser, who resigned.

title: Placer Dome Expansion
description: The Canadian gold producer Placer Dome Inc. said today that it had plans to build five new mines and raise its gold output by 25 percent in two years. Placer said it expected to start building five new mines as far afield as Venezuela and Australia in the next year at a cost of $1.1 billion. The mines should produce a combined 800,000 ounces of gold annually, letting Placer reach its annual production goal of 2.5 million ounces in 1998 rather than 2000 as previously forecast.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Dutch Printer Maker Buying a Siemens Unit
description: The Dutch printer and copier maker Oce-van der Grinten said yesterday that it had agreed to pay around 900 million guilders ($552 million) to take over the printing arm of the Siemens Nixdorf unit of Siemens A.G. of Germany. The takeover, set for April 1, will leave Oce with more than 15,000 employees and, based on 1995 figures, worldwide sales of almost 4 billion guilders ($2.45 billion).

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Oliver Rejoins Reds
description: The Cincinnati Reds signed the free-agent catcher JOE OLIVER to a one-year contract yesterday and released catcher DAMON BERRYHILL to make room on the 40-man roster. Oliver's deal is worth $500,000, including incentives.

title: Yonkers N.A.A.C.P. Unit Head Quits Over Issue of Free Speech
description: The president of the Yonkers branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, who took over in November after the national leadership suspended his predecessor for questioning the value of busing, resigned yesterday to protest the national organization's decision to uphold the suspension.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RITE AID TO OPEN 77 STORES IN NEW YORK CITY AREA
description: The Rite Aid Corporation is expected to announce today that it will spend more than $200 million to open 77 drugstores in the New York City area by January. The store openings, which are expected to create 2,000 jobs, are part of the three-year expansion plan by the nation's biggest drugstore chain. Of the 77 stores, 28 are to be in Manhattan, 20 in Staten Island, 14 in Brooklyn, 9 in Queens and 6 in the Bronx. Rite Aid, based in Camp Hill, Pa., opened 50 stores in the metropolitan area in the last year. The expansion comes as Rite Aid is having trouble obtaining approval from the Federal Trade Commission for its $1.8 billion bid for Revco D.S. Inc.

title: Audit Raises Flag at Baby Superstore
description: Baby Superstore Inc. said today that an audit of its 1996 fiscal year results disclosed that it might have overstated its cash reserves. As a result, the company's shares plunged 29 percent.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GRACE JONES, the flamboyant pop singer and model, married her 21-year-old former bodyguard, ATILA ALTAUNBAY, on Saturday in Rio de Janeiro, Reuters reported.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Abbey Bank Reports Rise in Yearly Net
description: Abbey National P.L.C., Britain's largest publicly traded mortgage lender, said yesterday that its 1995 pretax profit rose 10 percent because of better income from loans to consumers and treasury operations. The bank, which converted from a building society in 1989, said profit before tax rose to L1.03 billion ($1.58 billion), from L932 million in 1994.

title: Dance in Review
description: When in Choreographic Doubt, Strike a Pose, or Several Poses Sally Gross, Bryan Hayes and Carolyn Lord University Settlement

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;2 Hurt in Small-Plane Crash
description: A pilot and his passenger were injured yesterday morning when their small plane crashed into a runway fence just after takeoff at Linden Municipal Airport, officials said. Joshua Ray, of Lodi, a part-time flight instructor, and Gary Wasylyk, a photographer from South River, were taken by helicopter to University Hospital in Newark, where they were in stable condition, a hospital spokeswoman said.

title: Joseph S. Robinson, 89, Lawyer Noted for Roles in War Cases
description: Joseph S. Robinson, whose long career as a lawyer was highlighted by a series of cases involving military brutality, stolen royal treasure and jurisdiction over a soldier accused of killing a Japanese civilian, died on Wednesday at his home in Westhampton, L.I. Mr. Robinson, who also maintained a home in Manhattan, was 89.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Giving to Neediest Fund Surpasses Last Year's
description: With three days left in its 1995-96 drive, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has edged ahead of last year's final total, securing at least a third-place finish in the campaign's history.

title: Panel Clears Rise in Bridge and Tunnel Tolls
description: The finance committee of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday approved toll increases on major bridges and tunnels from $6 round-trip, to $7, the last step before a vote tomorrow by the M.T.A. board.

title: Chess
description: For the first time this year, at the 58th running of the elite Hoogoven International Tournament in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands, the spectators were invited to select "the player of the round." The prize was $300. It seemed like a good idea until it ran up against the Ukrainian grandmaster Vasily Ivanchuk.

title: INSIDE
description: Habits, Not Genes, Predict Healthy Old Age

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BANK OF NEW YORK CO., reached an agreement to acquire the unit investment trust servicing business of Investors Fiduciary Trust Co., Kansas City, Mo., for an undisclosed amount.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When the Susan Smith Blackburn Awards for female playwrights were presented in Manhattan on Monday evening, MIMI KILGORE, the sister of Susan Smith Blackburn, said she hoped the 12 recipients would follow in the path of previous winners.

title: 2 Sides Agree To Exhume One Victim In Bomb Case
description: The men accused of bombing the Federal building here made their last scheduled appearance in court in Oklahoma today, with lawyers agreeing to exhume a body in hopes of solving the mystery surrounding a leg found in the rubble.

title: To Be Young, Gay and Going to High School in Utah
description: For Kelli Peterson, a 17-year-old senior at East High School here, the Aztec and U.F.O. clubs held no appeal; her primary concern was intensely personal -- easing the loneliness she felt as a gay student.

title: GOLF;Couples Making Return To Championship Form
description: This is a good time to look in on Fred Couples, as he stands on the 18th tee at the Doral Resort and Spa getting ready to unload on his drive. All day long, during a hit-and-giggle skins game, Couples has been blowing his drives well past his playing partners, hitting his ball almost ridiculous distances.

title: Reforming Civil Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Allow Cuban Exiles to Make U.S. Policy;Castro's Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: THE POP LIFE;What's Better, To Win Or Sing?
description: In some ways it can be more beneficial for a musician to perform at the Grammy Awards ceremony than to win a Grammy. Though the show's ratings have been dropping in the last three years, an appearance on the Grammy Awards show, which is to be televised by CBS tonight at 8 from the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles, can increase an album's sales by 5 to 80 percent.

title: Coleman Discusses a Deal
description: The Coleman Company, the maker of camping and outdoor recreational products, said today that it was negotiating to add Camping Gaz's popular blue portable stove to its product line. Coleman said it was close to concluding talks on an acquisition of Application des Gaz S.A., the French camping equipment maker that is 70 percent controlled by Butagaz. Coleman's shares rose $1 today, to $40.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Coleman is 80 percent owned by the financier Ronald O. Perelman's MacAndrews & Forbes Holding Inc.

title: Chip to Block TV Gore Popular in Canada Tests
description: Maxine Lawson says she did not think much about violence on television until her 2-year-old son, Caden, came into the kitchen one day after watching the Mighty Morphin Power Rangers and started making karate chops.

title: BASEBALL;Gooden, Key Hit Hard; Torre Looks Other Way
description: The Yankees got an intrasquad peek today at two pitchers high on their wish list to make the team's starting rotation. Put it this way: It's a good thing the regular season doesn't start tomorrow.

title: Sports of The Times;Alone on the Ice With a Precious Memory
description: SHE used to look out at the ice and wonder how they did it. How they could talk themselves into their routines, their jumps, without a partner's support, without the power of loving hands around their waist.

title: AT&T to Provide Its Customers With Free Access to the Internet
description: AT&T said yesterday that it would offer its telephone customers five hours of free Internet access each month for a year, bringing computer network service a step closer to becoming a utility like electricity or water.

title: Chief Is Appointed For Mental Health
description: Dr. Neal L. Cohen, the clinical director of psychiatry at Mount Sinai Medical Center, was named Commissioner of the city's Department of Mental Health, Mental Retardation and Alcoholism Services yesterday by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Chargeurs of France To Split Into 2 Parts
description: Chargeurs S.A., a French company with textile, entertainment and automotive interests, said yesterday that it would break itself into two separate companies -- one pooling its media operations, the other its textiles and other businesses.

title: POLITICS: VIEW FROM ABROAD;From Japan to Britain, Foreign Leaders and Press Look Askance at Buchanan Fever
description: Patrick J. Buchanan, the America First candidate, is wary of foreigners. Not surprisingly, the ill feeling is mutual.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Barclays Earnings Rose 12% in 1995
description: Barclays P.L.C., Britain's third-largest bank, said yesterday that its 1995 pretax profit rose 12 percent because provisions for bad debt fell and income from most businesses increased. Profit before tax rose to L2.08 billion ($3.21 billion), from L1.86 billion in 1994, the company said. The bank also said it intended to buy back 40 million shares, or 2.5 percent of the share capital. Last year it repurchased 25 million shares.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Japan to Heed Copyright Law on Music
description: Under pressure from the United States and European nations, the Japanese Government plans to strengthen its music copyright laws this year, a Government official said today.

title: U.N. and Yugoslavia Lift Sanctions on Bosnian Serbs
description: The United Nations and Yugoslavia lifted sanctions against Bosnian Serbs today as a reward for accepting peace.

title: Bulls Go 0 to 50 The Quickest
description: They reached 50 victories faster than any team in league history, but the Chicago Bulls are far from where they want to be.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KENNETH MILLER and DIANE TAPP were on their way to the opening of an exhibition of Beethoven sonata scores on Monday evening in Carnegie Hall, which is named for Mr. Miller's great-grandfather Andrew Carnegie. Suddenly, Mr. Miller says, he was seized with inspiration.

title: The Everglades Is Nobody's Swamp
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Seeks to Loosen Bill's Ban on an Abortion Method
description: Saying he has "studied and prayed about this issue," President Clinton, in a letter to Congress, is urging lawmakers to amend a bill that would outlaw a late-term form of abortion so it would allow exceptions for cases where the life or health of a woman was at risk.

title: POLITICS: PERSONAL FINANCES;Alexander Still Draws Scrutiny for Making Small Investments Pay Well
description: In 1979, when a lawyer named Lamar Alexander was sworn in as Governor of Tennessee, he and his wife, Honey, listed their net worth at $151,000.
