title: Who Had Last 'Ha!' in Negative Ad of 1884
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Suicide at Police Station
description: A man awaiting questioning in a holding cell at the Bergen County police headquarters used a shirt to hang himself Monday night, the authorities said yesterday. The man, Curtis Lee Martin, had been accused of stabbing and slashing two people during a brawl in Ridgefield Park.

title: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;Forbes Claims Victory in Arizona Race
description: Further complicating an already muddled Republican Presidential competition, Steve Forbes claimed victory in the Arizona primary today, while Senator Bob Dole prevailed in primaries in North Dakota and South Dakota.

title: Journal;The V-Chip G-String
description: The Hollywood mogul Barry Diller, half-joking, says he is looking forward to attending tomorrow's much-ballyhooed White House meeting between the President and show-biz potentates so he can "see how Mr. Murdoch and Mr. Turner treat each other." As recently as Monday Rupert Murdoch was accusing CNN of "brown-nosing foreign dictators" in retaliation for Ted Turner's recent characterization of him as a "schlockmeister."

title: Less Booze at 'Police Week'
description: The investigation into the drunken melee involving New York City police officers in Washington D.C. last spring has come to a successful close. One officer has resigned, two have been dismissed and a handful have been suspended. In addition, about 30 officers have been disciplined for such infractions as taking their weapons to the Washington convention against regulations. The most recently dismissed officer was the so-called "naked man," who symbolized the disorder by cavorting, drunk and unclothed, through a hotel lobby.

title: Stretching Muscles, Not Wallets: Where to Work Out for Less
description: IN New York, where private-school tuition approaches that of Harvard University and where having a good French meal may require cashing out the money market account, it may come as a surprise that there are actually some places where you can exercise each day for less than the price of a caffe latte.

title: Empire Blue Cross Reduces Losses and Adds to Reserves
description: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, one of the nation's biggest and most troubled health insurers, reported yesterday that it had reduced its losses last year and had added substantially to the cash reserves it needs to stay in business.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Remains of 167 People Found in Guatemala
description: Anthropologists have found the burned remains of 167 people killed by the army in a clandestine cemetery in the highlands state of Quiche, human rights officials said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TAX RULING LIFTS PHILLIPS PETROLEUM EARNINGS
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said yesterday that its first-quarter net income would be increased by about $565 million because of a favorable tax ruling related to a natural gas operation in Alaska. The company will receive about $375 million in pretax refunds from the Internal Revenue Service in the next few years, with the first $200 million expected in the next 60 days. The refunds will amount to about $275 million after taxes. The company said the remaining $290 million of the after-tax gain was money Phillips had accrued for taxes and interest but had not yet paid. Phillips reported net income of about $111 million, or 43 cents a share, in the first quarter last year. Its shares rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $35.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 2,000 Are Evacuated From L.I. Mall as Fumes Make 10 Sick
description: More than 2,000 shoppers and employees were forced to leave the Green Acres Mall this morning when fumes from a truck pumping waste water from a basement escalator shaft made 10 people ill, the authorities said.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A 30th-Anniversary Concert for Continuum
description: Like many useful musical organizations, Continuum was started almost by accident. Cheryl Seltzer, a pianist, and Peter Perrin, a composer, pooled their resources to put on an all-Webern concert at Columbia University. It was well received, and before long friends were suggesting that they explore the works of other composers as well.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Roussel and Cheveldae Trade Places
description: The Philadelphia Flyers traded goaltender DOMINIC ROUSSEL to Winnipeg yesterday for goalie TIM CHEVELDAE and a third-round pick in the 1996 entry draft.

title: Real Estate;A haven for after-work volleyball shows that amenities are back in corporate office parks.
description: A 72,000-square-foot volleyball center in a corporate office park in this town 20 miles west of Philadelphia is a prime example of the growth of recreational amenities in corporate and industrial areas.

title: Transit Board Delays Decision On Braking System for Rail Line
description: New Jersey Transit's directors postponed a decision today on whether to speed up the installation of an automatic braking system on the Hoboken commuter rail lines.

title: Parks Restrict the Sale of Art, Not Its Creation
description: To the Editor:

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Heating Oil Surges on Concern About a Decline in Inventories
description: Heating oil prices surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange for the fifth consecutive session as concerns grew over supply.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Staff at Greystone Is Assailed
description: A State Senate task force heard testimony yesterday about problems at another state psychiatric hospital, Greystone Park. The panel questioned hospital officials about reports of sexual abuse of female patients. Witnesses testified about patient escapes and the suicide of a patient this month while staff members on duty were asleep.

title: Who Had Last 'Ha!' in Negative Ad of 1884
description: To the Editor:

title: Still Talking About Tax Cuts, Congress Goes Back to Work
description: Congressional Republicans sought today to reclaim their party's agenda from the rhetoric of its Presidential campaign, insisting that what the economy needed was old-fashioned budget balancing and tax cutting.

title: Terror in Israel
description: The armed terrorists of Hamas and Islamic Jihad number only a few hundred at most. But they have killed more than 100 Israelis in suicide bombing attacks since Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization reached their historic peace agreement two and a half years ago. On Sunday Hamas struck again, setting off two nail-studded pipe bombs that killed 27 people, injured 77 and broke an undeclared six-month truce.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Whitman Tours 'Boot Camp'
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman toured the state's first experimental boot camp for juveniles yesterday, and told the young cadets that they were "truly pioneers." The $3 million camp, which opened in Wharton State Forest in Burlington County on Feb. 1, was authorized by one of several bills relating to juvenile justice passed by the Legislature last year.

title: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;Dole Takes a Slap, Several of Them, at Alexander
description: behalf of Senator Bob Dole.

title: In Myanmar, Fight for Freedom Hasn't Faded
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;LeBOW PAYS HIS NOMINEES FOR THE RJR NABISCO BOARD
description: The financier Bennett S. LeBow, who with Carl C. Icahn has begun a proxy fight with the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, has been paying the 10 nominees they hope will replace members of the company's current board, according to a filing with Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. LeBow, who is one of the nominees, and his Brooke Group Ltd. plan to pay the nominees as much as $450,000, part of the estimated $7.4 million Mr. LeBow has spent in his bid to force RJR Nabisco to spin off its food operations immediately. The company has said an immediate spinoff will not benefit shareholders.

title: Britain and Ireland Move to Restart the Peace Effort in Ulster
description: The Irish and British Governments announced early this morning that they had agreed on a new initiative aimed at reviving the Northern Ireland peace effort.

title: Bagel Store Expansion
description: The Manhattan Bagel Company said today that it planned to add at least 160 bagel stores in 1996, doubling its total number of outlets. The company, based in Eatontown, N.J., said this year's openings would include the chain's first stores in Canada under a franchise agreement with Comac Food Group, which will open at least 100 stores in the next five years, including seven in 1996. Manhattan Bagel said it added 102 stores in 1995, bringing its total to 160 stores in 15 states.

title: Lauded Officer Suspended as a Malingerer
description: A New York City police detective who was once praised as a hero for shooting three gunmen in a Brooklyn beauty parlor was suspended yesterday and called a malingerer for calling in sick too many times.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Merit Pay Gains a Foothold
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority's Board of Commissioners ratified a four-year contract for middle managers yesterday that for the first time will provide merit raises rather than automatic pay increases. The contract freezes wages for the first two years, and allows increases based on performance for the final two years, Edward Gross, the authority's acting executive director, said.

title: Duke of Atholl, 64, Rich Scot With Castle and Private Army
description: George Iain Murray, the 10th Duke of Atholl, who was one of Scotland's richest landowners and the commander of of Britain's only private army, died yesterday at a hospital in Perth, Scotland.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Starks Criticizes Nelson's Coaching Style
description: For a change, John Starks was cool and calculating. His words were thought out and measured. The volcanic Knicks guard refused to erupt. Instead, he elaborated.

title: Baby Superstore Soothes Investors
description: Baby Superstore Inc. said today that the amount of an overstatement of cash reserves was $3.9 million at the most. Analysts said they had been bracing for a bigger restatement, and the stock rebounded.

title: Turkish Chief Set for Deal to Bar Islamic Party
description: Jarred by a pro-Islamic party's close brush with power, Prime Minister Tansu Ciller of Turkey said here today that she was ready to make sacrifices to form a center-right coalition taking shape in Ankara, in order to block the party from any future role in government.

title: A Place Where Corks Are Sure to Pop
description: MORE French Champagne is drunk in New York than in any other American city. And soon, New York will have a place devoted not only to French Champagne but also to sparkling wines from other parts of the world. The Bubble Room, due to open in late March at 228 West Broadway (North Moore Street), in TriBeCa, is the brainchild of Eric Macaire, an owner of Jubilee near Sutton Place, and Eric Benn, a wine lover and an investor in that restaurant.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Conservative Hat Enters Ring
description: Calling himself "the most fiscally conservative candidate in the race," State Assemblyman Leonard Lance, Republican of Flemington, said yesterday that he would seek the Republican nomination for the seat being vacated by United States Representative Dick Zimmer.

title: Russian Church Breaks Off From Orthodoxy's Historic Center
description: The Russian Orthodox Church has severed ties with the historic center of Eastern Orthodoxy, the Patriarchate of Constantinople, in a dispute over the independence of the church in Estonia.

title: COMPANY NEWS;A MERGER FOR INTERIM SERVICES AND BRANDON SYSTEMS
description: Interim Services Inc. and the Brandon Systems Corporation signed a merger agreement yesterday valued at about $163 million. Interim said that Brandon stockholders would receive 0.88 Interim Services share for each Brandon share held. Interim said the merger, which would be recorded as a tax-free pooling of interests, was expected to close in June. Interim Services, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., provides flexible staffing and home health care services. Brandon Systems is an information technology staffing company in Secaucus, N.J.

title: Hearing Begins for Bishop Who Ordained Gay Deacon
description: In a cathedral hall turned ecclesiastical courtroom, nine purple-shirted Episcopal Church bishops today began to consider whether a bishop who ordained a gay man as a deacon should become the first person in 72 years to be tried by the church as a heretic.

title: General Urges Combination Of Solutions In Drug Abuse
description: Playing down the timeworn image of a war on drugs, a four-star Army general nominated by President Clinton to head the Administration's campaign against illegal narcotics said today that so complex a problem must be solved with prevention, treatment and education programs as well as law enforcement.

title: Officials Split On Improving Train Safety
description: Techniques and technology needed to help prevent or limit the severity of railroad accidents like more than a dozen that have occurred across the nation in the last two months have existed for years, safety officials, union leaders and elected representatives testified today at hearings before Congress and the Maryland Legislature.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: VTEL Corp., Austin, Tex., to Sicola Martin, Austin, as the first agency of record for the video-conferencing company. The billings were estimated at $4 million to $5 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;A Consolidation For Tyco Toys
description: Tyco Toys Inc. said yesterday that it had consolidated the creative and media portions of its worldwide account, with billings estimated at $75 million, at one of its two roster agencies, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York. D.M.B.& B. has handled about $15 million in billings with the rest at Bozell Worldwide in New York.

title: Sarah Palfrey Danzig, Stylish Tennis Champion, Dies at 83
description: One of the most elegant tennis players ever to grace a grass court, Sarah Palfrey Danzig, a mainstay on the international circuit in the 1930's and an esteemed ambassador of the game thereafter, died yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 83.

title: Nonviolence of Castro's Foes Still Wears a Very Tough Face
description: Jose Basulto, the leader of Brothers to the Rescue and the pilot of the plane that returned safely to Florida on Saturday after two companion aircraft were shot down, used to fight Fidel Castro the old-fashioned way.

title: Nasdaq Posts a Rise of 7.5% In Uncovered Short Sales
description: The number of open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq market increased 7.5 percent for the latest period, the National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday outlining the economies and politics of Arizona, North Dakota and South Dakota, the three states that were about to hold Presidential primaries, gave an incorrect figure in some editions for the percentage of Arizona's population that is Hispanic. It is 18.8.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.S. Urged to Combat Counterfeiting Overseas
description: As a House panel delved into a mysterious threat from fake $100 bills in the Middle East, several Congressmen called today for expanding the Secret Service and the use of the nation's intelligence agencies to combat counterfeiting overseas.

title: BASEBALL;O'Donnell Is Likely to Jump Ship and Join the Jets
description: Neil O'Donnell is sleeping on it, but it is likely he will decide this morning to leave the Steelers and join the revamped Jets.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MICROCHIP TECHNOLOGY LOWERS EARNINGS ESTIMATE
description: The shares of Microchip Technology Inc. fell more than 20 percent yesterday after the company warned that earnings and revenue would be lower than expected in its fourth quarter, ending on March 31. The shares fell $7.50, to $28.50, in Nasdaq trading. Microchip, based in Chandler, Ariz., makes microcontrollers for cellular telephones and computer pointing devices and other products. The company said many of its customers were delaying orders because of high inventory levels. At least two brokerage houses downgraded the company's stock, and some analysts reduced their earnings estimates by 5 percent to 10 percent for the year that ends in March 1997.

title: Medical Certainty, Legal Limbo
description: In another state, the fate of Mariah Scoon, 5 months old, might well have already been decided. Instead of being connected to a mechanical ventilator at Long Island Jewish Medical Center, where doctors last week pronounced her dead based on no discernible brain activity, she might be buried, or cremated, the eulogies already spoken, the hymns already sung.

title: Where Madison Avenue Meets the Schoolhouse
description: This foray into free enterprise was approved by the school board here in the spring of 1993 and got under way that fall. At least one other entire district, in Osceola County, Fla., has now approved an advertising program of its own, and many others are thinking about it. The Board of Education in New York City, the nation's largest district, is considering a marketing company's school-bus advertising proposal that could bring the city's school system nearly $50 million over 10 years.

title: A Hate Vandal Strikes Again
description: Even as residents rallied tonight to protest a rash of anti-Semitic vandalism, the police said the vandal had apparently struck again in the Orienta Point section of this Westchester County village.

title: U S West's Continental Ambitions;Thanks to Communications Law, A Baby Bell Presses to Be a Cable Power
description: If you listened hard enough yesterday, you could almost hear the crack of a starting gun.

title: High Court Hands Corporations Victory on Class-Action Suits
description: In a significant victory for corporations seeking relief from onerous lawsuits, the United States Supreme Court ruled yesterday that state courts could approve global settlements in class-action cases, even when those cases involve Federal securities law claims that are beyond the jurisdiction of the states.

title: Actors Come on Cat Feet, Then Move On
description: GOING into the audition, Kimberly Wells had impeccable credentials.

title: Judge Responds to Abuse Furor
description: Judge Lorin Duckman of Brooklyn, who has come under intense criticism for his handling of two domestic violence cases and for suggestions that he might have beaten his wife, said yesterday that he did once have an experience with domestic violence -- as a potential victim.

title: Don't Allow Cuban Exiles to Make U.S. Policy;Unfair to Canada
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;LORAL ACKNOWLEDGES AN INVESTIGATION BY THE S.E.C.
description: The Loral Corporation said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating trading in shares of Loral prior to an announcement that the Lockheed Martin Corporation would acquire the company. On Jan. 8, Lockheed Martin said it would acquire most of Loral in a deal then valued at more than $7 billion. In a filing with the S.E.C. yesterday, Loral said the commission informed Lockheed on Feb. 8 that it had begun an informal inquiry into the trading. Lockheed said on Jan. 25 that the New York Stock Exchange had also asked for information on the trading. Also yesterday, Lockheed extended its offer until March 20 because the Federal Trade Commission had not acted on the transaction.

title: Canned Foods? Never! Well, Hardly Ever.
description: FRESH food may have achieved near-deity status, but even certified foodies open cans, often more than they realize. When asked what canned foods she uses, Sheila Lukins, the cookbook author, said: "Bumblebee white tuna in water and B & M baked beans. Those are about it."

title: Students Plan Tour to Support Affirmative Action
description: Students protesting attacks on affirmative action programs plan a three-month walking tour around California that is scheduled to culminate this August in a demonstration at the Republican National Convention in San Diego.

title: Good Habits Outweigh Genes As Key to a Healthy Old Age
description: HOW most people fare in old age may not be a matter of fate or genes, as many people believe. The way people age -- whether in their 70's and 80's they end up sick, demented and sexless or vigorous, sharp and libidinous -- is mostly a matter of how they live.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Market Place: Investors might want to carefully examine the reasons for Wal-Mart's drop in earnings.
description: SOME retail companies no longer need rising profits to keep their stock afloat these days -- they just have to be honest about a disappointing performance.

title: Foreign Affairs;J-a-p-a-n and C-h-i-n-a
description: With the Soviet threat now gone, and U.S. soldiers increasingly unpopular in Japan because of rape incidents in Okinawa, a lot of people are wondering how long the U.S.-Japan security alliance will hold and how long the U.S. will be able to station 47,000 troops here. Well, stop worrying. While the question is a legitimate one, the answer is obvious -- even though neither U.S. nor Japanese officials want to utter it aloud. So let me just whisper it here: What will keep the U.S. and Japan together in the coming decade is C-h-i-n-a.

title: Killer of 7 Executed After a 20-Year Stay On Texas Death Row
description: A man who confessed to killing seven people, including a 2-year-old girl, by stabbing them with a butcher knife in two murderous rampages more than 21 years ago, was executed here this evening.

title: Viewing the Barriers to Women's Careers
description: Sheila Wellington was about five minutes into a presentation yesterday morning when she spoke discouraging words: according to 325 chief executives in a new survey, women had not made it to the top of corporate America because they had not been "in the pipeline" long enough. Her audience -- a group of successful corporate women, mostly -- erupted in titters.

title: No Headline
description: People are largely responsible for their own old age."

title: COMPANY NEWS;MICRON ELECTRONICS TO CLOSE PC PLANT IN MINNEAPOLIS
description: Micron Electronics Inc. said yesterday that it would close its personal computer plant in Minneapolis and take a $30 million charge. The move, which will eliminate about 300 jobs, will result in a loss in the second quarter, ending this month, the company said. The plant was originally owned by Zeos International Inc., which merged last year with two units of Micron Technology Inc. of Boise, Idaho. Shares of Micron Technology, which owns about 80 percent of Micron Electronics, fell $3.125 yesterday, to $33.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of Micron Electronics fell $1.875, to $11, in Nasdaq trading. Micron Technology said on Monday that it would not install equipment at a new chip plant in Utah until demand improved.

title: Democrats Prepare Whitewater Filibuster
description: The partisan rivalries of Whitewater spilled beyond the hearing room today as Senate Democrats, accusing the Republican majority of a "political show trial," vowed a filibuster to block a plan for an open-ended extension of the inquiry into the convoluted affair and its connections to President Clinton and his wife, Hillary.

title: A Man Kills His Girlfriend, Then Himself
description: Just hours after he was sentenced under a plea bargain to probation for attacking his girlfriend's cousin with a baseball bat, a Bronx man shot and killed his girlfriend on Monday as their 3-month-old girl sat in her lap, the police said.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Nurse's Dismissal Is Urged
description: The State Department of Human Services has recommended that a nurse be dismissed for neglecting her duties and mistreating a 64-year-old patient who died at Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital, a department spokesman said yesterday. The nurse, whose name was withheld, was scheduled to appear today at a hearing before a disciplinary review board, said the spokesman, John McKeegan.

title: Bellinzona Journal;Poor Swiss Get U.S. Bill: $125 Billion and Change
description: This is a town of steep lanes, floodlighted castles atop rocky outcroppings and thick Alpine mists. It finds relief from February's glumness mainly in weeklong Carnival festivities.

title: BASKETBALL;The Teams Are Chosen For Preseason N.I.T.
description: U.C.L.A., Duke and Indiana, three teams that have won the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship in the last decade, will be among the 16 teams participating in the 1996 Preseason National Invitation Tournament.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Top Honors For Ogilvy Direct
description: For the fifth consecutive year, Ogilvy & Mather Direct, a unit of the WPP Group, took top honors from the judges of the John Caples International Awards for excellence in direct marketing. At the 18th annual ceremony last week in New York, the Ogilvy Direct offices in Malaysia, New York, New Zealand and Singapore won 8 of 59 prizes in 20 categories. Rapp Collins Worldwide, a unit of the Omnicom Group, followed with five awards.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Phillips Stuns White Sox by Retiring
description: Chicago White Sox left fielder TONY PHILLIPS surprised his new team yesterday by announcing his retirement from baseball. Phillips, a free agent who signed a two-year, $3.6 million contract with the White Sox on Jan. 20, left their Sarasota, Fla., camp last Saturday and returned to his home in Scottsdale, Ariz., for family reasons. On Monday night, he phoned Chicago General Manager RON SCHUELER and said he was retiring.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;An offbeat campaign enlists a giant bee to sing the praises of flora.
description: YOU certainly have heard of a spelling bee. Now brace yourself for a selling bee.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;From 'Atoms for Peace' to Chernobyl
description: You don't hear much these days about Atoms for Peace. Championed by several administrations after World War II, the effort promised a limitless supply of energy for the entire world. Now, scientists involved say, a half century of work that brought that dream to the verge of reality has been stopped flat by Federal budget cutbacks. Theirs is pretty much the point of view of tonight's elegiac edition of "The New Explorers."

title: Whatever Happened to Box-Office Star Power?
description: Mary Reilly," a drab, somnolent and expensive drama in which Julia Roberts plays the maid in the Jekyll-Hyde household, opened -- and virtually closed -- over the weekend. Its tepid performance at the box office ($2.8 million for a movie that cost $70 million to make and market) has already tagged the film as not only one of the most visible mishaps of this still-young year but also of Ms. Roberts's career.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SWIMMING;Foschi Pursuing Legal Remedies
description: The lawsuit by the Olympic hopeful JESSICA FOSCHI against swimming's governing bodies was moved from a Federal court to a New York state court yesterday in the event that the sport's international body tries to prevent her from competing.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Are Losers Two Ways
description: The losses kept piling up for the Rangers last night. They lost a 5-3 verdict to the Washington Capitals at Madison Square Garden.

title: Arafat's Police Hunt Bombers, Pushed Hard by Israelis
description: The Palestinian police, investigating two suicide bombings that killed 27 people on Sunday, rounded up scores of Islamic militants today in the West Bank and Gaza and identified two Palestinians as suspects, saying they have been missing from their homes at a refugee camp in Hebron for several days.

title: Nikkei Below 20,000
description: Stocks dropped here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 80.43 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, at 19,919.97, its first close below 20,000 this year. On Tuesday, the Nikkei fell 479.87 points, or 2.34 percent.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Kvaerner of Norway May Bid for Trafalgar
description: Trafalgar House, the British construction and shipping company, said yesterday that the Norwegian shipbuilder Kvaerner had informed it that it was interested in making a bid for the company. Earlier this month Kvaerner bought the power subsidiary of the Finnish engineering company Tampella. But it failed two months ago in a hostile attempt to buy Amec P.L.C., a British engineering company.

title: A Bold Gamble Or Tit-for-Tat?
description: Is turnabout fair play?

title: POLITICS;Election On Line
description: Computer users may obtain late results of the Republican Presidential primaries in Arizona and North and South Dakota from The New York Times's two services: The New York Times on the Web, at http://www.nytimes.com, and @times, on America Online.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BOMBARDIER DECIDES NOT TO BID FOR FOKKER
description: Bombardier Inc., the Montreal-based aircraft maker, said yesterday that it had decided against making an offer for Fokker N.V., leaving the Dutch commuter aircraft maker with only a few days to find an alternate plan to avert bankruptcy. "The risks involved were too high," a Bombardier spokesman said. Bombardier, a company with a record of turning around troubled plane builders, had been seen as Fokker's best hope for survival. A unit of Bombardier, Short Brothers of Northern Ireland, makes wings for Fokker, and a spokesman said the unit was still in talks with Fokker. Meanwhile, Hans Wijers, the Dutch Economics Minister, said he expected Samsung of South Korea to make its intentions on Fokker clear in the next few days. Fokker's majority shareholder, Daimler-Benz A.G., halted its support for the company last month.

title: Food Notes
description: Cooking in Venice

title: NASA Contacts Its Lost Satellite
description: NASA managed to communicate today with the satellite that has escaped its connection with the space shuttle Columbia and discovered that it had a dead computer.

title: Nurse With H.I.V. Emphasizes Safety
description: Three and a half years ago, shortly after Lynda M. Arnold had begun her afternoon nursing shift in the intensive-care unit at Community Hospital in Lancaster, Pa., she was told to put an intravenous line into a patient's arm.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Frederick Adams, 64, Connecticut Health Official
description: Dr. Frederick G. Adams, a Hartford dentist and public-health champion who was Connecticut's Health Commissioner under Gov. William A. O'Neill, died on Sunday at his Hartford home of complications from Lou Gehrig's disease. He was 64.

title: Business Travel;Four airlines are adding some extra creature comforts at Newark International Airport.
description: BUSINESS travelers flying Virgin Atlantic, Scandinavian Airlines System, Lufthansa or British Airways from the new international terminal at Newark International Airport will soon get some extra creature comforts. These four carriers have or are building elaborate departure lounges there, the first for any foreign airline at Newark.

title: Kellogg Ends Pensions for Some Directors
description: The Kellogg Company has ended pensions for its nonmanagement directors. Kellogg, which makes Rice Krispies and Special K cereals and Pop Tarts, said in a preliminary proxy statement this week with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was swapping stock grants, to be held in trust, for the retirement plans.

title: Extend the Whitewater Inquiry
description: Senator Christopher Dodd of Connecticut, reluctantly agreeing to renewal of the Senate Whitewater committee's expiring mandate, suggests limiting the extension to five weeks, ending April 3. Along with the minority leader, Tom Daschle, and other leading Senate Democrats, Mr. Dodd told reporters yesterday that they were prepared to filibuster against any extension beyond early April.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: U.S. Labor Making Use of Trade Accord It Fiercely Opposed
description: Courtesy of Nafta, the trade agreement that American organized labor has so reviled, union officials here trotted out an experimental new tactic today: allowing the cavalry from Mexico to sound the charge.

title: County Seeks Good Rating For Debt Issue
description: Orange County, Calif., courted Wall Street yesterday in an effort to get an investment-grade rating for about $830 million in new debt that the bankrupt county plans to issue in May.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Low Comedy Disguising Lofty Thoughts About Art
description: The place is Venice in the late 16th century, shortly after the Battle of Lepanto, in which the navies of Venice and its European allies triumphed over the Ottoman Empire. The future of the Mediterranean as a Christian sea has been assured. To celebrate this historic event, Venice has commissioned its most talented and fiercely independent painter, Galactia, to depict the battle on a canvas measuring 1,000 square feet. It is to be Renaissance Venice's epic, a majestic equivalent to "Victory at Sea."

title: COMPANY NEWS;REVLON ANTICIPATES HIGHER PRICE FOR ITS PUBLIC OFFERING
description: Strong demand for Revlon Inc.'s proposed initial public offering of 15 percent of its class A common stock has led the company to increase the potential price per share. Just a few weeks ago, the company said it was hoping to raise as much as $165 million by selling 7.5 million shares for $19 to $22 each. Now, Revlon believes the shares could be sold for $23 to $25 each, raising as much as $187.5 million. Revlon is closely held by the financier Ronald O. Perelman's MacAndrews & Forbes Holding Inc. The offering is expected to be priced and sold after the market closes today.

title: Hewlett-Packard in Deal
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it would buy an equity stake in Businessweb, a company in Cambridge, Mass., that develops business applications for the Internet. Financial terms were not disclosed. Hewlett-Packard, the computer giant based in Palo Alto, Calif., also said the two companies had signed a joint marketing and consulting agreement.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Marta Ferreira-Pero, president and creative director of the JMCT Publicidad division of Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, New York, was promoted to the new post of chairwoman. Richard Brunton, management supervisor, was promoted to succeed her as president; a successor has yet to be named for the post of creative director. Erica Gruen was named to the new post of media services director at Merkley Newman Harty, New York and Atlanta, a unit of the Omnicom Group. She had been senior vice president and strategic media resources director at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C.

title: Study Reports Small Risk, If Any, From Breast Implants
description: The largest study by far of silicone breast implants and disease finds that if implants pose any health risk at all, it is a very small one.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Alanis Morissette;Better to Sing The Teen-Age Life Than Live It
description: ALANIS MORISSETTE doesn't have a problem with self-esteem anymore. That was when she was younger, just a teen-ager -- not the self-assured 21-year-old whose album "Jagged Little Pill" has sold five million copies, lodged itself at No. 1 and gleaned six nominations for Grammy Awards, which will be announced tonight. Her songs about being misused and angry, uncertain but getting stronger, have made her a heroine to young girls across North America.

title: Sex Criminals Sacrifice Anonymity in Court
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Human Animals, Killing Like Wolves
description: LOVE THY NEIGHBOR A Story of War By Peter Maass 305 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: Esther S. Manz, 88, Founder Of TOPS Weight-Loss Group
description: Esther S. Manz, who was a 208-pound housewife pregnant with her fifth child when a kitchen-table gathering in 1948 inspired her to found TOPS, a weight-loss support group that grew into a 300,000-member nonprofit organization, died on Monday at the Heritage Nursing Home in Milwaukee. Mrs. Manz, who made her home in Greenfield, Wis., a suburb of Milwaukee, was 88. TOPS, which stands for Take Off Pounds Sensibly, draws its philosophy from something the 5-foot-2-inch Mrs. Manz, then 40, observed in group sessions intended to prepare women for childbirth: the power of mutual support in helping participants remain within their doctors' guidelines for weight.

title: Ruling on Clinton
description: A Federal judge today rejected a plan to have President Clinton testify by videotape in the criminal trial of his former Whitewater partners. Defense lawyers immediately demanded that Mr. Clinton testify in person. Judge George Howard Jr. told lawyers that he would not transport them and court officials to Washington for Mr. Clinton's testimony.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Clinton Asks Congress To Send Jordan F-16's
description: Citing the need to support Jordan's efforts for peace in the Middle East, President Clinton requested Congressional approval today for funds to send Jordan 16 F-16 fighter jets.

title: POLITICS: BOB DOLE;Dole Counts On a Surge Of Support In the South
description: Senator Bob Dole today took his retooled campaign to South Carolina, the gateway to a surge of primaries and caucuses over the next month that should decide the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Shipbuilder Rescued
description: The creditor banks of Bremer Vulkan A.G. pledged to grant almost 100 million German marks ($70 million) in fresh credit to keep the cash-short shipbuilder afloat for the next two months, the group's administrators said yesterday. "Production can continue," the court-appointed administrator, Jobst Wellensiek, said after Bremer Vulkan's 40 creditor banks hammered out an interim solution to the company's fiscal problems on Monday. Bremer Vulkan, Germany's largest shipbuilder, with yards dotted across northern Germany, filed last week for protection from creditors after presenting a loss of 1 billion marks ($700 million) for 1995 and saying many of its units were insolvent. (Reuters)

title: U.S. Makes the Best of UN's Softer Denunciation of Cuban Downing
description: WASHINGTON  The U.S. ambassador to the United Nations said Tuesday that she was "delighted" with a Security Council denunciation of Cuba for its downing of two unarmed U.S. civilian planes.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Showing Off Bus of Future
description: For decades, New York's bus system, the largest in the country, was also notorious for spewing highly polluting exhaust into the air.

title: Don't Allow Cuban Exiles to Make U.S. Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Twin Russian Pianists Play the Lively Ones Julia and Irina Elkina Merkin Concert Hall

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Four More Years for Bills' Thomas Smith
description: The Buffalo Bills signed cornerback THOMAS SMITH, a restricted free agent, to a four-year contract worth $6.8 million yesterday. Smith, the Bills' No. 1 draft pick out of North Carolina in 1993, had two interceptions last season and led the team by knocking down 16 passes.

title: Portrait From New Era Of Nation's Gambling
description: Her nimble fingers dance across the red felt semicircle, dealing cards and sweeping up chips. She calculates at lightning speed, rewarding good luck with more chips, and grimacing as she cleans out a loser.

title: BASEBALL;After His Seasons of Grief, Flora Is on the Field Again
description: Baseball is just baseball again to Kevin Flora: a field of dreams and not a reminder of tragedy. That's saying a lot, considering what the Mets' 26-year-old outfield prospect has been through the last three years.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Despite Bradley's Battle, Nets Fall to Heat
description: Like their respective teams, Shawn Bradley and Alonzo Mourning battled this one out until well after the final buzzer.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the listing of new equity issues in Business Day on Feb. 20 referred incompletely to an offering of 1.6 million units by Lightpath Technologies Inc. Besides one class B warrant and one share of class A common stock, each unit consists of one class A warrant.

title: A GIANT MERGER OF PHONE AND CABLE
description: U S West, a regional phone company, will acquire the nation's third-largest cable operator in a multibillion-dollar deal. Business Day, page D1.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Victims'-Family Law Argued
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court heard arguments yesterday on the constitutionality of a new law allowing the family and friends of a murder victim to testify during the death-penalty phase of a trial.

title: Owners of Barney's Will End Partnership With Restaurateur
description: In the latest unraveling of a Barney's business relationship since the company filed for bankruptcy protection last month, the owners, Bob and Gene Pressman, said yesterday they would dissolve a partnership with the restaurateur Pino Luongo.

title: Sports of The Times;Nets Should Keep Beard Next Year
description: THE rich get. You know what the rich get. They get a piece of the action. They get a long-term contract. They get the power to call in the moving van.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;A Costly Gesture by Bullets' Howard
description: JUWAN HOWARD of the Washington Bullets was fined $5,000 by the National Basketball Association yesterday for making an obscene gesture when he was ejected from Friday night's game against Charlotte. Howard made the gesture after he was ejected with 2 minutes 49 seconds left in the fourth quarter of the 100-96 loss at Landover, Md. He also kicked a water cooler across the court. An ejection carries an additional automatic fine of $1,000.

title: HOCKEY;Finally, Gretzky Is Traded to Blues
description: For the second time in his magnificent career, Wayne Gretzky has been traded in a megadeal that could alter the balance of power in the National Hockey League.

title: POLITICS: AIR TIME;Fox Offer: The Fur Flies
description: To hear the wrath of Rupert Murdoch's competitors yesterday, one would think that the chairman of the News Corporation had proposed treason. What Mr. Murdoch said, in a speech on Monday, was that his Fox television network would give an hour of free time to the major-party Presidential candidates in the fall, so they could make a final campaign pitch to the public.

title: Sex Shops and Patrons Join In Suits Challenging Zoning
description: In a widely expected challenge to a New York City zoning law that restricts sex-related businesses, the New York Civil Liberties Union and a lawyer for more than 70 business owners filed suit yesterday, saying the law would violate constitutional guarantees of free speech, unlawfully restrict consumer access and eliminate 85 percent of the city's adult entertainment industry.

title: BASKETBALL;Overlooked, Maybe, but Definitely Not Overmatched
description: Power ratings are in the eye of the beholder.

title: Gtech Sells Amtote
description: The Gtech Holdings Corporation has sold its Amtote International Inc. unit to the closely held Mudge Acquisitions Group of Baltimore. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Nuclear Middlemen
description: The Senate is scheduled to hold hearings today on a dangerous new treaty negotiated by the Clinton Administration that would lift longstanding controls on nuclear trade. Unless the Senate rejects the treaty, it will go into effect within two months.

title: Consumers Feel More Upbeat, Survey Shows
description: Consumers felt much better about the economy in February, a monthly survey showed today. Analysts took the finding as support for the recent assessment by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, that economic weakness would likely prove temporary.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Most-Wanted Delinquent Parent Surrenders in Support Case
description: The most wanted delinquent parent in a child-support case in New York State sat low in his Pontiac Firebird today and stared at the Nassau County Family Court building. By his side was a well-thumbed Bible. In his hands were some notes, scribbled on the back of a cardboard box, which included the name of the sheriff to whom he was supposed to surrender.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Power and Tension In Provocative Readings Stephen Hough, Pianist Walter Reade Theater

title: HOCKEY;Devils Seeking Offense From Defenseman
description: The Devils are looking at newly acquired defenseman Phil Housley to solve their seasonlong lack of goal production, which has left the Stanley Cup champions ahead of only the lowly Ottawa Senators in scoring goals in the 26-team National Hockey League.

title: Recalling a Life Ended With a Bus Bombing
description: Two days before Sara Duker was killed by a suicide bomber in downtown Jerusalem, a couple of postcards arrived at the home of the Moffets, whose children she used to baby-sit.

title: Near Sarajevo, a Quest To Heal War's Hatred
description: Every evening, after walking his beat in this suburb newly transferred from rebel Serbian control, Radovan Zidovic, a police officer for the Bosnian-Croat Federation, drives to a hospital in Sarajevo. He weeps at the bedsides of his daughter and father, who were gravely injured by a Bosnian Serb grenade, and wonders why he spends his days cheerfully greeting his former enemies, offering them his hand and the reassurance that they should stay in their homes.

title: HOCKEY;Islnders Simply Outclassed by Red Wings
description: The Detroit Red Wings visited Long Island tonight and showed why they are the best team in the National Hockey League.

title: At the Nation's Table;A Country Retreat With Opulent Feasts
description: Twin Farms, a country getaway in Barnard, Vt., is a movable feast.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: AT&T to Offer Customers Free Internet Access AT&T, pushing aggressively into the Internet business, said it would offer its telephone customers five hours of free Internet access each month for a year.

title: Pataki Rebukes Aide Over a Fund-Raiser
description: Gov. George E. Pataki rebuked one of his top aides today for agreeing to act as a host for a fund-raising event for a member of the State Assembly.

title: Wine Talk
description: WHAT's all the fuss about merlot, anyway?

title: COMPANY NEWS;BMW PLANS AN EXPANSION AT SOUTH CAROLINA PLANT
description: The German car maker Bayerische Motorenwerke A.G. said yesterday that it would invest an additional $200 million at its factory in Spartanburg, S.C. BMW said it would add about 300,000 square feet of manufacturing space to the plant, which now contains 1.2 million square feet and employs about 1,500 workers.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Parade Ends a Festival In Cuban Troupe's Tour
description: A festive parade concluded the program that the Cuban National Folkloric Dance Ensemble brought to Brooklyn College on Sunday afternoon. But the entire matinee was a festival.

title: The Neediest Cases;'Penny Philanthropist' Inspires Dozens to Make Small Donations
description: He spoke, and people listened. George C. Ginsberg, 96, known to relatives as Papa George and to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund as the Penny Philanthropist, has never been bashful about the amount that he gives, which usually hovers between $1 and $10. He has urged others not to refrain from giving simply because they could not give large sums.

title: AT&T Chief, Who Cut Jobs, Defends Pay
description: Robert E. Allen, AT&T's chairman and chief executive and the man who ordered 40,000 people cut from the company's payroll, received stock options last year that increased his total pay package to $16 million from $6.7 million.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Performing Works on Piano From a Core Repertory Andre Watts Avery Fisher Hall

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;A Southwest Pork Stew Updated
description: Guisado is a stew of pork from the Southwest that usually calls for hours of cooking. The recipe adapted here, like many old recipes, can be tinkered with slightly to produce a dish in much less time. This one can be ready in less than half an hour.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Penguins' Francis Fined and Suspended
description: RON FRANCIS of the Pittsburgh Penguins was fined $1,000 and suspended for two games without pay by the league yesterday. Francis, the league's third-leading scorer, was penalized because of a checking-from-behind incident against Montreal Canadiens defenseman VLADIMIR MALAKHOV on Saturday, the league said. Francis received a minor penalty for the incident at 10 minutes 38 seconds of the first period. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about the WHX Corporation's takeover bid for Teledyne Inc. misstated the action taken on Monday. As the article noted, WHX raised its bid for Teledyne and hinted at a proxy fight for control of the company; Teledyne is not bidding for WHX.

title: Fund Growth Sets Record And Doesn't Break Stride
description: It may sound like a broken record, but Wall Street loves the tune: Investors have continued to pour money into stock and bond mutual funds in February, barely pausing for breath after their purchases set a record in January.

title: U.S. SAYS CUBANS KNEW THEY FIRED ON CIVILIAN PLANES
description: The Clinton Administration made public today a transcript of aerial radio conversations that American diplomats say proves Cuban military pilots knew they had targeted a small civilian plane and screamed with glee when they made a direct hit.

title: Carjackers Fleeing Police Strike Pedestrian
description: Two men taking a truck for a test drive yesterday with a salesman in Queens threw the salesman out and, chased by the police, sped into Brooklyn, where they struck and critically injured a 17-year-old girl.

title: About New York;Red Hook Is Awaiting A Court Date
description: THE people of Red Hook await justice. They've already picked out a home for it inside a yellow brick building guarded by a rusty fence and plywood-covered windows.

title: Cable Chief Has a Full Agenda, and $1.2 Billion
description: If U S West completes its planned purchase of Continental Cablevision, Amos B. Hostetter Jr. stands to make about $1.2 billion from the sale of his 40 percent stake in the cable company. But Mr. Hostetter, the chairman of Continental, is not slowing down at age 59.

title: BASKETBALL;Surgery for High School Star
description: Ronnie Fields, one of the top high school basketball players in the nation, underwent three and a half hours of surgery today to repair a broken bone in his neck, which he sustained in a car accident early Monday. The surgery involved fusing three cervical vertebrae.

title: Personal Health
description: CARPAL tunnel syndrome has plagued workers for more than 100 years, but not until it struck the nation's reporters and editors with a vengeance did this debilitating disorder of the wrist, hand and arm become a household word.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bond Traders Still Jittery As Prices Fall
description: The mood among bond traders remains jittery, and prices moved lower for the third consecutive day yesterday as investors focused more on this week's supply of new Treasury securities than on the long list of positive economic factors reported yesterday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Germany Reports a Decline In Output for Recent Quarter
description: The German Economics Ministry said today that the nation's seasonally adjusted gross domestic product fell slightly in the fourth quarter of 1995 from the previous quarter, and was only slightly higher than for the comparable period in 1994.

title: Ford Offers Taurus Designed for Japan
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it expected to increase its car sales in Japan with a new model: a United States-built Taurus with right-hand drive and features specifically for the Japanese market.

title: Riley Discusses His Old Squad
description: As his Miami Heat prepared to play the Nets tonight at the Meadowlands, Coach Pat Riley had some thoughts about the Knicks.

title: Pataki Adviser Gets Subpoena Over Inaugural
description: The Democratic-controlled Assembly issued subpoenas today to Gov. George E. Pataki's top economic adviser and a private lawyer, seeking information about the corporation that financed Mr. Pataki's three-day inauguration last year.

title: School's Corporate Rescue: Cash for Books and Desks
description: When MIPS Technologies, one of the country's largest microchip manufacturers, started a nationwide contest to find a school that could most benefit from a corporate donation, it fully expected principals to put computers, software and other high-tech equipment at the top of their wish lists.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Imagining and Improvising
description: For the last two years Wynton Marsalis has played a benefit for Smalls in Greenwich Village, virtually unannounced. Mr. Marsalis started a three-day stand on Monday night, using a group of young musicians who were some 10 to 15 years his junior. Completely informal and attended by musicians and jazz fans, the show brought out the best in everyone; the point was to improvise, to make the material vanish under the weight of the imagination.

title: Company Sees Stock Fall 46%
description: The shares of Health Management Inc. plunged 46 percent today after it said it would restate some fiscal 1995 financial results and take a $15 million to $20 million pretax charge in its third quarter because of accounting irregularities. Its top officer took a lesser post and a second officer resigned.

title: Justice Denied in Oklahoma
description: In explaining his decision to move the Oklahoma City bombing trial to Denver, Federal Judge Richard P. Matsch said that it would not be possible to impanel an impartial jury in Oklahoma because the extensive local media coverage had "demonized" the defendants, Timothy J. McVeigh and Terry L. Nichols.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: MUSIC REVIEW;On Ives, the Arguments Continue
description: The debate about Charles Ives still rages in some circles, but generally speaking, those who consider this crusty old New Englander an amateur whom posterity has perversely canonized have been outvoted by those who consider him a great American original. The American Composers Orchestra and its music director, Dennis Russell Davies, presumably subscribe to the prevailing view, but at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon, they provided ample fodder for both sides of the argument.

title: FILM REVIEW;When Rancid Rat Meets Righteous Indignation in India
description: The difference between Singh (Mohan Agashe), a brutish landowner who bullies and bribes his way through Sandip Ray's film "Target," and the typical modern screen villain is that Singh is scarily recognizable as a man rotting in his own power. A greedy, paranoid alcoholic whose favorite activity is hunting wild game, Singh rules over a rural village of "untouchable" laborers in contemporary India like a feudal despot. Imagine a slightly less maniacal version of the Rev. Jim Jones, and you'll have a picture of Singh and his aura of dread.

title: Glaxo's Trade Loophole
description: Congress finds it hard to remedy the simplest mistakes when powerful corporate interests are at stake. In 1994, when it approved a new trade pact with more than 100 other countries, it unintentionally handed pharmaceutical drug companies windfall profits. More than a year later, Congress has yet to correct the error.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GROUP LED BY FLUOR WINS FLORIDA TRAIN CONTRACT
description: A group led by the Fluor Corporation won a contract yesterday to build a $4.8 billion bullet train linking major Florida cities -- Miami, Orlando and Tampa -- over the next decade. The group, Florida Overland Express, plans to provide rail service at speeds up to 220 m.p.h. between Miami and Orlando by 2004. Florida has committed $1.75 billion to the project; another $3 billion would be financed with tax-exempt bonds. Florida Overland Express includes Fluor and Odebrecht S.A. of Brazil. Each would each have a one-third stake. The other partners are Bombardier of Canada and GEC Alsthom, co-owned by Alcatel Alsthom of France and the General Electric Company of Britain.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: The Virtues of Competition, Heard 30 Years Later Misha Dichter 92d Street Y

title: At the Nation's Table;Diet Vacation Without Spa Prices
description: Wally Arnold, the kitchen manager and chef in the Old Captiva House at 'Tween Waters Inn, armed with his trusty computer and eight years of working with visiting spa groups, crafts menus for guests who want a diet vacation without the priciness of a full service spa.

title: To Privatize Faster, Try a U.S. Yard Sale
description: To the Editor:

title: 1 Million Bake-Off Winner Is a He
description: BY cleverly arranging the contents of some cans and boxes, a single father was able to earn $1 million yesterday. Kurt Wait won the Pillsbury Bake-Off in Dallas with a can of sweetened condensed milk, a can of pears, a box of devil's-food cake mix and a jar of butterscotch-caramel-fudge ice-cream topping.

title: Bombing Suspects' Neighbors Fearful
description: A pall of unease fell over this refugee camp near Hebron today, the home of two Palestinians suspected of being the suicide bombers who killed 25 people in two attacks in Israel on Sunday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Twins Come to Terms with Cordova
description: MARTY CORDOVA, the American League rookie of the year, and the Minnesota Twins agreed to a $6.3 million, four-year contract yesterday. Cordova, who hit .277 last season with 24 homers and 84 runs batted in, gets $500,000 this season, $800,000 in 1997, $2 million in 1998 and $3 million in 1999. The Twins have a $3.75 million option for 2000. Cordova will not be eligible for free agency until after the 2001 season. (AP)

title: Mayberry Re-signs With Tampa Bay
description: Center Tony Mayberry re-signed with Tampa Bay today, becoming the second of the team's 11 unrestricted free agents to reach an agreement to remain with the Buccaneers.

title: Novo Says Court Has Reversed An Injunction Against Hormone
description: Novo Nordisk A/S, a biotechnology and pharmaceuticals company based in Denmark, said yesterday the Federal Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit had reversed an injunction from a lower court that blocked sales of its genetically engineered human growth hormone in the United States.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE scene: Second Avenue in the 70's.

title: An Embattled Judge Breaks His Silence
description: Judge Lorin Duckman of Brooklyn, criticized for his handling of two domestic violence cases and for suggestions that he might have beaten his wife, said yesterday that he did once have an experience with domestic violence -- as a potential victim.

title: Joseph Barr, 78, Bank Executive Who Held Several Federal Posts
description: Joseph W. Barr, a former Treasury Secretary, Congressman and bank executive, died on Friday in Playa del Carmen, Mexico, where he was vacationing. He was 78 and lived in Hume, Va.

title: World News Briefs;Poltical Motive Alleged In Killing of Cambodian
description: A Oscar-winning Cambodian actor slain in Los Angeles may have been killed by agents of the Khmer Rouge, his brother said today.

title: New Electronic Gear: Ready to Consume Or Only Half-Baked?
description: WHEN people ask at what point they should embrace new technology and be confident it is here to stay, I think of the exquisitely fashioned buggy whip that lies coiled on a table in my living room.

title: Big Business Can't Run From Workers' Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: HOCKEY;Lemaire Wants Housley To Energize Power Play
description: Phil Housley practiced with the Devils for the first time today and looked as if he had been with the team for months. The defenseman seemed to know all of Coach Jacques Lemaire's drills, and no one ever stopped to point things out to him.

title: Big Business Can't Run From Workers' Plight;For a New Capitalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Agency Votes To Start Talks On Lilco Plan
description: Determined to cut the highest electric bills in the continental United States, a state agency voted today to begin negotiations to replace the Long Island Lighting Company with a hybrid public-private system.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;C.P.A. Admits to Fraud
description: A certified public accountant from Barnegat admitted yesterday in Federal Court that he collected $22,361 in fraudulent refunds from the Internal Revenue Service by filing 12 phony tax returns.

title: Israel and Syria in New Talks, With Hopes for Modest Gains
description: Despite the passions aroused in Israel by a Palestinian bombing campaign and a simultaneous Israeli election campaign, Israel and Syria opened their third round of American-mediated peace talks today with room for modest progress on water, security and economic issues.

title: Death Penalty Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Data Differ on Health Benefits
description: More New Jersey businesses than ever are providing health benefits to their workers, and more of the coverage is taking the form of health maintenance organizations, the New Jersey Business and Industry Association said yesterday.

title: Malcolm T. Wordell, Navy Ace, Dies at 84
description: Malcolm T. Wordell, a World War II fighter pilot who won three Distinguished Flying Cross medals and graduated from the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis without a blemish on his record, died here on Monday. He was 84.

title: Daiwa Bank Admits Guilt In Cover-Up
description: Daiwa Bank Ltd. of Japan pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that it covered up more than $1 billion in trading losses at its New York branch, and it agreed to pay $340 million in fines as it moved to put the scandal behind it.

title: Auto Suppliers Find a Niche in Safety
description: Auto parts companies are putting a growing emphasis on safety, displaying new products at a convention here this week that range from stronger windows to rotating headrests.

title: A Needless Mental Health Tragedy
description: There is a lot of finger-pointing in the case of Jaheem Grayton, the 15-year-old accused of causing the death of a young woman who fell or was pushed to the tracks during a recent robbery in the New York City subway. Who was most responsible for insuring that Mr. Grayton, a troubled youth under treatment for mental illness, took his prescribed medication -- the hospital that treated him for a month and then discharged him, the clinic that was to provide follow-up treatment but did not, or his family? The case deserves a thorough review by state authorities to remedy apparent defects in the system that let a troubled patient go too long without supervised care.

title: Sylvia Williams, 60, Museum Director
description: Sylvia H. Williams, director of the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of African Art for 13 years, died yesterday at Georgetown University Medical Center. She was 60 and lived in Washington.

title: Rivals Yawn at U S West Cable Deal
description: U S West's telephone rivals are almost cavalier in their reaction to the company's $5.3 billion acquisition of Continental Cablevision, which was announced on Tuesday. "It just means that somebody else's name goes on your cable bill," said Stuart C. Johnson, president of Bell Atlantic's video services division.

title: More Talking to the TV
description: To The Home Section:

title: DANCE REVIEW;Protecting a Harvest, Choosing a Wife
description: Charles Moore was a wonderfully elegant and reserved performer who seemed to believe that the African and Caribbean dances he presented, some of them reconstructions of rarely seen material, could sell themselves. That restraint -- and an atmosphere of bubbling joy -- were hallmarks of the program presented by the Charles Moore Dance Theater on Saturday afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Japanese Stocks Gain
description: Japanese stocks were trading higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 205.40 points, or 1.03 percent, to close at 20,125.37. On Wednesday, the index fell 80.43 points.

title: Albany Leaders to Support Temporary Financing Plan
description: New York's legislative leaders agreed today to support the use of temporary spending measures to finance the government for the first part of the next fiscal year if the drawn-out battle in Washington over the Federal budget continues.

title: Terror in Israel: Who Will Bring Hamas to Heel?
description: The violent blasts that shattered six months of relative calm between the Palestinians and Israelis have disclosed a basic difference in what each expected from their peace: Israel wanted security, the Palestinians a land.

title: Cervix Length Tied To Early Birth Risk
description: The length of a pregnant woman's cervix may be an important clue to her risk of giving birth prematurely.

title: Revlon Public Offering Priced at $24 a Share
description: The initial public offering of Revlon Inc. was priced at $24 a share yesterday by the cosmetic company's underwriting group, one of the lead underwriters, Merrill Lynch & Company, said.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Fields's Doctors Optimistic
description: Doctors treating the Chicago prep basketball star RONNIE FIELDS say he should be able to return to school in two weeks and could be practicing basketball again just five months after surgery on his spine.

title: Osaka Journal;For Old Gangster, Long Arm of Mob Won't Let Go
description: It is not just that he has been kidnapped, bombarded with death threats and slashed in the head so gravely that he almost died.

title: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;South Carolina Is a Crossroads For the G.O.P.
description: With red lipstick from farewell kisses still smeared across both cheeks, Todd E. Alexander worked his last shift at Clinton Mills Industries' Lydia plant, a hulking old textile mill that plans to shut its doors in April. During a midday break, the 23-year-old maintenance technician explained how his involuntary search for a job had intersected with his search for a Presidential candidate in the state's Republican primary on Saturday.

title: M.T.A. Tolls to Rise 17% For Bridges and Tunnels
description: The price of driving from one borough to another is to rise on March 24, with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board vote yesterday to raise the tolls on its major bridges and tunnels to $3.50 each way, from $3.00.

title: POP REVIEW;Bubblegum With a Sense Of Humor
description: Though some fans like to think of punk rock as a reaction against pop music, it began as an imitation of pop performed by musicians with lax standards of perfection and little technical skill. At Wetlands on Sunday night, Weston, a quartet from Pennsylvania, brought punk back to its roots as crude bubblegum pop.

title: Out of a Job, Walesa Decides to Take to the Lecture Circuit
description: Forget the shipyard. Lech Walesa, who announced after his defeat that he was planning to pick up tools and don coveralls at his old workplace, has decided to behave like a more normal ex-President.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Thai Airways Plans Expansion of Fleet
description: The board of Thai Airways International P.L.C. approved a plan yesterday to order 21 new airplanes in the next five years at an estimated cost of $5 billion. The board also approved the sale of 31 older planes in its fleet, according to the airline's chairman, Siripong Thongyai.

title: For Geriatric Prisons
description: To The Home Section:

title: Singapore Debate Terms
description: To the Editor:

title: Report on Massacre Provokes A Political Storm in Mexico
description: Mexico's shaky political balance was weakened today as opposition leaders threatened to storm out of crucial talks on election reforms to protest what they claimed was an attempt to whitewash the massacre of 17 peasants by police in the state of Guerrero last June.

title: Cuba's 2 Steps Back
description: To many, Cuba's decision to shoot down two civilian planes over the Straits of Florida last weekend came as a surprise, given President Fidel Castro's recent campaign to improve relations with the United States. But Mr. Castro has always lashed out at enemies, real or imagined, whenever he feels threatened, and he and his Government are feeling especially threatened these days.

title: Rabbi Albert J. Amateau, 106, Sephardic Leader
description: Albert J. Amateau, who spent years as a social worker, rabbi, lawyer, Federal official and businessman and still found room for a lifetime of civic and charitable endeavors, died on Feb. 9 at his home in Santa Rosa, Calif. He was 106.

title: TV Executives Reach Broad Accord on Rating Violent Shows
description: After years of denouncing the idea as unworkable and an infringement on free speech, executives from throughout the television industry have reached agreement on the broad outlines of a violence ratings system that would be used with new technology to let households automatically block out violent shows.

title: CHRONICLE
description: After eight weeks at home, the centenarian GEORGE BURNS has ventured out to his favorite hangouts -- his office and the Hillcrest Country Club in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Michigan Bids For Auto Jobs Of the Future
description: The Governor of Michigan called today for a large-scale educational program that would use computer networks and tax credits to help train workers for future job openings in the automobile industry.

title: Government Faces Decision on Milken Probation
description: Michael R. Milken is scheduled to complete three years of probation tomorrow.

title: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;Divided Verdicts From the Early Primaries Are Raising the Stakes for the Next Batch
description: Just days after his candidacy was written off by his rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination, Steve Forbes found himself back at the center of attention today after his relentless championing of a flat-tax proposal finally paid off with a victory on Tuesday in the Arizona primary.

title: Currents;Style Underfoot for Less
description: CUSTOM hand-tufted area rugs and runners by Christine VanDerHurd add snap to any room, but they used to take a bite out of the decorating budget. That will change next month, when the English textile designer introduces a collection of lower-price, machine-made rugs for around $800 (6 by 9 feet). Her four patterns in charcoal and natural wool will include the loopy pair of tattooed cherubs above, a design that recalls early-American calligraphy. Stores are still in negotiation. Information: (212) 343-9070.

title: Leading High School Decides to Change Its Entrance Policy
description: The school board has unanimously approved a new entrance policy for Lowell High, one of the country's most academically rigorous schools.

title: House Vote Keeps Peanut and Sugar Price Supports
description: The House narrowly rejected efforts tonight to eliminate Government price supports for peanuts and sugar, which critics contend cost American consumers billions a year.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a rift between the Russian Orthodox Church and the Orthodox Patriarchate of Constantinople misstated the day when the breach became official. It was Friday, not Sunday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;B.P. SEEN IN EUROPEAN DEAL WITH MOBIL
description: The British Petroleum Company and the Mobil Corporation plan to combine their European refining, gasoline-station and lubricants operations in a $5 billion deal, according to articles today in The Financial Times and The Wall Street Journal. Under an agreement expected to be announced today, B.P. would control the refining and marketing businesses, while Mobil would handle the lubricants operation, the newspapers said. B.P. would have a 70 percent interest in the venture, which would have combined annual sales of $20 billion. The companies are expected to take charges totaling $400 million to start the venture. Company officials declined to comment last night. Separately, Mobil agreed yesterday to sell its Tucker Housewares subsidiary, which makes plastic containers and other products, to the Zeta Consumer Products Corporation for an undisclosed price. (Reuters)

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Voting on Welfare Limits
description: Anyone convicted of a drug offense would be denied general welfare assistance under a bill the Assembly is voting on today. But a person found guilty of drug possession could become eligible for assistance by completing a drug rehabilitation program, said the bill's sponsor, Assemblyman Raul Garcia, Republican of Union City. Anyone convicted of distributing drugs would be permanently excluded.

title: INSIDE
description: Loans Delayed for China

title: Calls Stop Many a Jump Off Mid-Hudson Bridge
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLF;A Relaxed Approach By Faldo
description: The big man and the young woman were strolling across the stepstones today at Doral Resort and Spa. Hand in hand, through the flowers and past the big marble fountain in front of the hotel, they bounced like a couple of carefree school kids, into the lobby and down the stairs.

title: Hospital Ordered to Keep Brain-Dead Baby Alive
description: A Queens judge ordered hospital officials to maintain a brain-dead infant on a mechanical ventilator yesterday so lawyers for the baby's parents can present their arguments for sustaining medical treatment to a higher court.

title: POLITICS: THE BALLOT;Ruling Puts Forbes on Primary Ballot Across New York
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled yesterday that Steve Forbes's name should appear on the Republican Presidential primary ballot across New York, insuring that the March 7 primary will be the most competitive since state Republicans adopted restrictive primary rules 40 years ago.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Groupe Paribas Begins Takeover Bid for Rival
description: The French holding company Groupe Paribas began a $1.8 billion takeover bid yesterday for Navigation Mixte, a rival holding company. Paribas raised its stake in Mixte to 51 percent from 31 percent by buying shares from the investment company Societe Centrale d'Investissement and the German insurer Allianz. It bought the shares at 800 francs, or $161, each and offered to buy more shares at the same price, valuing the takeover at 8.9 billion francs, or $1.79 billion.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.F.L.;Brown Signs With Cardinals
description: LOMAS BROWN, one of the National Football League's best left tackles for much of his 11-year career with the Detroit Lions, has agreed to a three-year, $9 million contract with the Arizona Cardinals. Brown, 32, an unrestricted free agent, has been a Pro Bowl selection six straight years.

title: Bridge
description: As a curtain-raiser tonight to the Spring National Championships beginning in Philadelphia tomorrow, the American Contract Bridge League will induct six players into the Bridge Hall of Fame.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Grows, But Gap With Japan Slims
description: The nation's trade deficit worsened slightly in December, making the 1995 total the biggest in seven years, the Commerce Department said today. The figures immediately added fuel to the debate on trade that has played a key role in the Presidential campaign so far.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Another Close Call For UMass
description: Massachusetts dodged a second straight defeat tonight.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;At Pepsi and Coke, New Marketing Steps
description: The Pepsi-Cola Company and the Coca-Cola Company are undertaking initiatives to help market their soft-drink brands.

title: No Death Penalty In Drug Slaying
description: A Federal jury failed to reach a unanimous decision Wednesday on whether to impose the death penalty on two men convicted in the drug-related slaying of an Ulster County man. As a result, the men will not be executed.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MICRON PLANS TO WEIGH SPINOFFS OF TWO UNITS
description: Micron Technology Inc. said yesterday that it would consider spinning off its communications and flat-panel-display units as separately traded companies. Kipp A. Bedard, vice president for corporate affairs, said the company, which makes semiconductors, had no timetable for such spinoffs but would consider them if the units were able to bring products to market profitably. Mr. Bedard said Micron, which is based in Boise, Idaho, would retain a majority interest in any units it spun off. Micron Communications brought out its first commercial product late last year, while the first products from the flat-panel unit are due late this year or early in 1997, Mr. Bedard said. (Reuters)

title: AT HOME WITH: David Guterson;Amid the Cedars, Serenity and Success
description: DAVID GUTERSON has been away from home for only two hours, but when he walks into the kitchen of his shingle-style bungalow, telephone messages line the door frame.

title: Cost Cutting Cancels Airdrops Of Food and Mail to Antarctica
description: In the latest belt-tightening step forced upon the National Science Foundation, the agency has canceled the customary midwinter airdrop of supplies and mail for 1996 to two of the three research stations the United States operates in Antarctica.

title: Changing Her Mind, Diana Agrees to Divorce
description: The Princess of Wales said today that she had reluctantly changed her mind and would agree to divorce her estranged husband, Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Jordan and Barkley Fined
description: MICHAEL JORDAN and CHARLES BARKLEY were fined $10,000 each by the National Basketball Association for failing to show up for a media availability day on the Friday before the N.B.A. All-Star Game in San Antonio. Jordan and Barkley were reportedly playing golf at the time, either in Las Vegas or Phoenix.

title: ON HOCKEY;Gretzky Deal Looks Good on Paper
description: The trade of Wayne Gretzky from Los Angeles to St. Louis could be a good deal for just about everyone involved, directly and indirectly.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Helping a Family Care For a Child With H.I.V.
description: Selina H. lost her older sister to AIDS in 1994, leaving behind three children. One child went to live with an aunt, one stayed with a maternal grandmother in Manhattan and one moved to South Carolina to be with a paternal grandmother.

title: POLITICS: NEW YORK STATE;NEW YORK PRIMARY SUDDENLY EMERGES AS A CRUCIAL TEST
description: With a nudge from Steve Forbes's resurgent campaign, the Republican Presidential primary in New York has suddenly emerged as a central contest on the election calender, presenting a largely uncluttered race between Mr. Forbes and Senator Bob Dole for 93 convention delegates, being chosen by the voters next Thursday.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Bradley Is Gaining in Stature
description: Shawn Bradley outplayed one All-Star center on Wednesday night. But as good as Alonzo Mourning is, he is not Shaquille O'Neal, the Wunderkind the Nets and Bradley have to face for the first time this season on Thursday night.

title: No Headline
