description: IF Freud were suddenly to reappear on West End Avenue, he might feel right at home with -- or possibly on -- the antique chaise in the office of Dr. Richard Fulmer, a psychotherapist. With its elaborately carved legs and pleasing plumpness, it is the archetypal analytic couch (except for its rose twill upholstery).

title: CHRONICLE
description: Is there something diabolical in the latest remake of the classic 1955 French thriller "Diabolique?"

title: Agency Sees Risk in Drug To Temper Child Behavior
description: In a report released today, an international narcotics agency documents a dramatic increase in the use of a stimulant drug to temper the behavior of American children and says the drug could pose dangers to the children's well-being over the long term and lead to adolescent addiction when improperly used.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page caption yesterday with a picture by Agence France-Presse showing the arrival of the Cuban Foreign Minister, Roberto Robaina, misstated the purpose of his visit to the United Nations. He did not brief the Security Council; he consulted with the President of the General Assembly and other officials.

title: Chicago Pneumatic Move
description: The Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company said this week that it would close its Utica plant, which has 430 workers, within the next year. The company said on Tuesday that it would move its headquarters and manufacturing operations to a site in the Charlotte, N.C., area to be closer to its shifting customer base.

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL;Giants Are Lacking Togetherness
description: Freedom has always come at a hard price. With National Football League free agency the price is a loyalty vacuum within teams, and the hole it is carving out of the Giants is about as big as the moon.

title: Study of Welfare Families Warns of Problem for Schoolchildren
description: A new study of 790 Atlanta-area families receiving welfare has found warning signs that their young children are likely to have problems in school.

title: A Sure Vote-Getter: Banish Leap Day
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: BEHIND THE SCENES;Former Carolina Governor Promises His State for Dole
description: I'm back in the cross hairs," said Carroll A. Campbell Jr., the natty, self-assured former Governor of South Carolina, sipping coffee in an effort to shake the effects of only three hours' sleep.

title: A Nuclear Arms Plan, and a Question Mark
description: Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary laid out a plan today for managing the Government's nuclear weapons stockpiles in the coming decades but postponed a decision on the most controversial aspect: how to dispose of tons of surplus plutonium and bomb-grade uranium.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HANSON TO SELL SOME FORESTS AND SAWMILLS
description: Hanson P.L.C., the British-American industrial conglomerate, said yesterday that it would sell forests and sawmills in the American South to the Weyerhaeuser Company for $500 million. Hanson said its Cavenham Forest Industries subsidiary would sell 661,200 acres of timberland in Louisiana and Mississippi, as well as four sawmills, to Weyerhaeuser, which is based in Tacoma, Wash. This is the first announced disposal since Hanson said in December that it would sell all of Cavenham's timber and sawmill operations in the United States. (AP)

title: Liz Claiborne Buyback
description: Liz Claiborne Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy back up to $50 million in stock from investors. The company, a women's clothing maker based in New York, had been authorized to buy back $500 million of its shares, of which it has already bought or has agreed to buy about $499 million. Based on yesterday's closing price of $31.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, the additional buyback would involve about 1.6 million shares.

title: A Cultural Reluctance To Spare the Rod;Newcomers Say Americans Spoil Children
description: The immigrant mothers sat along the edges of Brooklyn playgrounds and talked about two methods of discipline: the American way, and the way they brought with them from their homelands.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;Nebraska Hospital Confirms That Frazier Is a Patient
description: The former Nebraska quarterback TOMMIE FRAZIER, who led the Cornhuskers to a national championship at the Fiesta Bowl last month, has been hospitalized.

title: HORSE RACING;As Others Run, Cigar Rests
description: Two major handicaps worth $1.5 million in prize money will be run this Saturday at tracks 3,000 miles apart, but the injured Cigar will not run in either race. Instead, he will be resting in Barn 7 at Gulfstream Park here while nine other senior stars of racing meet in the Gulfstream Park Handicap with Cigar's stablemate, Wekiva Springs, installed as the favorite today at 8-5.

title: Bill Is Passed To Block Loss Of Insurance
description: The New York State Legislature approved a bill yesterday that would prevent Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield from canceling longstanding health insurance policies for 650 of the state's sickest residents, who have serious chronic conditions ranging from AIDS to multiple sclerosis to hemophilia.

title: SKIING;So Many Skiers, So Few Slopes
description: On a good snow day, a mountain resort can become as overcrowded as a movie theater showing an Oscar-winning film. Most ski areas make do with longer-than-usual lift lines, but some choose to turn down new arrivals. That can be a headache, too.

title: AT&T Plans to Discontinue Network Notes
description: In an embarrassing retreat tied to the explosive growth of the Internet, the AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it would discontinue a highly touted service designed to connect businesses with their partners and customers through AT&T computers and the Lotus Development Corporation's popular Notes software.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: COLLEES
description: Tournaments

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Medvedev's Russia Bid Refused
description: The International Tennis Federation has rejected a bid by the Ukrainian star ANDREI MEDVEDEV to play Davis Cup for Russia. Medvedev was born in Kiev, Ukraine, but his parents were ethnic Russians.

title: Bell Companies Assail AT&T's Internet Plan
description: A day after AT&T announced its ambitious new strategy to offer millions of consumers low-cost access to the Internet, its archrivals, the local Bell telephone companies, were crying foul.

title: Arizona Voting Puts Forbes Back in Race
description: Although his candidacy had been written off by his rivals, Steve Forbes found himself back in the running for the Republican Presidential nomination after his proposal for a flat tax finally paid off with a victory on Tuesday in the Arizona primary.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;The Gloom And Doom Of Dowland
description: 'The Complete Solo Lute Music'

title: Stormy End Of Drought Is Unfolding In Nevada
description: Water has always been scarce in Nevada, which gets six inches of rain in a good year. Not a single river crosses the whole state. The runoff from the Sierra Nevada piddles into two sizable lakes or evaporates in the desert.

title: Talks on Ulster Set for June 10 By 2 Premiers
description: Declaring that they had resurrected hopes of bringing peace to Northern Ireland, the leaders of Britain and Ireland said today that negotiations among all sides over the future of the troubled province would begin June 10.

title: BASEBALL;A First-Place Finish Spells Woe for Boston
description: Every schoolboy and schoolgirl in New England knows it. They presumably learn it before they learn any other history -- the Mayflower, Plymouth Rock, the Boston Tea Party, the Minutemen, Lexington and Concord, the Battle of Bunker Hill. They know that the Boston Red Sox have not won the World Series since 1918.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Rituals With Slapping, Stomping and Tapping
description: Movement seemed to talk, or even squawk, when David Parker and the Bang Group performed on Sunday night at St. Mark's Church in the Bowery as an attraction of the church's Danspace Project. The outrageously imaginative Mr. Parker made the sound of dancing often as important as its look.

title: New Leader For Kennedy Arts Center
description: James A. Johnson, a Minnesotan who has had successful careers in politics and business, has been selected as chairman of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, a Clinton Administration official said tonight.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Victorian House Is the Star of a Show
description: LEIGHTON HOUSE is alive again with dinner parties, concerts and a celebrated red-haired model posing in the flower-filled studio. Even Lord Leighton himself is back, though out of sight, dying over and over again in a back bedroom.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Connecticut Halts Rutgers
description: Of course the Connecticut basketball team beat Rutgers tonight. Why would one expect anything less from the nation's fourth-ranked team, a 20-point favorite against a struggling Scarlet Knights team whose coach is fighting to keep his job?

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Arts Council Ends Grants
description: Saying it needed to deploy its resources more efficiently, the New Jersey State Council on the Arts recently announced the suspension of a $400,000 program that annually awards grants to 60 to 70 artists.

title: Executive Changes
description: APPLE COMPUTER INC., Cupertino, Calif., named George Scalise chief administrative officer.

title: Market Place: Those Wild Swings, Examined;Big Market Moves Have Increased. Get Used to Them.
description: Volatility in the stock market has zoomed this year, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing -- or dropping -- more than 50 points almost every other day.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Prices for Heating Oil Pull Back As the Decrease in Supply Eases
description: A five-day surge in heating oil prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange ended yesterday as an industry report signaled that a recent tightening of supply was easing.

title: Corrections
description: The introduction yesterday to a transcript of what the United States described as a radio log of the downing of two planes operated by an anti-Castro group misidentified the group's home base. It is Florida, not Cuba.

title: CLOSE TO HOME;The Mush Young Men Write and Rue
description: IT was very embarrassing. We were all sitting in the living room. I was reading, and our sons, 5 and 4, were playing with their toys on the floor. My wife was on the sofa going through a box of her mementos -- old theater programs, dried corsages -- with our 8-year-old daughter.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was, RONALD S. LAUDER said, one of the more gratifying days of his life when he received the Hungarian Medal of Honor, Hungary's highest civilian honor, last week.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the funeral of Sara Duker, a New Jersey resident who was killed in the bus bombing in Jerusalem on Sunday, misstated the death toll from the attack. The dead numbered 24, including the bomber, not 27; 3 other people died the same day in a separate bombing.

title: Manuscripts at Morgan, Both Heritage and Lure
description: From the outside, the basement room where the Pierpont Morgan Library stores its extensive collection of original music manuscripts looks like an impenetrable bank vault.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday about a Canadian test of the so-called V-chip, a system that selectively blocks television reception, omitted a passage in some copies. Readers wishing copies of the complete article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DETAILS OF CAMPBELL TAGGART SPINOFF ARE RELEASED
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies announced the terms yesterday of the planned spinoff of its baking business. The company expects to distribute to stockholders one share in the business, Campbell Taggart Inc., for every 25 Anheuser-Busch shares held, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The new concern, to be renamed the Earthgrains Company, will distribute a total of 10.2 million common shares, based on the 254 million Anheuser-Busch shares outstanding as of Jan. 31. Based on the closing price Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange, the spinoff is valued at $684.7 million. Anheuser-Busch also agreed to sell its Cape Cod Potato Chips business, as well as the plant in Hyannis, Mass., where the chips are made, back to the founder, Steve Bernard. Terms were not disclosed. (Dow Jones)

title: Rene C. McPherson; Corporate Chairman And Dean, Was 71
description: Rene C. McPherson, a former chairman and chief executive of the Dana Corporation and later dean of the Stanford Business School, died on Feb. 26 at his home in North Key Largo, Fla. He was 71.

title: Reviving the Peace Effort in Ireland
description: The Irish and British Prime Ministers took a welcome and much-needed step yesterday in announcing a plan to rescue the beleaguered effort to achieve peace in Northern Ireland. The Irish Republican Army, seemingly fed up with waiting for all-party talks to begin, irresponsibly resumed its terror campaign earlier this month with bombings in London. Now the Irish and British leaders have proposed a pathway to the talks the Irish rebels say they have wanted all along. But for the new plan to work, the I.R.A. must reinstate the cease-fire it ended on Feb. 9.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;A Florida agency learns that missteps, like a client defection, can accompany a  move up in size.
description: A SMALL creatively focused agency has embarked on an ambitious strategy to convince big advertisers that South Florida has more to offer them than sunshine, "early bird" discounts on dinner and buildings painted teal.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Slow Demand At Auction Erases Gains
description: Treasury prices were mixed yesterday despite data that pointed to continued moderate inflation.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COASTAL SAYS IT PLANS TO SELL ITS COAL OPERATIONS
description: The Coastal Corporation said yesterday that it was seeking buyers for its coal operations. Coastal said its directors had approved a management recommendation to proceed with a sale of the operations, which had operating revenue of $460 million and operating earnings of $99 million in 1995. The company said proceeds would be used in part to repay high-cost debt. Coastal, based in Houston, gets most of its revenue from a natural-gas pipeline system. The company produces and markets coal through the ANR Coal Company in the Eastern United States and the Coastal States Energy Company in the West.(Reuters)

title: Vic Janowicz, 66, Winner of Heisman in 1950
description: Vic Janowicz, the Ohio State football star who won the 1950 Heisman Trophy, died on Tuesday at Riverside Methodist Hospital in Columbus, Ohio. He was 66.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COLEMAN TO BUY STAKE IN MAKER OF CAMPING EQUIPMENT
description: The Coleman Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 60 percent of Application des Gaz S.A., a French maker of camping equipment, from Butagaz, a subsidiary of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, for about $58 million. Coleman, a maker of camping equipment based in Golden, Colo., said Application des Gaz had about $200 million in revenue in 1995. Coleman said it planned to try to buy the 30 percent of Application des Gaz that is publicly held. It also holds an option to buy Butagaz's remaining 10 percent stake. Coleman is 80 percent owned by the financier Ronald O. Perelman's MacAndrews & Forbes.(Dow Jones)

title: Banking Agency Will Not Sue First Lady's Former Law Firm
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that it would not sue Hillary Rodham Clinton's former law firm for its work on behalf of a failed savings and loan that was owned by the Clintons' business partner in the Whitewater real estate venture.

title: Let Prosecutors Appeal Bail and Sentencing
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Kamieniecki Recalls Personal and Professional Alarms
description: The incident occurred almost five months ago, but for Scott Kamieniecki it is as fresh in his mind as if it happened yesterday. The Yankee pitcher called home from Seattle on the eve of the first post-season start of his major league career and heard some chilling news.

title: Calendar: Exhibitions And a Benefit
description: Spain in the Americas Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway (Washington Avenue); (718) 638-5000.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Big and Bold 'Medea' From Spain
description: The vigor and variety of Spanish dance were affirmed on Tuesday night when the National Ballet of Spain opened a two-week season at City Center. The Madrid-based troupe took choreographic looks at many regions and eras and performed every dance with white-hot intensity.

title: 3 Questioned in Carjacking That Hurt Girl
description: Three men were being questioned by the police in Queens last night in connection with a carjacking on Tuesday in which a 17-year-old Brooklyn girl was critically injured.

title: Death Penalty Is Ruled Out By Morgenthau in Slayings
description: In his first decision in a capital case since New York State reintroduced the death penalty last year, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday that he would not seek to execute two young men charged with killing three members of a Harlem family in a robbery last October.

title: PRESIDENT AGREES TO TOUGH NEW SET OF CURBS ON CUBA
description: Driven largely by the downing of two civilian American planes by the Cuban military, Congressional negotiators and the White House agreed today on a package of sanctions intended to punish Fidel Castro by curbing foreign investment in Cuba.

title: Currents;Bridge to Rival Beans and Cod
description: SOME cities have a landmark gateway -- New York's Statue of Liberty, the St. Louis Arch. In 2001, Boston's low-rise skyline will gain as its emblem a 300-foot-tall cable-stay bridge of steel and concrete. The design by the Swiss architect Christian Menn, with its asymmetrically divided roadway, the first of its kind in this country, will span from North Boston to Charlestown. It will be visible across the city, said Shirin Karanfiloglu, the project manager.

title: Pataki Calls for Judicial Panel to Remove a Brooklyn Judge
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today urged a commission that investigates judicial misconduct to remove a Brooklyn Criminal Court judge who has faced withering criticism over his handling of two domestic violence cases. And he said that if the panel did not oust the judge, Lorin Duckman, he would ask the State Senate to do so -- a punishment that it has meted out only once, in 1872.

title: Husband Charged In Officer's Death
description: Saying in court that he wanted to commit suicide, a Brooklyn man was charged yesterday with murdering his estranged wife, a police officer, in a case in which he had repeatedly insisted she had shot herself as he tried to stop her.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;France Sells Total Stake
description: The French Government sold 9.5 million shares of the oil company Total yesterday for 3.1 billion francs, or $622.4 million. The shares, representing a 4 percent stake, were offered at 326 francs each, or $65.45, to French and international institutional investors, the Finance Ministry said. The Government now holds just 1 percent of Total. (Reuters)

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Indicted in False Identity Case
description: A 27-year-old man has been indicted on charges that he stole another man's identity, but prosecutors say they do not know why he did it. The indictment, unsealed yesterday, accuses Michael Dickhaut, formerly of Chester, of stealing the name and Social Security number of a Colorado man, John Colletta, with whom he had worked in the 1980's.

title: U.S. Delays New Financing of Companies' Trade With China
description: The Export-Import Bank has agreed to defer any new financing for American companies doing business in China for at least a month at the request of the Clinton Administration, which is weighing how to respond to evidence that China has shipped nuclear weapons-related technology to Pakistan.

title: Castro's China Model
description: For a year or so, President Fidel Castro has been relaxing Cuba's rigidly controlled economy, inviting foreign investment under highly favorable terms, visiting Europe and Latin America to woo political support and making life easier for the Roman Catholic Church. A few weeks ago, he released three political prisoners to a visiting member of Congress, who took them to Miami. It was beginning to look as if Mr. Castro, who is 69, was finally mellowing.

title: Israel, Terrorism and a 'Peace Process'
description: To the Editor:

title: Solomon Asch Is Dead at 88; A Leading Social Psychologist
description: Solomon E. Asch, a pioneering social psychologist who studied how peer pressure shapes human behavior but believed that most people act decently when they are not shackled by ignorance, died on Feb. 20 at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 88.

title: Motions in Bombing Trial
description: Lawyers in the Oklahoma City bombing case agreed today to a schedule that will push the trial of the two men charged, Timothy J. McVeigh and Terry L. Nichols, at least into next fall.

title: No Headline
description: He had physical and psychiatric problems so serious that if we had read in the paper that he had been a victim of some horrible crime, people would have screamed and said that child-protective services had failed him."

title: Day at the Races, Night at Journalism
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Novelist With No Center Who Invented Himself
description: JERZY KOSINSKI A Biography By James Park Sloan Illustrated. 505 pages. Dutton. $27.95.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;49ers Offer Hampton $16.5 Million Over Six Years
description: Rodney Hampton is not gone yet and there is still a chance he will remain a Giant, but the San Francisco 49ers are making it difficult. Last night they offered him a six-year, $16.5 million deal that would include a $3.6 million signing bonus.

title: Currents;That Cuddly Farm in 'Babe'
description: MOVE over, "Rocky Horror Picture Show." "Babe" is attracting a cult following, but the endearing movie fable owes its charm not just to its cast of verbally gifted livestock (Mr. Ed, meet Bambi) but also to its sylvan production setting. The talking-pig story takes place on Farmer Hoggett's too-good-to-be-true thatch-roof farm, which was built from scratch by the production designer Roger Ford in Robertson, Australia -- where real life folksy street signs proclaim:

title: PRO BASKETBALL;King's Late Spree Compounds Woes For New York
description: As miserable as the Knicks have been on their Western road trip, they met a team tonight that could relate to them rather well.

title: Currents;An Era for the Etching's Bite
description: SOBERING and austere, "Alone in a Crowd," an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, depicts life in Depression-era and World War II America. The artists of the lithographs and etchings, like their subjects, are black. John Woodrow Wilson's 1945 "Streetcar Scene", showing a commuting shipyard worker, suggests the irony and alienation of African-Americans who proudly supported the war effort only to suffer in a segregated society. The Brooklyn Museum is at 200 Eastern Parkway; (718) 638-5000.

title: HOUSE PROUD;Ingenuity Counts, Neatness Doesn't
description: THOSE who can walk are in the minority at the home of Ralf David Hotchkiss, an engineer who has designed a wheelchair for people in underdeveloped countries, where roads are made of mud, sand or snow.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a move by Barney's Inc. to dissolve a partnership with the restaurateur Pino Luongo misstated Barney's plans for Mad. 61, the restaurant inside the Barneys specialty store on Madison Avenue in Manhattan. Barney's Inc. will continue to own the restaurant, which is managed by Mr. Luongo; it is not selling the restaurant to Mr. Luongo.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;N.F.L. Urges Seattle Solution
description: Paul Tagliabue, the National Football League commissioner, met yesterday with Seattle government and business officials hoping to keep the Seahawks from moving to Southern California.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SAMSUNG TO BUY A STAKE IN NEW REGENCY PRODUCTIONS
description: The Samsung Corporation of South Korea said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $60 million for a 7.4 percent stake in New Regency Productions, an independent film production company in Burbank, Calif. Under the agreement, Samsung also obtained the rights to distribute New Regency's films in South Korea. New Regency has produced movies like "Heat," "J.F.K." and "Pretty Woman." (Bloomberg Business News)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nation's Trade Deficit Widens to a 7-Year High The nation's trade deficit worsened slightly in December, bringing the 1995 total to $111 billion, the biggest in seven years. The figures immediately added fuel to the debate on trade -- and fear of job lesses -- that played a key role in the Presidential campaign so far.

title: World News Briefs;'Black Boxes' Recovered From Jet Where 189 Died
description: A United States Navy search team today retrieved the cockpit recorders of a chartered jet that crashed off the Dominican Republic on Feb. 6, an Embassy spokeswoman said.

title: Wells Fargo Selling 61 Banks to Bar Antitrust Step
description: Wells Fargo & Company said today that it would sell 61 branches with $2.5 billion in deposits to eliminate antitrust objections to its planned $11.6 billion purchase of First Interstate Bancorp.

title: Metro Matters;Judge Wasn't Alone in Failing Victim
description: IT is now tragically apparent that Galina Komar, killed by a former boyfriend only weeks after his release from jail, did not have to die. The system might have saved her. But it faltered.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Scatting and Reharmonizing
description: Dominique Eade's first set at the Five Spot on Monday night couldn't have been the best show she has ever sung, but it did give an indication why her reputation among some musicians is as high as it is. Ms. Eade at her best flashed an immensely appealing sound, dry but sensual, and a virtuosity that gave her the liberty to fool with dissonance and play with the implications of pitch.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Wildflowers From Seed

title: Prosecuting Judge Duckman
description: Judges are easy targets. It is always unwise and frequently unethical for them to defend their reasoning publicly. The judiciary is designed to be insulated from the whims of public opinion, and engaging in recriminations or justifications politicizes what should be a contemplative job. The public, meanwhile, is sending only one message: Ignore the law and Constitution, and rule as harshly as possible.

title: Antitrust Review Is Seen On Thomson Deal for West
description: The Thomson Corporation's proposed $3.43 billion purchase of the West Publishing Company, a leading provider of legal research materials, is likely to be examined closely by Federal antitrust regulators, Government officials said today.

title: Nokia Issues Warning on Profit; Will Stop Making Televisions
description: Nokia Oy, the Finnish telecommunications equipment company, issued its second profit warning in three months yesterday, and said that it would stop manufacturing televisions.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Club to Run Pre-Primary Poll
description: By the time New Jersey holds its primary on June 4, the Republican presidential nominee may already be a foregone conclusion, despite the volatile nature of the race. To give the state more influence in the nominating process, the newly formed New Jersey State Republican Club will sponsor a presidential preference poll on March 2, said the club's founder, Charles Garrod. Registered Republicans will be able to cast their vote by fax (908-463-8339), E-mail (njgopclub@aol.com), or by letter (P.O. Box 1269, Piscataway, 08855).

title: Stockpiles Fell in December, Signaling Production Growth
description: Although storms and other special factors are making interpretation difficult, evidence mounted today that the economy could be perking up with the approach of spring.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VETERINARY CENTERS OF AMERICA INC., Santa Monica, Calif., which operates veterinary hospitals and laboratories, will acquire the privately held Pets' Rx Inc., which operates veterinary centers in California and Nevada, for stock now valued at $18.7 million.

title: Essay;18 U.S.C. Section 1001
description: Sometimes it's the little things that bring you down.

title: Sports of the Times;The Giants Will Lose Hampton
description: WHILE the Jets' negotiations with quarterback Neil O'Donnell lingered, the Giants were about to be confronted with a financial decision on Rodney Hampton: Either match the 49ers' six-year, $16.5 million offer, including a $3.6 million signing bonus, or lose the rugged running back who holds their career rushing record.

title: Sharing Grief and a Pledge for Peace
description: Family, friends and fellow students today mourned the loss of Matthew Eisenfeld, a young rabbinical student they believed destined to be a leader of his religious community before his death on Sunday in a bus bombing in Jerusalem.

title: Our Towns;Ex-Hostage Lighting Up Switchboard
description: TERRY A. ANDERSON, the new WVOX radio show host, sat in the hot, almost airless, community studio, cool as early spring. "I offer no more than simple fact, plain argument and common sense," he said, quoting Thomas Paine in a smooth, soothing disk jockey voice. "This is my version of 'Common Sense.' "

title: POLITICS: STRATEGY;Buchanan Attacking All Fronts
description: Deeply disappointed by his third-place finish in the Arizona primary and puzzled by the muddied state of the Republican field, Patrick J. Buchanan nursed a mug of coffee this morning and wondered what strategy to pursue next.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Go Cold as Ice At Garden
description: Not so long ago, it was one of their greatest assets. But as of late, Madison Square Garden has not been kind to the Rangers.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HUNT PETROLEUM TO BUY UNIT OF COLUMBIA GAS SYSTEM
description: Columbia Gas System Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its oil and natural-gas exploration and production unit to the Hunt Petroleum Corporation for about $200 million. Columbia, which emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in November, will use proceeds from the sale of the unit, the Columbia Gas Development Corporation, to repay some of the short-term debt it took on as part of its bankruptcy reorganization. In addition to getting $200 million in cash, Columbia will receive a royalty interest in certain oil and gas leases. Columbia, which is based in Wilmington, Del., announced plans to sell the unit, which is based in Houston, in October. Hunt, a privately held exploration and production concern based in Dallas, is separate from the Hunt Oil Company, also of Dallas. (Dow Jones)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-12

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nelson Explains Change to Sparks
description: A day after John Starks said that playing for him had become a nightmare, Knicks Coach Don Nelson maintained that there was nothing personal in his recent benching of the shooting guard.

title: 5-20 Years in Fatal Attack
description: The youth who struck the first blow with a baseball bat in the beating death of another youth was sentenced to 5 to 20 years on Tuesday.

title: Currents;Internet Surfers Master Art of Cyber-Haggling
description: CALL it virtual antiquing. Instead of early-morning prowls along West 26th Street, some collectors browse and bargain for treasures through E-mail chat. Arielle Greenberg, 23, of Long Island City, Queens, posted a message the other day in rec.antiques.marketplace, an Internet news group. Her message read "subject: wtb 1920's hats," and she included her E-mail address. The essential lingo is "wtb" (want to buy), and "fs" (for sale). Two days later she heard from a man in Tempe, Ariz., who sent her two Victorian, hats, " not in great shape, but I've never seen anything like them," Ms. Greenberg said. She offered $35 for both, postage included, and mailed off a check. Ms. Greenberg also helped a fellow cyber-haggler find a McCoy lily-pattern pitcher (above) in Waterloo, Iowa, for $25, not the $85 it would fetch in the East. Another friend plays the spoon market: "wtb yellow Bakelite soupspoons."

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: One Governor's Sway
description: Carroll A. Campbell Jr., the former Governor of South Carolina who helped George Bush win there in 1988, is promising to do the same for Bob Dole in Saturday's primary.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DIANA CORPORATION TO SELL FOOD DISTRIBUTION BUSINESS
description: The Diana Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its meat and seafood distribution unit, though it did not disclose the buyer or the sale price. Diana, which is based in Milwaukee and which also makes telecommunications equipment, has been looking for a buyer for the food distribution unit, the Atlanta Provision Company, since July. Atlanta Provision contributed $215 million, or 86 percent, of Diana's revenue in the 1995 fiscal year. The company said it would call off the acquisition if the sale did not close by March 15. Shares of Diana jumped $2.75, or 16 percent, to $19.50 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Hitachi to Sell PC's in U.S.
description: Hitachi Ltd. said today that its United States personal computer arm would introduce a line of notebook computers in the United States by spring.

title: Turkish Rivals Agree on 'Grand Coalition'
description: Turkey's rival conservative parties agreed today on the outlines of a "grand coalition" that would exclude an Islamic party from sharing power in the government.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Tokai Bank Plans To Write Off Debt
description: Tokai Bank Ltd. said yesterday that it would write off about 800 billion yen, or $7.69 billion, of problem loans this fiscal year, taking a huge loss to bring its bad debts under control. Other large Japanese banks are expected to follow Tokai's example to put the worst of their bad debt problems behind them.

title: COMPANY NEWS;A STOCK BUYBACK OF UP TO $500 MILLION IS PLANNED
description: Deere & Company said yesterday that it planned to buy back as much as $500 million of its common stock. Deere, the maker of agricultural equipment based in Moline, Ill., said it would make the purchases from time to time in the open market and through private transactions. Deere has about 262.5 million shares outstanding. (Dow Jones)

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Guinness Awards Red Stripe Account
description: The Guinness Import Company said yesterday that it had named Gotham Inc. in New York to handle advertising for Red Stripe lager beer. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: Clinton Is Cool to Democrats' Ideas on Shielding U.S. Workers
description: The Clinton Administration today gently flicked cold water on recent proposals by Congressional Democrats to change the tax laws in order to encourage business to treat workers better.

title: Rookies' Win Big in the 38th Grammy Awards
description: A cheating ex-boyfriend and a voice full of breaks and wails brought four major Grammy Awards to Alanis Morissette, the 21-year-old Canadian songwriter who was the big winner tonight in the 38th annual Grammy Awards. Her "Jagged Little Pill" was named album of the year and best rock album; its first single, "You Oughta Know," was named best rock song and best rock female vocal performance.

title: In a First, 2000 Census Is to Use Sampling
description: To cut costs and improve accuracy, the Census Bureau said today that it would actually count only 90 percent of the United States population in 2000 and rely on statistical sampling methods to determine the number remaining.

title: BASEBALL;In the Spot to the Right, Mets Pencil In Everett
description: Carl Everett wore a bewildered look this morning when he peered at a bulletin board in the Mets' clubhouse. In front of him was a diagram outlining where each player was to stand for the team photo that will be taken at 8 A.M. Thursday. The players were represented by quarter-sized circles and identified by their respective jersey numbers.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Passion by Way of Iceland And the Idiosyncratic
description: The lonely residents of Iceland had never seen a symphony orchestra when the Icelandic composer Jon Leifs conducted the Hamburg Philharmonic on tour in 1926. The island nation had no full-time orchestra until the founding of the Iceland Symphony in 1950. It might not seem possible for such a remote place to have cultivated a first-class orchestra in so little time, but the Iceland Symphony, under the direction of Osmo Vanska, defied expectations with a sensational Carnegie Hall debut on Tuesday night.

title: Rockefeller Center Properties Is Sued
description: The financier Sam Zell has sued Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., contending the company breached an agreement to recapitalize with a $250 million infusion from Mr. Zell.

title: Israel, Terrorism and a 'Peace Process'
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: ON THE AIR;3 Networks Admit Error in Arizona Primary Calls
description: Three television networks admitted yesterday that they were wrong on Tuesday night when they used information from exit polls to project that Senator Bob Dole would finish third in the Arizona Republican Presidential primary.

title: Economic Scene;Chile has a good private pension plan, but would it work here?
description: AS goes Chile, so goes the world? While Chile's gross domestic product is smaller than Connecticut's, the born-again capitalist economy has a way of inspiring imitators. For along with having the fastest growth rate outside Asia, Chile is also the first to create a truly private social pension system. And the country's virtually painless transition from a bankrupt public pension system has policy wonks around the globe panting to learn the secret.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Sex Crimes Bill Up for Vote
description: For five years, the parents of a 20-year-old college student tried to convince the Cape May County Medical Examiner's office that their daughter did not die accidentally in 1990 but was raped and fatally beaten in Wildwood. They succeeded last year in getting the official cause of death changed. If her killer is ever found, however, he could be tried for murder but not rape because the statute of limitations for sexual assault expires after five years.

title: The Power of Rich Candidates
description: Steve Forbes's victory in Tuesday's winner-take-all Arizona primary has displayed with new force the distorting effect of big money on American politics. Mr. Forbes spent some $4 million in Arizona, according to the runner-up, Bob Dole, who says he spent less than a fourth of that. The spending blitz allowed Mr. Forbes to capture the Arizona delegation at a cost of about $100,000 per delegate. Congress has no more urgent task than to clean up a campaign financing system that gives undue advantage to rich candidates and influence-seeking campaign donors whose heavy spending subverts the democratic process.

title: HOCKEY;Is Great One Not So Great?
description: Stan Fischler, SportsChannel's cantankerous hockey commentator, loves to argue and court controversy. And after the Islanders-Red Wings telecast Tuesday night, Fischler ravaged hockey's largest name: Wayne Gretzky.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Stay or Go? It's All Up to O'Donnell
description: Neil O'Donnell wrestled with the decision last night: Does he take the Jets' money and run to New York or does he remain a Pittsburgh Steeler?

title: Liberties;Gasping for Eire
description: I'm not taking the fall.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about rail safety misidentified a Federal official conferring at a hearing with Berle Schiller, chief counsel of the Federal Transit Administration. The official was Kate Hallahan of the Transportation Department's Office of Congressional Affairs, not Jolene Molitoris, the Federal Railroad Administrator.

title: Cost of Substance Abuse Put at $20 Billion
description: One of every five dollars New Yorkers pay in city taxes is spent coping with the effects of smoking, drinking and drug use, according to a study released yesterday by the Center for Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University.

title: HOCKEY;Devils' Stevens Left Holding the Phone
description: The National Hockey League said that Devils Captain Scott Stevens would be available yesterday for a conference call with the news media. Then came the Wayne Gretzky trade, which led the league to cancel the call "because of media interest."

title: President Of Retailing Chains Quits
description: In what many analysts say might signal a larger, imminent change in the Dayton Hudson Corporation's department-store unit, the company announced yesterday that the president of the unit had resigned.
